He is currently the president of the International Galapagos Tour Operators Association. With its outsized demographics and yearnings for adventure, the baby boom has been reshaping the travel industry for decades, from shoestring student trips in the 60s to singles resorts in the 70s and the luxury hotel boom of the 90s. Now, as the economy slowly recovers, the travel industry is hoping that boomers will indulge their wanderlust.

title: Leader of Players Union Is Put on Indefinite Leave
description: Billy Hunters long, sometimes-controversial tenure as the head of the N.B.A. players union could be nearing an ignominious end.

title: In Praise of Turnips, Year Round
description: MOST COOKS think of turnips only in winter, but I reach for them all year long. Whether braised in stews or simmered in soups, slivered into salads or simply sliced, buttered, salted and nibbled raw as a snack (a favorite with my 4-year-old), turnips are quietly making a bid for your attention.

title: Because Green Goes With Everything
description: Ron Shiffman, an Israeli-born, Bronx-raised urban planner and a Park Sloper long before the Slope was chic, has spent half a century trying to make New York a more livable city. The journalist Jack Newfield once wrote that Mr. Shiffman has saved more New York neighborhoods than Robert Moses has destroyed.

title: Q & A
description: A Roommate Leaves a Stabilized Apartment

title: National Kidney Foundation Radio Ad
description: A radio commercial is part of a new campaign by the National Kidney Foundation.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A five-bedroom colonial in Hewlett Bay Park, N.Y., and a seven-bedroom historic estate in Freehold, N.J.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A SoHo duplex co-op, a Yorkville co-op and a Downtown Brooklyn condo.

title: Newfangled Noodles
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Suicide Bombing in Turkey
description: TimesCast: A fatal attack in Ankara exposes tensions in Turkish society.

title: Signs That Its Time for a New Broker
description: Every so often, a story so perfectly illustrates what can go wrong when you trust someone with your money that it serves as a kind of users manual for any investor who comes along afterward.

title: For Weekend Athletes, Groups Can Be More Fun
description: HONG KONGGroups can be more fun. Thats a growing consensus among amateur athletes around the world.

title: In Another Opening, Myanmar Holds a Literary Festival
description: Authors once imprisoned for their writings will be among those featured in Myanmars first international literary festival, which runs from Friday through Sunday.

title: Image of the Day: Feb.1
The Sweet Spot: Feb. 1
description: In this weeks episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the transformation of our favorite magazines, who runs them, and why theyre succeeding and failing.

title: Movie Review | Koch
description: A Times critic reviews Koch.

title: Have Math Skills; Seeking Planet-Saving Career
description: Heres a quick post about the handoffs that occur in this human race as one generation proffers advice to the next.

title: U.S. Releases New Rules for School Snack Foods
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday released its long-awaited nutritional guidelines for snack foods sold in schools, an effort to combat the expanding waistlines of school-age children.

title: The Many Faces of Harbaugh
description: 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh can convey boredom, surprise, happiness and contempt with his facial contortions.

title: At the Table With Ed Koch
description: Mentally, Im always noshing, Ed Koch told Mimi Sheraton, then the restaurant critic for The Times, when they dined together at Lutece in 1982. He told her he kept jars of pickles at Gracie Mansion and at his Greenwich Village home. The former mayor, who died Friday morning, was known as a good eater, but he preferred cheap, homey and informal restaurants, Ms. Sheraton wrote. She asked him if he felt uncomfortable in an expensive restaurant, and he told her: Only if Im paying for it. Not when Im a guest.

title: Prince, Last Jettisoned Piece of Pistons Glory Days, Could Lift Grizzlies
description: Wednesdays trade involving the Memphis Grizzlies, Toronto Raptors and Detroit Pistons did not lack compelling headlines: about a small-market team managing costs by cutting a bloated contract, about another teams approach to roster construction, and about a much-criticized general manager reeling in the deals most underrated chip.

title: Ang Lee and the Solution to the Unsolvable
description: LOS ANGELES  Making this film was a nightmare.

title: Saying It All Without a Word
description: NEW ORLEANS  Jim Harbaugh can scream when he is silent and pose questions without words. He can say anything without saying anything. His facial expressions are part of his charm, a window into his personality and coaching style, a way for Harbaugh to express the full spectrum of human emotion.

title: Merck Delays Osteoporosis Drug
description: Merck said on Friday that it would delay seeking approval for an experimental osteoporosis drug, an announcement that helped send the companys shares down 3 percent on the same day it announced its fourth-quarter earnings for 2012.

title: On Our Radar: A Reprieve for the Wolverine?
description: Federal officials propose listing the wolverine as threatened under the Endangered Species Act after repeatedly deferring its consideration. The animals western habitat has been eroded by declines in mountain snows related to climate change. [Fish and Wildlife Service]

title: Philadelphia Papers Reach Tentative Deal With Union
description: The Philadelphia Media Network, which publishes of The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Daily News and Philly.com, reached a tentative two-year contract with its union that guarantees that both papers will continue to be run as daily print publications.

title: College Is (Still) Worth It
description: Every week I hear from recent college graduates who question the value of their higher educations. They are indebted, un- or underemployed, and horribly discouraged.

title: Brothers Develop New Device to Halt Allergy Attacks
description: Twin brothers Eric and Evan Edwards grew up with serious food allergies and were under doctors orders to carry their medicine everywhere they went.

title: Griners Season for the Record Book
description: Scoring 40 points for the fourth time in her career at Baylor, senior forward Brittney Griner made breaking the Big 12 scoring record look easy in a 90-60 win over Texas Tech on Wednesday.

title: Crow Indians Lawsuit Against F.B.I. Agent to Proceed
description: Two families from the Crow Indian Reservation in Montana can proceed with a lawsuit against an F.B.I. agent that accuses him of failing to properly investigate crimes against American Indians on and around the reservation, the United States Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Refining Helps Profit at Exxon Mobil
description: HOUSTON  Exxon Mobil reported strong earnings on its refining and chemical businesses for the fourth quarter on Friday, compensating for disappointing results in its oil and gas businesses.

title: The Muffin Man Goes Gluten-Free
description: For people who need to eliminate gluten from their diet, baking becomes a challenge. Beginners often find gluten-free baked goods too dense. Even the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman didnt like the flavor of a commercial gluten-free flour mix, which left her gluten-free cookies and tart-shells with a strong taste of bean flour. As a result, she created her own gluten-free mix for baking muffins. She writes:

title: Teenagers in The Times | January 2013
description: Each month we round up all the latest articles and multimedia published on NYTimes.com about young people, so that teachers and students can find this rich collection of nonfiction writing all in one place.

title: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Television Critic
description: The characters talk boldly about sex, but their actions are often shy and unsatisfying. The contrast of the generation thats been taught that pretty much anything goes sexually trying to act cool while struggling with their vulnerabilities is generally fresh and original and insightful about this generation.

title: Pop Quiz Answers
description: Data Interpretation: 1. e., 2. c.

title: Big Ticket | Full-Floor Luxury for $12.9 million
description: A full-floor condominium with ample Park Avenue frontage and white-glove amenities in a prewar building that underwent a luxurious and luminous two-year makeover under the direction of the architect Barry Rice in 2004, sold for $12.9 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The original listing price was $15 million.

title: A Million Strong: Helping Them Through
description: THE class was humanities, the book under discussion Mary Shelleys Frankenstein. Suddenly an alarm blared and 20 students, some calm and some not, filed out of the makeshift classroom. Kandahar Airfield in southern Afghanistan was under rocket attack, again.

title: Collector Says He Will Donate Johns Works to MoMA as promised
description: The art collector Donald L. Bryant Jr. is dismissing recent accusations that he is trying to go back on a pledge he made to the Museum of Modern Art and the artist Jasper Johns that he would donate three important paintings by Mr. Johns to the museum.

title: To Peel, or Not to Peel
description: This weeks column and video are a love letter to turnips, which are easy to adore if you take the time to get to know them.

title: His Honor, Mr. Koch
description: It is hard to imagine New York City without Edward Koch impressing himself on its every facet, demanding, in his trademark imperiousness, to be saluted by one and all. His death Friday at the age of 88 is a moment of unalloyed sadness in the citys history. For while Mr. Koch had a decidedly mixed record of City Hall management through some of the best and worst of times, he made an ber-career of distilling and billboarding the citys essence as he saw it, usually with himself at the center of things.

title: Tales From the Pressroom About a Man Who Relished Publicity
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who died on Friday at age 88, loved to be in the spotlight and to spar with the press. Here are the recollections of the man from three reporters at The New York Times who covered him:

title: At the Movie Theater, Paying Tribute to a Mayor
description: He loved New York like no other mayor I can remember before or after. And people felt it.

title: Feeling For | A Brief Note
description: For the amount of consideration men are giving to tailored suits and good jeans these days, its astonishing that when it comes to what to wear underneath, theyre much less discerning. Exposed waistbands often reveal oversize logos and patterns that would not otherwise be acceptable in any other kind of garment  which is to say nothing of the entire genre of action-hero-inspired underwear. Thankfully, a slew of undergarment-centric brands are offering cleaner, more minimal options in nicer fabrics, slim fits and rid of any obnoxious branding. Special Delivery is a New York-based company that uses incredibly soft and durable supima cotton from North Carolina to cut its range of comfortable briefs ($36) and these slightly shorter, trimmer boxers ($48; specialdeliverynyc.com). Sunspel, under the consultation of the young British designer-of-the-moment J. W. Anderson, and the Swedish-based Bread & Boxers (packaged appropriately in white bread bags) are also making uncomplicated undies.

title: Who Should Be Obamas Next Energy Secretary?
description: As Matthew L. Wald and others reported this morning, Energy Secretary Steven Chu is poised to head back to California, leaving President Obama with a new opportunity to signal his approach to energy and climate policy in his final term.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 1
description: A view of the day in sports, including Davis Cup action in Charleroi, Belgium and a skeleton world championship in St. Moritz, Switzerland.

title: How Your Broker Repelled (or Attracted) You
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I point to four signs that you may want to use in finding a new stockbroker or financial adviser. Theyre drawn from the case of Philip Horn, a Wells Fargo broker who may soon go to jail for his fraudulent activity.

title: Week in Review: Wall Streets Friend Atop the S.E.C.
description: Federal authorities are investigating firms hired to help banks clean up misdeeds like foreclosure abuses. | Battling big beer. | The renewable energy industries are pushing for more financing options. | MF Globals bankruptcy is near a happy conclusion. | Under fire, Chesapeake Energys co-founder is to depart. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says that Mary Jo Whites work for Wall Street is a problem. | Beneath the calm, SAC Capital worked to contain the fallout from an inquiry.

title: Know Your Investment
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan takes note of the 20th anniversary of the creation of the first exchange-traded fund, the Standard & Poors Depositary Receipts E.T.F., which tracks the performance of the S.& P. 500 index and is bought and sold like a single stock.

title: Vows: Lisa and David
description: David Jacobsen likes to write snarky songs that pour battery acid on the traditional love ballad. His fiance, Lisa Schwartz, thinks hes hilarious.

title: What About Penn?
description: Everyones been making a huge deal this week about the 100th anniversary of Grand Central Terminal, throwing around words like Beaux-Arts and landmark.

title: The Role of the Military and Veterans in Politics
description: The recent death of Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a celebrated World War II veteran, coincided in many ways with the waning influence of veterans in American politics. There are now only three World War II veterans in Congress: Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, Representative Ralph Hall of Texas and Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan. Over all, the number of veterans joining Congress has perpetuated a four-decade-long slide.

title: Movie Review | Warm Bodies
description: A Times critic reviews Warm Bodies.

title: How You Know the Super Bowl Is Near: Just Look Up
description: NEW ORLEANS  It has been a long week of festivities, but the Super Bowl is now two days away and I can see the finish line. Personally, I want it to hurry up and get here because as it gets closer, Im becoming more and more excited about the game itself. I really think it has the makings of a classic.

title: The French Debate Gay Marriage, in Their Fashion
description: PARIS  The invitation-only soiree at the Rond-Point Theater on the Champs-lyses last Sunday gathered 1,000 of this citys glitterati, among them government ministers, intellectuals, politicians, artists and even union leaders, to support the legalization of same-sex marriage in France.

title: Privacy Flaw in Paths iPhone App Shares Location Data
description: 4:59 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from a Path employee.

title: French President to Visit Troops in Mali
description: MUNICH  President Franois Hollande of France was on his way to Mali on Friday evening to thank French soldiers, to underline the need for a political solution to Malis divisions and to emphasize to French voters his resolute and so-far successful intervention in the former French colony.

title: Movie Review | John Dies
description: A Times critic reviews John Dies at the End.

title: Edward I. Koch in His Own Words
description: A selection of Op-Ed articles and Letters to the Editor by the former mayor.

title: The Mouse That Roars
description: TESTED Nissan Versa SL

title: Not So Quiet or Quick, but It Scoots Over Snow
description: TESTED 2013 Subaru XV Crosstrek

title: How Do You Get to Carnegie Hall? Start in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Every night, Mohsen, a slight, awkward 13-year-old boy, goes home from school to an orphanage here and does something that would probably have been impossible a dozen years ago: he practices his violin before going to bed.

title: A Mercedes With Tenure
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  Though Naomi Harleys 1976 Mercedes-Benz 240D is not exactly the same shade of yellow as the taxis waiting for fares at the train terminal here, it blends in well enough that she can sneak into the line along Hudson Place and pick up a visitor. Its a useful perk of owning the squared-shouldered sedan, but the ruse has occasionally backfired  when cab-seeking patrons have opened a door to get in.

title: What Happened to All Those Eggs?
description: Baby girls enter the world with enough of them to populate perhaps 40 small cities. A dozen or so years later, the first will make a debut of its own. And in the months and years to come, others will appear regularly, sometimes greeted with relief, other times with disappointment, perhaps most often with a touch of annoyance.

title: Pictures of the Day: Mali and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Mali, Kashmir, Pakistan and China.

title: Documentaries Thrive in Sandys Ruins
description: For three and a half years Ben Kalina struggled to find just the right elements and imagery that would make his documentary Shored Up, a convincing statement about rising seas, beach erosion, the fragility of barrier islands and the wisdom of replenishing oceanfront property.

title: Father Guilty of Manslaughter in Shaken-Baby Case
description: After spending five years in jail awaiting trial, a Chinese immigrant was convicted of manslaughter on Friday for the death of his 2-month-old daughter.

title: Gifts for Keeping Warm and Connected While on the Go
description: Gadgets and equipment that enable communication, music on the run, good old-fashioned sledding and other items.

title: An Eye for the Radical Perspective
description: Part movie guide, part manifesto, Amos Vogels 1974 book Film as a Subversive Art has loomed large in many a film buffs coming of age. A mind-expanding compendium of cinematic radicalism  from silent-era comedy to antiwar agitprop, avant-garde experiments to hard-core provocations  it is an idiosyncratic bid to create an anticanonical canon. The book has introduced generations of cinephiles to a wide array of seditious and often challenging work, but at its core is a simple, even utopian premise: Subversive cinema shows its viewers new worlds and new ways of seeing the world.

title: Graduates Going for Broke
description: IT wasnt too long ago that a graduate degree was a ticket to the good life, or at least to a nice bump in salary. But the lingering impact of the financial crisis, coupled with the continuing escalation of college costs and new barriers to borrowing, have changed the calculus.

title: Few Thrills With a Diesel Continental
description: WHAT WAS IT? Lincoln Continental Mark VII with the turbodiesel engine option.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 1
description: Subjects include the Bolshoi Ballet, the Pacific Northwest Ballet and Christine Andreas.

title: Learning From Failure
description: AMERICANS love success stories. Go to the Web sites of the United States Agency for International Development, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation or a plethora of global health and development organizations, and youll find articles, charts and videos documenting their triumphs and innovations, with the promise of more on the way.

title: Mates in Peril, Actress in Clover
description: The Man Who Knew Too Much

title: Kerrey, in Reversal, Decides to Quit Job at New School
description: Bob Kerrey has resigned as president emeritus of the New School, two weeks after joining an experimental higher education venture based in San Francisco, the university said Friday.

title: Video and Images of New Clashes in Cairo
description: Last Updated, 7:16 p.m. As our colleagues Kareem Fahim and David Kirkpatrick report, Egyptian protesters clashed with riot police officers outside the presidential palace in Cairo on Friday night.

title: Off the Field, on the Screen
description: Michael Strahan, with his weekly gig on Fox NFL Sunday, is one of dozens of football players who have found a welcoming home on sports programming  either as commentators or game analysts  once their gridiron careers have come to an end. These days, stars like Dan Marino, Phil Simms and Boomer Esiason, and even journeymen like Tim Hasselbeck and Rich Gannon, can be found on the air talking about the sport they once played. (Though perhaps none made the transition from player to commentator more memorably, or did it better, than Frank Gifford and Dandy Don Meredith when they were on Monday Night Football in the 1970s and 80s.)

title: The Fifth Quarter
description: On the Friday before the presidential inauguration, Michael Strahan paid impromptu homage to Michelle Obamas new bangs during a taping of Live With Kelly and Michael, the morning show he co-hosts with Kelly Ripa. Seated next to Ms. Ripa at the desk they share five mornings a week, Mr. Strahan entertained the crowd in the shows studio by donning a wig, batting his lashes and staring longingly into the camera  a ridiculous gesture for any man, let alone one who stands 6 feet 5 inches, weighs 240 pounds and helped the New York Giants win the Super Bowl in 2008 with his talent for driving quarterbacks into the turf.

title: Warrior Voices
description: RON CAPPS sat alone in a truck in a Darfur desert preparing to shoot himself in the head. He had been in the military for 22 years, serving in the Army and working for the Foreign Service in the worlds hot spots, including Afghanistan, Iraq, Kosovo, Sudan and Rwanda. Hed debriefed Iranian terrorists held in Iraq, observed rebel forces and assessed the carnage theyd left behind in Sudan, counted the mass graves of the hundred thousand killed in the civil war in Zaire  and reported all back to Washington. After five wars in 10 years, Mr. Capps had developed post-traumatic stress disorder, and it was killing him.

title: For Super Bowl Ticket Prices, the Sky May Not Be the Limit
description: Dont expect ticket prices for Super Bowl to stop rising. Thats effectively what Roger Goodell said on Friday at his annual state of the league address in New Orleans.

title: Feeling For | Jen Kao for Anthropologie Bracelet
description: Adding to its revolving repertory of guest designers, Anthropologie is introducing some Eastern flair through Jen Kaos Bali-influenced line starting this Monday. Taking cues from the designers trip to Bali in 2009, all the pieces were inspired by something I felt that I needed while traveling, says Kao. Whether it was a dress to wear to the Rock Bar at night or shorts to the beach, she says, I designed each piece to be easy and work together to tell the same story. The collection includes tailored separates and jewelry priced from $98 to $1,298  ideal for those left pondering what to pack while still being cost conscious. The multicolored rubberized rope can be customized for multiple purposes, says Kao about the piece shown above. A woman can wear it as a longer necklace or wrap it around her wrist as a bracelet.

title: A Truce in the Bragging Wars
description: MOMMY BLOGGERS (and their daddy counterparts, too) agree about almost nothing. Some favor co-sleeping; others do not. Some favor banning video games; others do not. Similar disputes surround breast-feeding, vaccines, cursing and whether its O.K. to force-feed your child broccoli.

title: Shame Serves as a Muse
description: I am covered in dog. Four, to be precise: little, big, bigger, mutant (Gomer, a 125-pound Leonberger). Daphne is a little needy, the novelist Ann Leary says as the Labradoodle wedges her head between my knees and refuses to budge. We dont get too many visitors out here.

title: Afghan Youth to Perform at Carnegie Hall
description: A group from the National Institute of Music will perform in New York on Feb. 12.

title: Ed Kochs Unconventional Portrait
Timing Tips for the ACT and SAT
description: HOW do you pace yourself during standardized tests? Jordan Liss, a sophomore at the University of Michigan, faced this question each time he took the ACT, which was five times. The last thing a student wants to do is a math problem trying to figure out how much time they have, Mr. Liss said. He thought a timer would help, but every time I brought a watch on the test day it was declined for its own reason, like being capable of beeping or browsing the Web.

title: Expressly for Execs
description: HOW many 45-year-old upper-level managers want to bone up on high school geometry and grammar? Not too many. So perhaps its not surprising that in the global competition for executives willing to invest weekends in an E.M.B.A. program, a growing number of top business schools no longer require an entrance exam.

title: Just Dont Call It a Drone
description: CHARLES A. TAYLOR loves radio-controlled model airplanes  a hobby, he decided, that could give him a leg up in a potentially lucrative new industry: drones. Mary A. Wallace expected to end up in management at an airport or airline but switched majors to remotely piloted planes because, incongruously, there would be less travel. Thomas Boutain wanted to start a company serving farmers around the Minnesota town where he grew up, mapping moisture, growth, pests and other conditions in their fields, from the air.

title: You, Too, Can Make It Work
description: ON Project Runway, which just started its 11th season, Tim Gunn famously advises the competing designers to Make it work. Gentle and invariably honest, he nudges them toward realizing their own voice and potential while staying on deadline.

title: Prometheus, Raw and Fiery
description: What a difference a conductor can make.

title: Big Names on Campus
description: ELECTION season is approaching, and aspiring student body presidents are drafting platforms, posting fliers and plotting ways to capture votes. For last Februarys election, with the $1,000 cap on campaign spending lifted at the University of South Carolina, Kenny Tracy unleashed Kenny for Carolina T-shirts, sunglasses, koozies and mood cups that turn his campaign color, blue, when liquid is added. Mr. Tracy won after spending about $2,200.

title: Clip: Caesar Must Die
description: A scene from Caesar Must Die, directed by the Taviani brothers.

title: Class Assignments
description: Love them or loathe them, but you cant ignore them. We invited students to share a photo of their favorite class project.

title: A Formula for Owner Loyalty
description: Naomi Harleys 1976 Mercedes-Benz 240D has rolled up more than 250,000 miles and is still reliable nearly four decades later.

title: Little Time to Prepare; Now a Legacy to Keep
description: On a recent cold and rainy afternoon, Pretty Yende sat on a couch in the press room of the Metropolitan Opera House, retracing the path that took her from a childhood in South Africa to her acclaimed Met debut last month. On Jan. 17 she received a raucous standing ovation from the audience after singing Adle in Rossinis Comte Ory opposite the star tenor Juan Diego Flrez. Now, dressed in leggings and boots and wearing rimless, flexible glasses that resisted her frequent attempts to fix them in place, Ms. Yende, a 27-year-old soprano, looked more like a graduate student than like a diva.

title: A Humble Chair Speaks Volumes
description: WHEN IT COMES to describing the magnetic power that California has held on the American imagination, where do you start? In 1848, when gold was discovered in Sutters Mill? Or 70-odd years later, in Hollywood, when they discovered glitter?

title: Brothers, Romans, Filmmakers
description: Nearly 40 years ago the brothers Paolo and Vittorio Taviani wrote and directed Allonsanfan, starring Marcello Mastroianni as a revolutionary in the Napoleonic era. After its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival Mr. Mastroianni met with reporters, and when they asked him about the unusual experience of working with two directors on the same film, he feigned surprise. Were they two? he asked.

title: Black Cabs of London Get a Bailout From China
description: LONDON  For more than six decades, black cabs have been as much a part of Londons street scene as gray rainy days.

title: Playful Superheroes, Walking on Walls. Will They Fly Next?
description: Trisha Browns Set and Reset  surely the most beloved and irresistible work of postmodern dance  will be 30 years old this year. On Thursday evening it returned to the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Howard Gilman Opera House for a single performance during the Trisha Brown Dance Companys current season there.

title: The Difference Between Kochs City and Today
description: A look back at the tenure of Edward I. Koch.

title: Now Showing | Andy Kaufman
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Improvising With Cornel West, After a Trip to Hell
description: How do they dance in hell? According to Sean Currans new Fireweather, the first half of his companys program at the Joyce Theater, the damned gravitate to the floor. Stretch and spring up as they might, something keeps pulling them down.

title: An Editors Third Act
description: In late 2010, Jesse Pearson was putting the finishing touches on his final issue as editor in chief of Vice magazine. The cover featured a photo of a car crash; the back page an image of James Joyces death mask hovering above the authors supposed last words: Does nobody understand?

title: Do Parents Really Brag Too Much?
description: Do you brag about your children?

title: The Week in Pictures for the New York Region, Feb. 1
description: Subjects include a dolphin in the Gowanus Canal, the retirement of a Manhattan mailman after 45 years on the job and the reopening of a historic church in the East Village.

title: A Melting Pot of Sounds, With Latin Spices
description: You might have to contain your need for immediate comprehension when you hear David Virelless music at the Village Vanguard this week. It wont slot easily into what you know.

title: More Antlers on the Wall
description: Im sorry, I dont understand the question.

title: Bank of America Suffers Widespread Outages; Hacking Is Not Suspected
description: Bank of America customers were unable to access their online banking accounts, mobile payment systems or the companys telephone call centers on Friday.

title: Wheelies: The Hail-a-Cab Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Contraception Compromise
description: The Obama administration has tried everything it can think of to accommodate religious groups that dont want to pay for their employees birth control.

title: Subaru Gives Its Hatchback a Lift
description: The XV Crosstrek, a thoroughly likable crossover based on the Impreza, is impressive not for its speed but for its ability to adapt to driving conditions.

title: Hunters Lawyer Responds to Unions Move
description: After Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, was placed on indefinite leave Friday, Thomas R. Ashley, his lawyer, issued this statement:

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 1
description: More photographs.

title: I Paid for a Piston, So Toss Me Your Keys
description: Have you ever bought a gift on your friends wedding registry and wondered, Why cant I do this for me, for nonwedding things? If youre in the market for a 2013 Dodge Dart, you can, with the Dodge Dart Registry. If that sounds like a crowd-funding exercise, it is, but one for new cars instead of start-ups and hipster rock bands.

title: Winters Balm: A Bubbling Pot of Polenta
description: IM ALWAYS IN THE MOOD for polenta. Furthermore, I always make it from scratch, stirring a pot of good cornmeal slowly over a low flame. Yes, there is instant polenta, and the packaged type in plastic tubes  shun them. You wouldnt buy instant coffee, would you?

title: Making Mozzarella, a Hands-on Affair
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Dave Briegel, 54, knows that this is not the seasonally correct time to sit down to a plate of fresh mozzarella with tomatoes and basil. Still, he was happy that he and his partner, Ted Manzke, 67, were attending a recent mozzarella-making class at Olssons Fine Foods, a tiny gourmet shop here that specializes in cheese.

title: Police Video of Shootings at South African Mine Raises Questions
description: Last year the South African police shot and killed 34 miners after a strike and unrest at a platinum mine in the town of Marikana. The police have long argued that they were acting in self-defense. But footage shown by Britains Channel 4 News this week seems to show a more complex series of events.

title: Novellas Sympathetic Portrayal of Armenians Causes Uproar in Azerbaijan
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan   A novella by an Azeri author that portrays ethnic Armenians sympathetically has provoked an uproar in Azerbaijan, with Azeri lawmakers denouncing the work and protesters burning the authors portrait outside his house.

title: Bill Cunningham | Old Hat
description: Annie Hall and her felt hat have returned for a new generation.

title: Schizophrenia and the Art of the Possible
description: To the Editor:

title: Moveable Feast Macroeconomics
description: Ah, Paris in the 1920s. It was the era of Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald, Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas, sovereign debt and stabilization. Wait, what?

title: The Library and the Architect Respond to a Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo and Clemency
description: To the Editor:

title: Building a Job Network
description: To the Editor:

title: College Graduation Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: German Legislators Vote to Outlaw Bestiality
description: BERLIN  Germanys upper house of Parliament, the Bundesrat, voted Friday to criminalize for the first time using an animal for personal sexual activities and to punish offenders with fines of as much as $34,000. It was the final legislative hurdle for a bill the lower house passed in December.

title: A Robot at My Side, to Help and Advise?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Suspects Are Identified in Texas Prosecutors Death
description: KAUFMAN, Tex.  The county courthouse here reopened Friday, the day after it was locked down and closed after the fatal shooting of a lead prosecutor by an unknown killer or killers.

title: Postal Service Considers Sale of Bronx General Post Office
description: The money-starved United States Postal Service is considering selling the Bronx General Post Office on the Grand Concourse  an official city landmark, a centerpiece of life in the borough for more than 75 years and a monumental gallery of the work of Ben Shahn, one of Americas leading Social Realist artists. Postal operations would move to a much smaller leased space.

title: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow
description: So many great new bands:

title: The King of New York
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Kids Draw the News: Special 3-D Assignment
description: This assignment is about Very Small Apartments.

title: Seeing Darwin Through Christian Eyes? It All Depends on the Christian
description: On Jan. 22, Rush D. Holt, a Democrat who represents central New Jerseys 12th Congressional District, introduced a resolution designating Feb. 12, 2013  Charles Darwins 204th birthday  as Darwin Day, recognizing the importance of science in the betterment of humanity.

title: Twitter Hacked: Data for 250,000 Users May Be Stolen
description: Twitter announced late Friday that it had been breached and that data for 250,000 Twitter users was vulnerable.

title: A Worldwide Race Has a Winner, but Is Not Over
description: During the frigid early hours Sunday, Franois Gabart was on the verge of becoming the youngest winner of the Vende Globe, the solo, nonstop, around-the-world sailing race.

title: To Thwart a Powerful Intruder, He Let Him Open the Door
description: The young man was strong, but the intruder was stronger. The man was inside his apartment, pulling at the doorknob, trying to close the door, but the intruder in the hall had gripped it with both hands and jammed a leg against the wall for leverage. The door was opening, inch by inch.

title: District 3 Winter Regional
description: The District 3 Winter Regional ended on Jan. 21, Martin Luther Kings Birthday. Jay Borker of Greenwich, Conn., and Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn., won the concluding Open Pairs. They finished just under half a board ahead of Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J., and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City. Helen Raleigh and Robert Heitzman Jr. of Suffern, N.Y., were third.

title: Another Reset With Russia in Obamas Second Term
description: MOSCOW  Four years ago, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. used an audience of world leaders at an annual security conference in Munich to propose a reset with Russia, the Obama administrations first big foreign policy statement. But as Mr. Biden arrives in Germany for the same conference this weekend, the United States is quietly adopting a new approach to its old cold war rival: the cold shoulder.

title: In Burrows Across the City, Its Groundhog Day Year Round
description: Staten Island Chuck lives the pampered life one would expect of a celebrity groundhog, lounging in a heated nursery at the Staten Island Zoo and noshing on sweet potatoes as the world outside shivers.

title: Mets Bullpen Continues to Be a Concern
description: General Manager Sandy Alderson has continued to make it clear, through both actions and words, that he is less than confident about the state of the Mets bullpen.

title: Earl Williams, Baseball Slugger, Dies at 64
description: Earl Williams, a slugging if ambivalent catcher and infielder  My favorite position is batter, he once said  who won the National League rookie of the year award in 1971 but whose promise went unfulfilled amid a welter of minor controversies, died early Tuesday at his home in Somerset, N.J. He was 64.

title: In New York, Echoes of a Talkative Mayor
description: A chance encounter at a Citarella. An impromptu performance in a tourism commercial. A tough job interview. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who died on Friday, left a lasting impression on those who met him. Readers were invited to share their reflections about the mayor. Following are excerpts:

title: On the Beach, With Jets
description: In San Diego the weather is almost always right for a trip to the beach. Not so in New York, yet on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater, members of New York City Ballet were dressed for a dip. Young love was in the air, and if you couldnt smell the ocean, you could see it. The corps de ballet danced the Pacific.

title: Funeral Arrangements
description: Edward I. Kochs funeral will be held at 11 a.m. on Monday at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street in Manhattan. The funeral will be televised by NY1.

title: In Senate, Traditional Decorum Gives Way to New Discord
description: WASHINGTON  If Senator John McCain had an inkling of curiosity how his old buddy Chuck Hagel felt as the senator raked him over the confirmation coals on Thursday, Mr. McCain would get a slight taste an hour later during his own rendezvous with rudeness.

title: A Day for Isolation and Creative Design
description: Twelve years ago, fresh out of college, Zac Posen was a wunderkind of the fashion industry, starting his own label and making his name among the established brands. Now, at 32, after some setbacks, he is reintroducing himself to the public as a judge on Project Runway, which began its 11th season last month. He will also show his fall collection at the Plaza on Feb. 10. Mr. Posen lives in SoHo with his partner, Christopher Niquet, 34, a stylist and fashion editor, and three lovely ladies: Tina Turner, a poodle; Betty Blue, a dapple miniature dachshund; and Candy Darling, an English cream miniature dachshund.

title: Health Cares Trick Coin
description: LONDON

title: Where Las Vegas Stardust Rests in Peace
description: LAS VEGAS  We may be made of star stuff, as the astronomer Carl Sagan once said, but our imaginations contain a strong dose of Stardust  at least as the word appears here. The capital S, its 17-foot-tall body peppered with bulbs, is shaped like a coy lightning bolt. Its jagged strokes change thickness and meet at unexpected angles, like the stylized clothes of The Jetsons. The Ts are like toon sketches of rays shooting from stars.

title: The New, Weird World of Atlanta Rap
description: Years ago Atlanta took control of hip-hops center, both geographically and sonically. But as the hub of the genre, its been a steadily moving target, far more volatile than New York or Los Angeles ever were in their heyday. Trap music, snap music, strip club anthems: Atlanta can be almost anything it sets its mind to.

title: F.T.C. Suggests Privacy Guidelines for Mobile Apps
description: WASHINGTON  In a strong move to protect the privacy of Americans as they use the Internet on their smartphones and tablets, the Federal Trade Commission on Friday said the mobile industry should include a do-not-track feature in software and apps and take other steps to safeguard personal information.

title: Making Room for Southern Cuisine
description: Biscuits and Barbeque opened in Mineola last March in a 1940s railway-car diner. When Joan Gallo, who has lived in Mineola for 17 years, noticed that the space was available, she decided it would be perfect for her style of hearty, down-home Southern food. She and her business partner, Thomas Sullivan, also own the 15-year-old Delta Grill in Manhattan; Bobby Bouyer is their chef in Mineola.

title: Washington Post Joins List of News Media Hacked by the Chinese
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The question is no longer who has been hacked. Its who hasnt?

title: The Ed Koch Show
description: I never doubted that I would be a good mayor, said Ed Koch, with a self-satisfied smile. I never did.

title: Investigators Begin to Test Other Electrical Parts on the 787
description: Investigators have not found enough evidence in the charred remains of two Boeing 787 batteries to determine why they overheated, and they are expanding their examination of other electrical components, regulators in Washington and Tokyo said on Friday.

title: Tribal Battles Displace Thousands in Darfur
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Intense clashes between two Arab tribes fighting over a gold mine in a remote corner of Darfur, Sudan, have displaced around 100,000 people, becoming one of the biggest crises in Darfur in years, United Nations officials said Friday.

title: Big, Bold Italian Food, No Skimping on Cheese
description: Anchoring the back corner of a Bloomfield strip mall, Carbones Kitchen presents a warren of rooms accented everywhere in black. Black leather booths, black window casings, a big, black wrought-iron wine rack, black cocktail napkins, even black ceilings all strike a raffish contrast with the vermilion walls of the main dining room.

title: A Soccer Star Who Rarely Stands Still
description: LONDON  For club and country, Clint Dempsey will do what has to be done.

title: Washington Post Says It Will Seek New Home
description: The Washington Post, another newspaper struggling to trim costs, is planning to move out of the District of Columbia headquarters where its news staff has worked for nearly four decades.

title: Suicide Data Report, 2012
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs has released a report showing the latest statistics on suicides by soldiers.

title: As Suicides Rise in U.S., Veterans Are Less of Total
description: Suicides among military veterans, though up slightly in recent years, account for a shrinking percentage of the nations total number of suicides  a result of steadily rising numbers of suicides in the general population, according to a report released on Friday by the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: As U.S. Growth Lags, Some Press the Fed to Do Still More
description: WASHINGTON  In the five months since the Federal Reserve started a campaign to increase growth and reduce unemployment, the economy has slowed and unemployment has increased.

title: More Lessons About Charter Schools
description: The charter school movement gained a foothold in American education two decades ago partly by asserting that independently run, publicly financed schools would outperform traditional public schools if they were exempted from onerous regulations. The charter advocates also promised that unlike traditional schools, which were allowed to fail without consequence, charter schools would be rigorously reviewed and shut down when they failed to perform.

title: Authentic Thai Fare, With Heat Held in Check
description: My first visit to a Thai restaurant, some 30 years ago, is hard to forget: the opening gambit, a soup made with coconut milk and insanely hot peppers, had the 10 of us begging for pitchers of water, our tongues numb to everything that followed. Ive risked authentic Thai food only a few times since, despite the meteoric rise in its popularity, but after dining at the estimable Durian, in Larchmont, where the heat is held in check and dishes can dazzle, I could see myself getting on something of a Thai kick.

title: A Good Compromise on Contraception
description: The Obama administration has proposed a sensible way to provide women who work for religiously affiliated institutions with free coverage of contraceptives while exempting the organizations they work for from financial or administrative obligations to provide the coverage.

title: Police and Protesters Clash Near Egypts Presidential Palace
description: Opposition to President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt led to violent clashes Friday outside the presidential palace in Cairo.

title: In a Suburban Home, Some Unwelcome Guests
description: The cat story gets me every time. A mature, well-to-do husband and father sits in his manorlike suburban living room, drink in hand, and recalls a pet cat he had in his youth who inexplicably turned against him. Nothing violent. The cat just stopped liking him and wanting to be in the same room with him. Not long after that, he had the animal euthanized; now he is haunted by the experience.

title: Critics Say Proposed Guidelines for Japans Nuclear Industry Will Hinder Business
description: TOKYO  Proposed new safety guidelines for Japans nuclear industry  strict enough that they could keep reactors shuttered for years for emergency upgrades  have set off intense political maneuvering by those who say the regulations will cripple business just as hopes were rising for economic relief.

title: Rosa Parks, Revisited
description: Most of what you think you know about Rosa Parks may well be wrong.

title: A Classic That Still Delivers a Good Scare
description: A good scare is the point of most thrillers, and the production of Wait Until Dark now being staged at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport delivers a spellbinding final scene that fulfills the promise of the plays, and the subsequent movies, reputation as a classic.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Japan eases its decade-long restrictions on American beef imports, the new BlackBerry 10 operating system is released, and economic growth in the United States turns narrowly negative.

title: A Man of Certitude and Joy
description: I WAS a late arrival to the Ed Koch fan club. I grew up in a liberal, Jewish, Bella Abzug-loving household, and my parents spoke of him with a level of contempt they usually reserved for Republicans. Centrist Democrats are a dime a dozen these days, but back in the 1970s the prospect of a union-bashing, death penalty-backing Democrat winning City Hall was driving Manhattan Jewish liberals crazy. I was expected to hate him.

title: High Points, and Other Stops, in a Painters Career
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  In a painting hanging in the Bellarmine Museum of Art, a little girl in a crimson dress stands alone on a city sidewalk littered with crumpled paper. Entwining her hands behind her back, she looks down, her expression a mix of defiance and disappointment.

title: First Pull-Ups, Then Combat, Marines Say
description: WASHINGTON  How many pull-ups does it take to make a female Marine?

title:
Algeria Sowed Seeds
of Hostage Crisis as
It Nurtured Warlord
description: ALGIERS  To the Algerians, the desert warlord in the swirling blue robes was a man of his word  the key to managing the crisis next door in northern Mali  and for months they lodged his representative here in the Algerian capital in high style in one of the citys finest hotels.

title: Baseball Officials Navigate Puzzle of Anti-Aging Clinics
From Abstract Expressionism to Nude Self-Portraits
description: Like most painters of her generation, Joan Semmel, who was born in the Bronx in 1932, started off painting abstractly. In the 1970s, however, she returned to the figure  and a new set of problems. Not only was she working in a supposedly moribund medium  the radical 60s were filled with calls for the death of painting  but she was returning to a fraught traditional form. As a feminist, how could Ms. Semmel paint the female figure  particularly the female nude  without returning it to its old role as a passive object presented to a historically male viewer?

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Feb. 2, 2013
description: "I wasnt lying, I wasnt embellishing, I wasnt making it up. It shows the pattern of complicity. It shows the cover-up.

title: Lottery Numbers
Syrias Rebel Fighters
description: Antigovernment leadership is emerging inside Syria  a phenomenon unfolding on battlefields only intermittently visited by outsiders.

title: Quizzical Cries
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Have you ever gotten the feeling while solving that you are not so much cracking the code as successfully guessing?

title: Corrections: February 2, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Why So Many New York Street Names Include Park
description: Q. Why are there so many city streets named Park, many of which arent near parks? Are they named for specific parks?

title: A 49ers Lineman Really Does Feel All the Weight of His Position
description: NEW ORLEANS  Joe Staley has a dream. It is not about football, really, and certainly not about winning a Super Bowl title, though Staley, a San Francisco offensive lineman, would very much enjoy that. It is about his pants.

title: Students Disciplined in Harvard Scandal
description: Harvard has forced dozens of students to leave in its largest cheating scandal in memory, the university made clear in summing up the affair on Friday, but it would not address assertions that the blame rested partly with a professor and his teaching assistants.

title: A Rebel Commander in Syria Holds the Reins of War
description: ALEPPO, Syria

title: A City Where Underground Gambling Plays by Its Own Rules
description: NEW ORLEANS  There is a man living here named Michael. He is in his 30s, went to high school in the Uptown area and enjoys watching his two children run around and play. He is, in his own words, a regular, boring family guy. He has also had a bookmaker since he was 14.

title: Wounded Candidate in Armenia Likely to Postpone Vote
description: An opposition presidential candidate who was shot and wounded Thursday outside his home in the capital said Friday that he would probably seek to postpone the Feb. 18 election. The candidate, Paruir A. Airikyan, 63, is one of eight opponents challenging President Serzh Sargsyan, who is widely expected to win re-election by an wide margin. Mr. Airikyan was shot in the shoulder by an unknown assailant but is expected to make a full recovery. Investigators offered no immediate motive for the attack. He spent years in Soviet prisons for promoting Armenian independence and was stripped of his citizenship and expelled to Ethiopia in 1988. He lived in Los Angeles before returning to Armenia after the fall of the Soviet Union. He has run for president several times but never won more than a small share of the vote. A provision in the Constitution allows for the postponement of elections by two weeks if a candidate faces an insurmountable obstacle and potentially for another 40 days if the obstacle cannot be removed.

title: Smartphone as Wingman
description: With Valentines Day looming, Adele Ernsberger decided to go on a blind date. But instead of having a friend set her up, she turned to a smartphone app.

title: Nets Get Just About All They Can Handle From a Bulls Team Missing 3 Starters
description: The hardest Nets player to please, Gerald Wallace, had 13 rebounds in 41 minutes in Brooklyns 93-89 win over the Chicago Bulls on Friday, a scratching, clawing, wrestling match of a basketball game that would seem right up his alley.

title: Felton Fights Off Pain as Knicks Hold Off Bucks
description: Raymond Felton grimaced. He then shook his head in anger. A few minutes later, he was crouched on the court at Madison Square Garden, the pinkie finger on his right hand throbbing. Felton did not want to drink from the water bottle that was given to him when he was forced to go to theKnicks bench. He threw it to the court with his left hand.

title: Koch: Recalling the 105th Mayor
description: In Edward I. Kochs early political base, Greenwich Village, and around the city, New Yorkers share feelings and recall encounters with the former mayor.

title: Alabama: Hostage Standoff Continues
description: A hostage standoff in Midland City continued for a fourth day on Friday. Law enforcement officials released a photograph of Jimmy Lee Dykes, left, who they say raided a school bus, shot the driver and is holding a 5-year-old boy in an underground bunker. Mr. Dykes, 65, has a record of run-ins with the law as well as with his neighbors. While officials gave little indication of what was happening on the hill where the bunker is situated, activity continued throughout the day, and the school bus on which the initial confrontation took place was towed away.

title: Basketball Prospector
description: From the moment he shakes your hand and looks you square in the eye  part military dad, part concerned priest  Tom Konchalski is assessing: Are you Division I material, or simply junior college?

title: New Images of Syrias First Lady and Irans Space Monkey Cast Doubt on Two Reports
description: Last Updated, Saturday, 12:37 p.m. Bad news, readers. New images appear to cast doubt on the accuracy of two of the weeks most widely reported stories: the rumored pregnancy of Syrias first lady, and the pioneering spaceflight of an Iranian monkey.

title: The Model for a Tribute to Model Players
description: The N.F.L. will present its Walter Payton Man of the Year award on Saturday, an honor that goes to a player who excels on the field and is known for his charitable activities off it.

title: How the Auto Industry Fared in January
description: How the automobile industry fared in January.

title: The Waiting Is Finally Over for a 30-Year-Old Rookie
description: NEWARK  Matt Anderson had to wait until he was 30 for word that he had been promoted to the N.H.L. When the Devils finally reached out, a balky cellphone nearly caused him to wait even longer.

title: U.S. Proposes to Protect Wolverines
description: The federal Fish and Wildlife Service proposed Friday to give Endangered Species Act protections to the wolverine, one of the largest and hardiest members of the weasel family, largely because climate change is whittling away its wintry habitat in the northern Rockies.

title: A Pregame Reunion in Brooklyn
description: A free throws distance from the Barclays Center in Brooklyn  all right, maybe a three-point shot  Woodland, a dark, earthy American bistro, gets a crowd as diverse as the events at the new arena. When the Rolling Stones played, wrinkled rock fans turned up for the charred Cornish hen ($21) and the crispy pork shank ($24). When the Brooklyn Nets are in town, there are office parties and tieless finance guys and pregame groups, like the one that showed up Wednesday night to celebrate the reunion of two old friends with a meal and some basketball (the Miami Heat, led by LeBron James, later trounced the home team).

title: Mariachi in New York
description: Mariachi originated as a folk style in Mexico, of course, but mariachi bands have long been part of the fabric of New York as well.

title: Leading the Rebel Fight for Aleppo
description: C.J. Chivers, a correspondent for The New York Times, profiles Abdulkader al-Saleh, a k a Hajji Marea, who leads the largest Syrian antigovernment fighting group operating in and around Aleppo.

title: Mexican Music for Lifes Milestones
description: Rock stars play in clubs, orchestras play in concert halls, and mariachis play anywhere, everywhere, from morning till night. On your average Saturday, Mariachi Real de Mexico, an 8-to-12-man band founded in 1991, plays five gigs across New York  zooming around town in a GMC Yukon that sports the license plate MARIACHI. They have booked up to 10 shows on a single day; graced Chinese weddings, traditional quinceaeras and Carnegie Hall; and performed for the pleasure of Henry A. Kissinger, Bruce Springsteen and one particularly lucky pup. We asked, Wheres the birthday person? remembered Ramon Ponce Jr., 37, the bandleader, chuckling. And it was a birthday party for a dog.

title: Ran City, but Didnt Own a Piece of It
description: In a city where residents are both doomed and blessed to live crammed on top of one another, one New York City politician shared an apartment building with two of his great nemeses. As mayor, he earned the keys to Gracie Mansion but would not relinquish his rent-controlled apartment downtown. And rather than buy a home, as the American dream decrees, he preferred to spend his entire adult life as a renter, right until the very end.

title: Goodell Says Suspensions May Rise for Hits to Head
description: NEW ORLEANS  N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell suggested Friday that the league could use suspensions more often to enforce its crackdown on hits to the head. During the season, the league suspended Ravens safety Ed Reed for his third violation of rules prohibiting helmet-to-helmet hits on defenseless players. The suspension was overturned on appeal by Ted Cottrell, an N.F.L. hearing officer.

title: Ferrol Sams, Doctor Turned Novelist, Dies at 90
description: Ferrol Sams, a country doctor who started writing fiction in his late 50s and went on to win critical praise and a devoted readership for his humorous and perceptive novels and stories that drew on his medical practice and his rural Southern roots, died on Tuesday at his home in Fayetteville, Ga. He was 90.

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 2
description: NEWS Four years after Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. proposed a reset with Russia, the United States is quietly adopting a new approach to its old Cold War rival: the cold shoulder. David Herszenhorn and Andrew E. Kramer report from Moscow.

title: Mayor Turned Movie Critic
description: Ed Koch was never one to keep quiet. I say exactly what I think, he told reporters on his first day as mayor.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: As pilgrims flock to the Maha Kumbh, a mass gathering in which Hindus travel to bathe in the confluence of the Ganga and Yamuna rivers, Soma Basu and Bharat Lal Seth examine the impact on the rivers and the surrounding areas. In their article in Down To Earth magazine, Ms. Basu points out that the large number of people drawn to the event help cause water pollution and demand a large number of resources such as waste disposal, sanitation facilities and basic amenities like food, water and electricity. She writes that despite the authorities claim that they are prepared for the pilgrimage, the region remains ill equipped to deal with such crowds.

title: In a Memphis Cheating Ring, the Teachers Are the Accused
description: MEMPHIS  In the end, it was a pink baseball cap that revealed an audacious test-cheating scheme in three Southern states that spanned at least 15 years.

title: So, Howd He Do?
description: Ed Koch, the blunt-spoken and theatrical three-term mayor of New York City, who became a national emblem for the way New Yorkers talk and behave, often asked straphangers at subway stops to assess his record with a Howm I doin?

title: Veterans in College: Share Your Stories
description: Graduate, graduate, graduate, the secretary of veterans affairs, Eric K. Shinseki, recently implored the audience at a conference of the Student Veterans of America. But what, exactly, will it take to ensure that veterans succeed in college?

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) BETTY & CORETTA (2013) Angela Bassett (above left, with Mary J. Blige) portrays Coretta Scott King, the wife of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (Malik Yoba), and Ms. Blige is Betty Shabazz, the wife of Malcolm X (Lindsay Owen Pierre). Together, these women inherited the mantle of the civil rights movement when their husbands were assassinated  resulting in a relationship that spanned more than three decades. Ruby Dee narrates this fictionalized account of their friendship.

title: When the Law Says a Parent Isnt a Parent
description: It is easy to interpret the popularity of a network television series like Modern Family as proof that we have mainstreamed the various and sweeping ways domestic life has reshaped itself over the past two decades. A nation of squares would not embrace a comedy about a badly dressed, middle-aged gay couple raising an adopted Vietnamese baby, we tell ourselves, no matter what they might say in Copenhagen or Berlin.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Taliban Militants Attack Pakistani Base
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Taliban militants killed at least nine soldiers and four paramilitary soldiers in an attack on a Pakistani Army base in northwestern Pakistan early Saturday, officials said. Ten civilians, including three women and three children who were living in a nearby compound, were also killed.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Chief Minister Omar Abdullah has appointed two of his close aides to take charge of the National Conference party in the Jammu region and the Kashmir region of the state, India Today reported. The move is considered a step toward preparing the young brigade in the party to take over the reins from the old leadership.

title: Timbuktu Gives Frances President an Ecstatic Welcome
description: TIMBUKTU, Mali  Frances president, Franois Hollande, paid a triumphant visit to this ancient city on Saturday, receiving a rapturous welcome from thousands of people who gathered next to a 14th-century mosque to dance, play drums and chant Vive la France! The muezzin, whose singing calls residents to pray five times a day, wore a scarf in the colors of the French flag as he shouted, Vive Hollande!

title: The Early Word: Push and Tug
description: In Todays Times

title: Strahans Journey to Hall: Never a Sure Thing
description: Michael Strahan stands a good chance of being elected to the Hall of Fame later today.

title: India Moves to Strengthen Sexual Assault Laws
description: On Friday, a special meeting of the Union Cabinet approved an ordinance to strengthen laws to deal with sexual violence against women. While the ordinance approved some suggestions made by the Justice Verma Committee making stalking, voyeurism and acid attacks punishable under criminal law, it diverged on issues such as marital rape, capital punishment and the prosecution of armed forces personnel who commit sexual assaults. The ordinance has received a mixed response from lawyers and womens groups, who were agitating for more holistic legislation.

title: Five Accused in New Delhi Gang Rape Case Plead Not Guilty
description: The five men accused in a brutal gang rape that led to nationwide protests entered not guilty pleas on Saturday to the 13 charges filed against them.

title: Keeping Score: What Stats and Simulations Say About the Super Bowl
description: Carlton Chin, a portfolio strategist and fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method. They have previously written about the B.C.S. national title game, the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, and last years Super Bowl.

title: The Gun Report: February 2, 2013
description: The second victim in Wednesdays shooting in an office complex in north-central Phoenix has died. Mark Hummels, a partner at Phoenix law firm Osborn Maledon, was shot in the neck and back when Arthur Douglas Harmon, 70, opened fire on Hummels and Steven D. Singer after an arbitration meeting. Singer died Wednesday.

title: Cockroach Ideas
description: Three decades ago, when I went off for my year in the U.S. government, an old hand explained to me the nature of the job: it was mostly about fighting bad ideas. And these bad ideas, he went on to explain, were like cockroaches: no matter how many times you flush them down the toilet, they keep coming back.

title: Doctors to Prescribe Self-Help Books, Poetry for Mental Health Ills
description: LONDON  Doctors in England will soon be prescribing books as well as pills to patients suffering from anxiety and depression.

title: Government Spending in the Crisis
description: Mostly a note to myself. Not long ago, the usual suspects were going on and on about how government spending had soared under Obama, pointing to spending as a share of GDP. Some of us tried to point out that this bump represented two temporary factors: 1. GDP was depressed thanks to the crisis, so the spending share was correspondingly elevated 2. Emergency aid programs, notably unemployment benefits, were up because of the crisis. The implication of this argument was that the government spending share would decline as the economy recovered.

title: President Claims Shooting as a Hobby, and the White House Offers Evidence
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama mentioned last week that he had picked up a new hobby  skeet shooting at Camp David  it was a surprising disclosure by a president whose main identification with guns these days is his effort to ban assault rifles and high-capacity magazines.

title: WWS 543, Class 1: A Brief History of Trade Policy
description: Slides (pdf).

title: Charlotte Longs for Its Blue Period
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Michael Jordan has added a hint of his beloved North Carolina Tar Heels blue to the uniforms of the Charlotte Bobcats, perhaps hoping that will endear the N.B.A. franchise to the city it has called home since 2004.

title: Love and Lessons From the Niners
description: The night the San Francisco 49ers advanced to Super Bowl XLVII, I got a text from my old friend Brian, whom I hadnt spoken to in years.

title: Dangerous From Any Angle
description: NEW ORLEANS  At bottom, football is math. A brutal, ruthless form of it, but math. The offense schemes to gain an advantage  more blockers than defenders  while the defense plots to foil those plans.

title: In Short Time, 49ers G.M. Quietly Made a Lot of Noise
description: NEW ORLEANS  On the eve of the 2011 N.F.L. draft, Trent Baalke struck confidants as calm. This surprised them, because Baalke is not exactly the calm type. They describe him as intense and meticulous and opinionated, which is how he went from a South Dakota State assistant coach to an obscure Jets scout to general manager of the San Francisco 49ers.

title: A Real Kick in the Head
description: Demba Bas first game back at St. James Park against Newcastle United was a real kick in the face. Literally.

title: N.F.L. Joins With G.E. in Effort to Detect Concussions
description: NEW ORLEANS  The N.F.L., faced with increasing concern about the toll of concussions and confronted with litigation involving thousands of former players, is planning to form a partnership with General Electric to jump-start development of imaging technology that would detect concussions and encourage the creation of materials to better protect the brain.

title: Southern Louisiana Is a Pipeline to the N.F.L.
description: At the start of the 2012 football season, there were 61 players from Louisiana in the N.F.L., many of them from the river towns between New Orleans and Baton Rouge.

title: As Self-Immolations Near 100, Tibetans Question the Effect
description: NEW DELHI  A crowd of Tibetans came here to Indias capital last week, bearing flags and political banners and a bittersweet admixture of hope and despair. A grim countdown was under way: The number of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire to protest Chinese rule in Tibet had reached 99, one short of an anguished milestone.

title: In Louisianas River Towns, a Flow of Talent
description: HAHNVILLE, La.  Hahnville High School was surely one of the few teams in the country to hold full-contact spring football practice in January, only two months after the previous season ended. That is not its only distinction.

title: Variety: A Shorter Diagramless
description: Administrivial Starting Square Alert! This diagramless is 17 squares wide by 17 squares deep and has regular crossword symmetry. 1 Across begins in the first square of the first row.

title: Kidnappings Imperil Talks With Rebels in Colombia
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The recent kidnappings of two police officers in Colombia by the countrys largest rebel group have cast a shadow over peace talks between the rebels and the government, disheartening a nation weary of the decades-old conflict.

title: Spanish Leader Pledges Transparency Amid Corruption Inquiry
description: MADRID  Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain pledged on Saturday to provide complete transparency about his own financial assets and those of other politicians in his party to refute what he described as apocryphal documents showing that he and others had received regular payouts from a secret parallel account maintained by the party.

title: What It All Means, From Squib Kicks to Salsa Stains
description: Some experts have posited that it takes about 10,000 hours of intense study to learn a language. Although the CBS pregame show for Sundays Super Bowl may seem that long, the reality is that fans hoping to be fluent in football by the kickoff do not have nearly that much time. As a reference, then, The New York Times offers this primer.

title: Syrian Opposition Leader Confers With U.S. and Russia
description: MUNICH  The leader of the Syrian opposition council, Sheik Ahmad Moaz al-Khatib, met here on Saturday with representatives of the United States and Russia  who fundamentally disagree on how to resolve Syrias civil war  but the meetings were separate and there was no indication, officials said, that any progress had been made toward a workable plan to bring the violence to an end.

title: Marxists Claim Bombing of U.S. Embassy in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  A Marxist group with a history of political violence in Turkey claimed responsibility on Saturday for a suicide bombing at the American Embassy in Ankara the day before, releasing a statement calling the United States the murderer of the peoples of the world.

title: We Can Be Healthy and Rich
description: Just about everyone agrees that health care in America is too expensive, and that something must be done to control the rising costs. Except for one group: hospitals and the unions representing hospital workers.

title: Egypts Government Apologizes After a Beating Is Televised
description: CAIRO  Egypts interior minister offered a rare apology on Saturday after officers under his command were seen on television beating a naked man two blocks from the presidential palace. But under what his family said was police coercion, the victim, Hamada Saber, said in an interview later that the officers had been helping rather than attacking him.

title: Delaware, Cradle of Super Bowl Quarterbacks
description: NEW ORLEANS  For all the Heisman Trophy winners and national championships that Ohio State, Texas and Southern California have combined to produce, those marquee football programs have never had one of their quarterbacks start a Super Bowl. The same is true for Oregon, Auburn and a host of other traditional powerhouses.

title: Backstage Glimpses of Clinton as Dogged Diplomat, Win or Lose
description: WASHINGTON  Last summer, as the fighting in Syria raged and questions about the United States inaction grew, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton conferred privately with David H. Petraeus, the director of the C.I.A. The two officials were joining forces on a plan to arm the Syrian resistance.

title: Breeding Grounds for Super Bowl Quarterbacks
description: A look at where the starting Super Bowl quarterbacks played in college.

title: Bronx Youth Is Accused of Throwing Boy, 9, From Roof
description: A 9-year-old Bronx boy who had been thrown from the roof of his apartment building was able to identify his attacker to a police officer, and that led to the arrest of a neighbor, the police said on Saturday.

title: The Great Gerrymander of 2012
description: HAVING the first modern democracy comes with bugs. Normally we would expect more seats in Congress to go to the political party that receives more votes, but the last election confounded expectations. Democrats received 1.4 million more votes for the House of Representatives, yet Republicans won control of the House by a 234 to 201 margin. This is only the second such reversal since World War II.

title: Imbalance of Power
description: The party that gets the most votes usually wins the most seats in Congress, but that did not happen in the November election in states with gerrymandered districts.

title: Decades of Leadership, Making an Exit
description: IT is considered a given, among many in management, that every employee is replaceable. When even the most valuable staff member walks out the door, someone else takes over and does the job. Life goes on and change is good.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Treating the Mentally Ill
description: Discussing a psychiatrists objections to mandated treatment.

title: The Way Out
description: When the Baltimore Ravens and the San Francisco 49ers take the field on Super Bowl XLVII, five of the players will come  from a troubled region in the northern Everglades known as Muck City.

title: The Pistol Formation
description: The Ravens will have to adapt quickly to thwart Colin Kaepernick and the 49ers Pistol offense.

title: The Horses of War
description: The Civil War is not normally called a horses war, but it most certainly was: cavalry and artillery horses, draft and pack horses and mules, approximately one million on the Union side alone. The seat of war was also the lap of Americas horse culture  or, rather, cultures, north and south.

title: On Loss and Regret
description: YOURE in Florence and you want to buy something, say, a rare perfume, for your mother in the States. You know which store she would like and that she will both wear this scent and treasure it, the way older people know how to be frugal and extravagant at the same time. But as youre about to buy it, you already poison the gift with this thought: the day will come, perhaps sooner than you know, when you will have to clean out her house before giving her things away and you will find the selfsame bottle there, at once oblivious or indifferent to the tragedy that has occurred, the scent still summoning up the smile you imagined on her face as you roamed that dark, large store by Santa Maria Novella on that sunny day when you said, Why not, itll make her happy.

title: Dangerous Gun Myths
description: The debate over what to do to reduce gun violence in America hit an absurd low point on Wednesday when a Senate witness tried to portray a proposed new ban on assault rifles and high-capacity magazines as some sort of sexist plot that would disproportionately hurt vulnerable women and their children.

title: The Way Out
description: WHEN the Baltimore Ravens and the San Francisco 49ers take the field during the Super Bowl today, the teams will have five players who come from a small, conflicted region in the northern Everglades known as Muck City. The dark, silty soil surrounding the Florida towns of Belle Glade and Pahokee, some 45 miles west of Palm Beach, creates a fertile region for agriculture.

title: The Virtual Middle Class Rises
description: NEW DELHI

title: Nagging Concerns Before the Big Game
description: President Obama injected some reality into the endless Super Bowl rituals glorifying the game with his candid remarks about the long-term damage from concussions suffered on the playing field. Mr. Obama said the sport will most likely have to change in order to reduce the traumatic hits that can leave players suffering dementia years after their careers have ended.

title: A Cruel Blow to American Families
description: The Internal Revenue Service has issued a hugely disappointing ruling on how to calculate the affordability of health insurance offered by employers. Its needlessly strict interpretation of the Affordable Care Act could leave millions of Americans with modest incomes unable to afford family coverage under their employers health insurance but ineligible for subsidies to buy coverage elsewhere.

title: Banks, at Least, Had a Friend in Geithner
description: TIMOTHY F. GEITHNER left the Treasury Department last week after four years as secretary. So how did he do?

title: John Kahrs
description: John Kahrs is a Disney animator and the director of the Oscar-nominated animated short film Paperman, which is distinctive for its melding of traditional hand-drawn and computer-generated animation techniques.

title: House Group Works to Present Its Own Immigration Plan
description: The group met, on and off, in almost complete secrecy for nearly four years. It lost members to political disagreements, and to re-election battles. After the November elections, it regrouped and redoubled its efforts.

title: Will Justice Kennedy Vote for Voting Rights?
description: Justice Anthony Kennedy regards himself as a teacher. The main role of the Supreme Court, he has said, is to instruct Americans about the Constitutions fundamental values so they know what it takes to preserve American democracy.

title: A Fan Who Knows How It Feels to Win
description: At the 2008 Beijing Olympics, the swimmer Michael Phelps took time out from his pursuit of Mark Spitzs gold medal record to talk about his N.F.L. fantasy draft.
