Born and bred in Baltimore, Phelps counts as one of his most cherished mementos from Beijing a Ravens jersey, signed by all the players, which he received early in his race to eight gold medals.

title: My Grandfather the Outlaw
description: MY fathers father embodied the American dream. His is the kind of story trumpeted from the stages of our political conventions, the kind of life held up as an affirmation of the rewards this country holds for people willing to take chances, work like crazy and insist on something better for their children than they themselves ever knew.

title: Courts Could Alter N.F.L. Plan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Seeing Things
description: WARNER, N. H.

title: Wall St. Is Pounding on Avons Door
description: SOME C.E.O.s are tough acts to follow. Andrea Jung isnt one of them.

title: Whats in a Rules Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Interest Rates and Housing Bubbles
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing Lincoln as a C.E.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Police Lie Under Oath
description: THOUSANDS of people plead guilty to crimes every year in the United States because they know that the odds of a jurys believing their word over a police officers are slim to none. As a juror, whom are you likely to believe: the alleged criminal in an orange jumpsuit or two well-groomed police officers in uniforms who just swore to God theyre telling the truth, the whole truth and nothing but? As one of my colleagues recently put it,Everyone knows you have to be crazy to accuse the police of lying.

title: Pond Hockey in Chicago
description: A look at an adult-league game held Friday night on what is thought to be the stadiums first rink in at least 60 years.

title: Genomic Analysis, the Office Edition
description: THE price of sequencing a persons genome  putting in order all three billion base pairs of DNA in a set of human chromosomes  keeps dropping. But interpreting the billions of letters in a persons DNA blueprint for use in medicine, and keeping that highly personal information secure and anonymous, is still a complex task.

title: The Boys at the Back
description: Boys score as well as or better than girls on most standardized tests, yet they are far less likely to get good grades, take advanced classes or attend college. Why? A study coming out this week in The Journal of Human Resources gives an important answer. Teachers of classes as early as kindergarten factor good behavior into grades  and girls, as a rule, comport themselves far better than boys.

title: On Ice at Soldier Field, Its Like Youre a Kid Again
description: CHICAGO  The weather was picturesque for hockey at Soldier Field on Friday. Snow fell on a clear and cold winter night on the shore of Lake Michigan. The rest of the scene was less conventional. Two teams made up of adult recreational league players, some who only recently learned the sport, skated before more than 60,000 empty seats.

title: Raging (Again) Against the Robots
description: THE robots are coming! Word is they want your job, your life and probably your little dog, too.

title: A Towns Environmental Debate on Drilling
description: Leases for 114,932 acres of federal land across Colorado are being auctioned off next month as a historic effort to increase domestic natural-gas production.

title: Stay Focused, and Your Career Will Manage Itself
description: This interview with  Terry Leahy, former chief executive of Tesco, the British supermarket chain, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Colorado Communities Take On Fight Against Energy Land Leases
description: PAONIA, Colo.  For a glimpse into the complications of President Obamas all of the above energy policy, follow a curling mountain road through the aspens and into central Colorados North Fork Valley, where billboards promote gently grown fruits and farmers sell fresh milk and raw honey from pay-what-you-can donation boxes.

title: Nips and Tucks and Big Budget Cuts
description: UNLESS lawmakers act by March 1, the budget sequestration process will start cutting government spending automatically  reductions that would amount to $1.2 trillion by 2021. Congress and the White House agreed in 2011 to the sequestration, and many people see it as a kind of political gimmick.

title: Weighing the End of Life
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Maybe Management Isnt Your Style
description: IF you asked all your friends, your family and  I regret to say  your co-workers to talk about their jobs, I think youd conclude that there is no shortage of bad bosses in this world. Studies have shown that poor managers can cause good employees to leave and, ultimately, can seriously reduce productivity in a workplace.

title: Bucks Sanders Is a Sudden Sensation
description: When the Knicks Tyson Chandler crouched for the tipoff of Friday nights game against the Milwaukee Bucks, he did not realize that he was matching up at midcourt against a version of his former self, in the opposing center Larry Sanders.

title: Super Bowl Advice: Brendon Ayanbadejo
description: Brendon Ayanbadejo of the Baltimore Ravens discusses his past Super Bowl experience and what advice he has for his teammates.

title: Super Bowl Advice: Mario Manningham
description: Mario Manningham of the San Francisco 49ers discusses his past Super Bowl experience and what advice he has for his teammates.

title: When Commerce and Illness Intersect
description: WHEN Contagion: How Commerce Has Spread Disease first crossed my desk, I stared at that subtitle and thought, Oh great, as if international business isnt doing enough wrong these days, now its guilty of spreading disease. I expected another populist diatribe.

title: Super Bowl Advice: Jonathan Goodwin
description: Jonathan Goodwin of the San Francisco 49ers discusses his past Super Bowl experience and what advice he has for his teammates.

title: N.H.L. Grapples With Applying Its Own Concussion Protocols
description: Colorados Gabriel Landeskog, the youngest captain in N.H.L. history and last seasons Calder Trophy winner as the leagues top rookie, did not play last week. But what happened to him in the aftermath of a heavy body check he received raised concerns that the leagues concussion protocols may be out of step with current scientific research.

title: Super Bowl Advice: Randy Moss
description: Randy Moss of the San Francisco 49ers discusses his past Super Bowl experience and what advice he has for his teammates.

title: Super Bowl Advice: Ray Lewis
description: Ray Lewis of the Baltimore Ravens discusses his past Super Bowl experience and what advice he has for his teammates.

title: Super Bowl Advice: Clark Haggans
description: Clark Haggans of the San Francisco 49ers discusses his past Super Bowl experience and what advice he has for his teammates.

title: French President Receives Warm Greeting in Mali
description: President Franois Hollande of France was welcomed enthusiastically after French soldiers drove out the Islamist militants who had occupied Timbuktu for months.

title: Stormy Weather: Blues in Winter
description: I have been trying to get a grip on my winter blues. Philosophy has a long history of handling the experience of distressed states. The ancients were concerned with stand-out types of psychic debilitation; Descartes, Kant, and Nietzsche probed, each in his own way, into the dark side of mood and temperament; Kierkegaard passed the mic to fear and trembling; Heidegger based his existential analyses on anxiety; and Sartre drilled down on sheer nothingness. Philosophers wondered whether it was possible to feel at-home in the world, given our basic homelessness  a predicament that many of them saw as the uprooted nature of our dwelling on this earth. I count on these abyss-gazers to land me safely, without much illusion, and somehow to keep me going, even if the trek is bound to be mournful.

title: Israels Mr. Normal
description: TEL AVIV

title: At This Hole, Golf Captures The Spirit of a Keg Party
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Like green flags at a racetrack, the birdie putts of Josh Teater and Martin Flores dropped on the 15th hole Friday, signaling to their caddies that the race was on.

title: No Satisfaction
description: Im Stephanopoulizing tomorrow, and as part of the preparation I had to watch a bunch of Superbowl ads. There went a series of 30-second chunks of my life Ill never get back.

title: A Macbeth Mash-Up
description: TEACHERS and education experts often ask what a particular reform or innovation looks like in the classroom. We say the classroom, as if an ideal classroom exists that somehow resembles every other classroom in America. In reality, every classroom has its own dynamic, and every class Ive ever taught looks different from every other class. Perhaps more important, they also sound different.

title: Big Game Advice From Those Who Know
description: Ray Lewis, Randy Moss and others with Super Bowl experience share the advice they have given their teammates.

title: To Do the Expected, the U.S. Is Bracing for the Unexpected
description: The taut drama of the World Cup can be enjoyed only by teams that emerge from the more rugged slog of regional qualifying, and though the United States is a tournament regular now, having participated in the previous six editions, regarding qualification as a formality still feels like a taboo.

title: Upside of Distraction
description: Writing a book consists largely of avoiding distractions. If you can forget your real circumstances and submerge yourself in your subject for hours every day, characters become more human, sentences become clearer and prettier. But utter devotion to the principle that distraction is Satan and writing is paramount can be just as poisonous as an excess of diversion. I tried to make writing my only god, and it sickened my work, for a while. The condition endemic to my generation, attention deficit disorder, gave way to its insidious Victorian foil: monomania.

title: Self-Reliance, Learned Early
description: IM the oldest of six. My dad was an engineer at Xerox and started his own medical technology company on the side, which was ahead of its time and did well. When I was an adolescent, we moved from Rochester to Arizona, where he started a second company, which sold an oil-based product used in items like sinks and bathtubs.   That company failed as a result of the 1970s oil embargo.

title: In the World Economy, the Ditch Is Never Far Away
description: WHEN you see a car being driven firmly within its lane and well under the speed limit, theres nothing to worry about.

title: Mickelson Leads but Isnt Ready to Spike Ball
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  While Phil Mickelson, the 18- and 36-hole leader, was grinding like a pepper mill Saturday at the Phoenix Open, Padraig Harrington kicked footballs into the crowd at T.P.C. Scottsdales signature par-3 16th.

title: Minnesotas Roller-Coaster Ride Takes Crushing Dive
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Tubby Smiths first five seasons as the mens basketball coach at Minnesota featured more rises, dips and potholes than a San Francisco street, with a sprinkling of bad karma from the programs five stints on N.C.A.A. probation from 1976 to 2004.

title: Frank Video of Mass Sexual Assault in Cairo Is Released by Anti-Harassment Activists
description: Egyptian activists released a brutally frank video on Friday, using images recorded during the mass sexual assault of a woman last week in Cairos Tahrir Square to urge volunteers to join their campaign against attacks during demonstrations.

title: Speedy Pierce Complements Slippery Rice for the Ravens
description: NEW ORLEANS  When evaluating game film of prospective Baltimore Ravens, the running backs coach Wilbert Montgomery abides by a singular philosophy.

title: The Most Wanted Gun in America
description: PASADENA, Md.

title: Hope and Fear Mix as a Hostage Situation Drags On
description: MIDLAND CITY, Ala.  The vigils continued in and around this southeastern Alabama town on Saturday. They were held in private homes, at the gazebo next to City Hall and, perhaps most somberly, on the grassy hill where swarms of federal agents were watching the underground bunker where, they said, a man named Jimmy Lee Dykes had held a 5-year-old boy hostage for more than four days.

title: Q. and A. With Viviane Reding
description: Viviane Reding, the vice president of the European Commission and the justice commissioner of the European Union, was asked to comment on trans-Atlantic data protection issues for the Slipstream column by Natasha Singer in the Sunday Business section. The following is Vice President Redings full statement, sent on Jan. 31, 2013.

title: Data Protection Laws, an Ocean Apart
description: OVER the years, the United States and Europe have taken different approaches toward protecting peoples personal information. Now the two sides are struggling to bridge that divide.

title: In Hard Economy for All Ages, Older Isnt Better ... Its Brutal
description: Young graduates are in debt, out of work and on their parents couches. People in their 30s and 40s cant afford to buy homes or have children. Retirees are earning near-zero interest on their savings.

title: Gun Control Group Buys Ad Time for Super Bowl
description: One of the nations leading gun control groups has bought television time during Sundays Super Bowl in an effort to push Congress to pass universal background checks on all firearm purchases.

title: For the Niners Punter, Remaining on the Sidelines Is a Good Thing
description: In Andy Lees first seven seasons, the San Francisco 49ers went 39-73. As the teams punter he was called on to bail out the struggling offense time and again, a skill he mastered. The 2004 sixth-round draft pick led the N.F.L. in punts three times and punting yards twice. He became a perennial All-Pro and Pro Bowler, and one of the leagues top directional punters.

title: Letter From Consumer and Civil Liberties Groups on Privacy Laws
description: A coalition of American advocacy groups composed a letter to senior Obama administration officials seeking to bridge a divide in the way the United States and Europe handle the protection of peoples personal information.

title: Woman Found Dead After Vanishing on Vacation in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  A Staten Island woman who failed to return home from a vacation alone in Turkey last month, setting off a frantic search by American and Turkish authorities, was found dead on Saturday, according to her family and the Turkish authorities.

title: Louisianas N.F.L. Success
description: For years the Bayou State has sent more players to the N.F.L. than any other state per capita. Local football coaches explain the reasons why.

title: Irans Space Agency Confirms Reports on Launch Used Images of Two Different Monkeys
description: A senior official at Irans space agency confirmed on Saturday that state media reports on the launching of a monkey into the thermosphere had used images of two different monkeys. The official insisted, however, that the monkey had survived the journey and that Iran was not trying to cover up a failed flight.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 3
description: Gun control, the military and immigration take center stage on the Sunday shows this week.

title: A Whiff of Cologne
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Wilkommen to the German version of The New York Times. Just kidding, but we do have an interesting puzzle by Dan Schoenholz that gives us a whiff of some words of German origin that have been adapted (some more than others) into the English language. Some people dont mind when foreign words are used in an American crossword puzzle, and I fall into that group. However, I can think of at least one person I know who will do this puzzle and get ticked off by the fact that the entire theme is made up of words in another language. Whatever floats your boat, I say. Theres always a new puzzle tomorrow.

title: Hey, Beyonc, Its Your Look, but Maybe His Moment
description: FOR THE LAST MONTH Rubin Singer has savored the thought that he was asked by Beyonc Knowles to design her outfit for her Super Bowl performance on Sunday. Mr. Singer is a little known designer in New York  I dont feel new, but I am, he said  and he has stayed tight-lipped on the design, while wondering what the mega-exposure could mean to his career.

title: Interview With Hillary Clinton
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton was interviewed by Michael R. Gordon and Mark Landler on Thursday, her second-to-last day as secretary of state. Below are excerpts from the interview, which was conducted in her State Department office. Some of the questions have been edited for brevity.

title: With Modern Facility, England Must Update Mind-Set
description: An evocative mosaic depicting legendary England players and iconic moments of past glories greets visitors to the English Football Associations new St Georges Park facility.

title: Militants Goal in Algeria Gas Plant Siege: Giant Fireball
description: TIGUENTOURINE, Algeria  The goal of the heavily armed militants who seized the desert gas plant here is becoming increasingly clear: to turn the forest of pipes and tubes into a giant bomb, and to blow up everything and anyone around. What none of them knew was exactly how, in the endless maze of metal, to do it.

title: Twitter End to Love Story Born in Russias Protests
description: MOSCOW  Into the swirl of riot police officers they marched side by side as the Romeo and Juliet of the revolution  inspiring, fearless and beautiful on the streets of Moscow.

title: Kochs Lunch Mates Convene Without Him, and Hes Still the Center of Attention
description: Edward I. Kochs weekly luncheon club convened as usual on Saturday, but with a few differences.

title: Iceland, Fervent Prosecutor of Bankers, Sees Meager Returns
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  As chief of police in a tiny fishing town for 11 years, Olafur Hauksson developed what he thought was a basic understanding of the criminal mind. The typical lawbreaker, he said, recalling his many encounters with small-time criminals, clearly knows that he crossed the line and generally sees the difference between right and wrong.

title: Mortons Murder Conviction Comes to Define Anderson
description: Growing up in the 1960s, Ken Anderson admired the great trial lawyers in movies: Gregory Peck in To Kill a Mockingbird and Spencer Tracy in Inherit the Wind. The good guys who broke down lying thugs on the stand.

title: Lawmakers Aim to Limit Drones and Safeguard Privacy
description: A drone, no bigger than a toy airplane, hovered north of the Texas Capitol, floating over the heads of lawmakers who were momentarily distracted from their morning meetings. Several of them gathered beneath it, faces tilted skyward, marveling over a pair of goggles that allowed them to watch live video of the crafts panoramic birds-eye view.

title: Plenty of Money in State Coffers, but Not to Spend
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: The Worlds No. 1 Player Breaks His Own Record
description: Magnus Carlsen produced another dominating performance last month at the Tata Steel tournament in the Netherlands.

title: Disgraced Owner, but What About Cadillac Ranch?
description: Cadillac Ranch, located just off Interstate 40 a few miles west of Amarillo, is one of the most famous roadside attractions in America. The art installation, consisting of 10 tail-finned, brightly painted Cadillacs planted nose down in a pasture, was financed in 1974 by Stanley Marsh 3, the eccentric Panhandle oil heir and arts patron.

title: Parcells Is Chosen for Pro Football Hall; Strahan Falls Short
description: NEW ORLEANS  Bill Parcells, the only coach to lead four teams to the playoffs and the winner of two Super Bowls with the Giants, highlighted a class of seven inductees to the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday.

title: Battered California Republicans Find Hope in a Long Shot
description: LOS ANGELES  Kevin L. James, a conservative talk show host running for mayor of Los Angeles, was sitting in his campaign office recently pondering which was his bigger obstacle to victory: being openly Republican, or being openly gay.

title: A Career With Many Stops but Only One True Home
description: Most members of the Pro Football Hall of Fame have two or three team logos in their past, but Bill Parcells was elected Saturday with five on his rsum: coach of the Giants, the Patriots, the Jets and the Cowboys before joining the Dolphins as director of football operations.

title: Drowned in a Stream of Prescriptions
description: VIRGINIA BEACH  Every morning on her way to work, Kathy Fee holds her breath as she drives past the squat brick building that houses Dominion Psychiatric Associates.

title: Japanese Premier Wont Take Step in Relocating U.S. Base Before Meeting Obama
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said Saturday that he would not immediately ask the Okinawan authorities for approval to begin constructing a long-stalled American air base, casting doubt on his governments hopes to show progress in a troubled base-relocation plan ahead of his planned trip to Washington later this month.

title: Lottery Numbers
Stephen Simon, Conductor Who Led a Handel Revival, Dies at 75
description: Stephen Simon, a conductor who in the 1970s and afterward helped spirit the Handel revival into being in the United States, died on Jan. 20 in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Egyptian League and Fans Try to Heal With Help From an American Coach
description: CAIRO  It took only 12 minutes for Al Ahly to score the Egyptian soccer leagues first goal in 366 long and bloody days.

title: Many High Schools Still Allow Full-Contact Practices in Off-Season
description: The N.F.L. has been working to address the issue of concussions and brain trauma by pouring millions of dollars into research, changing on-field rules and adding medical staff during games. Notably, the league has also limited the number of full-contact practices during the season.

title: Caltech Ends Losing Streak at 228
description: The baseball team at California Institute of Technology broke a 228-game losing streak Saturday with a 9-7 nonconference victory over Pacifica. The team last won on Feb. 15, 2003.

title: Charlotte Smallwood-Cook, a Pioneering District Attorney, Dies at 90
description: Charlotte Smallwood-Cook, who is believed to have been the first woman elected a district attorney in New York State, died on Jan. 26 in Batavia, N.Y. She was 90.

title: Lady Malcolm Douglas-Hamilton, American Who Aided Britain in War, Dies at 103
description: In 1939, Lady Malcolm Douglas-Hamilton, who died on Jan. 14 at 103, had neither that title nor that name. She was Natalie Latham, a fixture of Manhattan society whose beauty drew notice in Vogue magazine. She had achieved a dollop of fame when she and her two young daughters, nicknamed Mimi and Bubbles, appeared together in matching swimwear in a Life magazine photo spread, having captivated a photographer at a beach club one day.

title: Stoudemire Gives Knicks Jolt in Their Blowout of Kings
description: In the Knicks lexicon this season, few terms are as forbidding as back to back  as in games played on consecutive nights. This was the test they had before them this weekend, and for the Knicks, it has not always been easy to limber up two days in a row.

title: Top Donors to Republicans Seek More Say in Senate Races
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  The biggest donors in the Republican Party are financing a new group to recruit seasoned candidates and protect Senate incumbents from challenges by far-right conservatives and Tea Party enthusiasts who Republican leaders worry could complicate the partys efforts to win control of the Senate.

title: Lunch for Hizzoner
description: At their weekly lunch, friends and colleagues of Edward I. Koch now have one seat missing around the table. However, they decided not to let the former mayor's death break a tradition.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Feb. 3
description: "When youre older, they just see gray hair and they write you off.

title: Carolyn Aishton, Gerald Ouderkirk Jr.
description: Carolyn Euretta Aishton and Gerald Baker Ouderkirk Jr. were married Saturday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Randolph L.C. Weber, an associate pastor at the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Nicole Fitlow and Haran Rashes
description: Nicole Elizabeth Fitlow and Haran Craig Rashes are to be married Sunday in Livonia, Mich. Rabbi Kim Blumenthal is to officiate at the Detroit Marriott Livonia.

title: Lisa Schwartz and David Jacobsen
description: Finding a Bohemian (With a Day Job)

title: Elizabeth Ambrose and Steven Johnson
description: Elizabeth Jane Ambrose, a daughter of Jeannie V. Ambrose and Edward F. Ambrose Jr. of Oakmont, Pa., was married Friday evening to Steven Paul Johnson, the son of Diane L. Johnson and Ashton J. Johnson of Youngsville, La., at St. Peters on Capitol Hill, a Roman Catholic church in Washington. The Rev. William Byrne, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Adriana Salazar and Ben Lopez
description: Ignoring the Invitations Fine Print

title: Gitika Ahuja and Rajeev Kaul
description: Serenade on a Secluded Beach

title: Carrie Drazan and Howard Hersch
description: Carrie Erin Drazan, the daughter of Cheryl A. Drazan and Andrew M. Drazan of Old Brookville, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Howard Scott Hersch, the son of Harriet K. Hersch and Ronald M. Hersch of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Cantor Richard Berman officiated at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y.

title: Corrections: February 3, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: In Villages, Praying for the Souls of Tibetan Self-Immolators
description: BEIJING  Since November, when winter began in the high Tibetan Plateau, thousands of Tibetan villagers have been gathering daily to pray for the souls of the nearly 100 Tibetans who have burned themselves to death in protest over Chinese rule, in a show of widespread support for the self-immolators among ordinary people, according to witness testimony from a person recently returned from the region.

title: Wreck-It Ralph Scores Big at Annie Awards
description: LOS ANGELES  Wreck-It Ralph is headed to the Oscar podium, at least if the animation industrys biggest awards gala is any indicator. Annie Awards voters gave it five trophies on Saturday night, including one for best feature.

title: Dozens Die in Attack on Police in Iraqi City
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide car bomber attacked a provincial police headquarters in the northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk on Sunday morning, the police and the citys civil defense director said, killing at least 36 people and wounding 105. Three other suicide attackers who tried to enter the police headquarters after the blast were killed by the police.

title: Affleck Rides On at Directors Guild Awards
description: LOS ANGELES  The Directors Guild of America anointed Ben Affleck as its filmmaker of the year for Argo, his third film.

title: Pollution in China
description: Fresh air is a casualty of Chinas economic expansion.

title: Super Bowl: Do You Speak Football?
description: The Super Bowl speaks to all of us in different ways, but first, you have to at least be fluent in football.

title: Untouchable in Iraq, Ex-Sniper Dies in a Shooting Back Home
description: HOUSTON  From his perch in hide-outs above battle-scarred Iraq, Chris Kyle earned a reputation as one of Americas deadliest military snipers. The Pentagon said his skills with a rifle so terrorized Iraqi insurgents during his four tours of duty that they nicknamed him the Devil of Ramadi and put a bounty on his head.

title: This Week in Small Business: Leave the Building
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Despicable Me
description: Funny: Angry Bear finds some of the usual suspects explaining How to Debate Paul Krugman, and the answer appears to be this: invent a straw man who bears no resemblance at all to the economist/columnist of the same name, and ridicule that imaginary person.

title: How Does Job Loss Affect Life Expectancy?
description: Phillip B. Levine is an economics professor at Wellesley College and an associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research, an affiliate of the National Poverty Center. Last fall he was one of the authors of a study that adds a health dimension to the idea that baby boomers are the greatest victims of the Great Recession. Dr. Levine and his co-authors, Courtney C. Coile and Robin McKnight, concluded that the life expectancy of boomers ages 57 to 61 who lose their jobs  and health insurance  may be decreased by as much as three years. However, the life expectancy of those 62 and older who lose jobs is unaffected  in part because Social Security and Medicare provide a safety net to cushion the blow.

title: Pepsis Next Coke Parody Involves Pepsi Next
description: 5:00 p.m. | Updated One of the two combatants in the cola-wars battle to be waged Sunday night during Super Bowl XLVII is trying to get an early jump on the other.

title: When Help With Homework Is Too Much
description: Id always thought that being a parent is, in part, a teaching job.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 3 P.M. (Animal Planet) PUPPY BOWL IX Sixty-three of the cutest bruisers around, rescued from shelters across the country, go in for tackles, fumbles and Fido first downs, above (and vie for the title of M.V.P., as in Most Valuable Puppy), at Geico Stadium. Dan Schachner calls plays and penalties as the Ref; stars from the series Finding Bigfoot, Tanked and Call of the Wildman provide analysis and commentary. A hedgehog pep squad cheers from the sidelines; Meep the Bird tweets the action online. Aerial coverage is provided by the Ice Breakers blimp and its hamster crew. Sloppier ground-level angles are offered by the ever-popular water-bowl camera; an upgraded puppy cam, to watch the action from the players perspective; and the kiss cam. Not to be missed: the Kitty Halftime Show. The action is repeated at two-hour intervals throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: Warm Bodies Leads on a Cold Weekend for Movies
description: The Super Bowl usually takes a bite out of moviegoing, but yikes: Despite one successful counterprogramming effort  Warm Bodies, aimed at teenage girls, opened to solid results  total ticket sales for the weekend fell 24 percent compared with last year, which was also a very slow box-office period. The biggest casualty was Sylvester Stallone, whose unfortunately titled Bullet to the Head (Warner Brothers) took in an anemic $4.5 million, for sixth place, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

title: United States and Mexico Reach Tomato Deal, Averting a Trade War
description: The United States and Mexico have reached a tentative agreement on cross-border trade in tomatoes, narrowly averting a trade war that threatened to engulf a swath of American businesses.

title: Study Discovers Internal Trigger for Panic Attack in the Previously Fearless
description: In the past few years, scientists have learned a lot about fear from a woman who could not experience it. A rare illness had damaged a part of her brain known as the amygdala and left her eerily unafraid.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Snow Whites Children Top the List
description: At No. 1 on the graphic books paperback best-seller list this week is Volume 18 of Fables, by Bill Willingham and Mark Buckingham. Fables, published by DC Comics, is about storybook characters (from Cinderella to Pinocchio) making their way in the modern world. The ongoing series reaches issue No. 125 this month with an adventure about the Big Bad Wolf, who is learning to drive, and Snow White. In the world of Fables, the Wolf and Snow are married and have had children, two of whom take center stage in this volume, titled Cubs in Toyland. Its difficult to say too much without spoiling the story, but their daughter Therese goes off on an adventure that has some dire consequences. It starts out as a trip to an island of misfit toys, but the playthings have a very sad secret.

title: Which G.O.P. House Members Might Support Immigration Reform?
description: Last Monday, a bipartisan group of eight senators agreed to a set of overarching principles for immigration reform. On Tuesday, President Obama traveled to Las Vegas to outline his own proposals. Mr. Obamas speech was followed by reports that a bipartisan group of representatives in the House were hashing out a set of measures.

title: Candidate for President of Paraguay Dies in Crash
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Lino Oviedo, a candidate in Paraguays presidential election and one of the countrys most polarizing political figures, was killed in a helicopter crash on Saturday night while returning from a rally in northern Paraguay, government officials said Sunday.

title: Live Analysis of Super Bowl XLVII: Ravens 34, 49ers 31
description: Ben Hoffman, Andrew Das and a host of Times reporters, photographers and editors provided live coverage and analysis of the N.F.L. championship game, the commercials and the halftime show. Readers also got to rate the ads and saw how their predictions fared in the Crystal Bowl prediction game.

title: Reina Gives City a Point, but Not Much Hope
description: Manchester Citys Sergio Agero rescued a point on Sunday against Liverpool in Englands Premier League, but little else.

title: Tabascos Ties to Football Burn Deep
description: AVERY ISLAND, La.  Walter Stauffer McIlhenny, the fourth chief executive of the McIlhenny Co., the makers of Tabasco sauce, was a farsighted risk taker. The son of one of Theodore Roosevelts Rough Riders, he was an expert marksman who was wounded at Guadalcanal in 1942. He did not have the bullet in his leg removed until the next year so he could keep fighting.

title: Raising Voices and Awareness for Overlooked Works
description: In the program notes provided for the latest concert by the Da Capo Chamber Players at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday, Patricia Spencer, a flutist and the sole remaining member of the groups original 1970 personnel, offered an unusually candid and personal essay to explain the evenings offering.

title: From State to State, Varied Responses to the Issue of Gun Violence
description: Although the debate over curbing gun violence after the massacre in Newtown, Conn., is breaking down mostly along partisan lines in the nations statehouses  with several Democratic governors calling for stricter gun laws and most Republicans urging tighter security or revamped mental health policies  the handful of exceptions show the political and geographical complexities of the issue.

title: 2 Top Officers at Barclays to Step Down
description: LONDON  Barclays said on Sunday that its chief financial officer and its general counsel would resign, the latest departures after the British banks involvement in a series of scandals, including an investigation into the manipulation of global interest rates.

title: Israeli Strike Into Syria Said to Damage Research Site
description: WASHINGTON  The Israeli attack last week on a Syrian convoy of antiaircraft weapons appears to have damaged the countrys main research center for work on biological and chemical weapons, according to American officials who are sorting through intelligence reports.

title: More Literary Remixes From a Mash-Up Artist
description: The most generous reaction to David Shieldss recent books would be to assume they are straight-faced parodies in the vein of those performed by Joaquin Phoenix or Andy Kaufman, sly commentaries on the cultures already rampant solipsism. But all signs are that hes serious.

title: Official Says Iran Is Open to New Round of Nuclear Talks
description: MUNICH  Irans foreign minister said Sunday that his country was open to a renewed offer of direct talks with the United States on its nuclear program and that it looked favorably on a proposal for a new round of multilateral nuclear negotiations on Feb. 25 in Kazakhstan.

title: Lawyers Fight to Keep Auction Sellers Anonymous
description: New Yorks highest court has decided to review a recent ruling that could force the states auction industry to end its longstanding practice of keeping sellers names anonymous.

title: Pentagon Expects U.S. to Retain Presence in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagons top civilian and military officials on Sunday expressed an expectation, even a desire, that American troops would remain in Afghanistan after the NATO mission ends in December 2014, although they emphasized that no decision had been made.

title: Before the Big Game, Indulging in All Things New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  You knew it had to start with the crawfish.

title: Paganinis Melody, Borrowed for Keyboard
description: The theme of Paganinis jaunty Caprice No. 24 has proved irresistible to many classical composers, most famously Rachmaninoff. Like Bachs Goldberg Variations the Caprice has inspired myriad arrangements for instruments as eclectic as marimba, brass ensemble and balalaika.

title: On Decimated Shore, a Second Life for Christmas Trees
description: LONG BEACH, N.Y.  It is February, but the smell of Christmas wafts up from the shores of Long Beach these days.

title: The Author Himself Was a Cat in the Hat
description: The Cat wore a hat. Everyone knows that.

title: A Moment With the Mayor
description: NEW ORLEANS  In a previous post I noted how there were many spots available at the bar at Sylvain, one of the more popular eating and drinking establishments in the French Quarter these days. Shortly after filing that dispatch, the beaming, triumphant New Orleans mayor, Mitch Landrieu, and his wife, Cheryl, came in, sat next to me and ordered a couple of drinks. He graciously agreed to a quick interview to discuss what this day has been like for him, as well as what he thinks will happen on the field tonight.

title: Sinewy Sparks and Creative Combustion
description: While working on the choreography for a play about Marie Antoinette, Karole Armitage became turned on by the idea of voyeurism. In Maries time the court got to watch the queen dress, eat and sleep; in Ms. Armitages premiere of Mechanics of the Dance Machine, performed by Armitage Gone! Dance on Thursday at New York Live Arts, the body is on display in no uncertain terms. But even though the dancers wear next to nothing  nude bikinis for the women and short trunks for the men  this dance, with its mix of duets and group sections, remains as distant as a painting.

title: A Singer Figuring It Out as She Goes Along
description: In 2008 Allison Weiss released an EP called The Only Girl at an All-Boys Pool Party, the last song of which was I Was an Island. Its a jagged little number, with scratchy guitars and sweet, yelping vocals, part pop-punk, part confident 80s rock. The lyrics are imaginative, wounded and direct, and they begin like this:

title: The Face of Americas Illegal Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  In my latest Letter From Washington, I write about the Kumbaya moment that immigration reform seems to be enjoying  and the certainty that it will not last as the hard work of writing laws gets underway. But who are the illegal immigrants?

title: Adding Pages to a Songbook
description: Can one astoundingly gifted singer revive a beloved but dormant jazz vocal tradition? They say it takes only one to start a movement. As Ccile McLorin Salvant spun songs into a brilliant silk tapestry at the Allen Room on Saturday evening, I thought, Here she is. If anyone can extend the lineage of the Big Three  Billie Holiday, Sarah Vaughan, and Ella Fitzgerald  it is this 23-year-old virtuoso born in Miami to a French mother and a Haitian father and trained in France.

title: A Test Before the Vows
description: On Thursday evening Opera Lafayette presented a graceful and witty production of Flicien Davids Lalla Roukh at the Rose Theater. This opra-comique set in Mughal India had fallen into oblivion since its wildly successful premiere in 1862, well ahead of the wave of other French operas like Bizets Pcheurs de Perles, Delibess Lakm or Meyerbeers Africaine.

title: Hit With a Ray Gun
description: Administrivial Cox & Rathvon Alert! You love their Acrostics that run here in The New York Times, but the Hex team of Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon are now also offering their fabulous Boston Globe crossword puzzle to puzzleheads for the low, low price of $10.00 annually. If the Acrostics are just not enough Hexing for you, click here to join.

title: Finding Comfort in Moving Between Old and New
description: There was a time not long ago, before major-record labels almost completely cut their losses with jazz, when young bandleaders were busy covering bases and making cases. They wanted to show you how much they knew of the jazz tradition and how authoritatively they could play it. These were defensive actions, and also perhaps the last manifestations of hope that jazz could have a general listenership.

title: Shakespeares Mighty Sorority
description: Fashion is hardly the first thing on Tina Packers mind in Women of Will, her impassioned exploration of Shakespeares heroines, which opened Sunday night at the Gym at Judson. Yet even in this month, when designers are strutting their wares on runways all over New York, theres unlikely to be a more compelling demonstration of how clothes make the woman than the one provided by Ms. Packer, a longtime, multifarious interpreter of Shakespeare.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Feb. 4
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include factory orders for December (Monday); the Institute for Supply Management nonmanufacturing index for January (Tuesday); weekly jobless claims, fourth-quarter productivity and consumer credit for December (Thursday); the trade deficit for December and wholesale trade inventories for December (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Saturday Open Pairs at District 3 Winter Regional
description: The winners of the Saturday Open Pairs at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., last month were William Ehlers of Madison, N.J., and Corey Krantz of Drexel Hill, Pa.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Intrigues Shadow in a Church
description: ST. PAUL  The playwright John Patrick Shanley had good reason to hesitate when the composer Douglas J. Cuomo proposed that they collaborate on an operatic version of Doubt, Mr. Shanleys Pulitzer Prize-winning play, which had already been reborn as an Oscar-nominated film. The story, claustrophobically set in the parish grounds of a Roman Catholic church in the Bronx and inner-directed in its drama, lacks classic qualities of opera, typically the most extroverted of forms.

title: 3 Guys Bound by Only a Name
description: Opened on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Unemployed Adman Makes a Deal With His Body
description: A toothless examination of marketing and morality, lex de la Iglesias As Luck Would Have It combines lecture, farce and soapy sentiment in a single misshapen package.

title: Reformers Aim to Get China to Live Up to Own Constitution
description: BEIJING  After the chaos of the Cultural Revolution, the surviving Communist Party leaders pursued a project that might sound familiar to those in the West: Write a constitution that enshrines individual rights and ensures rulers are subject to law, so that China would never again suffer from the whims of a tyrant.

title: Medical Pay Model: Hospitals and Doctors Weigh In
description: To the Editor:

title: Shunning the Safe, FX Indulges Its Dark Side
description: The FX channel can be a rugged place, full of prostitutes, charlatans, spies, bikers and thugs. But its a nice place if you are trying to make a show.

title: Californias Hydraulic Fracturing Hotbed
description: The Monterey formation in Southern California is partially composed of oil and gas-rich shale plays, areas considered promising for production. As hydraulic fracturing operations expand in the region, the number of wells dotting the landscape may grow from a few hundred to a few thousand.

title: Irish Tycoon Found, Hazy on Abduction
description: DUBLIN  The story of an emaciated, ragged man found wandering barefoot in the middle of a quiet country road last week in County Leitrim, near the border with Northern Ireland, continues to confound the police, even after he was identified as a missing Irish property tycoon who said he was abducted eight months ago and tortured during his captivity.

title: Diane Wolkstein, Childrens Author Who Spurred a Storytelling Revival, Dies at 70
description: Diane Wolkstein, a childrens author and folklorist who once upon a time served as New York Citys official storyteller, deputized to revive the dying art in this city of eight million stories, died Thursday in Kaohsiung, Taiwan. She was 70.

title: Citizen Zhu
description: Zhu Ruifeng is a citizen reporter on a mission to expose corruption in China. But his passion for truth has cost him his marriage, and possibly more.

title: Service Is Held for School Bus Driver Who Tried to Prevent Kidnapping in Alabama
description: OZARK, Ala.  The service for the school bus driver had the feel of a state funeral.

title: Once BlackBerry Focused, a Campus Widens Its View
description: WATERLOO, Ontario  The University of Waterloo, in a city that people outside Canada would struggle to find on a map, is one of the worlds best technology schools.

title: Teen Vogue, a Survivor at 10 Years
description: After a long day of classes, homework and college preparation, Susannah Davies, a 17-year-old high school junior, takes a break by flipping through her print copy of Teen Vogue, the fashion magazine she has subscribed to since the sixth grade.

title: The Verge Hires  Writer Who Quit CNET in Protest
description: Greg Sandoval, the CNET senior writer who resigned in protest when the sites parent company, CBS, interfered with its editorial coverage last month, has been hired by The Verge, the Web site that first revealed the full extent of CBSs involvement.

title: Andr Cassagnes, Etch A Sketch Inventor, Is Dead at 86
description: Andr Cassagnes, a French electrical technician who half a century ago invented Etch A Sketch, the mechanical drawing toy that has lately become an American political simile, died on Jan. 16 near Paris. He was 86.

title: A Drug Maker Objects
description: To the Editor:

title: Airlines, Getting Greener
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyoncs Super Bowl Outfit
description: Here are a few details about Beyonc Knowless costume for her Super Bowl halftime performance at the Super Dome in New Orleans. The outfit, by the New York-based designer Rubin Singer, included a cropped black leather motorcycle jacket and a leather bodysuit made with strips of python and iguana, with insets of lace. Mr. Singer, who has worked with Ms. Knowles before, had a Valkyrie in mind. More warrior women. He also designed the costumes for Michelle Williams and 120 backup singers

title: Late Surge Turns Nail-Biter Into Easy Devils Win
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Seven games into a lockout-shortened 48-game regular season, the Devils knew they would be tested Sunday. They responded with a stout defensive effort in front of the reserve goalie Johan Hedberg before erupting for three goals in the final 3 minutes 54 seconds in beating the Islanders, 3-0.

title: Question of Aiding Cyprus Places Germany in a Bind
description: PARIS  When German officials said they would save the euro zone at all costs, the prospect of bailing out Russian oligarchs was not what they had in mind.

title: Envisioning Tiny Apartments, No Bathroom Required
description: Gianluca Polenzani, 6, knows exactly what he wants out of an apartment. There has to be a bed big enough for sleepovers. Two bathrooms would be nice. And he requires at least one air-conditioning unit, preferably a brand he knows and trusts.

title: After Assad, Chaos?
description: AMMAN, Jordan

title: Tax Loopholes May Be Next, Obama Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said in a televised interview on Sunday that he could foresee a budget deal in Congress that did not include further increases in tax rates but instead focused on eliminating loopholes and deductions.

title: A Chance at Justice in Guatemala
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Tracking the Pack
description: IN December, wolf 832F ventured out of her territory in Yellowstones Lamar Valley. As soon as she left the park, she lost its protections, and the wolf, a 6-year-old alpha female, was shot and killed by a hunter.

title: Friends of Fraud
description: Like many advocates of financial reform, I was a bit disappointed in the bill that finally emerged. Dodd-Frank gave regulators the power to rein in many financial excesses; but it was and is less clear that future regulators will use that power. As history shows, the financial industrys wealth and influence can all too easily turn those who are supposed to serve as watchdogs into lap dogs instead.

title: Basking in Home Crowds Warmth, Mickelson Never Gives Up Lead
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The marshal at the first hole at T.P.C. Scottsdale introduced Phil Mickelson on Sunday by mentioning his three Masters victories and two Phoenix Open titles but not his city of residence.

title: Broad Powers Seen for Obama in Cyberstrikes
description: WASHINGTON  A secret legal review on the use of Americas growing arsenal of cyberweapons has concluded that President Obama has the broad power to order a pre-emptive strike if the United States detects credible evidence of a major digital attack looming from abroad, according to officials involved in the review.

title: Vast Oil Reserve May Now Be Within Reach, and Battle Heats Up
description: FELLOWS, Calif.  Secure in this states history and mythology, the venerable Midway-Sunset oil field near here keeps producing crude more than a century after Southern Californias oil boom. Many of its bobbing pump jacks are relatively short, a telltale sign of the shallowness of the wells and the ease of extracting their prize.

title: New Jerseys Useful One-Gun-a-Month Law
description: A New Jersey statute limits purchases of firearms in the state to one handgun a month, with some exceptions. The superintendent of state police, for instance, can exempt collectors or competitive shooters from the limit so they can buy a set of guns all at once.

title: Film Financier Faces a Critical Juncture
description: LOS ANGELES  During the baseball strike of 1995, Thomas Tull, then a 24-year-old laundromat owner, was audacious enough to turn up at a training camp for the Atlanta Braves. They looked at his swing and sent him home.

title: Europe Moves Ahead on Privacy
description: The European Union is considering far-reaching privacy regulations that would give the citizens of its member countries significant control over how Web sites and marketing companies collect and use data about them. Years in the making, the effort stands in stark contrast to the much slower pace of discussions about online privacy laws in Washington.

title: More in France Are Turning to Islam, Challenging a Nations Idea of Itself
description: CRTEIL, France  The spacious and elegant modern building, in the heart of this middle-class suburb of Paris, is known as the mosque of the converts.

title: A New Space Race, or Chances to Collaborate?
The Dispute Over Returning Antiquities
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Seeking Home Buyouts in Flood Zones
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is proposing to spend as much as $400 million to purchase homes wrecked by Hurricane Sandy, have them demolished and then preserve the flood-prone land permanently, as undeveloped coastline.

title: A Million Jobs at Stake
description: With enormous struggle, the sluggish economy managed to create 2.2 million jobs last year. But beginning at the end of this month, at least half that amount  more than a million jobs  will start to disappear because of a mindless government austerity program that no one in Washington seems able to stop.

title: Amid All the Contradictions, Another Championship for Lewis
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Sexual Abuse Scandal Grips and Divides Hispanic Parishioners in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  At Dolores Mission Church in Boyle Heights, there was no shrinking from the news reverberating through the pews. The Rev. Scott Santarosa spent time usually reserved for the homily talking instead about what he called really painful stuff.

title: More Taxes and Less Heat
description: Suzanne Daley of The New York Times reports on how Greeks are turning to dirty and environmentally damaging solutions for heat after the government raised taxes on heating oil by 450 percent.

title: On Book-Tour Circuit, Sotomayor Sees a New Niche for a Justice
description: CHICAGO  At her Wednesday night book talk here, Justice Sonia Sotomayor glided through her audience of 700, dispensing homespun wisdom through a cordless microphone, interrupted by impromptu applause.

title: Rise in Oil Tax Forces Greeks to Face Cold as Ancients Did
description: ATHENS  Even in the leafy northern stretches of this city, home to luxury apartment buildings, mansions with swimming pools and tennis clubs, the smell of wood smoke lingers everywhere at night.

title: Lawyers Say Surveillance of Muslims Flouts Accord
description: Civil rights lawyers have asked a federal judge to appoint an independent monitor to review the New York Police Departments counterterrorism efforts. The lawyers said the polices tactics have placed Muslim communities under surveillance in violation of longstanding federal court guidelines.

title: Lottery Numbers
Selling Amnesty
description: Lets assume that President Obama and the Democrats sincerely want an immigration bill, that this is not a trick to trap Republicans into an anti-immigrant vote that will alienate Hispanic voters and secure Democratic advantage for a generation.

title: Services to Reflect Koch: Proudly Jewish on His Own Terms
description: The final resting place of Edward I. Koch, the former New York City mayor, is, in many ways, very Jewish. A Jewish star tops his monuments headstone. Its inscription, which he wrote, includes an epitaph proclaiming he was fiercely proud of his Jewish faith.

title: Notorious Attack Spurs India to Approve New Rape Laws
description: NEW DELHI  Indias government on Sunday approved tough new laws to deter sexual violence against women, including the death penalty in certain rape cases, as leaders moved to respond to public outrage over a recent gang rape case in the national capital.

title: Super Bowl Ads Speak to a Generation. But Which One?
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, it is 2013, but anyone who watched the commercials during Super Bowl XLVII on Sunday night might be excused for believing it was a year when Modern Family meant the Cleavers, the Bradys, the Huxtables or the Conners.

title: New Details Suggest a Defense in SAC Case
description: At the center of the governments insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is a trade that directly involves Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the fund.

title: Fresh Questions Over a Bank of America Settlement
description: Bank of America has long rued its decision in 2008 to acquire Countrywide Financial, the subprime mortgage giant. To date, the bank has set aside some $40 billion to settle claims of mortgage misconduct that occurred before it acquired the freewheeling lender.

title: As Extremists Invaded, Timbuktu Hid Artifacts of a Golden Age
description: TIMBUKTU, Mali  When the moment of danger came, Ali Imam Ben Essayouti knew just what to do. The delicate, unbound parchment manuscripts in the 14th-century mosque he leads had already survived hundreds of years in the storied city of Timbuktu. He was not about to allow its latest invaders, Tuareg nationalist rebels and Islamic extremists from across the region, to destroy them now.

title: Saving Timbuktus Priceless Artifacts
description: Amid all the fighting in Mali, residents of Timbuktu managed to preserve many ancient manuscripts, until recently.

title: Before Game Is Decided, Superdome Goes Dark
description: NEW ORLEANS  It was not New Orleanss brightest moment. About 90 seconds into the second half of Sundays Super Bowl, the lights on one half of the Superdomes roof suddenly went out. Internet connections in the press box were cut, and the scoreboards went dark.

title: Distillerys Small Batches Will Soon Be Less Small
description: In 1869, federal troops raided more than a dozen neighborhood whiskey-making operations in Brooklyn and dragged their equipment back to the Navy Yard. The seizure did not sit well with some in the troubled Fifth Ward neighborhood; the soldiers were greeted with curses and a hail of bricks tossed from the rooftops on Little Street.

title: Suspect Is Arraigned in 9-Year-Olds Fall From a Bronx Roof
description: The lawyer for a Bronx teenager accused of throwing a 9-year-old boy from the roof of their apartment building told a judge at his arraignment on Sunday that what happened was a tragic accident.

title: Turkish Authorities Seek Killer of Tourist From S.I.
description: ISTANBUL  It was her first trip overseas, but in many ways Sarai Sierra was the epitome of a modern young tourist  alone yet constantly connected.

title: An Evolving Country Begins to Accept Sara, Once David
description: Ten summers ago, on an early evening stroll in Bangkok, I met a baby elephant. The animals owner was walking him past the open-air food stalls of one of the city night markets where, for the price of five Thai baht, one could purchase a handful of bamboo stalks and feed it to the little fellow. Concentrating on the broken sidewalk under my feet, and wishing not to trip, I hadnt noticed the elephant until I nearly walked smack into him, eyeball to eyeball. Needless to say, it was a startling encounter. In my beloved Bronx, I had bumped into plenty of interesting creatures but no elephants. Being in Bangkok for extraordinary reasons, and in need of good luck, I fished into my purse and found a coin. I patted the head of the elephant for good measure as he crunched up his vegetarian treat.

title: For the Ravens Jones, a Trip Home and 2 Trips Into the End Zone
description: NEW ORLEANS  Jacoby Jones is not the most notable native Louisianian on the Baltimore Ravens; that would be safety Ed Reed. He is also not the Ravens player best known for on-field dancing; that honor goes to the retiring linebacker Ray Lewis.

title: Academic Study Weakens Israeli Claim That Palestinian School Texts Teach Hate
description: JERUSALEM  An academic study of the contents of Israeli and Palestinian Authority textbooks, to be published Monday, finds that each side generally presents the other as the enemy, but it undermines recent assertions by the Israeli government that Palestinian children are educated to hate.

title: Scarlet Fever Probably Didnt Blind Mary Ingalls
description: Those are among the first words of By the Shores of Silver Lake, by Laura Ingalls Wilder, and they are haunting ones. Generations of children who had grown to know Mary in the first books of the Little House series read them with the same sense of shock  Mary, the annoying, bossy, well-behaved sisterly nemesis to the wild half pint Laura, blind?

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) MEA MAXIMA CULPA: SILENCE IN THE HOUSE OF GOD (2012) Alex Gibney documents the case of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy, above, a Roman Catholic priest in Wisconsin who died in 1998 after having molested dozens if not hundreds of children in his care at a boarding school for the deaf, resulting in a trail of denial and cover-up from rural America to the Vatican. Mr. Gibneys methods are a blend of solid journalism and cinematic sensationalism, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The reliance on melodramatic music and lurid  though not explicit  re-enactments does not seem to me to make the movie more powerful, but rather the opposite. There is something to be said for a clear and unblinking recitation of facts, and thankfully Mr. Gibney does a lot of that. But the heart of the film, the real source of its emotional impact, Mr. Scott said, lies in a remarkable series of interviews with some of the men, most now in their 60s, who endured Father Murphys assaults when they were children and who have worked for almost 40 years to bring his crimes to light. John Slattery, Jamey Sheridan, Chris Cooper and Ethan Hawke interpret their words.

title: Word of the Day | chafe
description: chafe \chaf\ verb and noun

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Feb. 4
description: "They belong to all of humanity. It is our duty to save them.

title: Power Fails and 49ers Surge, but Ravens Win
description: NEW ORLEANS  The lights went out at the Superdome during the Super Bowl. Only then did the game really begin.

title: Beyonc Silences Doubters With Intensity at Halftime
description: A main requirement for a halftime performer at the Super Bowl is indestructibility. Too much is on the line for anything but. The halftime show is time-constrained, highly choreographed and responsible for keeping hundreds of millions of people around the world entertained between aggressive bursts of football and extremely expensive bursts of commercials. It is a show, but more important, it is the glue that holds the night together, the short money that keeps the long money flowing.

title: Medicines Co. Buys Cholesterol Drug Rights
description: The Medicines Company is licensing the rights to a powerful type of cholesterol-lowering drug from Alnylam Pharmaceuticals, entering one of the hottest races in the industry.

title: Simms Is Short of Analysis, and CBS Is Out of Sync
description: I was wondering if Sean McManus, the chairman of CBS Sports, slipped into the networks booth at the Superdome on Sunday night to give Jim Nantz and Phil Simms a pep talk.

title: Kaepernick, Showing Guts, Falls Slightly Short of Glory
description: NEW ORLEANS  San Francisco quarterback Colin Kaepernick slumped forward toward the microphone, his eyes aimed downward, his face blank. Reporters pressed in all around him. They wanted to know how it felt for his final drive to end 5 yards from the end zone, 5 yards from a lead in Super Bowl XLVII.

title: No Corrections: February 4, 2013
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Flaccos Precision Typical of Elite Quarterbacks
description: NEW ORLEANS  Neither of Joe Flaccos two brothers was on the field in the Super Bowl on Sunday night. Flacco, the Baltimore Ravens quarterback, was not part of any pregame controversies involving deer antler spray, and he did not turn this game into a much-publicized finale of his retirement tour. At this point, there is no such thing as Flacco-ing.

title: Super Bowl Ads: Readers React
description: As advertisers tried to generate buzz by releasing commercials early online, Times readers voted Sunday night on which of the games ads stuck out, and which of the ads they could have done without.

title: Why Always Him? Balotelli Scores Twice in Milan Debut
description: Mario Balotelli made a dramatic return to Italy on Sunday by scoring two goals for A.C. Milan in its 2-1 victory over Udinese.

title: In Chinas Most-Watched Divorce Case, 3 Victories, 1 Defeat
description: BEIJING  For over a year, Chinese society has been riveted by the case of Kim Lee, an American woman who did something extremely unusual: go public with accusations of domestic violence against her wealthy and famous husband, Li Yang.

title: After 17 Seasons, Lewis Retires
description: A look at Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewiss storied football career through pictures.

title: Jim Harbaugh Criticizes Officiating in Super Bowl
description: San Francisco Coach Jim Harbaugh took issue with a few of the calls in the waning moments of the Super Bowl.

title: With a Son on Each Sideline, the Harbaughs Remain Neutral to the End
description: NEW ORLEANS  Two days before Thanksgiving in 2011, Jack Harbaugh received an unsolicited phone call from Archie Manning. Harbaughs sons, Jim and John, were about to face each other as coaches of the San Francisco 49ers and the Baltimore Ravens. Over the years, Manning had watched two of his sons, Peyton and Eli, battle each other and he wanted to sympathize.

title: News Quiz | February 4, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Super Bowl Replay: Ravens 34, 49ers 31
description: The Baltimore Ravens survived a second-half rally by San Francisco and a power outage to win in New Orleans.

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 4
description: NEWS A secret legal review on the use of the United States growing arsenal of cyberweapons has concluded that President Barack Obama has the broad power to order a pre-emptive strike if the United States detects credible evidence of a major digital attack looming from abroad, according to officials involved in the review. David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker report from Washington.

title: Felling Trees to Save Kashmirs Wullar Lake
description: A vast shoreline forest of willow trees is being chopped down and dredged out in Kashmir Valley to help restore water levels, fish stocks and wildlife in one of Asias largest bodies of freshwater.

title: Bones Under Parking Lot Belonged to Richard III
description: LEICESTER, England  Until it was discovered beneath a city parking lot last fall, the skeleton had lain unmarked, and unmourned, for more than 500 years. Friars fearful of the men who slew him in battle buried the man in haste, naked and anonymous, without a winding sheet, rings or personal adornments of any kind, in a space so cramped his cloven skull was jammed upright and askew against the head of his shallow grave.

title: Challenging the Laws of Physics in the Subway
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pirates Seize French-Owned Tanker and Hold 17 Aboard
description: HONG KONG  A French-owned oil tanker that went missing off the Ivory Coast is believed to have been hijacked by pirates who are holding the 17 sailors on board, a maritime agency said Monday.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 4, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article What Is Middle Class in Manhattan?

title: A Conversation With: Former Solicitor General Gopal Subramanium
description: A recently-issued report from the Justice J.S. Verma Committee, established to recommend reforms to Indias sexual violence laws after the gang rape of a 23-year-old woman in Delhi sparked nationwide protests, has been described as a game changer: it represents a scathing critique of the Indian state and governing class, while suggesting ambitious reforms to the countrys legal, judicial and political system.

title: A Hard Life on the Roof of the World
description: It is a harsh, unforgiving existence for the 1,200 Kyrgyz people who live at the end of the remote and inhospitable Wakhan corridor in Afghanistan, a 140-mile-long strip of land surrounded by China, Tajikistan and Pakistan. Less than half of the children there live to see their fifth birthday. And it is commonplace for women to die during childbirth.

title: Does Being a Fan Help Define Who You Are?
description: Are you a fan of a particular sports team  or actor, television show, musician, band, movie, writer or anything else? Fanhood can bring you joy, and make feel like youre part of a community with other like-minded people.

title: New Archbishop of Canterbury Takes Office
description: LONDON  On the eve of a divisive vote in Parliament on the legalization of same-sex marriage, Justin Welby, the former bishop of Durham, on Monday took over formally as the 105th archbishop of Canterbury, the spiritual head of the worlds 77 million Anglicans, saying he shares the Church of Englands opposition to marriage among people of the same gender.

title: Commonwealth Games Organizer in India Could Face Life in Prison
description: Suresh Kalmadi, the former chief organizer of the 2010 scandal that marred the Commonwealth Games, was charged Monday with cheating, conspiracy and causing a loss of more than $16 million to taxpayers by a Delhi court.

title: February College Checklist for Seniors
description: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselors Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

title: Ravens Soar to Super Bowl Victory
description: In the article For the Ravens Jones, a Trip Home and 2 Trips Into the End Zone, Sam Borden writes about the Baltimore Ravens Super Bowl victory.

description: LONDON  Luigi de Vecchi has been appointed chairman of corporate and investment banking for continental Europe at Citigroup, the bank announced on Monday.

title: A 49ers Defense That Simply Wore Down
description: Were you wondering where Aldon Smith (19 games started) was during the Super Bowl? He played (2 tackles, 1 QB hit), although he wasnt very effective.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Chip Brown on Witnessing North Dakotas Oil Boom
description: Chip Brown, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover article about life in and around the Williston Basin in North Dakota, which is experiencing its biggest oil boom. He last wrote for the magazine about thefilmmaker Whit Stillman.

title: How Green Is My Hotel?
description: The Hague  seen from the outside, the Court Garden Hotel, with its 1970s utilitarian commercial exterior, doesnt appear particularly green.

title: Trial by Video
description: BEREZNIKI, Russia  I can barely see you, the young woman on the videoscreen said, her high-pitched voice trembling. You are just a dark silhouette. And I cannot see or hear the defense or the prosecution at all.

title: Five Questions for: Author Jamil Ahmad
description: Jamil Ahmad is the author of The Wandering Falcon, a novel that delves into the lives of the tribal population living in the border region of Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iran. This is the debut novel of the former Pakistani bureaucrat, now in his 80s. He has spent more than 20 years in the Balochistan and Frontier provinces in Pakistan during his service.

title: Japan Airlines Says 787 Grounding Will Cost It $7.5 Million
description: TOKYO  Japan Airlines said on Monday that the grounding of its Boeing 787 Dreamliner fleet would cost it 700 million yen, or $7.5 million, in earnings through March and that it would seek compensation from Boeing.

description: The series is featuring occasional works of fiction. This is one.

description: Soccer is known throughout much of the world as the beautiful game. But the sports ugliest side  the scourge of match-fixing  will not soon go away.

title: Ex-Official Pleads Guilty to Old Charge in Britain
description: LONDON  A former British government minister announced his resignation from Parliament on Monday, after reversing his longstanding denials to accept responsibility for persuading his former wife to take the blame for a speeding offense he had committed a decade ago.

title: Q.& A.: Recording Video on an SD Card
description: Q.

title: Victory Declared for Beyonc
description: Super Bowl halftime shows can be polarizing, if only because so many recent acts have been past their prime, but the only controversy over Beyoncs performance Sunday was whether her set somehow overtaxed the Superdome and led to a blackout. Most reviews made note of Beyoncs controversial lip-syncing at the recent presidential inauguration. A sampling:

title: On Our Radar: A Power Plant, Imploded
description: A 1950s-era power plant on San Diego Bay that was long viewed as a polluting eyesore is blown up to make way for a park. {The Los Angeles Times]

title: Peace Talks Start Between Myanmar and Rebels
description: BANGKOK  China hosted peace talks between the Myanmar government and ethnic Kachin rebels on Monday, as outside pressure grew on both sides to end the intense fighting of recent weeks.

title: Bolshoi Director Accuses Rivals
description: MOSCOW  Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, who was severely burned by an acid attack on Jan. 17, says he was targeted by a group of people who hope to replace the theaters current leadership and who had previously attacked another top executive at the ballet, prompting that man to leave his post in 2011.

title: Therapy Plateau No Longer Ends Coverage
description: Ellen Gorman, 72, a New York psychotherapist, cant walk very far and gets around the city mainly by taxi, which is really expensive, she said. Twice since 2008 her physical therapy was discontinued because she wasnt progressing. But after a knee replacement last year, she is getting physical therapy again, exercising with her therapist and building up her endurance by walking in the hallway of her Manhattan apartment building.

title: Signs of a Possible Defense in SAC Case
description: The governments insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors centers on a trade involving Steven A. Cohen, the hedge funds billionaire founder. But new details cast doubt on how authorities have portrayed the trade, suggesting a possible line of defense for the portfolio manager and raising questions about whether the government will be able to build a case against Mr. Cohen, DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Lattman report.

title: Opinion Report: One Gun Per Month
description: From the editorial page

title: Schneidermans Chief of Staff Is Leaving
description: ALBANY  Attorney General Eric T. Schneidermans chief of staff, Neal Kwatra, is departing to set up his own political consultancy.

title: So Why Did the Power Go Out at the Super Bowl?
description: Richard Rainey of The Times-Picayune offered a possible explanation for the power failure at the Superdome on Sunday. Electrical work was an urgent matter at the stadium in the months leading to the Super Bowl. Rainey said its not clear whether theres a connection between the emergency work and Sundays blackout. But what is clear is that a lot of work needed to be done.

Sanger and Thom Shanker in Mondays New York Times.

Archaeology Is Awesome
