title: Osborne Promises More Regulatory Power to Split Up British Banks
description: LONDON  British regulators will have the power to split up banks that fail to separate risky trading activity from retail banking, George Osborne, the countrys chancellor of the Exchequer, said on Monday.

title: Oracle to Buy Acme Packet for $2.1 Billion
description: Oracles deal machine has come to life once more, as the enterprise software giant agreed on Monday to buy Acme Packet for $2.1 billion to bolster its communications product offerings.

title: The Sonia Show
description: Justice Sonia Sotomayor is revising the role of the detached, cloistered Supreme Court judge as she tours the country with her new memoir, My Beloved World.

title: Money, Wealth, and Models
description: Some further thoughts inspired by the welcome hatred of the usual suspects toward yours truly. One quite common statement among the Austrianish horde is something along the lines of Its ridiculous to imagine, as Krugman does, that you can create real wealth by printing more pieces of paper.

title: Pereira Says Officials Made Right Call
description: Mike Pereira, the Fox Sports analyst and former N.F.L. supervisor of officials, gave the officials a passing grade in the Super Bowl.

title: The Gun Report: February 4, 2013
description: Weekends are always when most people get shot. This weekend, a famous sniper was killed by a troubled veteran he was trying to help, two kids were shot by accident (one wounded, one killed) and a shooting took place outside a church on Sunday.

title: Rate Expectations (Wonkish)
description: FT Alphaville links to a puzzling piece by Maasaki Kanno, who argues that the relative success of Abenomics in Japan, so far, reflects a divergence in expectations between the currency and bond markets:

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Disappointing Super Bowl Ads, and a Hollywood Outsider Makes His Move
description: For those viewers hoping for exciting, high-quality performances in the Super Bowl Sunday night, the Baltimore Ravens and the San Francisco 49ers delivered in thrilling style. For those more interested in the advertisements than the football, the results were more disappointing, Stuart Elliott writes in The Times. The commercials, he says, fell back on familiar strategies and themes that would have been more appropriate for the Eisenhower administration, with a joke about a mother-in-law, a gag about the word panties and an ad set at a prom, among others. It was a missed opportunity for marketers, Mr. Elliott writes.

title: Pressures Mount on European Media
description: The euro crisis is damaging Europes media. In Germany, a leading newspaper closed and another newspaper has been placed in receivership. Many newspapers are cutting back on staff for lack of advertising. Reporting will suffer, say editors.

title: In Words and Unmistakable Song, Kochs Bond With City Is Celebrated
description: After the eulogies by a mayor and a former president, after the loving references to Uncle Eddie by a 17-year-old grandnephew, after the coffin had been lifted on the shoulders of the Police Departments ceremonial unit, the 10,000-pipe organ in Temple Emanu-El played a piece that is not usually heard at a funeral, but that seemed singularly appropriate for the funeral of Edward I. Koch: New York, New York.

title: Moscow Exchange Prices I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The Moscow Exchange, Russias largest bourse, said on Monday that it had priced its shares at 55 rubles ($1.83) to 63 rubles ($2.10), in a listing that would value the company at up to $4.6 billion.

title: What Sacha Baron Cohen Refused to Do and Other Producers Secrets
description: LOS ANGELES  Who knew that movie producers  alternately reviled and exalted, depending on their access to money  could be so chatty? A panel organized by the Producers Guild of America last week produced a slew of revelations, from the bet that a Django Unchained producer, Stacey Sher, made against her own Oscar chances to Ang Lees real feelings about Hollywood.

title: A New Year, but Some Old Issues
description: Last weeks column concluded with the comment that a resolution to the Chinese-Japanese dispute over the Diaoyu/Senkaku Islands seemed far away despite hopeful talk about the possibility of a summit meeting between Xi Jinping of China and Shinzo Abe of Japan.

title: What Were Reading
description: National Geographic Traveler: Chicken potpie. Whoopie pie. Shoo-fly pie. A crusty guide to chowing your way through the Pennsylvania Dutch Country.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Shell Denies Tax Evasion in India
description: The Indian unit of the Anglo-Dutch oil company Royal Dutch Shell said Monday that it would challenge a notice by the Indian tax authorities alleging tax evasion through the transfer of shares.

title: Carlyles Investment Ideas, by Podcast
description: The Carlyle Group is making its debut on iTunes.

title: Blackout Is a Boon for Super Bowl Ratings
description: 8:43 p.m. | Updated CBS came close to matching the audience levels of the two most-watched television events of all time Sunday night, turning an electrical failure in the New Orleans Superdome into a likely ratings advantage for its coverage of Super Bowl XLVII.

title: Malala Yousafzai, Pakistani Girl Shot by Taliban Militants, Speaks in New Videos
description: Last Updated, 4:54 p.m. Speaking on camera for the first time since she survived an assassination attempt by the Pakistani Taliban last year, the young activist Malala Yousafzai began with the words, Today you can see that Im alive. The 15-year-old, who was shot in the head as she left school in Pakistans Swat Valley four months ago, promised that she would continue to be an outspoken advocate of the right for every girl, every child, to be educated.

title: Bombshell Doesnt Exist, but Its Songs Are Real Hits
description: On any given night at Maries Crisis, a cozy singalong piano bar in Greenwich Village, the pianist can be reliably counted on to deliver a fistful of standards. Songs made famous by Broadway royalty  Barbra, Liza, Patti  come out to play.

title: U.S. Roster vs. Honduras
description: Twenty-four players will train Monday in Miami, two days before the start of the final round of regional qualifying for a berth in 2014 World Cup in Brazil. The United States opens play in the hexagonal against Honduras in San Pedro Sula (4 p.m. Eastern; TV, beIN Sport).

title: Where Strange Is Normal
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: BMW Recalls 1 Series ActiveE for Powertrain Problem
description: BMW is recalling vehicles in its test fleet of 1 Series all-electric cars designed to help define the future of mobility because of a possible immobility problem, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Leading Off: The Weirdest, Wildest Super Bowl
description: When Ray Lewis finally stops preening for the cameras, Jim Harbaugh stops bellowing for a holding call and people finally run out of lights-out jokes, this Super Bowl will find its rightful place in the pantheon of Super Bowls as the strangest one ever: It started out as a Ravens romp, featured a halftime show that could have been seen from space had the Superdome not been a dome, and then became a combination of social commentary on the failing state of our infrastructure and slapstick comedy drawn from the lessons of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Frank Ocean Suggests He Will Not Press Charges Against Chris Brown
description: 11:52 a.m. | Updated  Frank Ocean has published an online message suggesting that he will not press charges against Chris Brown in connection with a brawl the two singers had in a parking lot last week. In a paragraph on his Web site that did not mention Mr. Brown or the fight, Mr. Ocean wrote: Ill choose sanity. No criminal charges. No civil lawsuit. Forgiveness, albeit difficult, is wisdom.

title: Owner Gets Lesson in Managing Sales Reps
description: At the last meeting of the She Owns It business group, Beth Shaw, founder of YogaFit, wondered why her recently hired sales representative was not meeting expectations. As that conversation continued, Ms. Shaw came to see the importance of a good customer-relations management system. She also considered putting role-playing exercises in place for her sales representatives and setting clear goals for them  from Day 1.

title: Italian Government Blocks Premiere of Film on Berlusconi
description: A documentary film that offers a scathing portrait of Silvio Berlusconis tenure as Italys prime minister has had its premiere in Italy postponed at the request of the government there. Girlfriend in a Coma was to be shown in Rome on Feb. 13, but it is now scheduled to be shown only after Feb. 24, the date of a national election in which Mr. Berlusconi is a candidate.

title: Clearing Homes From Flood Zones
description: TimesCast: A buyback proposal for New York homes damaged in Hurricane Sandy. | New cyberattack capabilities for President Obama. | Greeks struggle to pay for home heating.

title: A Closer Look at Moderating Views of Climate Sensitivity
description: | Live Updates below |Worse than we thought has been one of the most durable phrases lately among those pushing for urgent action to stem the buildup of greenhouse gases linked to global warming.

title: Quick One-Dish Meals, Some Cooking Required
description: This week, in response to readers requests on the Recipes for Health Facebook page, I focused on quick one-dish dinners. You may have a different opinion than I do about what constitutes a quick meal. There are quick meals that involve little or no cooking  paninis and sandwiches, uncomplicated omelets, scrambled eggs, and meals that combine prepared items with foods that you cook -- but I chose to focus on dishes that are made from scratch. I bought a cabbage and a generous bunch of kale at the farmers market, some sliced mushrooms and bagged baby spinach at Trader Joes, and used them in conjunction with items I had on hand in the pantry and refrigerator.

title: The Question You Should Be Asking About the Stock Market
description: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Arizona Mining Project Wins Crucial Permit
description: A Canadian mining company has come one step closer to building a mile-wide, half-mile-deep open-pit copper mine on public land 30 miles south of Tucson. On Thursday, Arizonas Department of Environmental Quality granted Rosemont Copper, a subsidiary of Augusta Resource of Vancouver, a crucial air quality permit, saying emissions from the proposed mine would not violate federal standards for carbon monoxide, nitrogen and sulfur dioxide, or fine and large particles.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 4
A Sung-Through Plea to the Academy (Just Kidding)
description: LOS ANGELES  You know you are an Oscar front-runner when you merit a parody. So Anne Hathaway must be sitting pretty, now that a spoof of her Academy Award-nominated turn as Fantine in Les Misrables, with its show-stopping I Dreamed a Dream, is racking up hundreds of thousands of views on YouTube.

title: Next Stop: Ed Koch Station? M.T.A. Suggests Otherwise
description: He has a bridge. He has a movie. But it seems that a subway station may be one honor too many for Edward I. Koch.

title: Feeling For | Aurlie Bidermann Miki Dora Necklace
description: A longtime favorite of the fashion flock for her whimsical take on a tribal aesthetic, Aurlie Bidermann is moving up  or rather down  to Barneys New Yorks recently refreshed first floor on Madison Avenue to showcase her latest jewels starting tomorrow. Nestled among her spring collection is the Miki Dora necklace, a twist on her preppy nautical rope bracelets. The piece is exclusive to the store and is finished in a gold patina. Dont let this one sail away.

title: Kitty Kelley Writing Book on Women in the Senate
description: Kitty Kelley, the author of unauthorized best-selling biographies of Oprah Winfrey and Nancy Reagan, will turn her gossipy form of reporting to the women of the United States Senate, her publisher said Monday. The book is tentatively set for publication in the spring of 2016.

title: Works Owned by Lucian Freud Head to British Museums
description: When the British painter Lucian Freud died in 2011, at the age of 88, his heirs faced a considerable inheritance tax. But his estate, taking advantage of a provision in British law that envisions acceptance in lieu of taxes, has now blunted that burden by donating works by two influential 19th-century French artists, Corot and Degas, to British arts institutions.

title: Responding to a Digital Attack
description: The Timess David E. Sanger discusses a secret legal review concerning President Obamas powers in the face of a major cyberattack on the United States.

title: Syrian Rebels Free 3 Hostages in Exchange for Captured Fighters
description: MOSCOW  Two Russian steel plant workers and an Italian citizen kidnapped by rebels in Syria have been freed in exchange for captured rebel fighters, the Russian Foreign Ministry said on Monday.

title: The Get-Barry-Off-Antarctica Origami Puzzle
description: Barry Hayes currently lives and works at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station at the center of Antarctica  the coldest, windiest and driest continent on the planet. Hes been there for the past three months, but austral winter will soon be rolling in. Its time to go home.

title: Is it Flat-Foldable?
description: The Get-Barry-Off-Antarctica Origami Puzzle featured in Numberplay originally emerged from research into the fundamental mathematics of paper-folding: can a given crease pattern be folded into a flat origami?

title: Despite Reorganizations, Scant Signs of Change in Airline Industry
description: Given the many airline Chapter 11 cases in this country, you might expect that there would be some room for innovation. You would be wrong.

title: Street Style: Turtlenecks
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Jan. 28.

title: Obamas Shifts May Affect U.S. Legal Plan on Gay Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  The practice of law would be much more pleasant, many lawyers will tell you over a second Scotch, if it did not require clients. It is one thing to construct an airtight legal argument and quite another to deal with the demands of inconstant human beings.

title: Walkabout  2/4: Super Bowl Exodus, and Best and Worst of U.S. Airports
description: Easy Come, Easy Go After yesterdays Super Bowl, about 42,000 people are expected to board planes at Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport. With visitors arriving by Friday for festivities leading up to Fat Tuesday, Feb. 12, its a busy week for the Big Easy. (The Associated Press, via Huffington Post)

title: Investigation Reveals Match-Fixing in Hundreds of Games
description: Criminal organizations have infiltrated the highest levels of European and international soccer, threatening the integrity of the sport, global law enforcement officials said Monday as they disclosed the results of a 19-month investigation that indicated that hundreds of people had been involved in match-fixing. The matches fixed included qualifying games for the World Cup and for the European Championship, and two Champions League matches, including one in England. David Jolly and Sam Borden have the story.

title: Moodys Warns Jefferies on Excessive Pay
description: The $78 million compensation package that the Jefferies Group doled out to its top executives raised more than a few eyebrows  including those at Moodys Investors Service.

title: Back to the Future, in the Kitchen
description: Its 1967, and the legendary anchorman Walter Cronkite is touting the kitchen of 2001: meals are automatically programmed from menus given to the automatic chef via typewriter or punch computer card, and used dishes are melted down, leftovers and all, to be made into new dishes, so that there is no waste. Smithsonianrecently featured him in a nostalgic blog post about his CBS documentary program, The 21st Century.

title: Audio Excerpt
description: Jamaica Kincaid reads from See Now Then.

title: Joseph Mitchell Back in The New Yorker
description: This weeks edition of The New Yorkers annual anniversary issue includes a never-before-published piece by Joseph Mitchell, one of the magazines most celebrated contributors.

title: Look of the Moment | Kerry Washington
description: The Girl: The Scandal actress who took home the award for Best Actress in a Drama Series at the NAACP Image Awards in Los Angeles on Friday.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Fill-In | Where Las Vegas Stardust Rests in Peace
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first six paragraphs of the museum review Where Las Vegas Stardust Rests in Peace by Edward Rothstein.

title: Zinging Spielberg and Hooper, Praising Bigelow and Lee
description: LOS ANGELES  The Directors Guild has a unique tradition on the awards circuit, allowing each of its feature film nominees to give a speech and accept a prize medallion before the actual winner (this year it was Ben Affleck) is announced. They will get to keep the medallions, said the ceremonys host, Kelsey Grammer, as a reminder of just how close they came.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Lia Armatas joined the New York office of Arnold Worldwide as director for creative services. She succeeds Tara Maldonado, who left, the agency said, to focus on her floral design business. Ms. Armatas had been creative resource manager at Grey New York, part of the Grey division of the Grey Group, which is owned by WPP. Arnold Worldwide is part of the Havas Creative division of Havas.

title: Out of Darkness, Springing Into Action
description: NEW ORLEANS  When half the Superdome went dark Sunday, so did the N.F.L.s control center, up near the top of the stadium, above the last row of seats. Among the two dozen gathered there was Doug Thornton, the buildings manager since 1997.

title: Fox News Monitors Geraldo as He Mulls Political Office
description: Geraldo Riveras stated interest in running for a Senate seat in New Jersey has been derided as a joke and a publicity stunt. But his employers are taking it seriously.

title: Girls Lead in Science Exam, but Not in the United States
description: Girls outperformed boys in more countries in a science test given to 15-year-old students in 65 countries  but in the United States, the scores reverse.

title: Energy Department Is the Latest Victim of an Online Attack
description: The Energy Department was hit by an online attack last month that compromised the personal data of several hundred employees.

title: Tactics for Getting the I.R.S. on the Phone
description: If you need help with a federal tax question, the Internal Revenue Service offers free, live assistance by telephone. But youll probably need to be patient when you call.

title: Campaign Just Wants to Say Know to Kidney Disease
description: A public service advertising campaign that seeks to help in the fight against kidney disease is using new technologies not only to lower production costs but also to gain attention.

title: Besides the Gym and Great Views, Dont Forget to Mention the Garbage Disposal
description: The online listing for a condominium in Brooklyn Heights advertises five bedrooms and wide-open views of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Statue of Liberty and the Manhattan skyline for $4.995 million. A 19th-floor two-bedroom on East 59th Street offers floor-to-ceiling windows, a gas fireplace and two balconies; corporations and pieds--terre welcome, $2.495 million. And a penthouse on Greenwich Street offers a 500-square-foot terrace and a pet spa for $6.195 million.

title: McCains Iran Humor Isnt Fully Appreciated
description: Senator John McCain just cant help himself, it seems. At least not when theres a joke to be told about Iran.

title: Motorsports Monday: Showing Off the 2013 Models
description: Formula One teams have begun unveiling their 2013 models.

title: Super Bowl Ads Recall Days Gone By
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: The successes and failures of this years Super Bowl ads. | Ang Lee on the technology behind Life of Pi. | An interactive project encourages action against human trafficking.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Super Bowl Ads Recall Days Gone By
description: The successes and failures of this years Super Bowl ads. The Oscar-nominated director Ang Lee on the technology behind Life of Pi. An interactive project empowers students to take action against human trafficking.

title: Pigeons, in All Their Genetic Variety
description: They might be called the rats of the sky, but Charles Darwin certainly saw something in pigeons. It turns out the father of evolution saw in the birds an amazing variety of variation in color, shape and form.

title: Pigeons Get a New Look
description: In 1855, Charles Darwin took up a new hobby. He started raising pigeons.

title: Despite Expectations, Corporations Could Face More Cases of Criminal Liability
description: Mary Jo White, the nominee to be chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has stated that she is not a fan of pursuing cases of criminal liability against corporations. Such views are likely to draw scrutiny during her confirmation process, but it does not necessarily mean companies facing sanctions can expect an easy ride in Washington.

title: Take the Over on Underwear
description: Yes, the Ravens pulled off what turned out to be an exciting win over the 49ers. Yes, Beyonc was amazing. And, yes, that 35-minute power failure in the second half made this one of the strangest Super Bowls ever. But on Twitter, one of the most comment-worthy events of Sunday night came about an hour into the game: that you-had-to-see-it-to-believe-it commercial for Calvin Klein underwear. Will Matthew Terry turn out to be the Marky Mark of 2013?

title: Bruno Mars, Rihanna and Sting to Perform Together at Grammys
description: To the ever-growing list of artists already scheduled to perform at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, add this unlikely combination: Bruno Mars, Rihanna and Sting. The trio will perform together during the show, the Recording Academy announced Monday, as will Kelly Clarkson. All but Sting also are nominees for awards this year.

title: A President and His Governor Catch Up
description: They spoke intently and uninterrupted, eyes fixed on each other for about five minutes despite the swirling crowd around them.

title: The Decoded Pigeon, Living Gluten-Free, and a Problem With SimplyThick
description: Carl Zimmer on sequencing the pigeon genome, one womans choice to dump gluten and Catherine Saint Louis on the complicated case of a food thickener that has raised safety concerns in premature babies.

title: Microsofts Reller Talks Windows 8 Sales
description: The introduction of Windows 8 did not restore growth to the personal computer business over the holidays. Microsoft, though, says the product is just getting warmed up.

title: Home With the Flu? 20 Years of the Family Medical Leave Act
description: Tuesday is the 20th anniversary of the Family and Medical Leave Act. During those 20 years, it has been used more than 100 million times by employees caring for new babies, tending sick parents and spouses, and coping with illness.

title: Effective Addiction Treatment
description: Countless people addicted to drugs, alcohol or both have managed to get clean and stay clean with the help of organizations like Alcoholics Anonymous or the thousands of residential and outpatient clinics devoted to treating addiction.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Treats

title: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
description: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

title: U.S. Accuses S. & P. of Fraud in Suit on Loan Bundles
description: The Justice Department filed civil fraud charges late on Monday against the nations largest credit-ratings agency, Standard & Poors, accusing the firm of inflating the ratings of mortgage investments and setting them up for a crash when the financial crisis struck.

title: Brain Shape Linked to Cocaine Addiction
description: Why are some people able to use cocaine without becoming addicted? A new study suggests the answer may lie in the shape of their brains.

title: A Contest of Caillettes
description: Sampling the fare at the First World Championship of Caillettes in the town of St.-Pray.

title: Forget Top Chef. Here, Meatballs Compete.
description: PARIS  The Ardche region in south-central France is famous for chestnuts, sheep farming, Stone Age cave paintings and a scenic river.

title: Governor, a Casualty of Sandy
description: 5:57 p.m. | Updated

title: A Play on Natures Patterns
description: If ages from now, when New York City is covered in dust, archaeologists were to dig through its many layers and uncover the stainless-steel sculpture that currently stands at the southeast corner of 54th Street and Avenue of the Americas, what would they think?

title: The Evolution of the Ed Koch Obituary
description: When former New York Mayor Edward I. Koch died early on Friday, The Times was prepared. At least, it looked that way.

title: Top Iranian Politicians Exchange Accusations
description: TEHRAN  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad escalated a bitter political fight this week with Irans most influential political family by disclosing secret film recordings of what he purported were fraudulent business deals.

title: Study Flags Duplicate Financing
description: The government may be wasting millions of dollars by paying for the same research projects twice, according to a new analysis of grant and contract records.

title: Remembering Chris Kyle, a Deadly American Sniper
description: In the fall of 2006, my infantry platoon gathered in a dusty patrol base in Baghdad to watch our own being killed in fuzzy, pixilated video clips. An insurgent sniper named Juba was terrorizing Baghdad with precise and methodical shots at allied troops, and it was all captured on film. A soldier in a turret falls in a puff of smoke. Another soldier standing along a road is shot in the head.

title: The Sound and the Fury
description: Q. Nearing 70, I have increasing difficulty hearing conversations, yet music in restaurants is too loud. Why?

title: Super Bowl Ads Recall Days Gone By
description: The ads CBS broadcast nationally represented a missed opportunity for marketers to show that they understood how modern consumers think and behave.

title: Bet on U.S. Pays Off for Germanys Carmakers
description: It was only a few years ago that some economists were arguing that Europe was decoupling from its long dependence on trade with the United States and predicting that the Continents future lay with the so-called tiger economies of Asia.

title: Gallup Conducts Review of Tracking Poll Methodology
description: After an election season in which it received significant criticism for the results of its Daily Tracking poll, Gallup announced last week that Michael Traugott, a polling expert from the University of Michigan, is helping the company review its election polling methods.

title: Focus on Hospitals July Effect
description: Some people believe that being admitted to a teaching hospital in July, when the new medical residents have just arrived, is a guarantee of poor care, and some research supports that view. But a new study suggests that fear of the July effect may be exaggerated.

title: Assad Can Avoid Trial by Leaving, Coalition Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias opposition coalition gave qualified backing on Monday to its leaders surprise offer last week for a dialogue with President Bashar al-Assad to end the civil war, pressing him to respond definitively and even offering the added inducement that he could avoid trial if he resigned and left the country.

title: Warning Too Late for Some Babies
description: Six weeks after Jack Mahoney was born prematurely on Feb. 3, 2011, the neonatal staff at WakeMed Hospital in Raleigh, N.C., noticed that his heart rate slowed slightly when he ate. They figured he was having difficulty feeding, and they added a thickener to help.

title: Turks Turn to DNA in Search for Staten Island Womans Killer
description: The authorities in Turkey have obtained a court order allowing them to take DNA samples from 21 people who have been questioned in the bludgeoning of a New York woman who was found dead in Istanbul over the weekend, according to Turkish news reports.

title: Bureaucracys Salaries Defended in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  Days ahead of a summit meeting where leaders of the European Unions 27 member states are to wrestle again with a proposed seven-year budget, a spokesman for the blocs executive body was forced to defend the salaries of some officials.

title: Really? Timing of Meals Affects Weight Loss
description: THE FACTS

title: Photo Replay: February 4
description: The day in sports includes a happy Super Bowl mom, high-flying performers at the world ski championships and a team time trial through the desert.

title: NBC Universal Puts Cable Units Under One Executive
description: NBCUniversal announced Monday that it was consolidating all of its cable entertainment properties under Bonnie Hammer, the longtime head of the USA network and other NBC cable channels. The move elevates Ms. Hammer to a position among the most prominent and powerful female executives in the television business.

title: Viewing the Nazis Through Their Childrens Eyes
description: One of the curiosities of the current Academy Award season is that Australia was competing in the best foreign-language film category with a German-language film. Cate Shortlands Lore, a drama about the waning days of World War II, did not pick up a nomination, but it has created a stir everywhere its been shown, winning audience awards at festivals on its way to opening in New York on Friday.

title: Finding Poetry in Cancer
description: When Kyle Potvin learned she had breast cancer at the age of 41, she tracked the details of her illness and treatment in a journal. But when it came to grappling with issues of mortality, fear and hope, she found that her best outlet was poetry.

title: Obama Presses for Gun Measures, Offering Up Minneapolis as a Model
description: MINNEAPOLIS  President Obama traveled to the nations heartland on Monday to press his case for tougher national gun laws, even as he appeared to acknowledge that expanded background checks on gun sales were far more likely to pass Congress than a ban on military-style assault weapons.

title: Driving Precautions
description: To the Editor:

title: Avoiding Everyday Hazards (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A $100,000 Prize for Yo-Yo Ma
description: Yo-Yo Ma, the popular and successful cellist who has already received several major cash awards, has won another: the $100,000 Vilcek Prize, given by the Vilcek Foundation. The foundation, which this year is recognizing achievements in contemporary music, also gave three $35,000 awards to three other musicians: the British-born songwriter James Abrahart, known as JHart; Samuel Bazawule, a Ghanaian producer and composer known as Blitz the Ambassador; and Tigran Hamasyan, an Armenian-born vocalist and pianist.

title: What I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of India Today
description: Tyler Cowen writes the One Sentence Book Review for The One Page Magazine, as well as a regular column for the Sunday business section.

title: Men Who Took Silicon to Silicon Valley
description: Silicon Valley is a deceptively grand title for the new American Experience documentary Tuesday night on PBS. Fairchild Semiconductor would be more accurate. It could even be called Robert Noyce or, with a musical score and some dance numbers, Noyce!

title: Venture Capitals Sluggish Performance
description: American venture capital needs a reboot. A decade of insufficient shrinkage hasnt fixed wimpy performance. At 6.1 percent annually over 10 years to September, according to Cambridge Associates and the National Venture Capital Association, V.C. fund returns undershoot boring stock indexes like the Nasdaq and the Russell 2000.

title: Steps Taken to Fill In Gender Gap
description: Eight dances by eight different dance makers  even for a sampler, thats a lot of dishes. In Working Women, which ended its run at the Joyce Theater on Sunday, what connects them is that the choreographers are all female. Thats hardly an uncommon distinction, but theres still enough bias in favor of putting men in charge that women can use a little special attention.

title: Ang Lee on Directing Life of Pi
description: The director explores how his roots in theater contributed to the making of Life of Pi, which received Oscar nominations for best picture and best director.

title: A Top-Tier Quarterback Set to Be Paid Like One
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: 4,500 Tons of Evidence of Strike in Seville
description: SEVILLE, Spain  Along one of the windy streets of Sevilles historic Santa Cruz neighborhood, Alfonso Jos Carnerero vila, a hotel employee, was enjoying a drink with colleagues and friends on the doorstep of a wine cellar on a recent day, trying hard to ignore the overflowing pile of trash nearby.

title: Rwandas Health Care Success Story
description: In the less than two decades since the 1994 genocide that killed nearly a million Rwandans and displaced another two million, the country has become a spectacular public health success story and could provide a model for the rest of Africa, according to a new analysis by American health experts.

title: Sri Lankan Leader Seems to Reject Greater Autonomy for Tamils
description: NEW DELHI  The president of Sri Lanka appeared to rule out greater political autonomy for the countrys Tamil ethnic minority on Monday, despite promising for years to support the idea in the wake of a bloody civil war.

title: Mayor Bloomberg Eulogizes Ed Koch
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered the eulogy for Edward I. Koch, the three-term New York City mayor who died at 88.

title: Obama Talks Gun Control in Minneapolis
description: With members of Congress looking pretty squishy on some aspects of gun control &#8212 like banning civilian ownership of weapons that are designed to kill as many people as possible in as short a time as possible while in combat  President Obama delivered his first big speech on the subject since he unveiled his own regulatory priorities.

title: Vain Glorious | Make Up For Ever Bus Tour
description: Make Up For Ever is sending its makeup artists on the road. The mobile Make Up School kicked off its tour on Friday, in Los Angeles, and will make eight more stops across the United States through April. The goal: teaching cosmetics enthusiasts how to use what products they already have (regardless of the brand), what to ditch (like that foundation that doesnt match your neck) and what to get. The price: a Like on Facebook. Each pupil will get 30 minutes with her own makeup artist, a professional photo of her after look and, for an additional $30, a limited-edition Remix Make Up Bag designed by Christina Ricci. To see the tour schedule and book a 30-minute appointment, go to makeupbagremix.com.

title: Winning a Losing Battle
description: Before we get to the story of how Jesse Schenker, a young chef in the West Village, managed to shed 55 pounds, let us consider what he consumed during a recent Monday night on the town.

title: Bill Clinton Speaks at Kochs Funeral
description: Former President Bill Clinton speaks at former Mayor Edward I. Kochs funeral.

title: Poll Finds Slight Decline in Cuomos Popularity After Gun Package
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo saw only a modest decline in his popularity among New York State voters after winning passage of strict new gun laws last month, and voters approve of the new laws more than two to one, according to a Siena College poll released Monday.

title: For One Monopoly Token, the Days Are Numbered
description: Despite the onslaught of high-tech games played on smartphones, tablets and giant flat-screen televisions, some old-fashioned board games played at a more methodical pace endure. Of those, perhaps the most popular is Monopoly, which was born 78 years ago.

title: Bad Pharma and a Look at Oscillation
description: BOOK

title: Seeking Offense and Depth, the Rangers Trade a Fighter
description: The Rangers traded Mike Rupp to the Minnesota Wild on Monday, exchanging one of their more frequent fighters for more depth at forward.

title: A Clash in Pennsylvania Over Fracking and Water Tests
description: A war of words has broken out between environmentalists and the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection over the cancellation of a meeting on the states testing of water from water wells near natural-gas drilling sites.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Cambodia, New York and Myanmar.

title: Treating Constipation in the Old
description: The incidence of chronic constipation increases with age, but its causes remain unknown, and recommendations for treatment vary widely. Now a review of 16 randomized controlled trials separates the treatments backed by scientific evidence from those that are not.

title: Pneumonia Strain Has Spread
description: Infection with Klebsiella pneumoniae is a serious danger to older hospitalized patients, with an estimated mortality rate as high as 40 percent. It has generally been treated with broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotics. Another class of antibiotics, carbapenems, is used as an antibiotic of last resort for the most persistent infections.

title: Staten Island Chuck: The Untold Story
description: The following note from Joyce Wadler, a former Times reporter, appeared mysteriously in our mailbox today. Attempts to confirm its truthiness were foiled when City Rooms fact-checking staff went out for crullers and never returned, so we are publishing it as is. Caveat lector.

title: Most Food Illnesses Come From Greens
description: Spoiled shellfish and unrefrigerated mayonnaise are notorious for causing digestive troubles, but the most common cause of food-borne illness is leafy vegetables like lettuce, according to a new study, and the most common cause of death is contaminated poultry.

title: A Tattoo to Help a Soldier Remember
description: A vampire couple who live in an Italian lemon grove, a pack of girls sent away by their werewolf parents to be educated by nuns, a minotaur and his human family joining the great westward American migration, a teenage girl whos dating a ghost, a group of Japanese women turned into silkworm slaves by a greedy silk merchant  many of the characters and predicaments depicted in Karen Russells fiction belong to that wondrous world of fable that first captivated us as children and that still retains a magnetic hold over many of our imaginations.

title: Tagg Romney Declines Senate Bid in Massachusetts
description: The possibility of a new Romney campaign was dashed on Monday evening when Mitt Romneys oldest son, Tagg, announced that he would not pursue John Kerrys now-vacant Senate seat in Massachusetts.

title: For the Oscar Nominees, Fake Fog and Air Kisses
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  If the Oscars are a horse race, then the annual nominee luncheon here is the paddock. With the qualifying rounds over and voting set to begin, the competitors are ritually assembled for a high-wattage gathering and a cordial glass of Champagne or two before the bell rings and the jockeying starts in earnest.

title: Gluten-Free, Whether You Need It or Not
description: Eat no wheat.

title: Never Mind the Parallels, Dont Read It as My Life
description: LOS ANGELES  Jamaica Kincaid, whose novel See Now Then is her first in 10 years and widely presumed to be autobiographical, wanted to set a few things straight. First, unlike the fictional Mr. Sweet of the novel, her former husband, Allen Shawn (also short and also a composer), never used an expression like off the banana boat to describe Ms. Kincaid, who is from Antigua. Nor did he compare her to Charles Laughton or create a nocturne called This Marriage Is Dead.

title: U.S. Military Suspends Ban on Afghan Airline
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American military on Monday lifted at least for now a recent decision to blacklist one of Afghanistans main airlines, Kam Air, on suspicion of drug smuggling, and it agreed to share details of its accusations with the Afghan government.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Super Bowl Tech, and Listening With Google Glass
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Sing Out to the Balcony? Oh, Wait, Its Just TV
description: The conventional wisdom about the first season of Smash, NBCs musical within a soap opera, was that it started on a high note it couldnt sustain. The pilot received overwhelmingly positive reviews, but by the last episode it was hard to find anyone who would say a kind word about the show. People were more likely to be tweeting about a misbegotten musical number or how much they hated Ellis, the personal assistant who filled the obligatory young Machiavellian schemer role in the style of All About Eve.

title: Republicans Versus Consumers
description: On Friday, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell sent a letter to President Obama, cosigned by 42 other Senators, insisting on structural changes to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau  a government agency created after the Great Recession to stop private mortgage lenders, money transfer agencies, credit card companies and the like from ruining ordinary Americans in pursuit of ever-higher profits. Unless those changes are made, Mr. McConnell said, the Senate by golly is not going to approve the appointment of a director.

title: The Players Are Many, the Effect Subdued
description: The title of the latest CD by the saxophonist Wayne Shorter, which will be released on Tuesday, is Without a Net. Its also an apt description for the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which has been playing symphonic music without a conductor for 40 years. On Friday evening they joined forces at Carnegie Hall, where they performed works that Mr. Shorter wrote and arranged for jazz quartet and chamber orchestra. The result, though virtuosic in part and often riveting, somehow fell short of the sum of its parts.

title: Avenue Capital Prepares New Fund for Europe
description: The Avenue Capital Group, the hedge fund run by Marc Lasry, is increasing its bet on Europe.

title: Into a Songs Mysterious Heart
description: Listening to Amanda McBroom perform her song The Rose at the Caf Carlyle on Wednesday evening, I pondered the notion that one persons art is another persons kitsch. It would be easy to dismiss this beloved inspirational ballad as a greeting-card homily. To me, however, The Rose is art: a miraculous burst of empathy that transcends clichs with its concentrated intensity of feeling as it searches for a definition of love.

title: An Asteroid, So to Speak, Lands Onstage
description: After conducting the Juilliard Orchestra in a vibrant performance of Mark-Anthony Turnages colorful Ceres, which received its New York premiere on Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall, Mark Wigglesworth turned to the audience and said that it used to be common practice to repeat a new work during a concert. So the ensemble played Ceres twice, offering a welcome chance to hear it again.

title: Familiar Hotel Signs Glow in Unfamiliar Places
description: I KNOW that travel is enriching and that locally managed hotels in exotic places can provide wonderful experiences.

title: Kicking Yourself for Missing That Wigman Tour Back in 30?
description: In 1930 Mary Wigman, one of the innovators of expressionist modern dance in Germany, toured the United States. In 1973 she died, and on Friday at the Museum of Modern Art she returned.

title: Stirring Music for a Stormy World: A Symphonic Bridge to Understanding
description: Beethovens Ninth Symphony culminates with the ultimate call for understanding and joy among all people, the just and unjust alike, to translate a crucial phrase from Schillers Ode to Joy, the text for the final choral movement. Schiller describes joy as a gift of divinity to mankind. But only those who know the joy of forming an abiding friendship or winning the love of a spouse, only those who can call at least one soul theirs, are truly able to join in this song of praise.

title: Untamed Instincts, but Traditional Roots
description: Last year, in the first season of the ABC drama Nashville, one of the main characters, Avery Barkley (Jonathan Jackson), wished intensely that his band might snag a slot opening for the acclaimed folk-pop dullards the Lumineers when they came to town. But on Nashville, even though the show was fiction, the details were real: his band didnt get the gig, because Lindi Ortega did.

title: Science News and Readers Views
description: You write, we listen.

title: New Albums by My Bloody Valentine, Josh Groban and Tim McGraw
description: MY BLOODY VALENTINE

title: Standoff in Alabama Ends in Boys Rescue and Kidnappers Death
description: MIDLAND CITY, Ala.  A six-day standoff between an angry and violent survivalist who held a 5-year-old boy hostage in an underground bunker and a legion of local, state and federal law enforcement officials ended on Monday with the death of the kidnapper and the freeing of the boy.

title: Troupe Is Said to Be Seeking New Leaders
description: Labyrinth Theater Company, which rose to prominence Off Broadway during the 2000s under the leadership of the actors Philip Seymour Hoffman and John Ortiz, has gone on to suffer a string of critical disappointments and is now searching to replace its current artistic directors, according to company members.

title: Museums Grapple With the Strings Attached to Gifts
description: For museums and other institutions confronted with the sometimes onerous restrictions that donors place on major gifts, forever can be a very long time.

title: In Performance: Will Chase
description: Will Chase puts a country spin on Both Sides of the Coin from the Broadway revival of The Mystery of Edwin Drood.

title: Cause Sought in Bus Crash That Killed 7 in California
description: LOS ANGELES  The mountain highway where a tour bus crashed Sunday night, killing at least seven people and injuring dozens more, remained closed Monday as investigators combed the roadway for evidence of what caused the bus to careen out of control.

title: Red Carpet: N.A.A.C.P. Awards
description: Kerry Washington and Jamie Foxx were among those honored at the N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards on Friday night.

title: Facebook to Tell Users They Are Being Tracked
description: Facebook has agreed to be transparent about, well, the obvious: You are being tracked so advertisers can better aim at you, and you can opt out if you make the effort.

title: Mental Tests Are Ordered for Cole Bombing Suspect
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  The military tribunal case stemming from the 2000 bombing of the American destroyer Cole bogged down on Monday when prosecutors asked for a mental health evaluation of the defendant, citing defense lawyers repeated assertions that he is suffering from post-traumatic stress because of torture by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Dell Nears a Buyout of More Than $23 Billion
description: Dell Inc. neared an agreement on Monday to sell itself to a group led by its founder and the investment firm Silver Lake for more than $23 billion, people briefed on the matter said, in what would be the biggest buyout since the financial crisis.

title: Egypt: Two Coptic Christians Sentenced for Stealing Weapons
description: A criminal court on Monday sentenced two Coptic Christians to three years in prison for stealing weapons from soldiers during a 2011 clash that left more than two dozen Copts dead. The clash took place on Oct. 9, 2011, when a group of Coptic Christians marched to the state television building to protest discrimination under the generals then ruling Egypt. Video of the episode showed soldiers who were guarding the building driving over protesters with armored vehicles and firing into the crowd. Twenty-seven people died, mostly Coptic Christians. The military has maintained that weapons were stolen from its soldiers and then fired at them and the protesters, causing the soldiers in the vehicles to panic. Last year, the army charged three soldiers who were said to have lost control of their vehicles with the wrongful killing of some of the protesters. But a military court acquitted them. Lawyers for the two Coptic Christians convicted Monday said they would appeal.

title: U.S. Defender Jumping In With Both Feet This Time
description: The United States national team will open the final round of World Cup qualifying on Wednesday in Honduras, and Timothy Chandler will be a significant addition to the teams backline. Once he enters the game, he will finally be an official American player.

title: Party-Line Voting Makes Scott Brown Part of a Dying Breed in the Senate
description: Scott P. Browns decision not to run in a special Senate race in Massachusetts is a blow to Republican hopes of reclaiming the Senate. Mr. Brown might have had a 50-50 chance of capturing the seat formerly held by Secretary of State John Kerry. But Republicans as popular as Mr. Brown are hard to come by in Massachusetts.

title: Hand of U.S. Is Seen in Halting Generals Rise in Mexico
description: As Mexicos military staged its annual Independence Day parade in September, spectators filled the main square of Mexico City to cheer on the armed forces. Nearly 2,000 miles away in Washington, American officials were also paying attention.

title: Microsoft and Huawei to Sell Windows Smartphones in Africa
description: BERLIN  Microsoft, taking aim at the worlds fastest-growing smartphone market, said on Monday that it would team up with Huawei of China to sell a low-cost Windows smartphone in Africa.

title: Lavonne Paire Davis, Baseball Pioneer, Dies at 88
description: Lavonne Paire Davis, a star in the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League of the 1940s and 1950s and a consultant for the hit movie A League of Their Own, died on Saturday in the Van Nuys section of Los Angeles. She was 88.

title: Violence Act Returns in Test of Republicans Appeal to Women
description: WASHINGTON  For all the attention on the Republican Partys efforts to attract Latinos, the first test for the party on 2012s lessons learned will arrive this week for a voting bloc that has drifted out of its grasp: women.

title: Lakers Are Again a Changed Team
description: The Los Angeles Lakers are returning to the New York stage, and its anyones guess what that portends: Dominance? Dysfunction? Brilliance? Petulance? All of the above? Some of the above?

title: Taxi, Bike or Boat?
description: Rolls-Royce, Segway or tuk tuk three-wheeled taxi? Hotels around the world are offering business travelers more ways to get to their meetings.

title: Debate Over Gun Control Is One-Sided in Idaho
description: BOISE, Idaho  Somewhere in America, supposedly, there is a debate about regulating guns. But it is hard to find here.

title: Mali Rebels, Now Aiding French, Say Theyre Holding Militants
description: PARIS  French warplanes bombed Islamist militant bases and depots deep into northern Mali to disrupt their supply routes, French officials said on Monday, as secular Tuareg rebels in northern Mali said they had captured two Islamist commanders near the Algerian border.

title: Seeking a Companys Elusive Sales Data
description: Prominent Wall Street investors are arguing acrimoniously over whether the nutritional supplements company Herbalife is a pyramid scheme.

title: How to Build a Country From Scratch
description: The filmmakers Florence Martin-Kessler and Anne Poiret present a 12-step program to establish the worlds newest country: South Sudan.

title: How to Build a Country From Scratch
description: In 2011, we embarked on the first of four trips to Juba, the soon-to-be capital of South Sudan. Our mission as filmmakers was to follow the state builders  those people in the South Sudanese government and in the United Nations who would be on the front line of implementing, step by step, a road map for the worlds newest state.

title: Billion-Dollar Ideas
description: A look at a few markets in the technology industry that are creating numerous billion-dollar companies.

title: A Billion-Dollar Club, and Not So Exclusive
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The number of privately held Silicon Valley start-ups that are worth more than $1 billion shocks even the executives running those companies.

title: Waiting Times at Ballot Boxes Draw Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON  With studies suggesting that long lines at the polls cost Democrats hundreds of thousands of votes in November, party leaders are beginning a push to make voting and voter registration easier, setting up a likely new conflict with Republicans over a deeply polarizing issue.

title: Europeans Await Report on Bus Blast in Bulgaria
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  A meeting of top government officials and security personnel of this small Balkan country on Tuesday could have wide-reaching repercussions for Europes uneasy dtente with the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah. Expectations are rising that Bulgarian officials will confirm a link between Hezbollah and the suicide bombing in July 2012 that killed five Israeli tourists and a Bulgarian bus driver and wounded dozens of others in Burgas on the Black Sea coast.

title: Bill to Squelch Convoluted Left Turns Gains in New Jersey Senate
description: It is the peculiar fate of the New Jersey driver, as indelible as a shoreside weekend or a Bruce Springsteen composition, if less easily romanticized.

title: A Convenient Morality
description: Last week, the Obama administration proposed a further tweak to its rules about insurance coverage of contraception, trying to quiet religious organizations complaints that the edict tramples on their beliefs. Roman Catholic officials have been especially vociferous. Their moral conviction, they insist, cannot be slave to secular convention.

title: The Philosophy of Data
description: If you asked me to describe the rising philosophy of the day, Id say it is data-ism. We now have the ability to gather huge amounts of data. This ability seems to carry with it certain cultural assumptions  that everything that can be measured should be measured; that data is a transparent and reliable lens that allows us to filter out emotionalism and ideology; that data will help us do remarkable things  like foretell the future.

title: A Burden of Care Over Seized Exotic Wildlife in Thailand
description: KHAO PRATUBCHANG, Thailand  Thailand wants to shed its image as a place where many types of wildlife  turtles from Madagascar, marmoset monkeys from South America, baby sun bears, exotic birds  are for sale, an international trade driven by the global market in exotic meats and rare pets.

title: Thailand Cracks Down on Animal Trafficking
description: The Thai government wants to shed its image as a place where many types of wildlife  turtles from Madagascar, marmoset monkeys from South America, baby sun bears, large exotic birds, to name a few  are for sale.

title: Academic Counseling Racket
description: On the day after the Super Bowl, I got a call from Michael McAdoo, a 22-year-old defensive lineman for the winning Baltimore Ravens. I had been expecting his call for several weeks, ever since the North Carolina Court of Appeals refused to revive his lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. and the University of North Carolina, where he had played for two years before being declared permanently ineligible. Though he didnt dress for the big game  hes been injured most of his short professional career  McAdoo had attended the teams practices and meetings; he told me hed been too busy to call earlier.

title: Them Bones
description: Perhaps the final ignominy in the troubled reign of Richard III is this: The monarchs bones have been found buried under a parking lot in the city of Leicester, England. The skeleton was discovered in September, its spine deformed in a manner consistent with contemporary descriptions of Richard, who died in 1485. Now, thanks to DNA taken from the skeleton and compared with Richards modern descendants, there is no doubt that this is the man who, in Shakespeares words, wore fortune buckled on his back. He was 32 when he died, and his death in battle ended the struggle for succession called the Wars of the Roses.

title: A Death Penalty Case in Puerto Rico
description: Puerto Rico abolished the death penalty in 1929 and, a generation later, made it unconstitutional. The islands Bill of Rights expressly decrees that the death penalty shall not exist there. But as a commonwealth of the United States, the island is subject to federal law, including the death penalty for many federal crimes.

title: Explaining, or Maybe Not, Failure in Talks With Teachers
description: Our mayor being true to himself, Michael R. Bloomberg journeyed to Albany last week to lecture state legislators on his decision to blow up negotiations with our teachers union and so lose $240 million for New York City schools.

title: Litmus Tests
description: One dispiriting lesson from Chuck Hagels nomination for defense secretary is the extent to which the political space for discussing Israel forthrightly is shrinking. Republicans focused on Israel more than anything during his confirmation hearing, but they werent seeking to understand his views. All they cared about was bullying him into a rigid position on Israel policy. Enforcing that kind of orthodoxy is not in either Americas or Israels interest.

title: Goal to Go
description: After being down 22 points, San Francisco began a furious comeback. With 2:39 left in the game and trailing by 5, the 49ers found themselves with first-and-goal from the 7. Four plays later, their Super Bowl dreams were dashed.

title: More Jobs, Higher Pay
description: In President Obamas first term, the fiscal stimulus and the auto-industry rescue of 2009 created and preserved millions of jobs. But the stimulus ended years ago, replaced with temporary measures that have been insufficient to propel the economy forward. Health care reform in 2010 was a major step in the effort to support the middle class, but its broad effects will be felt only in the years and decades to come.

title: Target Date Funds at Fidelity Fall Short of Rivals
description: Fidelity Investments is the giant of target date mutual funds, one of the hottest ideas in 401(k) plans.

title: Vote to Eliminate Ban on Gays in Boy Scouts Is on Agenda at Board Meeting
description: IRVING, Tex.  A proposed shift by the Boy Scouts of America to drop its national ban on gay leaders and scouts, and allow local scout units to decide for themselves, was the center of attention as the organizations national board gathered here on Monday for a three-day meeting and a vote on the issue.

title: For Raven, a Glorious Return (to Hometown and End Zone)
description: NEW ORLEANS  Just as Emily London-Jones stepped into her office at Xavier University on Monday morning, co-workers engulfed her in a way that the San Francisco 49ers could never seem to encircle her son, Jacoby.

title: A Postgame Follow-Up on Super Bowl Commercials
description: THE reactions to the advertising bowl that was played inside Super Bowl XLVII are offering a fascinating look at the dominant types of commercials  emotional and humorous  that Madison Avenue prefers for its big event.

title: Tech-Savvy Baruch College Students Seek an Edge in Registration
description: Wall Street companies use high-speed trading software to generate billions of dollars in profits. Fans of performers devise their own programs to help their favorite stars win online popularity contests.

title: Muzak, Background Music to Life, to Lose Its Name
description: For the word Muzak, the long elevator ride is finally over.

title: I.B.M. Slims Down Its Big Data Offerings
description: I.B.M. is cutting the price on its least-expensive Power server computers by 50 percent, to under $6,000. The pricing move is one of a series of hardware and software announcements on Tuesday intended as a strategic push more broadly into the fast-growing market for Big Data technology and to tailor offerings for smaller businesses.

title: Bookish, New Web Site, Provides Information on Books and Authors
description: Bookish, the Web site built by top publishers to provide information on their books and authors in a literary magazine-like format, opened for business Monday night.

title: Do Black Intellectuals Need to Talk About Race?
Sponsors for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Cats Indoors
description: To the Editor:

title: Nominee for S.E.C. Chief
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of Adderall Abuse and Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Generics and Patient Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Known for Crime and Poverty, but Working on Its Image
description: MARSEILLE, France  In a building here, down by the old port, immigrants from the colonies, most of them North African, were showered, deloused and examined before entry into France. A sort of French Ellis Island, the structure had been abandoned for 40 years and was nearly demolished in 2009. Now, it is being rehabilitated as a museum, for an exhibition opening on March 1 called Regards de Provence, Mediterranean Reflections  part of Marseilles celebration of itself as a European Capital of Culture for 2013.

title: For Lundqvist, Question Gets Old but Rivalry Doesnt
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Henrik Lundqvist has a talent for making the very difficult look easy, but Monday it was hard for him to hide the effort. Perhaps there was no way he could come up with the save on this one.

title: Immigration Hearings Set to Open in the House
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Representative Robert W. Goodlatte of Virginia, said on Monday that a series of hearings he will schedule in the coming months would examine different pieces of a possible overhaul of the immigration system, including proposals for a pathway to citizenship for 11 million illegal immigrants in the country.

title: A Final Farewell for Edward I. Koch
description: Past and present office-holders and other dignitaries attended funeral services for the former three-term New York mayor.

title: Heres Looking at You, Kid
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Im blogging this puzzle on Sunday, just as the Super Bowl is starting, but more importantly, as all the good food is being put out. Nevertheless, I will be here with you while the incredibly yummy chicken wings are being devoured, because that is the kind of deadline-busting service we provide here at Wordplay. Never let it be said that the copy editors and I dont make sacrifices for this blog.

title: Amid Criticism, College Says Event on Israel Can Proceed
description: Facing criticism for its decision to co-sponsor an event with speakers from an international group that advocates Israels withdrawal from disputed territories where Palestinians live, Brooklyn College indicated Monday that it still planned to do so  but would also host future events featuring opposing views.

title: How Long It Took Different Groups to Vote
description: The average length of time that different groups waited to vote in 2012, according to a survey of 10,200 people across the country.

title: An Unhappy Meal and an Aborted Business Trip
description: I WAS going to go into academics, but then decided to serve the marketing machine by going into public relations. A lot of my travel involves conferences, speaking engagements and, of course, pitching new business and meeting with existing clients.

title: Reporting for Duty, Kerry Pledges to Protect Diplomats
description: WASHINGTON  In his first day at the office as secretary of state on Monday, John Kerry sought to send the message that he had an affinity for the nations diplomats and would look after their security.

title: Los Angeles Archdiocese Is Accused of Failing to Release All Abuse Records
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles released 12,000 pages of internal files last Thursday on priests accused of sexually abusing children, saying that it was finally abiding by a settlement it signed with victims six years ago to make the painful history public.

title: New Idea for Penn Station Entails Relocating a College
description: In the early 1990s, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan proposed transforming the sprawling post office on Eighth Avenue, with its Corinthian columns, into a grand entryway to the busiest transit hub in North America, Pennsylvania Station. Since then, a succession of plans for what is to be known as Moynihan Station have surfaced with fanfare, only to sink later.

title: Sinopec to Raise $3.1 Billion in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, the state-owned oil and refining giant better known as Sinopec, is selling new shares worth up to 24 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $3.1 billion.

title: A Ritual Jewish Boundary Stirs Real Town Divisions
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, N.Y.  Every Saturday, Eugene Milanaik, a nurse anesthetist, walks more than five miles back and forth between his Orthodox synagogue and his weekend house on Dune Road. When it rains, he gets soaked, because he cannot carry an umbrella. When his 3-year-old grandson is in town, as he was last weekend, his wife must stay home, because she cannot push his stroller.

title: Lottery Numbers
Ex-Sniper Extended Hand to Troubled Marine Accused in His Death
description: LANCASTER, Tex.  On Saturday, when Chris Kyle, a retired Navy SEAL sniper, parked his truck outside Eddie Ray Rouths house in this Dallas suburb, the two men were virtual strangers. Their plan was to spend the afternoon at a remote shooting range, one of Mr. Kyles techniques for helping struggling veterans adjust to civilian life.

title: In Rebuilding, Alderson Puts the M-E-T in Methodical
description: The equipment van idled in the players parking lot at Citi Field on Monday, loaded with bats and balls and hopes and dreams, bound for Port St. Lucie, Fla. Sandy Alderson, the Mets general manager, will follow soon, with his golden retriever, Buddy, by his side. Alderson does not know precisely when he will leave because his daughter is due to deliver her third child this weekend. With the Mets these days, it is always about the kids.

title: Port Deal Pushed by Menendez Could Benefit Former Aide, Not Just a Major Donor
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  It turns out that the lucrative port security contract pushed by Senator Robert Menendez would enrich more than just a major benefactor.

title: McCain Opposes Filibuster Over Hagel
description: WASHINGTON  Several Republican senators  notably John McCain  said Monday they would oppose a filibuster of former Senator Chuck Hagels confirmation as secretary of defense, moving the nominee much closer toward approval.

title: In 2 Trailers, the Neighbors Nobody Wants
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.  Two trailers in this wealthy beach town stand as testament to an increasingly intractable problem for localities across the country: where to let sex offenders live after prison.

title: Behind the Competition
description: Fidelitys target-date retirement mutual funds have consistently been outperformed by its two main rivals.

title: Report Says 54 Countries Helped C.I.A. After 9/11
description: WASHINGTON  Some 54 countries helped facilitate the Central Intelligence Agencys secret detention, rendition and interrogation program in the years after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, according to a new human rights report that documents broad international involvement in the American campaign against Al Qaeda.

title: Arlene C. Ackerman, Superintendent, Dies at 66
description: Arlene C. Ackerman, who won national accolades for improving student performance as a schools superintendent in all three cities that hired her  Washington, San Francisco and Philadelphia  even as her bulldozer management style rankled union leaders and politicians, died on Saturday in Albuquerque. She was 66.

title: Bishop John DArcy, Who Sounded Alarm on Sex Abuse, Dies at 80
description: Bishop John DArcy, who was ignored by his superiors in the 1980s when he warned about priests who later figured in the sex-abuse scandal that rocked the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, died on Sunday at his home in Fort Wayne, Ind., where he had led the Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend for 24 years. He was 80.

title: Ohio: Governor Will Seek to Cover More Under Medicaid
description: Gov. John R. Kasich, a Republican, said he would seek to expand the Medicaid program in Ohio to cover several hundred thousand more adults with incomes up to 138 percent of the poverty level. Expanding the program is a central goal of President Obamas health care law, but the Supreme Court ruled last year that it was an option for states, not a requirement. The federal government is supposed to pay the entire cost of Medicaid for newly eligible beneficiaries from 2014 to 2016, and 90 percent or more in later years. Mr. Kasich said he would reverse his decision if the federal government did not cover its promised share.

title: 20 Rebounds for Chandler and Win for Knicks
description: Tyson Chandler and Steve Novak were unaware that Monday was the first anniversary of the start of Linsanity, which says quite a bit about the season the Knicks are having. This past summer, Chandler and Novak watched Jeremy Lin, their friend and teammate, leave the Knicks for the Houston Rockets.

title: Gas Buildup and Spark Blamed in Blast
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexicos attorney general said Monday that a buildup of gas ignited by a spark from a faulty electrical system had caused the explosion at the headquarters of Mexicos state-owned oil company, which killed at least 37 people last week.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Feb. 5
description: Its one of the most sacred rights you have. They should make it as painless as possible.

title: Word of the Day | saturnine
description: saturnine \sa-tr-nin\ adjective

title: Feeding a Disease With Fake Drugs
description: WASHINGTON

title: Memo Cites Legal Basis for Killing U.S. Citizens in Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration lawyers have asserted that it would be lawful to kill a United States citizen if an informed, high-level official of the government decided that the target was a ranking figure in Al Qaeda who posed an imminent threat of violent attack against the United States and if his capture was not feasible, according to a 16-page document made public on Monday.

title: Editors Note: February 5, 2013
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Five Questions for: Journalist and Author Mary Harper
description: Mary Harper, the Africa editor at the BBC World Service, is the author of Getting Somalia Wrong? Faith, War and Hope in a Shattered State, which was released in February 2012. While she is particularly interested in Somalia, which she visits regularly, Ms. Harper has reported from several other African conflict zones, including Algeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Sudan. India Ink interviewed Ms. Harper at the Jaipur Literature Festival.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 3 P.M. (TCM) CAMELOT (1967) Richard Harris stars as King Arthur; Vanessa Redgrave is Guenevere, his queen; and Franco Nero, above left with Harris and Ms. Redgrave, is Lancelot du Lac, her lover and her husbands best knight, in this adaptation of the Lerner and Loewe musical, directed by Joshua Logan and written by Alan Jay Lerner. It is hard to feel cozy with people you simply dont understand, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. If were supposed to regard theirs as a clandestine mnage--trois, which is likely to be suspected from the campy way Mr. Harris sometimes performs, it isnt developed sufficiently to make it daring or interesting. Nonetheless, the film won Oscars for best art direction, best costume design and best music.

title: Worse Than Poisoned Water: Dwindling Water, in Chinas North
description: BEIJING  When 39 tons of the toxic chemical aniline spilled from a factory in Changzhi in Chinas Shanxi province at the end of December, polluting drinking water for hundreds of thousands of people downstream along the Zhuozhang River and dangerously fouling the environment, it seemed a grave enough disaster. And it was.

title: News Quiz | February 5, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 5
description: NEWS Gen. Moiss Garca Ochoa was blocked from becoming defense minister of Mexico after American officials expressed their concern that he had ties to drug traffickers. Ginger Thompson reports from New York, Randal C. Archibold from Mexico City, and Eric Schmitt from Washington.

title: UBS Posts $2 Billion Loss Tied to Legal Settlements
description: LONDON  The Swiss bank UBS on Tuesday reported a large loss for the fourth quarter, driven by the costs of settling legal matters, including its role in a global rate-manipulation scandal.

title: Will All Be Forgiven for Timothy Chandler?
description: Brian Sciaretta, a regular contributor to the Goal blog, spoke with the German-American defender Timothy Chandler for an article that appeared in Tuesdays editions of The Times. Chandler, 22, has made only nine appearances for the United States national team, all in international friendlies, but by opting not to make more in the past two years he had become a source of frustration for American coaches and fans.

title: Barclays Sets Aside $1.6 Billion More for Legal Costs
description: 8:01 a.m. | Updated

title: British House of Commons Approves Gay Marriage
description: LONDON  The House of Commons voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to approve a bill legalizing same-sex marriage in Britain, indicating that the bill is assured of passage as it moves through further legislative stages.

title: Toyota Says It Expects a Big Gain in 2013 Sales
description: TOKYO  Lifted by strong sales in the United States and a weaker yen, Toyota Motor on Tuesday raised its profit forecast for the full financial year by 10 percent, to 860 billion yen, as the company, the worlds largest automaker, recorded a return to profit levels it has not seen in years.

title: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 5, 2013
description: The question was written by Jessica Lahey. It comes from the article That Cuddly Kitty Is Deadlier Than You Think

title: Bones of King Richard III Have Been Found
description: In the article Bones Under Parking Lot Belonged to Richard III, John F. Burns and Alan Cowell write about the discovery of King Richard IIIs bones.

title: Liberty Global Reaches Deal for Virgin Media
description: 8:07 p.m. | Updated

title: U.S. May Have Trouble Gauging North Korean Nuclear Test
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Even if North Korea follows through with its threat to conduct a third nuclear test, Washington and its allies will have difficulty determining whether the device detonated is made of plutonium or uranium, a prominent American nuclear scientist and South Korean officials said on Tuesday.

title: Money Changes Everything
description: Depending on when youre reading this column, economists have a pretty good guess as to what kind of mood youre in. If its Sunday, youre almost certainly happier than if youre catching it on a Monday. Either way, theres a good chance youre in a lousy mood if its 7 a.m. (Sorry!) Youll be happier around lunchtime, sadder at 2 p.m. but should perk up by 8 in the evening.

title: Is School Designed More for Girls Than Boys?
description: Girls tend to develop certain skills earlier than boys: for example, the ability to sit still and stay attentive. Our school day, more often than not, demands that students do just that  sit for long periods of time and listen attentively  or else suffer a lower grade or disciplinary action. Now, girls are outperforming boys at all levels of the educational ladder, from kindergarten to graduate school.

title: An X-Ray of Russian Corruption
description: Before James Watson, Francis Crick and Maurice Wilkins won the Nobel Prize for their discovery of DNAs double helix, Photo 51  an X-ray photograph  helped them identify the molecules complex structure. And just as photography made visible what scientists suspected, Misha Friedman is training his camera on what seems like a common trait in his national genetic code.

title: Ahmadinejads Ally Arrested as Fight With Political Family Grows
description: TEHRAN  Iranian judicial authorities arrested a protg of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Monday, the latest round in an escalating power struggle between Irans elected leader and the countrys most influential political family.

title: Muslim Girls Quit Rock Band After National Controversy
description: The three Muslim teenage girls, Aneeqa Khalid, Noma Nazir and Farah Deeba, just want to play rock and roll and heavy metal music.

description: WASHINGTON  Imagine driving from New York to Washington on one gallon of gas. It may sound far-fetched, but a 17-year-old took the challenge.
