title: Japan Says China Aimed Military Radar at Ship
description: TOKYO  Japan said Tuesday that a Chinese military vessel trained a radar used to help direct weapons last week on a Japanese naval vessel near disputed islands in the East China Sea. The Japanese Defense Ministry also said that a Chinese frigate directed the same kind of radar at one of Japans military helicopters in a previously undisclosed episode on Jan. 19.

title: Our Vision: Make Sales to End Sweatshops
description: There have been a lot of grim stories lately involving the manufacture of clothing.

title: Silicon Valleys Favorite Stories
description: Silicon Valley rose up en masse last year to trash the reality series Start-Ups: Silicon Valley, mostly for the sin of making it look as if just about anyone who was good-looking and self-confident could start an Internet company. If you were striving here to succeed or were covering those trying to succeed, wouldnt you want to believe that skill if not genius was required too?

title: Recapping Strategic Calls in Super Bowl
description: The Fifth Down contributor Chase Stuart analyzed many of the coaching calls in the Super Bowl, but first, as a Jets fan, he was forced to endure a flashback on the opening play by the 49ers:

title: Germany and Drones
description: BERLIN  When France launched a military intervention in Mali last month, Germany appeared to be in the familiar position of the bashful, gentle giant. No German combat troops would be sent to support their French comrades, Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle declared. Instead, the German government sent two cargo planes and promised the delivery of 50 flak jackets in the very near future.

title: Iran Nuclear Talks to Resume This Month
description: WASHINGTON  Breaking a deadlock over the location and timing of new talks on its disputed nuclear program, Iran has agreed to resume its stuttering dialogue with world powers later this month in Kazakhstan, Iranian and Western officials said on Tuesday.

title: Trafficked Through Thailand
description: The number of confiscated tigers continues to rise as Thailand, one of the worlds biggest hubs for illegal wildlife trafficking, cracks down.

title: A Deal for Dell
description: A deal for Dell is almost here. In what would be the biggest buyout since the financial crisis, Dell was close to an agreement to sell itself to a consortium of its founder, Microsoft and the private equity firm Silver Lake for more than $23 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced.

title: Irish Premiers Apology Fails to Appease Workhouse Survivors
description: DUBLIN  Advocates for survivors of a Roman Catholic workhouse system that kept generations of young women and girls in virtual slavery expressed disappointment and anger on Tuesday at Prime Minister Enda Kennys failure to formally apologize after a report found extensive state involvement in the institutions.

title: At Odds With the Government, Japans Central Bank Chief Offers an Early Exit
description: TOKYO  The governor of the Japanese central bank, Masaaki Shirakawa, said on Tuesday that he had offered to step down on March 19, three weeks before the end of his term, under intense government pressure on the bank to take bolder steps to resuscitate the deflationary economy.

description: From the editorial page

title: Trouble With Like
description: We continue our tour of After Deadlines favorite grammar gaffes. (In case you missed it, we already covered who vs. whom and agreement problems.) This week: the many misuses of like.

title: Walking Dead Man Walking: An Exit Interview With Glen Mazzara
description: On The Walking Dead, there are no guarantees which members of its still-living ensemble will stick around from one week to the next  and that goes for the creative team as well. Glen Mazzara, the show runner of this hit AMC survival-horror drama, is the latest to leave the show: after steering The Walking Dead through its second and third seasons, Mr. Mazzara, a former producer of The Shield, announced in December that he was parting ways with AMC and with The Walking Dead  having taken over the show from Frank Darabont, who developed it from the comic-book series and was deposed after its first season.

title: Tuesday Reading: Most Food Illnesses Come From Greens
BP Earnings Fall on Lower Production and Higher Costs
description: LONDON  BP on Tuesday reported a decline in fourth-quarter profit from a year earlier, a reflection of the asset sales the British oil giant has made in the wake of the Gulf of Mexico disaster that have left it a smaller company.

title: The Breakfast Meeting:  Super Bowl Ads Hewed to the Sentimental or Comical, and Muzak Faces the Music
description: Most of the 46 commercials that ran during Super Bowl XLVII were either emotional or humorous, Stuart Elliott writes in The Times. Comic actors like Tracy Morgan and Amy Poehler anchored irreverent spots for MiO Fit and Best Buy, and some of the memorable ads in a largely disappointing crop relied on sentimentality. For example, The Chrysler Group ran two tributes to veterans and American farmers to sell Jeep Cherokees and Dodge Rams. Other sponsors, like Anheuser-Busch InBev, used both approaches. An ad for Budweiser showed one Clydesdales reunion with the man who raised it, echoing a popular YouTube clip of a lion named Christian; and an ad for Bud Light featured Stevie Wonder as a voodoo king casting good luck spells for ardent football fans. Suzanne Vranica of The Wall Street Journal also covers the more successful Super Bowl ads.

title: Ted Cruzs Perfect Record
description: Ted Cruz of Texas has been in the Senate for all of a month, but has already compiled an impressive voting record, according to the Washington Times. He is the only senator who has been on the losing side of every vote he has taken this term, a zero-for-11 record.

title: Dell in $24 Billion Deal to Go Private
description: 9:22 p.m. | Updated

title: A Son Cuts, and a Father Struggles
description: To protect his familys privacy, the author of this essay has asked that his name be withheld, and because of the sensitive, but important, nature of the subject, Ive agreed. This is the first anonymous post since Ive taken over here at Motherlode, and I expect such contributions to be rare. Even when an issue is delicate, a writer who wants to be heard on a topic should be willing to speak publicly.

title: WWS 543, Class 2: The One Minute Trade Policy Theorist
description: Slides (pdf).

title: Daily Report: A Billion-Dollar Club, and Not So Exclusive
description: The number of privately held Silicon Valley start-ups that are worth more than $1 billion shocks even the executives running those companies, reports Quentin Hardy in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: Footballs Over. Now What Do We Watch?
description: While the Monday after the Super Bowl may be the day of the actual hangover  especially if you make a drinking game out of every time Phil Simms said something ludicrous on the CBS broadcast, and lets hope you dropped that idea by the opening kickoff to avoid needing medical attention  Tuesday is the day of the sports hangover.

title: Rendez-Vous With French Cinema Puts Focus on  Renoir
description: A score of films ranging from drama to comedy by established and rising talents, as well as a selection of work by and about Jean Renoir will make up the 18th edition of Rendez-Vous With French Cinema, a series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and Unifrance Films, an entity sponsored by the French government, the society announced Tuesday. The showings, scheduled to take place not only at Lincoln Center, but also at the IFC Center, BAMcinematek and the Paris Theater, will begin Feb. 28 and run through March 10.

title: About.me Buys Itself Back From AOL
description: Heres your next challenge as a founder of a start-up: Sell your company to a digital behemoth for tens of millions of dollars, then buy it backfor a fraction of the cost. Oh, and keep the change.

title: New Director Named for National Portrait Gallery
description: The National Portrait Gallery in Washington will have a new director on April 1: Kim Sajet (pronounced SAY-et), the current president and chief executive of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania. Ms. Sajet, who was born in Nigeria, raised in Australia and is a citizen of the Netherlands, will be responsible for a staff of 65, an annual budget of about $9 million, and 21,000 objects that include Gilbert Stuarts famous unfinished portrait of George Washington, photographs of Abraham Lincoln and videos of more recent presidents.

title: On Our Radar: A Research Station on Skis
description: To deal with shifting ice in the Antarctic, a British research station has extendable legs on giant skis so they can move in unison. [RTTNews]

title: What Were Reading
description: Japan Today: Is there really much difference between good-enough sushi and sublime sushi? The comments on this article about life as a sushi apprentice in Tokyo suggest that even to ask the question may be threatening to Japanese culture. Via Agence France-Presse.  Julia Moskin

title: The Japan Story
description: Dean Baker is annoyed at Robert Samuelson, not for the first time, and with reason. The idea of invoking Japan, of all places, to justify fears that stimulus leads to inflation or asset bubbles is just bizarre. And while there is much shaking of heads about Japanese debt, the ill-effects if any of that debt are by no means obvious.

title: Crash Injuries End Vonns Season, but Not Her Hopes
description: SCHLADMING, Austria  The Olympic champion Lindsey Vonn, whose record-breaking ski racing career has frequently mixed stirring triumph with frightening spills, tore two knee ligaments in a tumbling crash Tuesday and will need reconstructive surgery. Vonn fell in the super-G of the Alpine world championships, a race contested one year and two days before the scheduled start of the Sochi Olympics in Russia.

title: Bulgaria Implicates Hezbollah in July Attack on Israelis
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  The clues to a fatal bomb attack on Israeli vacationers in Bulgaria included a charred tour bus, a decapitated head and a fake drivers license.

title: The Army Behind Dells Big Deal
description: Huge leveraged buyouts dont happen all by themselves.

title: New Bridget Jones Novel Coming in November
description: It has been some 14 years since Bridget Jones last put pen to paper (or fingertips to a keyboard) to record her weight, her caloric intake and her shags in her celebrated diary. Now that celebrated, self-deprecating literary protagonist (and sometime alter ego of the author Helen Fielding) will return in her first novel since the publication of Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason.

title: Apple to Highlight Self-Published Books
description: Yet another sign that self-publishing is making inroads into the traditional houses: On Tuesday Apple will include a feature that organizes a group of popular self-published e-books together and then gives them prominent display on iBookstore.

title: Chinese Blogger Thrives as Muckraker
description: BEIJING  With his five cellphones constantly ringing, it is not easy these days to get the undivided attention of Zhu Ruifeng, a professed citizen journalist whose freelance campaign against graft has earned him pop-star acclaim and sent a chill through Chinese officialdom.

title: Ahmadinejad Visits Egypt, Signaling Realignment
description: CAIRO  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejads historic three-day trip to Egypt, the first in three decades by an Iranian leader, started pleasantly enough on Tuesday.

title: Companion of Delhi Gang Rape Victim Testifies in Court
description: The male friend who witnessed the fatal rape of a young woman by a group of attackers in New Delhi in December entered court in a wheelchair to testify on Tuesday.

title: Surplus Paint From the Brooklyn Bridge Now Could Be Yours
description: The Brooklyn Bridge may not be for sale, but surplus paint from the span is.

title: On Online Matchmaker for Tax Preparers and Clients
description: The traditional way to find a tax preparer is to ask your friends and family for a recommendation. But what if you dont want to go the word-of-mouth route  and risk ending up with your eccentric second cousin doing your taxes (or your ignorant but well-meaning friends idea of a good accountant)?

title: Reasons to Be Suspicious of Buyouts Led by Management
description: With the help of the private equity firm Silver Lake and Microsoft, Michael S. Dell, the founder and chief executive, is buying back his computer company.

title: Elizabeth Meriwether Answers Your New Girl Questions
description: Previously we heard from the creators of Modern Family, Homeland and Justified.

title: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday called on Congress to quickly pass a new package of limited spending cuts and tax increases to head off substantial across-the-board reductions to domestic and military spending set to begin on March 1, but his appeal for more revenue was dismissed by Republicans.

title: House Sister, Collector of Properties, Held in Chinese Graft Case
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese police said on Tuesday that they had detained Gong Aiai, popularly known as House Sister, in a corruption case that has gripped China for weeks after it was revealed that Ms. Gong and her family had accumulated dozens of houses and other properties. She was caught on Sunday, the police said, and is being held on suspicion of forging official identity papers and other documents she used in an effort to escape detection.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 5
A Rationale for Killing
description: A memo outlines the Obama administrations views on killing American citizens linked to Al Qaeda.

title: Celtics Find a Way Without Rondo
description: During Doc Riverss tenure, the Boston Celtics have made an amusing habit of heading into the All-Star break haggard and hobbled, only to work themselves back into playoff contention.

title: Capturing Modernisms Chic and Sheen
description: Ezra Stoller, the American architectural photographer, left behind a trove of modernist classics of modernist classics. Picture Eero Saarinens TWA Terminal, or Philip Johnsons Glass House, or the Manufacturers Trust building by Gordon Bunshaft, with its bank vault by Henry Dreyfus. Chances are youve got one of Stollers images in mind. Immaculate, self-effacing and with a mix of light and shadow revealing every angle and surface, his photographs stressed geometry, transparency, timelessness  like the buildings.

title: Architecture Photography by Ezra Stoller
description: Mr. Stollers pictures helped fix modern design in Americas consciousness.

title: Anna Karenina, Pi and Skyfall Win Art Director Awards
description: Members of the Art Directors Guild divide their choices for the years best production design over several categories. But even so, the winners, announced over the weekend, do overlap somewhat with the Oscar nominees.

title: The Gun Report: February 5, 2013
description: Need to call the National Rifle Association? You ought to try it just to hear the hold message. Thanks for calling the National Rifle Association, a soothing female voice intones. Due to the attacks on our Second Amendment, we are experiencing higher than usual wait time. The number, by the way, is 1-800-672-3888; choose option 2.

title: Exit Light, Enter Night
description: Last Wednesday the French government decreedthat as of July, all shops and offices in France must shut off their lights at night. The action is intended to reduce the print of artificial lighting on the nocturnal environment. Thierry Cohens portfolio Starry, Starry, Starry Night, which appeared in this past weekends magazine, shows us what major cities might look like if there were no light pollution.

title: S.&P. Calls Governments Suit Meritless
description: Standard & Poors Ratings Services defended its corporate practices on Tuesday, saying a civil lawsuit filed by the Justice Department that accuses the firm of inflating its ratings of mortgage investments was meritless.

description: Inside the new restaurant that is a winning blend of the refined and the unpretentious.

title: Nuance Meets Its Kentucky Roots
description: WHEN I HEARD that a new restaurant on West 26th Street had named itself after Maysville, the Kentucky town where Rosemary Clooney was born, I wondered why nobody had thought of this before. The singer had hopscotched her way across lyrics laden with enough food references to inspire a full menu.

title: Preparing for the Iditarod
description: A view of some of the two- and four-legged competitors getting ready for the Iditarod sled dog race next month in Alaska.

title: Top Judge Says Bail in New York Isnt Safe or Fair
description: Castigating the bail process in New York as unfair to the poor and susceptible to allowing dangerous suspects to be set free, the states top judge called on Tuesday for an overhaul of the bail system that would bring the state closer in line with the rest of the country.

title: In Performance: Will Chase of The Mystery of Edwin Drood
description: The Mystery of Edwin Drood, now in a Roundabout Theater revival on Broadway, is set in a Victorian music hall where actors are putting on a performance of Charles Dickenss last, unfinished novel. In this scene, Will Chase, who plays the actor Clive Paget (who portrays the villain John Jasper), puts a country twist on the number Both Sides of the Coin. The show continues through March 10 at Studio 54.

title: Most Facebook Users Have Taken a Break From the Site, Survey Finds
description: Facebook is the most popular social network in America  roughly two-thirds of adults in the country use it on a regular basis.

title: Study Slams Nuclear Waste Practices at Hanford
description: Management and disposal of radioactive waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State, marred by problems for more than two decades, is the focus of a harsh new assessment by the Government Accountability Office.

title: U.S. Accuses S.&P. of Fraud
description: The Justice Department accused the credit ratings agency of inflating its assessment of mortgage investments that spurred the 2008 financial crisis

title: Sax Inspiration in a Greek Epic
description: Since recording his first album just over 20 years ago, Chris Potter has earned his stature as the most commandingly skilled saxophonist of his generation, an improviser of deft insight and athletic poise. His high profile as a sideman in the studio with Steely Dan, and in bands led by the drummer Paul Motian, the bassist Dave Holland and, most recently, the guitarist Pat Metheny has sometimes overshadowed his output as a bandleader.

title: Americas Moral Volcano
description: For all the wealth of visual material made to document the Civil War  photographs, battlefield sketches  Americas landscape painters seemingly paid little attention to the wars events. Despite occupying a dominant position in the countrys culture at the time, they rarely depicted Civil War battlefields. But much lies beneath the literal surface: many of their paintings demonstrate a strong sense of the tension and turbulence of the times, conveyed by the skies and the terrain.

title: Warm Mushing Season
description: It has been an unusually warm winter in Alaska, and that has caused trouble for mushers and their sled dogs.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Fighting Poverty
Warm Weather Forces Changes Ahead of Iditarod Race
description: WILLOW, Alaska  By 9:30 most mornings here in the worlds unofficial dog-sledding capital, Luan Marques has harnessed 10 Alaskan huskies to his sled and shot off into the awakening woods for a training ride, his sights set on the famous Iditarod competition next month.

title: N.W.S.L. Keeps the Dream Alive
description: Many of us who were invested in Womens Professional Soccer rejoiced when the National Womens Soccer League was announced.

title: Hockey Night in Queens
description: Whether youre a hockey fan or not, you can grab dinner Wednesday evening at M. Wells Dinette, a cafeteria inside MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, while cheering for either the Montreal Canadiens or the Boston Bruins as they face off on the big screen. The dinette normally does not serve dinner, so why now? Hugue Dufour, the chef and co-owner of the restaurant, happens to be French Canadian, and the Bruins are to the Canadiens what the Red Sox are to the Yankees. The dinner, starting at 7 p.m., costs $60, and includes fried chicken, Philly cheesesteaks, pizza, fondue, poutine and more. Reservations can be made at mwellsreservations@gmail.com. Be sure to include contact information and the size of your party. The restaurant, at 22-25 Jackson Avenue, (718) 786-1800, has announced new hours: noon to 6 p.m. every day except Tuesdays and Wednesdays, when the museum is closed.

title: Common Application Releases New Essay Prompts
description: The new Common Application  which received some criticism a few months ago for removing the topic of your choice essay prompt  has released five new essay prompts for the 2013-14 admissions season, Inside Higher Ed reports.

title: Red Carpet: Academy Awards Luncheon
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences had a luncheon on Monday to honor this years Oscars nominees, including Jennifer Lawrence and Denzel Washington.

title: The Things Credit-Rating Analysts Say

title: Rivals Dont Mean to Rain on Dells Parade, but
description: Dell may be promoting its $24.4 billion leveraged buyout as the next step in its turnaround plan. But some of the computer makers rivals couldnt resist throwing a few jabs at the company all the same.

title: North Korean Propaganda Video Imagines a Brighter World, Without Manhattan
description: Last Updated, 3:52 p.m. When aliens strike, the climate goes berserk, the Russians invade, an asteroid threatens the Earth, New York City is often the first place to be destroyed. Hollywood has long used the citys skyline to demonstrate what destruction looks like in action movies and video games. It seems as if North Korea, in seeking to show how an assault on America would play out, also has Manhattan squarely in its cross hairs.

title: Spielberg and Affleck Get the Last Laughs
description: LOS ANGELES  What do you do as a follow-up to an introduction by Bill Clinton? At the Directors Guild Awards on Saturday, Steven Spielberg and the team from Lincoln called in a different kind of artillery in Martin Short.

title: And Spotifys Grammys Go To
description: On Sunday night, hundreds of artists and musicians will gather in Los Angeles, hoping to take home one of the most prestigious awards in music at the Grammy Awards.

title: Not Letting Anything Slide
description: Anything you can do I can do better. The Irving Berlin line pretty much sums up the mind-set of global cruise lines, which are offering such a staggering number of itineraries that they are forced to stand out by trumping one another.

title: Do Your Board Members Represent Your Interests?
description: Whenever small-business owners and entrepreneurs come to me looking for capital, I encourage them to think about the trade-offs involved in choosing debt or equity. Sometimes there is no choice, and they have to pick one or the other. But often there is a choice, and thats when its especially important to think things through.

title: China Issues Proposal to Narrow Income Gap
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government issued a long-awaited plan on Tuesday to narrow the gulf between rich and poor, offering broad vows to lift the incomes of workers and farmers and choke off corrupt wealth but few specific goals to rein in the nations wide inequality.

title: Dressing for the Bitter Cold, but Still Observing the Sabbath
description: Hasidim have hoodies too  though theirs are intended for winter Sabbaths.

description: A woman was hit by a truck in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday morning and died later from her injuries, according to the police.

title: Talking About Pucci in the Present Tense
description: For me, the real shocker wasnt that Beyonc lip-synced the national anthem at President Obamas inauguration (you were expecting maybe Maria Callas?), complete with dramatic shedding of unnecessary earphone. It was that the long-sleeved, boatnecked black gown she was wearing bore the label of Emilio Pucci.

title: Justice Department Faces Uphill Battle in Proving S.& P. Fraud
description: The Justice Department accused Standard & Poors of issuing faulty credit ratings on securities tied to mortgages. The 119-page civil complaint is chock-full of e-mails that paint a picture of shoddy practices and greed as S.& P. purportedly watered down its standards to generate more business.

title: Dont Let Iran Stall for Time
description: FEW of President Obamas original foreign policy goals have eluded him so much as engagement with Iran.Over the weekend, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced during a speech in Munich that the United States was ready for direct talks with Iran.With the risk of war over Irans nuclear program looming, the offer is prudent, but it is also beside the point.As Iran continues to evade negotiations  literally in this case, since the Iranian foreign minister was in the same building as Mr. Biden  the real question is not whether America should talk to Iran, but how to get the Iranians to talk to us in earnest.

description: The $24.4 billion buyout of Dell sets a number of private equity records.

description: MIAMI  A judge on Tuesday rebuffed George Zimmermans request for a five-month delay of his trial in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, saying it would begin as scheduled on June 10.

description: Submissions to City Rooms Kids Draw the News assignment on the school bus drivers strike in New York City.

description: WASHINGTON  The flaws in the American election system are deep and widespread, extending beyond isolated voting issues in a few locations and flaring up in states rich and poor, according to a major new study from the Pew Charitable Trusts.

title: 2 Pulled From Pond in Central Park After Falling Through Ice
description: Updated, 2:56 p.m. | Two people were rescued from the frigid water of the pond in Central Park after falling through the ice around 2 p.m. Tuesday, the Fire Department said. A firefighter in a wet suit entered the pond, in the southeast corner of the park near 59th Street and Fifth Avenue, and helped pull them to safety.

title: Cantor Speech Expands His Visibility and Party Vision
description: Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, seeking to soften the image of a Republican Party that has been focused almost exclusively on budget cutting, laid out an expansive social agenda on Tuesday for education, health care, job training and scientific research  what he called creating the conditions for health, happiness and prosperity.

title: Cuomo Acted Like Hitler in Gun Push, Official Says
description: ALBANY  A Republican state assemblyman unhappy with the way Gov.Andrew M. Cuomo pushed the Legislature to approve strict new gun laws said Tuesday that Hitler and Mussolini would have been proud of the governors actions.

description: Tuesday in science, sharks with an image problem, good teeth get more dates, dog geniuses and remembering your dreams. Check out these headlines and other science news from around the Web.

title: Quirks of the Game: The Other Calls That Altered the Course of the Super Bowl
description: In the final seconds of the Super Bowl, announcers, pundits and fans argued whether the lack of a pass interference call on San Franciscos frantic fourth-and-goal play changed N.F.L. history, although its likely a minority of people outside the Bay Area believed that and fewer still believed it was wise of 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh to whine about it at his news conference afterward.

title: France Arrests 4 It Says Planned to Aid or Join Militants
description: PARIS  The French police arrested four men on Tuesday who were suspected of seeking to aid or join Islamic militants in the African desert, while French air and ground forces continued operations against militants in northern Mali.

title: A Death Penalty Fight Comes Home
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Kirk Noble Bloodsworth, a beefy, crew-cut man whose blue T-shirt read Witness to Innocence, took the microphone in a church hall here and ran through his story of injustice and redemption one more time. Twenty years ago, he walked out of a Maryland prison, the first inmate in the nation to be sentenced to death and then exonerated by DNA.

title: State Debt Guarantees That Are Hidden Add to Worries in Europe
description: When it comes to euro zone hot spots, few international investors these days are likely to be losing sleep over Slovenia or Malta.

title: So Jennifer Lawrence and Sally Field Start a Car Pool
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The Oscar nominees luncheon is an annual occasion for surreal showbiz congratulations, and the far-reaching back-slapping doesnt stop there. A few hours after the luncheon and its attendant media blitz  when nominees do a round-robin of interviews by the pool at the Beverly Hilton here  there was another celebration of their talents at nearby Spago.

title: Plug-In Ecosystem Available at Indiana Mall
description: Electric car owners who visit the Clay Terrace mall in the Indianapolis suburb of Carmel can connect to a charging station that taps into energy from the sun. On Jan. 30, the mall cut the ribbon on a Plug-In Ecosystem that combines solar power, a large storage battery and both Level II and Level III chargers. For the time being, the electricity is free.

title: Kids Draw the News: Your School Bus Strike Drawings
description: The Last Assignment

title: A Pocket Speaker System Hits a New Low
description: For quite a while the FoxL from Soundmatters was the gold standard of pocket-size speakers for its unusual sound quality-to-size ratio. It pumped out mighty good sound for a speaker so small.

title: Mean Streets to Grub Street? Scorsese Films New York Reviews 50th Anniversary
description: Having captured the mean streets of Little Italy and the 19th-century gangs of New York, Martin Scorsese is currently aiming his cameras at a more high-brow Gotham subculture: The New York Review of Books.

title: Jim ONeill, Prominent Goldman Economist, to Retire
description: Jim ONeill, the economist who a decade ago coined the term BRICs  the acronym for the emerging growth economies in Brazil, Russia, India and China  plans to retire from Goldman Sachs Group later this year, the firm announced on Tuesday.

title: Problems at the Polls in 2008
description: States effectiveness varied in how they administered the 2008 presidential election, according to an analysis of several indicators by the Pew Charitable Trusts.

title: Babbitt Exhorts Obama to Protect Public Lands
description: Bruce Babbitt, the interior secretary in the Clinton administration and a former governor of Arizona, made one of his periodic forays out of the political wilderness on Tuesday to criticize the Obama administration for favoring oil and gas development over conservation on public lands.

title: New Problems in Syria: Hepatitis, Closed Hospitals, Ambulance Shortages
description: GENEVA  Outbreaks of hepatitis A and other diseases spread by poor hygiene are now becoming problems among Syrians displaced by the civil war, the World Health Organization said Tuesday. It is one of at least four United Nations agencies seeking to add a new sense of urgency to the humanitarian crisis afflicting the country.

title: Pub Grub With a Wink and a Smile
description: The doors going to be where the door is, Wylie Dufresne said last Thursday afternoon, standing in a space in the East Village that will soon become his new restaurant, Alder. Were not moving the door.

title: Are Immigrants Taking Your Job? A Primer
description: Immigration reform is back on the table, reviving debates about whether immigration is good or bad for American-born workers.

title: U.S. Contends S.& P. Purposely Used Faulty Models
description: 10:18 p.m. | Updated

title: Alec Soth Hits the Road
description: When it came time to assign a photographer to this past weekends cover story about the oil boom in North Dakota,Alec Soth was the obvious choice. He not only lives in the neighboring state of Minnesota, where he was born and raised, but he also has delivered strong covers for us in the past. He also is the type of photographer who loves wandering around with an open-ended assignment, capturing people in ordinary settings.

title: Donor, Citing Fraud, Sues Imam Tied to Mosque Near Ground Zero
description: The imam and former spiritual leader of an Islamic community center and mosque near ground zero is accused in a new lawsuit of defrauding donors to his nonprofit organizations of millions of dollars, using the money for personal real estate, lavish trips and a luxury sports car.

title: Dells Lonely Club Deal
description: Dells $24 billion leveraged buyout involves essentially a club of one. And Silver Lake Partners, the sole private equity firm included, is not even really the charter member.

title: His Twists and Turns, on Paper and in Life
description: J. G. Ballards extraordinary novel Crash (1973) is about a form of symphorophilia: car crash sexual fetishism. In The New York Times Book Review, D. Keith Mano didnt just review it; he reacted as if someone had thrown a severed head into his lap.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 5
description: A view of the day in sports, including sadness on the slopes at the Alpine world championships in Austria and happiness in the streets of Baltimore for Ravens fans.

title: Hops and Spirits Renew an Old Friendship
description: For years, the craft-beer and craft-distilling movements have toiled away at their parallel but separate efforts. Now the two have a shared enthusiasm to talk about.

title: Front Burner
description: In a weekly column, Florence Fabricant recommends things to read, taste, covet, order, cook, give and more.

title: Face Time | Ivanka Trump
description: Ivanka Trumps fragrance and body lotion, scented in a floral Oriental blend, are the newest additions to her self-named empire. In addition to playing creative director of her own collection, Ivanka also divides her time working for the Trump Organization, judging The Apprentice, and playing mom to her 18-month-old daughter Arabella alongside husband Jared Kushner. Here, she tells T about her inspirations, eco-friendly ways and beauty essentials.

title: Off the Menu
description: Preview Harlow

title: Prosecutors Ask Judge to Revoke Chris Browns Probation
description: A Los Angeles prosecutor told a judge on Tuesday there is no credible evidence that the singer Chris Brown completed the community service he was ordered to do as part of his sentence for assaulting Rihanna four years ago, The Associated Press reported.

title: Guest Post | Who Are You Online? Considering Issues of Web Identity
description: Wednesday (Feb. 6) is Digital Learning Day, an annual opportunity to contemplate the place of technology in the classroom and in our lives.

title: Georgian Sees Closer Ties With Russia
description: TBILISI, Georgia  As Russia took steps to resume imports of Georgian-produced wine and mineral water, Georgias new prime minister, the billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili, said Tuesday that he was making progress on one of his campaign promises  to repair the countrys badly frayed relationship with its huge neighbor.

title: Gluten-Free for Children With Sensitivities, and Without
description: Eat no wheat.

title: Zynga at a Crossroads in Mobile Quest
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Zynga has been on a monumental losing streak. Hits have been rare, profits nonexistent and crucial employees are fleeing.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Yemen, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Egypt.

title: If You Like Steppenwolf, Try the Black Keys
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Ahmadinejad Attacked With Shoe in Cairo
description: Last Updated, 5:44 p.m. Mahmoud Ahmadinejads visit to Cairo, which started with an affectionate welcome on Tuesday from Egypts new Islamist president, turned less pleasant as the day wore on. First, Mr. Ahmadinejad, the Iranian president, was lectured by a senior Sunni Muslim cleric and then was nearly struck with a shoe by a man furious at Irans support for the Syrian government.

title: The Spending Brownout
description: For misguided reasons of ideology and inertia, Congress seems determined to throw more than a million people out of work over the next two years. This is the price of the unnecessary spending brownout known as the sequester, and today the failure to stop it became even more inexcusable.

title: Profit Slides 6% at Disney as Movie and TV Divisions Lag
description: LOS ANGELES  Higher costs at ESPN and lower DVD sales resulted in a 6 percent decline in quarterly profit at Disney, the company said late Tuesday. But Disneys video game and Web unit finally swung to a profit and the conglomerate steered attention toward potential Star Wars growth.

title: Jets Finalize Coaching Staff
description: The Jets completed their staff overhaul Tuesday, announcing a group that includes seven new coaches and five others who will assume different responsibilities in 2013. Mike Devlin, formerly the tight ends coach, is now in charge of the offensive line, replacing Dave DeGuglielmo. Steve Hagen, formerly the Cleveland Browns tight ends coach, takes over for Devlin.

title: Hillary 2013 Gives Way to Hillary 2016
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Clinton woke up today with no place to go  at least in an official capacity.

title: A Three-Way Game of Musical Teasing
description: Ian Bostridge and Angelika Kirchschlager sang beautifully on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall. So much for the obvious. Both singers are big names who rarely appear on opera stages this side of the Atlantic, and the reputations of their voices  Mr. Bostridges cleareyed tenor, Ms. Kirchschlagers richly hued mezzo  would have been sufficient to draw a capacity crowd to their recital of Hugo Wolf songs, presented as part of Lincoln Centers Great Performers series.

title: Peeling Through Layers, With Drums and High Kicks
description: Na pas un gramme de charisme is a worthy title for Claude Wamplers new show: it translates, roughly, as Hasnt an ounce of charisma. Ms. Wampler is not alone in this creation, which I saw at the Kitchen last weekend; it was made in collaboration with Amelia Saul (who performs), John Tremblay (who designed the set) and Antonius Wiriadjaja (the wizard behind its use of visual technology). During the course of more than 36 years of intensive theatergoing, I must have seen drearier shows, but they do not stay in the memory, and it is likely that this too will pass into the oblivion it so richly deserves.

title: University Revokes German Officials Doctorate
description: BERLIN  A German university has moved to strip the countrys education minister of her academic title after ruling that she plagiarized parts of her doctoral dissertation some 30 years ago.

title: Red Bulls Wheeling and (Still) Dealing
description: Kenny Cooper will never be mistaken for Lionel Messi (too tall) and Dax McCarty will never be mistaken for Frank Lampard (too short).

title: My Head Talks At Business Insider
description: Not much blogging today or probably tomorrow  course prep! But I talked to Business Insider, last week, and you can watch my head discourse on the US economy, technology and inequality, Japan, and the deficit.

title: Friends, Romans, Countrymen, All Brought to Life by Inmates
description: Its easy to imagine that the performers in Caesar Must Die, a riff on Shakespeares Julius Caesar, are cut from coarser, more authentic material than that found in most productions. The movie, after all, is set in an Italian prison and cast almost entirely with real inmates. The prisoners rough faces and darting eyes, the crooked arc of one mans nose and the unnervingly sly line of anothers smile, suggest so much (murder most foul, to borrow a line), as do the occasional shivery biographical asides, particularly about the mafia, that jostle alongside the plays poetry. These men, surely, know about betrayal, vengeance and power, a knife in the gut and hands washed in blood.

title: Trayvon Martins Birthday Remembered Online
description: As my colleague Lizette Alvarez reports, a Florida judge denied a request by George Zimmermans lawyer to delay his June 10 trial in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin.

title: Chocolate Caramels Worthy of Your Sweetheart
description: More and more of the countrys finest artisanal chocolate markers are producing caramels. So which ones should you give your Valentine?

title: The Best in the Box
description: With Valentines Day nigh, the lure of the heart-shaped bonbons box pulls hard. Maybe youre thinking of buying your sweetheart a box of retro buttercreams, or sophisticated (but, yawn, predictable) ganache truffles? Or perhaps a selection of artisanal, austerely bitter, single-origin chocolate bars?

title: Playing With Passion for a Patron
description: Luminaries of the contemporary classical-music world, from New York and points beyond, gathered at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening to remember one of their own. Ralph Kaminsky, who died in January 2012 at 85, was not a performer, composer or arts executive but a music lover with a passion for discovery and a benefactor whose quiet generosity bolstered his community.

title: Pentagon to Extend Certain Benefits to Same-Sex Partners
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is preparing to expand benefits to same-sex partners of military personnel, but it remained doubtful that the Pentagon could offer the medical, dental and housing allowances desired by gay and lesbian couples, officials said Tuesday.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: A Social Creative Network, and a Bit of Hacking History
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: With Chocolate, Go for a Fortified Wine
description: The Dining section sampled 27 candies to find the best American small-batch, handmade chocolate-covered salted caramels, just in time for Valentines Day. Here are some thoughts on what to drink with them; share your suggestions in the comments section below.

title: In/Out: New Hope for Massachusetts G.O.P.
description: BOSTON  With just over three weeks to go before candidates need to submit 10,000 signatures to the state, the special election for Senate in Massachusetts is still waiting for its first major Republican contender after several of the partys prominent members declined to make a run. On Tuesday morning, one such candidate took a step toward getting in.

title: Release of 13 Episodes Redefines Spoiler Alert
description: This article about House of Cards contains no spoilers.

title: At This Marathon, No Running Shoes Are Required
description: No concert, however epic in duration, could encompass the entirety of the contemporary classical world, which has grown too broad and variegated to sample in one sitting. But as a microcosm of the teeming activity that falls under the broad umbrella of the new-music rubric, the Music of Now Marathon, a recently instituted annual event at Symphony Space, does nicely. Programmed by Laura Kaminsky, a composer and Symphony Spaces artistic director, the marathon is the opening event in Composers Now, a monthlong series organized by Tania Len, which includes dozens of concerts throughout the city.

title: Wild, Wired, Remembered
description: When a jittery Richard Pryor emerges from underneath a desk in Uptown Saturday Night, playing a black private eye who is not a sex machine to anybody, a jolt of adrenaline shoots into this sluggish comedy that keeps it wired long after hes gone.

title: Ouster Sharpens Debate on the Sage Grouse
description: The ouster of a Nevada wildlife official has fanned a debate over whether the sage grouse can best be kept off the Endangered Species List by protecting its habitat or by killing more of its predators.

title: A Guide to Spying on Cisco Phone Calls
description: 7:35 p.m. | Updated to remove an erroneous reference to a Java security flaw.

title: In Propaganda Video, Only North Korea Sleeps Easy
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea is not known for its subtlety, famous instead for its soaring patriotic rhetoric and threats to turn the capital of its rival, South Korea, into a sea of fire.

title: Lackluster Start for BlackBerrys New Phone in Canada
description: 4:27 p.m. | Updated Added comment from company on success of the BlackBerry inroduction in Canada and Great Britain.

title: Corporate Forces Endangered the Twinkie, but May Save It
description: Snack cake aficionados rejoice, the Twinkie will live.

title: Restaurant Loses Effort to Have Ex-Delivery Workers Suit Dismissed
description: A lawsuit brought by former delivery workers against an Upper West Side restaurant that deducted money from their tips to pay the service fees of food-delivery Web sites can proceed, a federal judge has ruled.

title: Night Watch
description: Alzheimers and dementia patients at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale receive much-needed stimulation and a chance to socialize.

title: Muslims Find a Voice
description: Arab-Muslims in Brooklyn are finding power in the voting booth.

title: Waste Not
description: The artist Song Dong has turned the contents of his mothers former home in Beijing into an installation at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: City as Frame
description: The art of the Biennale as part of Venices noble architecture.

title: Photographs From Final Salute
description: Excerpts from a Pulitzer Prize-winning series about fallen military personnel that originally appeared in The Rocky Mountain News.

title: In New Orleans, Vivid Flavors of Vietnam
description: Hawking her ya-ka-mein soup at a recent New Orleans concert, Linda Green went through her basic sales pitch: its beef and noodles. Its a local secret, she told me. Its an African-American tradition. But then came an odd clincher.

title: Bryant Says Stars Must Take Active Role in Union Matters
description: Creating a healthier, more functional N.B.A. players union will require deeper involvement from its members, but especially from its most famous members, according to perhaps the most famous member of all.

title: Twitter Buys Company That Mines Chatter About TV
description: Twitter confirmed on Tuesday that it was acquiring Bluefin Labs, a company that analyzes online chatter about TV shows and companies and sells its findings.

title: U.S. Soccer Gets Down and Digital
description: One day before the United States national team plays at Honduras in its opening match of the final round of regional World Cup qualifying, U.S. Soccer released some digital goodies for fans  apps for smartphones and tablets, and a Facebook app.

title: Harlems 125th Street Attracts Big Retailers
description: The recession slowed commercial real estate development everywhere, but it was particularly hard on Harlem, which had only recently begun to attract national retailers after decades of disinvestment. A number of projects had to be shelved when the financial markets dried up.

title: People With Mental Illness More Likely to Be Smokers, Study Finds
description: People with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness, two federal health agencies reported Tuesday.

title: Security Pioneer Creates Service to Encrypt Phone Calls and Text Messages
description: SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO Attention, Snapchat:You have some very serious competition.

title: California: Detectives Examining Church Documents
description: The Los Angeles Police Department is examining thousands of pages of newly released church files detailing decades of sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests to determine if any new criminal charges could be brought, officials said Tuesday. Much of the focus will be looking for new information on priests who were previously investigated, the police said. But detectives will also try to determine if there is any evidence of criminal activity by top church officials, like failure to report abuse to law enforcement. It is unclear how many of the cases are within the statute of limitations, said Cmdr. Andrew Smith, a spokesman for the Police Department. Clergy members were not legally required to report child abuse until 1997. Last week, facing a court order, the Los Angeles Archdiocese released the files on 122 priests accused of sexually abusing children as part of a record $660 million settlement.

title: Carnegie Mellon Chooses a New President
description: Subra Suresh, the director of the National Science Foundation, has been chosen as the next president of Carnegie Mellon University and will assume the post on July 1. At the foundation, Dr. Suresh, a materials engineer, was the host of a Global Summit on Scientific Merit Review. The meeting brought together, for the first time, the heads of leading science financing agencies from nearly 50 countries and led to the creation of the Global Research Council, a vehicle for multinational collaborations. Dr. Suresh, 56, who has been on leave from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology since joining the foundation in 2010, earned his bachelors degree in his native India at the Indian Institute of Technology Madras and his doctorate at M.I.T. He is the co-author of more than 240 journal articles, has registered 21 patents and has written three widely used materials science books.

title: U.S. to Release First Installment of $51 Billion in Hurricane Sandy Aid
description: Federal officials plan on Wednesday to release the first installment of a nearly $51 billion emergency aid package to help millions of victims of Hurricane Sandy in the Northeast.

title: Liverpool Game Is Part of Match-Fixing Investigation
description: After a European police agency revealed that its investigation into widespread fixing of soccer matches included a Champions League game played in England in the past few years, fans and news media members paged through old results to try to guess which game was tainted. Did it involve Manchester United? Manchester City? Chelsea?

title: NBCs Broadcasts of 2014 Winter Games Will Begin a Day Early
description: NBC Universals love of the Olympics is well known. It has carried all the Winter and Summer Games since 2000.

title: Art Auctions Here and Abroad
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico: Six Tourists Are Raped in Home Invasion Near Acapulco
description: Five armed and masked men broke into a beach house near the port of Acapulco and raped six Spanish tourists, the authorities said. Eight other people in the same group, which included a Mexican woman who was not attacked, were bound during the assault, which began at 2 a.m. Monday. The citys mayor, Luis Walton Aburto, acknowledged that the episode would affect the image of Acapulco, which officials have been trying to rehabilitate after years of skyrocketing cartel-related violence. But Mr. Aburto also played down the attack, saying such things happen all over the world. Shortly after, he issued an apology for his comments and offered to increase security in the city.

title: Remembering a Pioneer in Fields Far Beyond His Sport
description: Twenty years ago, on Feb. 6, 1993, Arthur Ashe died of complications from AIDS at age 49. He was my best friend and client for 23 years, and his death continues to touch me, almost daily.

title: Bipartisan House Plan Focuses on Gun Trafficking
description: WASHINGTON  Members of both parties in the House outlined a plan on Tuesday to stiffen penalties on the illegal purchase and transportation of guns, a rare show of agreement on an issue where bipartisanship has been scarce.

title: Health Insurance Companies Get in Shape for 2014
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Since Patrick J. Geraghty arrived here a year and a half ago to lead the states largest health insurer, Florida Blue, he has expanded its operations in Medicare and Medicaid, entered arrangements with hospitals and doctors, bought a medical group, and dabbled with a new private sector marketplace that allows employees to choose plans from different insurance companies.

title: The Global Farmland Rush
description: WASHINGTON

title: Indias Speech Impediments
description: INDIA is in the throes of what Salman Rushdie rightly calls a cultural emergency. Writers and artists of all kinds are being harassed, sued and arrested for what they say or write or create. The government either stands by and does nothing to protect freedom of speech, or it actively abets its suppression.

title: India vs. China vs. Egypt
description: NEW DELHI

title: Mr. Cuomos Sandy Plan
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York wants to spend as much as $400 million to buy and raze damaged homes in the floodplains of New York State. These properties, victims of Hurricane Sandy, would then be turned into parks, bird sanctuaries, dunes or simply stretches of open beach, serving as buffer zones to protect residents inland from future floods.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Lets Others Keep Danger at Bay
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras  Near the start of an afternoon news conference inside a hotel ballroom here on Tuesday, a member of the local news media prefaced his question to Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States soccer team, with a greeting.

title: Essie Mae Washington-Williams, Child of Famous but Secret Father, Dies at 87
description: Essie Mae Washington-Williams, who lived for decades with a stunning secret  that she was the interracial daughter of Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, a former segregationist who never acknowledged her publicly as his child  died Monday in a nursing home near Columbia, S.C. She was 87.

title: Colorado Gun Control Proposals Face Fight
description: DENVER  Democratic lawmakers in Colorado, a state haunted by two of the worst mass shootings in American history, unveiled a broad package of gun-control measures on Tuesday, but they stopped short of proposing a ban on assault rifles or any other types of firearms.

title: Study Looks at Particles Used in Food
description: Nanomaterials, substances broken down by technology into molecule-size particles, are starting to enter the food chain through well-known food products and their packaging, but there is little acknowledgment by the companies using them, according to a new report from a nonprofit group that works to enhance corporate accountability.

title: One-Third the Man He Used to Be, and Proud of It
description: IPSWICH, England  Who knows what the worst moment was for Paul Mason  there were so many awful milestones, as he grew fatter and fatter  but a good bet might be when he became too vast to leave his room. To get him to the hospital for a hernia operation, the local fire department had to knock down a wall and extricate him with a forklift.

title: Immigration Reform Issue: The Effect on the Budget
description: The stars could hardly have shone brighter on the prospects for immigration reform than in the early months of 2007.

title: Cal Mens Golf Team Plays and Pays Own Way to Top
description: TUCSON  The spring semester started at the University of California the week before the Arizona Intercollegiate, which presented a problem for two of the top players on the Bears No. 1-ranked mens golf team.

title: When Can the U.S. Kill One of Its Own?
Debevoise & Plimpton Drops Trusts and Estates Practice
description: Last month, the nations leading trusts and estates lawyers convened at a Florida resort to discuss the latest in estate planning.

title: Standard & Poors Stands Accused
description: The financial crisis could never have happened without the credit-ratings agencies issuing stellar ratings on toxic mortgage securities that inflated the bubble. Before the Justice Department filed civil fraud charges this week against Standard & Poors, the nations largest credit-ratings agency, it seemed as if the entire ratings industry  which reaped record profits in the boom years  was going to escape, unrepentant and unpunished. That may now change.

title: To Kill an American
description: On one level, there were not too many surprises in the newly disclosed white paper offering a legal reasoning behind the claim that President Obama has the power to order the killing of American citizens who are believed to be part of Al Qaeda. We knew Mr. Obama and his lawyers believed he has that power under the Constitution and federal law. We also knew that he utterly rejects the idea that Congress or the courts have any right to review such a decision in advance, or even after the fact.

title: Drone Strikes Risks to Get Rare Moment in the Public Eye
description: SANA, Yemen  Late last August, a 40-year-old cleric named Salem Ahmed bin Ali Jaber stood up to deliver a speech denouncing Al Qaeda in a village mosque in far eastern Yemen.

title: Nutrition Bar Aims to Debunk Diet Myths, With a Smile
description: IN a coming episode of Debunking the Diet, a new Web series produced by Luna, the nutrition bar for women, the comedian Erin Gibson quizzes women on the street about how much fiber they are supposed to have daily.

title: The Star Who Dwells on Wherever He Isnt
description: Had he stuck to his original plan, been resolute, Dwight Howard  and not Brook Lopez  would have been the tallest lord of Flatbush on Tuesday night. He would have spent the first half of this N.B.A. season rising with the Nets in the less competitive East instead of falling with the Lakers in the merciless West.

title: With a Super Bowl Ad, Scientology Gets a Crowd
description: After several months of mounting accusations over the treatment of its members, the Church of Scientology on Sunday tried to spread a softer, gentler message using the biggest advertising event in the country: the Super Bowl.

title: School Plans Its 17th Move, but Its First Since 1892
description: After debating nearly seven years about where to move, the board of the Collegiate School, New York Citys oldest and one of its most prestigious private schools, announced Tuesday that it had purchased land for a new building between West 61st and 62nd Streets and between West End Avenue and Riverside Boulevard.

title: The Cosmetics Wars
description: If all goes according to schedule, next month the European Union will become cruelty-free, banning without exception the sale of cosmetics ingredients that were tested on animals.

title: Sign Up Scarlett or Al. Well Do a Show (a Broadway Revival).
description: Scarlett Johansson knew there had been other Broadway revivals of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof recently, in 2008 and in 2003, but so what? She wanted to play Tennessee Williamss famed Maggie the Cat on Broadway. Her only worry about timing, she recalled, was a tight window between wrapping movies in 2012 and filming a Captain America sequel in 2013.

title: A Partnership Seeks to Transform Kent State and Kent
description: KENT, Ohio  Though it is home to the second largest campus in Ohios state university system by enrollment, this small Cuyahoga River city spent much of the last four decades neglecting, if not deliberately retreating from, its history as a college town and its place in the annals of the Vietnam War era.

title: Small Town Wins Its Standoff With a Kidnapper
description: MIDLAND CITY, Ala.  In the front seat of Bus 04-02 sat a boy named Ethan.

title: Bringing Back History and a Neighborhood
description: CLEVELAND  The grassy field at East 66th Street and Lexington Avenue in this citys Hough neighborhood has a rich baseball past.

title: Report on Targeted Killing Whets Appetite for Less Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON  Early in his first term, President Obama rejected the vehement protests of the Central Intelligence Agency and ordered the public disclosure of secret Justice Department legal opinions on interrogation and torture that had been written in the administration of George W. Bush.

title: Cairo Activist Fighting Tear Gas With Tear Gas
description: CAIRO  As hundreds fled the advancing armored cars of riot police officers, Mohamed Mokbel ran forward.

title: Pete Flint
description: Mr. Flint, 38, is chief executive of Trulia, a real estate Web site he founded in 2005 with Sami Inkinen while they were graduate students at Stanford University. The company, which is based in San Francisco, has more than 3.5 million residential sales listings nationwide.

title: Knicks Chandler on Cusp of a Team Rebound Mark
description: Willis Reed, one of the Knicks greatest players, is best known in New York for being the captain of a team that won two championships. Not many people know that he is the only Knick to twice grab at least 20 rebounds in three consecutive games, both times in the late 1960s.

title: Fewer Are Sentenced to Die
description: Death sentences have dropped to the lowest levels since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976. The number of states abolishing the death penalty has also increased in recent years.

title: Firm Denies Deception in Big Check Tied to Iran
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  When German customs agents at the Dsseldorf airport found a check for the equivalent of nearly $70 million in Venezuelan currency in the carry-on bag of a former Iranian economy minister last month, it seemed like the elements of an international thriller.

title: Result of Not Following Through
description: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! Pete Muller is starting up his Muller Monthly Music Meta (or MMMM. No, Im not kidding.) This year, a new mega-meta will be included in the contest, which solvers can guess at any time. Click here to be part of the fun.

title: Revival Is Planned for a Derelict Downtown Newark Park

title: Getting Into Your Exercise Groove
description: This isnt meant as an insult, but you are physiologically lazy. So am I. So are we all. Using treadmill testing, scientists have definitively established that, like other animals, humans naturally aim to use as little energy as possible during most movement. So when we walk or run, our bodies tend to choose a particular cadence, a combination of step length and step frequency, that allows us to move at any given speed with as little physiological effort as possible.

description: How genetics may influence childrens calm under pressure.

title: Why Can Some Kids Handle Pressure While Others Fall Apart?
description: Noah Muthler took his first state standardized test in third grade at the Spring Cove Elementary School in Roaring Spring, Pa. It was a miserable experience, said his mother, Kathleen Muthler. He was a good student in a program for gifted children. But, Muthler said, he was crying in my arms the night before the test, saying: Im not ready, Mom. They didnt teach us everything that will be on the test.  In fourth grade, he was upset the whole week before the exam. He manifests it physically, his mother said. He got headaches and stomachaches. He would ask not to go to school. Not a good sleeper anyway, Noah would slip downstairs after an hour tossing in bed and ask his mom to lie down with him until he fell asleep. In fifth grade, the anxiety lasted a solid month before the test. Even after the test, he couldnt let it go. He would wonder about questions he feared he misunderstood, Muthler said.

title: Peeking Into the Sex Lives of Endangered Turtles
description: Studying any animal in the wild is hard enough, let alone one that spends 30 years at a time out at sea. Because of its ocean-faring lifestyle, scientists know next to nothing about the life style of the critically endangered hawksbill sea turtle, save for the fleeting observations they make when female turtles come to beaches to lay their eggs.

description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Last week some inhabitants of the Palestinian village of Burin, near Nablus, set up a small and peaceful protest camp on private land in an attempt to protect the village from encroaching Jewish settlers. On Saturday, the Israeli Army evicted the Palestinians. According to one report, the settlers uprooted nearly 100 olive trees, a 16-year-old Palestinian was wounded, 20 people suffered tear gas inhalation, and a mosque was set on fire.

title: Documents in S.& P. Case Show Alarm
description: Documents included in the Justice Departments lawsuit against Standard & Poors provide a glimpse at the companys inner working in the run-up to the financial crisis. Tensions appeared to be escalating inside the firms headquarters in Lower Manhattan as it publicly professed that its ratings were valid, even as the home loans bundled into mortgage-backed securities, or M.B.S., were failing at accelerating rates, Mary Williams Walsh and Ron Nixon write in DealBook. Together, the documents show a portrait of some executives pushing to water down the firms rating models in the hope of preserving market share and profits, while others expressed deep concerns about the poor performance of the securities and what they saw as a lowering of standards.

title: Now Bidding | The Watchmen Covers
description: Comic book fans with deep pockets will have a chance to own a piece of Watchmen when the covers of the first three issues are sold at Heritage Auctions this month, in a sale that ends on Feb. 22; issue No. 1 alone is expected to bring in more than $100,000. (Three additional auctions will follow in May, August and November, each featuring three covers from the original 12-issue series published by DC Comics.) Written by Alan Moore and illustrated by Dave Gibbons, Watchmen ushered in a new level of mature storytelling with adult themes and flawed heroes. Gibbons sold the covers and original artwork to Watchmen  pitifully cheap, he noted  nearly as quickly as he created it, fearing that there would be no takers. It seemed like a good idea to me at the time, he said. In my experience, the sort of comic art that sold well were kind of money shots  big action shots of the heroes in costumes doing something interesting. I realized that Watchmen was filled with a lot of meat and potatoes stuff, people standing around talking, which I didnt think would be as popular. The series went on to become a perennial best seller. It was adapted into a live action film that was released in 2009 and, last year, DC began publishing a series of prequels called Before Watchmen, which caused some consternation with fans and creators who felt that Watchmen should stand alone.

title: The Non-Decisive Decade
description: Yesterday the CBO came out with its updated budget outlook  and the release was met with a collective yawn. Why? Basically, because the projections over the next decade just didnt show the kind of fiscal disaster everyone in DC wants to believe in. Thats not to say that the outlook is completely benign  CBO still thinks well end the decade with high debt by historical standards, especially under the alternative fiscal scenario that assumes that some cuts that are supposed to happen under current law wont. (Im still waiting for the wonks at CBPP and elsewhere to do a full analysis; as best I can tell, a truly realistic scenario would lie in between the baseline and the alternative). But theres nothing there lending comfort to the Greece, Greece I tell you crowd.

And if youve been reading here for awhile, youre aware of the reality, for better and worse, of oils long goodbye and the gas age.

We will respond to the threat of climate change, knowing that failure to do so would betray our children and future generations,he said at the start of one of the longest passages devoted to a single subject in the speech.

description: Given that Super Bowl Sunday is the biggest day of the year for advertising as well as for football, Madison Avenue waits each year after the game with bated breath for the results of the myriad analyses, polls and surveys of consumer responses to the commercials.

title: After Floating Idea of Lifting Ban on Gays, Scouts Delay Decision
description: The Boy Scouts of America, which confirmed last summer its policy barring openly gay people from participation, then said last week that it was reconsidering the ban, announced Wednesday that it would postpone a decision once more, until May, as talk of gay men and lesbians in the ranks has roiled a storied organization that carries deep emotional connection and nostalgia for millions of Americans.

title: To Egypt or Not to Egypt?
description: Sanctuary Retreats is offering new 10-night trips from Cairo to Aswan in six departures April through September, capitalizing on a decision by Egypt last year to lift the 18-year ban on Nile River cruises north of Luxor. The lengthened itineraries, on three ships with 40 or fewer cabins, visit sites like the rock tombs of Beni Hassan and the Valley of the Kings. The new offering comes as the cruise-ship giant Norwegian said that it would drop Egypt from its Mediterranean route through 2015, citing security concerns.

title: Lens: Photos at El Museo del Barrio
description: Starting today, some 80 images will be on display in superreal: alternative realities in photography and video, a new show at El Museo del Barrio, in East Harlem. Whats on display is shot with a documentarians eye, but includes a dose of mystery and otherworldliness. A spare-looking installation is designed to address the short attention span of the viewer in the digital age, forcing one to stop and look a little longer at how the images were created.

title: Vain Glorious | Sachajuans Body Care Collection
description: Stockholm-based beauty brand Sachajuan  already a cult favorite among hair industry pros and celebrities thanks to its popular algae-infused styling products  is finally bringing its range of body washes and lotions stateside. Instead of marine ingredients, this collection relies on beta-glucan, a soluble fiber made from oats, for its moisturizing and skin-soothing properties. All the formulas are very light but still effective, and the lotion absorbs really quickly so theres no dry-down time needed, says Misha Anderson, co-founder of Woodley & Bunny apothecary and Sachajuans U.S. distributor. The body products come in three subtle unisex scents that wont overwhelm the nose, and the simple packaging is firmly in keeping with the brands minimalist aesthetic. In Swedish culture, they have a word called lagom  the idea that things should be chic yet understated and functional, Anderson says. This line embodies that in every way.

description: If youve had a question youve been itching to ask a financial adviser, but were worried about the cost of getting the advice, nows your chance.

They are operatives used to working in the shadows, so the first set of challenges the films director, Dror Moreh, faced was convincing them to sit in front of his camera, reflect on the role they and their agency have played in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and answer his questions about specific operations.

title: Rigoletto in Vegas, Manon Lescaut in the Metro

Here, Mariusz Trelinskis staging of Puccinis Manon Lescaut  through Feb. 8  situates the opera in the waiting room of a subway station.

title: 2 Azeri Opposition Leaders Are Charged With Inciting Riots

description: Amy Kellner is a photo editor at the magazine.

The new biography Nelson Mandela, written and illustrated by Kadir Nelson; Fifty Cents and a Dream: Young Booker T. Washington, by Jabari Asim with illustrations by Bryan Collier; and Light in the Darkness,a story about how slaves learned in secret, written by Lesa Cline-Ransome and illustrated by James E. title: Wiped Out by Sandy, an Owner Sizes Up the Risk in Starting Over
description: The Automobile Film Club of America has played a supporting role in New York-based film and television productions since 1993. It owns a fleet of vehicles  including police cruisers, taxis and vintage automobiles  that have squired stars and models in advertising shoots, TV shows and action films, including two Spider-Man movies and two Men in Black films. Woody Allen rented a 1964 Porsche Cabriolet for one movie and bought an Aston Martin that was totaled in another. When they crash something, they buy it, said Ralph Lucci, the owner.

title: Should a Victim of Hurricane Sandy Risk His House to Revive His Business?
description: We just published a case study about the Automobile Film Club of America, a company that has played a supporting role in New York-based film and television productions since 1993. Based in Stapleton, on Staten Island, a half-block from the waterfront, the company was overwhelmed last October by Hurricane Sandys surge, when its 6,000-square-foot lot and 57 cars were submerged in saltwater. I have mechanics, they all say theyre totally junk, said Ralph Lucci, the companys owner, of the cars. It took five hours to destroy the business.

description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras  Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, was having some fun with numbers Wednesday morning before the mens national team took the field to begin the final round of World Cup qualifying.

description: During the 2012 campaign, President Obama and Vice President Biden and many other people, including our editorial page writers, pointed out that Mitt Romneys campaign boiled down to one proposition: Just trust me.

title: The Latest on Rasheed Wallace
description: Rasheed Wallace has a new goal. He wants to be able to participate in his first full practice in more than a month when the Knicks return from the All-Star break.

title: Clashes Erupt in Damascus as Prospects for Syrian Talks Dim
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian insurgents attacked military checkpoints and other targets in parts of central Damascus on Wednesday, antigovernment activist groups reported, shattering a lull in the fighting as prospects for any talks between the antagonists appeared to dim.

title: In the Wrong Record Book
description: Wasnt it less than a week ago that Alex Rodriguez was in the P.E.D. spotlight after a newspaper article in Miami New Times linked him to an anti-aging clinic in South Florida?

title: Staying Private on the New Facebook
description: Facebook is a personal vault that can contain photos of your firstborn, plans to bring down your government and, occasionally, a record of your indiscretions.

title: Cruises Get a Channel
description: Cruise Industry TV, a YouTube channel that provides industry news, was recently started by Cruise Lines International Association, which represents major cruise lines. The channel will host videos from member lines that highlight destinations and ships, and provide tips and other consumer-friendly information.

title: Malawis Leader Makes Safe Childbirth Her Mission
description: Malawi is a country of rolling hills and marshy flatlands, where 85 percent of the population live in the countryside, most subsisting on less than $2 per person per day, typically from corn and tobacco farming. It is also a country with extremely high maternal mortality. In the U.S., 1 in 2,400 women are at risk of dying while giving birth over the course of their lives; in Malawi, it is 1 out of 36. If the countrys new president, Joyce Banda, has her way, that will soon change.

title: Old Friends Help New York Review Celebrate 50 Years
description: The eager crowd milling in the lobby of Town Hall on Tuesday night looked ready for the opening of an A-list movie. For one thing, Daniel Craig was present. James Bond is standing over there, a man said. A stranger next to him, a woman in a large furry hat, peered over. Is he really? How exciting!

title: Russia and Stravinsky Are Themes for SummerScape Festival
description: The Bard SummerScape festival, which will run from July 6 to Aug. 18, will focus on Russia and explore the cultural impact of Igor Stravinsky, devoting its final two weekends to a broad survey of his music, organizers said in announcing the new season.

title: Things Get Rough on Twitter Over Gun Debate
description: 2:50 p.m. | Updated Twitter is often full of short-burst, back-and-forth argument, but Clara Jeffery, the co-editor of Mother Jones, found out that the debate can turn dark after tweeting last Saturday about the death of Chris Kyle, an ex-sniper who was killed at a gun range by a fellow veteran he was trying to help. (Hat tip to Peter Sterne for putting together a list of the tweets on Storify.)

title: Smash Premiere Falls Short, Loses Viewers
description: 3:25 p.m. | Updated It may be time for NBC to change the title of its Broadway drama, Smash. After its second-season premiere Tuesday night, the show might more appropriately be called, Smithereens.

title: Things Serious People Believe
description: Duncan Black is struck by a Meet the Press transcript in which Bob Woodward declares that

title: Highlights From the International Watch Salon
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Political Intelligence
description: David Brooks: Gail, let me start out with a troubling issue before I get to a bunch of encouraging ones. How would you vote on the Chuck Hagel nomination for secretary of defense? I would probably still vote yes, but only because I think a president should be given enormous deference to fill out his team.

title: Recruits Stay True to SEC as Teams Shift Loyalties
description: There is always talk about inroads and pipelines, coaching staffs that reshuffle and conferences that realign. But on national signing day, the Southeastern Conference, as it has for nearly a decade, ruled the national recruiting scene.

title: Stone Links: Is Same-Sex Marriage Homophobic?
description: That question, answered in the affirmative, was the focus of a short post  by the philosopher Roger Scruton and the theologian Philip Blond at The Spectator on Monday. The authors think its a mistake for homosexual couples to conform to heterosexual norms, and that by doing so they are absorbed into a structure that does not give due credit or recognition to [homosexuals] distinction and difference. Their position turns on an understanding of the concept of equality which sees the latter as valuable not because it erases differences, but preserves them. Stressing that gays deserve not just acceptance but celebration and recognition, they claim that what is most likely to achieve that is equity that respects difference not equality that destroys it. Scruton and Blond elaborate their position further in a Green Paper for the think tank ResPublica.

title: For Women, Reduced Access to Long-Term Care Insurance
description: This was a very, very good business for a short time, with people buying long-term care insurance like it was candy in a candy store, said Michael Perry, a vice president at the Opus Advisory Group, a strategic financial planning firm in Purchase, N.Y.

title: From PETA, a Video of Animals Strutting Their Stuff
