description: The advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather has created an animated video for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, just in time for Fashion Week. In a reversal of roles, animals in exotic outfits are seen preening on a catwalk, while backstage naked humans are confined to cages. Although the spot doesnt directly target China or other Asian countries that supply fur and leather products, including India, the only caged human clearly visible is a Chinese girl. Ogilvys Beijing office produced the video.

title: Picasso Fetches $44.8 Million at Auction
description: A canvas Picasso painted of his lover Marie-Thrse Walter seated by a window that had sold for $7.5 million at a Christies auction in 1997 brought $44.8 million, including fees, at Sothebys in London on Tuesday evening.

title: Libertys Bid for Virgin Media Pushes the Envelope on Debt
description: Liberty Globals $23 billion offer for Virgin Media is a turning point in postcrisis deal finance. This merger in cable television has most of the hallmarks of the precrisis boom.

title: Darwins Pigeons: Learning About Evolution From Bird Traits
description: Overview | In this lesson, students read about a study that sheds new light on Charles Darwins hobby of breeding pigeons. They learn about the origins of genes responsible for certain traits in pigeons, explore how scientists unravel the connections between genes and physical characteristics, and create their own selective breeding program.

title: Scientists Find Life in the Cold and Dark Under Antarctic Ice
description: For the first time, scientists report, they have found bacteria living in the cold and dark deep under the Antarctic ice, a discovery that might advance knowledge of how life could survive on other planets or moons and that offers the first glimpse of a vast ecosystem of microscopic life in underground lakes in Antarctica.

title: Sounds of the Road, in 17-Syllable Verse
description: Well beeped, City Room readers. On the occasion of the citys decision to take down those seemingly unavailing No Honking signs, we asked you to send us a Honku or two to mark the moment. You responded in droves, with extreme literary alacrity. Here is some of your work:

title: Two-Tax Rise Tests Wealthy in California
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  It is getting awfully expensive to be a millionaire in California.

title: With R.B.S. Settlement, Legal Tab for Banks Grows and Grows
description: LONDON  The sprawling investigations into interest-rate manipulation, money laundering and inappropriately sold products, while bad for many London-based banks, have turned into a goldmine for lawyers, accountants and other advisers.

title: Symbol of a Struggle
description: MIERCUREA CIUC, Romania  A city of 38,000 on a plateau in eastern Transylvania, Miercurea Ciuc is famous for three things: its status as one of Romanias coldest places; its brewery, where the countrys Ciuc beer is produced; and its ice hockey team, which has won the last six Romanian league championships.

title: Selling Jewelry and a Lifestyle, a Snapshot at a Time
description: For those who suffer from #fomo (fear of missing out), its a good idea to avoid the Instagram feed of Dannijo, a fashion jewelry line favored by downtown socialites and celebrities.

title: Excerpt: 'Community'
description: The NBC sitcom returns Feb. 7 after a lengthy hiatus.

title: Video of Protests Across Tunisia After an Opposition Leader Is Gunned Down
description: As my colleagues Monica Marks and Kareem Fahim report, there were protests across Tunisia on Wednesday following the assassination of Chokri Belaid, a leader of the secular opposition.

title: Fame Tries to Keep Up With a Busy Stylist
description: Kate Young, 37, a stylist for red carpet supernovas like Natalie Portman, Rachel Weisz and Michelle Williams, can often be spotted in Manhattans garment district, darting into designers showrooms to inspect their latest dresses.

title: Little Blog Post About Little Particles
description: Nanoparticles are really little; a nanometer is a billionth of a meter. A nanoparticle might be 10 nanometers, or 100; it doesnt matter much. By comparison, a human hair is around 100,000 times thicker. Needless to say, you cant see a nanoparticle.

title: Think You Can Beat Them?  Readers Who Get the Top Categories Right
description: (Vote for, share and keep track of your Oscar favorites with The Timess interactive awards ballot. Start Your Oscar Ballot)

title: Honda Plans Big Product Push at Geneva
description: Honda will be making a major product statement at the Geneva Motor Show on March 5, introducing three important models.

title: Mayor Backs Colleges Plan to Welcome Critics of Israel
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a vocal supporter of Israel but also a frequent advocate of free speech, on Wednesday forcefully defended Brooklyn Colleges decision to co-sponsor a panel discussion about a movement that calls for economic boycotts and sanctions against Israel.

title: Desperate Dad: Amity Gaige Talks About Schroder
description: In Schroder, Amity Gaiges third novel, an increasingly distressed father in the middle of a custody battle takes off on an unexpected road trip with his 6-year-old daughter, Meadow. The novel takes the form of a long letter written by the father, Eric, to his wife, Laura, trying to explain his actions. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Gaige discussed the slipperiness of identity, why this is her darkest novel yet, and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Democrats Seek to Stave Off $1 Trillion in Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  With at least one million jobs on the line,Senate Democrats on Wednesday said they were closing in on legislation to temporarily head off nearly $1 trillion in cuts that were already affecting Pentagon decision-making and could force significant reductions in staffing and services across the government.

title: An Interview With James Dyson
description: The entrepreneur discusses the importance of teaching creativity and his drive for innovation.

title: PC Industry Shifts as Dell Goes Private
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: The effects of Dells landmark deal. | Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. | The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

title: A Nice Clean Sport With No Reffing Controversies
description: Some friends are upset because the U.S. looked so miserable in that 0-0 draw with Canada in Houston last week. I can only say that match had nothing to do with World Cup qualifying. It was the equivalent of a baseball spring training game, when the regulars dont quite make the bus ride, George Vecsey writes on his Web site, in anticipation of todays game between the United States and Honduras. Read more here.

title: Highlights: The Westminster Dog Show
description: News, photos and behind-the-scenes accounts from the 137th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York City.

title: What to Do if Your W-2 Is Missing
description: Most workers have received their W-2 forms from their employers by now. Companies are required to provide the forms to employees, showing their annual income, tax payments and other deductions, by Jan. 31.

title: Getting Models Into Fighting Shape
description: For models, the former boxer Michael Olajide Jr. is the heavyweight of trainers  the go-to guy for girls who have to get runway-ready in a hurry.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Industry Shifts With Dell Deal
description: The effects of Dells landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

title: Late-Night Chills at South by Southwest
description: Vampires rise and so does Rob Zombie in this years Midnighters lineup at the South by Southwest film festival. The program will include nine after-dark films that either wallow in the creepy or bask in the crazy.

title: Trade Group Lawsuit Challenges Olive Oil Labeling
description: The North American Olive Oil Association, a trade group that represents the olive oil business in the United States and Canada, is suing Kangadis Food, saying it falsely labeled its Capatriti brand as olive oil when the product is a fat from leftover olive skins and pits.

title: A How-To Guide for Banks Facing Libor Settlements
description: The settlement announced Wednesday by the Royal Bank of Scotland with United States and British authorities is the third deal by a global bank emerging from the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate, or Libor.

title: FINAL: Honduras 2, U.S. 1
description: The United States mens soccer team lost to Honduras, 2-1, on Wednesday in the first game of the final round of regional World Cup qualifying.

title: Rap Duo Wins the Week With Thrift Shop
description: Beyonc sang for an estimated 104 million people at the Super Bowl on Sunday, and Justin Bieber has scored his fifth No. 1 album. But the biggest victory in the music industry is an independent rap duo from Seattle and its hit song about the pleasures of smelly secondhand clothes.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 6
description: A view of the day in sports, with cycling through the sands of Qatar.

title: Panetta Warns of Dire Consequences to Military From Budget Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  In the wake of President Obamas appeal to Congress to stave off across-the-board military and domestic spending cuts, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned Wednesday that reductions from the automatic cuts would curtail American naval operations in the western Pacific by as much as a third and force one-month furloughs for as many as 800,000 Defense Department civilian employees starting this spring.

title: Leader Signals G.O.P. Shift on Wages and College Aid
description: The Republican leader of the New York Senate said Wednesday that his caucus was open to raising the states minimum wage and creating a private fund to help the children of illegal immigrants pay for college.

title: Detain: No. Kill: Yes.
description: What would Senator Obama have made of the targeted killing memo that NBC News published on Monday? In a December 2007 interview with Charlie Savage  then of The Boston Globe, now of The New York Times  Mr. Obama didnt specifically address drone strikes. But he did say it was unlawful to detain U.S. citizens without charges, and argued that its always preferable for the commander in chief to obtain support from Congress prior to military actions.

title: Good News and Bad for Pompeii
description: ROME  Italy on Wednesday inaugurated a project financed by the European Union to restore the ancient city of Pompeii, a day after the police arrested a former restorer on charges involving inflated contracts and placed several others under investigation. Two years after the announcement that the union would commit more than $140 million to the restoration of Pompeii, where exposure to the elements and ill-fated interventions have led to routine collapses, the unions regional affairs commissioner, Johannes Hahn, visited the city on Wednesday with three Italian government ministers.

title: Google Buys E-Commerce Company to Improve Shopping Search
description: Google is moving deeper into e-commerce. On Wednesday, it announced it has agreed to acquire Channel Intelligence, a company that provides services to online retailers, for $125 million.

title: 5 From Queens Charged in Toy-Smuggling Scheme
description: Winnie the Pooh was the first to come to the attention of law enforcement officials, when customs agents seized a shipment of bubble blowers from China that illegally used the portly bears image.

title: Apples iPad Dominated PC Market During Holiday Season
description: The iPad is defined as a tablet, but you might as well call it a personal computer. Over the holiday season, about one in six people buying computers around the world bought Apples tablet, according to research from Canalys.

title: Calling All Anti-Models
description: MAURICE MAULTZ WAS zooming along West Fourth Street on a skateboard, thinking about the 300 pieces of film he had to scan for a class project at New York University, when he noticed a photographer taking his picture. Also, the photographer was surrounded by what appeared to be a small group of Japanese tourists, all of them staring at him.

title: Depression and the Limits of Psychiatry
description: Ive recently been following the controversies about revisions to the psychiatric definition of depression. Ive also been teaching a graduate seminar on Michel Foucault, beginning with a reading of his History of Madness. This massive volume tries to discover the origins of modern psychiatric practice and raises questions about its meaning and validity. The debate over depression is an excellent test case for Foucaults critique.

title: A Gastro Pub by the Palms in Miami
description: To many Miamians, Pubbelly is not just a great gastro pub. Its not even just the flagship restaurant in what has fast become an exceedingly successful mini-empire. In Miami, the Pubbelly guys, as theyre almost universally referred to, are often spoken of as folk heroes and credited with having fundamentally transformed the citys food landscape with six spots in just over two years, and another scheduled to open this year. If you ask Andreas Schreiner, who with Jose Mendin and Sergio Navarro opened Pubbelly in late 2010, that kind of recalibration of the Miami food scene was exactly their goal.

title: The SLS Hotel South Beach: Good for Gawking. Sleeping, Not So Much
description: Stats

title: Magazines React to Post Office Cutbacks: The Friday Evening Post?
description: 4:22 p.m. | Updated The magazine industry, which has already been hurt by advertising declines and the loss of readers, spent Wednesday afternoon reeling from the latest news that they no longer would be able to get magazines delivered on Saturdays.

title: Japan Subsidy for Whaling Is Challenged
description: TOKYO  A wildlife conservation group said in a report on Wednesday that Japan has been propping up its whaling industry with nearly $400 million in tax money in recent years, stepping up subsidies even as consumption of whale meat here has slumped.

title: Scene City: Social Animals Come Out of Their Shells
description: A benefit for Eric Goodes Turtle Conservancy draws the party people.

title: Guests With a Hard Shell
description: Heres something you might not know about turtles: some of them can still have sex when theyre 200 years old.

title: New Polls Show Rise in Support for Obamas Handling of Immigration
description: Following President Obamas campaign-style blitz last week to unveil his proposals for immigration overhaul, the publics rating of his handling of the issue appears to be on the rise, with several of his proposals enjoying broad support.

title: United States Announces New Iran Sanctions
description: The United States blacklisted Irans state broadcasting authority, Internet-policing agencies and a major electronics producer on Wednesday, an action that widened the American sanctions effort to pressure the Iranian government over not only its disputed nuclear program but also over the stifling of domestic dissent and access to information.

title: Runway Crescendo: Strut Over, Beethoven
description: At Carolina Herreras fashion show on Monday at Lincoln Center, dont expect to hear the Knifes Full of Fire, Haims Dont Save Me or Rihannas Diamonds.

title: Rubio to Deliver State of the Union Rebuttal
description: Senator Marco Rubio will give the Republicans response to the State of the Union address, party leaders announced on Wednesday.

title: If the Shoe Fits
description: Leave it to Miuccia Prada to dream up this seasons most boundary-breaking shoes. For her futurist Japanese-inspired spring collection, the designer sent models down the runway in Harajuku girl-style platforms and metallic judo socks with ribbon thong detailing, which left one or two fashion editors wondering if these otherworldly concoctions would actually make it into the stores. Starting tomorrow, and continuing through the end of the month, the Prada Fifth Avenue store will let clients customize select styles, from floral-embroidered bow getas (Japanese wooden sandals) to high satin sandals in colors like classic black and white, pale pink and metallic silver. And if you dare to wear, you can add your own initials  in gold lettering  on the soles. (Delivery takes six to eight weeks.)

title: Carnegie Mellon Selects New President
description: Carnegie Mellon University has selected Subra Suresh, the director of the National Science Foundation, as its new president, our colleague Tamar Lewin reports:

title: A Capitalist Case for Emancipation
description: Abraham Lincolns Emancipation Proclamation was met with both roars of approval and curses of outrage. Many of the most vocal supporters spoke in moral and political terms, arguing that slavery was either a sin or an abuse of intrinsic human freedom. But a third case was made too, one often overlooked today: slavery had to end because it violated the laws of the free market.

title: Tortorella, in a Mellower Mood
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  It doesnt happen often, but a kinder, gentler John Tortorella emerged after practice here Wednesday afternoon, as he tempered the paint-peeling criticism he leveled at his Rangers after a 3-1 loss to the Devils on Tuesday night.

title: Judge Asked to Settle Twombly Foundation Dispute
description: A Delaware judge has been asked to settle a feud among the directors of a foundation established by Cy Twombly, the American artist who died in 2011. The complaint, which was filed in the Chancery Court in Wilmington last week, asks the judge to appoint a custodian to break an ongoing deadlock among the Foundations divided, four-person board of directors, according to court papers.

title: In Lisbon, a Sleek Three-Bedroom Aerie
description: A recently renovated apartment in Amoreiras Towers is on the market for $1.15 million. The complex was built about 30 years ago by the Portuguese architect Toms Taveira.

title: House Hunting in ... Portugal
description: A THREE-BEDROOM CONTEMPORARY APARTMENT OVERLOOKING LISBON

title: Nigeria and Burkina Faso in Africa Final
description: Burkina Faso ousted Ghana in a penalty-kick shootout, 3-2, after playing to a 1-1 draw after 120 minutes, and Nigeria rolled over Mali, 4-1, in South Africa on Wednesday in the semifinals of the Africa Cup of Nations. On Sunday in Johannesburg, the two countries will play for the title and a berth in this years FIFA Confederation Cup in Brazil.

title: Online Campaign Draws Attention to Case of Saudi Father Accused of Rape and Torture
description: Reports that a man in Saudi Arabia, who has appeared on television as a preacher, had raped and tortured to death his 5-year-old daughter have fueled outrage online about the way the legal system works in the conservative kingdom and about the lack of protections for domestic abuse victims.

title: Where Chicken Nuggets Dip Themselves
description: An installation by Banksy, the pseudonymous, secretive British artist, was unveiled on Wednesday at 89 Seventh Avenue South in Greenwich Village.

title: Nannycam Video of Baby Being Slapped Leads to Arrest
description: Staten Island prosecutors have charged a 52-year-old nanny with endangering the welfare of a child after a hidden camera recorded her slapping the face of a 5-month-old girl.

title: The Nuclear Power and Natural Gas Equation
description: Duke Energy is weighing the issue of how to replace the power generated by its troubled Crystal River nuclear plant in Florida, which the company has announced that it will permanently shut down.

title: App Smart: Video Editing
description: Kit Eaton reviews apps that turn smartphone video into fun short films.

title: Former Top Media Banker Sues Los Angeles and 2 Police Officers
description: 5:48 p.m. | Updated

title: Tools of the Trade for the Smartphone Cineaste
description: Ill bet that your smartphone is full of lots of little video clips. You know, ones that you make when you see something cute, surprising or beautiful. They may be nice mementos, but Ill also bet they are not great examples of cinematography. Instead of just leaving these clips in their raw state on your phone, you can use apps to trim off unneeded parts, string clips together or add special effects.

title: No One Forgets a Name When Its Strange
description: Whats in a name? Beats me.

title: Matthew Perry Becomes a Dreamer
description: The Field of Dreams just got another dreamer.

title: Same Classroom, New Curriculum on Community
description: One of the many reasons to watch the first three seasons of Community, the fiercely quirky and unapologetically smart NBC sitcom, was that you actually had to watch it. Every offhand remark, every reaction shot, every bit of physical business communicated something (usually something funny). More than any other show in prime time it demanded that you pay attention.

title: A Crack in the Ice Between Musicians and Management
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Sibeliuss music is thought by many to reflect the long, deep winters of his native Finland. So if youre looking to Sibelius to shed a bit of warmth, it must be cold.

title: Theater World Friends Bring Ailing Playwright Closer To Home
description: About a dozen friends and colleagues of the adventurous Cuban-born playwright and director Mara Irene Forns gathered Wednesday morning near the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to await her arrival at Amsterdam House, the nursing home to which she was transferred from another facility in upstate New York. Just before 1 p.m. the small throng waved and applauded as Ms. Forns, 82 and gaunt but seeming to enjoy the attention, was wheeled into the home.

title: Professor Pinault Pays a Visit
description: Going into the fall 2013 collections on Thursday, there is no question that the fashion landscape is getting younger. This season, were all looking forward to seeing the maturing work of a large group of designers who have entered the business over the last decade, many of them right out of college.

title: Now Serving Spite and Dutch Malaise
description: The Dinner, Herman Kochs internationally popular novel, is an extended stunt. Mr. Koch confines his story to one fraught restaurant meal, where malice, cruelty, craziness and a deeply European malaise are very much on the menu. The four diners can leave the table occasionally, headed to the restrooms or the garden or the handy room of flashback memories. But mostly they sit and seethe at one another as a miserable night unfolds.

title: An Author Attracts Unlikely Allies
description: In 1974 Thomas Nagel published What Is It Like to Be a Bat?, a short essay arguing that the subjective experience of consciousness  what philosophers call the qualia  could not be fully reduced to the physical aspects of the brain.

title: About Last Night | The Marni Fragrance Party
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Egyptian Prime Minister Criticized for Soliloquy on Ignorant Mothers
description: Last Updated, Thursday, 1:21 p.m. With angry protesters challenging the Egyptian governments grip on strategic cities of the Suez Canal, the army chief warning of the potential collapse of the state, violent sexual assault plaguing demonstrations in Tahrir Square and more than 50 deaths in the latest round of street clashes, the nations prime minister spoke this week on state television about a social problem that few people saw coming: unclean breasts.

title: Scouting Report
description: FASHIONS NIGHT OUT may come only once a year, but there are still plenty of ways to partake of macarons this Fashion Week. At the BARBARA BUI celebration at Intermix on Thursday, East Village-French confections like candied bacon with maple cream cheese meringue from Macaron Parlour will be on offer. At 1003 Madison Avenue from 6 to 8 p.m. R.S.V.P. at rsvp@intermixny.com.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Feb. 7
description: Get noticed in playful jeans; lounge in style with Creatures of the Wind; and stay dry in a new line of mod raincoats.

title: A Gathering of Songs and Friends
description: As he explained to the audience at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Tuesday night, the composer Kevin Puts did not know much about song when he was asked to serve as curator for a whole program of them. The invitation came last year from Michael Barrett, the associate artistic director of the popular New York Festival of Song, who was recruiting a composer to plan one of the organizations NYFOS Next programs, a mini-series devoted to recent American songs.

title: Fans Hooked, a Ballet Company Casts About for Converts
description: The terrific density of New York City Ballets repertory, without parallel anywhere in the world, is something its audience often takes for granted. Were now less than halfway into the fourth week of the companys six-week winter season. Already it has presented 21 ballets. These include 12 by George Balanchine, 2 each by Jerome Robbins, Peter Martins and the promising young choreographer Justin Peck, as well as one each by William Forsythe, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon.

title: Celebrating 20 Years of Life After a Legend
description: It hasnt quite been two decades since Jacqulyn Buglisi and three of her colleagues in the Martha Graham Dance Company formed a troupe of their own. At the time Graham was declining, and Ms. Buglisi hoped to continue the Graham line from where Graham had left off. But the works on the opening-night program of Buglisi Dance Theaters 20th season, which began at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, could have passed for much older than 20. And thats including the two premieres.

title: Eyes on Gun Violence, Lawmakers Propose Expanded Mental Health Access
description: Seeking to put their stamp on the Congressional debate over how to deal with gun violence, a bipartisan group of senators will introduce a bill Thursday that would seek to strengthen the nations mental health services and perhaps stave off violent acts by the mentally ill.

title: Homes for $1.3 Million
description: Properties in Atlanta, Vermont and Minnesota.

title: What You Get for ... $1.3 Million
description: ATLANTA

title: Music Seems Familiar, Even When Its Not
description: The Book of Kohelet, or Ecclesiastes, contains one of the most frequently quoted phrases from the Bible: There is nothing new beneath the sun. The world-weary author of the text then continues, Sometimes there is something of which one says: Look, this is new!  it has already existed in the ages before us. Qohelet is the title of an instrumental work by the Argentine composer Osvaldo Golijov, which the St. Lawrence String Quartet performed on Monday evening at Zankel Hall as part of an all-Golijov concert that attested to his profound interest in Middle Eastern and Mediterranean spiritual traditions. Mr. Golijov holds this seasons Richard and Barbara Debs Composers Chair at Carnegie Hall.

title: It Took a Village to Film Lincoln
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  If there were an oral history of the making of Lincoln, it might start with a 6-year-old Steven Spielberg visiting the Lincoln Memorial in Washington one winter. I was freezing my little tush off, and my uncle brought me to meet this giant, he recalled in an interview here on Monday. I had no idea who he was except he was bigger than me and really intimidating.

title: Longtime Animosity at Bolshoi Described
description: MOSCOW  It remains a mystery who threw acid into the face of the Bolshoi Ballets artistic director, Sergei Filin, three weeks ago. But new information about the Bolshoi did emerge this week: The theaters director and its most prominent male dancer went public with a range of accusations, revealing dramas that were simmering long before the attack, though, in the end, they may have no connection to it.

title: News Corp. Posts Gain on Strength of Cable Channels
description: 8:54 p.m. | Updated Strong growth at News Corporations cable channels FX, Fox News and regional sports networks helped the company more than double its net income in the three-month period that ended Dec. 31, offsetting lingering costs related to a phone-hacking scandal and the cost of a planned split of the media conglomerate into two publicly traded companies.

title: Young Man With a Lengthy To-Do List
description: Its been a monumental few years for the 21-year-old Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov, who recently won the Tchaikovsky and Rubinstein competitions and made his debut with the New York Philharmonic. On Tuesday, just a day after signing a new partnership with Deutsche Grammophon, Mr. Trifonov gave his Carnegie Hall recital debut, which the label will release as a live recording.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Vine Restriction, and Amazon Money
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Zeke Jabbours Tournament in Boca Raton, Fla.
description: Zeke Jabbour hosts an annual pro-am bridge tournament at the St. Andrews Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla., that raises money for Parkinsons research. The date, the Sunday before the Super Bowl, is carefully chosen because there are no playoff football games that day.

title: The Fashion Week Diet
description: I lost five pounds on the Fashion Week Diet, and I ate anything I wanted!

title: In an Old Packard Plant, Life Goes On
description: A semi-retired autoworker calls 90,000 square feet of abandoned factory space home.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Greece, Syria, Tunisia and Iraq.

title: Life in the Ruins
description: DETROIT  Allan Hill has an unwavering faith in Jesus and a slow startle response, traits that have served him well in his adopted home. For the last seven years, Mr. Hill, a 68-year-old semiretired auto-body worker, has lived in an old Packard plant, the concrete hulk that was once headquarters of the long-defunct automobile manufacturer and is now, in the words of the Motor City Muckraker blog, a lawless wasteland.

title: Trees That Make the Best Neighbors
description: The feud with my neighbor has festered for a year or two now. He cusses at my children when they sled down the knoll near the property line. He grouses when I shovel snow near his garage. Come to think of it, the feud consists of my neighbors being a sorehead and my having the misfortune to live next door.

title: For U.S. Leader in Afghan War, Much Time Making Peace
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After 19 months in Afghanistan, Gen. John R. Allen, the commander of American and coalition forces here, is leaving a war that has become as much about damage control and crisis diplomacy as fighting the Taliban.

title: The Skys the Limit
description: Experts offer suggestions for buying trees, ranging from Southern magnolias to Tibetan cherries.

title: Interview With Gen. John R. Allen on Leaving Afghanistan
description: The New York Times interviewed Gen. John. R. Allen on Sunday, a week before his scheduled departure from Afghanistan after 19 months as the commander of the American and allied forces.

title: BMW Confirms 3 Series Gran Turismos
description: BMW officially confirmed Wednesday an expansion of its Gran Turismo line to its popular 3 Series, with the addition of 328i and 335i models.

title: A Second Chance
description: When Jay Fielden rebuilt his house after it burned down in 2010, it was an opportunity to make the midcentury gem more livable.

title: Restoration Drama
description: WILTON, CONN.  In the annals of domestic horror stories, Jay Fieldens is as gothic as they come. It begins with the collapse of Lehman Brothers and the attendant financial meltdown in the fall of 2008. He and his wife, Yvonne Orteig Fielden, now both 43, and their two young children had just moved into their new home, a sturdy example of Connecticuts storied collection of modernist glass houses, which they had bought for $900,000 in 2007 and spent eight months renovating.

title: Better Place, Proponent of E.V. Battery Swapping, Pulls Out of U.S. and Australia
description: Better Place, a company that provides charging infrastructure for electric vehicles, said on Wednesday that it would wind down its operations in North America and Australia and concentrate solely on Denmark and Israel.

title: Shopping for Serving Utensils
description: James Klein and David Reid, the married partners of the New York porcelain company KleinReid, believe that tableware and serving utensils are the most intimate things at your dinner party.

title: Serving Utensils
description: James Klein and David Reid believe in the power of table settings. Because when you entertain, almost nothing else comes under such close scrutiny.

title: Summoning Nature for Healing
description: The Crown Sky Garden, on the 11th floor of the Ann and Robert H. Lurie Childrens Hospital of Chicago, is a 5,000-square-foot area for play and contemplation and the second healing garden completed last year by Mikyoung Kim. Ms. Kim, a 44-year-old landscape architect, is regarded as an artful weaver of nature and sculpture. The Sky Garden features a bamboo grove and interactive furniture that emits sounds when an embedded brass hand is touched with a live one.

title: Reflections by the Thousands
description: With its shimmering metal clusters, the Argent suspension light by Terzani looks like something from the glam 70s, but it was inspired by old pirate films. When you open the chest  the one you used to see in childs movies  it looked like an explosion of coins, said Dodo Arslan, the designer.

title: A New Home for Homer
description: The interior designer Richard Mishaan is reintroducing Homer, the stylish shop he owned from 1997 to 2008. (It would still exist, he said, had the Whitney Museum not reclaimed the Madison Avenue space.) Homer is now in Greenwich Village, but Mr. Mishaan aims to replicate the uptown experience. He will transform the store four times a year. Well lighten things up for summer, he said, and have more-substantial pieces for the holidays. The mix includes contemporary and vintage furnishings, as well as Mr. Mishaans own, more-affordable furniture designs for Bolier and lighting for Urban Electric. The store will be arranged in vignettes. I want to give people design ideas and start a dialogue, he said. 56 University Place (East 10th Street), (212) 744-7705, homerdesign.com.

title: On the Road Again
description: The Bowlus Road Chief makes an Airstream look about as design forward as a dogcart. The glittering, riveted-aluminum, lozenge-shaped trailer was engineered by an aircraft designer named William Hawley Bowlus in the 1930s (he also built the Spirit of St. Louis).

title: Precision Engineering for Beer
description: The German glassmaker Spiegelau, in partnership with Sam Calagione, the founder of Dogfish Head, and Ken Grossman of Sierra Nevada brewery, has introduced an I.P.A.-specific beer glass, perhaps the worlds first, surely the most obsessively considered.

title: Sales at Stark, Alessi and Others
description: Rugs, fabric and wall coverings are up to 75 percent off at Stark through Sunday (wool broadloom, regularly $180 a square yard, is $99 a square yard): Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, (212) 752-9000, stark-home.com.

title: O to Honor a Jazzman, With a Very Difficult Name to Spell
description: A few weeks ago, Ken Biberaj, a candidate for City Council, was preparing for a town-hall meeting to be held in the Amsterdam Houses near a cul-de-sac on West 63rd Street.

title: At the Vortex of Music and Fashion
description: There are so many of these girls in fashion nowadays who call themselves a D.J., said the house-music D.J. Honey Dijon with a sigh. She was at SNice, a vegetarian cafe in the West Village, dressed casually in a sleeveless black Alexander Wang shirt and a slouchy beanie from Supreme.

title: Share Your Fashion Week Instagrams
description: Are you planning to attend New York Fashion Week? If not, will you be getting a glimpse of the action outside the tents, on the streets of New York or at the parties? From Thursday, Feb. 7 through Feb. 14, we will be featuring a gallery of your Instagrams from Fashion Week. Share your photos with us  scenes, portraits, details  by tagging them on Instagram with #NYTFashion. Remember, we are looking for images that represent the whole culture of Fashion Week, from the runway, behind the runway and beyond. Start snapping!

title: Crew-Only 787 Flight Is Approved by F.A.A.
description: Federal regulators said on Wednesday that they had approved one flight of a Boeing 787, with a flight crew but no passengers, as the companys engineers study possible changes to the planes electrical systems that could reduce the risk of another battery fire.

title: The Mascara Crowd Muscles In
description: It has become commonplace to see fashion bloggers in the front row of runway shows, whether its Man Repellers Leandra Medine at Yigal Azroul, Tavi Gevinson at Rodarte or Bryanboy at D & G.

title: Player Ratings: Honduras (2) vs. U.S. (1)
description: The United States mens national team opened the final round of regional World Cup qualifying in poor form Wednesday, losing to Honduras in San Pedro Sula.

title: Walt Sweeney, All-Pro and Critic of N.F.L., Dies at 71
description: Walt Sweeney, an All-Pro guard for the San Diego Chargers in the 1960s and 70s who accused the team of handing out drugs to players and fostering his own addiction, died on Saturday at his home in San Diego. He was 71.

title: English Hospital Report Cites Appalling Suffering
description: LONDON  Shockingly bad care and inhumane treatment at a hospital in the Midlands led to hundreds of unnecessary deaths and stripped countless patients of their dignity and self-respect, according to a scathing report published on Wednesday.

title: Trimming the Trends
description: Designers hint at purging collections of showy trims and prints.

title: Group of Young Immigrants Seeks a Direct Path to Citizenship for All, Regardless of Age
description: A national organization of young immigrants said Wednesday that it would press for a direct and straightforward seven-year pathway to citizenship for all 11 million illegal immigrants in the country, and would not support measures that only offered citizenship to young people brought to the United States as children.

title: Brooklyn Event Expanding Into a Four-Race Series
description: On a chilly night in March 2008, a dozen or so cyclists sped through Brooklyns industrial Red Hook neighborhood on fixed-gear bicycles, dodging city buses and parked cars as bewildered neighbors looked on. The clandestine race was coined the Red Hook Criterium, but it was more spectacle than sporting event.

title: Look for Thrills Without the Frills
description: Its a cherished maxim in the retail trade. Buyers tell me all the time that their customers like things with stuff on it, said Sharon Graubard, a fashion trend forecaster in New York. How else to explain collections last year that groaned with fancy trims: faux gems, fringe and enough gilt to trick out a mini-Versailles?

title: Can You Squeeze In One More?
description: Getting a front-row seat during New York Fashion Week offers attendees the chance to be photographed by paparazzi before the show begins, to actually see the clothes on the models as they strut by, and to exchange a self-congratulatory glance with Anna Wintour (even if that glance goes unacknowledged by the Vogue editor).

title: Seeking Redress for a Mothers Life in a Workhouse
description: DUBLIN  Samantha Long and her twin sister, Etta Thornton-Verma, were born in 1972 and adopted at 9 months. They never knew their birth mother and decided to try to track her down in the mid-1990s. Nothing prepared us for what we found, Ms. Thornton-Verma, who lives in New York, recalled in a telephone interview last week.

title: Report Clouds the Picture on Yankees Catching
description: The Yankees thin catching corps was left more vulnerable when it was revealed Tuesday that Francisco Cervelli, one of the two leading candidates to be the teams starting catcher, had visited a Miami clinic under investigation for dispensing performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Justices Plans for Event Tied to Pepsi Stir Outcry by Yale Alumni
description: WASHINGTON  A long-running dispute between Yale University and some of its alumni over the universitys connections to PepsiCo, the giant beverage and snack company, has  in a way  reached the Supreme Court.

title: Portraits From Silver: A State of Mind
description: When she turned 60, Vicki Topaz found herself wondering how other women of her generation were experiencing aging. Here is a sampling of their images and comments.

title: Italian Bank Confirms Loss of $985 Million in Secret Deals
description: FRANKFURT  Monte dei Paschi di Siena, an ancient Tuscan bank whose troubles have shaken Italian politics and caused jitters around the euro zone, on Wednesday confirmed earlier estimates of losses from a series of secret transactions that were used to conceal the scope of the banks problems.

title: Silver Becomes Her, in a Shows Portraits
description: Amy Hempels silver white hair is a fact of life. But more than that, it is a banner of identity. Ms. Hempel, the short story writer, recalled recently that a former beau had spied her as she was running to meet him for a movie date. As she caught up with him, he murmured appreciatively: I knew that was you. I saw that flag of hair.

title: Tutus
description: Bushwicks industrial blocks are a haven for raves, after-hours parties and other grubby creatures facing extinction in Manhattan. But Tutus, a neo-rustic bar/restaurant/club that opened last October, is a harbinger of normalization.

title: Berlusconis Brother Uses a Racial Slur for Mario Balotelli
description: ROME  It was considered a coup, politically as well as athletically, when Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister, shelled out 20 million euros last month to land Mario Balotelli, the star striker, for his soccer team, A. C. Milan. But some of the bloom was lost this week when Paolo Berlusconi, the brother of the former prime minister, referred to Mr. Balotelli in loose translation as the little black boy, using a word that is clearly derogatory in Italian.

title: Vonn Aims for a Full Recovery While Ligety Wins
description: SCHLADMING, Austria  One day after Lindsey Vonns season-ending crash, she said she planned to come back better than ever for the 2013-14 World Cup season.

title: Guy F. Tozzoli, 90, Who Led Team That Built Twin Towers, Is Dead
description: You are going to build the trade center, Guy F. Tozzoli was told on his 40th birthday in 1962 by the head of the Port of New York Authority. Eleven years later, he had.

title: Beauty Spots
description: French Twist

title: A Hospital Offers a Grisly Lesson on Gun Violence
description: PHILADELPHIA  In a darkened classroom, 15 eighth graders gasped as a photograph appeared on the screen in front of them. It showed a dead man whose jaw had been destroyed by a shotgun blast, leaving the lower half of his face a shapeless, bloody mess.

title: Multinational Search in Bulgaria Blast
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  Law enforcement and intelligence officials from several countries are working to find two presumed Hezbollah members, a Canadian and an Australian, both of Lebanese descent, who are believed to be behind a deadly bombing of a bus full of Israeli tourists in Bulgaria.

title: Veronica Beard: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: At 31, a Fast Start on Tour; at 17, a Big Debut
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  They are two South Korean-born golfers whose pursuit of the American dream has brought them to the Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, but from there the stories of James Hahn and Si Woo Kim sharply diverge.

title: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Wednesday directed the Justice Department to release to the two Congressional Intelligence Committees classified documents discussing the legal justification for killing, by drone strikes and other means, American citizens abroad who are considered terrorists.

title: Leaving Behind Malibu in Search of a New Dream Home
description: ONE of the best-known residents of Malibu, Calif., alongside billionaires like David Geffen and Larry Ellison, is embarking on a national promotional effort to help sell her home there for the eye-popping price of $25 million.

title: U.S. Wilts in Honduras in a World Cup Qualifier
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras  The phrase was repeated like a mantra here this week: Get the job done, the American players said, until the words nearly lost their meaning.

title: De Blasio Donors Hit Maximum, but Keep Giving
description: In an aggressive bid to increase contributions from major supporters, Bill de Blasio, the public advocate, has been taking donations to defray old campaign debts from people who have already given the maximum permissible amount to his current campaign for mayor.

title: Governor of Illinois Tells Legislators Pension Costs Put State at Critical Juncture
description: CHICAGO  After a year of unfruitful attempts to solve Illinoiss fiscal crisis, Gov. Pat Quinn used his State of the State address on Wednesday to implore legislators again to curb pensions costs that he said were squeezing out education, public safety and other vital services to the tune of $17 million a day.

title: Chris Brown Goes to Court, With Rihanna in the Front Row
description: As Rihanna sat in the front row and blew him a kiss, Chris Brown went before a judge on Wednesday to answer allegations from prosecutors that he had failed to complete a sentence of community service after pleading guilty to assaulting her in 2009, The Associated Press reported.

title: Justice(s) at Work
description: This column is prompted by the eye-catching headline that appeared two weeks ago: Share of the Work Force in a Union Falls to a 97-Year Low, 11.3%. As the article explained, many factors  global, domestic, economic, political  have contributed to the steep decline in the unionized work force, in both the private and public sectors. The trend, while accelerating, isnt new. And on the surface, certainly, it has little to do with the Supreme Court.

title: My Kingdom for a Corpse
description: Richard III is staging a comeback.

title: Putins Vision of Olympic Glory Meets a More Earthbound Reality in Sochi
description: SOCHI, Russia  Cranes, dump trucks and more than 70,000 construction workers are now toiling 24 hours a day to transform this once sleepy Black Sea resort into its new role as sleek host of the 2014 Winter Olympics.

title: The Priest That Preyed
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Hunter Defends His Union Record
description: NEWARK  The first hint that Billy Hunters 16-year tenure running the N.B.A. players union might be over came in an unsigned letter, delivered to his Harlem home last Friday morning.

title: Hip-Hop Speaks to the Guns
description: The work of the rapper Kendrick Lamar should enjoy heavy rotation in the White House these days. In this time of Tucson, Aurora, Colo., and Newtown, Conn., Lamars major-label debut album, good kid, m.A.A.d city, gives us a broad reckoning with the meaning of everyday gun violence unfolding far from the tragic spectacle. Good Kid has earned its share of praise from critics and hip-hop fans, but it perhaps has the most to offer to those shocked into action by the senseless massacres weve endured over the past few years.

title: Rachel Comey: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: The Questions Brennan Cant Dodge
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.

title: Study Seeks Biomarkers for Invisible War Scars
description: Over the past decade, about half a million veterans have received diagnoses of post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury. Thousands have received both. Yet underlying the growing numbers lies a disconcerting question: How many of those diagnoses are definitive? And how many more have been missed?

title: Fix the Sink Before December
description: With less than a year left in office, Mayor Michael Bloomberg would leave an important legacy if he could actually eliminate the huge backlog in repairs needed in New York Citys public housing  home to more than 400,000 people.

title: No Snail Mail on Saturday
description: The United States Postal Service is wisely going ahead with a long-debated plan to eliminate Saturday mail delivery, with or without Congresss blessing. The public, increasingly reliant on Internet communication, has registered 70 percent approval in opinion surveys of the cutback as a no-brainer in modern life that would mean an estimated savings of $2 billion a year.

title: Storms Toll Creeps Inland, 4 Tiny Feet at a Time
description: At first, Sarah Heming thought it was one of her dogs pitter-pattering across the second floor of her two-story rental in Brooklyn Heights late at night. But the sounds intensified in places where the dogs just couldnt go; there was frantic scrabbling in the walls, followed by weighty thuds, and squeaks. There was scampering under the stove.

title: Drug Inquiry Focuses on Athletes Ties to Team at University of Miami
description: The University of Miami named its baseball stadium after Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez after he donated $3.9 million to renovate the field. One of baseballs premier hitters, Ryan Braun, played for the university from 2003 to 2005 before leaving to begin his professional career. The Washington Nationals star pitcher Gio Gonzalez calls an assistant for the universitys baseball team his off-season strength coach.

title: Court Urged to Reverse a Ruling on Terror
description: The Obama administration on Wednesday urged a federal appeals court to overturn a sweeping ruling by a district judge that blocked the government from enforcing a statute related to the indefinite detention without trial of terrorism suspects.

title: Europes Plan for GPS Limps to Crossroads
description: FUCINO, Italy  With lofty dreams of European unity increasingly grounded by economic woe and the weight of narrow national interests, an array of computer screens here in central Italy blinks with faint signs that  far away in space, at least  Europes often quarreling nations can still sometimes find common cause.

title: Immigration and the Middle Ground
description: The House Judiciary Committee held its first hearing on immigration on Tuesday, and it was not encouraging.

title: Lighter Menus Appeal to Diners and Owners
description: Driven by pressures like consumer demand and looming federal regulations that will require them to post calorie counts on menus, restaurant chains around the country are adding more nutritious choices and shrinking portion sizes.

title: Tavares Plans to Take the Islanders Back to the Top
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  It says everything about the makeup of Islanders center John Tavares that he believes they can reach the playoffs for the first time in six seasons, despite all the evidence to the contrary.

title: A Plan Aims to Reconnect Residents With the East River Waterfront
description: As New Yorkers have watched the waterfront around Manhattan open up in recent years, one stretch has lagged: the East River waterfront, especially from the Brooklyn Bridge north to 38th Street, where the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive impedes access, bike lanes are squeezed by development and, now in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, storm surges threaten parkland.

title: For Hagel, a Distinction Comes With an Asterisk
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama declared at the White House on Jan. 7 that Chuck Hagel, his nominee to be secretary of defense, would be the first person of enlisted rank to run the Pentagon. The distinction, which Mr. Obama called historic, quickly made its way into news media reports around the globe, including in The New York Times.

title: Are Government Layoffs the Problem?
Fighting Malnutrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Elections and Free Throws: Analyzing the Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruining a Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics and Politics of Targeted Killings
description: To the Editor:

title: Treatment of A.D.H.D.
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistani Militant, Price on Head, Lives in Open
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Ten million dollars does not seem to buy much in this bustling Pakistani city. That is the sum the United States is offering for help in convicting Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, perhaps the countrys best-known jihadi leader. Yet Mr. Saeed lives an open, and apparently fearless, life in a middle-class neighborhood here.

title: With Care, Newtown Tries to Move On Amid Tokens of Grief
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  In the 1,500 or so cards and letters in Box 58 at the Newtown Municipal Center, a mother named Ursula recalled the 6-month-old she lost in an auto accident; a 9-year-old, Hayden Toland-Yeh, pondered mortality; and Robert M. Sutton, a lawyer from Myrtle Beach, S.C., wrote movingly about the gun violence that ravaged his family when he was 6.

title: Armstrong in Discussion to Tell Details to Doping Officials
description: Less than one month after confessing to using performance-enhancing drugs throughout his career, Lance Armstrong is in talks with the United States Anti-Doping Agency to possibly disclose who helped him dope and how he covered up his doping for nearly a decade.

title: Lottery Numbers
Those Created Equal
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Lets start out by talking about Germany. Because clearly weve got ourselves a trend here.

title: The Heart Truth: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Corrections: February 7, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Smoking, Once Used to Reward, Faces a Ban in Mental Hospitals
description: MANDEVILLE, La.  Annelle S., 64, who has paranoid schizophrenia, took an urgent drag on a cigarette at a supervised outdoor smoke break at Southeast Louisiana Hospital.

title: After Down Year, Giants Cut Bradshaw and Canty
description: After a season in which they deteriorated from Super Bowl champions to a perplexing, uneven team unable to reach the playoffs, the Giants began making changes in earnest Wednesday with the release of running back Ahmad Bradshaw and defensive tackle Chris Canty.

title: Drone Strikes Under Scrutiny
description: In more than a decade at war since Sept. 11, 2001, the United States has relied increasingly on drones to kill people away from the battlefield. It has faced few constraints. Now an overdue push for greater accountability and transparency is gathering steam, propelled by growing unease that Americas drones hit targets in countries with whom it is not formally at war, that there are no publicly understood rules for picking targets, and that the strikes may kill innocent civilians and harm, not help, American interests.

title: Asbury H. Sallenger Jr., Coastal Risks Expert, Dies at 63
description: Asbury H. Sallenger Jr., a leader in the nations research on the causes and effects of sea level rise, storms and other coastal hazards, collapsed and died on Tuesday at his home in Oldsmar, Fla. He was 63.

title: New Rove Effort Has G.O.P. Aflame
description: WASHINGTON  Their battle with Democrats will have to wait. For now, Republicans have their hands full fighting one another.

title: The Knicks Cant Stop Wall, Who Stops the Knicks Winning Streak
description: WASHINGTON  The Knicks objective was the same with eachWizardspossession in the fourth quarter: stop John Wall. They tried different tactics  double-teaming Wall on the pick-and-roll, or trapping him when he dribbled over midcourt. Raymond Felton, J. R. Smith and Iman Shumpert all had their chance to guard Wall. All three failed.

title: In Chile, Video Appears to Show Sailors Vowing to Kill Foreigners
description: The military establishment was put on the defensive on Wednesday after a video shared widely on social networks appeared to show Chilean sailors chanting, I will kill Argentines, I will shoot Bolivians, I will behead Peruvians. The short video, which apparently was made in a coastal area of Chile where the sailors were on a training run, drew quick condemnations. Cecilia Prez, a spokeswoman for President Sebastin Piera, called the images shameful. The commander of Chiles Navy, Edmundo Gonzlez, said the videos authenticity was under investigation. The spread of the video comes at an awkward time for Chile, traditionally among Latin Americas largest arms importers, as the country faces territorial disputes with Bolivia and Peru.

title: With A.L.S. in Family, Chief at Bloomberg Joins Fight
description: Daniel L. Doctoroff watched in pain as his father developed a limp one day, was found to have Lou Gehrigs disease, and died within two years. Then an uncle also developed symptoms of the same disease, and died soon after.

title: Trial of Former College Quarterback Accused of Rape Starts Friday in Montana
description: HELENA, Mont.  The trial of Jordan Johnson, a former starting quarterback at the University of Montana accused of raping an acquaintance, begins in Missoula, Mont., on Friday, extending a cloud of scandal that has hung over the campus for two years.

title: E-Mails Imply JPMorgan Knew Some Mortgage Deals Were Bad
description: When an outside analysis uncovered serious flaws with thousands of home loans, JPMorgan Chase executives found an easy fix.

title: U.S. Increases Pressure of Economic War on Tehran
description: TEHRAN  All over this city of 12 million people, high-rises are under construction, local engineers and Chinese contractors are rushing to finish a multilevel highway, and the streets are lined with billboards promoting the latest tablets and washing machines made by South Korean companies like Samsung and LG. Supermarkets are fully stocked, and it seems as if new restaurants and fast food joints are opening up every day, and never lacking for customers.

title: California: Archdiocese Will Release More Files
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles says that it will release more documents and undo redactions in response to complaints that the files it released last week on priests accused of sexual abuse were incomplete or that the names of church officials who had handled abuse cases had been blacked out. J. Michael Hennigan, a lawyer for the archdiocese, said that he had no idea why the documents were missing, but that as journalists, lawyers and victims caught the omissions, the archdiocese would add the information to the files it had posted online. Last week the archdiocese, under court order after a six-year dispute, made public internal church documents on 124 priests accused of abuse.

title: Nets Win but Dont Look Very Sharp in Doing It
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  By the fourth quarter, Nets Coach P. J. Carlesimos joke seemed prophetic. Speaking before the game Wednesday against the Detroit Pistons, Carlesimo mentioned his teams inability to put away lesser opponents.

title: Five Online Courses Are Eligible for College Credit
description: The American Council on Education, the leading umbrella group for higher education, and Coursera, a Silicon Valley provider of online education, announced on Wednesday that five Coursera offerings were similar enough to traditional college courses to be eligible for credit. Students who want to take the free classes for credit would have to pay a fee to take an identity-verified, proctored exam, and for a transcript to submit to the college of their choice. Similar transcripts are accepted by 2,000 colleges and universities for courses offered by the military or by employers. The Coursera classes are the first MOOCs  for massive open online courses  to be declared eligible.

title: Tanya Taylor: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Colorado: Contested Gas Leases Are Delayed
description: After facing a public outcry over plans to lease thousands of acres of public lands in Colorados North Fork Valley for oil and gas drilling, federal officials announced Wednesday that they would not put the parcels up for bid at auction this month. Officials at the Bureau of Land Management, which regularly auctions energy leases on public lands across the West, said their decision had removed 20,555 acres from bidding. Residents in the valley told federal officials they worried that the arrival of hydraulic fracturing on public lands could taint their air and water quality, and threaten their reputation as a budding haven for organic farms and orchards.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Feb. 7, 2013
description: I move about like an ordinary person  thats my style. My fate is in the hands of God, not America.

title: Microsoft Attacks Google on Gmail Privacy
description: On Thursday, Microsoft plans to unveil a new print, television and online advertising campaign that attacks Google on an issue that Microsoft believes is one of its great vulnerabilities: privacy. The ads will showcase research that shows most people dont know that Web e-mail providers like Google scan the contents of their e-mail messages to deliver personalized ads to them  and when they do find out, they dont like it.

title: The Persistence of Racial Resentment
description: Although there was plenty of discussion during the 2012 presidential campaign about the Hispanic vote and how intense black turnout would be, the press was preoccupied with the white vote: the white working class, white women and upscale whites.

title: Profound Weight of Layoffs Is Seen in Work Trends Survey
description: Layoffs have touched nearly every American household in some fashion over the last few years, according to new survey data to be released Thursday by the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University.

title: Think Like a Doctor: A Confused and Terrified Patient
description: The Challenge: Can you solve the mystery of a middle-aged man recovering from a serious illness who suddenly becomes frightened and confused?

title: Word of the Day | sedition
description: sedition \si-di-shn\ noun

title: Investigators Say Menendez Intervened on Friends Behalf
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey intervened with federal health officials on two occasions in the last four years in an effort to help a close friend in a billing dispute with Medicare, federal investigators said Wednesday.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 1:30 P.M. (MoreMax) THE DESCENDANTS (2011) Matt King (George Clooney, in an Oscar-nominated role), a real estate lawyer whose family tree includes the earliest white settlers in Hawaii as well as indigenous royalty, struggles to make the right decision regarding his familys birthright: a pristine and picturesque tract on Kauai. Should it be sold to developers? In the meantime his wife, Elizabeth (Patricia Hastie), is in a coma in a Honolulu hospital after a boating accident. Not long after her doctors inform Matt that he is about to become a widower and a single father to two difficult daughters, Scottie (Amara Miller) and Alex (Shailene Woodley), he learns that Elizabeth was having an affair. Robert Forster portrays Elizabeths enraged father, who blames his daughters condition on Matts tightwad ways; Matthew Lillard plays Brian, the object of Elizabeths affection; Judy Greer is Brians wife; Nick Krause (above, with, from left, Mr. Clooney, Ms. Miller and Ms. Woodley) is Alexs goofy sidekick; and Beau Bridges is Matts cousin. Mr. Clooneys actorly instincts have never been keener or more generous, and Ms. Woodley gives one of the toughest, smartest, most credible adolescent performances in recent memory, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this drama directed by Alexander Payne and based on the novel by Kaui Hart Hemmings. He added: Mr. Payne, with a light touch and a keen sense of place  this Hawaii is as real and peculiar as the Nebraska of About Schmidt or the California wine country of Sideways  has made a movie that, for all its modesty, is as big as life. Its heart is occupied by grief, pain and the haunting silence of Elizabeth, whose version of events is the only one we never hear. And yet it is also full of warmth, humor and the kind of grace that can result from our clumsy attempts to make things better.

title: Child Sexual Abuse Rampant and Untreated in India, Report Says
description: Child sexual abuse continues to be disturbingly common in India, despite widespread awareness of the problem, because of social stigma and negligence, Human Rights Watch said in a report issued Thursday.

title: In Worldwide Soccer Corruption Scandal, an Asian Tie
News Quiz | February 7, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Credit Suisse Returns to Profit and Plans More Cost Cuts
description: 4:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Fight Expands in Damascus as Diplomatic Hopes Sink
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Clashes between Syrian insurgents and loyalist troops in Damascus raged for a second day on Thursday and spread to the suburbs and other areas, activist groups reported. They said fighting also erupted in the large Palestinian refugee neighborhood of Yarmouk on the capitals southern outskirts, which has been drawn into the civil war at least twice in the past few months.

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 7
description: NEWS Tunisian officials moved quickly Wednesday to contain the fallout after a leading opposition figure was assassinated outside his home. They announced that they would restructure the Islamist-led government and form a national unity cabinet as thousands took to the streets in protests that security forces beat back with tear gas. Monica Marks reports from Tunis, and Kareem Fahim from Cairo.

title: Five Questions for: Author Tahar Ben Jelloun
description: Tahar Ben Jelloun is a Moroccan-born poet and novelist who writes in French and lives in Paris. His book Racism, as Explained to My Daughter, was translated into Hindi and Urdu. The award-winning writer first visited India 20 years ago, and he plans to write about what has changed in India since then. He spoke to India Ink during the Jaipur Literature Festival through a French translator.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Chief Resigns as Company Posts Loss
description: BERLIN  Alcatel-Lucent said Thursday that its chief executive, Ben Verwaayen, would step down as the company, a maker of telecommunications equipment, posted a big loss for the fourth quarter.

title: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 7, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article The Author Himself Was a Cat in the Hat.

title: Meet the New Monopoly Token, and Mourn the Old
description: For One Monopoly Token, the Days Are Numbered, wrote Vijai Singh on Feb. 4. On Feb. 6 Hasbro announced which one, and introduced the new token that will take its place. Use both articles to answer the questions below.

title: Byker in Black and White
description: On clear days in Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, a small yet bustling working-class city in northeast England, the view from the hills of Byker can be spectacular. That shabby neighborhoods rows of brick houses and terraced streets overlook a historic city center, the river and sometimes far beyond.

title: A Hollow Case for Big Banks
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Whats the Most Memorable Thing You Ever Got in the Mail?
description: A love letter? A present? An award? A school acceptance? A check? A note from a long-lost friend?

title: New Uncertainty Grips Tunisia After Assassination
description: TUNIS  Tunisias governing Islamist-led party on Thursday rejected a proposal by the prime minister to form a government of national unity, deepening the countrys political crisis a day after a leading opposition politician was assassinated outside his home.

title: What I Wish My Financial Aid Applications Revealed
description: In the post-independence, patriarchal society of India, women from the working classes were rarely educated. My grandmother, for example, attended school until only the eighth grade; she was married off soon after.

title: The Early Word: Share
description: In Todays Times

title: Obama Plans Fund-Raising Trips to Aid Senate and House Candidates
description: President Obama may have run his last political campaign, but that does not relieve him of his obligations to the Democratic Party.

title: 4 Years After Crisis, Ireland Strikes Deal to Ease a Huge Debt Load
description: LONDON  The Irish government, trying to lighten the staggering debt burden of bailing out some of its biggest banks four years ago, reached a deal on Thursday with the European Central Bank to give the country more time to repay some of those loans.

title: Just Like That, Ahmad Bradshaw Is Gone
description: It may not seem right, but running back Ahmad Bradshaw is no longer a Giant. He appeared to be the least-surprised person in the tristate area.

title: To Protect Your iPhone, Added Armor and a Honeycomb
description: Moshi, a maker of stylish accessories for digital devices, has expanded its line of cellphone cases with a couple of new designs for the iPhone 5.

title: Economic Growth in India to Fall to 5 Percent
description: Indias gross domestic product is expected to drop significantly to 5 percent for the fiscal year ending in March, according to advance estimates released by Indias Central Statistics Office on Thursday, declining from the 6.2 percent growth rate seen in fiscal year 2012.

title: Tip of the Week: A Quick Trip Through the iTunes Libraries
description: Apples iTunes 11 program moves all the various media libraries from a vertical panel on the left side of the window to a small Library pop-up menu in the top-left corner. For a quicker way to switch between media types instead of moving the mouse up to the menu, Apple has also included iTunes keyboard shortcuts to jump instantly to the desired collection.

title: Sloshing Around the Shows
description: The fashion crowd is in for a long and wet week. But neither stormy weather nor a flu epidemic can pose a threat to the flock of fashion designers, editors, buyers and fans that will storm New York on Thursday. More than 300 designers will present their fall 2013 collections at Lincoln Center, Made Studios and other venues in the city. From crowded back stages to crammed front rows, all eyes and minds will be on the fall shows.

title: The Wheat Lowdown
description: Those of us who cook believe that you have to cook to eat; baking bread is different. With so many relatively decent loaves readily available in stores, bread-baking is more of a hobby. The result, of course, will be eaten and enjoyed  and bakers know the rewards of blowing peoples minds with a good loaf: You made that?  but baking is not mandatory. (I say that having just paid four bucks for a baguette that would serve better as a kitchen sponge.)

title: With This Start-Up, Your Favorite Novel Never Has to End
description: In 2005, Valla Vakili fell in love with a French crime novel. He was so fascinated by Total Chaos and its antihero, a hard-drinking detective from the slums of Marseille, that he rerouted a planned vacation through that city, which is Frances second-largest. There he immersed himself in the characters world.

title: Frank Ocean Can Fly
description: Frank Ocean did not want to ride in my rented Ford Fusion; that much was clear. After I parked the car, he met me outside his modernist apartment building in Los Angeles and led me to the garage where he rents three parking spots for three different BMWs. He was dressed casually  gray hoodie, jeans, high-top Vans with red laces, baseball cap  and he jumped lightly from the curb to the parking blocks as we walked toward his late-model blue BMW M3. Ocean no longer had driving privileges as a result of some recent violations, on top of which he was cited for marijuana possession a few weeks earlier. You can drive, he said, though I could tell that it was killing him.

title: This Robot Does Do Windows
description: The robots at this years Consumer Electronics Show fell largely into two categories: floor cleaners and toys. But there was an exception.

title: Weaker Yen Helps Sony Trim Losses for Quarter
description: TOKYO  Sony pared losses in the last quarter of 2012 and stood by an upbeat profit forecast for its full financial year Thursday, thanks to a weak yen that helped compensate for disappointing sales of its cameras, flat-panel televisions and video game consoles.

title: Britains Embrace of Gay Rights
description: LONDON  It was after I jotted down the words on the placards being waved at the pro-gay-marriage demonstration  Who do you think made your wedding dress?; Sexual orientation is not a belief  that I realized the downside of taking a toddler to work.

title: Rate-Rigging Investigation Rolls On
description: The global investigation into interest-rate manipulation has emboldened prosecutors to crack down on banks, and the settlement with the Royal Bank of Scotland on Wednesday underscored that strategy. I want financial institutions to know that this department will absolutely hold them to account, said Lanny Breuer, head of the Justice Departments criminal division. As part of the $612 million deal that American and British authorities reached with R.B.S., the banks Japanese unit was required to plead guilty to criminal wrongdoing, echoing an earlier action taken against a subsidiary of UBS. These cases represent the first units of a big bank to agree to criminal charges in more than a decade, DealBooks Mark Scott and Ben Protess write.

title: E.C.B. President's Comments Send Euro Lower
description: FRANKFURT  The president of the European Central Bank on Thursday cited the rising value of the euro as a possible threat to the regions economic recovery, comments that immediately sent the euro down sharply against the dollar and yen.

title: May Cause Greed, Lust or Retirement
description: The marketing campaign for Side Effects, Steven Soderberghs tight and twisty new pharma-caper, includes a Web site for a fictitious antidepressant called Ablixa. You can tell the site is fake because the professional consultation it offers is provided by Jude Law, who plays a psychiatrist in the film. But the embedded commercial is a perfect parody of something that has become very familiar in recent years: a vague and seductive montage of sad and happy scenes accompanied by new-agey music and, interrupting the inspiring sales pitch, a sotto voce recitation of warnings and possible complications.

title: K.K.R.s Earnings Rise 22% on Investment Gains
description: Improving markets lifted the fortunes of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in the fourth quarter, as the investment firm reported a 22 percent rise in profit.

title: Opinion Report: Drones
description: From the editorial page

title: Straight Outta Congress: A Hip-Hop Tribute to House of Cards
description: One week into its release, House of Cards continues to knock down boundaries: this political thriller is the first original series to be commissioned by Netflix, the streaming video service; the first to make all 13 episodes of its debut season available at once; the first whose finale could be spoiled online almost as soon as you could watch the pilot. And now it appears to have set a record for the speed at which it has inspired a hip-hop tribute: I Cant Stop Watching House of Cards is the creation of Adam WarRock (the nom de rap of Eugene Ahn) and it has already earned an endorsement of sorts from the House of Cards show runner, Beau Willimon. For the uninitiated, the video wont spoil any crucial House of Cards plot points, though it will give you a thorough introduction to the series star Kevin Spaceys fluctuating Southern accent.

title: Asset Sales Help Lift Profit at New York Times Company, but Ad Revenue Declines
description: The New York Times Company reported a big jump in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, largely because of gains from asset sales.

title: On Our Radar: What Happened to All the Moose?
description: Minnesota officials ban moose hunting indefinitely, citing a steep decline in the animals population. The number of moose has fallen by 52 percent since 2010  not because of hunting, the state says, but possibly because of unusually hot summers or the spread of a tick-borne disease. (The moose are now being tracked with G.P.S. collars.) [NBC News]

description: Dear Diary:

description: What a difference a year has made for Lazard.

description: Sofia Coppola, Giambattista Valli and Peter Beard share their favorite moments with Lee Bouvier Radziwill.

title: Daily Report: Europes Plan for GPS Limps to Crossroads
description: With lofty dreams of European unity increasingly grounded by economic woe and the weight of narrow national interests, an array of computer screens in central Italy blinks with faint signs that  far away in space, at least  Europes often quarreling nations can still sometimes find common cause, reports Andrew Higgins in Thursdays New York Times.

title: The Gun Report: February 7, 2013
description: One thing thats been a little surprising since we began the Gun Report seven days ago is how many Second Amendment absolutists have been commenting. Dont you realize that more people are likely to die from drowning in the bathtub than from an accidental gun shot? they argue. Cant you see that criminals will always find a way to get a gun, and the law-abiding will be rendered helpless? Isnt it unfair to focus on gun deaths instead of, say, deaths by auto accident?

title: The Real Lee Radziwill
description: While she has long captivated the public as one of Truman Capotes swans, the sister of Jackie Kennedy and a European princess, with romantic liaisons from Peter Beard to Aristotle Onassis, not one of those labels begins to capture the true woman. The inimitable Radziwill  direct, free spirited and true to her own ideals  offers a rare, personal glimpse into her remarkable world.

title: The Undecade
description: John Boehner speaks:
