description: HONG KONG  Hewlett-Packard, one of the worlds largest makers of computers and other electronics, is imposing new limits on the employment of students and temporary agency workers at factories across China. The move, following recent efforts by Apple to increase scrutiny of student workers, reflects a significant shift in how electronics companies view problematic labor practices in China.

title: Peter Hauri, Psychologist Who Focused on Insomnia, Dies at 79
description: Peter Hauri, a psychologist who was among the first researchers to study the mysterious mechanics of a good nights sleep, and who established widely used guidelines for avoiding insomnia without drugs, died on Jan. 31 in Rochester, Minn., where he had been director of the Mayo Sleep Disorders Center until he retired in 2000. He was 79.

title: Brooklyn Legislator to Lose $67,000 for False Travel Filings
description: Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. has run afoul of the authorities to an extent that is unusual even for the caldron of scandal that is New Yorks capital.

title: Iran Shows Video It Says Was Made by U.S. Drone
description: In what Iran is calling a new demonstration of its military advances, state television has broadcast clips from what was described as encrypted video footage extracted from the camera of an unarmed American surveillance drone, which was seized in Iranian territory in December 2011.

title: N. Hoolywood: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Fleeing a Grim Reality, and Returning to Rise Above It
description: PHILADELPHIA  It was still early, but the crowd noise at Tom Gola Arena had begun to taper, and Gerald Galloway could sense things were not heading La Salles way.

title: Pro-Palestine Speakers at Brooklyn College Attract Protests Outside
description: Tensions were evident everywhere as two pro-Palestinian speakers arrived Thursday night at Brooklyn College. Protesters began gathering across the street from the student center, where the college-sponsored talk was scheduled, more than an hour before the event was to start. And police officers were stationed at the entrance to the building, searching bags and checking attendees names and identifications against an approved list.

title: A More Significant Minority
description: Two significant votes in the House this year have passed with most Republicans voting no. Since 1991, just 33 bills have passed without the support of most of the majority party.

title: Prosecutors Appeal for a 7th Term: Were Not Done
description: Charles J. Hynes, the longtime Brooklyn district attorney, officially announced on Thursday that he would seek a seventh term as the boroughs top law enforcement officer, setting him up for the toughest re-election campaign of his nearly 24-year career.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Garden Debut, 19-Year-Old Ranger Earns Hat, if Not Quite Hat Trick
description: J. T. Miller, playing in his second N.H.L. game, gave an electrifying performance Thursday night, scoring two goals to lead the Rangers to a 4-1 victory over the Islanders at Madison Square Garden.

title: Kenneth Cole: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Architect of Bounties Is Hired by Titans
description: The last of the bounty punishments passed into history Thursday as the N.F.L. reinstated the former New Orleans Saints defensive coordinator Gregg Williams, who was hired by the Tennessee Titans as a senior defensive assistant.

title: A Problem Continues to Blow Past the Knicks
description: None of the Knicks wanted to give John Wall all the credit for ending their five-game winning streak Wednesday night.

title: Doubts About Players and Suspected Drug Provider
description: For nearly a decade, as Major League Baseball has tried to solve its doping riddle, its investigators have repeatedly encountered vivid tales of star players using banned substances.

title: Schilling Talks About Banned Substance Offer
description: In a radio interview on Wednesday about doping in baseball, Curt Schilling said that an employee for the Red Sox once approached him about using banned substances.

title: Mariners and Hernandez Closing In on a Record Deal
description: The price for elite pitching will soon cross a new threshold. Felix Hernandez and the Seattle Mariners were on the verge of a contract extension Thursday that would make him the first pitcher in baseball history to earn $25 million per season on a multiyear deal.

title: Even for the Dead, Theres a Race to Make the A-List at Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  On Oscar night everyone is dying  sometimes literally  to win something.

title: 19-Year-Old Claims a Milestone for Black Nascar Drivers
description: Darrell Wallace Jr. will become only the fourth black driver in the 65-year history of Nascar to race full-time in a national series when he competes in the Camping World Truck Series this season.

title: Aging Easy Riders Beware
description: If youre over 40 and planning to hop on a motorcycle, take care. Compared with younger riders, the odds of being seriously injured are high.

title: Word of the Day | outspoken
description: outspoken \aut-spo-kn\ adjective

title: N.Y. Fashion Week Survey
description: At the start of the New York fall 2013 collections, we asked fashion show goers what they were most looking forward to seeing, how they were staying energized, and what they were wearing.

title: Jets Hire Coaching Assistants
description: Brian VanGorder, who spent four years as the Falcons defensive coordinator before holding the same position at Auburn last season, will coach the Jets linebackers next season. He replaces Bob Sutton, now the defensive coordinator in Kansas City. The Jets also hired Bobby April III as a defensive quality-control coach. He held the same job the last two seasons in Philadelphia.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) SHAKESPEARE UNCOVERED Actors and directors tour some of Shakespeares greatest works in this series, which continues here as David Tennant, who recently starred in the Royal Shakespeare Companys production of Hamlet, compares notes with Jude Law, above right with Mr. Tennant, on the challenges of the role and tries to master the meaning of the play alongside Simon Russell Beale and Ben Whishaw. At 10 on Channel 13 and at 11 on Channel 49, the series concludes as Trevor Nunn, who has directed 30 of Shakespeares 37 plays and is determined to stage them all before he retires, explains the magical world created in The Tempest, Shakespeares last complete play, with the help of Helen Mirren and the director Julie Taymor, who collaborated on a 2010 film adaptation.

title: China Denies Directing Radar at Japanese Naval Vessel and Copter
description: HONG KONG  China on Friday denied Japanese accusations that its ships directed a radar capable of aiding weapon strikes at a Japanese naval vessel and helicopter near disputed islands recently, then lobbed its own accusation: that Japan was trying to fan tensions. The latest exchange underscored the depth of a festering discord between the two countries, and trading partners, over the territorial dispute.

title: Settlement Between Armstrong and Company
description: A 2006 settlement agreement between Lance Armstrong and SCA Promotions regarding a dispute over a bonus payment. SCA had withheld that bonus payment for Armstrongs 2004 victory because of doping allegations.

title: Lawsuit Against Armstrong
description: SCA Promotions filed a lawsuit against Lance Armstrong, seeking repayment of the bonuses the company paid him for his Tour de France victories.

title: News Quiz | February 8, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Torture on the One Hand, Abuse on the Other
description: Makers and takers  or at least the far-right definition of same  square off against one another in Would You Rather, a derivative horror movie with highfalutin pretensions.

title: Hazards of Reporters Job Include Puck to Face
description: Hockey players are known to be among the toughest athletes, but hockey reporters can shrug off a little blood to do their jobs, too.

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 8
description: NEWS Hewlett-Packard, one of the worlds largest makers of computers and other electronics, is imposing new limits on the employment of students and temporary agency workers at factories across China. The move, following recent efforts by Apple to increase scrutiny of student workers, reflects a significant shift in how electronics companies view problematic labor practices in China. Keith Bradsher reports from Hong Kong and David Barboza from Shanghai.

title: Five Questions for: Author and Filmmaker Laleh Khadivi
description: Laleh Khadivi is an author and filmmaker who was born in Esfahan, Iran, and grew up in California. Her first novel, The Age of Orphans, received the Whiting Award for Fiction, the Barnes and Noble Discover New Writers Award and an Emory Fiction Fellowship, and it was translated into eight languages. Her latest novel, The Walking, will be published in March. Her debut documentary film, 900 Women, premiered at the Human Rights Watch Film Festival in 2001. India Ink interviewed Ms. Khadivi at the Jaipur Literature Festival.

title: European Leaders Agree, Finally, to a Lower Budget
description: BRUSSELS

title: At Least 26 Killed in Bombings Across Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A series of explosions across Iraq killed at least 26 people on Friday, continuing a spate of violence that has marked recent political turmoil and witnessed demonstrations now on seven consecutive Fridays.

title: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Feb. 8, 2013
description: The question was written by Katherine Schulten, and comes from the article Even for the Dead, Theres a Race to Make the A-List at Oscars.

title: Questions About the U.S. Drone Campaign
description: In Drone Strikes Risks to Get Rare Moment in the Public Eye, Robert F. Worth, Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane report on the United States drone campaign in Yemen. The program is receiving additional scrutiny this week because of the Senates confirmation hearing of John O. Brennan for director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Use this article, and the articles linked in questions below, to understand this complex issue.

title: Bringing Color to Newcastle
description: When Sirkka-Liisa Konttinen moved to Byker, an English neighborhood in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, she was drawn to the laughter, the children playing in the streets, the energy. For her, this blue-collar community brimmed with life.

title: What Food Would You Like to Judge in a Taste-Off?
description: Spicy pepperoni pizza? Creamy coconut popsicles? Crispy mac and cheese? Or subtly sweet black cherry soda?

title: Azerbaijan Is Rich. Now It Wants to Be Famous.
description: In March 2010, Ibrahim Ibrahimov was on the three-hour Azerbaijan Airlines flight from Dubai to Baku when he had a vision. I wanted to build a city, but I didnt know how, Ibrahimov recalled. I closed my eyes, and I began to imagine this project. Ibrahimov, one of the richest men in Azerbaijan, is 54 and has a round, leathery face with millions of tiny creases kneaded in his brow and the spaces beneath his eyes. He walks the way generals walk when they arrive in countries that they have recently occupied. In the middle of his reverie, Ibrahimov summoned the flight attendant. I asked for some paper, but there wasnt any. So I grabbed this shirt in my bag that I hadnt tried on. I took the tissue paper out, and in 20 minutes I drew the whole thing.

title: Tunisians Anger on Display at Funeral
description: TUNIS  In a show of anger at Tunisias Islamist-led government, tens of thousands of people filled a hilly cemetery in the capital on Friday to bury Chokri Belaid, an opposition politician whose assassination this week stirred fears here and throughout the Arab world that political violence could subvert the uprisings born in Tunisia two years ago.

title: The Problem With Playing the Scholarship Game
description: Decades ago, the Oscars were acknowledged to be a self-congratulatory publicity blitz with a thin veneer of drama, sometimes intended to authenticate the managerial efforts of Hollywoods money men. The honors were meted out beforehand, with the ceremonial excess tacked on as an afterthought three months after the winners had been announced.

title: Virginia Cavalry Canters Into N.A.S.L.
description: Mark Simpson is an ambitious man, but that should be expected. A three-time M.L.S. Cup winner with D.C. United as well as an accomplished indoor player, he has a new project  the Virginia Cavalry of the North American Soccer League.

title: The Early Word: Drones
description: In Todays Times:

title: The Family and Medical Leave Act, 20 Years Later
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and was chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Bill Clinton.

title: Q.& A.: Saving Space and Shows on a TiVo
description: Q.

title: 8 Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Baku
description: In this Sundays magazine, Peter Savodnik explores Bakus attempt to become a new hub for the itinerant filthy rich. In some sense, the article was born a couple years ago when Peter and I worked on a piece for Bloomberg Businessweek about Eurovision, the pan-European song contest in which American Idol meets Davos with drum machines. Azberbaijan, which isnt even really in Europe, was hoping to use its 2011 victory to jump-start a nation rebranding campaign. As it happens, it might just work out.

title: Daily Report: H.P. Directs Its Suppliers in China to Limit Student Labor
description: Hewlett-Packard, one of the worlds largest makers of computers and other electronics, is imposing new limits on the employment of students and temporary agency workers at factories across China, report Keith Bradsher and David Barboza of The New York Times.

title: Power Outage at Delhi Airport Affects Flights
description: An electrical power failure at the Indian capitals main airport disrupted the radar system on Friday, delaying some flights.

title: Is This Business for Sale Too Good to Be True?
description: My post last week that asked whether you would pay $6.2 million for a specific heating, ventilation and air-conditioning business brought a lot of great comments with lots of smart analysis. Some readers  including Fred T and vulcanalex  say that the profits this business claims to be generating sound too good to be true.

title: Pakistans Media Police
description: ISLAMABAD  Maria Khan, the host of a Pakistani television talk show, raided a massage parlor in a private residence in Lahore last week and accused the women working there of being prostitutes. Accompanied by the police, Khan and her Baat Say Baat camera crew threatened the employees with arrest, rifled through their purses, and cross-examined them about their work. The womens faces were caught on camera despite their repeated requests not to be filmed. Khan made racist comments about the parlors Chinese owner, and even went so far as to contact the father of one employee and accuse him of pimping out his daughter.

title: A Sportswriter and the Gay Super Bowl
description: Pointing you in the direction of this fine column by Chuck Culpepper of Sports on Earth on Thursday.

title: The Executors Assistant
description: Im serving as executor for my fathers estate, a role few of us are prepared for until were playing it, so I was grateful when the mail brought The American Bar Association Guide to Wills and Estates  the fourth edition of a handbook the A.B.A. began publishing in 1995.

title: Horse Meat in Food Stirs a Furor in the British Isles
description: LONDON  Few things divide British eating habits from those of Continental Europe as clearly as a distaste for consuming horse meat, so news that many Britons have unknowingly done so has prompted alarm among shoppers and plunged the countrys food industry into crisis.

title: Storms Heavy Snow and High Winds Lash at the Northeast
description: UPDATED For the latest version of this story, please click here.

title: Whaling: Who Gets to Decide if Cultural Tradition Justifies Slaughter?
description: Japanese whaling is losing money, in part because younger generations are losing their appetite for whale meat. As a result, the Japanese government is subsidizing the controversial industry.

title: A Bond Forged in Crucible of the Art World
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Answers for Boomers Affected by the Great Recession
description: Phillip B. Levine is an economics professor at Wellesley College and an associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research, an affiliate of the National Poverty Center. Last fall he was one of the authors of a study that adds a health dimension to the idea that baby boomers are the greatest victims of the Great Recession. Dr. Levine and his co-authors, Courtney C. Coile and Robin McKnight, concluded that the life expectancy of boomers ages 57 to 61 who lose their jobs (and health insurance) may be decreased by as much as three years. The life expectancy of those 62 and older, however, who lose jobs is unaffected  in part because Social Security and Medicare provide a safety net to cushion the blow. Dr. Levine took questions this past week about the research.

title: A Farewell Fit for a King
description: King Norodom Sihanouk was a deeply flawed leader with one quality that endeared him to Cambodians: He genuinely loved his people.

title: Opinion Report: Mary Jo White
description: From the editorial page

title: Einhorn Versus Apple
description: David Einhorn says he still loves Apple. But the company needs to change, the hedge fund manager says. Mr. Einhorn, head of Greenlight Capital, filed a lawsuit on Thursday to block a plan by Apple to eliminate preferred shares and urged fellow shareholders to join him. The standoff sets up an unusual clash between two sides who can each claim a huge following on Wall Street, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes.

title: A Poem for a Good Neighbor, Ed Koch
description: Dear Diary:

title: Signs of a Shift on Immigration Among G.O.P. Rank-and-File
description: With notable speed after the Nov. 6 presidential election, a number of Republican politicians and opinions makers  from House Speaker John A. Boehner to the talk show host Sean Hannity  altered their positions on immigration and expressed a new openness to comprehensive reform.

title: Friday Reading: A Helpful Guide for Wills and Estates
French Communists Abandon Hammer and Sickle
description: LONDON  The Communist Party of France has sparked a revolution among the comrades by removing the hammer and sickle from their membership cards.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Oscar Race Beyond the Grave, and Crowdsourcing Design
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has learned that selecting deceased movie figures for their Oscar night memorial reel can be as fraught as picking winners, Michael Cieply writes in The New York Times. Lobbying tends to be fierce, even though the committee that chooses whom to include is a closely guarded secret, and feelings tend to get hurt. This years awards will almost certainly include Ernest Borgnine, Charles Durning, Nora Ephron, Tony Scott, Richard Zanuck and Marvin Hamlisch, but since the Academy expanded the list to include notable film industry figures like makeup artists and publicists, there are often unpredictable honors and snubs. The commemoration of lesser-known figures has led to the exclusion of Corey Haim, Farrah Fawcett and Bea Arthur, among others, omissions that can feel less like benign neglect than a slight. The Academy maintains a much longer obituary list on Oscars.com.

title: With a Technological Boost, How To Keep It Simple and Not Sound Stupid
description: A new text-editing widget has thrown down a gauntlet to advocates of simple writing, and gone viral on Twitter. What part of that dont you understand?

title: Helping a Worrier Become a Warrior
description: Is your child a warrior, or a worrier?

title: The Gun Report: February 8, 2013
description: The big news on Thursday, of course, was of the ex-Navy reservist who, four years after being fired from the Los Angeles Police Department, vowed to kill his former colleagues. Christopher Jordan Dorner, 33, posted a 6,000-word manifesto on his Facebook page promising a violence of action before shooting and killing the daughter of a former L.A.P.D. captain who Dorner blamed for his firing, her fianc, and a police officer. Dorner also shot and wounded two officers. A sprawling manhunt ensued, and in the confusion, two women were accidentally shot by police.

title: Cold Trail and Blizzard Hamper Search for Ex-Officer in California Killings
description: BIG BEAR LAKE, Calif.  The search for the former Los Angeles police officer wanted in three killings continued throughout Friday here, even as a blizzard covered the mountains with a foot of snow. But as no new traces of the suspect were found, the authorities wondered if he had somehow slipped through their fingers.

title: Model-Morphosis | Marine Van Outryve at Creatures of the Wind
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2013 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Marine Van Outryve from One Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by James Boehmer for Nars and hair by Odile Gilbert for Krastase.

title: WWS 594E, Class #1: Overview of the Welfare State
description: Slides (pdf). Yes, they look kind of scrappy; this is a clas, not a business presentation

title: A Farewell for a King
description: Interactive Feature: A Farewell for a King

title: Full Spectrum of a Photographer Who Made Color Cool
description: PARIS  A half century ago, when photographic purity was seemingly defined by the classical black-and-white images of Henri Cartier-Bresson, Ansel Adams and Marc Riboud, the American artist Joel Meyerowitzs first step in his chosen career looked like a serious mistake: He shot in color.

title: Calls Grow Louder for Politician Accused of Rape to Resign
description: KOCHI Demands for a fresh investigation of an Indian politician accused of raping a teenager in 1996 gained momentum after the young womans mother urged the Congress Partys leader to dismiss the lawmaker.

title: Delacroixs Liberty Leading the People Is Defaced in France
description: The famous Delacroix painting Liberty Leading the People has been defaced by a vandal, BBC News reported, but the authorities say they have detained a woman accused of writing on the artwork and that any damage to it may be easily removed.

title: Corporate Hoarding and the Slow Recovery
description: Lots of talk now about Apples cash hoard, which is actually kind of amazing: this is supposedly our cutting-edge technology company, and it apparently cant find things it wants to invest in. Or more accurately, given its incredible profits, it cant find enough things to do with all the money it makes.

title: Common Core Practice | Match-Fixing, a Kings Bones, Voting Problems
description: What should soccer officials do about widespread match-fixing?

title: Behind the Scenes: 'Brave'
description: A look at how the character Merida's hair was created in "Brave."

title: Apollos Profit Nearly Doubled in 4th Quarter on Investment Gains
description: The markets have been kind to private equity firms, and Apollo Global Management is no exception.

title: Downton Abbey vs. Girls': Whos Happier?
description: BROOKLYN  Can we have too much freedom?

title: Post Office Slows Rate of Losses for Quarter
description: WASHINGTON  Holiday shipping and the 2012 election helped the Postal Service stem its losses, but the agencys financial woes continued in the first quarter, which ended Dec. 31.

title: Finally Its the Academys Turn to Vote
description: With all the momentum-building and repeat-speechifying, it may seem as if the Oscar winners are a foregone conclusion. But fear not, latecomers and fans of movies that arent Argo: Academy members do not even begin voting on the nominees until today.

title: Moscow on Ice
description: Skaters make the most of the citys efforts to transform its public spaces.

title: Snoops and Cheaters
description: I shared a hotel suite with my 20-year-old stepson, a sophomore in college. I couldnt resist reading the texts on his phone, which he left in the bathroom, and deduced that he and his friends were cheating on tests. I want to tell my husband (his dad), but if we confront him, my stepson will know I was checking his phone. Knowing we violated that trust will drive a wedge in an already tenuous relationship. Yet we find cheating abhorrent. Do we confront my stepson? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

title: Jodi Picoult Does Not Write Chick Lit
description: Terrible things happen to your characters. Your new book, The Storyteller, features a woman in Auschwitz. Past characters have included victims of a school shooting and parents of kids born with horrible diseases. Is it a little sadistic to put your characters through all this?  I dont think Im sadistic. Im superstitious. Theres a part of me that illogically believes if I write about a child with cancer, then my kids are going to be safe. If I write about a school shooting, it wont happen where we live. If I write about infidelity, then my marriage is going to be safe. Of course it does not work that way, and I know that.

title: Why Would You Ever Give Money Through Kickstarter?
description: For about three years, between the ages of 12 and 15, I spent much of my free time on Internet forums devoted to the collectible-card game Magic: The Gathering. It became an obsession, consuming my mind and becoming the only thing I wanted to talk about. And once I realized that nobody I ever met face to face was particularly interested in a long debate on the merits of Zuran Orb vis--vis Claws of Gix, I turned to the Web.

title: My Twinkie Barricade
description: I smelled like nondairy cream filling, my fingers slick with oils. I felt spongy. I had eaten an entire box of Twinkies after school, a months ration of treats, and I was in a world of consequences. I stood in the kitchen stunned by my own lapse in control and surrounded by the evidence of my savagery. I watched the clock. My father was on the way home to a debris field of plastic wrappers and a boy with near crystalline blood sugar. When he arrived, inflated in his quilted parka, he saw the story quickly, and sighed.

title: How Tough Is Daniel Day-Lewis?
description: The Big Profile By Dave Itzkoff

title: Return of a Tabloid Dreamscape
description: Thomas Adss operatic version of The Tempest, which had its premiere in 2004 at the Royal Opera House in London and arrived at the Metropolitan Opera last fall, was conceived as a capital-M Masterpiece: three acts, big cast, full chorus, Shakespearean source.

title: The 1.27.13 Issue
description: HELPING VICTIMS OF CHILD PORNOGRAPHY

title: A Secretary to Match the Setting
description: The emperor of the American outdoors usually wears a cowboy hat, for the lashing dust and searing sun in the domain of the Interior Department, one-fifth of the United States. James Watt, the most small-minded head of that agency in modern times, wore one. So did Ken Salazar, the outgoing secretary.

title: Who Made That Zipper?
description: In the 1900s, Gideon Sundback, a Swedish migr who worked at the Automatic Hook and Eye Company of New Jersey as an engineer, began to tackle one of the most difficult technical problems of his time  fastening clothing. For a woman of the era, getting dressed meant a struggle with a gantlet of buttons and hooks that stretched from bodice to skirt. Her boots alone might require navigating 20 to 30 buttons. An inventor named Whitcomb Judson had tried to solve this problem in the 1890s by designing a mechanism that allowed you to pull on a tab and automatically fasten or unfasten all the hooks. But the hooks had a tendency to pop open.

title: What Were Reading
description: Details: Yet another roundup of cocktail trends declares that the speakeasy is pass. Also, canned beer is apparently in. (But was it ever really out?)  Robert Simonson

title: How Dell Tried to Avoid Potential Buyout Pitfalls
description: If a runner is the only person in a race and runs really hard, can there still a winner? Thats the feeling I had reading through the acquisition agreement for Dell filed late Wednesday.

title: The Bag Men of Chinatown
description: The salesman, who just sold me a knock-off Celine bag, said something I couldnt understand into a walky-talky hanging from the wall. He had to check if the coast was clear, he explained. After his co-worker up front squawked back to him, he led us out of the cramped back room, through the secret door cut into the stores false rear wall and back out onto Canal Street. It was the second false wall my friend and I had passed through that day on our quest to buy knock-off designer bags for the magazines Fashion Week-inspired Nine of a Kind, in this Sundays issue.

title: Google Changes Its Ad Program to Try to Solve the Mobile Ad Riddle
description: Google has a mobile problem, and it is trying to fix it.

title: Who Wants to Be No. 1? Anyone?
description: The way college basketball is headed these days, March has some company in the madness department. January got the silliness started and now February is staging its own string of wild endings and unpredictable matchups and all the glorious byproducts of parity run amok. How do you explain five No. 1 teams falling in five consecutive weeks? How does the latest temporary No. 1, Indiana  coached by a Harbaugh brother-in-law!  forget how to play defense on the final play, making Illinoiss buzzer-beater an open layup? Why are all those big-name coaches walking around with glassy stares and throbbing headaches?

title: Storm Watch Hits Fashion Week
description: Designers, like everyone else in the city, were keeping a close eye on the weather Friday morning as the Northeast braced for a potentially crippling snowstorm. Even if the storms impact on New York is minimal, designers were warning that their shows might be delayed at Fashion Week. At the very least, it will be difficult for the hundreds of retailers, editors, models and makeup artists to get around Manhattan during shows scheduled Friday through 10 p.m.

title: Photos of The Moment | Creatures of the Wind
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Poet and Prophet of El Barrio May Soon Be a Pauper
description: Update, Feb. 12 | Many readers have expressed interest in donating to Mr. Melendez. Here is his address: P.O. Box 268, New York, N.Y. 10029-0260. Also, a fellow poet, Roberto Garcia, has begun an online fund-raising campaign through the site fundly.com. Click for his fund-raising campaign.

title: Safety Agency Investigating Brake-Light Problem in Pontiacs
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether General Motors should have included an additional 550,000 vehicles when it recalled about 8,000 cars in 2009 for a brake-light problem, according to a report the agency posted on Friday on its Web site.

title: The Lumineers, Top 40s Unlikeliest Act
description: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The Times, talks to host Ben Ratliff about his sojourn in Denver with the folk-rock band the Lumineers, one of the most rapid and instructive success stories of 2012.

title: Fire Destroys Offices of Israeli Soccer Team
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday condemned as shameful the recent protests by soccer fans here of their teams recent recruitment of two Muslim players, hours after the offices of the team were burned in what the police suspected was arson by some of those fans.

title: In the Rockies, Growing Support for Renewables
description: A new poll tracking the conservation attitudes of residents of the six Rocky Mountain States shows that support is strong for greater protection of public lands and investment in renewable energy. It also offers some clues to why public policy does not dovetail with public opinion in those areas.

title: Updates on the Winter Storm
description: A ferocious storm system buried some some parts of the Northeast in more than two feet of snow and left more than 650,000 homes and businesses without power. Journalists from The Times reported on the storm and its aftermath.

title: Better Not Rely on Style Points
description: Managers in the upper echelons of soccer tend to be an unstylish bunch, with wardrobes that speak less of Savile Row than of the bargain rack on the Island of Misfit Clothes.

title: Patient Voices: Eating Disorders
description: Anorexia, bulimia, binge eating and excessive exercising  eight men, women and children discuss living with and recovering from an eating disorder.

title: To Make a Good Parm Sandwich, Stick to the Basics
description: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

title: Instagramming Fashion Week
description: A selection of your Instagram photos from New York Fashion Week.

title: The Crucible
description: Jim Crace grew up along Londons northern perimeter in a housing estate that felt, he has said, like the last building before the countryside began. In one direction stretched an interminably rural England, in the other an interminable metropolis. Through this accident of childhood, Crace developed an edgeland imagination that has powered his writing ever since, attracting him to dramatic showdowns between clashing values. His characters typically face some encroaching, inhospitable new order, as in Harvest, his glorious new novel, where they must scramble to adapt or be mowed down.

title: Macmillan Will Settle a Lawsuit on E-Books
description: 7:31 p.m. | Updated

title: Call of the Wild
description: Years ago, when I was teaching at Berkeley, I received a peculiar note circulated among faculty members by the head of the humanities center. Maurice Sendak had been invited to give a public lecture, the note said, and he was scheduled to arrive on campus very soon. But he had asked for a NordicTrack machine and 12 down pillows, items that my colleague was scrambling to find. I had no down pillows to spare, but I did, as it happened, have a NordicTrack gathering dust in my basement. Thus began my acquaintance with Maurice, an acquaintance I treasured, though it never blossomed to the point where I dared ask him what he wanted with all of those pillows.

title: Cellphone Service Without Signing on the Dotted Line
description: LAST month, I upgraded my sons cellphone  something he had looked forward to with breathless anticipation ever since his last cellphone drowned in a California pool over the summer.

title: U.N. Says 5,000 Syrians a Day Are Now Fleeing War
description: GENEVA  Syrias conflict is now driving 5,000 people out of the country each day in an increasingly desperate scramble for safety, the United Nations refugee agency said Friday as it reported a surge in their numbers to nearly 800,000.

title: Penn Station Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion Weak: Give That Coachs Outfit a Red Card
description: LONDON  Alex Ferguson pulled a woolly hat around his ruddy face. Rafael Benitez stood in a snowstorm in a suit that did not fit. The usually suave Andr Villas-Boas resorted to covering his legs with a grandpa-by-the-fire-style blanket.

title: Democracy, Hacked
description: In a little more than a decade, since he won the popular vote but lost the presidential election to George W. Bush in 2000, the former vice president and Tennessee senator Al Gore has been a best-selling author; starred in an Oscar-winning documentary, An Inconvenient Truth (2006); won the Nobel Peace Prize, in 2007, for his environmental activism; and made a fortune some have estimated to be bigger than Mitt Romneys, thanks in part to the recent sale of his stake in the Current TV network to Al Jazeera. In The Future: Six Drivers of Global Change, Gore takes on a subject whose scale matches that of his achievements and ambition.

title: When Dinner Is Over, and a Child Is Still Hungry
description: Im quandary snatching today.

title: Hard-Luck Cases
description: The men in Jess Walters pungent new story collection, We Live in Water, are coming apart. These men  and they are exclusively men, save a few catalytic female characters  are what society (and ex-wives) commonly label disappointments. Trading in ill-considered choices, they have made a habit of letting folks down  their women, their kids, their friends, their creditors and, chiefly, themselves. Walters protagonists endure a buffet of self-inflicted misfortune, everything from meth addiction to dodgy parenting, often served in a combo platter with a side of unlucky in love. His characters are all searching, with varying levels of commitment and insight. None succeed.

title: Lady Lazarus
description: It is hard to believe that if Sylvia Plath had not taken her own life  in 1963, at the age of 30  she would quite possibly still be alive today. Her rival Adrienne Rich, three years her elder, died just last year. But how could Plath live to comb gray hair? Her suicide does not seem like something that just happened to happen. In her poetry, she forces us to see her death as a destiny and a culmination: The woman is perfected. / Her dead /Body wears the smile of accomplishment, / The illusion of a Greek necessity, she wrote in her last poem, Edge, just six days before she died.

title: Spread the Word
description: When you read David Shields, the first thing you learn is that he takes literature very seriously. The second thing you learn is how seriously he takes his taking seriously of literature. Theres a striking moment in the closing pages of his new book, How Literature Saved My Life, when he tells us that he is interested only in literature that obliterates the boundary between life and art. Acutely aware of our mortal condition, he writes, I find books that simply allow us to escape existence a staggering waste of time (literature matters so much to me I can hardly stand it). If there were such a thing as a quintessentially Shieldsian pronouncement, this may be it, with its odd tonal mixture of the bombastic and the beseeching. Shields wants you to know that he is a writer for whom neither life nor art is a matter to be taken lightly.

title: A Public Discussion of Secret Strikes
description: The Senate confirmation hearing of John O. Brennan, President Obamas nominee for C.I.A. director, focused on drones and targeted killing.

title: War Machines
description: The historian Daniel Boorstin once complained to me about the Smithsonian Institutions decision in 1980 to delete the final two words from the name of its Museum of History and Technology. Boorstin had a point. Scholars of other fields do often tend to underestimate the influence of technology. Although most of us know that World War II brought us radar, the literature of that titanic conflict is by no means exempt from this phenomenon. For instance, the biographer Joseph P. Lash subtitled his 1976 wartime account of Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill The Partnership That Saved the West, in response to which I once heard a British scholar carp, If Lash is right, then why did all those scientists and intelligence officers and factory workers bother working so hard?

title: Avoiding Defeat
description: Two graphs introduce the text of The Endgame, Michael R. Gordon and Bernard E. Trainors instructive yet analytically shallow account of the Iraq war after the fall of Baghdad. The first depicts weekly attacks in Iraq from early 2004 to mid-2010, the second civilian deaths from January 2006 to May 2010. The graphs present identical images: bad news getting worse until early 2007, then pronounced improvement. The message is clear: In early 2007 a decided turn occurred. As with the Civil War after Gettysburg or the war in the Pacific after Midway, a conflict that had been going badly suddenly started heading in the right direction.

title: Attention, Shoppers
description: In her introduction to Overdressed: The Shockingly High Cost of Cheap Fashion, the journalist Elizabeth L. Cline recalls buying seven pairs of $7 shoes at Kmart. Regret follows, and soon afterward, a wardrobe inventory. When Cline cleans out her closet she discovers, among other things, 61 tops, 60 T-shirts, 15 cardigans and hooded sweatshirts, 21 skirts and 20 pairs of shoes, most of which she never wore.

title: Leaving the Man Cave Hand in Hand, Laugh by Laugh
description: Pamela Taylor and EamesYates were married in Snowmass, Colo., in 2006, a few days after a howling September snowstorm. Yet the wedding took place outside as planned, in a grove of evergreen trees, with 200 shivering guests.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE QUEEN OF KATWE  A Story of Life, Chess, and One Extraordinary Girls Dream of Becoming a Grandmaster.  By Tim Crothers.Scribner, $26.

title: Working Stiffs
description: Gene Kerrigans new police procedural, THE RAGE (Europa, paper, $17), isnt your typical Irish crime novel with moody cops and colorful crooks who talk like poets and act like animals. The singular characters who go about their business in Dublins crippled economy may be on opposite sides of the law, but in Kerrigans book theyre all working-class stiffs struggling to get by.

title: See for Yourself
description: When it comes to picking childrens books, I am a lot like those old ladies you see in Upper West Side supermarkets, tapping, squeezing and smelling the melons on display: Is it ripe, dear? Bringing a childrens book into your home is not something to take lightly. An obliging parent may be asked to read it a hundred times. Nay, a thousand times. The big-eyed sheep that seemed so cute while you were flipping through pages in the store soon begins to vex. Over time, reading the book becomes like ripping off a Band-Aid. Even small defects  an irritating drawing, the misuse of the word presently, a character who speaks in rhyme  can form blisters on the parental soul. No, darling, not again. Lets pick another book, please. Ive seen the best minds of my generation destroyed by the 38th reading of Knuffle Bunny Too.

title: Common Goals
description: A small town in Maine is flooded with Somali refugees looking for a better way of life. The soccer team gets a jolt of inspiration and outstanding play from its new, non-English-speaking players. They might just have a chance to beat their archrivals! At least, so says Tom Bouchard, the handsome, nice-guy team captain and narrator. Getting in the way are Toms nasty, dimwitted girlfriend Cherisse, his hapless bad-boy friend Donnie, and prejudices and culture clashes on both sides.

title: Daughter of the House
description: As a girl, I was obsessed with prostitutes. The hookers I saw on television wore silk kimonos and had cigarettes permanently attached to their lips  mean on the outside but like bruised baby birds on the inside. My experiences baby-sitting showed me I wasnt the only girl interested in a so-called life of sin. At 12, I once picked up a daisy-covered address book, to find only one entry, under P, Prostitute, followed by a list of massage parlor numbers.

title: Seven Stories
description: Vampires have had their moment in young adult literature, as has dystopia, so it takes an idea of real originality to stand out from the vamp/love/fate/doom pack. In this book, the idea is sevenfold and the talented writer who works his considerable magic is Marcus Sedgwick, author of other acclaimed Y.A. novels including White Crow and Revolver.

title: Editors Choice
description: SANDALWOOD DEATH (University of Oklahoma, paper, $24.95) and POW! (Seagull, $27.50), by Mo Yan. Translated by Howard Goldblatt. Abuse of power, gross materialism, corruption and venality are the targets of the Chinese Nobelists satirical novels.

title: Paperback Row
description: HORSESHOE CRABS AND VELVET WORMS: The Story of the Animals and Plants That Time Has Left Behind,  by Richard Fortey. (Vintage, $16.95.) A paleontologist, Fortey has spent most of his life looking at fossils. Here he pursues the distinguished groups of organisms that have survived the many cataclysms thrown at them over the past 450 million years: horseshoe crabs and velvet worms, but also lungfish, musk oxen, jellyfish and cockroaches.

title: Inside the List
description: HER MOMENT: Sister Souljahs new novel, A Deeper Love Inside, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 7. Souljah is having a good run: this is her third consecutive best seller, and earlier this month the Web site For Harriet included her debut novel, The Coldest Winter Ever, on its list of 100 recommended books by black women. (Other authors on the list included canonical figures like Toni Morrison, Octavia Butler and Zora Neale Hurston, as well as celebrated younger ones like Edwidge Danticat, Martha Southgate and ZZ Packer.)

title: Up Front
description: Allison Glock, who reviews Jess Walters new story collection this week, knew early on that she wanted to be a writer. My mother is a former beauty queen turned shrink, she explained via email. If that isnt fodder for a writing career  coupled with the fact that I would never be a beauty queen or shrink  I dont know what is. When I was very young, working in my grandfathers corner grocery in West Virginia, I would sneak on top of the giant freezers and hide so I could watch folks come in and out, listening to what they said, what they didnt say, my grandfather at the register in his apron, smoking, or in the back making hamburg from an entire side of beef. (After breaking down the cow, cleaver in hand, hed flex his biceps and dare me to hang off of it.) I remember feeling like everything I was watching was operatic somehow. Like I was privy to secrets. I knew even then that if I kept quiet and paid attention, my world would be filled with stories. That this suggestion of boundless possibility happened in a tar-strip-road factory town was an additional gift. Stories that count are everywhere, all the time. Beauty too.

title: Stargazing: New York Fashion Week, Day 1
description: The predicted blizzard of 2013 was still a day away when New York Fashion Week started on Thursday, yet it was already the main subject of conversation as the shows began at the tents at Lincoln Center. Topic A: What would the snow mean for those carefully planned outfits of the front-row regulars?

title: Live Streaming Now: Jason Wu
description: Check in daily to see in-the-moment backstage, on and off the runway photos from select New York Fashion Week shows.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Beautyblender Cosmetic Sponge
description: In the fall and winter, dont women want velvety skin? asks makeup artist Maki Ryoke, who turned out one pristine complexion after another backstage at Costello Tagliapietra. The answer is obvious; the challenge, however, is actually achieving a flawless, even-toned face that looks completely natural. Want Ryokes advice? Put down the foundation brush, forget about using your fingertips and opt for her favorite skin-perfecting tool: the Beautyblender cosmetic sponge. Designed to be used in a dabbing motion, It gives you the effect of actual skin texture, so it amazingly looks like youre not wearing anything, she says. In addition, its rounded egg-shape allows you to blend makeup without leaving behind a single streak. For the Costello Tagliapietra runway show yesterday, Ryoke gave the models faces a slightly dewy finish by first wetting the sponge with mineral water. Im quite lazy, and the sponge does all the work, she says with a laugh.

title: The Church and the Mandate
description: Last Friday, President Obama offered religious leaders his latest (unnecessary) compromise on the so-called birth control mandate.

title: A Million Pieces of Home
description: Unless theres terrible news Africa doesnt get much notice in this part of the world. But at the Venice Biennale six years ago it was the object of thousands of beauty-bedazzled eyes, even if some of those eyes didnt know at first what they were looking at.

title: The Art of El Anatsui
description: The Ghanaian artist El Anatsui is the subject of a retrospective exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Buy, Buy, Buy
description: Analysts have been overwhelmingly bullish on Apple stock, even at $705 a share. Now that the stock has dropped 36 percent, they still recommend investors buy it, though some are starting to waver.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Karen Russell talks about Vampires in the Lemon Grove; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Adam Kirsch discusses two new biographies of Sylvia Plath; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Weekend Fare
description: A Valentines Day-themed cooking class for singles and couples at BLT Fish, 21 West 17th Street, in Chelsea, will cover how to shuck oysters on Saturday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Amy Eubanks, the executive chef, will offer tips on how to open the bivalves during the class, which includes a three-course lunch at $80 per person or $130 per couple. To book a seat, call (212) 691-8888 or e-mail info@bltfish.com.

title: Fighting Off the Coffee Curse
description: Until this year, John Vandermeer, an ecologist and coffee researcher at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, had never lost a tree to fungus.

title: Photos of The Moment | Kenneth Cole
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Activism at Its Best: Greenpeaces Push to Stop the Pulping of Rain Forests
description: Theres much about 20th-century-style environmentalism that doesnt work in this era. Demonizing Big Coal or Big Oil in climate campaigns gives a pass to those of us filling up our gas tanks or relying on electricity at home.

title: Online Abuse of Teen Girls in Kashmir Leads to Arrests
description: SRINAGAR Online abuse and a fatwa aimed at a rock band of Muslim teenage girls in Kashmir have led to arrests and a threat of a lawsuit.

title: Shakespeares Globe to Stage Henry VI at Historic Battle Sites
description: Hot on the heels of the news that a New York theater company will be staging Richard III in a suddenly historically correct parking lot, Shakespeares Globe has announced that it will take a touring production of the Henry VI trilogy to four English battle sites that figure in the plays.

title: Bad Hair Days at Pixar
description: Alongside Life of Pi and Game of Thrones, Brave was a big winner at the Visual Effects Societys VES Awards, held on Tuesday in Los Angeles and honoring yes, visual effects. Pixars story of the archery-loving reluctant princess earned four prizes, including best animated feature and best animated character, for its heroine, Merida. It shouldve really earned a prize for her hair.

title: Off the Charts: Its a Mans Recovery
description: Women lost fewer jobs than men during the recession, but since the total number of workers hit bottom in December 2009, the bulk of the new jobs have gone to men.

title: This Weeks Movies: Feb. 8
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the new Steven Soderbergh film Side Effects, the comedy Identity Thief and a drama set in postwar Germany, Lore. See all of this weeks reviews here.

title: The Cookie Titan of Tucson
description: Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, examines the power of sales on a door-to-door mission with Mary Ruiz, a 10-year-old Girl Scout cookie-selling powerhouse.

title: Popcast: The Lumineers, Top 40s Unlikeliest Act
description: This week, Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The Times, talks to host Ben Ratliff about his sojourn in Denver with the folk-rock band the Lumineers, one of the most rapid and instructive success stories of 2012.

title: SUNY Trustees Vote Unanimously to Shutter Long Island College Hospital
description: The State University of New York trustees voted unanimously Friday to close Long Island College Hospital, saying it was in such bad shape financially that it threatened the viability of the universitys Brooklyn medical school and related facilities.

title: A Shortage of Apartments for Sale
description: The number of real estate listings in Manhattan reached a 10-year low last month.

title: Buyer Rivalries Resume
description: Heres another byproduct of the apartment shortage: bidding wars are back.

title: Dear Owner: Please Sell
description: A shortage of New York City apartments for sale is forcing real estate agents to take extreme, if not desperate, measures in order to conjure up listings.

title: Filed Under Awesome Use Cases
description: Via GigaOM: How two scientists are using the New York Times archives to predict the future

title: Bookshelf: Be Mine
description: New picture books celebrate romantic and friendly affection.

title: Family Foundations Prepare for the Next Generation
description: AS parents, we worry about our children. And if we have more than one, we worry about how they will interact with each other, not just when theyre young but when theyve grown up. Independence is great; interdependence is what keeps them together when were gone.

title: Bookshelf: Be Mine
description: I HAIKU YOU  Written and illustrated by Betsy E. Snyder. 32 pp. Random House. $9.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 8)

title: Calendar: Coming Cruises in Japan, China, Honduras
description: Kyoto, Japan The Clipper Odyssey, a 118-passenger cruise ship owned by the luxury travel company Abercrombie & Kent, will travel around Japan, departing from Kyoto on May 24. Because of its small size, the ship will be able to dock in shallow ports like the one on Miyajima Island, home of the Itsukushima Shrine. But its not too small to fit a library, gym, outdoor pool, a hair salon and other amenities onboard. Rather than a fading mega-band, the star attraction is Geoffrey Kent, the owner of the travel outfitter, right, who will be on hand to take credit (or blame) for the journey. (abercrombiekent.com)

title: Movie Review | Side Effects
description: A Times critic reviews Side Effects.

title: How Children Learn to Sell
description: In this weekends Your Money column and an accompanying video, I highlight the exploits of Mary Ruiz, a 10-year-old girl in Tucson who sold more Girl Scout cookies last year than nearly any other child in the United States. But you dont need to be a Girl Scout to pick up all of the skills that come from looking people in the eye and trying to get them to part with their money through sheer force of verbiage.

title: Images From the Kumbh Mela
Seven Days on the Queen Mary 2
description: The first rule about traveling between America and England aboard the Queen Mary 2, the flagship of the Cunard Line and the worlds largest ocean liner, is to never refer to your adventure as a cruise. You are, it is understood, making a crossing. The second rule is to refrain, when speaking to those who travel frequently on Cunards ships, from calling them regulars. The term of art  it is best pronounced while approximating Maggie Smiths cut-glass accent on Downton Abbey  is Cunardists.

title: A Winter Voyage on the Queen Mary 2
description: Dancing, dining and even a moment when time disappears during a trip on the giant ship.

title: Pelosi to Bring Sandy Hook Guest to State of the Union
description: Representative Jim Langevins effort to bring victims of gun violence to the State of the Union address has a high-profile new participant, Jeremy W. Peters reports:

title: Packing for Sea and Sun
description: From shorts to sweaters, two cruise veterans share what they plan to pack for coming voyages.

title: Scenes From a Cruise
description: The peculiar world of life on a boat, as seen through the lens of Damon Winter, a Pulitzer-winning Times photographer.

title: Rethinking Payphones With NYTimes APIs
description: Recently, The New York Times was one of many partners involved in a hack day to generate ideas for rejuvenating and repurposing New York Citys 11,412 payphones. Ultimately, the goal is to contribute meaningfully and geekily to the larger effort to make the phones relevant to 21st-century city dwellers.

title: One Dish, One Hour
description: Fast-food from a restaurant is not as fast as you think. There is drive time to and from the restaurant, waiting time to pay and collect your food, and then it still takes a few minutes to sort through it and set it on the table at home. (Assuming you dont just eat it in the car.) But if you are willing to invest a few more minutes of time for a more healthful option, you can still make a homemade meal from scratch in less than an hour, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health column:

title: Comfort Food for a Blizzard
description: The snowstorm is approaching, and weather forecasters say its going to be one of the worst in a century. We know youre going to be home-bound, and everyone will be hungry, so we picked three of our favorite comfort food recipes to help you get through it.

title: Is There Anything We Cant Do on a Cruise?
description: Cruise lines keep adding to their itineraries in an industry push to get travelers of all stripes on deck. While many voyages still accommodate the middle-aged vacationer content to see the Caribbean from a chaise longue, an increasing number offer less-sedentary vacationers everything from glacier treks to trips to the ballet.

title: More Than Pushing Cookies
description: TUCSON  When you buy a box of Girl Scout cookies and devour 10 in a single sitting, as untold numbers of people will in the next month, you are propping up a pretty sizable enterprise.

title: Movie Review | Identity Thief
description: A Times critic reviews Identity Thief.

title: Migrating Back to the Wilds of the Stage
description: Among the many unusual aspects of Jennifer Monsons Live Dancing Archive, which opens a two-weekend run at the Kitchen on Thursday, it takes place inside a theater. Unusual, that is, for Ms. Monson, an esteemed choreographer and improviser who, for the past decade or so has situated most of her work outdoors.

title: Over 80 Cruises and Counting
description: When Richard Brooks retired in 1989 from a banking career in England, he embraced life on the sea. His first cruise was in 1985; he now estimates that hes taken more than 80. He and his wife, Valerie, live part of the year in Wheathampstead, a small village 20 miles north of London, and in Marbella, Spain. Below are excerpts from a conversation about the highs and lows of cruising, and where the values lie.

title: His Perfect Role Is His Current One
description: This is already the hardest show Ive ever done, Danny Burstein said, wolfing down a burger and a beer after a recent day of rehearsal for Talleys Folly. Its tough to take this busy actor entirely seriously  not because Lanford Wilsons 1979 play isnt daunting. It requires Mr. Burstein to share the stage with a single co-star, Sarah Paulson, in a tense romantic pas de deux, for roughly 100 uninterrupted minutes.

title: Spend a Year With a Football Coach, and He May Change Your Mind
description: It has been quite a month for football coaches. Nick Sabans joyless visage, already set in bronze on the Alabama campus, filled TV screens after the Tides latest title as a kind of national avatar for excellences grim rewards.

title: Movie Review | Lore
description: A Times critic reviews Lore.

title: The Netflix Fix
description: With deep pockets and a keen eye, Ted Sarandos is fusing Hollywood and Silicon Valley into a new TV paradigm.

title: Court Hears Arguments on Judges Rejection of S.E.C.-Citigroup Deal
description: 4:56 p.m. | Updated

title: At Retreat, Bill Clinton Tries to Rally House Democrats
description: LEESBURG, Va.  We miss you! someone in the audience of House Democrats shouted at the 42nd president of the United States.

title: Onstage, Trying to Connect to a Faraway War
description: Three blocks from Washington Square Park and more than 6,000 miles from Afghanistan, a group of graduate acting students ran through lines and tried to imagine something that for many in their generation is unimaginable: Whats it like to go to war and return home to a society that doesnt understand what youve been through?

title: Following a Herd of Bulls on Apple
description: Last September, Apple shares hit a record $705. And to the overwhelming majority of Wall Street analysts, that meant one thing: buy.

title: Leaving Las Vegas
description: The Mercedes SL in the 1950s helped turn the company into a luxury powerhouse, but the modern SL has grown fat, rich and happy.

title: On Our Radar: Snowstorms and Climate Change
description: A re-examination of the interrelationships between weather patterns like Fridays impending blizzard in the Northeast, greenhouse gas emissions and climate change. [Union of Concerned Scientists]

title: Respect for the Past, and Adventure in Their Future
description: In many ways, Caroline Trang Nguyen and Daniel Tran Gien epitomize the melding of cultures, interests and attitudes for which this nation is so widely known. Their early years were deeply influenced by the crucible that was the long conflict in Vietnam, from which their parents escaped, hers to Germany and his to Canada.

title: The Rockets Catch Fire
description: It was one year ago this week that a little-known Taiwanese-American point guard from Harvard became a global superstar.

title: New BlackBerry Will Definitely Not Be Big in Japan
description: Although Japanese consumers are among the worlds most voracious consumers of smartphones, BlackBerry said on Thursday that they wont be getting its new line of phones.

title: Week in Review: Just CC the Justice Department on Those E-Mails
description: David Einhorn sues Apple over its plan for stocks. | E-mails imply JPMorgan knew some mortgage deals were bad. | A guilty plea and a big fine for the Royal Bank of Scotland in the rate-rigging case. | Big law firms are backing away from trusts and estates. | S.&P. e-mails on the mortgage crisis show alarm and gallows humor. | Taking Dell private is the biggest challenge yet for its founder. | Investors seek Herbalifes elusive sales data.

title: These Doctors Make Condo Calls
description: Changes in modern medicine largely ushered out the era of the family doctor decades ago, but at one condominium building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, doctors are once again making house calls.

title: Library Chairman: Renovation Budget Still A Work in Progress
description: The budget plan for the New York Public Librarys renovation project is preliminary and imprecise at this point, Neil L. Rudenstine, the librarys chairman, acknowledged in a letter last month to trustees that was obtained by The New York Times.

title: Mets Sign Lyon for Bullpen
description: The Mets announced they signed right-hander Brandon Lyon to join a bullpen restocked with veteran arms.

title: Amish Sect Leader Sentenced to 15 Years in Hair-Cutting Attacks
description: The leader of a dissident Amish sect was sentenced on Friday to 15 years in prison for a series of bizarre beard- and hair-cutting attacks on other Ohio Amish that drew national attention.

title: Wave of Arson Attacks in Brazil Is Tied to Reports of Inmate Abuse
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A wave of arson attacks is spreading across a state in southern Brazil, largely targeting police installations, public buses and even the homes of prison officials in a region that has traditionally ranked among the countrys safest.

title: French Landmarks
description: Frances carmaking tradition, which might be described as ignoring tradition altogether, is on full display at Retromobile in Paris. Here are some highlights of this years exhibition.

title: Chinese Workers Rights
description: Call it a Lunar New Years present to Chinese students. Hewlett Packard issued new guidelines Friday, days before the start of the annual holiday when much of that country shuts down, requiring is suppliers to only employ high school and college students who actively volunteer to do the work. Students should also be free to leave upon reasonable notice and have the ability to complain about unfair practices.

title: U.N. Calls on Papua New Guinea to Curb Violence After Burning Death of Woman
description: GENEVA  Spurred by the killing this week of a young woman accused of witchcraft in Papua New Guinea, the United Nations on Friday called on the country to address increasing vigilante violence against people accused of sorcery and to revoke a controversial sorcery law.

title: BMW Designers Bring Their Approach to Olympic Bobsled
description: Its never too soon to start promoting the Olympics, especially if youve paid what NBC and its partners have paid for the television rights  $775 million  to next years winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

title: The Sweet Spot | A Trip to MoMA
description: From the Museum of Modern Art, A. O. Scott and David Carr go rogue and examine some of the more interesting works on view.

title: Feb. 10  16
description: Exploding Words, Exploding Time

title: On the Market | Los Angeles
description: A Malibu modern, a Beverly Hills Mediterranean, a Beachwood Canyon contemporary, a Bel Air French Traditional and a Spanish split-level.

title: Sally LaPointe: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: The Sweet Spot: Feb. 8
description: From the Museum of Modern Art, A. O. Scott and David Carr go rogue and examine some of the more interesting works in the galleries.

title: Jenni Kayne: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: By Gender and by Age, an Unequal Recovery
description: SINCE the job market in the United States hit bottom more than three years ago, men have benefited from the recovery far more than woman have, with middle-aged women doing particularly poorly.

title: Japanese Still Seeking Cause of 787 Smoke
description: Japans investigation of a battery that was smoking on a Boeing 787 flight there last month has not yet determined if the incident started in the same way as a fire on another 787 in Boston, a Japanese official said Friday.

title: Social Media Updates From Tunisia, as an Opposition Leader Is Buried
description: Last Updated, 3:44 p.m. Activists, bloggers and journalists in Tunisia posted a stream of images on social networks Friday, showing thousands of mourners packed into the largest cemetery in the capital, Tunis, for the funeral of Chokri Belaid, a leading opposition figure whose assassination two days ago triggered a wave of street protests against the Islamist ruling party.

title: Travel and the Storm
description: The winter storm dubbed Nemo by some has wreaked havoc on travel, leading to the cancellation of thousands of flights in the Northeast, the suspension of Amtrak service between New York City and Boston, and a ban on driving after 4 p.m. in Massachusetts. The Times will continue to report on the storms impact on travel in its live storm updates through the weekend.

title: In the West End, Directors in Residence
description: LONDONThats that theater taken care of, then!

title: Counselors Penalty for Child Sexual Abuse Is Halved, to 50 Years
description: The states corrections department has reduced by more than half the prison sentence of Nechemya Weberman, the unlicensed Hasidic counselor from Brooklyn who was convicted in December of child sexual abuse charges.

title: Passing On the Family Business
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, discusses the issues raised when wealthy families bring their children into the family foundation. For one, the next generation may favor different types of charities than their parents. And then, there are the families that have trouble getting along.

title: Living In | Millstone, N.J.
description: Because of strict zoning, many neighborhoods in this Monmouth County township consist of just a few large houses on sizable properties.

title: Street Lighting by Mother Nature
description: Driving through Millstone, one will stop for a crossing deer  or maybe even a horse  before having to worry about a traffic light. Thats because this town of 37 square miles doesnt have any, or much in the way of streetlights, either.

title: Success and Failure, Fashionably Speaking, in the Premier League
description: Sarah Lyall of The Times has a delightful article online now about the fashion successes (few) and failures (many) among Premier League managers. A taste:

title: Q & A
description: Altering Co-op Share Allocations

title: The Daily Do | Costello Tagliapietra
description: The classic uptown ponytail, worn low and over the ears, was modernized with some downtown texture.

title: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
description: 5:12 p.m. | Updated With a real blizzard bearing down on New England, the policy wonks in the White House tried every which way they could on Friday to warn of the dangers of a different kind of storm.

title: Big Ticket | An Architectural Mash-Up Sold for $19.5 Million
description: A full-floor condominium at One York, the glassy 21st-century tower that uses a pair of 19th-century TriBeCa loft buildings as its base and launching pad  the Mexican starchitect Enrique Nortens bold interpretation of an architectural mash-up  sold for $19.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Southeastern Asset Management to Fight Dells Takeover
description: 7:44 p.m. | Updated One of the biggest investors in Dell said on Friday that it would oppose the companys plans to go private, setting up a major potential roadblock for the biggest buyout since the financial crisis.

title: Young Conductor With a Mind of His Own
description: In recent years the orchestra world has been galvanized by two exciting conductors in their 30s: Gustavo Dudamel and Yannick Nzet-Sguin. Before long people may be talking about another conductor in that age bracket: the Spaniard Pablo Heras-Casado, 35, who led an impressive concert with the Orchestra of St. Lukes at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

title: Bazaar Bomb Claimed by Taliban Kills at Least 11 in Northwest Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A car bomb ripped through a town bazaar in northwestern Pakistans tribal belt on Friday, killing 11 people and wounding at least 31, local officials said. The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility.

title: When Can a Child Go Solo at a Ski Lodge (or Anywhere Else)?
description: So, what would you think if I set the kiddo up in the lodge with some hot cocoa and an iPad while I took a solo run down the mountain?

title: A German Rushes Past Skiings Dominant Woman
description: SCHLADMING, Austria  Maria Hfl-Riesch of Germany beat the overall World Cup leader, Tina Maze of Slovenia, to win the super combined on Friday at the Alpine skiing world championships with an aggregate time of 2 minutes 39.92 seconds. The 2010 Olympic gold medalist in the discipline, Hfl-Riesch edged Maze, who was tied for first with Anna Fenninger of Austria after the downhill leg, by 46-hundredths of a second.

title: Just a Storm? Not After the Hurricane
description: Perhaps in any other year, the noreaster would have been met with little more than a shrug in the New York region. Sure, some people would still have stocked up on batteries, water, food and snow shovels. But even they would have salted these purchases with knowing complaints about too much hype.

title: Chocolate Mousse
description: Melissa Clark shows how to make a chocolate mousse for Valentines Day that doesnt use cream or butter.

title: With No Confirmed Medicare Chief for 6 Years, Obama Tries Again
description: President Obama has renominated Marilyn B. Tavenner to run the agency in charge of Medicare and Medicaid, and his action provided a reminder that the agency has been without a Senate-confirmed chief for more than six years.

title: For Your Sweetheart, and More
description: There may be one true love, but there is no one true way to do dinner on Valentines Day. If youre paired off, you could book the traditional table for two at a restaurant. It will be filled with other couples doing the same, attempting to ignore one another while pitching woo over oysters on the half shell.

title: Grammys Will Honor Music Teachers
description: The Grammy Awards are adding a new honor for music teachers. Neil Portnow, the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, announced the new award for music educators, which will be presented for the first time next year. He made the announcement on Thursday evening at an event for the Grammy Foundations Music Preservation Project at the Saban Theater in Los Angeles.

title: A Good and Simple Chocolate Mousse
description: For years, chocolate mousse was off the menu in our house. My husband, Daniel, doesnt eat cream or milk, which pretty much meant than unless I wanted to substitute tofu or coconut milk (been there, wont be back), that fluffy dessert was something Id only be eating in restaurants.

title: Some Ratings Twists for Americans
description: Everything is not what it seems when it comes to the plot and characters of The Americans on FX, a spy thriller that follows a pair of K.G.B. agents living undercover in the suburbs of Washington D.C. during the Reagan era, and that appears to be the case for the shows ratings as well.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Lynda Barrys Freddie Stories
description: Two books are new on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. The Freddie Stories, by the cartoonist Lynda Barry, is at No. 3. It chronicles the ups and downs of Freddie, the teenage member of the dysfunctional Mullen family. It is published by Drawn & Quarterly. At No. 4 is the deluxe edition of The Books of Magic, by Neil Gaiman. It is published by DC Comics. It is illustrated by a quartet of powerhouse artists  John Bolton, Charles Vess, Paul Johnson and Scott Hampton. The story is about Timothy Hunter, a young boy on a tour through the magical realms of the DC Universe as mystical forces try to determine whether he will be the worlds most powerful mage.

title: A Bold Fowl, and Its Not Chicken
description: IT IS JUST AS EASY to roast as a chicken, but tastes immeasurably better. It is quite popular in Canada and Britain, and in France and Italy every butcher has it (cheaper than chicken, too).

title: Bolshoi Ballet Considers Suing One of Its Own
description: MOSCOW  The Bolshoi Ballet administration threatened to file a lawsuit against the dancer Nikolai Tsiskaridze on Friday, after he called for the theaters top executives to be dismissed over its response to the Jan. 17 acid attack on the ballets artistic director, Sergei Filin.

title: Braving the Elements for Jason Wu
description: Fashion Week is proceeding as normal, despite the icy sidewalks, a serious storm threat and the sudden absence of all of the beautiful people in their beautiful clothes and stilettos.

title: Book Review Podcast: Karen Russells Uncanny Stories
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Joy Williams reviews Vampires in the Lemon Grove, the new collection of short stories by Karen Russell. Ms. Williams writes:

title: French Ingenuity on Four Wheels
description: Paris  Soon after the turn of the 20th century, Marcel Leyat, like many mechanically inclined young men, decided to build a motorcar.

title: Stalled Out on Teslas Electric Highway
description: WASHINGTON  Having established a fast-charging foothold in California for its electric cars, Tesla Motors has brought its formula east, opening two ultrafast charging stations in December that would, in theory, allow a speedy electric-car road trip between here and Boston.

title: Like an Aging Elvis, Star Retains Its Power
description: Mercedes-Benz couldnt have known it at the time. But from the moment the SL300 flashed its novel gullwing doors at the New York auto show of 1954, this sports car began building Mercedes from an American obscurity into the luxury powerhouse it is today.

title: Succeeding With Excess
description: Long Americas most popular six-figure convertible, the Mercedes-Benz SL-Class has counted many doctors among its owners.

title: Cooking for Hizzoner
description: She was 24 years old and working as a personal chef for the first time ever. He was newly elected as New Yorks mayor, and therefore also new to the role of chief occupant and host of Gracie Mansion. Rozanne Gold worked for Edward I. Koch only 10 months, but they were formative for her as a young chef.

title: AARP Will Embrace Lifes Possibilities During Grammys
description: AARP will seek to cultivate a more contemporary image with a big new brand campaign that, to underline the message the advertising intends to convey, will make its debut during the CBS broadcast of the Grammy Awards on Sunday night.

title: Dear Valentine, I Hate It When You ...
description: HAVE you decided what to get for your valentine this year? You could try something classic, like chocolates. Or something blingy, like earrings. Or sexy, like lingerie.

title: Newtown Survivor to Attend State of the Union Address
description: Among the victims of gun violence who will be sitting in the House chamber on Tuesday night when President Obama delivers his State of the Union address will be a teacher who survived the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

title: Rooting for Fighting Irish, Even While at Duke
description: What makes you fall head over heels in love with a team? The usual fairy tale involves fathers and hometowns and afternoons spent at the ballpark, a closeness that rarely happens in other contexts.

title: Think Like a Doctor: A Confused and Terrified Patient Solved
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out the diagnosis for a 55-year-old man who was recovering from a terrible injury and suddenly became confused and paranoid. More than 250 readers wrote in with some very thoughtful assessments of this patients problem. Remarkably, 70 readers were able to make the diagnosis.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 1
description: VFiles celebrates at Bow, and Richard Chai parties at Mister H.

title: Photos of The Moment | General Idea
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 8
description: A view of the day in sports, including an Austrians celebration on a home ski course.

title: Do We Detect a Bit of a Chill?
description: Maybe it was the killer flu, the snowstorm or the decision by Marc Jacobs to delay his show to the last day. Whatever was to blame, New York Fashion Week doesnt seem to be living up to the hard-nosed partying for which it is known.

title: Clip: Like Someone in Love
description: A scene from Like Someone in Love, directed by Abbas Kiarostami.
