title: Jason Wu: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Pictures of the Day: Tunisia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Tunisia, Egypt, Bangladesh and Georgia.

title: Master of Illusions Faces His Own Mirage
description: The Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami is no stranger to the possibility of misunderstanding. You might even say that he courts the creative potential of not knowing all the facts.

title: On TV, an Everyday Muslim as Everyday American
description: On a Sunday afternoon several months ago, I was engaged in one of my favorite religious rituals, watching pro football on television. During a break in the game, I reflexively clicked the mute button on the remote control. But my eyes stayed fixed on a startling commercial.

title: Brooklyn College Protest
description: Pro-Palestinian speakers drew anger and support over a talk by the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement at Brooklyn College. The group calls for sanctions on Israel.

title: Updates on the Winter Storm
description: Throughout the day on Friday, which for many was a rainy, sloshy mess, New Yorkers salted sidewalks, stocked up on supplies and lined up at gas stations to fill their tanks, as local authorities from New York City to Maine activated their plans to battle the snow as it began to pile up.

title: Latecomer in Mayor Race Has Business Titans Buzz
description: Kenneth G. Langone, the billionaire co-founder of Home Depot, has pledged his financial backing. Peter S. Kalikow, the real estate investor, has cut a big check. And James S. Tisch, the chief executive of the Loews Corporation, is on board.

title: Orchestrating Each Grammy Detail
description: LOS ANGELES  Something was wrong with the video playing behind the R&B singer Frank Ocean as he rehearsed this week for Sundays Grammy Awards. The video was projected on a screen behind Mr. Ocean and onto a three-sided box around the keyboard in front of him, creating the surreal illusion that he was running down a desert road while he sang. But the images were slightly out of sync with the recorded track over which Mr. Ocean vocalized: his torso and his legs didnt quite line up. Rather than dreamy, the effect was disjointed.

title: Ferrari Museum Honors Sergio Pininfarina
description: Its one of the classic partnerships in automotive history: Two Italian nameplates, Ferrari and Pininfarina, automaker and design house, have long been associated with cars that many enthusiasts consider to be the greatest sports machines ever made.

title: Yigal Azroul: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: One Prism on the Undoing of Pinochet
description: The blunt title of No, directed by Pablo Larran and one of the five nominees for best foreign-language film in this years Academy Awards, refers to an inspiring moment in the history of Chile, his native land. In a straight up-or-down, yes-or-no plebiscite there in 1988, the citizenry ended the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet by voting him out of power, 15 years after he had seized control in a bloody American-backed coup.

title: A Detour on the Road to an Electric Future
description: When I embarked on a test of Teslas new East Coast electric vehicle charging network, I did not expect to become a rate-paying customer of Norwich Public Utilities, a small municipal electric provider in Norwich, Conn. But my Tesla Model S was running dangerously low on juice and I needed a quick fill-up to make it to the Tesla Supercharger station in Milford, Conn., about 60 miles away.

title: To Earth, Seeking Goodness
description: A small fire broke out during a preview performance of the Foundry Theaters enchanting production of Bertolt Brechts Good Person of Szechwan. Alarms clanged; the actors stood still. Eventually performers and audience members dutifully trooped out of the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa, to return only after a small phalanx of firefighters had clomped in and out.

title: Blizzards as Teachers
description: Watching the snowfall forecasts from the potent blizzard sweeping into the Northeast (were at the western edge of the robins egg 12-24 inches zone), I cant help but think back to March, 2010, when we lost power for five days after the Hudson Valley and other regions were paralyzed by several feet of snow. Heres a look back at my ridiculously inefficient effort to keep the toilets flushing by melting heaps of snow on the propane stove:

title: Cushnie et Ochs: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Rebecca Minkoff: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 8
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week, ranging from the New York City Ballet to a performance by Mumford & Sons.

title: About Last Night | Celebrating Ts Inaugural Issue
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 8
description: Subjects include the death of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, repairs to the Rockaway Boardwalk and an increase in the number of rats in New York City since Hurricane Sandy.

title: Ira Rubin, Champion Bridge Player, Dies at 82
description: Ira Rubin, one of the worlds greatest bridge players, died on Wednesday in Edison, N.J., after a long illness. He was 82.

title: John Fords Portraits of Loss and Redemption
description: One film is a devastating study of loss  of a family destroyed, a romance interrupted and an idyllic, rural community obliterated by industrialization and corporate greed. The other is an uplifting fantasy of a traditional community that continues to thrive by resisting modern encroachments, of a magnificent couple born out of conflict, and of a broken man who finds redemption by escaping the past and embracing the present.

title: Steak au Poivre Makes a Comeback
description: When I was young, French dining reigned; if you wanted to eat fancy, you ate French. Then the restaurant landscape changed dramatically, and French restaurants, whether classic or more casual, became increasingly rare. That was one reason the opening of Ma Maison Brasserie in downtown Millburn in July generated so much enthusiasm. Another was that its chef and owner, Franco Ammirati, also owns the towns beloved Caf Luna, an intimate Italian-style restaurant with a distinctive European feel.

title: The Show Goes on, Despite Showstopper Choruses in All Those Tunes
description: The vamp, an insistent musical motif that signals an imminent stampede, is a Broadway songwriting convention that the team of John Kander and Fred Ebb wielded with special force to announce the arrival of an imminent showstopper. Think of the instrumental tease that starts spreading the news in New York, New York. It is a shot of adrenaline that brings audience members to their feet, wired to sing along the instant the tune begins. Those who dont heed the message had better get out of the way.

title: A Comedian as Artist
description: When Andy Kaufman, the entertainer, so-called anti-comic and Elvis impersonator extraordinaire, died in 1984 at 35, he left behind two very distinct if connected personas.

title: Life Inside an Oil Boom
The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 8
description: More photographs.

title: New York Teams Sign Spanish Players
description: On a day when a comically named winter storm slammed the New York metropolitan area, leave it to two local soccer teams to remind fans of warmer days ahead.

title: Not Always Fun and Games
description: Walk into Walmart and you can usually find it: an aisle of weaponry, with names like the Firestrike, Rampage and Hail-Fire, advertising quick firing, ammunition clips and semi-auto capability. Build your arsenal! read the box for one, sitting next to a tactical vest meant to repel barrages of ... foam darts.

title: When Is a Gym More Than a Gym? When Its a Brand
description: When Jaime Gleicher travels, she likes her room to smell like home. So she brings a $42 grapefruit-scented candle from the place she considers her second one: SoulCycle, the group cycling chain.

title: Video: Protests at Brooklyn College
description: Pro-Palestinian speakers drew anger and support over a talk at Brooklyn College by members of the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement. The group calls for sanctions on Israel. A video captured the scene as protesters gathered at the event.

title: In These Ballets, Theres Nowhere for Dancers to Hide
description: Although choreographers were using chunks of Beethovens Fifth Symphony to accompany story ballets back in the 1820s, dancing to entire symphonies was essentially an innovation of the 20th century. Isadora Duncan first danced to Beethovens Seventh in 1904; Fyodor Lopukhov choreographed Dance Symphony in 1923; both were controversial.

title: Defying Boundaries of Place and Time
description: Parquet Courts

title: Theyre From the Future, and Canada
description: SQUAMISH, British Columbia  The people behind Continuum, a slick Canadian science-fiction drama recently imported to the United States by Syfy, are very conscious that their growing international audience is a demanding, detail-oriented bunch. But the other day during the filming here of a Season 2 scene that had actors in a drainage tunnel with a roaring helicopter at one end, one detail was beyond anyones control.

title: Oh, Baby! That Duke Sure Is a Dreamboat in the New Rigoletto
description: My sights are set on a swingin girl,So hop on, baby, lets take that whirl!

title: Simple Dcor, Ambitious Kitchen
description: Roots Bistro Gourmand  in West Islip is a spare, almost rustic-looking place with food that is anything but simple. As Philippe Corbet, one of the owners, explained in a telephone conversation after my visits, the roots in the name refers to the restaurants preparation of nearly everything, including sauces and desserts, from scratch. The bistro gourmand designation suggests that while this is a place with bistro classics like burgers and moules frites, the cooking is often more ambitious.

title: A Merlot That May Best Its Precursor
description: It seems possible that the 2010 merlot from Bedell Cellars, in Cutchogue, may ultimately outshine the charming 2009 merlot, which was served at the Congressional lunch in the Capitol after President Obamas public inauguration last month. The reason: many producers consider 2010 the most outstanding grape-growing season in the 40-year-old Long Island wine industrys history.

title: Fans Have Their Say, Loudly, After U.S. Loss
description: Jurgen Klinsmann does not tolerate complacency  in his players, in the news media and even within the United States national teams fan base. He said as much last June, after the United States defeated Antigua & Barbuda, 3-1, in Tampa, Fla.

title: Lews Cayman Islands Fund a Likely Issue at Confirmation Hearings
description: As recently as 2010, Jack Lew, President Obamas nominee to be the next secretary of the Treasury, had $56,000 invested in a CitiGroup venture capital fund based in the Cayman Islands notorious Ugland House, a building whose mailboxes are home to nearly 19,000 corporate entities, many of them tax shelters.

title: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire
description: Im in New York, theres a blizzard warning, so if ever there was a time for this

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 8
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the death of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, repairs to the Rockaway Boardwalk, and an increase in the number of rats in New York City since Hurricane Sandy.

title: The Secret Art of George W. Bush
description: W. paints! Who would have thought it? Thanks to a hacker known as Guccifer who wormed into the computer of the 43rd presidents sister, the world has learned that George W. Bush is an amateur  I would say serious amateur  painter. He may be some peoples least favorite president since Hoover, but as an artist he is, well, a heck of a lot better than any number of world leaders whose names spring to mind, foremost Winston Churchill and Adolf Hitler.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Bush Hacking, and Online Gambling From New Jersey
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Pump Boys Wont Open On Broadway This Season
description: Producers for the revival of Pump Boys and Dinettes announced late Friday that the shows Broadway opening, scheduled for April 8, had been postponed indefinitely.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Jason Wu
description: Bold sapphire-hued eye makeup experienced a resurgence on the spring 2013 runways, and it looks like Jason Wu is still feeling blue for fall. At his show earlier today, the makeup team, led by Diane Kendal, decked out models eyelids in a stunning indigo shade  a limited-edition eye shadow from his forthcoming cosmetics collaboration with Lancme (available this September). Theres a beautiful purplish-blue dress in the finale of the show, and Jason wanted to tie in that color with all the girls, Kendal explains. The rest of the face was kept muted: a touch of foundation on the skin, a light sweep of rosy-pink blush on the apples of the cheeks, and nude lips topped off with lip balm. The neutral elements of the face make the bright blue eyes look modern instead of retro, Kendal says. The eye shadow has a feathery effect to it as well, so the edges are softer  not as harsh as in years past.

title: Birth Control and Religious Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dogs Turn to Die
description: To the Editor:

title: Cause Found for Blackout in Big Game
description: The power failure that plunged the Super Bowl into darkness and halted play for more than a half-hour Sunday was caused by a device installed specifically to prevent a blackout.

title: Clinical Trials to Determine the Safety of Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bad Deal With Uzbekistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Christina Applegate Leaves Up All Night
description: NBC appears to be moving ahead with its revamped edition of the comedy Up All Night, despite losing not only the original creator of the series, Emily Spivey, and its most recent show-running producer, Tucker Cawley, but as of Friday, also its star, Christina Applegate.

title: Wanted: Six Smiling Robbery Suspects
description: Six young women are being sought by the police for a robbery in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: The Storm on Instagram
description: A selection of Instagram photos submitted by readers of scenes from the winter storm in the Northeast.

title: Women in Combat: Policy Catches Up With Reality
description: AT his confirmation hearing on Jan. 31, Chuck Hagel, President Obamas nominee for defense secretary, stated unequivocally, I will work with the service chiefs as we officially open combat positions to women, a decision I strongly support.

title: Can Big Data From Epic Indian Pilgrimage Help Save Lives?
description: Big data, meet humanity.

title: Personal Statement
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: How the Post Office Made America
description: THE Postal Services announcement that it plans to end Saturday mail delivery reminds us of its vulnerability to the technological convulsions of the information age. The agency lost nearly $16 billion last year; stopping Saturday delivery, starting in August, would save about $2 billion a year. To preserve the letter of the law, which requires six-day service, the agency would continue Saturday parcel delivery  a shrewd decision, since, thanks to booming e-commerce, the parcel business is one of the few sectors that is actually growing.

title: Making a Child, Minus the Couple
description: Rachel Hope is 5-foot-9 and likes yoga, dance and martial arts. A real estate developer and freelance writer in Los Angeles, Ms. Hope, 41, is seeking a man who lives near her, is healthy and fit, and has his financial stuff together, she said. Parker Williams, the 42-year-old founder of QTheory, a charity auction company also in Los Angeles, would seem like a good candidate. A 6-foot-2 former model who loves animals, Mr. Williams is athletic, easygoing, compassionate and organized.

title: Off The Runway: Day 2
description: Scenes from day two of New York Fashion Week.

title: The Archbishop Rebukes the Cardinal
description: It was an extraordinary moment in Catholic Church history  the rebuke of Cardinal Roger Mahony by his successor in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles following fresh documentation of the hierarchys cover-up of the rape and abuse of children by priests. Cardinal Mahony, two years into retirement, was unceremoniously relieved of all public duties last month by Archbishop Jos Gomez, who described brutal and painful records of evil deeds during the Mahony years.

title: Alabama: Suit Seeks to Stop Naming of Immigrants
description: A coalition of civil rights groups have filed a lawsuit to stop Alabama from publishing the names of all illegal immigrants arrested in the state. The suit was filed on Thursday on behalf of two men and two women who were arrested on charges of fishing without a license, a misdemeanor. Alabamas immigration law requires the State Department of Homeland Security to publish an online database of illegal immigrants who are charged with any crimes. The Web site has not yet been created. Lawyers with the American Civil Liberties Union, the Southern Poverty Law Center and the National Immigration Law Center said the site amounted to a black list from which individuals had no way to remove their names.

title: Drones, Brennan and Obamas Legacy of Secrecy
description: NEW YORK  John O. Brennans testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday was representative of the Obama administrations approach to counter-terrorism: right-sounding assurances with little transparency.

title: Blue-Ribbon Day With Outfit to Match
description: Karolina Kurkova, 28, has been posing for cameras since she was 15, experience that comes in handy for her latest role as a coach on Oxygens new reality show for would-be supermodels, The Face, which makes its debut Feb. 12. Ms. Kurkova, born in Decin, Czech Republic, is now living in Manhattan and Fisher Island, Fla. She is married to Archie Drury, a film producer.

title: A Psychics Legal Problems Grow, Perhaps Not Unforeseeably
description: Police officers and psychics more or less stay out of each others way in New York City. But an entire cottage industry of law enforcement has grown up around the 38-year-old fortuneteller and evil-spirit exterminator Sylvia Mitchell, and it was on full display in Manhattan Criminal Court this week.

title: Demonstrators Attack Allies of Georgian President, Injuring at Least 5
California: Sheriffs Deputies in Clique to Be Fired
description: The Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department moved to fire seven deputies who are accused of being part of a secret internal group known as the Jump Out Boys, which allegedly celebrated aggressive tactics and shootings. Sheriff Leroy D. Baca began the termination process against the deputies this week after reviewing results of an internal affairs investigation. The deputies can appeal the firings to the states civil service board. While investigators did not find any criminal behavior by the group, officials have recently begun to discipline such cliques because of concerns that they encourage unethical, ganglike and violent behavior and hurt the departments reputation, particularly in black and Latino neighborhoods. A pamphlet explaining the groups creed said members were not afraid to get our hands dirty, according to The Los Angeles Times, which first reported on the groups existence. The seven deputies were removed from duty with pay last year, officials said.

title: Innovation Nation at War
description: CHICAGO

title: Fitness for Office
description: Our topic for today is: How much do we care about physical fitness in an elected official?

title: Power Plays Rising as Referees Show Less Tolerance, Even Late in Games
description: Devils defenseman Andy Greene has never been a hockey scofflaw. So after his team lost an early-season game against the Montreal Canadiens, he complained about the hooking penalty he received in the last minute of overtime that set up the winning power-play goal.

title: Report Faults U.S. Use of Mexican Battery Recyclers
description: United States companies are sending spent lead batteries to recycling plants in Mexico that do not meet American environmental standards, according to an environmental agency created under the North American Free Trade Agreement, putting Mexican communities at risk.

title: A Hunters Menu Served With Colonial Charm
description: Having perfected her cooking during stints in Hawaii; Manhattan; New Orleans; Phoenix; Santa Fe, N.M.; and Telluride, Colo., Adrienne Sussman, the owner and chef of Adrienne Fine American Dining, settled in New Milford in 1996, largely because she found an eighteenth-century building there that could house her restaurant and herself. One of the reasons Im still surviving in this economy is I can live upstairs, Ms. Sussman said.

title: Nursing Home Plans Riverdale Apartments; Some Neighbors Opposed
description: There is no shortage of amenities offered by New York City apartment buildings, from wine cellars to rock-climbing walls and even private spas for pets.

title: Newspaper Wrestles With M.L.B.s Request for Documents
description: In the wake of George J. Mitchells damning report in 2007 on doping in baseball, Commissioner Bud Selig created a department of investigations to serve as Major League Baseballs police unit.

title: Shooting Suspects Racism Allegations Resound for Some
description: LOS ANGELES  For the Los Angeles Police Department, the allegations of departmental corruption and racism by a former police officer now accused of a revenge-fueled killing rampage are the words of a delusional man, detached from the reality of the huge improvements the force has undergone over the years.

title: Timothy Whites Photography
description: In a career that spans three decades, Mr. White has photographed Harrison Ford, Sophia Loren, Audrey Hepburn, Paul McCartney, Axl Rose, Whitney Houston and many more.  Here are some examples.

title: Have Banter, Will Travel
description: In 2005, after meeting on the set of Mr. and Mrs. Smith, Timothy White and Brad Pitt went on a five-day motorcycle ride in the Mojave Desert. The adventure was partly for fun (both love bikes) and partly for work (Mr. White took along a stylist, racks of clothes and two assistants, who followed in a Winnebago for a photo shoot).

title: A Growing App Lets You See It, Then You Dont
description: LOS ANGELES  The ephemeral now has value, at least for users of cellphones.

title: Artisanal Food, and Beer Made Downstairs
description: When I first reviewed Peekskill Brewery, in 2008, it had recently opened on the Peekskill riverfront. A leader of the booming gastro pub trend, it had a great burger, delicious bratwurst and an impressive lineup of craft beers. But what gave it an extra edge was a less common offering: its own beer, made on the premises.

title: Debating a Court to Vet Drone Strikes
description: WASHINGTON  Since 1978, a secret court in Washington has approved national security eavesdropping on American soil  operations that for decades had been conducted based on presidential authority alone.

title: Trial of 2 Liu Supporters Is Set in Campaign Fund-Raising Case
description: The trial of two allies of the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, will start on April 15, a judge said Friday after ruling that one defendant, now in the hospital, was competent to stand trial.

title: Bringing Ultra-Orthodox Traditions to Israels Parliament, Olive Branch in Hand
description: BEIT SHEMESH, Israel

title: Bill Cunningham | Shape Shift
description: As New York Fashion Week opened, women seemed to be making a silhouette statement, adding to the mystery of where fashion will go as the collections unfold.

title: Boy Scouts Say Gay Debate Was Ignited by a Leak
description: A leak from inside the Boy Scouts of America last month about discussions on possibly ending the groups national ban on gay members changed the debate itself by creating an impression that change was imminent, according to scouting officials and taped comments from a meeting of scoutings executive board obtained by The New York Times.

title: Teachers Aide Admits Making Pornographic Video of a Student
description: A teachers aide at a public school in Brooklyn who was accused last year of making videos of a child performing sex acts in classrooms pleaded guilty on Friday to federal child-pornography charges.

title: Survivors Stories of Abuse, Sewn Tight
description: Art exhibitions with a human rights theme can be really depressing  kind of in-your-face and gruesome, said Neil Tetkowski, director of university galleries at Kean University in Union.

title: Mississippi: State Health Exchange Is Disallowed
description: The Obama administration will not allow Mississippi to run its own health insurance exchange because of a disagreement between Gov. Phil Bryant and Mike Chaney, the states insurance commissioner. Mr. Chaney had been planning a state-based exchange over the objections of Mr. Bryant, a fellow Republican. But federal officials decided it was not feasible without Mr. Bryants cooperation. The alternatives are for the federal government to run an exchange for Mississippi or to run one jointly with the state. President Obamas health care law requires all states to have exchanges  online markets where people can shop for private health insurance and seek federal subsidies to help pay for it  by January 2014.

title: Reversing Course on Reports About a Classic
description: Before the release of The Pride of the Yankees, the 1942 biographical film about Lou Gehrig, there were reports that movie magic had been needed to solve a critical problem: making Gary Cooper, a right-handed movie star who was definitely not a ballplayer, into a credible version of the left-handed Gehrig, a Hall of Fame slugger with a .340 career batting average.

title: Left Behind Meets Upwardly Mobile in Boston
description: David Lindsay-Abaires plays, whether wacky or heartbreaking in their particulars, often focus on a woman facing adversity. Fuddy Meers was a funny romp with a chronic amnesiac, while the Pulitzer Prize-winning drama Rabbit Hole observed a suburban mother mourning a dead child.

title: Tommy Hilfiger: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: New York

title: After Just Two Episodes, NBC Cancels Do No Harm
description: After drawing two of the smallest viewing audiences in network history, the new NBC drama Do No Harm will not get a third try. NBC announced late Friday that it is cancelling the show, which was a retelling of the Dr. Jeykll and Mr. Hyde tale.

title: Nicole Miller: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: The Daily Shoe | Tabitha Simmons
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Venezuela Devalues Currency by a Third Amid Shortages and Inflation
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuela announced Friday that it was devaluing its currency, a step that had long been deemed necessary but could push the spiking inflation even higher.

title: Mr. Menendezs Ethics Problem
description: Senator Robert Menendez was never a distinguished choice for chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the position he ascended to this month by virtue of seniority. Concerns about that quality gap have sharply escalated amid new disclosures about Mr. Menendezs use of his position to advance the financial interests of a friend and big donor. Instead of trying to protect Mr. Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, needs to remove his gavel, at least pending credible resolution by the Senate Ethics Committee of the swirling accusations of misconduct.

title: Rag & Bone: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Rejected by Sothebys, Florida Pastor Is Arrested in New York Over Sale of Counterfeit Art
description: To hear Damien Hirsts critics tell it, his works may be among the easiest to duplicate in the art world.

title: A Look at Turkeys Past Gives Some Insight Into Its Unresolved Troubles
description: ISTANBUL  Two galleries in this citys old European quarter recently opened exhibitions that showcase the political violence that convulsed the country in the 1970s. The echoes for contemporary Turkey were unmistakable.

title: An Assassination in Tunisia
description: Tunisia is where the Arab Spring began just over two years ago. Until now it has set an encouraging example of progress toward democracy and pluralism. Free elections brought to power a coalition government pledged to pragmatic cooperation between a moderate-led Islamist party, Ennahda, and smaller, secular coalition partners.

title: Holiday Parking
description: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Sunday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Preppy Style and Joe Flacco at the Tommy Hilfiger Show
description: There was a snow delay at Tommy Hilfigers mens show on Park Avenue on Friday evening as many editors were slogging their way uptown from the previous show in Chelsea. So those who arrived on time were faced with an enormous and elaborate set design that made it seem as if they were walking into Mr. Hilfigers library (only the books lining the walls at a height of two stories were part of a mural, so there was nothing to read but the program).

title: Views of Intolerance in Many Forms
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  A new exhibition at the Suffolk County Historical Society includes objects and images that are rarely or never seen in a museum, said Kathryn Curran, executive director of the society.

title: Suspect in Botched Shooting Bought Gun Legally Despite Mental Illness
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The gentle pace of life on the campus of Ashley Hall, South Carolinas only all-girls preparatory school, appeared to be back on Friday. Parents lined up in the shade of the live oaks to pick up their children. A luncheon for alumnae of the school, which was founded in 1909, went on as planned.

title: Improper Efforts to Limit Competitive Drugs
description: Two big biotechnology companies, Amgen and Genentech, are lobbying state legislatures to limit competition to their biological drugs that will lose patent protection in the next several years. Before taking any action, lawmakers should wait for guidance from the Food and Drug Administration, the agency that reviews all drugs and their generic versions for safety and effectiveness.

title: Jason Wu Moves to the Grown-Up Table
description: Jason Wu said he never gave the storm much thought. What could we do? he asked before his show on Thursday in a Park Avenue church. We didnt have a contingency plan. In fact, looking around at the hairdressers and models backstage, youd think it was a normal scene.

title: Being Thom Browne: His Moment Is Now
description: Do you know this man? Do you know who he is? Julian Niccolini, the irrepressible co-owner and the host of the Four Seasons said one late January evening. Standing beside a corner banquette in the Grill Room  the prime power seat in a restaurant that, fully 54 years after Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Philip Johnson designed it, has yielded none of its luster to time  Mr. Niccolini put his hand on the shoulder of a shy, smallish man with a lantern jaw, a John Glenn crew cut and a suit that looked as though the laundry had shrunk it with him inside.

title: More on Guns, With Readers
description: Its happened again. Im impressed by my readers.

title: Seizure of Antiaircraft Missiles in Yemen Raises Fears That Iran Is Arming Rebels There
description: Photographs recently released by the Yemeni government suggest that an interdiction last month by the United States Navy and Yemens security forces seized a class of shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles not publicly known to have been out of state control.

title: Warm Memories for Past Champions of Westminster
description: J. R. and Stump were retired housemates and congenial bedfellows in Houston who shared a singular distinction: each won best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

title: A Storm Is No One, and Means Very Little
description: Humor was not The Weather Channels intent when it started to give names to winter storms a few months ago. But humor is what it has provided  along with no small amount of controversy.

title: Theres No Dressing Up a Bland Start
description: Many designers are counting on deliveries of fabrics and samples from Europe this weekend, so the storm will surely mean some last-minute scrambling to get pieces made (if fabrics arrive in time, that is) and eliminating other outfits altogether. Marc Jacobs moved his show from Monday to Thursday evening, but other companies wont have that flexibility.

title: Wanted in Officers Trial: Difficult-to-Shock Jurors
description: Have you visited Web sites like darkfetishnet.com, yumchat.com or girlsinabind.com was one of the questions on the form. Would evidence about highly sexualized violent conduct, bondage and sadomasochism make it difficult for you to be fair and impartial was another. The form, distributed in a Manhattan courtroom on Friday, also included an illustration showing a naked woman lashed to a spit being turned over a fire.

title: Giving New Meaning to the Term Character Actors
description: The giant screen is the first hint. It is multiplex-size, slightly tilted, spanning most of the upstage wall at the Yale Repertory Theater, showing a rich blue Irish sky at first. Then there is the AstroTurf-like floor, rising to create a little hill, representing the greenness of the Emerald Isle. There are a couple of big klieg lights and a towering movie-set crane.

title: For Some Landlords, Real Money in the Homeless
description: Willy Machan acknowledges he is a gadfly, someone who writes bristling letters to local officials to get conditions improved in his grim single-room-occupancy building. But he was surprised by what his landlord offered last July to persuade him to move out of the room he has lived in since 1984 and for which he pays $371 a month.

title: Gunmen Kill Nigerian Polio Vaccine Workers in Echo of Pakistan Attacks
description: At least nine polio immunization workers were shot to death in northern Nigeria on Friday by gunmen who attacked two clinics, officials said.

title: Number of Frisks Fell in 12, Police Data Show
description: The number of times New York City police officers stopped, questioned and frisked people in 2012 dropped by 22 percent from the previous year, according to statistics the Police Department released on Friday.

title: Knicks Hope to Get Back for Game at Garden
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The snowstorm that hit New York and the rest of the Northeast on Friday had the Knicks thinking they might have to stay here overnight after their game with the Minnesota Timberwolves. Whether the storm jeopardizes Sunday afternoons scheduled game between the Knicks and the Los Angeles Clippers at Madison Square Garden depends on when airports reopen in the New York area.

title: Suicide Conservatives
description: There used to be a political truism: Democrats fall in love, while Republicans fall in line.

title: Helmut Lang: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Panel Chairman Criticizes G.O.P. Request on Hagels Financial Data
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Carl Levin, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, told the committees top Republican on Friday that he and other Senate Republicans were out of bounds for demanding additional financial information from Chuck Hagel, President Obamas choice to be defense secretary.

title: Nets Said to Be Considering Deal to Send Humphries to Bobcats
description: The Nets could bolster their bench scoring and loosen their frontcourt logjam under a proposed trade with the Charlotte Bobcats.

title: Blizzard Slams the Northeast
description: A vast storm system continued to batter the region, deepening snow and threats of flooding and reopening the wounds of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Jesse Jackson Jr. Said to Enter Plea
description: Jesse L. Jackson Jr., the former congressman who resigned last year citing ill health, has signed a plea agreement with federal prosecutors who had been investigating his possible misuse of campaign funds, a person familiar with the case said Friday.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Feb. 9, 2013
description: I dont think its going to be as bad as theyre saying, but I said that with Sandy, too.

title: Lottery Numbers
Portraits of a Continents Vitality, Past and Present
description: Photography was invented in England and France at the height of the Industrial Revolution, but the 1990s brought a startling discovery to the international art world: some of the most artful portraiture ever created was produced in Africa over the last century. Malian Portrait Photography at the Samuel Dorsky Museum in New Paltz, N.Y., offers a small roundup of some of the newly acknowledged African masters, like Seydou Keta and Malick Sidib, and introduces lesser known ones like Hamidou Maga, Abdourahmane Sakaly and Tijani dgn Sitou. A companion exhibition, Photo-Rapide: Franois Deschamps, features work by Mr. Deschamps, an American photographer and SUNY New Paltz professor who lived in Mali during 2010 to 2011 on a senior research Fulbright fellowship, and extends the dialogue between African photography and contemporary practice.

title: Nets Find Out How Much Better Wall Makes the Wizards
description: WASHINGTON  When the Wizards John Wall stepped in front of C. J. Watson near midcourt early in the second quarter to swipe a loose ball and take it the other way, the play seemed harmless enough. Turnovers happen in basketball games, and Watson watched as Wall raced in for a two-handed dunk.

title: The Value of an Empty Beer Can
description: Q. My cousin collects beer cans. (Yes, I know.) I was wondering what New York City beer can is considered the most valuable as a collectible?

title: Corrections: February 9, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Canada: Spy for Russia Sentenced
description: A Canadian naval intelligence officer, who gave Russia secrets from five nations, including the United States, was sentenced to 20 years in prison on Friday. The officer, Sub-Lt. Jeffrey Paul Delisle, 41, said he began selling secrets in 2007 while distraught over marital problems. He was also fined $111,817, the amount Russia paid him. The nature of the information he sold has not been disclosed.

title: Pretty Obvious
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Well, I just thought this one by Peter Wentz was the CATS MEOW. Crunchy, fun, lots of unique entries, and a few easy entries with which to grab a toehold, making this grid tough but solvable.

title: Russia: Officer Jailed in Coup Plot
description: A Moscow court sentenced a former Soviet intelligence officer on Friday to 13 years in a prison colony for plotting an armed coup against the Russian government. The officer, Vladimir Kvachkov, a former colonel in the Soviet military intelligence service, was convicted of plotting to seize weapons from military caches and launch an attack on Moscow with a small group of ultranationalist supporters in 2010. Mr. Kvachkov told the RIA Novosti news agency shortly after his arrest that he was accused of trying to lead two groups of men armed with crossbows against government troops. He denied the charges. Earlier in 2010, he was acquitted of charges of trying to assassinate Anatoly Chubais, the architect of Russias unpopular market reforms, in 2005.

title: China: Uighur Scholar Monitored
description: Ilham Tohti, an outspoken ethnic Uighur scholar at a Beijing university who has been prevented from going to the United States, says that he is being closely watched by Chinas security forces and that his Web site has been hacked, according to a report on Thursday by Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the American government. Mr. Tohti was detained on Feb. 2 when he tried to board a flight to the United States, where he was to be a visiting scholar at Indiana University. His teenage daughter was able to board the flight and is now in the United States. Mr. Tohti was released after being questioned for eight hours. The Uighurs say they are oppressed by Chinese policies and experience discrimination from Chinas dominant ethnic group.

title: Suno: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: For a Broadway Fan, Once Is Not Enough
description: Aimee Kislin wears two guitar picks around her neck from her two great loves.

title: Senegal: Trial for Chads Ex-Ruler
description: A new internationally backed court opened on Friday in Senegal, and its judges will prepare a case against the former ruler of Chad, Hissne Habr, who has been living in exile in Senegal. Three countries have indicted Mr. Habr, 70, for crimes against humanity; Chad sentenced him to death for killings and torture carried out during his rule from 1982 to 1990. Senegals president, Macky Sall, agreed to set up the ad hoc court in Dakar, the capital, where Mr. Habr is to be tried by African judges under Senegalese law. European countries are paying two-thirds of the courts $10 million budget; the African Union has been criticized for paying for only 10 percent of the courts costs.

title: Berlusconi Remains Wild Card in Italy Race
description: ROME  One candidate promised to drop an unpopular new property tax and refund all prior payments in cash. Another called that proposal a poisoned meatball, disconnected from reality. A third suggested that Al Qaeda blow up the Italian Parliament  then backtracked  and the man generally considered the front-runner is campaigning on vague promises of stability, so has often been ignored.

title: A Faceless Teenage Refugee Who Helped Ignite Syrias War
description: AMMAN, Jordan  In a listless border town, the teenager goes unnoticed, one of the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have fled the Syrian civil war, dashing across villages and farms to land in Jordan, just five miles from home.

title: Slain Opposition Leader Buried
description: The assassination of Chokri Belaid has stirred fears in Tunisia and throughout the Arab world.

title: Local Stop: Stapleton
description: Stapleton, named in 1836, is a trove of memories, political, familial and architectural.

title: A Composer Who Talked for Hours
description: Unlike almost any other classical performer of recent times, Leonard Bernstein adamantly, and sometimes controversially, refused to compartmentalize and separate his emotional, intellectual, political, erotic and spiritual longings from the musical experience, Jonathan Cott writes in Dinner With Lenny: The Last Long Interview with Leonard Bernstein (Oxford University Press, $24.95).

title: The Brewer Kings of Staten Island
description: Even before Hurricane Sandy struck, the north shore of Staten Island called out for attention and appreciation. Plans to encourage the local economy include building a 60-story Ferris wheel near the St. George Ferry Terminal and, a short walk away in Stapleton, redeveloping the old Navy Homeport site. But Stapleton remains curiously trapped in its past, with remarkable buildings and an interesting if slightly down-at-heel commercial center.

title: Amid a Bloody War, Syrian Videos Show a Glimpse of Fun
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The video has gone viral in recent days: Syrian government soldiers, in camouflage gear, carrying rocket-propelled grenades and brandishing rifles, mugging for the camera while dancing in a circle to Ushers hit song Yeah!

title: After Sluggish Defense, Anthony and Knicks Deliver Rousing Comeback
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Knowing they would be stranded here overnight by the snowstorm in New York City, the Knicks played Fridays game with the Minnesota Timberwolves as if determined to make their unscheduled stay as miserable as possible.

title: Chocolate, Lollipops, Maybe Striped Bass
description: The chocolatier Jacques Torres, who started Jacques Torres Chocolate in 2000 as a small factory in Dumbo with his business partner, Ken Goto, now has five shops around the city. Mr. Torres, 53, who grew up in the South of France, shares an apartment in Hells Kitchen with his wife, Hasty, 37, who runs a chocolate business in California; in milder weather, he spends as much time as he can on his boat, docked in Jersey City, near the Statue of Liberty. On Sundays, Mr. Torres rides his bike and his motorcycle, checks up on his shops and often cooks dinner.

title: John E. Karlin, Who Led the Way to All-Digit Dialing, Dies at 94
description: A generation ago, when the poetry of PEnnsylvania and BUtterfield was about to give way to telephone numbers in unpoetic strings, a critical question arose: Would people be able to remember all seven digits long enough to dial them?

title: Billy Reid: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Beer and Change on Arthur Avenue
description: Cousins in Yankees caps greet each other with bear hugs and banter in Italian while their wives buy chops and cheese. Customers from Westchester and Milan stroll beside bins of mushrooms, past stacks of sopressata and beneath dried peppers hanging like witnesses to the shopping rituals of the last 72 years.

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 9
description: After a failed attempt to set spending targets at a summit meeting in November and in a 24-hour marathon of talks this week, European leaders finally agreed late Friday to a common budget for the next seven years. The new budget, which is slightly smaller than its predecessor  the first decrease in the European Unions history  reflects the climate of austerity across a Continent still struggling to emerge from a crippling debt crisis. James Kanter and Andrew Higgins report from Brussels.

title: Paul Tanner, Musician With Good Vibrations, Dies at 95
description: Paul Tanner, a former trombonist for the Glenn Miller Ochestra who played an unlikely role in the history of rock n roll when, using a device he helped invent, he performed the famous electronic accompaniment on the Beach Boys signature recording Good Vibrations, died on Tuesday in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 95.

title: John Kerr, Star of Tea and Sympathy, Dies at 81
description: John Kerr, a Tony Award-winning actor who was best known for roles that challenged bigotry in the 1950s in films like Tea and Sympathy and South Pacific, and who turned down a starring movie role because of ideological differences with its subject, Charles Lindbergh, died on Feb. 2 in Los Angeles. He was 81.

title: A Guide in the Darkness
description: When a life starts to unravel, where do you turn for help?

title: After Hurricane, a New Calling for Mothers
description: God could not be everywhere, as the proverb goes, so he created mothers. Fathers misplace their children at the supermarket; mothers miraculously transform tofu to make it palatable to 3-year olds. Mothers grow indignant when the world isnt as it should be. They carry placards and mobilize, often seeing themselves as the only custodians of sanity and efficiency left. Progressive movements through much of recent history have been testaments to the force of maternal will and tenacity.

title: In Camp, Reading Les Miserables
description: Victor Hugos Les Miserables was published in 1862 and English translations of the five parts that constitute the novel began to appear in America by years end. Hugo had begun the sprawling novel in the 1840s, put it aside, and come back to complete it between 1860 and 1862. He was an opponent of slavery, and in 1859 defended John Brown. Insurrection, he said, was a sacred duty. In the novel, Hugo name-checked Brown in a list of celebrated revolutionaries that included Washington, Bolivar and Garibaldi. Hugos focus was the July Revolution of 1830, but it is possible he had the American conflict in mind when he wrote, Civil war  What did the words mean? Was there any such thing as foreign war? Was not all warfare between men warfare between brothers?

title: Storm Leaves Northeast Reeling and Digging
Love and the 7:04 to White Plains
description: As part of the Transit Museums celebration of Valentines Day at Grand Central Terminal, Metropolitans Alan Feuer will be reading from his Missed Connections poetry. The poems, found in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org, are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added. In honor of the venue, Mr. Feuer will be reading a transit-focused selection. (Vanderbilt Hall at Grand Central Terminal, Thursday, Feb. 14, 6 to 8 p.m. Tickets are $10 in advance, $7 for members, $15 at the door.)

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Sundance) IN THE LOOP (2009) While giving an interview to the BBC, the British minister of international development (Tom Hollander) departs from the official line and becomes the focus of tensions between Britain and the United States as they gear up to invade a Middle Eastern country. Given a chance to backtrack, he digs himself in deeper. Peter Capaldi plays a British press officer. James Gandolfini (above, with Mimi Kennedy) is a dovish Pentagon general. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said, The genius of In the Loop, directed by Armando Iannucci and written by a crack team of British wits, is that it turns this mountain into a series of festering molehills. While the film is a highly disciplined inquiry into a very serious subject, he added, it is also, line by filthy line, scene by chaotic scene, by far the funniest big-screen satire in recent memory.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Himachal Pradesh: Heavy snowfall for three straight days in the hill state has shut down several arterial roads in the interior areas on Thursday, affecting vehicular traffic,accordingto an IANS report on the NDTV Web site. In Shimla, a popular holiday destination, at least 10 people, most of them tourists, were injured while walking on the slippery roads, the report said.

title: Amid Protests, India Executes Man in 01 Parliament Attack
description: MUMBAI, India  India hanged a man on Saturday who had been convicted of involvement in a 2001 attack on Parliament that killed nine people.

title: Springsteen Honored in Warm-Up to the Grammys
description: Bruce Springsteen was honored as the MusiCares Person of the Year at an annual concert in Los Angeles on Friday, where an all-star lineup of performers did songs from his catalog to raise money for indigent musicians.

title: Revisiting Guns, the N.F.L. and Costas
description: Bob Costas told the nation in early December that the N.F.L. was part of an unhealthy gun culture.

title: Hungry Enough to Eat a Horse?
description: LONDON  As new revelations emerged in the great horse meat scandal gripping the European food industry, there was no indication it would dim the enthusiasm of Continental foodies for their favorite equine delicacies.

title: Weddings, Indian Style
description: In a ballroom at the Hilton Hotel in Pearl River, N.Y., four small women wearing black suits were carrying large tote bags and talking quietly into headsets. We have another five minutes; theyre going to do the throwing of the rice, one of them said into her mouthpiece, as though it were a military directive.

title: Scientists Explore Options as Polar Bears Face New Threats
description: The surge of hunting that depleted many polar bear populations in the 20th century is largely under control. But just as the species has been recovering from that threat, global warming is creating new pressures through the loss of summer sea ice and other impacts on the bears preferred maritime habitat.

title: Heavy Snow in Northeast
description: Thousands without power as snow and wind batters the Northeast.

title: Japanese Relative Performance
description: More notes to myself. When people try to assess how Japan has done since its late-80s bubble burst, they often look at per capita GDP. But this can be deeply misleading, because of Japans low birth rate and aging population. In the figure below I compared the ratio of Japanese to US GDP per capita (from Total Economy Database) with the ratio of Japanese to US GDP per adult aged 15-64:

title: My Head is Everywhere
description: Tomorrow it will be talking on Chris Hayes, Fareed Zakaria, and Maria Bartiromo.

title: Photos of The Moment | Jason Wu
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Profits and Business Investment
description: And another notes to myself post. Below are corporate profits (after tax and inventory valuation adjustment) and nonresidential fixed investment (roughly speaking, business investment), both measured as shares of GDP. These arent exactly matched figures, because not all business investment comes from corporations. Still, I think they illustrate an important point. Business investment isnt actually all that low; you expect it to be relatively weak in a weak economy with excess capacity, but in fact its about as high a share of GDP as in the middle Bush years. Whats really out of line with previous experience is the level of corporate profits, which is arguably serving as a kind of sinkhole for purchasing power.

title: The Legacy of a Camera-Toting Huckster
description: Beginning in the 1930s the Texas-born filmmaker Melton Barker spent nearly four decades scurrying across America with a script and a camera, methodically making and remaking the same two-reel film. This might seem like a story of creative obsession  a compulsive monomaniac so intent on achieving aesthetic perfection that he became subsumed by his work  but Barker, one of at least several itinerant filmmakers working in the first half of the 20th century, was more huckster than auteur.

title: Kisses
description: A very brief and informal history of the red lip, inspired by the breadth of matte orange on the spring runway.

title: Photos of The Moment | Rag & Bone
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Marissa Webb: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Trans-Atlantic Clint
description: Who ever said American soccer players do not travel well?

title: A Big Hitters Baseball Life, Without the Bombshells
description: As balloting for the Baseball Hall of Fame geared up earlier this winter, rumors began to circulate about why the release of Mike Piazzas book was being pushed back to February, a month after the voting would be concluded and the final results tabulated.

title: Washington Officials Join in Mourning a Young Shooting Victim in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  By the hundreds, mourners filed into the pews of a packed church on this citys South Side on Saturday, clutching one another, weeping and wearing buttons adorned with the smiling face of Hadiya Pendleton, a 15-year-old girl whose death has come to represent the miserable cost of gun and gang violence.

title: Honoring a Picasso in Pinstripes in a Sketchbook
description: There is no telling how many get-well wishes Mariano Rivera has received while recovering from knee surgery. But at least 608 of them  including ones from a Mister Softee man in New York and some hardened Red Sox fans in Boston  have not yet been delivered.

title: Photos of The Moment | Tommy Hilfiger
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Israeli Says Syrian Media Misreported Exiles Views
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A public relations controversy erupted Saturday after a leading Israeli newspaper published comments from a brief interview with the leader of Syrias main exile opposition group.

title: The Gun Report: February 9, 2013
description: On Saturday, the Chicago political establishment will be out in force for a sad event: the funeral of 15-year-old Hadiya Pendleton, the honor student and band majorette who had participated in the Inaugural festivities  and was killed in a random shooting a week later. Michelle Obama will also attend the funeral.

title: Chicago Auto Show Features Few Introductions
description: The Chicago auto show, which opened to the public on Saturday, may not be counted among the worlds most significant in terms of new-model introductions or international prominence, but the citys McCormick Place convention center does have more floor space than any other United States arena where auto shows are held.

title: Lacoste: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Plugging In, Dutch Put Electric Cars to the Test
description: AMSTERDAM  When Patrick Langevoorts company issued him an electric vehicle two years ago, the first months were filled with misadventure: he found himself far from Amsterdam, with only a 25 percent charge remaining, unable to find the charging point listed on a map. Though the car was supposed to travel 100 miles on a full battery, he discovered that cold weather and fast driving decreased that range.

title: Six Killed in Shelling of Iranian Refugee Camp in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Six people were killed and more than 50 were wounded on Saturday when several dozen mortar shells fell on a refugee camp for members of an Iranian opposition group, according to an Iraqi police official.

title: Variety: A Sound Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Well, that was easy. Maybe its because I am a music lover, and there was so much here that was musical. Even so, I appreciated the melodic solve, as well as the quote that harkens back to the time of Victrolas and cylinder phonographs.

title: The Land of the Binge
description: AROUND the time that Netflix released an entire season of House of Cards at once, so that viewers could gorge on all 13 episodes, a friend sent me a plaintive e-mail about the way that foodie-favored restaurants give her no option other than gorging.

title: Cold, Hungry and Stuck on the L.I. Expressway
description: FARMINGVILLE, N.Y.  Lorna Jones decided to brave the blizzard on Friday, venturing onto the Long Island Expressway as the snow began piling up. So did many others here in Suffolk County.

title: Holding States and Schools Accountable
description: As Congress contemplates rewriting No Child Left Behind, President George W. Bushs signature education law, legislators will tussle over a vision of how the federal government should hold states and schools accountable for students academic progress.

title: Safety Concerns Stoke Criticism of Kennel Club
description: Margaret and James Hamilton were a dog power couple, seemingly the perfect people for raising and selling purebreds. Margaret was a breeder and a dog show judge who owned prizewinning Chihuahuas. Some of her litters were registered with the American Kennel Club, a stamp of approval from an organization charged with maintaining breed standards and registering purebreds around the country. Her husband, James, was a leader in a local A.K.C. Rottweiler club.

title: Its Not Easy Being Green
description: WASHINGTON

title: Sunday Dialogue: How to Give Families a Path Out of Poverty
description: Readers discuss safety-net programs, better-paying jobs and support for parents.

title: Beautiful Creature
description: In the year of the snake, Bulgari revisits its iconic Serpenti jewelry collection, which produced sinuous charmers like this 1960s enamel, gold and ruby watch.

title: Benh Zeitlin
description: Benh Zeitlin is the writer, director and soundtrack composer of the fantasy drama Beasts of the Southern Wild, which has been nominated for four Oscars. It was made for a fraction of the cost of other Oscar-nominated films, with scenes shot primarily in Louisiana swampland and with leading roles played by amateur actors.

title: On the Waiting List at the Debt-Rating Club
description: BETTER late than never.

title: Once Again, a Ranger Starts Off With a Bang
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  J. T. Miller said he did not expect to score on his first shift at Madison Square Garden as an N.H.L. player, and he certainly did not expect to hear fans chanting his name.

title: The Pyongyangs All Here
description: Google has now mapped the surface of Mars and the bottom of the ocean. So whats left, a person has to wonder  what remains uncharted?

title: After Ron Paul, Then What?
description: RON PAUL, Republican of Texas, has retired from the House, after winning more than two million presidential primary votes in 2012. He took the partys libertarian wing from ignorable fringe to significant faction. His son, Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, is angling to lead that faction, very possibly as a presidential candidate himself.

title: Svindal Navigates Ice and Fog to Win Mens Downhill Title
description: SCHLADMING, Austria  Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway continued his assault on mens ski racing, winning the downhill at the Alpine world championships on Saturday for his second medal in two events.

title: In Nigeria, Youre Either Somebody or Nobody
description: ABUJA, Nigeria

title: To Tear Down Walls, You Have to Move Out of Your Office
description: This interview with  Robert LoCascio, founder and chief executive of LivePerson, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: German Fascination With Degrees Claims Latest Victim: Education Minister
description: BERLIN  For 32 years, the German education ministers 351-page dissertation sat on a shelf at Heinrich Heine University in Dsseldorf gathering dust while its author pursued a successful political career that carried her to the highest circles of the German government.

title: The Secret to Fixing Bad Schools
description: WHAT would it really take to give students a first-rate education? Some argue that our schools are irremediably broken and that charter schools offer the only solution. The striking achievement of Union City, N.J.  bringing poor, mostly immigrant kids into the educational mainstream  argues for reinventing the public schools we have.

title: Its Sunday in the City: Lets Play Two
description: New York considers itself the mecca of basketball  a conceit infused by street ball legends, a deep roster of native-born N.B.A. stars and the mere existence of Madison Square Garden. The city requires no external validation on this point.

title: When E-Mail Turns From Delight to Deluge
description: IN the not-so-distant past, the chipper AOL sound of Youve got mail! filled me with giddiness and glee. I would eagerly check my in-box, excited to see what message had arrived.

title: In Bed With the President of Ghana?
description: WHEN my husband-to-be and I met the Ghanaian politician John Dramani Mahama at a friends wedding near Accra eight years ago, I liked him immediately. I kept up with his fortunes mostly through mutual friends, and I was happy to learn in 2009 that he had been elected his nations vice president.

title: Keeping Secrets
description: IF you only own a hammer, observed the psychologist Abraham Maslow, you tend to see every problem as a nail.

title: Im Begging, Dont Hack the Hacks
description: WASHINGTON

title: Spying on Law-Abiding Muslims
description: Nearly 30 years ago, the federal courts had to place limits on New York City police surveillance to protect law-abiding citizens who happened to be politically engaged on civil rights and other issues. Based on new court filings in a longstanding suit challenging police surveillance techniques, the courts may need to intervene to stop the New York Police Department from spying on law-abiding citizens once again, this time Muslims.

title: For John Westwood, Fathers Day in February
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  One Thursday every April is designated for children to accompany their parents to their jobs. Then there is the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, which Lee Westwood has turned into Take Your Father to Work Week.

title: India in the Slow Lane
description: Indias economy is about to clock its slowest annual growth rate in a decade. The government said recently that gross domestic product would likely grow at just 5 percent in the fiscal year that ends in March, a sharp fall from the 9-plus-percent growth rates of the mid-2000s.

title: The Body Under the Rug
description: The week I finished the manuscript of my family memoir, I had a terrible nightmare: a dead body turned up in my hotel room. I didnt kill this person, I thought to myself, but everyone will think I did. I went outside to clear my head and when I came back the body was gone. But dead bodies dont just disappear; as I was packing up to leave, I couldnt find my camera and, looking around, noticed a lump in the rug. Thinking the camera might have somehow ended up under the carpet, I lifted it to find a mans head, or rather the front third of a mans head, like a bloody mask. I put the rug down in horror. Now, they are definitely going to think I killed this person, I thought, before waking up.

title: The Daily Do | Rag & Bone
description: Rag and Bone runway hair appears effortless  a deep, side-swept part and a twisted chignon, but with a slept-in look.

title: Americas Beer Duopoly
description: Consumers will benefit from the Justice Departments antitrust suit to block Anheuser-Busch InBev, the countrys largest brewing company, from acquiring one of its competitors. This kind of action was seen less frequently in the Bush administration.

title: Digital Tags Help Ensure the Price Is Right
description: SOME decades ago, a grocery stores aisles were often filled with chunk-a-chunk-a sounds, as clerks stamped prices to the tops of cans and boxes before putting them on shelves. It was a labor-intensive operation, but it did result in a price being affixed to most every item in the store.

title: Russian Protest Leader Put Under House Arrest
description: MOSCOW  A Moscow district court ordered Sergei Udaltsov, a prominent opposition leader, to be placed under house arrest on Saturday, in one of the most assertive legal measures to date against a leader of the anti-Kremlin protests that began more than a year ago.

title: Any Solution to Syria?
description: NEW DELHI

title: The Gradual Selling of America the Beautiful
description: Of the 2.27 billion acres that constitute the land area of the United States, a little less than 30 percent  about 640 million acres  belongs to you, the American citizen. It is land acquired over the years by treaty, conquest or purchase by the federal government acting on behalf of the people, and indisputably belongs to neither the states nor individuals. But in the last few decades no part of the American land mass has stirred greater controversy.

title: Lost in the Stars of a Hotels Rating
description: THE Internet deserves credit for creating new and cash-saving ways to handle mundane tasks, like booking a hotel. But these innovations can come at a price, and the price is often insanity. Other times its rage. More often, its rages slightly mellower cousin, frustration.

description: ALL the recent talk in Washington about reforming immigration policy brings to mind Pat Paulsen, the comedian who, every four years, conducted faux campaigns for president.

title: In China, a Vast Chasm Between the Rich and the Rest
description: BEIJING  The passing coal miners in remote Shaanxi Province took one look at our marooned Audi and walked on, leaving us stuck on the sleet-covered mountain road.

title: Russia Detains 271 People During Security Raid in St. Petersburg
description: MOSCOW  Russian police and security officials in St. Petersburg detained 271 people, mostly migrants from Central Asia and the North Caucasus region, during a raid on Friday on Muslim prayer rooms at a central market. They said the raid was carried out to check residency permits and to eliminate networks of religious extremists planning terrorist attacks.

title: Steaks, the Family Business
description: MY family has been in the meat business for five generations, starting in the 1860s. My grandfathers family business specialized in beef. And my grandmothers family specialty was veal. Both families were in the Bronx.

description: Q. You want to move into management or a higher executive position, but youre so good at your current job that youre now defined by it. How can you find a way out of this pigeonhole?

title: Florida Republicans Brace for a Fraud Trial, and an Airing of Old Grudges
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The surroundings are far from opulent and the cocktails will have to wait, but as political events go, this one is expected to draw a whos who of present and past Florida political notables: a former governor, a former State House speaker and a former State Senate president are all expected to drop by, and the current State House speaker, too.

title: Baseballs Recurring Narrative: Every Year They Write the Book
description: The use of the word narrative seemed to rise sharply last season, at least in the press box and on blogs. It usually referred to a preconceived story arc and the tendency of reporters to shape articles through that frame. One player, R. A. Dickey of the Mets, used the word often, but Dickey was a writer, too; he released his autobiography before the season.

title: Captivity in Black and White
description: On Jan. 1, 1863  the effective date of the Emancipation Proclamation  a Massachusetts private named Alexander Hobbs recorded these words in his journal: I have now to chronicle an event which will be remembered by us all while we live. But Hobbs was not referring to emancipation. He wrote instead of a New Years Day battle in Texas and a story of captivity that revealed how fragile freedom could be, even after Lincolns proclamation.

title: Planning Ahead, With an Eye on Tax Changes
description: IF youve gathered up the documents and compiled the data for your 2012 tax return, congratulations. The next part, of course, may be painful: actually calculating your taxes.

description: FOR Colette Hayward and Margaret Selby, the problem is this: Maryland recognizes their 2009 marriage, but the federal government does not.

description: TAX preparation is moving to the cloud.

description: TAX planning can be difficult for a small business, all the more so when a lot of the work is left until the last minute  not by the owners or their accountants, but by Congress.

title: Looking Beyond Income, to a Tax on Wealth
description: INCOME tax rates have recently been raised slightly for some affluent people, and there is pressure for additional increases. But some economists say raising marginal income tax rates on high earners may miss the mark.

description: I HAVENT a clue what kind of psychiatrist Elisabeth Kbler-Ross was. But I do know she was a terrific financial planner.

title: Fund Let Voices Be Heard, and for One Boy That Was Enough
description: For more than 100 years, the stories of struggle that make up The New York Times Neediest Cases Funds annual campaign have inspired readers to help New Yorkers in dire financial need.

title: Venezuela, Despite Troubles, Proudly Seizes on a Hat
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuela seems to lurch from one crisis to another. President Hugo Chvez has virtually disappeared since going to Cuba for cancer surgery more than eight weeks ago. Last month, 58 people were killed in a prison when inmates clashed with soldiers. Inflation is spiking, the government just announced a currency devaluation and lurid murders are the stuff of daily headlines.

title: An Instagram Moment
description: A new trend has emerged in the staging of runway shows, one that acknowledges the way that many editors now view them. In addition to looking for trends of the season and the best looks for their magazines, almost everyone is scouting for that one outfit that will make a great post on Twitter or Instagram.

title: Battling College Costs, a Paycheck at a Time
description: If Steve Boedefeld graduates from Appalachian State University without any student loan debt, it will be because of the money he earned fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan and the money he now saves by eating what he grows or kills.

title: In Address, President Will Focus on the Middle Class
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday will seek to move beyond the politics of the moment to define a second-term agenda built around restoring economic prosperity to the middle class, using his State of the Union address to unveil initiatives in education, infrastructure, clean energy and manufacturing.

description: Social workers discuss their involvement with the Neediest Cases Fund and their profession.

title: A School Band With History Crams for Carnival
description: NEW ORLEANS  In other parts of New Orleans, school bands have spent recent weeks marching up and down narrow neighborhood streets, often followed by flocks of children. But not around McDonogh 35 High School in the Seventh Ward, where neighbors say the band remains in school, hunched over its music and cramming for Carnival parades.

title: The Winter Ball
description: Soccer in most of the world is played through the winter (at least in the Northern Hemisphere), and when foul weather intrudes it most often only dampens the field. At times, though, snow blankets the pristine playing surfaces, and the winter ball has to be rolled out.

title: Model-Morphosis | Liu Wen at Jason Wu
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2013 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Liu Wen for Marilyn Agency before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Diane Kendal and hair by Odile Gilbert.

description: The entrants are set for the N.B.A.s annual 3-point contest, an integral part of the leagues upcoming All-Star weekend, but determining who will be the favorite is difficult, given past results.

description: Zynga struggles to successfully migrate its games to mobile devices, Slovenia gives loan guarantees to several businesses and more restaurants add healthier options to their menus.

title: Blackhawks Thrive Away From Home
description: With the 48-game N.H.L. season about one-quarter complete, the Chicago Blackhawks are the leagues top team, despite a schedule that put them on the road for 9 of their first 11 games. Previously scheduled events like concerts and circus performances have limited their access to United Center, so the Blackhawks have played as many games at Phoenix as they have played at home.

title: Return of Wall Has Wizards Thinking the Unthinkable: A Run at the Playoffs
description: WASHINGTON  When the Wizards John Wall was rehabilitating his injured left knee this season, he did what he could to stay involved with the team. He went to road games. He attended practice. He watched game film on a monitor whenever he climbed on the teams antigravity treadmill.

title: Fuel and Food Are Quick, but the Fealty Is Forever
description: SELINSGROVE, Pa.  The fat columns and thick canopy are a neon Stonehenge, beckoning travelers to gather in pagan adulation. Out-of-staters passing by on Route 15 may be mystified by the name, but to residents of central Pennsylvania the brightly lighted Sheetz convenience store, stocked with Utz chips and a Cupoccino machine, is a source of pride  no, passion.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 10

description: LOS ANGELES  School officials in Santa Ana were in a bind several years ago: they wanted to build hundreds of new classrooms, but feared that voters would rebel against tax increases to pay for the construction.

title: James Muri, Bomber Pilot Honored for Valor in Battle of Midway, Is Dead at 94
description: James Muri survived the first half of June 4, 1942, on the strength of his Army Air Forces pilot training. That was the day of his first combat mission, and the first day of the Battle of Midway. He piloted an unwieldy B-26 twin-engine bomber through heavy antiaircraft fire, maneuvered it close to a Japanese aircraft carrier, dropped a torpedo and pulled away into a sky filled with enemy shells just as his bomb detonated.

title: Starr Saphir, Bird-Watching Guide in Central Park, Dies at 73
description: When Starr Saphir looked up at the star-speckled night sky, she thought of the multitude of moths, mosquitoes and other insects being pursued by swooping nighthawks.

description: The powerful storm that swept through the Northeast on Saturday buried some areas under as much as three feet of snow and forced evacuations of coastal areas in Massachusetts.

title: Snedeker Stays on Roll at Pebble Beach
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Two top-three finishes and a 68.3-stroke average were not enough to earn Brandt Snedeker a player of the month nomination in January. With more of the same play here, Snedeker, the FedEx Cup points leader, has established himself as Februarys front-runner.

His heroics included one of the most celebrated moments in Rangers history, when he beat the rookie goaltender Martin Brodeur with a wraparound in the second overtime of Game 7 at Madison Square Garden.

description: WASHINGTON  On Saturday afternoon, members of the George Washington mens basketball team ventured outdoors, in uniform, to hand out Revolution-era, tricornered hats to students who were waiting in line to get into Smith Center. It was a very long line.
