description: The following is the text as prepared for delivery of President Obamas State of the Union Address, as provided by the White House:

title: The Ethics of Raising Purebred Dogs
College Health Plans Respond as Transgender Students Gain Visibility
description: Over the last decade, as activists started pushing colleges to accommodate transgender students, they first raised only basic issues, like recognizing a name change or deciding who could use which bathrooms. But the front lines have shifted fast, particularly at the nations elite colleges, and a growing number are now offering students health insurance plans with coverage for gender reassignment surgery.

title: Reins Easing on New York Construction Loans
description: Construction in New York slowed to a trickle in the recession, but there are finally signs that the construction loan market is coming back to life.

description: David Axelrod, President Obamas former strategist, discussed the State of the Union address and the state of American politics in the wake of the election with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC.

description: Nine years ago in the Champions League, a young soccer coach watched from the sideline as his upstart team pulled off a last-minute Round of 16 upset against a powerhouse.

title: Cheryl McKissack Daniel
description: Ms. McKissack Daniel, 51, is president and chief executive of McKissack & McKissack, a New York company involved in several infrastructure projects, including Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, the World Trade Center and Columbia Universitys expansion.

title: Study Finds More Benefits of Folic Acid
description: Women taking folic acid, a B vitamin, before pregnancy were less likely to give birth to children with the most severe form of autism, a new study has found. Researchers in Norway and at Columbia University followed more than 85,170 Norwegian mothers who gave birth between 2002 and 2008, recording their prenatal diets and surveying them for six and a half years on average. Among their children, the researchers identified 270 with autism spectrum disorders, including 114 with autism disorder. The researchers found that the risk of having a child with autism disorder was reduced by 40 percent among women who had taken folic acid supplements during the critical developmental period from four weeks before conception and continuing eight weeks into the pregnancy. Still, the absolute risk that a child would have autism disorder was very low: 0.2 percent among women not taking folic acid, versus 0.1 percent among those who did. The study was published online on Tuesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Anxiety Over Future of Bike Lanes
description: During Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs tenure, New York City has become a cycling haven, with sprawling lanes across each borough and a bike-share program set to begin this spring.

title: Tired of the Duty-Free Shop? Go Check Out Those Rodins
description: ROISSY, France  When Steve and Kimberly Kulpanowski arrived at the Roissy-Charles de Gaulle Airport to fly home to Detroit, they could not believe their luck.

title: Perhaps Too Much Old Glory for Yanks?
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: After Rebuke, an Apology for Pastor in Newtown
description: In an unexpected reversal, the head of a conservative national Lutheran denomination has apologized after criticizing a pastor in Newtown, Conn., for taking part in an interfaith memorial service.

title: Unbeaten Since 2003, Wheelchair Champ Retires
description: Esther Vergeer did not simply go out on top. She went out after a decade of soaring out of other players reach.

title: De la Renta Show With Some Galliano Style
description: John Galliano was not physically present at the Oscar de la Renta show Tuesday night, though his presence most certainly could be felt in the collection.

title: A Smaller Rival Takes Aim at Pandora
description: ONE of advertisings great (or at least most amusing) traditions is the challenger attack ad, in which a fields No. 2 (or No. 3) player tries to distinguish itself by taking aim at the leader. When artfully done it can have a great effect, as in Aviss long-running We try harder campaign against Hertz, or Samsungs recent ads mocking the obedience of iPhone fans.

description: BERLIN

title: Sophie Theallet: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

description: RECENT SALE

title: Big Insurer Hires a Hospital Executive as Chief
description: WellPoint, one of the nations largest health insurers, announced on Tuesday that it had chosen an experienced hospital executive to lead it through sweeping changes created by the federal health care overhaul law.

title: New Pope? Ive Given Up Hope
description: THERE is a poignant air, almost wistful, to electing a pope in the modern world. In a time of discredited monarchies, can this monarchy survive and be relevant? There is nostalgia for the assurances of the past, quaint in their charm, but trepidation over their survivability. In monarchies, change is supposed to come from the top, if it is to come at all. So people who want to alter things in Catholic life are told to wait for a new pope. Only he has the authority to make the changeless church change, but it is his authority that stands in the way of change.

title: Dolan Is Seen as Long Shot to Be Pope
description: It was only a year ago that Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, received his red hat in Rome, marking him as one of the princes of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Another Delay for States Fracking Decision
description: Once again, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has delayed a decision on whether to allow horizontal hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, to begin in New York State. The states health commissioner says that a review of the potential health impacts of this controversial type of natural gas drilling is not complete.

title: Hurricane Center Seeks Expanded Authority to Issue Warnings
description: Days before Hurricane Sandy hit, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center knew that it was going to pack a wallop when it slammed into the East Coast.

title: Yankees Resale Market Will Compete With StubHub
description: During the past year or so, the Yankees have blamed ticket exchanges like StubHub for a relatively modest decline in their home attendance. According to the Yankees logic, fans are holding off buying tickets  including full-priced ones from the team  because plenty of tickets are being sold online for below face value thanks to speculators, who are driving prices.

title: My Familys Papers
description: WASHINGTON

title: G.O.P. Puts On a Calmer Face, Except for One Wild-Eyed Rocker
description: WASHINGTON  In the wake of their electoral drubbing in November, Republicans sought an image reboot at President Obamas State of the Union address, a new face that would be both more positive and less strident, youthful and multicultural but also quietly constructive and respectful.

title: Elie Tahari: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: For Mets, Reasons to Hope (in 2014)
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

title: France: Assembly Passes Gay Marriage Bill
description: The lower house of Parliament, after more than 100 hours of debate, approved a law on Tuesday that would legalize same-sex marriage and give the same rights to all married couples to adopt children. The bill, promoted by President Franois Hollande and his Socialist Party, which controls the legislature, passed by 329 to 229 in the National Assembly, despite loud opposition from religious leaders and from the center-right. The bill will come before the Senate on April 2, where it is also expected to pass.

title: The Search for a Champion
description: Scenes from the 137th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

title: Big Banks Are Told to Review Their Own Foreclosures
description: Washington is seeking help from an unlikely group in its effort to distribute billions of dollars to struggling homeowners in foreclosure: the same banks accused of abusing homeowners with shoddy foreclosure practices.

title: Hoboken Mayor Seeks Storm Protection More Suitable for High-Rise Buildings
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  Places long accustomed to the routine beatings of hurricanes have shaped this countrys traditional response to them: evacuate during the storm, then elevate the buildings or retreat inland to protect against the next onslaught.

title: V.I.P.: Very Important Pooch

title: North Koreas Defiance
description: North Koreas third nuclear weapons test has dashed any hope that its new dictator, Kim Jong-un, would be any more sensible than his father or grandfather before him. It has reaffirmed the international communitys utter failure to devise a policy that might reverse, or at least slow, the Norths nuclear program.

title: Lawmakers to Press Postal Officials on Decision to End Saturday Mail Delivery
description: WASHINGTON  The Postal Service is expected to outline at a Senate hearing on Wednesday its legal justification for ending Saturday mail delivery, a change opposed by several lawmakers who say the agency is circumventing a Congressional mandate.

title: Victimized by Credit Reports
description: The companies that compile and sell credit reports on 200 million Americans have often dismissed allegations of widespread errors in the reports. But a long-awaited study issued this week by the Federal Trade Commission shows that the problem is quite real  with one in five consumers having confirmed errors in their reports.

title: Lottery Numbers
From Dog Breeder to Westminster Judge
description: Seconds after Banana Joe, a 6-year-old affenpinscher, won Best in Show at the 137th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show Tuesday night, the toy dog was hoisted in the air in the loving embrace of his handler, Ernesto Lara. Once, twice, three times, Lara wiggled him in the air before securing him in a hug. Lara seemed happier than Banana Joe.

title: Holiday Parking
description: Because of Ash Wednesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Nevin S. Scrimshaw, Pioneer Nutritionist, Dies at 95
description: Dr. Nevin S. Scrimshaw, a nutritionist who improved the health of millions of children in developing countries by creating low-cost vegetable-based foods for weaning infants, died on Friday in Plymouth, N.H. He was 95.

title: Study Points to Shorter Treatments for Prostate Cancer
description: Men with high-risk prostate cancer treated with only 18 months of hormone therapy live just as long as those treated for a more standard 36 months, a new study has found.

description: David Lloyd, an American tenor who sang leading roles with the New York City Opera in the 1950s, died on Friday in the Bronx. He was 92.

title: Taking Guns to Holy Ground
description: MEXICO CITY  A young woman cradling a large crucifix left Mexicos holiest shrine, the Basilica of St. Mary of Guadalupe, on a recent afternoon and stopped at a tent outside, where soldiers were piling up pistols and rifles on a table, part of a citywide cash-for-guns program.

title: Vital City Revenue, Lost in the Fine Print
description: New York is the land of the invisible real estate scheme that one day becomes visible and then utterly bewildering. This week, we turn around and the city comptroller is revealing that 15 years ago, the city agreed to sell the land under the Marriott Marquis in Times Square to the hotel. If the comptrollers numbers are right  and the mayors Twitter robot moved quickly to mock him in a denial so substantive that it did not use up the entire 140-character allotment for posts  the city will come away with a dime on the dollar of the actual value of its land.

President Obamas message in the State of the Union address was clear: It doesnt have to be this way.

title: Challenged for His Seat at 89, a Senator Does Not Go Gentle

title: A Secretive Country Gives Experts Few Clues to Judge Its Nuclear Program

title: Why Four Workouts a Week May Be Better Than Six
description: A common concern about exercise is that if you dont do it almost every day, you wont achieve much health benefit. But a commendable new study suggests otherwise, showing that a fairly leisurely approach to scheduling workouts may actually be more beneficial than working out almost daily.

title: Raising Minimum Wage Would Ease Income Gap but Carries Political Risks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama called on Congress to raise the federal minimum wage to $9 an hour from $7.25 and to automatically adjust it with inflation, a move aimed at increasing the earnings of millions of cooks, janitors, aides to the elderly and other low-wage workers.

title: In Age of Spending Cuts, Making a Case for Government
description: WASHINGTON  Thirty-two years after President Ronald Reagan proclaimed that government is the problem and 17 years after President Bill Clinton offered a surrender of sorts on that issue by stating that the era of big government is over, President Obama made a case Tuesday night for closing out the politics of austerity.

title: Thai Soldiers Repel Attack in Big Setback to Insurgents
description: BANGKOK  Thai soldiers repelled an attack on a military outpost early Wednesday, killing at least 16 gunmen in what appeared to be a significant setback for ethnic insurgent groups leading a bloody uprising now in its ninth year.

title: Obamas Speech

title: No Ordinary Affenpinscher, Banana Joe Is Named Best in Show
description: Banana Joe, a black dog with a monkeylike face, became the first affenpinscher to win Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday night. He defeated six dogs, one a Portuguese water dog on the same night that Bo, who is the same breed, watched his master, President Obama, deliver the State of the Union address.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (TMC) GOON (2012) Seann William Scott (above right, with Liev Schreiber) is Doug Glatt, a bouncer who discovers a second career as a minor-league hockey player who gains popularity not by scoring goals but by winning brawls in this comedy directed by Michael Dowse and written by Jay Baruchel and Evan Goldberg. Doug has a softer side off the ice, where he meets Eva (Alison Pill), a hockey fan who is only partly resistant to his goofy charm. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden described a moment when this movie reveals its true colors and turns from a rowdy sports farce into something vaguely resembling the Rocky of hockey movies. He added: Behind the films brass knuckles are tender fingers. Why else would Goon use music from Puccinis Turandot to underscore critical dramatic moments?

title: Is There Another Way Forward Over North Korea?
description: BEIJING  Another nuclear test in North Korea. More United Nations-led sanctions. Increasing militarization in Northeast Asia, with South Korea planning to deploy cruise missiles capable of striking North Korea  and Pyongyang threatening unspecified second and third measures of greater intensity against the United States as punishment for persistent American hostility, with the nuclear test Tuesday just a first measure.

title: Fugitives Threats Against Police Drew Enormous Response

Dorner had a long list of grievances and potential victims, most of them police officers he had once worked with, and he was already suspected of killing the daughter of a retired police official and her fianc. So law enforcement officials moved rapidly to protect their own, removing officers from the streets and setting up the largest security detail in any city in recent history.

title: One for the Road

Their clothes convey a jet-set life where one flits breezily from Patmos to Punjab. Now Lucky Brand has tapped the duo to do a collection including flowy tops, delicately embroidered jackets and a souk-ready jute-and-leather tote that delivers the pairs signature style at prices that are downright proletariat.

title: Money for the Taking in the Niger Delta Swamps
description: When night falls on the Niger Delta, hundreds of people set sail on hand-made wooden boats toward the oil pumps jutting out along the swampy creeks. Clouds of smoke float in the night air. Makeshift fuel refineries  with the same machines once used to distill palm oil into gin  begin churning crude oil into diesel fuel.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  In her harshest criticism yet of North Korea, the incoming president of South Korea, Park Geun-hye, warned on Wednesday that the Norths pursuit of nuclear weapons would bring its government self-destruction.

description: In North Korea Confirms It Conducted 3rd Nuclear Test, David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun report on North Koreas first nuclear test since 2009.

title: Taking a Third Pass at Selling Movie Subscriptions
description: Twice in 2011, Stacy Spikes tried to start a subscription service for going to the movies. Called MoviePass, it offered cinephiles nearly unlimited access to theaters  up to one 2-D film each day  for a flat monthly fee. Mr. Spikes hoped his service would transform the industry; he wanted to see it go big. But something always got in the way.

title: Connie Britton Is a Late Bloomer
description: Connie Britton got over it a long time ago, the part that got away. But its a good story, and she still tells it with feeling: The year was 1995. Edward Burns, who had just directed her (and starred in) The Brothers McMullen, reached into his backpack one night over dinner and handed her a script that Cameron Crowe had sent him to read. Burns wasnt interested himself, wanting to act in his own films instead. But he thought Britton was perfect for the romantic lead.

title: How Napoleon Chagnon Became Our Most Controversial Anthropologist
description: Among the hazards Napoleon Chagnon encountered in the Venezuelan jungle were a jaguar that would have mauled him had it not become confused by his mosquito net and a 15-foot anaconda that lunged from a stream over which he bent to drink. There were also hairy black spiders, rats that clambered up and down his hammock ropes and a trio of Yanomami tribesmen who tried to smash his skull with an ax while he slept. (The men abandoned their plan when they realized that Chagnon, a light sleeper, kept a loaded shotgun within arms reach.) These are impressive adversaries  Indiana Jones had nothing on me, is how Chagnon puts it  but by far his most tenacious foes have been members of his own profession.

title: Do Violent Video Games Make People More Violent in Real Life?
description: Young people, especially boys, are playing bloodier and more realistic video games than ever before, and scientists are looking for links between real life violence and violent video games. However, the research so far is inconclusive.

description: The venture capital firm Lux Capital said on Wednesday that it had closed its third fund at $245 million, the biggest pool of capital it has raised to date.

title: Goodbye Pope, Hello Mufti
description: ROME  I was at a conference on religious freedom and interreligious dialogue here on Monday when, late in the morning, journalists in the back rows started receiving phone alerts and promptly left the room. The conference chairman interrupted the proceedings and apologized: The Italian journalists, most of them working the religion beat, had just received important news from the Vatican.

title: In Frothy Real Estate Market, Switzerland Tightens Capital Rules on Banks

title: Hope in a Bottle
description: My late father once told me that a person who wants to be loved should get into smells and poetry. Like great advisers everywhere, he failed to take his own advice. (He smoked a brand of cigarettes called Sweet Afton, after the poem by Robert Burns. That just about covered the terrain of his advice. My mother emptied his ashtrays for 30 years, then didnt speak to him for another 30.) But like any sentimental son, I sought to turn into wisdom the advice my father was too much himself to heed. And where my dad was merely trying it on, Baudelaire was for real. At an early age I developed, like him, a completely French sensitivity to the scent of skin and floating clothes. He called the male love of female smell a kind of androgyny, and he believed that a man without it  a man opposed to his feminine side  was really an incomplete being.

description: MADRIDThe European Central Bank and its president, Mario Draghi, want to ensure that their voices get heard beyond the financial district of Frankfurt.

description: PARIS  The ING Group, the largest Dutch bank, said on Wednesday that it would cut 2,400 jobs in its retail banking business as more of its customers adopted mobile banking.

title:
On Immigration,

Bipartisan Praise
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas nonconfrontational tone on an immigration overhaul in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night probably did more to advance the issue, lawmakers said, than if had he offered a fierce rallying cry, as he did about gun restrictions.

title: Avoiding the Curse of the Oil-Rich Nations
description: Every nation wants to strike oil, and after it happens, nearly every nation is worse off for it. It may seem paradoxical, but finding a hole in the ground that spouts money can be one of the worst things that can happen to a country.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Comcast Buys Rest of NBCUniversal, and Sites That Appeal to Book Lovers
description: 9:28 a.m. | Updated Comcast agreed to pay General Electric $16.7 billion to acquire their remaining 49 percent stake in NBCUniversal on Tuesday, Amy Chozick and Brian Stelter write. Brian Roberts, Comcasts chief executive, said that the acquisition was a necessary step given the rapidly changing television business and the necessity of owning content. Comcast bought a 51 percent share in NBCUniversal in early 2011, with the option of buying the rest of the company over the next seven years; the process was accelerated at least in part by a clash in corporate cultures between G.E. and Comcast. The deal will also include 30 Rockefeller Plaza and the CNBC headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., for about $1.4 billion. Naming rights are included in the deal, so the red G.E. sign atop 30 Rockefeller Plaza could be replaced with a Comcast logo.

title: Six More Journalists Held in British Hacking Case
description: LONDON  Adding momentum to police investigations that have already cost Rupert Murdochs newspaper empire in Britain hundreds of millions of dollars, Scotland Yard said Wednesday that six more journalists who previously worked for The News of the World were arrested at dawn on suspicion of hacking into cellphone messages.

title: Daily Report: Silicon Valley and Immigrant Groups Find Common Cause
description: Silicon Valley executives, who have long pressed the government to provide more visas for foreign-born math and science brains, are joining forces with an array of immigration groups seeking comprehensive changes in the law, reports Somini Sengupta of The New York Times.

title: Rising From Ruins
description: SEBASTIA, West Bank  I spent last Sunday, a gorgeous early spring day, visiting a colonnaded street leading to a Roman theater, the 30 B.C. temple of Augustus and a church built to commemorate the martyrdom of John the Baptist, which supposedly occurred on this hill. These and many more ruins can be seen in Sebastia, an ancient city first settled in the Early Bronze Age less than ten miles northwest of Nablus.

title: Now Streaming | Michael Kors Fall 2013 Womens Collection

description: A new, two-year project to promote an arts partnership between the United States and Cuba was announced Tuesday by the Joyce Theater Foundation and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The project is designed to offer Cubans arts administration training, internships and help creating a new dance work to be performed at the Joyce Theater.

title: Life of Pi, the Silent Version
description: David Magee is an Oscar nominee and a contender for a Writers Guild Award, this weekend, for his adaptation of the novel Life of Pi. But his fellow writers might look askance at his day job before becoming a screenwriter: he abridged books.

description: A group of health advocates and public health officials from major cities around the country are asking the Food and Drug Administration to regulate the amount of caloric sweeteners in sodas and other beverages, arguing that the scientific consensus is that the level of added sugars in those products is unsafe.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Columbus Dispatch: In this review of Creamy and Crunchy, a new history of peanut butter, it is revealed that the first commercial version was half peanut butter, half processed cheese. Shouldnt this be on the snack menu of every retro-American restaurant, alongside the deviled eggs and beer cheese?  Julia Moskin

title: Giddyup
description: Horse fiction is a staple among school-age readers, particularly girls, but for some reason picture books about horses are less common. This makes two new picture books, Noni the Pony and Rosies Magic Horse, welcome additions to the genre. Each demonstrates the pleasures of horses and ponies for children whose feet do not yet reach the stirrups.

title: Parnell Could Close for Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Bobby Parnell received a call from Manager Terry Collins on Tuesday night, and the message was simple: If Frank Francisco has to begin the season on the disabled list, then you are the Mets closer.

title: How to Help Veterans Succeed in College
description: In 2004, I returned from a year in Iraq to finish my undergraduate degree at the University of Rhode Island. Since I took more than a years leave of absence to deploy, I was forced to reapply to the university. While writing another entrance essay to explain how I spent my year off, I wondered why my school didnt have a peer support system for its students who are veterans.

description: A deadly bat fungus has spread to three caves in Cumberland Gap National Historic Park in Virginia, park officials have confirmed.

title: Lost in Translation? Try a Google App
description: The slow boat to Chongqing left at 4 the next morning, according to Tan Kao, a helpful young man who approached me in the bustling port of Fengjie, a Yangtze River town not accustomed to foreign visitors. But his English maxed out there, and I still had no idea how to book a ticket (and was deeply reluctant to return at 3 a.m. without one).

title: Rubios Thirst Trumps His Message
description: Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican of Cuban heritage, may be the savior of the Republican Party, as Time Magazine recently declared.

title: Lady Gaga Postpones Concerts Because of Illness
description: Lady Gaga has postponed four concerts in Chicago; Detroit; and Hamilton, Ontario, over the next week because she is suffering from severe joint pain brought on by an injury, the singer announced Tuesday on her Web site.

title: A Meal Discount for Well-Behaved Children?
description: Last summer while enjoying an anniversary dinner at a lovely  and pricey  waterfront restaurant, my husband and I realized that guests at a nearby table had two children who appeared to be under age 10. They had been so quiet and orderly  no one was demanding ketchup or complaining loudly  that it was an hour into our meal before we realized they were there.

title: At SAP Open, a Showcase for the Next Generation
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Over the weekend, Andy Roddick donned a knitted hat and a white golf glove at a celebrity pro-am in Pebble Beach, Calif., Americas one-time tennis poster boy trading in his workmans racket for leisure and a nine iron.

title: Cervelli Gives Brief Account of Visit to Clinic
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Francisco Cervelli understands he made a mistake. What he will not say is who urged him to make it.

title: Bill Clinton to Present Film Societys Chaplin Award to Barbra Streisand
description: Now that hes got a little more time on his hands these days, former President Bill Clinton seems to have a reignited passion for motion pictures. First, he turned up at the awards ceremony for the Golden Globes to sing the praises of Steven Spielbergs Lincoln, and now hell be giving a coveted film prize to Barbra Streisand. The Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Wednesday morning that Mr. Clinton will present its Chaplin Award to Ms. Streisand at a gala ceremony on April 22. Ms. Streisand, the actress, singer and director whose movies include Funny Girl, The Way We Were, Yentl and The Prince of Tides, was announced last month as the 40th recipient of the Chaplin Award. That honor has previously been given to artists like Catherine Deneuve, Sidney Poitier, Michael Douglas, Tom Hanks and Meryl Streep. The Film Society said its awards gala, to be held at Lincoln Center, would be attended by other celebrity guests and feature film clips and interviews celebrating Ms. Streisands career.

title: Paris to Madrid Gets Faster
description: The first direct Madrid-Barcelona-Paris high-speed train service is set to begin in April, cutting the current standard service running time to 9 hours from 15 hours. Spain inaugurated its first high-speed line connecting the country to France last month, an improvement heralded by Prince Felipe, but passengers currently have to transfer from Spains AVE trains to Frances TGV trains near the border.

title: After the State of the Union
description: Examining reaction to President Obamas address

title: Extending a Theme, Obama Promotes Resurgence in U.S. Manufacturing
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  The day after President Obama charted an expansive new view of the governments role in society, it seemed less and less likely that many of his proposals would survive the political riptide on Capitol Hill.

title: If You Like Janis Ian, Try Emily Hurd
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons generation.

title: 200 Years of Pride and Prejudice
description: Cover designs say a lot about the cultural reach of Jane Austens classic.

title: Madoff Continues to Affect Owners of the Mets
description: These days, the Mets could use a little extra cash. They are operating like a small-market club, preferring to stock up on low-salaried players and not acquiring major free agents.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 13
Calmly, Pick for Treasury Offers Replies to Senators
description: WASHINGTON Jacob J. Lew, President Obamas nominee for Treasury secretary, faced some fierce questioning on Wednesday from the Senate Finance Committeeon his tenure at the bailed-out Citigroup and on an investment based in the Cayman Islands. But the even-tempered, bookish Mr. Lew parried the blows and appeared likely to win the committees approval and Senate confirmation.

title: Not Just a Feminine Mystique': What Hasnt Changed Enough for Women and Family?
description: On The Timess Room for Debate online forum, Gail Collins led a discussion among five women about the 50th anniversary of The Feminine Mystique. Betty Friedan, she said, wrote a cry of rage and frustration about feeling trapped in her role. She asked her debaters, Whats your cry of rage today? and they answered, with passion you can see and hear (watch their discussion, a Google Plus video debate, here).

title: RHA Earphones Cut Frills and the Price
description: RHA, the Glasgow headphone company that makes some good-quality earphones at a modest price, has in a sense, downscaled. It has adapted some key components from its midprice earphones to produce the budget-price MA150.

title: The 200-Year Jane Austen Book Club
description: Lets just be honest about our superficiality. Even when it comes to the high-minded business of literature, people do judge books by their covers. Perhaps thats why Amazon produces glossy mock covers for its disembodied e-books, to be inspected and decided upon alongside the traditional print offerings.

title: Keeping Up the Pressure on Gun Violence
description: The Timess Megan Liberman sits down with Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia, president of the United States Conference of Mayors, to talk about his hopes for tougher gun legislation.

title: Only Scandinavian Sharks Were Used in the Making of This Film
description: Joachim Ronning and Espen Sandberg, who jointly directed Kon-Tiki, one of the five nominees for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film, came naturally to their subject, the explorer Thor Heyerdahls 1947 voyage across the Pacific Ocean on a balsawood raft. Friends since they were 10 years old, both men are from a small town in southern Norway that neighbors Heyerdahls birthplace, and as boys were enthralled when they visited the Kon-Tiki Museum in Oslo.

title: Westminsters Best in Show Hits Broadway: Banana Joe in Drood for a Night
description: You know how these show-business success stories go: one day youre just a hound nobodys heard of, the next youre making your debut on Broadway. In the latest chapter of the tale of Banana Joe, the affable affenpinscher who was named Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday night, this newly minted celebrity pooch is heading from Madison Square Garden to Studio 54 on Wednesday, where he will be joining the cast of The Mystery of Edwin Drood, the Broadway musical adapted from the unfinished Charles Dickens novel.

title: Photos of The Moment | Rodarte
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Well Flu Quiz
description: What surface is the most friendly to the flu virus? Wheres the best place to stand when youre talking to a sick person? And how are Australians curbing germs in schools?

title: What Sort of Leader Was Lincoln?
description: What kind of a leader was Abraham Lincoln? This is a question that has bedeviled every student of Lincoln who has ever considered it, even today, 204 years after his birth. There is virtual consensus that Lincoln was an exemplary leader, but opinion differs on the lessons to be drawn from his leadership. Did he exert features of moral grandeur and heroism necessary to steer the country through its deepest political crisis? Or was he an aspiring tyrant, especially in his use of executive power?

title: Curfew Lifts in Some Areas of Kashmir
description: SRINAGAR, Jammu and Kashmir  Authorities eased the curfew in the Kashmir Valley on Wednesday, its fifth day, lifting restrictions in several areas of the summer capital of Srinagar as well as the districts of Budgam, Pulwama and Kupwara.

title: In Speech, Obama Tempers Expectations of Syrias Future
description: WASHINGTON  Having overruled top advisers who had argued for arming the opposition in Syria, President Obama appeared to moderate his expectations for change in that war-torn country in Tuesdays State of the Union speech.

title: Memorable Moves by Nash in Rangers Win
description: When the Rangers acquired Rick Nash in the off-season, much was said about him being the missing piece of the puzzle  another playmaker who would help a team that struggled to score goals. So far this season the Rangers are scoring at a similar clip to last season (2.67 goals per game vs. 2.71 last season). But the Rangers, known more for their grinding play than their grace, have become a highlight reel presence thanks to Nashs fancy footwork.

title: A Cookie Workout
description: In what may be the first official collaboration between a pastry chef and a prominent model, Christina Tosi of Momofuku Milk Bar andKarlie Klossare traveling around the city today in a truck to pass out cookies and mark the end of Fashion Week. Lucky Peach features Ms. Tosi and Ms. Kloss in a video (with a cameo from Danny Bowien of Mission Chinese) making Perfect 10 Kookies, a gluten-free confection, in vintage Jane Fonda aerobics gear.

title: Alderson Talks About Mejia and Santana
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson spoke to reporters Wednesday morning and answered a variety of questions that lingered as spring training got under way.

title: Using Federal Oil Revenues to Cut Americas Oil Use
description: In his State of the Union message on Tuesday night, President Obama proposed the creation of an Energy Security Trust to find alternatives to dependence on oil for the nations transportation needs. The trust would be financed from revenue from oil and gas royalties that the federal government collects from companies that drill on federal land.

title: 11 Afghans Killed in Military Actions Near Pakistan Border
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  International military officials are investigating two episodes in which as many as 11 Afghan civilians may have been killed in what appeared to be American-led military actions.

title: Comcasts Prime-Time Deal
description: Comcast has smartly ad-libbed on an already winning script. Back in 2009, the cable operator engineered a complex, multistep deal with General Electric to buy NBCUniversal.

title: Collateral Damage? Researching a Connection Between Video Games and Violence
description: Overview | Do violent video games promote aggressive or hostile behaviors among gamers? How have social scientists tried to answer this question? Is it answerable?

title: Regulator Explains Decision to End Flawed Foreclosure Review
description: A top regulator shed light Wednesday on his decision to scuttle an independent review of bank foreclosures, portraying the flawed process as a boon to outside consultants and a barren maze for homeowners.

title: Bibhu Mohapatra: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: When Action Is the Family Business
description: Its not 1986 anymore, a sneering Russian villain (one of several in A Good Day to Die Hard) says to John McClane. Reagan is dead.

title: The Gun Report: February 13, 2013
description: The big news of the day, of course, was the firefight between law enforcement officials and a man presumed to be Christopher J. Dorner in Big Bear, resulting in the shootings of two police officers, one fatally. Lost in the furor were a number of multiple-casualty shootings of the sort that seem to take place every day. I guess thats why theyre not big news anymore  multiple shootings have become a dog-bites-man story. Heres our daily report:

title: Meet the Morgan Stanley C.F.O. Candidates
description: Who will be the next chief financial officer at Morgan Stanley?

title: The Struggle for Control of the Right
description: The rise of the Tea Party, which burst into national politics in 2009 and scored its first major electoral victories in 2010, set off a struggle within the Republican Party over just how far to the right the G.O.P. was willing to go. With that question settled  really, really far  we are now seeing the outlines of a struggle for control of the far right.

title: As Jamess Game Takes Off, Comparisons Are Harder
description: Since LeBron James was in high school, the name on the tip of everyones tongue has been Michael Jordan.

title: College Tips for Juniors From an Ivy League Dean
description: Our Counselors Calendar tells us that now is the time for juniors to begin their college search in earnest. So it was very timely to see that Eric Furda, the dean of admissions at the University of Pennsylvania, appeared on NBCs Today show on Wednesday to share admissions tips with college-bound students and their families. Watch the full interview below.

title: Bureaucrats Express
description: Brussels Airlines is adding direct Brussels-to-Washington flights five days a week in June, linking the United States capital with the seat of the European Parliament (above). The flights will be in addition to current ones the carrier offers through an agreement with United. The route comes a year after Brussels Airlines began offering its first trans-Atlantic route, from Brussels to New York. As flights are defined by their frequent passengers, this one will most likely be tame: expect bureaucrats on smartphones in airplane mode.

title: A Documentary About a Palestinian Village Sets Off a Dispute
description: No sooner had 5 Broken Cameras, a close-in look at the effect of Israeli occupation on life in a Palestinian village on the West Bank, been nominated for an Academy Award in the best feature-length documentary category than it set off a political dispute in the Middle East. With two directors the Palestinian Emad Burnat and the Israeli Guy Davidi  was it a Palestinian film or an Israeli film? Just the whiff of Israeli involvement was enough for some Arab countries to ban its exhibition.

title: Threes a Trend | Houndstooth
description: A Savile Row classic, houndstooth is getting updated this season: Thom Browne did it in dramatic molded, voluminous shapes; Tommy Hilfiger printed it on pony (another trend from this week); and Rag & Bone blew up the traditional check.

title: Excerpt: Holland Taylor in Ann
description: Holland Taylor in the Kennedy Center production of her solo show about Ann W. Richards, the former governor of Texas. The production opens on Broadway at the Vivian Beaumont Theater on March 7.

title: Nanette Lepore: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Should the Minimum Wage Be Raised for Waiters?
description: When President Obama said in his State of the Union address Tuesday that he wanted to raise the minimum wage, the chef Tom Colicchio took to Twitter to lend his support.

title: Executive Steeped in Print Joins Online Ad Venture
description: A former senior manager at a print industry leader is becoming the chief executive of a company that specializes in one of the most popular trends in online advertising.

title: In First Disclosure, Getco Reports Years of Sagging Profit
description: One of the most powerful firms in the secretive high-speed trading industry reported on Wednesday that its profit and revenue had been declining steadily since the financial crisis.

title: Giving Congress Information
description: Gail Collins: David, how did you like the State of the Union address? Im normally not a big fan of them, but I have to say I thought President Obama was great this year.

title: In Policy-Heavy Speech, Obama Appeals to Emotion on Guns
description: If there is one moment that is sure to be remembered from President Obamas State of the Union address on Tuesday, it will probably be his repeated demands for a Congressional vote on behalf of the victims of gun violence.

title: Vain Glorious | La Fille de Berlin
description: The famed perfumer Serge Lutenss latest offering may be ruby red in color and set to hit counters tomorrow on Valentines Day, but make no mistake, this isnt a sentimental homage to love. La Fille de Berlin takes its inspiration from the brave resilience of women during Soviet occupation in postwar Germany. Centered on a rich and powdery rose note and spiked with a hint of red pepper, the scent evokes both the feminine and formidable sides of a woman. Beauty is the moment in which you rise up, Lutens recently explained. It is the moment when you pick up your head, stride through your own ruins and climb up the mountain.

title: Blogging With Video, Hoping to Go Viral
description: It would take 72 hours to watch all the videos uploaded to YouTube every minute by would-be commentators, comedians, cosmetologists and various other content creators all hoping for a breakout hit.

title: Redskins Address the Name Issue (but Not Directly)
description: As a response to a festering controversy, this is an odd one. The Washington Redskins team name, long criticized by many, recently prompted the mayor of the District of Columbia to say that the name would have to be discussed if the Redskins were to pursue a move to the district from their current home in Landover, Md. Now, the team has launched a series of stories on its own Web site, Redskins.com, designed, it seems, to defend the name by writing about how proud many high schools are to call themselves Redskins.

title: Michael Kors: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Trade Puts Distance Between Family, Dog and Pitcher
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  The first thing Mark Buehrle said Wednesday about his brief and bitter experience with the Miami Marlins is that he knew he was taking a risk. The Marlins have a longstanding policy of refusing to give no-trade clauses, and he did not get one with his four-year, $58 million deal before last season. But he took the team at its word.

title: The Splashes and Roars of Life of Pi
description: From the crashing waves to the tiger roars to the flopping of flying fish, the lost-at-sea adventure Life of Pi, directed by Ang Lee, is as much an aural spectacle as a visual one. And 2 of its 11 Oscar nominations recognize those sound efforts, for mixing and editing. The distinctions can be confusing, but the sound editing process involves recording and preparing individual sounds, while the mixing process combines those recordings with dialogue and other elements to create a final soundtrack.

title: Ex-State Senator Files 2nd Guilty Plea in Fraud
description: A former New York State senator pleaded guilty on Wednesday to falsifying evidence in an attempt to cover up the theft of taxpayer money from a nonprofit agency that she founded, ending a prominent corruption case that included charges in federal and state courts.

title: Debt Mounting, Postal Service Asks to Alter Business Model
description: WASHINGTON  Saying that its debt could reach $45 billion by 2017 if Congress does not act, the Postal Service on Wednesday called on lawmakers to give it the flexibility to change its business model to keep itself solvent.

title: Wilpon Asserts Rebound for Mets Is Near
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Fred Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, appeared at the teams spring training complex Wednesday morning and did his best to paint a rosy portrait of a team that has not finished above .500 since 2008, has not been in the postseason since 2006 and continues to deal with questions about its ability to spend money to improve its unimposing roster.

title: Photos of The Moment | Narciso Rodriguez
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Prospect Park Lake, 11:03 A.M.
description: A successful skating session calls for a celebration.

title: Spanish-Language Media React to Rubio
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: A mixed reaction from Spanish-language media for Senator Marco Rubio. | The origins of computer matchmaking. | Streaming services create original content for children.

title: A Whodunit Committed by a Whole Classroom
description: The first dead body simply had to be a math professor, said Rebecca Shepard, 20, a sophomore at Sarah Lawrence College.

title: On the Issues: A Guide to Obamas Proposals
description: From gun violence to the campaign against terrorism, from climate change to the minimum wage, here is a guide to The Timess coverage of the policy areas President Obama discussed in his State of the Union address.

title: Dos and Donts for Successful Web Videos
description: Are your online video views low? Here are some tips  from production tricks to content editing  to keep your audience engaged.

title: Video of California Shootout Is Captured by CBS News Crew
description: While the final stage of the manhunt for Christopher Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer, unfolded on live television Tuesday evening  with local news channels broadcasting helicopter views of the cabin in the San Bernardino Mountains engulfed in flames  the authorities pressed the media to keep reporters at a distance, because, they suggested, the suspect could have been monitoring broadcasts of the operation as it unfolded.

title: After Cameo, Poland Spring Uncaps a Response
description: The phenomenon of brands reacting in real time in social media is fascinating to watch as it changes in real time.

title: Leading Off: Wrestling Is Ready to Defend Itself
description: Every once in a while, between the actual Games that make it relevant, the International Olympic Committee rears its indecipherable head and creates news that makes people slap their foreheads in wonder. Mondays version of this was the decision to drop wrestling as one of the Olympics core sports. Never mind that wrestling is one of the original ancient Olympic sports, is the kind of pure competition that has created indelible Olympic moments through the years and has not been riddled with doping scandals that have turned sports like weight lifting and road cycling into pharmacological contests as much as athletic ones.

title: Rivera at Spring Training Debut: I Feel Good
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mariano Rivera could not stop smiling. On the first day of workouts for Yankees pitchers and catchers, Rivera completed the most mundane of drills with a boundless joy usually reserved for children.

title: Farm to Table | MacKenzie-Childss Aurora Collection
description: To celebrate its 30th anniversary, MacKenzie-Childs, which is known for its whimsically decorated and patterned home accessories and furnishings, has introduced the Aurora collection of enamelware for the table and kitchen. Named after the Finger Lakes town in New York where the company is based, Aurora is a toile-like, vintage-inspired pattern in pastel colors that depicts pastoral scenes from MacKenzie-Childss headquarters, a 65-acre former dairy farm that overlooks Lake Cayuga. (If you look closely, you can spot silhouettes of the companys famous teapots in the trees.) And in the more-is-more spirit, Aurora is intended to mix with bolder designs like the classic Courtly Check. Prices for the collection, which includes plates, serving bowls, teakettles, and canisters, among other items, range from $36 to $108.

title: No Comment Necessary: Bragging Rights
description: Via The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

title: Discounting a Meal for Well-Behaved Kids
description: Via the Bucks blog and The Consumerist comes a story of a restaurant that rewarded a family with a discount for well-behaved kids printed right there on the receipt.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 6
description: CR Fashion Book fetes 2nd issue, Rodarte parties in East Village, Purple Magazine takes over the Standard.

title: Grobans All That Echoes Is No. 1
description: In time for Valentines Day, the pop-classical singer Josh Groban has a No. 1 album with his latest collection of heart-swelling ballads and tenor showpieces.

title: Scott Brown Becomes a Fox News Contributor
description: Fox News on Wednesday added the former Republican Senator Scott Brown to its contributor ranks, two weeks after Mr. Brown decided against another run for a Senate seat in Massachusetts.

title: Keystone XL Protesters Seized at White House
description: Four dozen environmental activists succeeded in getting themselves arrested outside the White House on Wednesday afternoon to draw attention to their demand that President Obama reject construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada.

title: ArcelorMittal Rejects Europes Pressure on Job Cuts
description: LONDON  Alarmed by the speed at which the steel industry is becoming a symbol of Europes economic decline, a top European Union official has called for the worlds biggest steel maker to postpone planned job cuts and factory closings.

title: Cybercrime Network Based in Spain Is Broken Up
description: MADRID  Europol, the European police agency, said Wednesday that it had dismantled one of the most efficient cybercrime organizations to date, led by Russians who had managed to extort millions of euros from online users across more than 30 countries  mostly European  by persuading them to pay spurious police fines for abusive use of the Internet.

title: Brooklynite Hits France, With Plans to Seduce
description: PARIS  Garrett Oliver popped the cork of one of his specialty brews, swirled the amber liquid into a wine glass and took a hearty sniff.

title: The Dawn of Computer Love
description: In 1959, two undergraduate engineering students, Philip Fialer and James Harvey, created one of the first computer matching dating services for a class at Stanford University.

title: Model Diary | Julia Nobis
description: Youve seen her on runways for Derek Lam, Victoria Beckham and Alexander Wang over the past few days of New York Fashion Week. Tonight, 20-year-old Julia Nobis walks in Proenza Schouler, and stars in their current spring 2013 campaign. When shes not in front of the camera, Brooklyn-based Nobis focuses on college courses in medicine.

title: Time Warner Considers Spinning Off Some of Its Magazines
description: 12:15 p.m. | Updated 9:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Natasha and Kid Who Would Be Pope Win Musical Theater Prizes
description: The musicals Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812, by Dave Malloy, and The Kid Who Would Be Pope, by Tom and Jack Megan, are the winners of the 2013 Richard Rodgers Awards for Musical Theater. The prizes, announced this week by the American Academy of Arts and Letters, are intended to help talented composers and playwrights get work produced in New York City.

title: On Our Radar: The Earths Surface, in Sharper Detail Than Ever
description: A satellite with new, far more powerful technology for monitoring the Earths changing climate, water supplies and agriculture will reach its orbit within two months, NASA says. [NASA]

title: How Social Media Affects Journalistic Objectivity
description: I spoke Tuesday at Harvard Universitys Shorenstein Center, where the former Timesman Alex S. Jones runs the show. My talk was called The New Objectivity: How Social Media Is Changing Traditional Reporting, a subject Ive written about frequently in blogs and columns.

title: Try a Little Tenderness
description: The philosophers, the lovers of wisdom, have pondered and written a lot about love, even erotic and romantic love, but they have given a cold shoulder to that offshoot of love  tenderness. Indeed, I dont believe I have ever heard a member of the Socrates guild even mention the lovely word in a remotely philosophical context.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Spanish-Language Media Reacts to Rubio
description: A mixed reaction from Spanish-Language media for Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida. The origins of computer matchmaking. Streaming services create original content for children.

title: Lew Faces Tough Questioning
description: Jacob J. Lew, the nominee for Treasury secretary, appeared at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Photos of The Moment | Michael Bastian
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Microcars From Georgia Museum Going on the Auction Block
description: Microcars are the Munchkins of the car world, the vehicles seized on by cartoon makers for comic relief. (The Isetta for Cars and the Zndapp Janus for Cars 2.)

title: Fresh From the Internets Attic
description: The Internet, it seems, has found its version of vinyl chic.

title: Kerry Says Trip Will Focus on Finding Syria Solution
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry said on Wednesday that he planned to use his first foreign trip to advance new ideas about how to persuade President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to yield power and agree to a political transition.

title: Bolero on Instruments Ravel Never Dreamed Of
description: During the course of Ravels haunting Bolero, the slinky, repeated theme is played in turn by a flute, a clarinet, a saxophone and more. But Ravel, a master of orchestration, would surely have been fascinated to hear the tune played on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall by a rubab, the national instrument of Afghanistan, plucked like a lute to produce a sound both tender and tart.

title: State of the Night Life? Healthy
description: As dowdy citizens hunkered down to watch President Obamas State of the Union speech, the oligarchs entrusted with dressing the nation spent Tuesday night celebrating what turned to be the busiest night of New York Fashion Week.

title: Visiting the Doctor, Virtually
description: Weve all wished at times that we could just chat with a doctor from our office, instead of taking time away from work to drive to the clinic. Now, a case study of medical care delivered online suggests that virtual visits can effectively treat some common ailments at a lower cost than in-person visits.

title: An Arresting Way for Boomers to Protest
description: Arguments about generational debt and how baby boomers might make amends usually revolve around Social Security and Medicare. But Lawrence MacDonald has another idea: get arrested, the way you did in the protests of your youth.

title: The Daily Shoe | Michael Kors
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Few States Look to Extend Preschool to All 4-Year-Olds
description: President Obamas call in his State of the Union address to make high-quality preschool available to every single child in America rallied advocates across the country who have long argued that inequity in education begins at a very young age.

title: A Look at Rubio's Bilingual Rebuttal
description: A mixed reaction from Spanish-Language media for Senator Marco Rubios State of the Union response.

title: Rachel Zoe: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: With Yankees in Ticket Resale Market, Elbows Are Out
description: The escalating war between the Yankees and StubHub continues. On Monday the Yankees said that they had formed their own ticket resale marketplace with Ticketmaster as a way to tamp down on speculators who they claimed were driving down prices and giving fans one less reason to buy from the team.

title: An Expensive but Logical Cable Deal
description: A 10 billion euro bid by Vodafone for Kabel Deutschland would be logical  and expensive.

title: Makeup With a Rebellious Hue
description: As with the clothes, makeup at fashion shows is increasingly a smorgasbord, rather than one look being in or out. Still, several strong themes seem to have emerged from the New York fall 2013 collections.

title: Indian Music Service, Taking Page From Spotify, Goes Pro
description: Western music fans have no shortage of digital music services to choose from, and that abundance is spreading around the world. Apples iTunes is now in 119 countries, and others are racing to plant their digital flags everywhere. This week, for example, Spotify opened in Italy, Poland and Portugal, bringing its reach to 23 countries.

title: Cisco Struggles to Adapt, Even as Profit Rises
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Cisco Systems is trying to pull off one of the toughest tricks in high technology, adapting a big legacy business to a vastly different future.

title: Jeremy Scott: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Practice for The Voice by Using Yours With Mobile Karaoke
description: Singing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember, partly because I love it and partly thanks to my Welsh heritage (were traditionally belting vocalists). But its been years since I last sang in a choir, and my singing is now confined to the shower and the occasional family game of SingStar on the PlayStation.

title: High Notes in a Clutch of Familiar Melodies
description: When does a karaoke performance transcend itself? Or a wedding bands faithful re-creation of an oldie but goody surpass an original recording whose grooves were etched in memory when you were a lonely teenager baying at the moon? These questions roiled in my head while watching the opening-night performance of John Lloyd Youngs show My Turn, at the Caf Carlyle.

title: Print on Print
description: Personal style isnt always about effortlessly mixing color and texture. Sometimes its about choosing one strong pattern and sticking with it.

title: Champions League: Round of 16/Day 2
description: Day 2 in the Round of 16 in the UEFA Champions League.. After a winter break we continue a featurette in which we hope to bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

title: On the Magic Side of Brooklyn
description: You probably think that Anthony Edwards has starred in more television series than he actually has  thats what eight seasons and 180 episodes of a show like ER will do for an actors reputation. In fact, ER is the only show he has headlined; before that hed done 10 episodes of Northern Exposure and a season of the 1982 sitcom It Takes Two, in which he was the teenage son of overworked parents played by Richard Crenna and Patty Duke.

title: J. Mendel: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: Art, Sport, Dead Animals: Its Competitive Taxidermy
description: The bombast of professional wrestling and the dolefulness of roadkill may have never struck you as a logical pairing, but perhaps they will once youve seen Immortalized, an aggressively strange new show on AMC that may be landing at just the right time. Football season is over, baseball season hasnt started, basketball and hockey arent for everybody, so why not competitive taxidermy?

title: The Creative Elation Embedded in Source Material
description: In the program notes for the current run at the Joyce Theater by his company, Evidence, Ronald K. Brown quotes a former teacher who told him not to give in to the pressure to create something new and always to show people where you have come from. Its sound advice when your dances and dancers are as extraordinary as Mr. Browns.

title: Pouring Ribbons
description: CHANNELING NOSTALGIA for atmosphere, New York night life has seen its share of faux speakeasies, filament light bulbs and mustachioed mixologists who resemble Dickensian chimney sweepers. At Pouring Ribbons, a second-story bar that opened last fall in the East Village, theres little interest in conjuring a Prohibition-era ambience  or really much ambience of any kind.

title: How Do You Document Your Trips?
description: In this weeks Getaway column, Stephanie Rosenbloom wrote about apps that help travelers document their trips digitally.

title: Like Fish in Waterfalls, Exploring Climate Types
description: Seven dancers appear in Scattered, a 2009 dance-theater work by the British company Motionhouse, and no offense to their hard-won bodies, but the most important element is the set.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Feb. 14
description: Jessica Hart, a model on what shes wearing now; James Colarusso, a painter, discovered jewelry making; Phillip Lim is making muscle T-shirts and blanket scarves from Louis Vuitton.

title: Opposites Attract, and Neither Is Left Unscathed
description: At the start of Aria Beth Slosss debut novel, two 14-year-old girls meet at school and strike up a rocky, intense friendship that lasts a lifetime. If this sounds like an unremarkable premise, it is. So is the way these two characters begin as diametrical opposites.

title: Pictures of the Day: Vatican City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Vatican, Syria, Mali and Colombia.

title: Talking Points on Gus Johnsons Talking
description: Call it a draw. For Manchester United. For Real Madrid. And for Gus Johnson.

title: Homes for $5 Million
description: Properties in Laguna Beach Calif., Austin, Tex., and Boston, Mass.

title: What You Get for ... $5 Million
description: LAGUNA BEACH, CALIF.

title: At New York Philharmonic, a Night to Celebrate China
description: Doomsayers have long proclaimed the demise of classical music, although given the myriad high-quality concerts almost every night in New York, it seems the genre must be dying elsewhere. The graveyard is certainly not in China, which has seen a surge of interest in Western classical music in the last decade. The New York Philharmonic has paid tribute in recent years to this enthusiasm with a gala event celebrating the Chinese New Year.

title: TV Is Stingy With the Roses and Chocolate
description: If your Valentines Day plans are already made, and they involve Champagne, limousines, prix fixe menus and generally gallant behavior, you can stop reading. Theres nothing here for you.

title: A Contemporary on the Caribbean
description: A four-bedroom beachfront property with a house and a cottage is on the market in St. James, Barbados, for $3.95 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Barbados
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM BEACHFRONT PROPERTY IN ST. JAMES

title: Photos of The Moment | Michael Kors
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Tenacious Playwright Is Creating His Moment
description: Fresh out of New York University in 2007 and anxious about his prospects as an actor, Paul Downs Colaizzo was too poor to afford therapy, so he opted for the $12.95 version  self-help books. He read dozens of them, absorbing mantras like dont take anything personally and be impeccable with your word, and developing the youthful moxie that has led to his unexpected emergence as an Off Broadway playwright.

title: Her Date Is a Single Dad; His, a Possible Killer
description: The romantic thriller Safe Haven plays like an extended infomercial for the lulling charms of Southport, N.C., where the movie was filmed. This picture-perfect town is presented as the go-to destination for terrorized damsels in distress. Here in this tiny paradise, where gentle waters lap the shore and gold-and-purple sunsets stretch all the way to heaven, a new beginning awaits.

title: Catching Eyes Away From the Runway
description: At the Rodarte show on Tuesday afternoon, the sixth day of New York Fashion Week, among the usual collection of editors, stylists and the occasional celebrity (Kim Gordon, Lizzie Tisch, Terry Richardson) sat a man in the front row, dressed in a slim-cut dark suit, open-necked white shirt and white sneakers, and looking a little out of place.

title: Love in an Edible Garden
description: A urban garden created by two men has become home to their wives and families.

title: Manhunt and Obamas Address Bolster CNNs Ratings
description: Perhaps aided by its live coverage of the manhunt in California, CNN had a good night Tuesday covering the State of the Union address as well.

title: Ding, Dong! The Witch Is Cute
description: The otherworldly inhabitants in Beautiful Creatures, a pop Southern Gothic amusement about teenage love and other powerful magic, tend to look fairly average, just paler and more dandified than average folks. Everyone else would call them witches, but they prefer Casters, as in spell casters, probably because the authors of the book on which the movie is based wanted a new name for that old black and white magic. Despite their rebranding, Casters move through a familiar genre world of ghosts, enchantments and honey-dipped accents, with slithering gators, trees shrouded in Spanish moss and lives wreathed in mystery. This being a PG-13 diversion, the bodies come draped too.

title: Their Trip to Bountiful
description: HOLYOKE, Mass.  It was the build-it-and-they-will-come principle that inspired two self-described plant geeks to buy a soulless duplex on a barren lot in this industrial city 10 years ago and turn it into their own version of the Garden of Eden. Their Eves, they figured, would show up sooner or later.

title: Where the Bonbons Are Buried
description: Soon after they moved in together, a woman well refer to simply as Ashley noticed that her boyfriend had amnesia when it came to remembering where household items were kept. If he needed a bandage, for example, he would ask her where to find it  repeatedly. Ill say, Its in the box in the bathroom, where it always is, Ashley said.

title: No More Antlers, Please
description: In a Williamsburg home, going easy on the Brooklyn.

title: Brooklyn, but Not by Design
description: To hear Elizabeth Sayner tell it, Brooklyn isnt just a borough. Its a design aesthetic, like midcentury modern or Beaux-Arts.

title: Barnes & Noble Warns of Lower Revenues
description: More bad news from Barnes & Noble Inc.

title: Fur Slinks Along Underground Tracks
description: On a recent frigid morning, when the thermometer barely reached 11 degrees in New York, the sidewalk glimmered with ice, fruit peddlers were absent and dogs shied away from the leash. Underground, however, the city was in its usual rush.

title: Shopping for Red Accessories
description: Alessandra Branca explains that when adding red to a room, use it in moderation.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. We renovated our kitchen and now the old tile floor looks outdated. Is there an inexpensive way to redo it that wont look cheap?

title: Red Accessories
description: FOR MOST OF US, Valentines Day is a good excuse for an extra splash of red, even if its just a bunch of roses or a heart-shaped box of chocolates. But for those who really love red, like Alessandra Branca, theres no need for an excuse, today or any other day.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Touch Technology and Flu Googling
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Tool Belts, Stud Finders and Sighs
description: Recently the Style network introduced Built, a reality TV series starring five male models who moonlight as construction workers. (The slogan: A great remodel starts with the right stud.) Teaming up with Kim Gieske, an interior designer, the Hott and Handy crew, as its known, tackles a renovation project each week, from a 1,000-square-foot clothes closet for a handbag hoarder named Adina to an outdoor room for a know-it-all contractor named Damon. The foreman of the group is Sandy Dias, a 34-year-old Hugo Boss model. Speaking on his hands-free car phone last week, Mr. Dias described his double life.

title: Christine Quinn on Tapping New Yorks Vein of Design
description: After months of vigorous planning, New York will have a 12-day celebration of design this spring extending over all five boroughs. NYC x Design will run from May 10 to 21, to coincide with the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and Frieze New York art fair on Randalls Island. Pronounced NYC by Design and interdisciplinary in scope, it will present the work of local designers and architects in museum exhibitions, conferences, studio tours, showroom displays, pop-up stores, art installations and a design film festival.

title: A Birthday Gift for Formica
description: A hundred years ago, a plastic-coated fabric was swapped for the mica commonly used in electrical insulation. Welcome, Formica. Eventually made of paper layers and used as a laminate, it went on to enjoy a long, sly life imitating wood grain and stone. Its a no-nonsense, absolutely reliable kind of material, said Abbott Miller, who has designed four new Formica patterns to honor the centenary.

title: Wheelies at the Museum
description: When we were planning the spring catalog, I came across a Brooklyn Cruiser parked in SoHo, said Emmanuel Plat, merchandising director of the retail division of the Museum of Modern Art, explaining how a bright red bicycle happened to be among the MoMA Stores latest offerings. We liked the idea of supporting a local company with an attractive and affordable bike that is great for commuting.

title: Full-Throttle Porcelain
description: Herms introduced its Rallye 24 dishes last month in a Paris garage stocked with vintage sports cars. And rightly so. The 49-piece collection of jewel-colored porcelain has a pattern of ellipses reminiscent of speedways. (Closer inspection also reveals a reference to the classic 1938 Herms anchor-chain bracelet, with its bisected oval links.)

title: How a Meredith-Time Warner Joint Venture Would Work
description: Many analysts have questioned how the Meredith Corporation could afford to buy a business as big as Time Warners non-news magazine titles.

title: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Desiron, Aero and Others
description: A large selection of cookware and tools is up to 55 percent off, through Monday, at Broadway Panhandler (a Cuisinart French classic 5.5-quart saut pan, usually $180, is about $100); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

title: In Tech, Does I.T. or Marketing Rule?
description: Doesnt anyone want to talk with the Chief Information Officer?

title: Awkward Bedfellows: Politics and Films
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  As Zero Dark Thirty, his narrative about the hunt for Osama bin Laden attracts scrutiny, the screenwriter Mark Boal has consoled himself with brouhahas of movies past. Warren Beatty came under fire for Bonnie and Clyde, in which he starred, because it was considered sensationalist and was pilloried for glamorizing violence. Demonstrators protested the depiction of the Vietnam War in The Deer Hunter, and protesters were arrested outside the 1979 Oscars. Apocalypse Now was a cultural punching bag for years during its much-delayed production. All of these films were, of course, judged differently by history.

title: New Republic Literary Editor to Split $1 Million Prize
description: Leon Wieseltier, the longtime literary editor of The New Republic, is among this years winners of the prestigious Dan David Prize, which is given annually to honor contributions to humanity and carries a $1 million dollar award.

title: Diverging Opinions on Business Conditions
description: Opinions on business conditions expressed by small and large businessmen have diverged in the last several years, according to surveys of the two groups  with small-business owners becoming more pessimistic.

title: The Daily Do | Philosophy di Alberta Ferretti
description: Romance reigned at Philosophy di Alberta Ferretti with fishtail braids woven and twisted together in a low chignon.

title: Remember, City Council, Forever Is a Really Long Time
description: The owners of Madison Square Garden are now looking to New York City to renew  in perpetuity  the special permit that allows them to operate an arena atop Penn Station, the countrys busiest transit hub.

title: Dunes and Drama on a Drive Through Oman
description: Just out of reach of the Arabian Seas hammering surf, we built a campfire on a deserted beach below the Queen of Shebas ruined palace. Then, exhausted after a day of driving, we unrolled our sleeping bags, and talked until late beneath an ocean of stars.

title: How to See India by Train
description: Indias 65,000 kilometers of train tracks embroider the subcontinent, connecting thousands of cities. In 2010, Monisha Rajesh, a London-based journalist, set out to discover the railways, detailing her adventures in her new book, Around India in 80 Trains.

title: Reed Krakoff: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: He Sings. She Acts. They Date.
description: When he picked up the Grammy for best new artist on Sunday night, along with his band mates from Fun., Jack Antonoff joined a rarefied subsection of the dating world: rock stars who are almost as famous as their actress girlfriends. Each generation seems to have at least one music-acting power couple of note and Mr. Antonoff and his current girlfriend, Lena Dunham of Girls, appear to have taken that spot for the millennials. (Though perhaps not without some competition from Marcus Mumford of Mumford & Sons, and his wife, the actress Carey Mulligan, and, to a lesser degree,Kate Hudson and Matt Bellamy, the Muse frontman.) Heres a look at the Antonoff-Dunham union and two other high-profile couples who predated them:Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin of Coldplay, and the little-remembered Faye Dunaway and Peter Wolf, of the J. Geils Band.

title: Ira Rubin at the 1968 Vanderbilt Knockout Teams
description: While looking for a deal featuring Ira Rubin, who died last week at 82 and was inducted into the American Contract Bridge Leagues Hall of Fame in 2000, I found the following from the final of the 1968 Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in New York City.

title: Scouting Report
description: V-Day

title: To Go: Plastic-Foam Containers, if the Mayor Gets His Way
description: It is the most humble of vessels for New York City foodstuffs, ubiquitous at Chinese takeout joints and halal street carts. In pre-Starbucks days, coffee came packaged in its puffy embrace.

title: An Arresting Trend in Intimate Wear
description: It was probably inevitable that we see fifty shades of lingerie.

title: Obamas Path from Rhetoric to Reality on Energy and Climate
description: On energy and human-driven global warming, President Obamas State of the Union address (and the background sheet providing detail behind the talking points) had something for everyone, making it hard  outside of a couple of specific proposals  to figure out how much action might follow the smoothly delivered rhetoric.

title: Off the Runway: Day 7
description: Scenes from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

title: North Carolina Approves Steep Benefit Cuts for Jobless in Bid to Reduce Debt
description: North Carolina lawmakers approved deep cuts to benefits for the jobless on Wednesday, in a state that has one of the nations highest unemployment rates.

title: Model Apartments: Runway to Real Estate
description: Trish Goff, a supermodel in the 90s, is now a real estate broker who attracts a hip and upscale clientele, mostly culled from her connections in fashion.

title: Model Apartments: Runway to Real Estate
description: With her wide-eyed all-American looks, Trish Goff was atypical among the second wave of supermodels of the 1990s. Exotic, heroin chic, angular, grunge  these did not describe Ms. Goff. But her extracurricular activities really set her apart from the pack.

title: Small Businesses Still Struggle, and Thats Impeding a Recovery
description: In the recovery so far, small businesses have largely been left behind. Initially, loans were hard to come by and consumers werent shopping. Now, small-business owners say, Washington is throwing up additional roadblocks.

title: Why Are Small Businesses Less Optimistic Than Big Ones?
description: In an article just published by The Times, Catherine Rampell notes that when it comes to optimism about the economy, there is a big gulf between small and large companies. Ms. Rampell reports that while measures of optimism for big companies now exceed prerecession levels, a recent survey from the National Federation of Independent Business found that expectations for business conditions six months from now were at their fourth-lowest level in nearly 40 years.

title: Steve Madden Is Back
description: One crisp morning last month, the shoe titan Steve Madden was ruminating over two sandals laid out on his desk in his factory in Long Island City, Queens: one black with a thin sole; the other creamy beige, its heel thick as sliced bread.

title: A New Medal Honors Drone Pilots and Computer Experts
