It cant be reduced to its technical components, whatever they are. Its metaphysical, yet without fixed or transcendent meaning. Its a crystal ball, without any clairvoyance. Who hasnt arrived at the logically borne-out if senseless belief that in the oceanic swell of Google lies hidden the answer to ones most private problem? In his latest book, Four New Messages, Joshua Cohen takes on the experiential properties of the online modality, its textures and tautologies, its effects on language and thus on humans and meaning. This seems at once a fundamental and ambitious place to begin mapping this void of a thing that we pretend, by not writing about it in literature, doesnt have much place in life, when the dirty truth is otherwise.

title: The Joads Cousins
description: Several years ago, in a Big Read discussion of The Grapes of Wrath, Susan Straight observed that Steinbecks classic novel reminds us really of how timeless the fight is for land and for dignity and for survival. That fight, on the grittiest urban and rural terrain of Southern California, has been a recurrent theme in much of Straights own fiction. In her eighth novel, Between Heaven and Here, she continues the story of the Picards and their kin  black, French-speaking refugees from violent Jim Crow Louisiana who headed west, literary relations of the Joads, struggling to realize their own version of the American dream.

title: Modern Safeguards for a Family-Owned Business
description: NO family wants to build a business only to see it disappear when family members get tired of running it. But lets face it, what that business really represents is a large majority of the familys wealth.

title: A Grammy-Winning Formula for Paul McCartney: Dont Show Up
description: Would you have any interest in speaking to Paul McCartney about the Grammy Award he won on Sunday, a publicist asked over e-mail the other day. O.K., O.K., twist our arms, why dont you?

title: An Exasperated Grammy Post-Mortem
description: Jon Caramanica and host Ben Ratliff outline the contorted logic of the Grammys, including the Black Keys Perplexity, the Folk-Stomp Realness Chimera, and the Law of Adele; separate and identify the qualities in popular music that the Recording Academy tend to privilege or ignore; and propose sensible and unlikely alternatives to the current system.

title: India Suspends AgustaWestland Deal
description: Indias Ministry of Defense said Friday that it has begun the process of canceling its contract with AgustaWestland for 12 helicopters after the Italian company was accused of bribing government officials.

title: Cuomo Spokeswoman Quits After Four Months
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos new communications director is leaving her post after just four months to reunite with her former boss, Jeffrey Zucker, the new president of CNN Worldwide.

title: What Do You Want to Know About Cruises?
description: While the 4,200 people aboard the Carnival Triumph finally have their ordeal behind them, the fire and the terrible conditions on board have raised questions about cruising in general.

title: This Week's Movies | Feb. 15, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on "No," "Like Someone in Love" and "Beautiful Creatures."

title: Thunder Stopped Streak, but Not James
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  If there is a moral victory the Thunder can take with them from their 110-100 loss Thursday to the Heat, its that they are officially the Team That Stopped LeBron James.

title: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
description: Paul Klee (1879-1940) created most of his angelic work in the final three years of his life, reflecting his awareness of his own physical decline, as well as the decline of civilization marked by the rise of Nazism. His minimalist angels appear in 80 drawings, watercolors, gouaches and paintings in Paul Klees Angels at the Folkwang Museum in Essen, Germany.

title: Affordability, and Pride of Place
description: When Kristin Hart bought a house five years ago in Van Cortlandt Village, a Bronx neighborhood that has a long history of community activism, she was soon drawn into local politics.

title: Living In | Van Cortlandt Village, the Bronx
description: A tranquil enclave of leafy streets and picturesque single-family homes in the area of the Jerome Park Reservoir.

title: BMW Recalling 30,000 X5 S.U.V.s for Brake Problem
description: BMW is recalling about 30,000 of its 2007-10 X5 sport utility vehicles with V-8 engines because they could lose power brake assist, according to a report the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: No Comment Necessary: Anti-Hagelians
description: Via Political Wire

title: Venezuela Releases Chvez Photographs as Health Is Debated
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Amid a heated national debate over the state of the health of President Hugo Chvez, the Venezuelan government on Friday released photographs of him for the first time since his cancer surgery in Cuba more than nine weeks ago.

title: Ligety Completes Rare Triple at Worlds
description: Shortly after Ted Ligety became the first man in 45 years to win three events at ski racings world championships on Friday, the United States ski team coach Sasha Rearick was asked to weigh the historic significance of Ligetys accomplishment.

title: Carol Miller on Work and Cancer
description: The disc jockey Carol Miller talks to Jo Maeder about staying relevant in the music business.

title: Photos of The Moment | Calvin Klein
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: This Weeks Movies: Feb. 15
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the Chilean political drama No, the supernatural romance Beautiful Creatures and the new film from the Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami, Like Someone in Love. See all of this weeks reviews here.

title: Let Us Now Celebrate Oscar Oversights and Missteps
description: Grantland is taking an early dive into March madness, Oscar version. Theyve made a bracket for the biggest travesties of the show, from the Crash win for best picture over Brokeback Mountain to Spike Lees being statue-less to Angelina Jolies kiss of her brother.

title: The Myth of the Rich Who Flee From Taxes
description: Last month, Vladimir V. Putin hugged his newly minted fellow Russian citizen, the actor Gerard Depardieu, posing for cameras at the Black Sea port of Sochi. I adore your country, Mr. Depardieu gushed  especially its 13 percent flat tax on personal income.

title: On Our Radar: Is Styrofoam Doomed in New York?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg says he will push in his final year in office for more recycling and electric vehicles, a curbside food-composting program and a ban on Styrofoam food packaging. Plastic foam, he says, is something that we know is environmentally destructive and that may be hazardous to our health, that is costing taxpayers money and that we can easily do without, and is something that should go the way of lead paint. [Bloomberg News]

title: The Model Deconstructed
description: The faces of New York Fashion Week discuss how they bring designers ideas to life in fleeting runway moments.

title: Currency War Confusions
description: OK, people have been asking me where I stand on the currency war issue. My answer is that its all a misconception, and it would be a very bad thing if policy makers take it seriously.

title: Recognizing Signs of Abusive Dating Among Teenagers
description: I wish February had been Teen Dating Violence Awareness Month when I was growing up. I might have realized that in the era before e-mails or cellphones, my boyfriends demand that we speak on the telephone every night was unreasonable. I was in college and my life revolved around those phone calls.

title: Kashmir Shuts Down After Call for Prayers for Afzal Guru
description: 11:12 p.m. | Updated

title: Farmers Supreme Court Challenge Puts Monsanto Patents at Risk
description: With his mere 300 acres of soybeans, corn and wheat, Vernon Hugh Bowman said, Im not even big enough to be called a farmer.

title: From Turkish Corpse to New York Cop
description: Viewers who wonder why the clean-cut star of the new CBS police drama Golden Boy, beginning Feb. 26, looks familiar might want to picture him instead in a flowing wig. And dead.

title: A Stealth Eminence of the Avant-Garde, and New Vinyl
description: Barry Altschul

title: Short Ribs Worthy of Winter Grilling
description: February may or may not be grilling season, depending upon your temperament and the climate where you live. I like to grill year-round, sometimes on an outdoor barbecue (even if theres snow), sometimes in the fireplace. Also handy is a ridged stovetop grill, and of course theres the broiler if need be. This means that kebabs, wings and even grilled vegetables are always an option, sunshine or not.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Michael Jordan, the basketball legend, turns 50 this weekend. To celebrate, Michael Jordans The Steak House, located in Grand Central Terminal, will feature a special five-course meal with wines for $125 per person, not including tax and tip. A complimentary slice of chocolate cake will be served to all guests. Contact Heather Lopez at (646) 453-5798 or rsvpmjtsh@theglaziergroup.com for a reservation. The celebration is one of several events marking the 100th birthday of Grand Central Terminal.

title: Death, Divorce, Disease. Childrens TV?
description: The first of the days many jolts arrived at about 9:05 a.m. Several dozen producers, writers and researchers for American childrens television had barely taken their seats in a basement screening room across the street from the United Nations. Soon after the lights dimmed, the screen filled with a group of children gathered in a wood shop. Completely unsupervised by adults, they unsteadily but zestfully wielded saws, hammers and nails to build miniature houses in a cheerfully produced segment from the German program Ene Mene Bu (And Its Up to You).

title: Fire at Pratt Institute Destroys Studios and Artwork of Students
description: Maria De Los Angeles, a 24-year-old student at the Pratt Institute, has an admissions interview at Yale Universitys graduate art school next month and was planning to show the officers there some of her 100 paintings and 300 prints.

title: Photos of The Moment | Marc Jacobs
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: College President Raises Concerns About Obamas College Scorecard
description: Catharine Hill is the president of Vassar College, a private, liberal arts institution in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Illness Is Only the Latest Obstacle
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: IFC Films Acquires The Canyons, Lindsay Lohan Movie With a Tale Behind It
description: If youve read about The Canyons and wondered what it might look like on a screen youll soon youll be able to see this Lindsay Lohan movie in a theater or on a television near you.

title: The Return of the Big Deal
description: Dealbooks Peter Lattman and The Timess Marcus Mabry discuss whether it is time to declare a mergers-and-acquisitions boom.

title: Popcast: An Exasperated Grammy Post-Mortem
description: This week on Popcast: a Grammy post-mortem, and a modest proposal.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 15
Trying to Make Sense of  the Pistorius Story
description: In the day following the arrest of the Olympic sprinter Oscar Pistorius on a murder charge, the work began to make sense of the story. That is a nearly impossible task, of course, with a day to pivot from nearly universal admiration and inspiration to a scene where he could have gunned down his girlfriend in cold blood, which is what the South African police are saying with premeditated muder charges. A haze of disbelief still hangs over the whole tragic turn, the man who inspired the world last summer now sobbing in a courtroom while his country tries to shake this into focus.

title: Now Onstage in Spain: Austerity
description: BARCELONA, Spain  There is no sign marking the door to La Poderosa, a dance and performance space on a scruffy street in the Raval neighborhood here. The door itself is low and set a few inches off the ground; to get inside, visitors have to climb up and duck down.

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 15
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gigantic Northeast snowstorm, Senator Frank R. Lautenbergs plans to retire and the Westminster Dog Show.

title: Recreating the Reign, the Better to Fall
description: Martha Graham always insisted that she was apolitical, but in 1935 she took a choreographic stand. The solo Imperial Gesture, created around the same time she turned down Nazi officials invitation to perform at the 1936 Olympic Games, showcased Graham as a monarch demonstrating absolute power before losing control and toppling to the floor.

title: The Daily Shoe | Marc Jacobs
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Feb. 17  24
description: Mardi Gras Flavor for New York

title: Between Love and Valentine
description: Back in my hometown of Ranchi, it was outside the Archies Gallery in the Church Complex that the angry-eyed young men of the Bharatiya Janata Partys militant wing, the Bajrang Dal, positioned themselves on Valentines Day. Except all they found was a sad trickle of people  those habitually late, and those who were the utterly nave. Everyone else would have come a week earlier, edging past shelves overflowing with Linda Goodman mugs and George Michael posters to the special corner that lay at the far end of the shop where a placard  in red, obviously, and shaped like a heart  would announce: 14 Feb is Valentines Day.

title: Common Core Practice | Brazilian Salaries, Afghan Strivers and Banana Joe
description: This week were adding something new to this feature, in which we collaborate with a classroom in New Jersey to create cross-curricular writing prompts aligned to the Common Core and grounded in Times content.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, John Burt discusses Lincolns Tragic Pragmatism; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Jeffrey Frank talks about Richard Nixon and Dwight D. Eisenhower; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: This American Life Looks at a High School Marooned in Violence
description: One of the discussions that comes up every time there is a mass shooting at a suburban school or a movie theater is how underreported other, equally disturbing killings are  like the ones at urban high schools and in city neighborhoods. Those deaths dont come in a single spasm, but instead are part of a chronic drip of bloodshed, day in and day out.

title: Still Fighting, Union Chief Is Likely to Take One on Chin
description: HOUSTON  Billy Hunters 16-year stewardship of the N.B.A. players union is likely to end Saturday afternoon in a hotel conference room where more than 30 players are expected to gather, deliberate and ultimately fire their longtime executive director.

title: Turning Over a Family-Run Business
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about the issues raised when the owners of a business want to keep the business in the family but see no obvious successors among their children or grandchildren.

title: Q & A
description: Dealing With an Illegal Sublet

title: MacFarlanes Already Got Excuses
description: Seth MacFarlane graces the cover of the next Entertainment Weekly, and in the accompanying interview, the creator of Family Guy-turned-Oscar host reveals whats been the hardest thing about his prep: the choreography.

title: Two Gentle Souls Who Found a Home in Each Other
description: Preston Bailey and Theo Bleckmann specialize in transporting people to very, very unusual places in their work. Mr. Bleckmann, a German-born experimental musician and singer, uses his voice to make all kinds of sounds: an electrical buzz, a flute or a wild groan you might hear in a dark forest.

title: The Sweet Spot | Times Square Thoughts
description: A. O. Scott and David Carr offer their impressions of Times Square, with some secret revelations. Is it the best place in the world, or the worst?

title: A Fashion Week That Was Actually All About Fashion
description: NEW YORK FASHION WEEK may well go down as one of the most subdued in recent memory. Minus the customary flaps over seating and the raucous altercations between invitees and overzealous publicists, high drama was in short supply.

title: Book Review Podcast: A Lincoln for Our Time
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Steven B. Smith reviews Lincolns Tragic Pragmatism by John Burt. In many ways, Mr. Burts book is a response to another classic account of the debate between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas, Harry V. Jaffas Crisis of the House Divided, published in 1959. Mr. Smith writes:

title: Injury to Senators Star Puts Spotlight Back on Penguins Cooke
description: The fortunes of the Ottawa Senators may have taken a drastic turn for the worse this week when they lost Erik Karlsson, their 22-year-old All-Star defenseman, for the season. Regarded by some as the N.H.L.s best player this season, he is involved in roughly one-third of Ottawas offensive production.

title: On Day 2, Youkilis Takes a Step Back
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Kevin Youkilis figured he handled his first spring training interview as a Yankee diplomatically on Thursday by dodging two opportunities to rip his former Boston Red Sox manager, Bobby Valentine.

title: Gun Violence in Chicago
description: On the streets with the nonprofit group Cure Violence. | An interview with Garry F. McCarthy, Chicagos superintendent of police.

title: Movie Review | 'Beautiful Creatures'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Beautiful Creatures.

title: The Sweet Spot: Feb. 15
description: In this weeks video, A. O. Scott and David Carr offer their impressions of Times Square, with some secret revelations. Is it the best place in the world, or the worst?

title: New York Fashion Week | Snap Sketch

title: Doctors Who Dont Speak Out
description: THE note sent by a doctor to several executives at Johnson & Johnson was blunt: an artificial hip sold by the company was so poorly designed that the company should slow its marketing until it understood why patients were getting hurt.

title: Dust to Dust, With Humiliation Just Before the End
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Though far, far more graphic images still await us, its the sight of that first, simple stain that shocks the most.

title: ICEs New Record
description: While Congress is dithering about comprehensive immigration reform, President Obamas enforcement team is hard at work deporting petty criminals who are here illegally.

title: Several Former Partners Ask Judge to Reject Deweys Bankruptcy Plan
description: 4:30 p.m. | Updated

title: George Romneys Revolutionary Rambler Is for Sale
description: 4:03 p.m. | Updated

title: Off the Charts: U.S. Trade in 2012 Outpaced Many Other Countries
description: In 2012, United States exports of goods rose 4.5 percent from 2011, a faster rate of growth than that of 10 other major countries but well below the growth rate of Chinese exports.

title: Floating Islands to the Rescue
description: Nutrient pollution is a growing problem along the Upper Mississippi, where water rich in nitrogen and phosphates from crop fertilizer flows directly into the river without the benefit of wetland filtration.

title: Answers to Reader Questions About the Meteorite Strike in Russia
description: You asked us great meteor questions, readers, ones that went beyond the mere fact of the seriously cool video coming from all over Russia. But we wanted to give you a deeper look at the science behind bombardments from space, so we called in a respected source to help.

title: Meteor Is Not Siberias First Brush With Objects Falling From Space
description: The apparent explosion of a small meteor over Siberia early on Friday was not the first time that that part of the world has had a too-close encounter with a space rock. The region was the scene of what is believed to be the largest space-related explosion in human history, 105 years ago.

title: In World Trade Data, Signs of a Slowdown
description: WORLD trade slowed last year, as major countries like Japan and Germany shipped exports that were worth less than those in 2011. The United States bucked the trend to some extent, but the 4.5 percent increase in exports was far smaller than the 15.8 percent jump in 2011.

title: Rio, With Eyes Open
description: If you want to know why people come to Rio de Janeiro, and came even during its years of bloody, decadent decline, stand on the Arpoador Beach promenade at days end. Before you lies an orchestral finale of a sunset: iridescent water, pastel-streaked skies and hazy silhouettes of cliffs to the west. Behind you are swarms of Cariocas, as Rio natives are known: men with phones tucked into the fronts of their bathing suits, swimmers shaking off droplets of water before ordering caipirinhas at an outdoor bar. At the moment when the neon-pink sun slips below the horizon, everyone stops, stands and claps: a nightly salute to city, beach and sky.

title: Sun, Surf and Soccer in Rio
description: See scenes from the city as it prepares for two big turns on the world stage.

title: In Grenada, Ocean Views With a Spice Scent
description: All I wanted to do in Grenada was veg on the beach. I had a stack of paperbacks, SPF 70 and reservations for a Balinese massage. It was my first time back to the Caribbean in 10 years, and my first beach vacation in nearly as long. The prospect of eternal days of sunshine, frothy novels and morning yoga to keep me from morphing into a true sloth seemed like heaven.

title: Skiing Old Trails of the New Deal
description: I climbed the final few feet to the top of the slope and turned around just in time to watch the last rays of sun set the town of Adams aglow, 2,000 feet below. I had arrived at the base of Mount Greylock, Massachusetts highest peak, on a gorgeous, bluebird January afternoon, just a few days after a storm had dumped a thick coating of fresh powder across New England. And I had made good time skinning up the trail.

title: In Zurich, a Short Trip to Japan
description: As expected from a restaurant owner who moonlights as the president of a local Slow Food chapter, Markus Baumgartner obsesses over his kitchens ingredients. He has direct relationships with all his purveyors, from a former banker who now raises salmon out of terraced ponds 25 miles from Zurichs city center to a cattle farming family 60 miles away whose small herd gets massages twice daily.

title: An Idyllic Retreat in a Tuscan Hamlet
description: Rates

title: Gleacher Confirms It Has Called Off Sales Process
description: The struggling investment bank Gleacher & Company confirmed on Friday that it had ended attempts to sell itself, at least for the moment, as it settled on the sale of its mortgage lending unit.

title: Lies to Win British Post Earn Conviction in New York
description: A New York lawyer who lied about her work experience and shaved nearly 20 years off her age in an effort to gain admittance to the British bar was convicted of all counts she faced by a judge in Manhattan on Friday.

title: 2Chainz Arrested on Marijuana Charges on Way to Concert
description: The rapper 2Chainz was arrested on drug charges on Thursday night, said the Maryland State Police, who briefly detained him as he traveled to perform at a concert. A police spokesman, Sgt. Marc Black, told The Associated Press that troopers had stopped a van for speeding on Route 50 near Easton, Md. The officers said they smelled marijuana in the car, conducted a seach and found a backpack with a marijuana grinder and trace amounts of the drug inside it.

title: Buffetts Kind of Deal
description: It is by now almost trite to say that there are deals and then there are Buffett deals. And the $23 billion acquisition of H.J. Heinz is certainly a Buffett deal.

title: Calling All Nico Fans
description: If youve secretly harbored the belief that Nico, the sultry German chanteuse who sang briefly with the Velvet Underground, was a major but sadly unappreciated cultural icon, your moment may be at hand.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper East Side duplex, a one-bedroom in the Flatiron district and a Carroll Gardens two-bedroom in a converted toy factory.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A tudor-style colonial with two pools, a green house and extensive patios, and a four-bedroom within walking distance of the Long Island Sound.

title: Gas Pipeline Draws Last-Minute Protests
description: In a last-ditch effort to block construction of a controversial natural gas pipeline in northeastern Pennsylvania, campaigners urged an interstate regulator on Friday to review the projects environmental impact.

title: A Meteor Streaking Through the Sky From Six Vantage Points
description: Here you can see six videos, uploaded to YouTube, aligned to represent the fiery trajectory from various viewpoints.

title: A Deal-Making Craze? Yes, With Caveats
description: Are we in the middle of a bull run for mergers?

title: The Fruits of Winter
description: Whether you are looking for an extra dose of vitamins or just love the flavors of fruit, winter is a time of abundance at the fruit stand. Martha Rose Shulman writes:

title: The G.O.P.s Nasty Newcomer
description: WHEN a Vesuvius like John McCain tells you that you belch too much smoke and spew too much fire, you know youve got a problem.

title: For a Weekend, at Least, Anthony and Garnett Unite
description: HOUSTON  Carmelo Anthony walked into the grand ballroom of the Hilton Americas hotel on Friday wearing a white and gold long-sleeve shirt and big brown sunglasses. Anthony captured what All-Star weekend is all about for many players: enjoying the spotlight.

title: Indian Troops Kill Pakistani Soldier in Kashmir Border Clash
description: NEW DELHI  Indian troops have shot and killed another Pakistani soldier at the de facto border between the two countries in Kashmir, adding to an unusually tense period in the disputed region.

title: U.S. Soccer Player Opens Up About Being Gay
description: It was around 11 a.m. Friday when David Testos cellphone began to vibrate constantly. There were missed calls. Voice mail messages. E-mails.

title: Beans With Bacon
description: Its winter. Its cold. Its perfect weather for a warming meal. Melissa Clark shows how to make red wine pinto beans with bacon.

title: Sun City Its Not
description: When the co-op conversion wave began in New York City in the 1960s, singles and young married couples flocked to the Upper West Side hoping to get a piece of the action. Some of those people, now in their 70s, are still there, cemented in place by apartments bought for a song or equally treasured rent-stabilized units.

title: Beans and Red Wine: Party Hearty
description: It started with a question from a friend.

title: Caught for Posterity in Love
description: Torture is the word Sandy Herrera uses to describe being photographed. I hate taking pictures, Ms. Herrera, 21, said. I guess Im insecure. Which is why her boyfriend of two years, Sergio Ramirez, 23, was floored when she suggested they pay a Valentines Day visit to the Bronx Documentary Center, which had invited couples from across the borough to pose for photographs.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Marc Jacobs
description: The beauty look is very Marc Jacobs: edgy, cool, very underground with a touch of rock, says the makeup artist Franois Nars, who works exclusively with Jacobs each season. Naming Marianne Faithfull and Joan Jett as the muses for the smoky-eyed, monochromatic look, Nars says the process of arriving at this concept was quite easy: We both love the 60s and 70s era. There were so many great characters at that time! The focus on black-and-white tones not only referenced the punk-rock chic inspiration, but was also a practical consideration. With the first part of the runway show taking place under a sepia glow, Nars needed to come up with an idea that would look striking in both types of lighting. So we did a black smoky eye with white pencil used on the inner rim to make the eyes pop and look bigger, and the eyebrows are strong and defined, he says. The skin is totally matte, and at the last minute I put a little grease on top of the eye makeup and clear gloss on the lips so it looks like the girl went out, stayed out all night and got her makeup a little sweaty.

title: When to Salt Your Beans
description: There are many opinions about when to add salt to a pot of simmering beans. Some experts say to wait until the beans soften before adding salt, otherwise the beans wont cook through. Others advise adding the salt right at the beginning of the cooking in order to season the beans through and through.

title: Fall Fashion: From Gray to Technicolor
description: Eric Wilson presents the highlights of New York Fashion Week for fall 2013.

title: Texas Senator Goes on Attack and Raises Bipartisan Hackles
description: WASHINGTON  As the Senate edged toward a divisive filibuster vote on Chuck Hagels nomination to be defense secretary, Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, sat silent and satisfied in the corner of the chamber  his voice lost to laryngitis  as he absorbed what he had wrought in his mere seven weeks of Senate service.

title: SAC Clients Said to Seek $1.7 Billion in Refunds
description: Clients of SAC Capital Advisors have asked to withdraw $1.7 billion from the giant hedge fund as the governments insider trading investigation intensifies, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Mexican Revolution
description: On arriving in the sleepy Mexican town of Mrida, one might wonder what all the recent fuss is about. The historical center, with its faded limestone mansions, narrow cobblestoned streets and monumental cathedral  one of the oldest in all of the Americas and built out of limestone rocks from ancient Mayan structures  is indeed picturesque. And the handful of modest-looking restaurants in town can certainly serve up a decent bowl of lime and tortilla soup. And if youre in the market to unload some pesos on a colorful hammock or an embroidered blouse, a few mom-and-pop tourist shops can help you do just that. But in truth, theres not much to shake a stick at here in this remote corner of the Yucatn.

title: Pablo Larran Discusses 'No'
description: Pablo Larran, the director of "No," talks about using vintage video cameras to shoot his film.

title: Where to Stay | Merida, Mexico
description: Find the best hotels, haciendas and houses to rent in Merida, Mexico, before it becomes the fashion packs next favorite destination.

title: Digital Diary: Are We Suffering From Mobile App Burnout?
description: At last count, I had 259 applications on my iPhone.

title: Relinquishing Purse Strings
description: As a substitute teacher in Boston during the 1970s school-busing crisis there, Orlando Bagwell was attacked by a mob and kicked into the street. He was rescued by a bus driver. Shortly thereafter Mr. Bagwell, a fledgling filmmaker, was hired by public television to work on a piece about a South Boston protester who had changed her mind and was advocating peace. Her son, it turned out, was one of Mr. Bagwells attackers.

title: Herbalife a Playground for Activist Investors
description: Herbalife has become the ultimate financial plaything.

title: What Makes Manhattan Cost So Much
description: Youve probably heard the stat before: The cost of living is twice as high in New York as it is in the rest of the country. In the Council for Community and Economic Researchs latest cost of living report, we find out exactly what that means, and what the biggest distortions are.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A New Superhero Power Couple
description: At the top of our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week is Vol. 2 of Justice League, the latest collection featuring the top heroes of DC Comics. In these stories, the heroes confront a new villain and readers get a glimpse into a new power couple, whose relationship will have repercussions for everyone. Vol. 1 of the series hits our paperback list at No. 7.

title: School Bus Drivers End Strike, in Win for New York Mayor
description: The main union for New York Citys school bus drivers ended its monthlong strike Friday, handing a victory to the Bloomberg administration, which had refused to give in to the unions demands for job protections.

title: Amazon to Investigate Claims of Worker Intimidation at Distributor in Germany
description: BERLIN  The workers came from across Europe to pack boxes for the online retailer Amazon at distribution centers in Germany during the Christmas rush. They did not expect to be watched over  some say intimidated  by thugs in neo-Nazi-style clothing and jackboots.

title: Pochettino Shows Promise on Englands South Coast
description: It was a subtle compliment, but one that echoed long after it had been uttered.

title: Curtain Call | New York Fashion Week
description: New York Fashion Week has ended but we leave you with some of our favorite designers taking their much deserved bows.

title: The Scent of MissoniHome
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Was that Fireball a Meteor or a Meteorite?
description: As Russian speakers will be aware, more and less profane versions of the question What was that? punctuated many of the spectacular videos recorded in and around the Siberian city of Chelyabinsk on Friday, as what NASA calls the Russian fireball screamed across the sky.

title: Why We Love Beautiful Things
description: GREAT design, the management expert Gary Hamel once said, is like Justice Potter Stewarts famous definition of pornography  you know it when you see it. You want it, too: brain scan studies reveal that the sight of an attractive product can trigger the part of the motor cerebellum that governs hand movement. Instinctively, we reach out for attractive things; beauty literally moves us.

title: For Whitney Cummings, Good and Bad Ratings News
description: When you have created or helped create three shows on television in less than two years, as the comedian Whitney Cummings has, the ratings can bring good news and bad news simultaneously.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 15
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: Heavy Refreshments
description: The 2013 Ram 1500 was supposed to get a modest freshening. But with a new engine here and an air suspension there, the upgrades really added up.

title: New York Top 5
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Movie Review | 'No'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews No.

title: S.E.C., Suspecting Insider Trading, Freezes Account Over Heinz Buyout
description: 8:52 p.m. | Updated

title: Trucks in Waiting: Whats Coming Next
description: The Ram 1500 was the first revamped full-size pickup to reach showrooms, but competitors have been working to update their trucks as well.

title: Fresh Prince of Pickups
description: WHITEFIELD, N.H.  Some latter-day puritans contend that excess is a moral abomination and just plain wrong. In the case of the latest Ram 1500 pickup, they would be wrong. Excess is precisely why the revamped Ram is so good.

title: Pictures of the Day: Jerusalem and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Jerusalem, West Bank, South Korea and Russia.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 15
description: More photographs.

title: In the Age of Specialists, One Focused on Cadillacs
description: NEW MILFORD, CONN.  Its a reality of auto restorers existence that their handiwork is often scattered far from where the makeover was performed. Seldom are the cars reunited in the way that the creations of a painter or sculptor are assembled for a retrospective show.

title: Here Comes the Giant Artificial Sun
description: The yellowish glow from the huge disc was visible through the front doors of the armory on Lexington Avenue. Within minutes of entering Marc Jacobss show, people were aware that they looked different and perhaps felt different, since the light robbed them of their natural color  the colors of their skin, hair, clothes.

title: Cadillac Man
description: Frank Nicodemus is bringing the icons of Detroits tailfin era back to their glory days.

title: Charges Against Jackson and Other Legal Documents
description: The charges against former Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. in federal court, his plea agreement and other case files.

title: Covering a Papal Election
description: A conversation with Ian Fisher, the former Rome bureau chief, and the religion correspondent Laurie Goodstein about reporting on the selection of a new pope.

title: Navigating With Devices That Know Landmarks
description: An important goal for makers of GPS navigation devices is to deliver maps and route guidance that will not be dangerous distractions for drivers.Spoken directions would seem to be a good solution, but telling people Turn right at Baker Street might just make people ignore the road ahead while straining to read street signs.

title: More Traction for Fuel-Efficient Tires
description: The engineers who create gallon-squeezing cars like the Toyota Prius use every available method to comply with the ever-tightening fuel-economy standards they must meet. Those solutions may include the use of hybrid powertrains, adopting lightweight materials, cutting aerodynamic drag and minimizing the friction losses of moving parts.

title: Lavish Lifestyle of a Lawmaker Yields Federal Charges
description: WASHINGTON  In the span of four years starting in 2007, Jesse L. Jackson Jr., then a representative from Illinois, amassed a collection of celebrity memorabilia, furs, jewelry and furniture.

title: Sauce for the Goose, French Style
description: Michel Barnier, the Frenchman who is the European Commissioner for internal market and services, spoke in New York on Friday at a luncheon sponsored by the Atlantic Council and the Clearing House, and made the plea for the United States to adopt International Financial Reporting Standards, something that now seems very unlikely.

title: Why Is Gaia Angry With Me?
description: You may not carry a laptop case made out of recycled fixed-gear bicycle tires. And it has probably been a while since you used yak dung to heat your home. But, hey, youre an environmentalist. At least, thats what you and your fellow boomers tell those pollsters whenever they ask.

title: Kenyan Court Rejects Suit Against Presidential Candidate
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The presidential election is less than three weeks away, yet a major question that could decide the outcome hangs in the balance: should two top candidates accused of committing grave crimes be allowed to run?

title: Movie Review | 'Like Someone in Love'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Like Someone in Love.

title: Furor Over Use of Horse Meat Grows in Britain Despite Testing
description: LONDON  Battling to contain the mounting crisis over horse meat in products labeled as beef, Britains food safety agency said Friday that more than 2,500 tests conducted by the food industry had shown that just 29 samples contained more than 1 percent horse meat.

title: U.S. Players Rally Behind Robbie Rogers on Twitter
description: Still think a gay athlete like Robbie Rogers wouldnt be accepted in the locker room? Some of Rogerss teammates showed their support on Friday via Twitter.

title: Its Passengers Departed, Cruise Ship to Undergo Inspection
description: MOBILE, Ala.  After five days aboard the lifeless cruise ship Triumph, most of the 4,200 passengers and crew members finally reached their homes on Friday as Carnival Cruise Lines hauled the Triumph to a shipyard for inspection and repairs.

title: The Boy Wonder of BuzzFeed
description: BenSmithing is now an official term! shouted Michael Hastings, a BuzzFeed reporter and author, at his book release party in Chelsea on a subfreezing night in January. The roomful of young reporters, ad salesmen and b-list political gadflies (Meghan McCain turned heads all night) hooted in approval.

title: Dashboard Cameras, Meant to Record Accidents and Mayhem, Capture Cosmic Event
description: Many of the detailed video images viewed around the world on Friday showing the explosive meteor in Russia can be traced to what may seem like an unlikely source: the countrys reputation for crazy motorists, stupefying traffic accidents and corrupt police officers. This has led many drivers in Russia to install dashboard cameras, which document every minute on the road.

title: Famous Faces Make a Splash, Again and Again
description: Didnt we just see her? There at the Marchesa fall 2013 show at the New York Public Library on Wednesday evening was Jada Pinkett Smith, in a sexy strapless black dress, sharing the front row with Miley Cyrus, the Cosmopolitan editor in chief Joanna Coles and Lake Bell.

title: New York Fashion Week | Take a Bow
description: New York Fashion Week has ended, but we leave you with some of our favorite designers taking their much-deserved bows.

title: In Spain, Graft Inquiry Is Widening
description: MADRID  For 20 years, Luis Brcenas toiled in obscurity for Spains governing Popular Party, working as a bookkeeper and treasurer. These days when he walks the streets of Madrid in his signature chesterfield coat, strangers lash out at him with just one word: Envelope!

title: From Has-Been to Life of the Party
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Janice Min, the editor of The Hollywood Reporter, looked a little dazed as she stood outside Spago the other night. And so what if she was? Facing a firing squad of 16 photographers and 7 TV cameras will do that to a person.

title: Todays Body Language With Yesterdays Steps
description: Ronald K. Brown and his company, Evidence, open their second program of the season at the Joyce Theater with Mr. Browns 2001 work Walking Out the Dark. Few dances begin more thrillingly.

title: Testifying to the Power of Gospels Folk Wing
description: More than half a century of American social history is embodied in the warm, earthy voice of the great R&B gospel singer Mavis Staples, who appeared at the Allen Room on Thursday evening as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series. Beyond being embracing and visceral, that voice is determined.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Vine Artists and Digital 2013
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital announce a blockbuster deal for H.J. Heinz, American Airlines and US Airways announce a merger, and Brooklyn Brewery sets its sights on France.

title: Livestrong Not Immune From Turmoil Surrounding Its Founder
description: Craig Staley could barely keep up with the demand for Livestrong merchandise at Mellow Johnnys Bike Shop in Austin, Tex., in 2008, when Lance Armstrong announced that he would return to professional cycling after a brief retirement. Customers at the store, co-owned by Armstrong, stocked up on yellow bracelets, T-shirts, sunglasses, hats and water bottles bearing the name of Armstrongs foundation, Livestrong, which had raised millions to aid cancer research and survivors.

title: A Night for Romantics
description: By most measures Alan Gilbert, now in his fourth season as the music director of the New York Philharmonic, has brought fresh artistic vision and purpose to the orchestra. But for some, Mr. Gilberts performances of repertory staples, though always strong, have lacked the excitement that he can bring to contemporary music, or to personal passions like the symphonies of Carl Nielsen or the early works of Schoenberg.

title: Photo Replay: February 15
description: Photo Replay: February 15

title: Easing the Passage From Prison
description: As family and friends made their way through the metal detector and past the uniformed guards, Lloyd Williams sat off to the side, going over his speech, mumbling to himself. In a few moments, the courtroom in the Harlem Community Justice Center would be filled with parolees turned graduates. After spending half his life in prison, Mr. Williams, 46, wearing a crisp suit and tie, was the valedictorian of sorts, one of the nights guest speakers.

title: Public Domain, My Dear Watson? Lawsuit Challenges Conan Doyle Copyrights
description: Some 125 years after his first appearance, Sherlock Holmes remains a hot literary property, inspiring thousands of pastiches, parodies and sequels in print, to saying nothing of the hit Warner Bros. film starring Robert Downey Jr. and such television series as Elementary and the BBCs Sherlock.

title: Facebook Says Hackers Breached Its Computers
description: Facebook admitted that it was breached by sophisticated hackers in recent weeks, two weeks after Twitter made a similar admission. Both Facebook and Twitter were breached through a well-publicized vulnerability in Oracles Java software.

title: Condom-Giveaway Program Celebrates Birthday
description: At an art gallery, placing four condom cakes by the front door sets a certain tone. At the event Friday morning celebrating the sixth birthday of the city health departments NYC Condom campaign, that tone was fun mixed with triumph.

title: Music Companies Fight Over the Scraps of EMI
description: After the main course, the leftovers.

title: From Abroad, High Doses of Adrenaline
description: Today concerts of works by Mahler and Strauss hardly count as adventurous programming. But when the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra was founded in 1888, these composers were grateful to find in it a passionate champion of their music at a time when it was by no means self-evident to encounter, as Strauss did with relief, an orchestra capable of playing all passages.

title: Boy Scouts Job Application
description: It turns out that the Boy Scouts of America  which has postponed making a decision about changing its policy of barring openly gay people from participation as scouts or scoutmasters  has another retrograde anti-gay policy.

title: Big Ticket | Towers of Limestone, Sold for $32.5 Million
description: The luster and lure of the statuesque limestone towers Robert A. M. Stern designed at 15 Central Park West have not diminished, nor apparently has the supply of well-heeled buyers who do not flinch at the notion of spending $7,000 or more per square foot for the privilege of residing there whenever they drop into town. A four-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath condominium with multiple Central Park vistas has sold for $32.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The original listing price last June was $36 million.

title: How the West Was Won: A Day-to-Day Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Saturday Reading: No Mail Today?
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Exits
Creating Hipsturbia
description: A yoga studio opened on Main Street that offers lunch-hour vinyasa classes. Nearby is a bicycle store that sells Dutch-style bikes, and a farm-to-table restaurant that sources its edible nasturtiums from its backyard garden.

title: Errors in Credit Reports
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Voting Easier
description: To the Editor:

title: New Identity, Same Old History
description: The Late Mathias Pascal

title: Under Colorful Lights, a Fusion Mix
description: Occupying a convenient spot around the corner from the Jacob Burns Film Center and across the street from the railway station, Miyabi is Pleasantvilles newest restaurant. It bills itself as an Asian bistro and sushi bar, a fusion mix that diners have seen before. What is surprising about Miyabi, however, is the dcor and its atmosphere, which is like Hollywoods idea of a nightclub.

title: Madison Square Garden, Permit Lapsed, Faces New Planning Pressure
description: Madison Square Garden has been operating without a zoning permit for three weeks and will keep doing so in the near future.

title: A Crisis in Germany?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 8
description: Pamela Loves jam at Milk Studios; Susanne Bartsch and Patricia Fields party at Marquee.

title: Lets Shut Down the Catwalks and Dance
description: After the final walk at the Marc Jacobs show Thursday night, many in the fashion set bolted home, either to catch up on sleep or to pack for London Fashion Week. But some partygoers were determined to finally let loose and celebrate the end of New York Fashion Week.

title: Kim Gordon Looks Back
description: I wasnt joking when I said Im not interested in talking about 1993, said Kim Gordon, singer and bassist of the band Sonic Youth.

title: Five-Year High Power Prices
description: The price of electricity in New England is running way above normal because the price of natural gas, which is used to generate electricity, has spiked.

title: Grazing Menu Goes Beyond Tacos
description: I had a moment of dj vu as I entered Bodega Taco Bar in Darien from the rear parking lot. The narrow passageway that leads to the dining room reminded me of the previous occupant of the space, Caf DAzur.

title: CNNs Cruise Ship Coverage Lifts Ratings
description: CNNs decision to cover one story  of a stranded Carnival cruise ship in the Gulf of Mexico  like no other channel could on Thursday appeared to pay off when the Nielsen ratings came in on Friday.

title: Nice Aliens, Evil Human
description: Another Smurf movie is due out this summer, but apparently someones market research indicated that the public appetite for blue animated characters might need sating before then. The result is Escape From Planet Earth, a childrens movie about space-traveling blue beings that has lots of high-flying escapades but fairly low aspirations.

title: Remembering the Natty Times
description: NOSTALGIA HAS BECOME  apologies to baseball  the great American pastime. So its slightly ironic that the 1998 film Pleasantville, about two modern-day teenagers accidentally transported to the 1950s black-and-white world of an old sitcom, was so ahead of its time. It even had the ambivalence right: at the films end, the sister, played by Reese Witherspoon, decides she actually prefers the 1950s to the 1990s, while the brother, played by Tobey Maguire, decides to go home in time.

title: Cambodia Sees Ethical Conflict in Import Panel
description: Cambodia has asked that a Sothebys executive who sits on a State Department panel that advises that agency on cultural property issues recuse herself from its deliberations on import restrictions for Cambodian antiquities.

title: How Wrestling Lost the Olympics
description: IN A.D. 393, the ancient Olympic Games were abolished  they had become too corrupt. Wrestling was among the first sports in those ancient Games; wrestling was also included at the start of the modern Olympics, in 1896.

title: In This House, Dont Fixate on the Views
description: The best attribute of Murder 3, described by the Bollywood press machine as an erotic thriller (hmm to both of those), is its primary setting: a gorgeous estate that deserves two thumbs up from the folks at Architectural Digest. Ah, that kitchen, that porch, that bedroom: Its house porn worthy of the films of Nancy Meyers (Its Complicated, Somethings Gotta Give).

title: Bill Cunningham | Playing Footsie
description: At New York Fashion Week showgoers were climbing over slush and snow in their exotic stiletto heels, some with open toes and backs.

title: Ira Rubin at the 1962 Cavendish Invitational Pairs
description: Here is another deal I found while researching Ira Rubin, who died on Feb. 6 at 82. This one occurred during the Cavendish Invitational Pairs in 1962, played in New York City. It featured an excellent defensive play by Rubins partner, Philip Feldesman.

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 15
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gigantic Northeast snowstorm, Senator Frank R. Lautenbergs retirement announcement and the Westminster Dog Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Lawsuit Against Prosecutor to Proceed
description: A federal judge ruled on Friday that a lawsuit by a wrongfully convicted man against the office of the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, and the New York Police Department could proceed, setting the stage for a trial in which Mr. Hynes could be called to testify in defense of his policies amid a heated re-election campaign.

title: Lincoln, the Play and Everything After
description: Tom Hanks, Steven Spielbergs frequent collaborator, snags himself a seat on Mr. Spielbergs bandwagon on Sunday when he turns up as the narrator of Killing Lincoln, a docudrama on the National Geographic Channel.

title: Two Observations on the Politics of the Minimum Wage
description: It looks as if President Obama has successfully set a political trap over the minimum wage. Raising the minimum is very popular  even a narrow majority of Republicans (pdf) are for it. But Republican leaders are opposed. And theyd like people to believe that their opposition is driven by sincere concern for workers who might lose their jobs.

title: New York Fashion Week: About Extremes
description: Cathy Horyn takes a look at the fall 2013 collections.

title: Incomes Flat in Recovery, but Not for the 1%
description: WASHINGTON  Incomes rose more than 11 percent for the top 1 percent of earners during the economic recovery, but not at all for everybody else, according to new data.

title: Unfashionable Yet Visionary
description: With the way art history is being written and rewritten these days, Neo-Expressionism is pretty much the odd man out. For one thing, its perpetrators were mostly painters and mostly male. For another, they tended to approach their work without the obvious Conceptual underpinnings that are now so de rigueur. Among the Germans, only the consistently subversive and innovative Sigmar Polke, never really a card-carrying Neo-Expressionist, has genuine street cred right now, while Anselm Kiefer has settled into a particularly overbearing style and a gassy form of art stardom.

title: Public Recreation Centers Looking to Stem Exodus
description: Under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the city has made fighting obesity and improving public health one of its top priorities.

title: Friday Night Music: Take the F Train
description: The Lone Bellow calls what they do Brooklyn country music; here they let their bridge-and-tunnel flag fly:

title: Stargazing: The Finale
description: The Ralph Lauren runway show always brings about a collective sigh of relief. There is the smooth check-in process, the generous riser-style runway seating and, in its usual time-and-day slot, the signal that you have survived another New York Fashion Week.

title: Welcome to Change
description: T is a magazine about style in all its dimensions. As such, it aspires not merely to reflect the times we live in, but to illuminate cultural shifts in a thought-provoking and exciting way. Style, to us, encompasses all the elements of life that arent absolutely necessary, but without which life would be less charmed, less beautiful and certainly not as fun.

title: Pan-Asian, With Dim Sum Every Day
description: There are some locations that seem to have a revolving door, with restaurants opening and closing in rapid succession. In Huntington, 92 East Main Street is one of them. The current occupant, Ting, a pan-Asian entry like its predecessors, opened in October and is owned by Yu Mei Zheng, a first-time restaurateur.

title: A Nights Toll: Two Teeth and $2,800
description: He awakened in his apartment two Wednesdays ago in agony. Searing pain, he said later. He found a mirror. Two of his teeth  a front one and one beside it  were missing.

title: Amid Turmoil at Museo del Barrio, Its Director Steps Down
description: Margarita Aguilar, the director of El Museo del Barrio since August 2011, has left the position amid turmoil at the museum, which in recent months has slashed its days of operation and instituted layoffs and furloughs, museum officials confirmed on Friday.

title: South African Star Reflects on Pistorius Case
description: LOS ANGELES  They are both A-list sports celebrities in South Africa, but Charl Schwartzel, the 2011 Masters champion, said he has never met Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star accused of fatally shooting his girlfriend.

title: Elizabeth and James: Fall 2013 RTW
description: New York

title: For the Cake Boss, Real-World Growth
description: THE LINE OUTSIDE Carlos Bake Shop Ridgewood last Sunday morning is not likely to be an everyday occurrence, according to Adam Bourcier, a spokesman who was guarding the door against occupancy overload. The presence of the throng had to do with who was inside for the grand opening, he said.

title: When the New You Carries a Fresh Identity, Too
description: When I was 5, my older brother informed me my last name wouldnt always be Wood. My father confirmed it. If your husbands last name is Peabody, youll have to become Mrs. Peabody, he teased. I hid behind my bedroom door to process this startling information privately. If I could so easily become a Peabody, did that mean I was worth less to my family than my two brothers, who would go forth and propagate the world with more children bearing the last name Wood? And just who was this Mr. Peabody and what was so great about him that I would give up my name to marry him?

title: Scorers Touch, Gone Missing in Philadelphia, Returns in Toronto
description: TORONTO  James van Riemsdyk grew up in New Jersey, played in college at New Hampshire and began his N.H.L. career in Philadelphia. But it took a move to Toronto to get van Riemsdyk playing like the power forward he was expected to be when he was selected No. 2 over all in the 2007 draft.

title: A Big Menu, Starring Fresh Seafood
description: Tsuru Japanese Cuisine is tucked into an ersatz village in Basking Ridge, but dont let the antiseptic surroundings deter you. If two visits are any indication of this place, theres nothing fake about the experience. Tsuru is a friendly spot offering simple, well-prepared food, especially fresh and delicious sushi and sashimi.

title: Child Abuse at Reservation Is Topic for 3 Lawmakers
description: Federal officials will hold a town hall meeting on the Spirit Lake Indian Reservation in North Dakota this month to discuss the reservations child sexual abuse problem, which last year led the federal government to take over the tribes social services program.

title: Collins Opens Door to Byrd in Outfield
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Marlon Byrd arrived at the Mets spring training center on Friday afternoon, and though his stay there has no guarantees, it started with a ringing endorsement that spoke to the teams underwhelming talent in the outfield.

title: In New England, a Natural Gas Trap
description: Electricity prices in New England have been four to eight times higher than normal in the last few weeks, as the regions extreme reliance on natural gas for power supplies has collided with a surge in demand for heating.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Good Fit for Todays Little Screens: Short Stories
description: The Internet may be disrupting much of the book industry, but for short-story writers it has been a good thing.

title: 19th-Century Perspectives on Two Great Rivers
description: In an age when the mere push of a button or the click of a mouse can summon a satellite view of just about any place on the planet, how can we understand the thrill that 19th-century Londoners felt as they gazed at painted views of the Catskills, or the excitement of New Yorkers looking at 3-D photographs  called stereographs  of Hyde Park?

title: Senators Overboard!
description: We seem to be short one secretary of defense.

title: As Fisheries Struggle, Debate Heats Up Over How to Help
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass.  B. G. Brown, a second-generation fisherman who chases cod and haddock from this port city, spent a recent morning rigging up his 31-foot commercial vessel to be manned alone. He had just lost his only crew member to the more lucrative lobster fishery, days after fishery regulators last month approved a 77 percent cut in the amount of cod that can be harvested from the Gulf of Maine waters here.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: All Bundled Up, but With Hearts on the Wing
description: There are things you should know about the weird and wondrous Maine town called Almost. It is the sort of place where a young woman, if she had a broken heart, might put all 19 pieces inside a brown paper bag and carry it around. The kind of town where a guy cannot deny that he has fallen in love because he suddenly starts falling down. (Collapsing completely. Over and over. Cant stand up for more than a few seconds.) A town where you can get up from a park bench, walk around the world and return by the end of Act II. Where the local hangout is the Moose Paddy and, as the waitress points out, Drinks are free if youre sad.

title: Ts Spring Womens Fashion
description: The spring womens fashion issue of T marks the unveiling of a redesigned magazine, from its features to its logo. Emphasizing elegance and simplicity, the issue begins with a profile of the 79-year-old style icon Lee Radziwill, photographed in her Paris apartment, and moves onto another Parisian paragon of style, the designer Azzedine Alaa, whose perfectly simple clothing is among fashions most celebrated. Also in the issue is a peek into the working lives of the duo behind the label Proenza Schouler, who are at their most creative at their Berkshires farmhouse; a profile of the PPR head Franois-Henri Pinault; and an introduction to Jonathan Anderson, a front-runner in a talented pack of new British designers. Additional highlights from the magazine include the best accessories of the season, an unexpectedly sophisticated retreat in Mexico and one of the chicest houses in London. See all from the issue ->

title: Kentuckians Dont Rule Out a Star as a Potential Senator
description: ASHLAND, Ky.  It would seem like a Republican fantasy: a famous actress, who has been described by her own grandmother as a Hollywood liberal, is floated as a Senate candidate in one of the countrys most conservative states, where she does not even live.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Rise of Drones in U.S. Drives Efforts to Limit Police Use
description: They can record video images and produce heat maps. They can be used to track fleeing criminals, stranded hikers  or just as easily, political protesters. And for strapped police departments, they are more affordable than helicopters.

title: Getting Preschool Education Right
description: Even before the cost estimates and program details have been made public, President Obamas proposal for expanding high-quality preschool education has encountered criticism from House Republicans. Yet decades of research has shown that well-designed preschool programs more than pay for themselves by giving young children the skills they need to move ahead. The challenge at the federal level will be to make sure that taxpayer dollars flow to proven, high-quality programs instead of being wasted on subsidies for glorified day care.

title: Transition in Afghanistan
description: The United States military faces tough challenges in one outpost as the draw down begins.

title: Teachers Pension Fund Divests Gun Holdings
description: The New York City teachers pension fund, reacting to an outcry that has intensified since the school shootings in Newtown, Conn., has voted to shed its portfolio of five gun companies despite the objections of a representative for a prominent gun-control advocate: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Showing Gifts to Mark an Anniversary
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  The Hofstra University Museum, founded in 1963, had a decision to make as its 50th anniversary approached: Of the more than 5,000 works in its collection, which would be put on display to celebrate the event?

title: Investors Beware
description: Across the country, state securities regulators are reporting an upsurge in fraud cases involving retirement savers who have been lured by brokers into complex investments.

title: Loyola Uses Retro Training Techniques to Stay Ahead
description: BALTIMORE  When the Loyola mens lacrosse team beat Maryland, 9-3, in the May heat of Foxborough, Mass., it won the universitys first Division I championship in any sport.

title: Holiday Monday
description: Washingtons Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday, Feb. 18.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: U.S. Military Faces Fire as It Pulls Out of Afghanistan
description: STRONG POINT HAJI RAHMUDDIN II, Afghanistan  When the last American soldiers to occupy this squat, lonely outpost in southern Afghanistan pulled out this week, they left the same way earlier units had arrived: ready for a fight.

title: Free Tuition at Cooper Union May Be Near End
description: The new academic building was glamorous, its perforated metal skin shooting up dramatically from the streets of the East Village, then swerving around a daring gash of glass. It made a statement about just how far the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art had come, from its 19th-century origins as a charity for the poor to one of the most selective colleges in the nation.

title: Taking a Break, of Sorts, From the Lakers Dysfunction
description: HOUSTON

title: Renew the Violence Against Women Act
description: This weeks 78-to-22 vote in the Senate to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act provided a refreshing demonstration of bipartisanship that the House would do well to emulate. Last year, the Republican-led House blocked the acts renewal over objections to new protections for gay, immigrant and American Indian victims of domestic violence and sexual assault. It falls to Speaker John Boehner to see that this does not happen again.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Feb. 16, 2013
description: "It was a light which never happens in life; it happens probably only in the end of the world.

title: Heading for a Hotter Time in Rio Than Expected
description: Three friends take a pleasure trip to Brazil. One man behaves like an immature jerk. Another is in over his head with disreputable business associates. The third is the requisite goody-goody. Lives are changed, for good and bad, but maybe not quite enough.

title: A Strange Show in the Sky Over Siberia
description: Hundreds were injured, most of them by glass shattered by the shock wave created when a meteor exploded as it entered the atmosphere.

title: Exonerating the Scottsboro Nine
description: Decades too late, the Alabama Legislature is moving to grant posthumous pardons to the Scottsboro Boys  the nine black teenagers arrested as freight train hoboes in 1931 and convicted by all-white juries of raping two white women.

title: Dont Mythologize Christopher Dorner
description: I am no stranger to peoples glomming on to deadly criminals and celebrating them as heroes. Bonnie and Clyde were killed just south of the town where I grew up. There was that movie made about the couple, as well as a musical and more songs that I can count. And every year the town celebrates the duo and their killing with a festival and a shootout.

title: New Scrutiny for a Bequest to an Order of Catholics
description: When Gabrielle D. Mee, a wealthy Rhode Island widow, left her $60 million fortune to a powerful Catholic order called the Legion of Christ in 2008, revelations had already begun to surface that its charismatic founder, the Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado, had molested under-age seminarians and fathered several children.

title: Corrections: February 16, 2013
description: Editors Note

title: Not Strictly Adhering to Tempo
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Michael Ashley has published five Sunday New York Times puzzles since 2001, but he returns after a brief absence with a change of pace: his first Saturday crossword in this paper.

title: An Ohio Christian College Struggles to Further Define Itself
description: CEDARVILLE, OHIO

title: Peek Into a Buildings History
description: Earlier this month as New York was bracing for a snowstorm, anyone who had downloaded the New York City Buildings Departments new smartphone app, NYC Buildings, got an alert about the impending blizzard.

title: Notes From a Gun Buyback
description: NEWARK

title: A Reminder of Personal Connections, Not Tarnished Brand
description: As Jax Mariash went under the tattoo needle to have Livestrong emblazoned on her wrist in bold black letters, she did not think about Lance Armstrong or doping allegations, but rather the 10 people affected by cancer she wanted to commemorate in ink. It was Jan. 22, 2010, exactly a year since the disease had taken the life of her stepfather. After years of wearing yellow Livestrong wristbands, she wanted something permanent.

title: Ecuadors President Shows Confidence About Re-election, Too Much for Some
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In the final analysis, Edwin Tats supports President Rafael Correa of Ecuador and wants him to be re-elected. He just does not want it to be too easy.

title: New York Panorama
description: Every Sunday in the Metropolitan section, a photographer offers a new slice of New York.

title: High School Junior Makes Mile the Race to Watch
description: The high point of the Millrose Games is typically the mens Wanamaker Mile, the finale of the countrys best known indoor track and field meet. At this years meet, which will be held Saturday at the 168th Street Armory in Upper Manhattan, the highlight may end up being the womens mile, which will be run more than an hour earlier.

title: Syrian Opposition Group Is Open to Talks, With Conditions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias main opposition body on Friday formally endorsed an initiative to pursue a political solution through talks with members of the Syrian government  provided that Syrias president, Bashar al-Assad, and security and military leaders involved in his bloody crackdown are excluded.

title: Yankees Practice Patience With Pinedas Return
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The rehabilitating pitchers always go first. Half the Yankees pitchers and catchers were still getting dressed or eating breakfast when Michael Pineda walked into the clubhouse Friday morning, toweled off his sweaty face and ditched his cap in his locker before heading to the training room.

title: Dr. Wheelchair Is In
description: On Roosevelt Island, Mike Acevedo, 54, is known as Dr. Wheelchair, because he has been keeping patients at the Coler-Goldwater Specialty Hospital and Nursing Facility rolling since 1976.

title: Pope Names German Industrialist to Head Vatican Bank
description: ROME  In one of his last official acts, Pope Benedict XVI on Friday named Ernst von Freyberg, a German aristocrat and industrialist, as the new head of the Vatican Bank, reducing the Italian presence in a secretive institution that has struggled to restore its credibility and meet international transparency norms.

title: A Flash in Russian Skies, as Inspiration for Fantasy
description: Life is scariest when it imitates science fiction. The stunning video of the meteor that whistled and boomed across Russian skies on Friday unnerved even those with long experience imagining catastrophic events. Past and present practitioners of fantasy fiction in print and movies reacted to the views with awe  and some new ideas.

title: Of History and Romance
description: On upper Broadway, where hair salons and barbershops bustle well into the evening and markets sell plantains in outdoor bins, a bar with incongruous chic invites the neighborhood in for a beer. Step inside Harlem Public on Broadway at 149th Street and the trendy touches borrowed from elsewhere in the city are easy to spot. There are 16 taps of craft beer and about a dozen whiskeys from local distilleries. The dcor is made from reclaimed wood and corrugated metal. An ambitious menu includes avocado fries, a peanut butter burger and a decadent grilled cheese sandwich. Right now the cast iron gas fireplace, which took months of wrangling to install, is on the fritz. But the six-month-old bar generates its own heat, humming to an alternative soundtrack. And on Feb. 24, it will start brunch service.

title: Lottery Numbers
Size of Blast and Number of Injuries Are Seen as Rare for a Rock From Space
description: The meteor that exploded over Russia on Friday set off the largest explosion of its kind in more than a century, at least according to Western scientists. And even more unusual for a meteor, it caused numerous injuries, mostly from flying glass, as the shock wave violently jolted the city of Chelyabinsk below.

title: 2 Prostituted by Force, Officials Say
description: A Queens couple held two young women in a foreclosed home, and used threats and violence to force them into prostitution for months, the district attorney said Friday.

title: Shadow Morton, Songwriter and Producer, Dies at 71
description: Shadow Morton, a songwriter and producer who for a brief, luminous period in the 1960s poured the discontents of adolescence into original hit songs, including Leader of the Pack and Remember (Walking in the Sand), died on Thursday in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 71.

title: Edith Houghton, Rare Woman Among Baseball Scouts, Dies at 100
description: The Philadelphia Phillies were perennial cellar-dwellers in 1946 when Edith Houghton, a slim, dark-haired young woman in her 30s, walked into the team office without an appointment and talked her way into an unlikely job. She became one of the first women  and to this day one of the only women  to scout for a major league baseball team.

title: Afghan Insurgent Is Killed on U.S.-Led Military Base
description: KABUL  American Special Operations Forces stopped a tribal leader as he was driving with his brother and 6-year-old son in an area rife with Taliban in southern Afghanistan on Wednesday. A quick examination of his identity documents confirmed that he was a wanted man.

title: Off the Court, and With the Family
description: A dozen years into his N.B.A. career, the New York Knicks center Tyson Chandler, 30, has quietly accrued some shiny hardware: an N.B.A. championship ring, an Olympic gold medal, and a Defensive Player of the Year trophy. But this season, Mr. Chandler, 7-foot-1, can no longer fly under the radar, as he likes to say. He was named to his first All-Star team and is playing, along with his teammate Carmelo Anthony, in Sundays game in Houston. Rare is the Sunday off from Knicks practice when he can spend the full day with his wife, Kimberly, 31, and their three children, Sacha-Marie, 6; Tyson II, 4; and Sayge Jozzelle, 2, in their Upper East Side apartment. His ideal Sunday is full of food, family, photography  and more food.

title: Richard L. Murphy, Who Aided Disadvantaged Youths, Dies at 68
description: Richard L. Murphy, a social policy innovator who aided tens of thousands of disadvantaged New York City children and teenagers through his community organization in Harlem and as the citys youth commissioner under Mayor David N. Dinkins, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: In Britain, an Authority on the Past Stares Down a Nasty Modern Storm
description: CAMBRIDGE, England

title: The Rite of Spring
description: Theres a dramatic formality to the seasons symphony of black and white fashion.

title: A New Crime, but Convictions Are Elusive
description: First, the victim testified, her boyfriend bashed her head against the bathtub. In the bedroom of her Upper East Side apartment, she said, he slammed her down so hard on the bed that the frame broke, punched her all over her body, and spat in her face.

title: Iran: Pistachio Exports Are Suspended
description: Pistachio nuts, one of Irans most profitable products, appear to be latest victim of domestic inflation, so much so that the government has ordered a moratorium on exports as part of an effort to increase the supply at home and reduce the price, which has doubled just in the past month. The Associated Press quoted Vice President Mohammad-Reza Rahimi as saying the export ban would last for six months. But it was unclear whether the move, which he announced Friday, would reduce domestic prices, particularly in time for Nowruz, the coming New Year holiday when pistachios are in especially high demand. It was also unclear to what extent the higher price reflected the declining value of the rial, Irans currency, which has been weakened by the effects of Western sanctions and what critics call the governments economic mismanagement. The chairman of Irans chamber of exports, Asadollah Asgaroladi, was quoted by the Fars News Agency as calling the export moratorium a mistake that would do little to ease the price and probably cost Iran more than $500 million in lost export revenue. He was also quoted as saying the ban would only strengthen the competitiveness of pistachios from the United States, which surpassed Iran in total pistachio production last year.

title: Keeping Reggae Alive
description: For 30 years, Watty Burnett, the roots reggae artist, has been living in Dix Hills, Long Island, working as a part-time electrician. He has three new albums on the way.

title: Colombia: Rebels Release Captives
description: The countrys largest guerrilla group on Friday released two police officers it had taken captive in a recent action that appeared to have briefly threatened the groups peace talks with the government. The police officers were captured by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, in January, shortly after the group ended a two-month unilateral cease-fire.
