title: From Stay-at-Home Moms to Back-to-Work Lawyers
description: Since 2007, the Pace University School of Law in White Plains has been running a program aimed at helping lawyers who had left the field  typically stay-at-home mothers  re-enter the legal profession. Called New Directions, the course consists of 11 weeks of classroom refresher training and then an 11-week internship working as a lawyer in any of a number of settings, including law firms, government and nonprofit agencies and corporate offices. Pace offers two sessions a year, typically of 12 to 18 lawyers each. About 95 percent are women, and the average age is about 50. To date, 150 people have completed the training, with about half going on to paying jobs as lawyers. The cost is $7,000; participants may qualify for retraining grants of up to $3,000 from the United States Department of Labor. Another school offering a similar program includes the American University Washington College of Law Lawyer Re-Entry Program. That course is six days, spread over three weeks, and costs about $1,500; there are no internships.

title: Q&A: Deleting Photos From the iPad
description: Q.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Robert Draper on Why the G.O.P. Is So Slow to Adapt to the Digital World
description: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover article about the attempts by young conservatives to revamp the Republican Party. He last wrote for the magazine about how Democrats finally embraced super PACs.

title: Face It
description: This comic is about putting things in perspective. For me, anxiety brings on an overwhelming tunnel vision. It can be scary but I try to let go and take a look around when Im anxious.

title: Tech Predictions for 2013: Its All About Mobile
description: If there is one theme that will be the topic of digital business this year, it is mobile.

title: Fatalistic, Reckless, Distrustful
description: MOSCOW  There is nothing like a meteor to showcase national character. When one blew up in the sky over Chelyabinsk on Friday morning, the defining traits of Russian citizens emerged for all to see.

title: Chvez Returns to Venezuela, Trailing Doubts
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In a surprise predawn homecoming, President Hugo Chvez returned to Venezuela on Monday more than two months after having cancer surgery in Cuba, potentially clearing up some of the legal questions that have roiled the nation during his long absence but doing little to dispel the deep uncertainty over who is running the country.

title: Monday Reading: Visiting Rio, With Eyes Open
Report Points to Risk of Serious Gap in Weather Satellite Data
description: A new report from the Government Accountability Office elevates the problem of looming gaps in satellite weather data to a high risk concern for the federal government

title: Anti-Apartheid Leader Forms New Party in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  Mamphela Ramphele, a respected veteran of the struggle against apartheid, announced on Monday that she had formed a new political party to compete against the governing African National Congress, calling on South Africans to join me on a journey to build the country of our dreams.

title: Incumbent Is Likely Victor in Vote for Armenian Leader
description: MOSCOW  Armenians went to the polls on Monday in an election that seemed certain to return President Serzh Sargsyan to office for a second five-year term, and to maintain stability in a country that has become an increasingly important, if uneasy, United States ally in monitoring Irans nuclear ambitions.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: The Tech Industry Looks to Online Gambling and Business Insider Appoints an Executive Editor
description: Developers across the technology industry are focusing on online gambling as their next billion-dollar business, David Streitfeld reports. Online poker and sports betting are certainly nothing new, but developers from giants like Zynga to specialists like Betable are creating more casual games on which users can bet, from casino staples like slots and roulette to considerably more creative diversions. Developers are currently aiming their products at foreign markets while trying to make inroads in the United States, where online gambling is still largely illegal. Legislation to legalize the practice is slow, facing headwinds from brick-and-mortar casinos and traditional antigambling factions.

title: The Great Dollar Decline
description: Matt OBrien is covering the continuing Scarborough freakout over bearded prophets of non-doom; better him than me. I would say that JoScar is making progress. He seems to have graduated from frantic appeals to imagined authority  nobody else is saying what that guy says!  to efforts to make his case with actual data. Unfortunately, you really need some background knowledge  actually, quite a lot of background knowledge  before you try using economic data to tell stories, a point OBrien makes abundantly clear.

title: Calls to Return Afzal Gurus Body to Kashmir Grow Louder
description: SRINAGAR, Jammu and Kashmir  A weeklong curfew may have prevented widespread protests and violence in Kashmir, but anger is still brewing over the central governments secret execution and burial of the militant Muhammad Afzal.

title: Human Rights and Sports Events
description: Earlier this month, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia sacked a senior Russian Olympic Committee official over rising costs and a delay in the construction work for the 2014 Winter Olympics.

title: Holding Obamas Feet to the Climate-Change Fire
description: At first glance, it was hard to tell whether they had come to bury Obama or to praise him.

title: The Gun Report: February 18, 2013
description: They say weekends are when gun violence really ratchets up in America. Here is our sad sampling for this weekend just ended:

title: First Response Targets Spanish Language TV
description: The birthrate among women in the United States reached a record low in 2011, led mainly by the decline in births among immigrant and native-born Hispanic women. That decline, along with the opportunity that the Hispanic community represents for advertisers, is at the heart of a new campaign from First Response to promote its pregnancy planning tools.

title: Working Out a Problem to Take a Grand Prize
description: Christian Wijnants, a Belgian designer with a 10-year-old brand, has won the International Woolmark Prize. The finals for the competition were in London on Saturday night, with Donatella Versace and Diane von Furstenberg among the judges, and Mr. Wijnants, 35, won for his innovative knitwear.

title: WWS 543, Trade Policy: Classes 3 and 4
description: Slides (pdf):

title: LWren Scott in London
description: Shortly before guests arrived for LWren Scotts dinner on Sunday evening at Caf Royal, Nicole Kidman appeared at a London screening of her new film Stoker in the designers cobalt wool dress with a gold collar, the same look shown that afternoon on Ms. Scotts runway. The actresss red-carpet image dominated the front page of The Daily Telegraph on Monday.

title: Photos of The Moment | Jonathan Saunders
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Abraham Lincoln Has Never Been So Adorable
Christopher Kane: Fall 2013 RTW
description: London

title: What Were Reading
description: Travel + Leisure: Fresh mozzarella, suckling pig, persimmon gelato: a guide to doing Rome right.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Danica Patrick Has an All-Star Weekend
description: In a marked change of pace from the usual Nascar gossip-disguised-as-news involving its only top-level female driver, Danica Patrick, there was actual news involving its only top-level female driver: she won the pole position at the Daytona 500 on Sunday. And while this would be notable because she is the first woman to accomplish that, this became news just by actually being news.

title: With Writers Prize, Argo Sweeps the Major Guilds
description: Argo, Zero Dark Thirty and Searching for Sugar Man were the big cinematic winners at the Writers Guild Awards, held simultaneously in New York and Los Angeles on Sunday evening.

title: Now Streaming | Burberry Fall 2013 Womens Collection
Aging Phillies Look for a Spark
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.

title: Used Car Prices Vary by Market, Analysis Finds
description: The city where you buy a used car can make a big difference in price, a new analysis finds.

title: Research: A Media Diet Can Lead to Less Aggressive Behavior in Children
description: When researchers helped parents choose a better media diet for 3- to 5-year-olds, the results were encouraging. In a randomized trial, the children who watched less violent programs and whose parents paid closer attention to what the children were watching were less aggressive than those in a control group, and they scored higher on measures of social competence as much as a year later.

title: Danica Patrick Wins Pole for Daytona 500
description: Danica Patrick and Daytona International Speedway would seem to be made for each other; each is known for serving up surprising plot twists. They teamed for another stunner Sunday, as Patrick, embarking on her first full season in Nascars Sprint Cup series, won the pole position for the Feb. 24 Daytona 500.

title: The Daily Shoe | Jonathan Saunders
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Erdem: Fall 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Jerry Buss, Lakers Owner and Innovator, Dies at 80
description: Jerry Buss, who bought the Los Angeles Lakers in 1979 and turned them into the N.B.A.s glamour team, winners of 10 league championships and the cornerstone of his Southern California sports empire, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 80.

title: Hong Kong Disneyland Turns a Profit
description: LOS ANGELES  Mickey Mouse is finally making money in Hong Kong.

title: Numberplay Will Not Appear This Week
description: Numberplay will not appear this week while Gary Antonick is on vacation. The series will resume on Feb. 25.

title: Problems With Precision and Judgment, but Not Integrity, in Tesla Test
description: As promised, Ive spent the past several days looking into the reporter John M. Broders test drive of the celebrated electric car known as the Tesla Model S. The article, which focused on two new superchargers on the East Coast, was understandably disturbing to the company and to the cars many admirers. The test drive, its safe to say, did not go well. In fact, its publication was accompanied by a startling photograph of the Model S on a flatbed truck, onto which it was loaded after depleting its battery charge on the last leg of the trip.

title: Organic Dry Cleaners Can Serve as Barometer of Gentrification
description: At the base of Crescent Street in Long Island City, Queens, you will hear the hum of traffic heading to and from the Queensboro Bridge and the rattle of subway cars hustling over elevated tracks, the same rumblings heard in that spot 20, 40 or 60 years ago. But if you look around, you will see signs of a neighborhood changed.

title: Film Editors Go With Argo, Too
description: In addition to the Writers Guild Awards, another closely watched guild ceremony took place this weekend, for the American Cinema Editors Eddies. Argo won in the dramatic category, and Silver Linings Playbook in the comedy category.

title: The Oldest No. 1, and the Newest Rivalry
description: As Victoria Azarenka beat Serena Williams, it looked from afar as if Azarenkas shots down the stretch were more accurate than her celebration.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 18
Savory Winter Pies
description: This week I slowed down and made pies: savory ones filled with vegetables. I was just back from the annual Worlds of Healthy Flavors invitational conference that the Culinary Institute of America and Harvard School of Public Health organize for the food service industry and was eager to get back to cooking the kinds of foods that the conference organizers are trying to help the food industry focus on. An entire general session was devoted to increasing menu emphasis on produce, with presentations by marketing specialists, nutritionists and, of course, chefs. This theme resonated throughout the three-day conference: if restaurant chains devoted more of their menu space to produce they could eliminate or reduce some of the less-than-healthy fare they are known for.

title: Walkabout  2/18: The costs of airlines merging and a perk for turning 40
description: When Two Become One While executives of American Airlines and US Airways argue that the two companies merger will benefit customers by offering more destinations, some economists and consumer advocates say it will come at a cost. (The New York Times)

title: Bucking a Trend, Supreme Court Justices Reject Video Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Sonia Sotomayor, populist, revealed a paternalistic streak this month, announcing that she had rethought her enthusiasm for video coverage of Supreme Court arguments.

title: Daniel Day-Lewis, Magazine Editor
description: For one of cinemas most reclusive talents, Daniel Day-Lewis has certainly been making the rounds. Now, ahead of the Oscars, the stylish mens quarterly Port Magazine tells T that the actor is guest-editing its film issue, which hits newsstands on March 14. Having Daniel share his friendships with me has been a humbling experience which sometimes left me speechless. On occasion, such as a lunch interview with Ray Winstone, which turned into a two day party, I was left legless, says Ports editor, Dan Crowe. The fact that he was able to do this during the awards season and all the work he had on with Lincoln is incredible. Port and Day-Lewis even convinced Winstone, the lovable Cockney rogue, to introduce the issue in the following video clip.

title: War and Peace to Get BBC Miniseries Treatment
description: For anyone who cannot get enough of War and Peace, the BBC on Monday announced that its latest drama project is an adaptation of this Tolstoy classic. The long novel will become a long series: six hourlong episodes scheduled to be broadcast on BBC One in 2015.

title: Drug Makers, in Shift, Join Fight Against Doping
description: The blood-enhancing drug EPO has improved the lives of millions of anemia patients, but Lance Armstrong and other top cyclists have turned the medicine into a byword for doping.

title: Goat Cheese, Chard and Herb Pie in a Phyllo Crust
description: Instead of making a top crust for this phyllo pie I take the overhanging layers of phyllo and scrunch them around the rim to make a nice crisp border for the pie. I didnt want to put on a top layer of phyllo because the filling is quite liquid before it bakes and sets up, and I was afraid that the phyllo would become too soggy.

title: Twins Dont Need C-Sections
description: Obstetricians increasingly recommend planned Caesarean sections for women having twins, but a new study has found that a C-section for healthy twins usually provides no advantage over vaginal delivery.

title: The Intersection of Coffee and Cocktails in Long Island City
description: The coffee and cocktail contingents of Long Island City are joining forces.

title: Vitamin Labels May Be Wrong
description: The amounts of vitamin D present in supplements sold over the counter often bear little resemblance to the descriptions on the bottle labels, a new study concludes.

title: Readers Digest Files for Bankruptcy, Again
description: Executives at Readers Digest must be hoping that the magazines second trip to bankruptcy court in under four years will be its last.

title: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
description: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

title: Young Drinkers Prefer Beer
description: While it has long been clear that many adolescents drink alcohol, despite its illegality, experts have never been certain what they are drinking. Now a nationwide survey finds that the favorite alcoholic beverage of underage drinkers is beer, and their favorite beer is Budweiser.

title: Christies Raises Its Commissions
description: 5:54 p.m. | Updated Its about to get more expensive to shop at Christies. On Friday the auction house sent an e-mail to its clients announcing that it was increasing its so-called buyers premium  the fee it charges buyers  for the first time since 2008.

title: When to Retire a Running Shoe
description: Ryan Hall, one of the worlds best distance runners, used to pride himself on wearing his running shoes into nubs. No more. Now he assiduously replaces his shoes after running about 200 miles in them. He goes through two pairs a month.

title: The Daily Do | Matthew Williamson
description: Matthew Williamsons English roses (naturally) felt authentically undone in easy, disheveled braids with haphazard bobby pins, to keep flyaways from their faces.

title: Finding Answers, or More Mystery, Through DNA Sequencing
description: As genetic sequencing becomes cheaper and more accessible, more families are using it to try to determine the cause of rare disorders. With it comes hope of answers and a small chance of treatment.

title: DNA Test for Rare Disorders Becomes More Routine
description: Debra Sukin and her husband were determined to take no chances with her second pregnancy. Their first child, Jacob, who had a serious genetic disorder, did not babble when he was a year old and had severe developmental delays. So the second time around, Ms. Sukin had what was then the most advanced prenatal testing.

title: Rattlestick Adds Buyer & Cellar, With Michael Urie, To Its Season
description: Michael Urie, who has become something of a New York stage regular (Angels in America, The Cherry Orchard) since the conclusion of the TV series Ugly Betty (not to mention the quick cancellation of his recent Partners), will be back this spring in a new play by Jonathan Tolins (The Twilight of the Golds, Secrets of the Trade).

title: The Myth of Reagans Miracle
description: Ramesh Ponnuru has a rather sad piece in todays Times, urging Republicans to revitalize themselves by emulating Reagans spirit rather than his specifics. Actually, its sad on two fronts.

title: Republican Senator From Nebraska Wont Run in 2014
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mike Johanns, a Nebraska Republican who is in his first term, announced on Monday that he would not seek re-election next year, the fifth lawmaker to bow out of a Senate that has become increasingly polarized and dysfunctional.

title: Kleybanova Plots Return After Two-Year Cancer Fight
description: Alisa Kleybanova of Russia, a former top-20 player who has won two WTA singles titles, plans to return to competition by the middle of this season, a considerable accomplishment for an athlete who has been fighting cancer for the past two years.

title: Taking on Mystery Diseases, Sociology of Prison Time
description: How genetics changing the fight against childhood diseases and how social science is changing the way we think about crime and punishment.

title: Now Showing | London Designers to Watch
description: London has long been known for its embrace of young, emerging designers. So in 2000, Lulu Kennedy founded Fashion East, a nonprofit that helps fledgling British talent find their wings by covering everything from production to a show during London Fashion Week. Today, these three artists to watch sent Fashion East-sponsored collections down the runway at the Tate Modern.

title: Burberry Prorsum: Fall 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Winter Wakefulness
description: Q. How do stink bugs remain alert indoors through the winter while apparently doing without food or liquid?

title: Talking Talent | Niia
description: If you have not heard of Niia, the jazz trained pianist and vocalist, you will very soon. Her first single, Made for You, made its debut last week on the Faders Web site and is available now on iTunes. Tony Kaye, of American History X fame, directed the rather dark Made for You video, complete with silicone life-size sex dolls. The 25-year-old musician, who has toured with Wyclef Jean and has garnered a cult following for underground James Bond-themed musical performances, has a voice that was born to sing torch songs.

title: Really? Probiotic Supplements Can Lower Cholesterol
description: THE FACTS

title: Criticisms of a Classic Abound
description: When the proposal for a book about the plight of the American housewife by a little-known journalist named Betty Friedan began circulating at the publishing house W. W. Norton in early 1959, not everyone was convinced that it was a world-changing blockbuster.

title: Office Space, by the Hour
description: Seasoned business travelers are used to booking a place to sleep. But a couch in the lobby?

title: Iberia Airline Workers Protest Job Cuts and Disrupt Madrid Airport
description: Striking ground workers and flight attendants for Iberia, the money-losing Spanish airline, clashed with riot police officers at Madrid-Barajas Airport on Monday, the first day of work stoppages to protest a plan to eliminate more than 3,800 jobs.

title: Critics of Executive Pay Put Pressure on Novartis
description: LONDON  A plan by Novartis, one of Switzerlands biggest drug makers, to pay its departing chairman $78 million to keep him from sharing his knowledge with competitors has added fuel to an already heated debate about executive pay.

title: Murphy to Miss Time With Midsection Discomfort
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets first injury concern of the year was revealed after the teams first full squad workout of spring training Monday afternoon.

title: Draghi Seeks to Ease Talk of Global Currency War
description: BRUSSELS  The president of the European Central Bank sought on Monday to ease fears that countries including Japan were deliberately weakening their currencies.

title: Luongo on Luongo (on Twitter)
description: The mystery started mysteriously enough last offseason: a hilarious Twitter account by the name @strombone1. The profile picture is an outline of a hockey goalie with a ? in place of the number. And its posts were all about Vancouver goalie Roberto Luongo, often poking fun at the drama around whether he would be traded after the Canucks demoted him to backup.

title: Chrysler to Offer Diesel in 2014 Ram 1500 Pickup
Photo Replay: February 18
description: The day in sports includes a tough day for the American tennis player Sloane Stephens, spring training stretches and Indian children playing through a fog.

title: A Moles Nose Knows, With Stereo Sniffing
description: Humans and many other mammals see and hear in stereo. But what about smell?

title: Model Diary | Maria Bradley
description: Maria Bradley  the part-time Brooklynite who walked in last Thursdays Marc Jacobs show, the luminous finale to New York Fashion Week  kicks off the London series of Model Diary for T. With two years of modeling under her belt, the 18-year-old from Wichita, Kansas, walked in the Giles show today.

title: Picassos Masterpieces Made With House Paint
description: Scientists using a high-energy X-ray instrument say they have solved the long-running debate over what kind of paint Picasso used in his masterpieces.

title: Pro-Gun Lawmakers Are Open to Limits on Size of Magazines
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Christopher S. Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, is haunted by many things that emerged from the investigation of the December mass shooting at a Newtown elementary school. Among them is the nagging question of what prompted the gunman, Adam Lanza, to put down his rifle after killing 20 children and pick up the pistol he used to end his own life.

title: The 2014 SS: Chevrolet Answers a Question, but Was Anybody Asking?
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Blame booming Chevrolet, which has more new vehicles to introduce than it knows what to do with, that the all new 2014 Chevrolet SS rear-drive performance sedan was introduced to the public and the media in the infield of Daytona International Speedway hours before the Nascar version of the SS was to debut on track in the first race of the season, a preliminary to the Daytona 500.

title: Dangers of Too Much Calcium
description: Calcium is an important nutrient for bone health, but new research suggests that older women who take large amounts may be at increased risk of heart disease and death.

title: In Europe, Mounting Debt May Push Companies to Public Markets
description: LONDON  The steady revival in European stocks is offering hope to the regions highly indebted companies seeking to raise money on the public markets.

title: Light Bulbs and Luminaries: Star Turns Onstage
description: They may have dug up the bones of Richard III, but the original performance of the play that made him famous will always remain something of a mystery.

title: Top Enforcement Officer of N.C.A.A. Is Ousted
description: In recent months, the N.C.A.A. has faced mounting criticism and broad challenges to its authority, with concerns raised about how it has conducted high-profile investigations.

title: Paul McCarthys Take On Snow White Among Armorys New Season Highlights
description: A phantasmagorical Snow White forest, a play about Garry Kasparov and Deep Blue and an electronic music opus staged in an idealized lunar landscape (the audience will slip on white robes) are a few of the highlights announced Monday by the Park Avenue Armory for its 2013 season.

title: Russian Legislators Body Is Found in a Barrel Filled With Concrete
description: MOSCOW  The body of a missing city legislator and construction tycoon was found in a private basement garage on the citys outskirts, inside a rusted metal barrel filled with concrete, the police said Monday.

title: Kings Case for Hall of Fame Still a Good One
description: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on the Times sports blogs.

title: An Anthropologists War Stories
description: What were our early ancestors really like as they accomplished the transition from hunter-gathering bands to more complex settled societies? The anthropologist Napoleon A. Chagnon may have come closest to the answer in his 35-year study of a remarkable population, the Yanomam of Venezuela and Brazil.

title: WWS 594E, The Economics of the Welfare State: Class 2
description: Health care slides (pdf).

title: Affording Addiction Help (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Video Game Vigilance (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising and Children (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Albums by Portal and Iceage
description: PORTAL

title: Goldbugs, Greece, and Affinity Fraud
description: Joe Weisenthal tries to understand why Barrons, which he describes as a quiet financial newspaper, has a hysterical cover story about Obama turning America into Greece, Greece I tell you. So you might want to note that theyve done this before. I dont regularly read Barrons or even notice what theyre saying, but I did note their frantic calls for a rise in interest rates back in October 2009, thats right, 2009  because inflation! confidence!

title: The Average American Knows How Many People?
description: The average American knows about 600 people. How do we know this? Researchers led by my Columbia colleague Tian Zheng posed a series of questions to a representative sample of 1,500 Americans: How many people do you know named Kevin? How many named Karen? How many named Shawn or Sean, Brenda, Keith or Rachel?

title: A Citywide Retrospective for the Poet and Playwright Sekou Sundiata
description: Sekou Sundiata, the poet, playwright, performer and educator who died in 2007 after a career featuring his signature themes of race, power and identity, will be the subject of a seven-month citywide retrospective, set to begin in April.

title: Susan Loves Illness Gives New Focus to Her Cause
description: During a talk last spring in San Francisco, Dr. Susan Love, the well-known breast cancer book author and patient advocate, chided the research establishment for ignoring the needs of people with cancer. The only difference between a researcher and a patient is a diagnosis, she told the crowd. Were all patients.

title: Science in Film and the Search for Weird Life
description: THEATER

title: Pattern Recognition | New Blue and White
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Uproar Over Netanyahus Ice Cream Is Welcome in One Parlor
description: JERUSALEM  His foreign minister had to resign after being accused of fraud. He was sharply criticized for his governments handling of Prisoner X, who committed suicide in prison. And now this, which made front-page news in Israel over the weekend: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stands accused of dipping into state coffers for an ice cream budget of $2,700 a year.

title: Stung by Argo, Iran Backs Conference Denouncing Hollywoodism
description: TEHRAN  As the trailer for Argo, an Oscar contender and a thorn in the side of the Iranian government, played in a conference room in a hotel here this month, Mehdi Tondro shook his head in disapproval.

title: Recent Developments in Health and Science News
description: It was a momentous week for asteroids  one that struck Earth, and one that didnt.

title: French Cite Recession in Delaying Budget Goal
description: PARIS  Citing a Europe-wide recession, Frances Socialist government is moving away from its promise to bring its budget deficit down to 3 percent of gross domestic product this year, arguing that the recession creates an exceptional circumstance requiring less austerity.

title: The Daily Shoe | Christopher Kane
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Prison and the Poverty Trap
description: WASHINGTON  Why are so many American families trapped in poverty? Of all the explanations offered by Washingtons politicians and economists, one seems particularly obvious in the low-income neighborhoods near the Capitol: because there are so many parents like Carl Harris and Charlene Hamilton.

title: J.W. Anderson: Fall 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Office Depot and OfficeMax Are Said to Be Discussing a Merger
description: Two of the big names in office supplies are hoping that a merger can make the business of selling staplers and toner more profitable.

title: Obama Could Revisit Arming Syria Rebels as Assad Holds Firm
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama rebuffed four of his top national security officials who wanted to arm the rebels in Syria last fall, he put an end to a months of debate over how aggressively Washington should respond to the strife there that has now left nearly 70,000 dead.

title: New Polio Strains That Protect Vaccine Factory Workers
description: Scientists have created new strains of polio intended to protect workers in factories that make polio vaccine. The new strains have the same ability to invoke an immune reaction as the live viruses now used to make vaccine do, but there is virtually no risk anyone will get polio if one of the new strains somehow escapes.

title: Committed to an Old Sound and Riffing on the Past
description: Endless Boogie isnt exactly a jam band. Its even less charismatic than that: a rehearsal band, maybe. Its music can sound like private catalogings of very specific taste. Its set on Friday at Cameo Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn  like the groups entire project  took the shape of consistently repetitive, one-chord riff-rock: it descended from music recorded between 1968 and 1974, more or less. Sometimes a chorus expanded a song to blues form, but that was about it for chord changes.

title: A Grab Bag of Sound
description: When the Finnish conductor Sakari Oramo led the New York Philharmonic for the first time in 2004, Anthony Tommasini ended a rave review in The New York Times by looking toward the future.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Q. and A. With Karlie Kloss
description: At just 20 years old, the model Karlie Kloss is already an industry veteran and remains one of the most in-demand models on the show circuit. T caught up with the Midwestern beauty backstage at Burberry Prorsum to talk about her new short do and makeup essentials.

title: Diners, Seedy Motels and TV Industry In-Jokes
description: Cult, a new series on CW, is about the mysterious circumstances surrounding a fictional television show  also called Cult, and also on CW. Sometimes when the characters in the real show are watching the fictional show, two CW logos appear on the screen at the same time. The scariest thing about this mildly ominous thriller may be the shameless heights to which it takes network self-promotion.

title: From Victor Hugo and Maybe a Batman Villain
description: Victor Hugos 1869 novel, The Man Who Laughs, has been adapted several times for the screen, notably in 1928 by the German Expressionist Paul Leni, with Conrad Veidt (The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari) in the title role. Lenis film, made in Hollywood, qualifies as swashbuckler, romance and horror movie.

title: A Network and Its Modern, Manly Goals
description: You can imagine the excitement among modern men when the announcement came last week that finally, more than 65 years into the television age, we are about to get a TV network intended just for us. So surprising was this news that we had not even prepared a suitable celebratory gesture. Chest bump? Too Neanderthalic. Forearm bash? Too steroidal. High five? Too unsophisticated. Fist bump? Too passive aggressive.

title: Exploring Gun Violence in Wake of Sandy Hook
description: The national PBS schedule is a placid thing, sketched out well in advance and usually subject to only minor tweaking. So the weeklong programming effort titled After Newtown, arriving two months after the mass killings at the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., represents a major effort in high-metabolism reporting and producing for a network accustomed to moving at a more deliberate pace.

title: Looking Back at a Domestic Cri de Coeur
description: On my first day of work at The New York Times, a young reporter spied me in the newsroom and rushed up to say hello. Hey! she said. Its another one of us! We were both in our 20s at a time when young women at The Times were a novelty, and that big smile from Anna Quindlen was an amazingly generous icebreaker. That was that: friends for life.

title: A Surreal Fish Tank With a Frogman, a Masochist and Bing Crosby
description: LONDON  The curtain rises on a spare white room framed on three sides by large glass windows. Behind one is a feverish jungle of foliage, behind another is a lone cactus on sand, and a third is filled by a fish tank. Into this spare whiteness steps Mechthild Grossmann, in a long, cream-colored dress.

title: Acoustic or Electric, Sounds That Call for Jumping Up and Down
description: There is a direct line of descent from Woody Guthrie through Bruce Springsteen to Tom Morello, the guitarist for Rage Against the Machine, whose alter ego, the Nightwatchman, is a militant left-wing acoustic folkie.

title: Industries Targeted by the Hackers
description: A new study by Mandiant, an American computer security firm, identified more than 140 organizations that have been compromised over the past six years by a single hacking group, called Comment Crew' or Shanghai Group.' Mandiant has assembled a circumstantial case that links Comment Crew to Unit 61398 of the Peoples Liberation Army.

title: Steuart Pittman, Head of Fallout Shelter Program, Dies at 93
description: Steuart Pittman, a Washington lawyer who was appointed by President John F. Kennedy in 1961 to create enough fallout shelters to protect every American in the event of a nuclear attack, and who resigned in frustration three years later amid heated debates over the feasibility, the cost and even the ethics of such a program, died on Feb. 10 at his family farm in Davidsonville, Md. He was 93. The apparent cause was a stroke, said his wife, Barbara.

title: Senators Rally to Topple Devils in Shootout
description: NEWARK  Games and seasons that can be decided by penalty-shot contests still rankle old-school N.H.L. fans eight years after they were introduced. But the shootout is a fact of life as the Devils found again Monday in a 2-1 loss to the Ottawa Senators at Prudential Center.

title: The State of the Block Response
description: Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his 12th and final State of the City address last week, which turned into a celebration of sorts of his three terms as mayor of New York. Because such speeches are, by nature, broadly cast, City Room reached out to readers for a more granular assessment, asking, Whats the state of your block?

title: Amazon Cuts Links to Company Facing Furor Over Security
description: BERLIN  The online retailer Amazon on Monday severed all contact with the security company whose guards are alleged to have worn clothing associated with neo-Nazis and intimidated immigrant temporary workers.

title: Morgan Stanley Strives to Coordinate 2 Departments Often at Odds
description: Several hundred Morgan Stanley retail branch managers descended on the JW Marriott Orlando Grande Lakes resort in Florida early this month for a retreat. They were greeted by an unlikely colleague, Colm Kelleher, who runs the companys sales and trading and investment banking departments.

title: Iran: Death Sentences for Fraud
description: An Iranian court on Monday confirmed the death sentences for four people convicted of participating in a $2.6 billion embezzlement scheme, the biggest fraud in Irans history. The four bankers and businessmen, including Mahafarid Amirkhosravi, the chief executive of the Arya Investment Group, were convicted of disturbing the countrys economic system through collusion and corruption in the banking network. They cannot appeal the courts decision. Twenty-five other people, including two government officials, have been sentenced to long prison terms and large fines, the spokesman of Irans judiciary announced Monday.

title: Israel: Obama to Receive Award
description: President Shimon Peres plans to give President Obama a special award at a state dinner next month when Mr. Obama is expected to visit Israel. Mr. Obama would be the first sitting American president to receive the award, Israels Presidential Medal of Distinction. Previous recipients include Henry A. Kissinger and the conductor Zubin Mehta. Barack Obama is a true friend of the State of Israel, and has been since the beginning of his public life, Mr. Peres said in a statement.

title: The Daily Do | Tom Ford
description: As slick as his trademark aesthetic, the hair at Tom Ford sinuously twisted once and tucked under itself so discreetly that it was like a disappearing act.

title: For His Second Act, Japanese Premier Plays It Safe, With Early Results
description: TOKYO  Since taking office less than two months ago, Japans outspokenly hawkish new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, has been in what some political analysts are calling safe driving mode. He has carefully avoided saying or doing anything to provoke other Asian nations, while focusing instead on wooing voters with steps to revive the moribund domestic economy.

title: Some Major Colleges Fear Looser N.C.A.A. Recruiting Rules
description: Greg McGarity, the University of Georgia athletic director, gathered the coaches from various teams in his office one morning several weeks ago to discuss the pending deregulation of recruiting in college athletics.

title: Is There Room for Varied Approaches to Energy and Climate Progress?
description: [12:33 p.m. | Update | Just in case you missed it,David Roberts criticism of this post is here and heresmy initial reply(Im on the run).]

title: Fuel Surcharges Push Up International Airfares
description: IN the first week of January, I was talking about fluctuations in fares for trans-Atlantic travel with Orit Keren, the president of OKT Travel, and Aik-Meng Tan, the vice president for sales.

title: W. Watts Biggers, Creator of Underdog Cartoon, Dies at 85
description: W. Watts Biggers, who with a partner created the 1960s cartoon Underdog as a way to sell cereal and wrote its infectious theme song, died on Feb. 10 at his home in Manomet, Mass. He was 85.

title: Burberry: Merchandised Sin
description: Christopher Bailey doesnt seem to have confidence that a woman can look sexy in an ordinary trench coat and a pair of kitten heels, though at one time in his career at Burberry he did. On Monday he opened his fall show with a translucent rubber pencil skirt and rubber bits on the famous trench. There were also animal-print trenches and secretarial skirts with tucked-in sweaters, all with low, wedge heels. Even if you didnt see the Christine Keeler reference on the press notes, you would have recognized the plain feminine shapes from early 1960s British films. The hair in the show was straight and natural looking, another reference to the era.

title: Nascar Drivers Speak Up, Aiming to Attract New Fans
description: NASCAR had come a long way from the days when it was dismissed as Southerners driving around in circles turning left. There was rising attendance at tracks, increasing television ratings for races and growing demand from marketers to be sponsors.

title: Yemen, Hailed as Model, Struggles for Stability
description: SANA, Yemen  The tents at the heart of this citys Change Square are now almost empty of protesters, and the canvas flaps quietly in the breeze. Two years after the start of its democratic uprising, Yemen has a new president and is in the midst of a lumbering transition process that has been held up by the Obama administration as a model for resolving Syrias bloody civil war.

title: Strangers on a Flight, Just Taking a Fling
description: I GREW up in a small town, just northeast of Scranton, Pa. In the past 20 or so years, Ive worked in buildings that had more people in them than my hometown. To say I dont like business travel would be a lie. Its a rush to fly someplace, and stay in a decent hotel. Im like a child about it.

title: Like the Ohio River, a Bridge Project Divides a Community
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Long ago, the Ohio River helped make this Rust Belt city a national pacesetter in manufacturing and transportation, providing it with an identity and an anchor. But as American life shifted toward the automobile, the river also became an impediment.

title: Unabated Violence Poses Challenge to Mexicos New Anticrime Program
description: MEXICO CITY  The new Mexican president, Enrique Pea Nieto, campaigned on a promise to reduce the violence spawned by the drug trade and organized crime, and to shift the talk about his nation away from cartels and killings.

title: No Country for Old Age
description: AMERICANS who fret about the wave of baby-boomer retirements should consider this: Since 2009, when China enacted a nationwide program of rural pensions, some 325 million Chinese have been promised retirement benefits. Thats more than the entire population of the United States.

title: Italy Votes on Its Future
description: Silvio Berlusconi, who resigned as Italys prime minister 15 months ago, is staging an appalling comeback. With less than a week to go before national elections this weekend, polls show that Mr. Berlusconis coalition has surged into second place, trailing the center-left coalition by single digits.

title: Finding Out Who Pays Your Doctor
description: The Obama administration issued a new rule this month that requires the makers of prescription drugs and other medical products to disclose what they pay doctors for various purposes, like consulting or speaking on behalf of the manufacturer. This overdue rule adds much-needed weight to previous, more limited disclosure requirements.

title: Unjust Mandatory Minimums
description: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. recently said that his top priority is to improve the criminal justice system. He can start by pushing Congress and the United States Sentencing Commission to fix the unfair problem of excessive mandatory minimum sentences.

title: Democrats Man for Battles Will Lead New Senate Charge
description: WASHINGTON  After two grueling election cycles, Guy Cecil, the brains behind the Democrats improbable Senate showings in 2010 and 2012, was expected to set aside his political combat boots for tasseled loafers and a sinecure somewhere in this city that pays handsomely for success.

title: Jeter Is Back on the Field and Keeping the Faith
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: The Popes Muffled Voice
description: There were reports over the weekend that cardinals might tweak the rules and begin the conclave to choose Pope Benedict XVIs successor sooner than March 15, which had been the earliest date mentioned. That would be a blessing. Already in the American news media its all pope all the time, a tsunami of papal coverage, and until a new pope is named, the tide wont quit. Youd be forgiven for concluding that hell actually have significant sway over Catholics in this country.

title: How Head Start Helps Children Get Ready for School
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Green Is Good for the Economy
Dealing With North Korea: What the History Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran: Rivals Forced to Apologize to Supreme Leader
description: Rival politicians apologized to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei over the weekend for having been embroiled in an unusually public feud involving secret tapes and a tit-for-tat impeachment. On Sunday, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad; the Parliament speaker, Ali Larijani; his brother, Sadegh Larijani; the chief of Irans judiciary; and all members of Parliament sent letters expressing sorrow and promising renewed allegiance to Ayatollah Khamenei, the supreme leader of Iran. The written apologies, reported by the state-run press, came a day after the ayatollah criticized both Mr. Ahmadinejad and the Larijanis for letting their own mutual animosity become public, raising speculation of irreparable rifts. The ayatollah had said in a speech that the whole matter made me feel sad.

title: What Data Cant Do
description: Not long ago, I was at a dinner with the chief executive of a large bank. He had just had to decide whether to pull out of Italy, given the weak economy and the prospect of a future euro crisis.

title: Body Found on a Beach Was Tied Up
description: The body of a woman that washed up on a beach in Breezy Point, Queens, had been bound by green rope at the hands and the feet, the police said on Monday.

title: Leak in Fuel Line Was Cause of Stricken Cruise Ships Trouble
description: A United States Coast Guard official said Monday that the fire that disabled the Carnival Triumph cruise ship began when a fuel line connected to one of the vessels engines sprang a leak.

title: Drones for America!
description: When I began thinking of this animated Op-Docs video, I had two things in mind. The first was the adoption of drones by the Seattle Police Department. (The program has since been scuttled.) The second was Yevgeny Zamyatins 1924 novel We, which was a forerunner to dystopian novels including George Orwells 1984, Aldous Huxleys Brave New World and Kurt Vonneguts Player Piano.

title: Drones for America!
description: In this animated satire, a former K.G.B. agent welcomes a future in which Americans live under the watchful eyes of drones.

title: Tracking Cyberattacks
description: David E. Sanger talks with Kevin Mandia, an Internet security expert, about new research linking cyberattacks against American companies to Chinas Peoples Liberation Army.

title: House Approves Storm Aid for Religious Institutions
description: WASHINGTON  The House of Representatives has overwhelmingly approved legislation that would allow the use of federal money to rebuild churches and synagogues damaged by Hurricane Sandy, despite concern that such aid could violate the doctrine of separation of church and state.

title: Seeking Direction in Yemen
description: Yemens transition has been held up as a model for resolving Syrias civil war, but beyond the capital, the country is more rudderless than ever.

title: Detective Work by the Books
description: Following is a selection of memos the New York Police Departments chief of detectives, part of an effort to standardize detective work and codify crime-solving tactics.

title: Behind the Injustices of Bail
description: To the Editor:

title: How Not to Fix Climate Change
description: After much back and forth, James E. Hansen and I had agreed on a date to meet. Hansen, the director of NASAs Goddard Institute for Space Studies, is the scientist most closely associated with climate change activists like Bill McKibben, who has led the charge against the Keystone XL pipeline, and Michael Brune, the executive director of the Sierra Club. In Hansens view, the country needs to start moving away from fossil fuels now, before the damage becomes irreversible.

title: Step-by-Step Instructions for Crime-Solving in the City
description: Detective work is measured in hunches followed, stories picked apart, doors knocked on and shoes worn through. Equal parts art and science, such tradecraft has long been passed down informally, one generation of investigators to the next.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Trouble With Online College
description: Stanford University ratcheted up interest in online education when a pair of celebrity professors attracted more than 150,000 students from around the world to a noncredit, open enrollment course on artificial intelligence. This development, though, says very little about what role online courses could have as part of standard college instruction. College administrators who dream of emulating this strategy for classes like freshman English would be irresponsible not to consider two serious issues.

title: Greco-Roman Wrestling Program May Be a Factory Without a Future
description: MARQUETTE, Mich.  When he heard the news last Tuesday, Barrett Stanghill retreated to his dormitory room on the third floor of Meyland Hall at Northern Michigan University and reconsidered his future. The executive board of the International Olympic Committee had voted to eliminate wrestling from the Summer Games, starting in 2020, and Stanghill found it almost impossible to process.

title: To Succeed, Housing Plan Must Navigate Fear and Criticism
description: New York City Housing Authority officials figured they had crafted an innovative way to dig out from under their chronic deficits.

title: Feminism's Next Act
A Reputation, Once Sullied, Acquires a New Shine
description: How do you describe Steven L. Rattner?

title: For Cano, Status and Pressure Are Rising
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Life is different for Robinson Cano these days. With Derek Jeter on the mend and Alex Rodriguez relegated to baseball purgatory for the foreseeable future, Cano has edged his way into one of the harshest spotlights in all of professional sports.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Feb. 19, 2013
description: I found one!

title: An Endorsement Hard to Pass Up, and Harder to Promote
description: Days before he died of congestive heart failure, former Mayor Edward I. Koch made an announcement in his hospital room: I want to help Chris Quinn.

title: Ban on Anchored Putts Becomes Personal Issue
description: LOS ANGELES  As the 90-day assessment period on the proposed ban on anchored putting winds down, the focus is shifting from the pragmatic to the personal.

title: Can Bronx Be a Destination? The Hope Is for Nights at a Time
description: Luxury touches like flat-screen televisions and hand towels twisted into swans await guests in each stately bedroom.

title: Looking Ahead to the 2014 Senate Races
description: The seats up for election next year, and the outlook for several key races.

title: Prosecutors, Shifting Strategy, Build New Wall Street Cases
description: Criticized for letting Wall Street off the hook after the financial crisis, the Justice Department is building a new model for prosecuting big banks.

title: Test Run: Mining Your Calendar to Cut Taxes
description: If youre like me, youll wait until a few days before taxes are due in April before filling out your returns. I can get away with procrastinating, in part, because I dont have to worry about some of the more tedious tax chores, like figuring out how many miles I drove last year in my personal vehicle for work purposes. Thats because my employer reimburses me for those expenses.

title: Corrections: February 19, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lamb Raiser
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  The title of todays post comes from the clue for 30 Down, which reminds me of one of the possible names tossed around for the BBC television show that eventually became Monty Pythons Flying Circus. For a brief moment, the show that deeply influenced my life was called The Toad Elevating Moment. You can elevate as many toads as you like, I believe, but if you raise a lamb, youre a EWE.

title: Chinese Army Unit Is Seen as Tied to Hacking Against U.S.
description: On the outskirts of Shanghai, in a run-down neighborhood dominated by a 12-story white office tower, sits a Peoples Liberation Army base for Chinas growing corps of cyberwarriors.

title: Little Red Beacon for Immigrant Laborers Shines On
description: The story of the Bay Parkway Community Job Center in Brooklyn can be charted in numbers.

title: Patrick Was Leading Way Even Before Winning Pole
description: On the first day that drivers arrived at Daytona International Speedway for Speedweeks, the Daytona 500 and the celebrated start of Nascars 2013 Sprint Cup season, the story making headlines was Danica Patricks romantic relationship with the driver Ricky Stenhouse, Jr.

title: From the Bronx, Planning a Long-Shot Run for Mayor
description: For Adolfo Carrin Jr., the magic number in the 2013 mayors race is not 40 (the percentage of primary votes needed to avoid a runoff), or $6.7 million (the maximum that candidates who receive public financing can spend).

title: Gym Class Isnt Just Fun and Games Anymore
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  On a recent afternoon, the third graders in Sharon Patelskys class reviewed words like acronym, clockwise and descending, as well as math concepts like greater than, less than and place values.

title: TV Anchor Accused of Choking His Wife
description: Rob Morrison, a news anchor for WCBS-TV, was arrested Sunday on charges of choking his wife during a domestic dispute at their Connecticut home, the police said on Monday.

title: The Owner Who Made the N.B.A. Cool Again
description: The enduring, clichd myth of the Los Angeles Lakers  perpetuated mostly by envious fans in other cities  is that the franchise owes its aura to its surroundings. That Hollywood made the Lakers cool, and the sunshine made them desirable. That the city made the dynasty.

title: Mindy McCready, a Singer Long Troubled, Dies at 37
description: Her life was one of those aching odysseys sermonized about across the musical landscape in which she performed. The rocket rise to stardom. The volcanic men. The depression. The drugs and booze. The brushes with the law. The heartbreak. The suicide attempts.

title: Nets Williams Acknowledges His Limits but Plans to Play
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A week after he had plasma therapy for his balky ankles, Nets point guard Deron Williams returned to practice Monday feeling a shade closer to his former self.

title: There Are Rings in Mets Future
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Before the Mets opened spring training this month, half a dozen of their players stopped playing the field.

title: Ford Turns to the Crowd for New Fiesta Ads
description: Four years ago, the Ford Motor Company brought out the Ford Fiesta subcompact with an innovative program that recruited young drivers  members of the target audience for the new car  to help introduce it through blogs and other social media. Now, that effort is being expanded into the realm of marketing as Ford plans a crowdsourcing initiative to create advertising for the 2014 Fiesta.

title: Word of the Day | exhilarating
description: exhilarating \ig-zi-l-ra-tiN\ adjective

title: Flyers Roll Over Islanders
description: The line of Claude Giroux, Matt Read and Jakub Voracek combined for 3 goals and 10 points, helping the Philadelphia Flyers break a slump with a 7-0 victory over the Islanders. Evgeni Nabokov made several key saves to keep the deficit at 1-0, but things got out of control in the game-turning second period. Philadelphia scored three times on only six second-period shots.

title: Kalyan Anand, the Sadhu From Madhya Pradesh
description: Why do millions of Indians, sometimes entire villages, brave the crowds to attend the Kumbh Mela? India Ink interviewed some of the estimated 100 million pilgrims who traveled to this years Kumbh Mela at Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, a 55-day pilgrimage during which Hindus take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins.

title: U.N. Report Shows Fewer Killings of Afghan Civilians, Suggesting Shift in War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For the first time in six years the number of civilians killed in Afghanistan declined, according to the annual United Nations report on civilian casualties.

title: Women Killed as Witches, in Papua New Guinea, in 2013
description: Theyre going to cook the sanguma, or witchcraft, mama!

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 10:40 P.M. (Starz) KILL BILL: VOL. 1 (2003) Uma Thurman, above, is the Bride in this film written and directed by Quentin Tarantino, and David Carradine is Bill, the man whose life she would like to bring to a premature end. Of course, that will have to wait until Vol. 2. First, she must battle two of his assassins (Lucy Liu and Vivica A. Fox) and a horde of masked samurai. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film, a densely referential pastiche of B-movie attitudes and situations, is above all an exercise in style. He added, But while being so relentlessly exposed to a filmmakers idiosyncratic turn-ons can be tedious and off-putting, the undeniable passion that drives Kill Bill is fascinating, even, strange to say it, endearing.

title: News Quiz | February 19, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Maoists Block Deal to Break Nepals Long Political Deadlock
description: NEW DELHI  Nepals major political parties failed on Tuesday to complete an expected agreement to settle a years-long political standoff, after Maoists insisted that the accord include amnesty for past crimes.

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 19
description: NEWS An overwhelming percentage of online attacks toward U.S. companies, organizations and government agencies originate from one area of a Shanghai neighborhood, home to a Chinese army unit, according to a report by the computer security firm Mandiant. David E. Sanger, David Barboza and Nicole Perlroth report.

title: Incumbent Wins Easy Victory in Armenia
description: President Serzh Sargsyan of Armenia easily won re-election to a second five-year term, according to preliminary returns released on Tuesday by the Central Election Commission.

title: In Affidavit at Bail Hearing, Track Star Denies He Intended to Kill Girlfriend
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  Early on Feb. 14, Oscar Pistorius says, he heard a strange noise coming from inside his bathroom, climbed out of bed, grabbed his 9-millimeter pistol, hobbled on his stumps to the door and fired four shots.

title: Orix of Japan in $2.6 Billion Deal for Rabobanks Asset Management Unit
description: HONG KONG  The Orix Corporation, a Japanese financial services company, said on Tuesday that it would pay 1.94 billion euros ($2.6 billion) to acquire the asset management business of the Dutch lender Rabobank.

title: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 19, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the television review Another Cog in the Machinery of Divahood.

title: Can Graffiti Ever Be Considered Art?
description: I dont know what art is, but. People have been finishing this sentence with I know what I like or I know it when I see it for a long, long time.

title: Motherhood, Reborn and Everlasting
description: Most human beings swoon at the first sight of a baby. No matter how homely  or loud  they elicit a primal response from pretty much everyone.

title: In Russia, Clues About the Type of Damage a Meteor Can Wreak
description: In In Russia, Ruins and Property Spared by Meteor, Side by Side, Andrew E. Kramer reports on the aftermath of the explosion that occurred in Siberia on Friday.

title: Nestl Removes  2 Products in Horse Meat Scandal
description: LONDON  First centered on Britain and Ireland, the scandal over beef products adulterated with horse meat escalated across Continental Europe on Tuesday after Nestl, one of the worlds best-known food companies, said it was removing pasta meals from store shelves in Italy and Spain.

title: BMW Recalls More Than 500,000 Cars for Cable Problem
description: An investigation by the Canadian automotive safety agency, Transport Canada, led BMW to recall almost 505,000 vehicles in the United States for a possible loss of electrical power that could cause the engine to stall.

title: Who Pays the Corporate Income Tax
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Q and A: Nina Hoss, at Home at the Berlinale
description: BERLIN  The German actress Nina Hoss has been a fixture at the Berlinale in recent years. She won the best actress prize in 2007 for Christian Petzolds Yella, served on the jury in 2011 and starred in one of the most acclaimed titles in last years competition, Barbara, also directed by Mr. Petzold (with whom she has made five movies in the past dozen years).

title: Novartis Scraps Non-Compete Payment to Departing Chairman
description: LONDON  Novartis, one of Switzerlands biggest drug makers, said Tuesday it scrapped a planned $78 million payment to its departing chairman because of pressure from shareholders and lawmakers.

title: Q&A: Controlling Access to a Kindle Fire HD
description: Q.

title: Simone Rocha: Fall 2013 RTW
description: London

title: This Week in Small Business: Dish Mobs
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Britain Names Head of New Bank Regulator
description: LONDON  Andrew Bailey was appointed on Tuesday as head of a new British regulator in charge of overseeing the countrys largest banks.

title: European Parliament Approves Plan to Bolster Carbon Trading
description: LONDON  Lawmakers in Brussels moved on Tuesday to shore up the sagging market for carbon emissions permits, a central component of the European Unions efforts to reduce air pollution.

title: Office Supply Retailers Weigh a Merger
description: Two of the big retailers of office supplies, Office Depot and OfficeMax, are hoping that a merger can help protect profitability in the age of the Internet and bulk discounters. The companies are in talks to combine in an all-stock deal that may be announced as soon as this week, a person briefed on the matter said on Monday, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced reports. The talks, while at an advanced stage, may still fall apart, this person cautioned.

title: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: In Transit
description: Most great cities in the world are marked by their spirit of dynamism. New York and Mumbai, often counted among the worlds fastest cities, are no different. Both these cities are in a constant state of flux, always moving, always in transit.

title: Opinion Report: Mandatory Minimums
description: From the editorial page

title: A Recipe for Pone
description: Dear Diary:

title: Celebrating Your Big Sober Gay Birthday
description: Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: More Season 3 Conversation With Downton Abbey Creator Julian Fellowes
description: In the first installment of an interview with the Downton Abbey creator and writer Julian Fellowes, he discussed how some key departures from the series occurred in Season 3, and how he is starting to think about his own exit from the show.

title: A Strategy to Prevent the Next Fukushima
description: Among the most striking elements of the catastrophe at Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactors in Japan were the hydrogen explosions that destroyed the upper parts of some of the reactor buildings. The hydrogen was released by a metal called zirconium in the overheated core.

title: Deconstructing Herod
description: JERUSALEM  King Herod killed many people in his time, among them wives, sons and, according to the New Testament, all the male newborns of Bethlehem. He had more victims beyond the grave: In 2010, the archaeologist Ehud Netzer died from a fall at Herodium, Herods magnificent desert palace, after spending his life studying the king and searching for his tomb.

title: Marco Rubio: The Electable Conservative?
description: Some commentators have expressed surprise upon learning about the very conservative voting record of Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who delivered the Republican response to the State of the Union address last week.

title: Photos of The Moment | Erdem
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Other Quality of Mercy
description: Istanbul  The quality of mercy, famously, is not strained. Yet it can be confused. At least thats my conclusion after a recent instance of Turkish officialdom trying to show compassion.

title: A Conversation With: Journalist and Author Rahul Pandita
description: Rahul Pandita, an associate editor with the Open magazine in Delhi, is a journalist and author who belongs to the Kashmiri Pandit community, Hindus who had to flee the Kashmir Valley in the early 1990s during a separatist insurgency by the Muslim majority.

title: Swift Diving in Bali
description: C. Drew Harvell is associate director for environment at the Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future at Cornell University. She is studying the health of coral reefs and marine ecosystems in Indonesia, and is helping to plan a new project, Capturing Coral Reef Ecosystem Services. This is her final post.

title: Tom Ford in High-Definition
description: Before Tom Ford jumped on a plane to Los Angeles early on Tuesday morning, I asked him to explain his fall collection. People hurried from Lancaster House in a complete state of puzzlement, if not panic that they would miss J.W. Andersons show.

title: Accusations of Chinese Hacking in Cokes Failed Big Deal
description: A new report on Chinese hackers depicts a wide-ranging cyberwar campaign against an array of American targets, from computer security providers to power plant suppliers.

title: Tuesday Reading: When to Retire Your Running Shoes
Russias Meteor Shower
description: Russia is left reeling after a spectacular meteor shower.

title: Brazen Jewel Robbery at Brussels Airport Nets $50 Million in Diamonds
description: BRUSSELS  They arrived at Brussels Airport armed with automatic weapons and dressed in police uniforms aboard two vehicles equipped with blue police lights. But their most important weapon was information: the eight hooded gangsters who on Monday evening seized diamonds worth tens of millions of dollars from a passenger plane preparing to depart for Switzerland knew exactly when to strike  just 18 minutes before takeoff.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Nascar Tries to Expand Its Audience and Esquire Network Defines the Modern Man
description: Nascar has begun a new advertising push to attract young, urban and multicultural fans to augment their current audience of predominantly older, rural, white men, Stuart Elliott writes. Nascar hired Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, a sophisticated Madison Avenue giant, to handle a campaign that would include commercials in Spanish and emphasize online offerings like Nascar.com and the 2013 edition of Fantasy Nascar. The initiative will be formally introduced on Sunday during coverage of the Daytona 500 on Fox and will feature television commercials with drivers standing in dramatic poses making emotional statements for the camera.

title: The Gun Report: February 19, 2013
description: Someone asked in a comment posted Monday why the gun deaths by Slates gun-death tracker since Newtown  1,903 and counting  seemed to imply so many more deaths than our daily Gun Report. The answer is simple: We are not trying to be comprehensive. We are simply doing a Google search a few times a day and selecting a handful of representative examples of that days gun violence. Sadly, we have many more examples to choose from than what we publish.

title: Daily Report: Chinese Army Unit Is Tied to Hacking Against U.S.
description: A growing body of digital forensic evidence  confirmed by American intelligence officials who say they have tapped into the activity of the army unit for years  leaves little doubt that an overwhelming percentage of the attacks on American corporations, organizations and government agencies originate in and around the headquarters of the Peoples Liberation Army in Shanghai.

title: Europe Moves to Cap Bank Bonuses, Britain Hesitates
description: LONDON  It is hard to imagine any European politician losing votes these days by promising to curb bankers pay, which may explain why members of the European Parliament are enthusiastically pushing for the toughest restrictions on bank bonuses since the 2008 financial crisis.

title: For S.E.C., Obstacles Aplenty in Pursuit of Suspicious Heinz Trading
description: Just a day after the buyout of H.J. Heinz was announced, the Securities and Exchange Commission took aim at an account, claiming it was used to trade on inside information about the deal to reap potential profits of over $1.7 million.

title: Talk of a Big Merger Gives Office Suppliers Stocks a Lift
description: 9:51 a.m. | Updated

title: With Cutbacks Days Away, Obama Tries to Pressure G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  Days away from another fiscal crisis and with Congress on vacation, President Obama began marshaling the powers of the presidency on Tuesday to try to shame Republicans into a compromise that could avoid further self-inflicted job losses and damage to the fragile recovery. But so far, Republicans were declining to engage.

title: Data, Stimulus, and Human Nature
description: David Brooks writes about the limitations of Big Data, and makes some good points. But he goes astray, I think, when he touches on a subject near and dear to my own data-driven heart:

title: In Performance: Taylor Mac of Good Person of Szechwan
description: Bertolt Brechts Good Person of Szechwan asks what it means to live a virtuous life in a corrupt society. In the Foundry Theaters new production, the actor Taylor Mac takes on dual roles: Shen Te, a hospitable prostitute turned shopkeeper and, in disguise, Shui Ta, her more pragmatically minded male cousin. In this scene near the end Shen Te reveals that she has taken on both identities and asks: Why is suffering reserved for the good and why is so much wickedness rewarded? The show runs through Feb. 24 at the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa.

title: Hes Talking to You: Scorsese to Give Jefferson Lecture for National Endowment for the Humanities
description: Speak to Martin Scorsese for even a few minutes on one of his favorite subjects  movies; rock music; the best way for Robert De Niro to break down an door in Raging Bull  and you are likely to get an enthusiastic barrage of verbiage as rich and dense as any academic lecture. (With, perhaps, a few colorful words that your college film professor would never say.)

title: Rihanna Steals the Attention at London Fashion Week
description: 3:31 p.m. | Updated The big news this London Fashion Week was supposed to be the return of Tom Ford to the runway, the London debut of LWren Scott (complete with a dinner Sunday night at the Caf Royale co-hosted by her boyfriend, Mick Jagger), the buzz surrounding such rising stars as Christopher Kane and JW Anderson and the emergence of the young British model Cara Delevingne as the next Kate Moss.

title: Oscar Contenders Are a Hit at the Box Office
description: No matter who wins the most awards on Sunday, there are already a huge numbers of winners this year: producers, distributors and theater owners. The nine best picture contenders have, en masse, grossed $918 million at the box office, according to Gitesh Pandya of BoxOfficeGuru.com.(Vote for, share and keep track of your Oscar favorites with The Timess interactive awards ballot. Start Your Oscar Ballot)

title: A Meteorite Rush
description: In a small Siberian village, residents are finding that rock fragments that rained down after Fridays meteor over Russia have monetary worth.

title: Irish Government Apologizes in Laundry Scandal
description: DUBLIN  Prime Minister Enda Kenny offered an unreserved state apology on Tuesday over Irelands failure to protect thousands of young women and girls consigned to virtual slavery in the so-called Magdalene laundries between 1922 and 1996.

title: What Were Reading
description: USA Today: Following a media and consumer backlash to its recent announcement that it would decrease the alcohol content of its bourbon by 3 percent, Makers Mark reversed itself, saying it would leave well enough alone.  Robert Simonson

title: Meadham Kirchhoff: Fall 2013 RTW
description: London

title: Donald Richie, 88, American Expert on Japan, Is Dead
description: Donald Richie, a prominent American critic and writer on Japan who helped introduce much of the English-speaking world to the golden age of Japanese cinema in 1959 and recounted his expatriate life there spanning seven decades, died on Tuesday in Tokyo. He was 88.

title: Pakistani Shiites End Protest After Authorities Vow to Take On Extremists
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Shiites ended three days of protest across Pakistan on Tuesday after the government promised to hunt down sectarian extremists responsible for a devastating bombing that killed 89 people in the western city of Quetta on Saturday.

title: Australias Best Reds Are Slow to Arrive
description: Stereotypes are always troubling, and wine stereotypes are no different. I bristle when I hear some European winemaker assert that Americans make only big, powerful, alcoholic wines. Of course, many Americans say the same thing about Australian wines: the reds are all heavy-bodied and high-octane, overwhelming combinations of thick fruit flavors, oak and alcohol. Or, in their inexpensive, mass-market manifestations, they taste like artificial confections.

title: The Small Picture: Meet Pumbaa, One Lucky Pig
description: Last week, we asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the essence of their businesses in a single shot. The results have started to pour in, and the photographs are great  many with moving explanations of why the owners do what they do.

title: A True Hollywood Story
description: As the tributes flowed in from everywhere, the sports world stopped to honor a giant now gone. The death of the Lakers owner Jerry Buss Monday at age 80 brought out all the usual remembrances, which included the proper credit for creating the Lakers phenomenon out of almost nothing, for spawning much of what we recognize as the modern N.B.A. out of so much magic dust. The tales of the man behind all that, though, were so colorful and so unlikely, it is worth taking a second to realize that if Jerry Buss had not been real, Hollywood would have had to make him up.

title: NBC News Hires David Axelrod as Political Analyst
description: NBC News announced Tuesday that it had hired David Axelrod, the chief political strategist for both of Barack Obamas presidential elections, as a full-time political analyst for the news organization.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Erdem
description: It didnt take long for the designer Erdem Moralioglu and the makeup artist Hannah Murray to decide who their beauty muse was this season. Wednesday Addams was the name that instantly came up, Murray says. Its the first time Erdem hasnt done color, so we knew we had to do something that was spooky but still beautiful. To create the illusion of moonlit skin, Murray applied Nars new Radiant Creamy Concealer highlighted with Copacabana Multiple for a luminous finish. The look is meant to be a little eerie, so Ive made all the girls uniform  each one has the same strong, dark brow, she says. Using a technique that she likened to wiggling a mascara wand, Murray brushed Narss brow gel (available in August) through to make individual hairs stand out. Teamed with glassy, ironed-straight manes by the stylist Luke Hersheson, the effect was utterly bewitching.

title: In Performance: Taylor Mac
description: The actor performs a scene from the Foundry Theaters production of Bertolt Brechts Good Person of Szechwan.

title: Not Coming Soon to a Theater Near You
description: The Austrian Oscar nominee Christoph Waltz hosted Saturday Night Live over the weekend and the director who gave him his big break here, Quentin Tarantino, was not spared. The show included this preview for Djesus Uncrossed, the god(father) of all historical revenge fantasies.

title: Student Crossword | The Great Recession
description: The Great Recession, (which, according to Economix blogger Catherine Rampell, earned its title by being the greatest economic downturn since World War II) began in Dec., 2007 and officially ended in June of 2009  though since then we have been struggling through a not-so-great recovery.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Fix Medicare to Save It
description: To the Editor:

title: Always! Be! Learning! Academics Meets P.E. Class
description: The description of the class sounds like a little bit of Glengarry Glen Ross lunacy brought straight to the elementary school gym: students were instructed to count by fours as they touched their elbows to their knees during a warm-up.

title: Former Deutsche Bank Trader Describes Difficulties in Tokyos Rates Market
description: TOKYO  One particularly tough trading day in the summer of 2007, Eddy Takata, then a derivatives trader with Deutsche Bank in Tokyo, threw up his arms in frustration and shouted, Manipulation!

title: A Hockey Pioneers Moment
description: Larry Kwongs career with the Rangers lasted a New York minute, but his legacy lingers some 65 years after his debut ended in disappointment.

title: Photos of The Moment | Christopher Kane
