description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Obama Speaks on the Sequester
description: Speaking at the White House, President Obama talked about a series of automatic budget cuts set to take effect soon.

title: Four Are Dead After a String of Shootings in California
description: TUSTIN, Calif.  A 20-year-old part-time college student was responsible for an hourlong early-morning shooting and carjacking rampage in Orange County on Tuesday that left four dead, including the gunman, the police said.

title: For Corporate Boards, Lessons From JPMorgans Trading Disaster
description: Michael W. Peregrine, a partner at the law firm McDermott Will & Emery, advises corporations, officers and directors on issues related to corporate governance, fiduciary duties and internal investigations.

title: T Magazines New Editor Pledges to Make Future Issues More Diverse
description: The new T magazine made an impressive start on Sunday. Thick with ads, its editorial content  including a fascinating cover story on the 79-year-old socialite Lee Radziwill  was strong.

title: Can There Be a Catholic Moment?
description: My weekend column made the case that Catholicisms influence on American political culture went into steep decline across the eight years of Benedict XVIs pontificate, as the Republicans turned from the solidarity-inflected language of compassionate conservatism to the rhetoric of makers versus takers and the Democrats swung leftward on abortion and picked religious-liberty fights with Catholic institutions. The American Conservatives Rod Dreher agrees with me, but basically argues that it was inevitably going to be thus, because the patterns of American modernity make any hope a Catholic moment in our politics or culture essentially chimerical:

title: Britain Continues Trade Push in India With Cameron Visit
description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain arrived in India this week with the largest-ever British business delegation to the country, part of Britains continuing efforts to woo its former colony.

title: Does the House of Cards All-You-Can-Eat Buffet Spoil Social Viewing?
description: For many viewers, one of the pleasures of watching the favorite-of-the-moment TV series is gathering around the digital water cooler to hash out the plot points, quibble with the details (How could the truck not hear Matthew coming? Did they have mufflers in 1920?) or share the satisfaction when a character gets his comeuppance.

title: Army Rocket in Syria Kills at Least 19, Rebels Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian antigovernment activists said on Tuesday that an army rocket had leveled several buildings in a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo, killing at least 19 people and possibly leaving dozens more buried under rubble. The attack appeared to have caused one of the worst civilian tolls in the embattled city since its university was struck in a multiple bombing a month ago.

title: Israel Releases Part of Report on Prisoner Xs Death
description: JERUSALEM  The man known as Prisoner X was found dead at 8:19 p.m. on Dec. 15, 2010, hanging by his neck in the shower of his cell. The noose was fashioned from a wet bedsheet, rolled and tied to the window bars. There was a hint of a sedative in his stomach and a wound on his left hand, but neither contributed to his demise, which was caused by asphyxiation.

title: Threes a Trend | Patent
description: T spots the latest trends on the runway.  In London, patent appeared on dresses and skirts, giving ladylike looks a bit of a subversive twist.

title: New Prize for Yiddish Plays
description: The National Yiddish Theater-Folksbiene is announcing a new play contest toencourage writers and directors to conceive and develop new works in Yiddish. The winning play or musical will be showcased during the first New York International Festival of Jewish Performing Arts, in 2015 to commemorate the centennial of Folksbiene (Yiddish for peoples theater), the longest continuously running Yiddish theater in the world.

title: Ask Well: Coaxing Parents to Take Better Care of Themselves
description: Question:

title: Starter: Bocuse Formally Opens With Arrival of Its Namesake
description: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.All through the day and well into the night, it was totally Bocuse.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 19
In the Year of the Snake, Challenges for the Chinese Economy
description: China is back to work after a weeklong holiday to celebrate the Chinese New Year. Most business shut for the entire week and the scale of human migration was awesome. This year, the Chinese made 440 million trips during the lunar holiday.

title: Help Find Con Man With a Badge, and Play What Did He Say?
description: The police are looking for an apparently very persuasive man who showed a fake police badge to a Midtown subway traveler and got him to hand over his cellphone.

title: Readers Weigh In on Working Your Way Through College
description: My article in the Sunday Business section two weekends ago, about the challenge of working your way through college these days without taking on any student loan debt or receiving any help from your parents, served as a Rorschach test of sorts for readers.

title: 'The Feminine Mystique' 50 Years On
description: The Op-Ed columnist Gail Collins speaks with four women about whats left in the fight for gender equality.

title: My Mother Gives Me Parenting Advice From Nazis
description: My mother gives me parenting advice from Nazis. That is not a euphemism for overly strict, by-the-book experts who tell you if you dont give your baby the right toys, your child is going to be a juvenile delinquent. No, my mother gives me parenting advice from an actual member of the National Socialist Party  and were Jews.

title: Last Chance for Warren Lee Hill
description: Warren Lee Hill, an intellectually disabled inmate with an I.Q. of 70, is scheduled for execution today in Georgia at 7 p.m.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: American Greetings Corporation, Cleveland, chose Mullen, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as agency of record for creative duties, digital ads and media planning and buying. The account, with spending estimated at $3 million, had been handled by Element 79, Chicago, which its parent, the Omnicom Group, merged into another Omnicom agency, the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide. The media duties had been handled by an Omnicom media agency, PHD.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Competition

title: Louro
description: Inside the Greenwich Village restaurant where the chef treats meals as dinner parties.

title: Checking Out Some Shopping
description: Imagine checking into your hotel and finding a closet stocked with clothing that personal shoppers have chosen with you in mind. This service, which comes on the heels of other design-conscious hotels introducing personal shopping services, is a new feature at the St. Regis Bal Harbour Resort in Miami Beach, Fla. The clothing, selected by a shopping team at Neiman Marcus, is based on an online questionnaire that guests can fill out specifying their favorite style icons  from the Mad Men character Betty Draper to George Clooney  as well as their body types and sizes.

title: China's Cyberwarriors
description: A report traces Chinese hacking efforts to a single building on the outskirts of Shanghai.

title: The Joys of Cooking
description: Not until Id tried sweet potatoes with butterscotch peas and curls of tender sepia; twirled dan-dan noodles in a hot-and-sour vinaigrette; turned velvety spinach and bluefoot shrimp around and around in Mozambican peanut sauce; slashed the yolk of a poached egg so it would spill out over crunchy rice and sour kimchi; and felt my mouth water at the first bite of tart passionfruit curd  not until then did it occur to me that I had been eating a tasting menu.

title: Candy Aims Print Ads at Consumers Hungry for Redemption
description: Editors Note: In Advertising is coming to you on Tuesday because of the Presidents Day holiday. Look for the newsletter next week on its regular day, Monday.

title: Bentley Redesigns the Flying Spur
description: Bentley would like people to stop thinking of its Flying Spur sedan as just a stretched Continental GT coupe with extra doors. To that end, Bentley is so thoroughly redesigning the existing model, the word Continental is being excised

title: General Selected for NATO Post Will Retire, Citing Wifes Health
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. John R. Allen, the four-star Marine Corps officer who served until earlier this month as the top commander in Afghanistan, will retire from the military to focus on health issues within his family, President Obama said on Tuesday.

title: How to Read Like a Bully Buster
Jay-Z Follows Top Publishing Executive to Warner Music
description: Music publishing, the side of the music business that deals with songwriters, is usually less visible than the star-filled recordings side, but it still has its share of intrigue and high-profile defections.

title: Bonnaroo and Firefly Festival Lineups Announced
description: The summer festivals are beginning to take shape, as Bonnaroo and the Firefly Music Festival released their lineups on Tuesday for this years events.

title: Why We Never Use Professional Recruiters
description: This column is called Building the Team. Its about leadership, which Ive focused on in my first few posts and will return to later. Its also about training, talent development, goal setting, culture and career development. But it starts with getting the right people on the team, and thats the theme I will address in my next few posts.

title: Les Misrables Coming Back to Broadway Next Year
description: A new stage version of the blockbuster musical Les Misrables will open on Broadway in March 2014, the producer Cameron Mackintosh said on Tuesday, in an attempt to capitalize on the popularity of the Oscar-nominated film and restore luster to the show in New York after a short-lived 2006 revival that even Mr. Mackintosh now admits was ill-conceived.

title: A Qualified Apology to Niall Ferguson
description: So, several people, including NF himself, have written in to say that Ferguson actually did concede that I was right about deficits and interest rates. Indeed he did; I missed it.

title: That Candys for Research, Not Eating
description: This years animation race is a free-for-all, with three stop-motion contenders and two box office blockbusters in Pixars Brave and Disneys Wreck-It Ralph.

title: A Personal Nightmare of Assault in India
description: In a hotel in southern India, in the midst of a dreamless sleep, I awoke inside a nightmare. I heard someone screaming. Im not sure how much time passed before I realized that it was my scream.

title: Wheelies: The Daredevil Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Dissecting a Trailer: The Parts of the Film That Make the Cut
description: How scenes from five of the nine best picture nominees were reassembled to promote the films.

title: New Comparison Shopping Site for Pet Owners
description: A dog owner with an entrepreneurial bent has started a Web site aimed at making it easier for pet lovers to find the right products at the right price.

description: Erskine Bowles tells a Politico event  now thats a match made in heaven  that

title: The Sequester Is Not an Abstraction
description: President Obamas plea this morning to avert the $85 billion sequester before March 1 was instantly ridiculed by Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader, as a campaign event. Thats presumably because the president spoke in front of a group of emergency responders whose livelihoods are threatened by the indiscriminate spending cuts, just as he often used middle-class Americans as backdrops on the campaign trail.

title: PEN World Voices Festival to Focus on Art and Politics
description: With Salman Rushdie returning as chairman, the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature will bring more than 100 writers from around the world to New York City to discuss both their art and politics this spring, from April 29 through May 5. One major theme of this years edition of the festival, the ninth, will be the notion of bravery in those realms, with panel discussions and other events honoring writers who have shown courage in their lives and work.

title: For Office Supply Stores, an Obvious Merger
description: Office Depot and OfficeMax are lucky to have each other. Uniting the two purveyors of pens, paper clips and printer toner is about as obvious as it gets in mergers and acquisitions. The potential synergies could be worth more than the market value of the two companies combined. As the Internet ravishes retailing, at least this corner can cling to life by merger.

title: Equipping the Fed for a Future Crisis
description: 5:33 p.m. | Updated to reflect alternative solutions proposed by the New York Fed chief.

title: Dissecting a Trailer: The Parts of the Film That Make the Cut
description: Trailer editors go to great lengths to convey precisely what they want you to expect about a film while still leaving room for intrigue.

title: Seeking to Avoid the Sequester
description: The Timess Michael D. Shear on how President Obama put pressure on Congress to avoid the across-the-board budget cuts.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 19
description: A view of the day in sports, including horse racing in England and picture day at Major League Baseball training camps.

title: This Charleston Harbor Battle Is Over Cruise Ships
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  In this Southern coastal city that runs on history and hospitality, a raucous civic debate belies a genteel veneer.

title: Scholar Finds Flaws in Work by Archenemy of Comics
description: For all the colorful adversaries that comic books have yielded, perhaps no figure in the history of that industry is as vilified as Dr. Fredric Wertham.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Simone Rocha
description: The minimalist mantra less is more has become a prevailing beauty theme of the fall 2013 London collections. Today at Simone Rochas show, the artist Shinobu presented her take on this seasons bare-faced makeup. I originally wanted to bring the pink from the clothes to the skin, she says, referencing the offbeat Pepto-Bismol palette of Rochas collection. However it became too pretty, so I switched to monochrome brown tones for a more sophisticated feel. M.A.C.s concrete eye shadow was blended over eyelids, right up to the brows, which were defined with M.A.C.s new Velux brow pencil. Ive drawn a straight line on top, then brushed the color down to the bottom before fading it out to the end, Shinobu explains. To finish, lip conditioner was patted over mouths and cheeks for a subtle, dewy shine. Sometimes the simplest look makes the most powerful statement.

title: When Mutant Mosquitoes Attack
description: Its no wonder that Goethe wrote The Sorcerers Apprentice near the dawn of the industrial age. The poem, which most of us now learn from Mickey Mouse, tells the story of a young man who, left to his own devices, mimics his bosss spell for making brooms fetch water pails. Once the task is done, he doesnt know how to stop the thing, so he chops the broom in half, which only enables it to work double duty. The sorcerer eventually returns, fixing the mess his subordinate has made (his situation never got quite as out of hand as Mickeys). Lesson learned: Solutions to problems at hand can create new, sometimes unforeseeable, challenges in the future.

title: Korean War Veteran Is Buried Six Decades After He Disappeared
description: The passengers aboard Delta Air Lines Flight 2125 didnt get up when the plane taxied into its gate at Baltimore Washington International Airport earlier this month. They didnt retrieve their bags from the overhead bins. Instead, they looked out the right side of the aircraft, where an honor guard and black hearse were waiting to escort the remains of Cpl. James R. Hare home, the final portion of a journey that spanned nearly 7,000 miles and six decades.

title: Palestinians in Prisons Refuse Meals in a Protest
description: JERUSALEM  Hundreds of Palestinian security prisoners in Israeli jails refused meals on Tuesday in solidarity with four hunger-striking detainees, and supporters held protests in the West Bank, as the Palestinians sought to pressure Israel before President Obamas visit to the region next month.

title: It Takes a B.A. to Find a Job as a File Clerk
description: ATLANTA The college degree is becoming the new high school diploma: the new minimum requirement, albeit an expensive one, for getting even the lowest-level job.

title: Will You Watch Raising Adam Lanza on Frontline?
description: On Tuesday at 10 p.m. Eastern time, PBSs Frontline will air its episode Raising Adam Lanza, which follows two Hartford Courant reporters as they interview people close to the Lanza family and attempt to uncover something about the gunman who fatally shot 26 people, including 20 children, at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., last December. (Check PBSs local schedule for times.)

title: Colombian Bank Buys HSBCs Panama Unit for $2.1 Billion
description: Bancolombia said on Tuesday that it had agreed to pay $2.1 billion to acquire HSBC Panama, as the bank continues to expand in Central America.

title: European Solar Importers Defend Chinese in Anti-Dumping Case
description: BRUSSELS  Importers of inexpensive solar panels from China said on Tuesday that imposing tariffs would lead to hundreds of thousands of job losses in the European Union, the biggest export market for the Chinese equipment.

title: Mantels Plastic Princess Remarks Ruffle Feathers in England
description: Hilary Mantel has won two Man Booker Prizes and huge sales for her novels Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies, with their acidic portrait of the doomed schemer Anne Boleyn. But her recent comments about another dark-haired royal wife, the Duchess of Cambridge, are getting some less than flattering reviews.

title: A Tropical Madeleine
description: Back in the 1970s, I was a teenager growing up in Puerto Rico and my mother was young, strong-willed and fashion-conscious. She was always ready to dress me in the latest fads, as best as we could afford, like midi skirts with suede boots and a gown straight from a bridal magazine for my quinceaera.

title: The Small Picture
description: Photographs from small business owners that explain why they do what they do.

title: Before Adele, There Was Lulu
description: Fans of Adele (and Duffy, Amy Winehouse, Emeli Sand and Paloma Faith) probably know that she is part of the second wave of British women with a deep affinity for American pop and soul music. The first was in the 60s, when the great triumvirate was Petula Clark, Dusty Springfield and Lulu, who made her first New York appearance in a 50-year career Saturday night at B.B. Kings.

title: Meteor Videos Set Online Viewing Record
description: How did you watch the videos of the meteor that lit up the sky over Siberia last week? If youre like many people, you went straight to YouTube, where dozens of amateur videos were uploaded soon after the rare occurrence.

title: Model Diary | Katlin Aas
description: Katlin Aas, the Estonia-born model whose four-year career includes a Marc Jacobs campaign and various runways ranging from Jean Paul Gaultier to Givenchy, has already been in more than 20 shows this season (including yesterdays Christopher Kane and Giles shows). And fashion month is only halfway over. For the last day of shows in London, the 20-year-old model tells T about life without a home base. I dont really have a home at the moment, she says, but I spend a lot of time in New York.

title: Palestinian Blogger Chips Away at Israels Image, One Ill-Advised Instagram at a Time
description: A young Israeli soldier was reprimanded by his superiors this week after his urge to share his military life with friends and strangers online led him to post a photograph on Instagram offering a view of the back of a Palestinian boys head in the cross hairs of a sniper rifle.

title: Warner Music Makes a Deal With Small Labels
description: When the Universal Music Group agreed to pay $1.9 billion for EMIs recorded music business in late 2011, it faced major opposition from independent groups, who feared that Universal  already the biggest music conglomerate  would gain too much market power. Last year, European regulators ordered Universal to sell about a third of EMIs recorded assets as a condition for approving the transaction.

title: Why Are We Maybe About to Start Tweeting About Male Nail Polish?
description: If you follow the magazine on Twitter, you generally know what youre in for. Descriptions of our latest articles, retweets of the glowing praise of our latest articles, calls for you to send us your first-day-of-school photos or words that should be banned, that sort of thing. This week, all expectations are about to be blown up. (Or maybe they wont! Who knows? Thats the thing about doing away with expectations!) Were turning over the Twitter controls to our culture editor, Adam Sternbergh. In part this momentous power shift relates to the fact that the Oscars are coming up, so people probably care even more about Adams great movie wisdom this week than they normally do. In (larger) part its because Adam needs a bigger platform to which to spread his insight about male nail polish.

title: Former BAM President to Receive Handel Medallion
description: Harvey Lichtenstein, the larger-than-life former president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music who transformed Fort Greene into a cultural hub and redefined the role of a performing arts center, is to receive the citys highest award for achievement in the arts on Wednesday from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Big, Dense Reds to Pair With Earthy Beans
description: The earthy beans, smoky bacon and rich red-wine reduction are ideal flavors to pair with dry, robust red wines. Two things to avoid: oakiness and sweet, jammy flavors.

title: New York Producers Mull a Broadway Transfer for Glass Menagerie
description: The American Repertory Theater is in talks with New York producers about transferring its current revival of Tennessee Williamss Glass Menagerie to Broadway in the near future, according to a theater executive familiar with the discussions.

title: State Control Draws Closer for Detroit After Fiscal Review
description: DETROIT  A review team appointed by the State of Michigan has concluded that Detroit is mired in serious financial problems, a step that draws the city ever closer to emergency oversight by a state-assigned financial manager.

title: Tofu Mushroom Quiche
description: This is a vegan quiche filled with a savory mix of blended tofu and mushrooms. It has a deep, rich umami flavor. No eggs are necessary to bind it; the tofu stiffens up when it bakes. You can use the crust of your choice. The yeasted crust is not vegan, as it contains an egg.

title: One on One: Susan P. Crawford, Author of Captive Audience
description: Using the Internet or a cellphone keeps getting more expensive. But for network providers like AT&T and Verizon Wireless, new technologies have made services cheaper to deliver. So why the higher prices?

title: F.B.I. Said to Be Looking at Suspicious Heinz Trades
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has opened a criminal inquiry into suspicious trades placed ahead of the $23 billion acquisition of H.J. Heinz, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Apple Computers Hit by Sophisticated Cyberattack
description: Cyberattacks, apparently, happen in threes.

title: Report of the Detroit Financial Review Team
description: A review team appointed by the state of Michigan has concluded that Detroit is mired in a serious financial problem, a step that draws the city closer to emergency oversight.

title: Jury Awards Mystery Writer Patricia Cornwell $50.9 Million
description: The best-selling mystery author Patricia Cornwell on Tuesday was awarded $50.9 million in a federal lawsuit, according to The Boston Globe.

title: General Allens Tenure in Afghanistan
description: Most Americans probably know of him only as a secondary character in the sweeping drama of David H. Petraeuss affair with his biographer, Paula Broadwell. But Gen. John R. Allen, who announced Tuesday that he would retire from the Marine Corps rather than become the top commander of NATO, was for more than a year and a half the commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan. And when he said farewell to the job recently, he made clear that he wanted to be remembered for more than his bit role in that scandal.

title: Sudan Troops Battle Rebels in Border Area
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Sudanese forces said late Monday that they had captured an area from rebels in the restive state of Blue Nile in fierce fighting that led to the deaths of 66 rebels and several government soldiers.

title: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 3
description: Matchday 3 in the Round of 16 in the UEFA Champions League. After a winter break we continue a feature in which we hope to bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

title: Threes a Trend | Feathers
description: T spots the latest trends on the runway.  At London Fashion Week: Christopher Kane used feathers to create whimsical trims, Erdem had them peaking out of silk and organza overlays and at Giles, they dangled from dresses like metal jewels.

title: NetSpend Sold to Payment Provider for $1.4 Billion in Cash
description: NetSpend, a publicly traded provider of prepaid debit cards, is being sold to Tsys for $1.4 billion, the companies announced on Tuesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Yemen, Gaza Strip and the Philippines.

title: Court Gives Investor an Edge in a Lawsuit Against Apple

title: Russia Aims to Defuse Conflict Over Schneerson Collection
description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin said on Tuesday that he blamed unjust rulings by the judicial authorities of another country for the tensions over a collection of books and manuscripts that is being sought by the Brooklyn-based Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic group, but offered to defuse the situation by transferring the works to a new Jewish center in Moscow.

description: Headliner Pizza da Solo

title: Front Burner
description: To Covet: I Dreamed I Was a Sushi Chef

title: The Language Is the Thing
description: Four actors play all the roles, audience members move seats every act and Polonius is in sneakers? Dont worry: The Bedlam companys Hamlet is not as gimmicky as it sounds.

title: Iran, Where Wrestling Is King, Mourns Loss of Sport in Olympics
description: TEHRAN  Not much has changed in the Marqoobkar wrestling club in South Tehran for decades. On a recent afternoon, boys in their wrestling singlets ran circles on a yellow mat, as they do every day, the tallest leading, followed by two dozen others and a tiny 9-year-old trailing behind. The canvas squeaked under their bare feet.

title: 2 Masters of the Business That Is Recorded Music
description: Who put the bomp, Barry Mann asked in his 1961 single, in the bomp bah bomp bah bomp? Mr. Mann wanted to shake that persons hand.

title: F.B.I. File on Times Publisher Was Destroyed Before His Death
description: The files kept by the Federal Bureau of Investigation about Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who led The New York Times as its publisher during its landmark publication of the Pentagon Papers, were destroyed 10 months before his death, according to records requests filed by a reporter.

title: Improvising, a Mover Lets You See Her Think
description: In Live Dancing Archive, one part of an excellent three-tiered production that opened at the Kitchen on Thursday night, Jennifer Monson, wearing a furry vest and nude fishnets, dives headfirst onto the floor. She puts on a platinum wig to sing along faintly to Antony and the Johnsons haunting Bird Gerhl. And she runs in loping steps that scrape the tops of her toes on the floor only to halt suddenly, lift a foot and raise her arms until every part of her remains calm but her twitching fingers.

title: Laughs Can Be Cheap at a Comedy Theater
description: How did the comedy juggernaut Upright Citizens Brigade Theater solve the most intractable problem of live theater today, the inexorable rise of ticket prices?

title: Dolan Says Its Highly Possible the Next Pope Could Be a Non-European
description: CardinalTimothy M. Dolan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, said on Tuesday that he believed it was highly possible that the next pope could come from a non-European country.

title: A Princess Skips Ahead to a Dream Come True
description: There may be no ballet harder to get right in the theater than The Sleeping Beauty. Its made up of innumerable details  musical, choreographic, decorative  that cover a wide range of what ballet theater can be, from pure classicism to scenic magic. New York City Ballets production of The Sleeping Beauty  first staged by Peter Martins in 1991 and little altered since  is a strangely conflicted experience. Its designs are largely of unusual loveliness. Many of its directorial decisions, grand or tiny, show intelligence and discrimination seldom found in this ballet.

title:
Justices Take Case on
Overall Limit to
Political Donations
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear a challenge to federal campaign contribution limits, setting the stage for what may turn out to be the most important federal campaign finance case since the courts 2010 decision in Citizens United, which struck down limits on independent campaign spending by corporations and unions.

title: As the Cantatas Unfurl, a Reprieve Is Affirmed
description: It is hard to believe that just a year ago the wide-ranging music programs of Trinity Church, one of New Yorks major spiritual and cultural centers, were threatened with extinction. Even wealthy nonprofit institutions have felt the press of the economic downturn, and the churchs robust programming was evidently thought unsustainable.

title: A Work by John Cage: Times Have Changed
description: When the New York Philharmonic presented the citys premiere of John Cages Apartment House 1776, in November 1976, the headline for a review in The New York Times by Allen Hughes  Hundreds Walk Out of Premiere of John Cage Work at Fisher Hall  illustrated in stark terms Cages status among conservative concertgoers.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Found Money and Seeing in the Dark
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Playing Beethoven, and Finding the Bar High
description: Framing Beethoven is the title of a lecture series that the Metropolitan Museum of Art is currently presenting alongside a six-concert survey of the complete Beethoven string quartets by the Endellion String Quartet. If there is a crime Beethoven is being set up for, it is, in the words of the museums publicity brochure, his impact on the death of Classicism.

title: Photos of The Moment | Ostwald Helgason
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Wild Oats
description: For many years, granola was the lumpy woolen sweater of the food world.

title: How Do You Granola?
description: Some use butter. Others use olive oil. And for at least one trailblazing California chef, the process involves pickled mango and a scattering of Fruity Pebbles.

title: Supreme Court Appears to Defend Patent on Soybean
description: WASHINGTON  A freewheeling and almost entirely one-sided argument at the Supreme Court on Tuesday indicated that the justices would not allow Monsantos patents for genetically altered soybeans to be threatened by an Indiana farmer who used them without paying the company a fee.

title: After Olympic Disappointment, an Overhaul
description: The months leading to last summers London Olympics had been exceptionally promising ones for the United States womens field hockey team. In fact, it did not seem unreasonable that the team would contend for a medal, which would have been only its second.

title: A Hip-Hop Moment, but Is It Authentic?
description: Even though hip-hop has countless shades, colors, splinter wings and internal dissenters, its still often spoken about as if it were an undifferentiated mass. Many consider it an outsider phenomenon, even though hip-hop has effectively become the center of pop music. This attitude partly stems from age, race and other things, but mainly from a refusal to see the world as it has become.

title: BHP Billiton Chief to Retire; an Insider Will Succeed Him
description: LONDON  BHP Billiton said on Tuesday that its chief executive, Marius J. Kloppers, would retire this year after almost two decades at the company.

title: Currency War Is Less a Battle Than a Debate on Economic Policy
description: Never mind about North Korea; the talk in some quarters is that the biggest threat to Asia and the rest of the world today may very well be a currency war, in which countries race to devalue their currencies in a desperate attempt to stimulate growth.

title: Why the School Bus Never Comes in Red or Green
description: A question came to mind as school bus drivers prepared to start their engines on Wednesday on 7,700 public-school routes in New York City and end their monthlong strike: Why are most school buses yellow?

title: Minnesota Congressman Meets Somali President
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Representative Keith Ellison, Democrat of Minnesota, visited Mogadishu on Tuesday and met with Somalias president, Hassan Sheik Mohamoud, in a rare visit to the strife-plagued country by a member of Congress.

title: At the Garden, a Long-Awaited Father and Son Reunion
description: Its as American as a Norman Rockwell print: Dad and son trundle down to the ol baseball park, glove in tow, to root for the home team. Its a bond thats pure, the love of a team passed down from one generation to the next.

title: Coalition to Apply Election Strength to Immigration Debate
description: In a new nationwide campaign, groups that favor a path to citizenship for most of the nations 11 million illegal immigrants will seek to mobilize the same coalition that helped to carry President Obama into his second term, while treading lightly enough to avoid disrupting the delicate immigration overhaul negotiations in the Senate.

title: Kelly Clarkson Assails Clive Davis Over His Memoir
description: 9:27 a.m. | Updated

title: A Composer So Fond of the Novel, He Hoped It Wouldnt Be a Film
description: As a first-time nominee, the composer Mychael Danna has made a good showing: he was recognized twice, for his score for Life of Pi and for the original song Pis Lullaby, from Ang Lees adaptation of the Yann Martel novel.

title: Prust Speaks: Tortorella Is Just Another Coach
description: Brandon Prust, the combative, effective wing who left the Rangers as a free agent last summer to sign a four-year, $10 million contract with Montreal, spoke Tuesday, two hours before he returned to Madison Square Garden for the first time. He was as well-spoken and quietly funny as he was in his two and a half seasons with the Rangers. His question-and-answer session with reporters follows.

title: Tom Hanks Makes His Broadway Debut
description: The star of the play Lucky Guy, written by Nora Ephron, sits down with Patrick Healy at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: Cemetery Fixtures Stolen, Police Say, but Not Carried Away
description: Update, Wednesday | Mr. Peduto, who is homeless, was arrested inside 3178 Tremont Avenue in the Bronx on Tuesday, around the corner from the cemetery, on charges of larceny and possessing burglary tools and drugs, the police said.

title: Obama Works the Phones to Calm Tensions on Immigration Plan
description: After a Presidents Day weekend whodunit of who leaked what and why  not to mention a he-said, she-said back-and-forth on the Sunday shows and in news releases  President Obama took to the phones Tuesday afternoon to quell rising tensions with Senate Republicans after a draft of a White House immigration plan was somehow leaked to the news media.

title: Nanotubes Seen as Alternative When Silicon Chips Hit Their Limits
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the next decade or so, the circuits etched on silicon-based computer chips are expected to shrink as small as they can physically become, prompting a search for alternative materials to take their place.

title: Chinas Cyberwarriors
description: Rendezvouss editor, Marcus Mabry, interviews David E. Sanger, chief Washington correspondent, on the efforts of Chinese hackers to infiltrate critical American infrastructure, from electrical grids to oil and gas pipelines. Is there a cyber-Cold War under way?

title: Iwan Baans Inclusive Eye
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Downton Finale Seen by 8.2 Million Viewers
description: The third season finale of Downton Abbey attracted 8.2 million viewers to PBS on Sunday night, giving the public broadcaster even more reason to celebrate the surprise British hit.

title: Photos of The Moment | Meadham Kirchhoff
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: PGA Tour Members Voice Opposition to Ban on Anchored Putting Stroke
description: MARANA, Ariz.  The PGA Tour members have spoken and now the anchored putting stroke is in the hands of the United States Golf Association and Royal & Ancient. The games guardians wanted feedback before making official their proposed ban of the anchored stroke, and they got it from tour players who, by all accounts, voiced a collective opposition to it.

title: Locally Grown Gets Tricky in the Cold
description: Locally grown. Market-sourced. Farm to table: These phrases have become the mantras of the American menu, promising ingredients that are supremely fresh, in season and produced within a tight radius of the restaurant.

title: Mayweather Moving to Showtime
description: Floyd Mayweather agreed to move to Showtime after more than 15 years at HBO for a pay-per-view revenue-sharing agreement that is believed to significantly exceed the financial guarantees that HBO offered to retain him. The deal is for Mayweather to fight six times, including May 4 against Robert Guerrero, over 30 months. He has fought only once in each of the last four years. He last fought two bouts in a year in 2007.

title: College Premium: Better Pay, Better Prospects
description: Ive written before about the growing wage premium for college degrees: how the wage gap between workers with a bachelors degree and workers with no more than a high school diploma has been growing over the years.

title: A Great Debate
description: This is the year of what should be a decisive debate on our countrys spending and debt. But our political debates seldom deserve the name. For the most part representatives of the rival parties exchange one-liners: The rich can afford to pay more is met by Tax increases kill jobs. Slightly more sophisticated discussions may cite historical precedents: There were higher tax rates during the post-war boom versus Reagans tax cuts increased revenues.

title: Supreme Court Gives F.T.C. a Win on Hospital Mergers
description: The Supreme Court on Tuesday strengthened the power of the Federal Trade Commission to block hospital mergers, issuing an opinion that could limit the ability of public hospital authorities to claim immunity from federal antitrust laws.

title: Jets Release Pace and Scott
description: Once symbols of the Jets free-spending habits and an aggressive win-now approach, linebackers Calvin Pace and Bart Scott are now casualties of a salary-cap crunch created, in part, by their contracts. The team released Pace, Scott, the safety and special-teams ace Eric Smith and offensive lineman Jason Smith, clearing about $31 million in cap space.

title: Union and N.F.L. Face a Trust Divide
description: The N.F.L.s scouting combine begins Wednesday night in Indianapolis, with the first groups of players  including the offensive linemen, one of the strengths of this class  arriving for the initial round of X-rays and orientation and 15-minute interviews with teams.

title: Critique of a Duchess Rubs Some the Wrong Way
description: LONDON  It is not often that sophisticated literary discourse is the topic of banner headlines on the front page of one of Britains hell-raising tabloids. And it is still less common for a prime minister to weigh in with his own stiffly reproving critique, turning the affair into dinner table talk across the country.

title: Rubios Place in the G.O.P.
description: Some commentators have expressed surprise upon learning about the very conservative voting record of Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who delivered the Republican response to the State of the Union address last week. Despite his recent support for immigration reform, Mr. Rubio has generally sided with most other Republicans since winning his Senate seat.

title: J. Ben Wauford
description: Mr. Wauford, 55, is a principal and the director of the New York office of the architectural firm Cooper Carry, which also has offices in Atlanta; Alexandria, Va.; and Newport Beach, Calif.

title: Neighbors Predicted Chaos. Now Theyre Just Irked.
description: It is perhaps telling that the worst commotion the neighborhood has experienced since the Barclays Center opened in Brooklyn has not been stirred up by rowdy Nets fans or hip-hop devotees, but by teenage girls milling for hours outside a Justin Bieber concert in November.

title: For Wright, Success Is Worth Waiting For
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

title: Trolling for a Summer 2024 Host, the U.S.O.C. Casts a 35-City Net
description: In canvassing for its next potential Olympic city, the United States Olympic Committee sent letters to the mayors of 35 American cities on Tuesday to gauge their interest in making a bid for the 2024 Games.

title: German Officials Signal Berlusconi Isnt Their Man
description: BERLIN  Asked in September if she feared a comeback by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany appeared at pains to hold back a smile as the room erupted in laughter. I am, as you know, a democratic politician and respect the outcome of elections in every country, she told reporters in Berlin.

title: In the End, He Stole Nothing and Gave Plenty
description: They burst from the ice-skating rink on Tuesday glowing out loud, in a way that only a mighty mob of girls and boys from 5 to 17 can.

title: Overdose Deaths Continue to Climb
description: Drug overdose deaths in the United States increased for the 11th consecutive year in 2010, rising 3.6 percent from 2009, federal officials reported Tuesday. There were 38,329 drug overdose deaths in 2010. Prescription drugs were involved in more than half of all overdoses, with 22,134 deaths from them, up 6 percent from 2009. Of those deaths, opioids, like oxycodone and morphine, were involved in an overwhelming majority, with 16,651 deaths in 2010, up 7 percent from 2009. Deaths from prescription drug overdoses quadrupled from 1999 to 2010.

title: Dozens of PGA Pros Say Drug Testing Is Limited
description: MARANA, Ariz.  The player most likely to be subjected to rigorous testing under the PGA Tours antidoping program would figure to be Tiger Woods, a 14-time major champion and one of the brightest stars in the sporting firmament.

title: Top Member of Taliban in Pakistan Is Captured
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghanistan authorities have captured a senior member of the Pakistan Taliban in a stretch of mountains near the frontier between the two countries, Afghan and Pakistani officials said on Tuesday. One Afghan official said the militant, Maulvi Faqir Muhammad, had been arrested after American airstrikes, some carried out via drones, had flushed him out of a more remote haven.

title: Lone Star Blues
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Losing My Leg to a Medical Error
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.

title: Old and Rich? Less Help for You
description: WASHINGTON

title: Gardner, Yankees Pest at Plate, Awaits His Place
description: TAMPA, Fla.  After Brett Gardner had surgery on his inflamed right elbow last July, he returned to the Yankees in time to contribute as a late-season pinch-runner, with a handful of plate appearances in the playoffs. It had been his goal all along to rejoin the team by the end of the season.

title: How to Prevent More Bond Rating Fiascoes
Religious Exemptions From Birth Control Mandate
description: To the Editor:

title: In Child Development, Early Intervention Is Vital
description: To the Editor:

title: The Feminine Mystique, 50 Years Later
description: To the Editor:

title: An Unexpected Mission for Frances Defense Minister
description: PARIS  Jean-Yves Le Drian, a lifelong Socialist, remembers vividly the day Nicolas Sarkozy called to offer him the post of defense minister.

title: Reproductive Rights in New York
description: New York State once led the nation in advancing womens rights. Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to re-establish that pre-eminence with an omnibus agenda on womens equality. The most important piece of that agenda would essentially enshrine in state law existing federal protections for abortion rights.

title: Chinas Cybergames
description: Washington has not had much success persuading Beijing to rein in its hackers even though American officials and security experts have long known that China is the main source of cyberattacks on the United States. Two recent developments, however, should raise the political costs for China and may cause it to alter its calculus. Refusal to change its conduct could make its relations with the United States even more difficult than they are.

title: Obamas Forecast on Cuts Is Dire, but Timing Is Disputed
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday painted a dire picture of federal government operations across the United States should automatic budget cuts hit on March 1: F.B.I. agents furloughed, criminals released, flights delayed, teachers and police officers laid off and parents frantic to find a place for children locked out of day care centers.

title: Now Batting: A Stronger, Mandatory Helmet
description: The beanball is one of the scariest plays in sports, a baseball hurtling at the head of a batter who cannot get out of the way. Over the years, they have led to concussions, skull fractures and, in a handful of cases, deaths.

title: After Adopted Boy Dies in U.S., Russian Officials Accuse Texas Woman
description: MOSCOW  Russian officials on Tuesday accused a Texas woman of fatally beating a 3-year-old boy she had adopted from Russia, setting off a new wave of outrage in a country already focused on American adoptions that have culminated in neglect or abuse.

title: Campaign Donations and Political Corruption
description: In a deeply worrisome move, the Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear a new campaign finance lawsuit that challenges long-established federal caps on the total amount an individual can contribute to federal campaigns in a two-year cycle. In a ruling last year, a special court in Washington correctly upheld those limits, which in some form have been included in federal law since 1974.

title: The Belly Dancing Barometer
description: The Daily News of Egypt reported that the national administrative court ruled last week that the popular Al-Tet belly dancing channel be taken off the air for broadcasting without a license. Who knew that Egypt had a belly dancing channel? (Does Comcast know about this?) It is evidently quite popular but apparently offensive to some of the rising Islamist forces in Egypt. It is not clear how much the Muslim Brotherhoods party had to do with the belly ban, but what is clear is that no one in Egypt is having much fun these days.

title: New Dreamliner Headache: Parking Space
description: With the Federal Aviation Administrations grounding of the 787 Dreamliner fleet in its fifth week, Boeing now faces a problem of where to store the airplanes that continue to roll off the assembly line at its giant factory 30 miles north of Seattle.

title: Knicks Set to Resume as Wallace and Camby Work Their Way Back
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Each of the Knicks had a task.

title: Rise in Complaints About Rats Prompts Call for New Eradication Program
description: New York City officials are calling for a publicly financed program to bait, kill and remove rats in the wake of reports that Hurricane Sandy sent droves of the rodents scurrying inland, with many of them taking up residence in new neighborhoods.

title: Denied New Government, Tunisian Premier Resigns
description: TUNIS  Tunisias prime minister resigned on Tuesday after failing to form a new government, saying the countrys political leaders, including those in his governing Islamist party, had disappointed Tunisians with squabbling that had led the country into a political crisis.

title: A Company That Runs Prisons Will Have Its Name on a Stadium
description: In recent years, where stadium naming rights could be sold, universities and professional sports teams have sold them  to airlines and banks and companies that sell beer, soda, doughnuts, cars, telecommunications, razors and baseball bats. This led to memorable examples like Enron Field, the KFC Yum! Center and the University of Phoenix Stadium.

title: French Family Kidnapped in Cameroon
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Seven French tourists, including four children, were kidnapped in northern Cameroon on Tuesday, the second large-scale hostage-taking in the region in four days. The French president and foreign minister pointed the finger at Islamist terrorist groups operating across the border in northeast Nigeria, possibly including the deadly Boko Haram organization.

title: A Dazzling Priests Lurid Fall, to Drug Case Suspect
description: From the time he joined the priesthood three decades ago, he seemed destined to become a star. As a confidant to two bishops and then as the erudite and clubbable pastor of two churches, Msgr. Kevin Wallin was a towering figure in the Roman Catholic Church in southwestern Connecticut.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Feb. 20, 2013
description: When you get 800 rsums for every job ad, you need to weed them out somehow.

title: Millions of Dollars Later, Landlords Reopen After Deluge
description: More than three months after Hurricane Sandy flooded Manhattans financial district, forcing the closure of about a quarter of its offices, all but a handful of those buildings have come back to life, defying predictions of a drawn-out recovery.

title: Mayweather Leaves HBO for Six Bouts on Showtime
description: At 35, Floyd Mayweather wants to keep making huge paydays for his fights, like the ones he earned while fighting at HBO.

title: City Rebuffed in Bid for Outtakes From Central Park Jogger Film
description: New York City lawyers were rebuffed on Tuesday in their efforts to subpoena outtakes from the documentary filmmaker Ken Burnss movie about the five men who were convicted and later exonerated in the racially charged 1989 Central Park jogger rape case.

title: Scott and Pace, Symbols of Jets Spending, Are Cut
description: Calvin Pace agreed to a $42 million pact with the Jets before the 2008 season. A year later, Bart Scott arrived on a $48 million deal.

title: Bark Up or Down? Firewood Splits Norwegians
description: OSLO  The TV program, on the topic of firewood, consisted mostly of people in parkas chatting and chopping in the woods and then eight hours of a fire burning in a fireplace. Yet no sooner had it begun, on prime time on Friday night, than the angry responses came pouring in.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sergeant Charged in Child Pornography Case
description: A New York City police sergeant was arraigned on Tuesday on numerous child pornography charges, after internal affairs investigators found several explicit images and videos on his laptop computer.

title: Corrections: February 20, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Make Waves
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert! The answer to each italicized clue is a compound word or a familiar two-word phrase. A certain four-letter word (spelled out clockwise by the circled squares) can follow the first half and precede the second half of each of these answers, in each case to complete another compound word or familiar two-word phrase.

title: Mapping Whatever Lives
description: Ow.

title: Avoiding Violent Images for an Anti-Poaching Campaign
description: DISTURBING online videos document the illegal killing and trade of wildlife, including film of poachers who shoot elephants with AK-47 assault rifles to take only their tusks, and poachers who shoot rhinoceroses with tranquilizer guns and remove their horns with chain saws.

title: Mets Pitchers Throw, but the Batters Are Mostly Taking
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  During their workout Tuesday morning, the Mets for the first time branched off into groups for live batting practice, a transitional exercise that marks the beginning of the buildup toward full-fledged games.

title: Fast New Test Could Find Leprosy Before Damage Is Lasting
description: A simple, fast and inexpensive new test for leprosy offers hope that, even in the poorest countries, victims can be found and cured before they become permanently disabled or disfigured like the shunned lepers of yore.

title: 3 Men Arrested in Scheme to Sell Counterfeit Car Parts
description: Federal authorities arrested three men Tuesday on charges of selling counterfeit brake pads and other automotive parts to repair shops, including those that service the citys yellow taxis and licensed livery cabs, officials said.

title: Israel: Deal Gives Netanyahu Rival Palestinian Portfolio
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced Tuesday night that Tzipi Livni, the former foreign minister who has long been a harsh critic of his handling of the Palestinian conflict, would join his next government, serving as justice minister and leading negotiations with the Palestinians.

title: Battle Lines Drawn for BPs Day in Court
description: HOUSTON  Unless the Justice Department and BP reach a last-minute settlement, the British oil company will return to court on Monday to face tens of billions of dollars in civil claims from the 2010 explosion on the Deepwater Horizon rig in the Gulf of Mexico that could cripple the company for years to come.

title: Germany: Court Backs Adoption by Same-Sex Couples
description: Children do not differentiate whether their parents are of the same sex, united in a civil union, or a man and a woman in a traditional marriage, and therefore neither should the law, the nations highest court said Tuesday, placing Germany on a growing list of European countries to expand the rights of same-sex couples. The Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe ruled in favor of a doctor from Mnster who had challenged existing laws that forbade her to adopt her same-sex partners daughter, who was raised by both women. The judges ordered the government to draw up legislation by June 2014 to allow such adoptions within same-sex unions.

title: School Bus Drivers See No Gain From Strike
description: They lost pay, watched bills pile up at home and endured cold days and nights on picket lines. They weathered criticism in some quarters as holdouts for archaic and costly job protections. And, perhaps most stingingly, the struggle bore no immediate fruit.

title: Nickelodeon Hopes Its App Wins Hearts
description: Nickelodeon has spent the last two years asking 9- and 10-year-olds what they want to watch on the iPad. The result: Very little actual television.

title: Blast Ignites Kansas City Restaurant, Causing Severe Injuries
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A popular restaurant in an entertainment district here became engulfed in towering flames on Tuesday evening after a gas main exploded, rattling the earth, leaving shards of glass and brick strewn about and injuring more than a dozen people, some severely.

title: A Digital Shift on Health Data Swells Profits in an Industry
description: It was a tantalizing pitch: come get a piece of a $19 billion government giveaway.

title: Ex-Ranger Shows Scrappiness His Former Team Now Lacks
description: The Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens are two very different teams from last season. Brandon Prust, the tough, scrappy wing, is perhaps the biggest reason.

title: Bronx Leader Wants a Public Registry for Offenders in Gun Crimes
description: New York State already keeps a public registry of sex offenders. Now a Bronx political leader is calling for a statewide registry to be created for people found guilty of another type of crime: gun violence.

title: On Hudson, Banks Ferries Are Finally in Service
description: It is a mystery that has drifted around New York Harbor for two years: Why did one of the worlds biggest investment banks buy two custom-made ferry boats and leave them bobbing, unused, on the Hudson River?

title: Community, Returning to Life, Asks, Where Is Everybody?
description: There werent enough people in Red Hook, residents said to one another in worried tones. The Brooklyn neighborhood felt lonely. Dwellers in the garden apartments along Pioneer Street, which took on about eight feet of water during Hurricane Sandy, were long gone. Dog walkers clients had moved, taking their canine charges with them. At least one restaurant was having trouble finding enough workers to reopen. Demand from would-be home buyers had ebbed.

title: Home Solar Systems to Be an Option for Honda Customers
description: Automakers have long resorted to incentives like zero-percent financing, rewards points and rebates to inspire customer loyalty. Now Honda is offering a different deal: inexpensive home solar power systems for customers.

title: Johnson Beats the Buzzer, Twice, to Lift the Nets
description: As energy sources go, Joe Johnson is fantastically deceptive, all sleepy eyes and shrugs and coy smiles, without a single signature exclamation in his emotional arsenal. There is nothing particularly electric about him, until the game is on the line and the seconds are ticking away and the ball is in his hands.

title: Woods and Obama, a Weekend Pairing That Cant Help but Draw Attention
description: MARANA, Ariz.  In the first round of the Accenture Match Play Championship, Tiger Woods will play Charles Howell III, who is well known in the golf world but not nearly as distinguished as the player Woods was paired with in a friendly competition Sunday in Florida.

title: Petro Vlahos, Special-Effects Innovator, Dies at 96
description: Petro Vlahos, a special-effects pioneer who developed the blue-screen and green-screen process that allowed Dick Van Dyke to dance with penguins in Mary Poppins, the blue-skinned Navi to live among floating mountains in Avatar, and TV weather reporters to point at sun and rain symbols that only their viewers can see, died on Feb. 10 in Los Angeles. He was 96.

title: No Consensus on a Common Cause of Foot Pain
description: There are more charismatic-sounding sports injuries than plantar fasciitis, like tennis elbow, runners knee and turf toe. But there arent many that are more common. The condition, characterized by stabbing pain in the heel or arch, sidelines up to 10 percent of all runners, as well as countless soccer, baseball, football and basketball players, golfers, walkers and others from both the recreational and professional ranks. The Lakers star Kobe Bryant, the quarterback Eli Manning, the Olympic marathon runner Ryan Hall and the presidential candidate Mitt Romney all have been stricken.

title: Concerns Grow About Severely Polluted Water in Chinas Cities
description: HONG KONG  The recent headlines about Chinas pollution problems  many are now calling it a crisis  have focused on the worsening air pollution in Beijing and other major Chinese cities, drawing worldwide attention to the issue.

title: Word of the Day | mendicant
description: mendicant \men-di-knt\ noun and adjective

title: At $3 Million, New Award Gives Medical Researchers a Dose of Celebrity
description: Eleven scientists, most of them American, were scheduled to be named on Wednesday as the first winners of the worlds richest academic prize for medicine and biology  $3 million each, more than twice the amount of the Nobel Prize.

title: Lured From Europe, Man Is Held in 2012 Theft of a Dal Drawing
description: The clue  a simple fingerprint on a juice bottle stolen from Whole Foods  was routine. But that, along with some creative undercover work, helped the authorities unravel the brazen daylight theft of a Dal drawing from an Upper East Side gallery that had gone unsolved for months.

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 7 P.M. (13, 49) AFTER NEWTOWN This PBS initiative exploring gun laws, mental illness and school security continues with a PBS NewsHour report by the science correspondent Miles OBrien about adolescent brain development and the factors that can lead to violent behavior. In Mind of a Rampage Killer, on Nova at 9, Mr. OBrien investigates theories about circumstances that would cause a person to enter a public place and open fire  and how science can help us recognize danger signs. And The Path to Violence, at 10, looks at the Safe School Initiative, a Secret Service program that has helped schools detect problem behavior, and examines how findings can be applied to the families of violent individuals. Sam Waterston narrates. Above, a scene from The Path to Violence.

title: News Quiz | February 20, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Irene Genovese, the Traveler from Italy
description: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this years 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.

title: Pistorius Defense Rebuts Police Testimony at Bail Hearing
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  What began on Wednesday as a day for the prosecution to solidify what it had described as an irrefutable case of premeditated murder against Oscar Pistorius, the Paralympic champion, turned into a near rout by the defense, which attacked the testimony of the states main witness, the chief police investigator.

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 20
description: NEWS Importers of inexpensive solar panels from China said Tuesday that imposing tariffs would lead to hundreds of thousands of job losses in the European Union, the biggest export market for the Chinese equipment. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

title: I Just Want His Body Back
description: BARAMULLA, Jammu and Kashmir

title: After Bulgarian Protests, Prime Minister Resigns
description: Prime Minister Boiko Borisov of Bulgaria submitted his governments resignation on Wednesday after a tumultuous week of public anger over rising electricity prices, corruption and worsening living standards that ignited mass protests nationwide and led to bloody clashes with the police on Tuesday night.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 20, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article BlackBerry, Rebuilt, Lives to Fight Another Day.

title: Hacking Campaign, Seen as Linked to Chinas Army, Targets U.S. Industry and Government
description: In Chinese Army Unit Is Seen as Tied to Hacking Against U.S., David E. Sanger, David Barboza and Nicole Perlroth report on evidence linking Chinas army to coordinated hacking attacks against the United States.

title: Cameron Calls Colonial-Era Massacre in India Shameful
description: NEW DELHI  Britains prime minister laid a wreath on Wednesday at the site of a notorious 1919 massacre that cost the lives of hundreds of Indians and has long been seen as one of the British Empires most shameful episodes.

title: Should Reading and Math Be Taught in Gym Class Too?
description: Gym class is for playing sports, like kickball and tennis, and running around. Or is it? Some gym teachers are incorporating reading, writing and math into their curriculum alongside traditional physical activities to help students meet new academic standards.

title: My Hometown': Teenagers Document America
description: What does America look like to young people today?

title: China Says Army Is Not Behind Attacks in Report
description: SHANGHAI  A day after a United States security company accused a Peoples Liberation Army unit in Shanghai of engaging in cyberwarfare against American corporations, organizations and government agencies, Chinas defense ministry issued a strong denial and insisted that the report was flawed.

title: Greek Workers Walk Out in Fresh Austerity Protest
description: ATHENS  Thousands of Greek workers walked off the job on Wednesday in the first nationwide protest against austerity this year, shutting schools, reducing staffing at state hospitals and disrupting transportation.

title: Cameron Calls Colonial-Era Massacre in India Shameful
description: NEW DELHI  Britains prime minister laid a wreath at the site of a notorious 1919 massacre that cost the lives of hundreds of Indians and has long been seen as one of the British Empires most shameful episodes.

title: Chinese Plan to Kill Drug Lord With Drone Highlights Military Advances
description: BEIJING  China considered using a drone strike in a mountainous region of Southeast Asia to kill a Myanmar drug lord wanted in the murders of 13 Chinese sailors, but decided instead to capture him alive, according to an influential state-run newspaper.

title: North Korean Video Shows Obama in Flames
description: North Korea has released a new propaganda video that shows President Obama and United States troops in flames and credits Washington with leading the impoverished country to become a proud nuclear power.

title: Mullin Museum Showcases Work of Gabriel Voisin
description: OXNARD, Calif.  Peter Mullins car museum is like a geode, a rock that looks like a ball of dried mud until you crack it open and discover the gemlike structures hidden inside. From the outside, the Mullin Automotive Museum looks like any other building in any other industrial park in any other suburban development. But walk inside and you are dazzled by the cars, which really are rolling sculptures and are displayed just as you might have seen them had you attended one of the Paris auto salons in the Art Deco era between the world wars.

title: The Reluctant Caregiver
description: Now and then, I refer to the people that caregivers tend to as loved ones. And whenever I do, a woman in Southern California tells me, I set her teeth on edge.

title: Wages and Employer Penalties
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Q&A: Locking Caps on an iPhone
description: Q.

title: Credit Agricole Cites Write-Downs in Posting a Record Loss
description: PARIS  Crdit Agricole, one of Frances biggest lenders, said on Wednesday that a series of write-downs and other charges contributed to its largest-ever annual loss.

title: Should British Politicians Apologize for Colonialism?
description: On Wednesday, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain appeared in Amritsar, in the Indian state of Punjab, where he laid a commemorative wreath at Jallianwala Bagh, the site of a 1919 massacre of Indian protesters by British forces that killed about 1,000, according to the Indian government.

title: Marissa Mayer Puts Her Stamp on Yahoo.com
description: 8:39 a.m. | Updated On Wednesday, Yahoo introduced a fresh new home page with Marissa Mayers stamp all over it.

title: What I Took Home in 2012
description: A year ago I wrote a series of posts that dissected my companys finances and culminated with a detailed accounting of how much money I made in 2011  $246,626, generated from revenue of $2,155,193. The event that prompted the analysis, writing an application for college financial aid, just happened again this weekend. So Im going to give you an update on how 2012 went and whether I was able to match what was by far my most rewarding year.

title: The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food
description: On the evening of April 8, 1999, a long line of Town Cars and taxis pulled up to the Minneapolis headquarters of Pillsbury and discharged 11 men who controlled Americas largest food companies. Nestl was in attendance, as were Kraft and Nabisco, General Mills and Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola and Mars. Rivals any other day, the C.E.O.s and company presidents had come together for a rare, private meeting. On the agenda was one item: the emerging obesity epidemic and how to deal with it. While the atmosphere was cordial, the men assembled were hardly friends. Their stature was defined by their skill in fighting one another for what they called stomach share  the amount of digestive space that any one companys brand can grab from the competition.

title: Robin Roberts Returns to Good Morning America
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated Now, Robin Roberts said to the staff of her top-rated morning show, Good Morning America, right after it wrapped on Wednesday, we can resume regular programming.

title: Obama Fleshes Out Plans for Infrastructure Projects
description: The White House on Wednesday fleshed out the plans President Obama announced in the State of the Union address to repair the nations ailing infrastructure.

title: Tunnel Vision
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian militarys recent flooding of tunnels at the border between Egypt and Gaza is its most aggressive attempt yet to restrict smuggling since Israel imposed a blockade on the Palestinian territory in 2005. Sewage water is reportedly being used to weaken the tunnels structure, sometimes trapping smugglers inside.

title: Europes Rift on Overfishing and Subsidies
description: Two weeks ago, the European Parliament voted overwhelmingly to require that the 27-nation blocs fisheries be managed on a sustainable basis within a few years.

title: Russian Lawmaker Quits After Real Estate Disclosure
description: MOSCOW  A senior lawmaker from Russias governing party, who was also the chairman of Parliaments ethics committee, resigned from the legislature on Wednesday over revelations that he owned more than $1.3 million worth of luxury real estate in Florida that he did not list on required disclosure forms.

title: Bobos in Berlin
description: BERLIN  Even hundreds of protesters couldnt thwart the eviction last Thursday morning when more than 800 police officers and a helicopter were deployed to dislodge the Glbol family from their home of more than 13 years.

title: Heinz Trades Draw F.B.I. Scrutiny
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining the suspicious trades placed ahead of the $23 billion acquisition of H.J. Heinz, DealBooks Ben Protess reports. The inquiry adds to the cloud hanging over the deal, after the Securities and Exchange Commission took action over the trading last week.

title: Now Streaming | Gucci Fall 2013 Womens Collection
description: The Spring 2013 womens collection show from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Arizona Senators Return to Fray on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  The political risks of supporting an immigration overhaul have long been apparent to Senator John McCain, as evidenced by his evolving position on the topic over the years. This week offered another sharp reminder of what getting out in front of the issue can mean when crowds at back-to-back town-hall-style meetings in Arizona turned hostile toward Mr. McCains plan to introduce legislation that could lead to legal residency for some who broke the law in entering the country.

title: Opinion Report: Abortion in New York
description: From the editorial page

title: Tom Hanks, Broadways New Kid
description: Tom Hanks swears. Not a blue streak, no, but its bracing to hear profanity from the man who has defined decency for three decades in Hollywood, playing white knights in Splash, Forrest Gump, Apollo 13 and the Toy Story series. If he is grandma-friendly on screen, he is looser and less predictable in person  as his old friend Nora Ephron was reminded several years ago when she sent him the screenplay for a biopic, Lucky Guy. Mr. Hanks took an instant dislike to his character, Mike McAlary, the muckraking columnist of New York City tabloids in the 1980s and 90s.

title: PopSugar, a Web Site for Women, Gets a Makeover
description: PopSugar, the blog that is eye candy for celebrity- and fashion-obsessed women, is getting a makeover.

title: Wednesday Reading: Losing a Leg to a Medical Error
U.S. Tycoon Savages Work-Shy French Workers
description: LONDON  Many in France are bristling over a letter from Maurice M. Taylor, an American tire tycoon, describing French employees as underworked and overpaid.

title: Fine Austrian Whines
description: Andrew Leonard:

title: A Swinging Bag and a Retort in the Subway
description: Dear Diary:

title: True or False? The Tussle Over Ping Fus Memoir
description: Did Ping Fu, a prominent Chinese-American businesswoman and author of a recent memoir, Bend, not Break, make up her horrible experiences during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution in order to gain United States citizenship? Did they help her become an American by claiming political asylum?

title: Questions About Hearing Loss? A Help Desk
description: This weeks Ask the Expert features Neil J. DiSarno, who will answer questions about hearing loss. [Update: The first set of Dr. DiSarnos answers can be found here. This feature is now closed to further questions.] Dr. DiSarno is the chief staff officer for audiology at the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association. From 1998 to 2012 he was chairman of the department of communication sciences and disorders at Missouri State University. Following are the types of questions that Dr. DiSarno is prepared to answer.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: A Childrens App Breaks Ground for Viacom, and Essay on Royals Causes Uproar
description: The childrens channel Nickelodeon plans to release an iPad app Thursday that could have serious implications for its parent company, Viacom, Amy Chozick writes. It represents Viacoms first attempt at a streaming app and could indicate how they will approach apps for channels like Comedy Central and MTV. The most interesting thing about the app is that Nickelodeons research indicated that 9- and 10-year-olds were more interested in associated content, like music videos, games and video clips, rather than watching full episodes on a tablet. So the app contains a lot of accessible content beyond streaming episodes of Nickelodeon favorites like SpongeBob SquarePants and iCarly, even for users who do not subscribe to a cable company that provides Nickelodeon.

title: Office Supply Rivals Merger Leaked by a Wayward Report
description: 8:56 p.m. | Updated

title: The Benefits of Positive Parenting
description: Is there a science to parenting?

title: The Gun Report: February 20, 2013
description: The gun rights folks like to talk (and talk and talk) about how people need guns to protect themselves from, you know, the bad guys. Oscar Pistorius has single-handedly shown why this type of thinking is misguided (Im being kind). In his second court appearance since being charged with murdering his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp, Pistorius explained in an affidavit why he shot her four times through his closed bathroom door. He thought an intruder had come in through the bathroom window  so of course he opened fire without so much as switching on a light. So there are two possibilities: the police version, which is that he murdered her in cold blood after a violent argument, or the Pistorius version, which is that it was a regrettable accident. Either way, if there was no gun in the house, Steenkamp would still be alive. By the way, did you know he tweeted in November, Nothing like getting home to hear the washing machine on and thinking its an intruder to go into full combat recon mode into the pantry! waa. Wayne LaPierre should testify in his defense.

title: Now Noshing | Jaffa Port Market
description: If unpredictability is a constant in the Middle East, so is the dash to find the next hot spot to nosh  and thats where Tel Aviv rarely disappoints. Ditto for Jaffa, a part of the Tel Aviv municipality where the Jewish and Arab communities mercifully mix, and often to scrumptious effect. It was in the sea opposite Jaffa that Jonah was famously swallowed by a whale, but now the serious nibbling is happening onshore at the large Jaffa Port Market, which after a partial opening in August is now in high gear.

title: Daily Report: Health Data Swells Profits in an Industry
description: As doctors and hospitals struggle to make new digital health records systems work, the clear winners are big companies like Allscripts that lobbied for that legislation and pushed aside smaller competitors, reports Julie Creswell of The New York Times.

title: Finding Peace During Noisy Trips
description: ITS CALLED THE QUIET ZONE. Introduced this month by AirAsia X, a budget airline based in Malaysia, this eight-row oasis offers soft lighting and a promise: no children younger than 12 allowed. The cost of keeping them out? An extra $11 to $36 a ticket.

title: Making Guns in Montana
description: Kalispell, Mont., has become the center of a growing firearms industry, particularly for high-end rifles and industrial rifle parts.

title: In Montana Towns Hands, Guns Mean Cultural Security
description: BIGFORK, Mont.  Jerry Fishers big and careful arms cradled a polished cutout of English walnut, which was aging in his workroom like a fine wine. The slight tapering along one edge gave a ghostly hint of its future as the stock of a handmade hunting rifle.

title: Treasure Hunters in Uniform: Monuments Men Remembered
description: We dont tend to think of World War II as a setting for one of historys biggest art thefts.
