Now some veterans of that war are being honored for recovering some of the most famous  and not so famous  art of the Western world: so much of it, in fact, that theres a good chance youve seen some of the thousands of works they have tracked down.

title: Step 1: Watch a Movie a Day for Two Years. Step 2: Make a Documentary.
description: For a first-time filmmaker, David France has had an impressive run with his initial effort, How to Survive a Plague, which has ended up being one of the five nominees for the Academy Award for best feature-length documentary.

title: Health Care Aside, Fewer Jobs Than in 2000
description: Uwe Reinhardt had a fascinating post Friday about the buffer that health care spending has provided in the last few years. Health care has provided a steady contribution to gross domestic product even as other sectors cut back dramatically. He also notes that in the last two decades, it has created more jobs on a net basis than any other sector.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York: La Newyorkina, which sells Mexican ice pops called paletas on the High Line and makes other sweets, has reached its Kickstarter goal to raise funds to rebuild the Red Hook production kitchen damaged by Sandy.  Maria Newman

title: Muscle Strain to Limit Murphys Training
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Second baseman Daniel Murphy returned to the Mets training camp Wednesday after being examined by team doctors in New York Tuesday afternoon.

title: Feeling For | Smythson Mara Clutch
description: Just in time for spring cleaning  and tax season  Smythson has invented a stylish way to keep your receipts in order. You can personalize the four sections inside the limited-edition Mara clutch with up to 10 characters per tab, meaning those purchases from Rodeo Drive wont get tangled with any from Gstaad.

title: Risk of Flooding Will Not Alter Plan to Preserve 9/11 Remains
description: Despite what is now a known risk of flooding, the Bloomberg administration and the 9/11 memorial foundation still intend to place the unidentified remains of World Trade Center victims at the bedrock level of the National September 11 Memorial Museum, as they have long planned to do.

title: Square Bundles Cash Register Equipment Into One Package
description: Using an iPad as a cash register sounds nifty, but businesses will still need additional gear to swipe credit cards and print receipts. Square, the payments start-up company, said on Wednesday that it was bundling all the components a business needs for accepting payments into one package.

title: Questioning the Motives Behind Your Financial Decisions
description: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Le Meridiens Eastern Campaign
description: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts plans to add nine new hotels to its roughly 100 properties in the coming year. Much of the expansion is taking place in Asia (including a hotel to open in Zhengzhou, China, rendered above), where six new Meridiens will open. The Starwood-owned brand is among several hotels, including the Marriott and the W, that have announced significant expansions in Asia.

title: Can Humans Do Better Than Dinosaurs When it Comes to Incoming Space Objects?
description: Can humans do better than the dinosaurs?

title: The Early Word: Retired
description: Todays Times

title: Families in Wartime
description: A child neednt know the historical context, complexity or details of either the Cultural Revolution in China or the Japanese internment in America to sense the trauma they wrought. Even adults recoil from contemplating it. Yet two new picture books offer narratively strong, visually arresting and moving examples of why and how picture books can conveywith immediacy and resonancethe impact of profound historical events.

title: Settling Is Not the Only Way to Resolve an Employee Lawsuit
description: Many small-business owners respond to employee lawsuits with grudging acceptance that, regardless of whether the company broke any laws, the sooner it pays a plaintiff to go away, the better. As repugnant as this may sound, it is a cost of doing business. That, at least, is one approach.

title: Gucci: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Student Crossword | Genetics
description: Learn more about genetics by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Conan OBrien to Host White House Correspondents Dinner
description: The White House Correspondents Dinner has lately become a bit of a round robin on late-night talk show hosts, and now Conan OBrien has agreed to take his turn.

title: A Quiet Meal, Polluted by Noise
description: I recently met a friend for lunch at a popular bistro new to both of us. We arrived and quickly found seats by the window. The dcor was lovely, and the menu looked terrific.

title: Same Old Drill? Let Them Wrestle
description: Trevor Pryce played in the N.F.L. from 1997 to 2010.

title: Debating Money in Politics
description: Nicholas Confessore on the implications of the Supreme Court's decision to hear a challenge to federal campaign contribution limits.

title: A Funky Gospel Sound Is Resurrected
description: The Rev. Gean West says he feels like Abraham, whom God made a father in his dotage. Its been 43 years since he and his brother Tommie formed the gospel group the Relatives in Dallas and 33 years since the band broke up after releasing a few funky singles but scoring no hits.

title: The Rove Machine
description: In the continuing struggle for control of the right, the Tea Party Patriots, a Georgia-based group, sent out a fundraising email portraying Karl Rove as a Nazi  and later apologized, claiming an outside vendor had added the doctored image without their knowledge.

title: Graphic Pop | Anya Hindmarch
description: Anya Hindmarch created a domino set extravaganza to show off her graphic-inspired accessories this week in London.

title: How Do You Handle Employee Litigation?
description: For many small-business owners, it has become conventional wisdom that the best way to deal with employee litigation is to settle quickly and move on, regardless of whether the owner or the company has done anything wrong. But that was not the approach taken recently by Jeffrey Herold of West Coast Trends.

title: Game On at Anya Hindmarch
description: The always-whimsical designer Anya Hindmarch created a domino set extravaganza to show off her graphic-inspired accessories this week in London. Hindmarch collaborated with set designer Rachel Thomas and world champion domino expert Robin Weijers, who arranged nearly 50,000 colored tiles in the space. As the dominoes tumbled and weaved, the various pieces from the collection were revealed. It was an eye-popping experience, to say the least. Herewith, an exclusive video.

title: Jesse Jackson Jr. Pleads Guilty: I Lived Off My Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  Jesse L. Jackson Jr., the former Democratic representative from Illinois, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to one felony fraud count in connection with his use of $750,000 in campaign money to pay for living expenses and buy items like stuffed animals, elk heads and fur capes.

title: Amid Confusion, School Bus Drivers Return to Work After Monthlong Strike
description: Several drivers could not find their buses. Some of the big yellow vehicles seemed ill prepared for the road, lacking license plates or inspection stickers. At a bus depot in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a driver for Reliant Transportation turned a key in his vehicles ignition, but it failed to start.

title: Street Style: Neon Beanies
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Feb. 11.

title: Trial Offers Rare Look at Work of Hezbollah in Europe
description: LIMASSOL, Cyprus  In a little-noticed trial in a small courtroom here on Wednesday, a 24-year-old man provided a rare look inside a covert global war between Israel and Iran, admitting that he is an operative of the militant group Hezbollah, for which he acted as a courier in Europe and staked out locations in this port city that Israelis were known to frequent.

title: Caffeine Linked to Lower Birth Weight Babies
description: New research suggests that drinking caffeinated drinks during pregnancy raises the risk of having a low birth weight baby.

title: Harriet Jacobss War
description: By early 1863, the former slave Harriet Jacobs was in better health than shed been in years. Nearly two decades earlier, she had escaped to freedom after years hidden away in the garret above her grandmothers home in Edenton, N.C. The confinement  within a crawlspace 9 feet long, 7 feet wide and 3 feet high  had been physically punishing, she noted in her narrative, Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl.

title: Carbon Trading Program Falters in Europe
description: LONDON  Just as President Barack Obama is trying to persuade Americans that a cap and trade system is the way to curb carbon emissions, the worlds flagship program in Europe is in danger of failing. The price of carbon traded in Europe has collapsed to around 5 euros per metric ton compared with 30 euros a few years ago, as I discuss in my Green column.

title: A Revolving Door in Washington With Spin, but Less Visibility
description: Obsess all youd like about President Obamas nomination of Mary Jo White to head the Securities and Exchange Commission. Who heads the agency is vital, but important fights in Washington are happening in quiet rooms, away from the media gaze.

title: Yankees Cautious After Hughes Injures His Back
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Phil Hughes arrived at camp penciled in as the Yankees No. 4 starter, and he felt his work over the winter had put him in good shape. After refining his mechanics and dropping that troublesome cutter from his repertory, he looked forward to playing a steady role this season.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 20
Still in Previews on Broadway, Cinderella Took In $1 Million Last Week
description: The Broadway musical Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella achieved a relatively rare feat last week, grossing more than $1 million even though the show is still in preview performances and has no star actors, according to box office data released on Tuesday.

title: The Miami Mess, Unraveled
description: I dont do this very often  and certainly not as often as I should  but this blog post, by Vishnu Parasuraman, who writes for a University of Miami fan site called Sebastians Pub, is worth a read. It is a devastating analysis of the N.C.A.A.s bogus investigation into its own unethical behavior in conducting its investigation of the University of Miamis basketball and football programs. I couldnt have said it better myself.

title: Biden Says Get a Double-Barreled Shotgun
description: During an online forum on Facebook hosted by Parents magazine, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. commented on gun ownership for personal protection.

title: Adding Fitness to Your Itinerary
description: Heavy dinners. Endless meetings. Delayed flights. Uncomfortable hotel beds. Business travelers contend with them all, and that takes a toll.

title: In West Vancouver, a Corner Apartment With Pacific Views
description: A two-bedroom on the 12th floor of a high-rise is on the market for $1,587,000.

title: House Hunting in ... Canada
description: TWO-BEDROOM WITH OCEAN VIEWS IN WEST VANCOUVER

title: What Front-Page Choices Say About The Timess Priorities
description: In the digital age, the matter of what stories are picked for front-page display in the print edition may seem archaic. Who cares, one might reasonably ask.

title: The Voting Is Over: Those Jazzy Envelopes, Please
description: The hard part of the 85th Oscar season is over, finally  and that includes referring to it as the 85th season.

title: Biden Shotgun Advice Draws Quizzical Response
description: Not every American has Secret Service protection, so Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has some advice for protecting ones self and home: Get a shotgun, just as he has.

title: Palestinian Filmmaker Detained at Los Angeles Airport
description: The Palestinian filmmaker Emad Burnat, the co-director of the Oscar-nominated documentary 5 Broken Cameras, was detained at Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday.

title: Lebanese Ex-Minister and Syrian Official Accused of Death Plot
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A Lebanese military court investigative judge on Wednesday charged a former government information minister and a high-ranking accomplice in the Syrian military of a conspiracy to kill Lebanese political and religious leaders and foment sectarian strife, recommending the death penalty for both.

title: Leading Off: A Push and a Shove
description: Is it ever O.K. for a college coach to shove a player?

title: Big Sensor, Small Body: A Concept That Works
description: When youre shopping for a camera, you have a million specs and features to consider. Size, weight, battery life, megapixels, zoom power. ... Can you guess which aspect consumers consider most important?

title: Cleaning Up Kunmings Waterways
description: Millions of dollars have been spent to clean up the waterways around Kunming, the largest city in Yunnan Province. But hurdles remain.

title: Banksy Work, Taken From London Wall, Turns Up in Miami, for Auction
description: Slave Labor (Bunting Boy), a 2012 work by the mysterious British graffiti artist Banksy, has vanished from a wall outside a discount store in London, and turned up at an auction house in Miami. And the town council in Haringey, the north London borough where the Banksy work appeared last May and disappeared last week, say that they want the piece returned.

title: Pope Considers Speeding Up Succession Process
description: VATICAN CITY  A week ahead of his expected resignation, Pope Benedict XVI is considering changing the rules for the election of his successor, potentially making the process start sooner, the Vatican said on Wednesday.

title: Fewer Bags Went Astray
description: Lost, damaged, delayed or pilfered luggage is a perennial headache for many air travelers, but 2012 was a good year. The nations 15 largest airlines reported the lowest annual rate of mishandled baggage in 25 years. The carriers posted an average rate of 3.09 reports of mishandled baggage per 1,000 passengers, the lowest rate since this data was first reported in September 1987, according to a recent Air Travel Consumer Report issued by the Department of Transportation. The carriers with the best rates last year were Virgin America, AirTran Airways and JetBlue Airways.

title: Hispanics: Californias Next Majority
description: How the states demographics have changed since 1980.

title: Report Says Stanford Is First University to Raise $1 Billion in a Single Year
description: Stanford last year became the first university to raise more than $1 billion in a single year, according to the Council for Aid to Educations annual college fund-raising survey.

title: Two Plays Planned for Broadway Are Delayed
description: Two plays that had been announced for Broadway this spring  Beth Henleys Miss Firecracker Contest and Eric Cobles Velocity of Autumn  have been postponed, according to the lead producer of both shows.

title: Talking Talent | Dane DeHaan
description: With a slew of films scheduled for 2013, his golden good-boy looks (reminiscent of a young Leonardo DiCaprio) and a coveted role in next years The Amazing Spider Man sequel, Dane DeHaan is topping every directors wish list. The 26-year-old Pennsylvania native (he also happens to be the face of the spring/summer Prada campaign) will star opposite Bradley Cooper and Ryan Gosling in The Place Beyond the Pines, as well as play Lucien Carr, a pivotal member of the Beat Generation, in Kill Your Darlings.

title: F.C.C. Moves to Ease Wireless Congestion
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission took a step on Wednesday to relieve growing congestion on Wi-Fi networks in hotels, airports and homes, where Americans increasingly use multiple data-hungry tablets, smartphones and other devices for wireless communications.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 20
description: A view of the day in sports, including pictures from baseball training camps in Florida and ski areas in Italy.

title: In Search of Republican Reformers
description: In the last week there have been not one but four impressive pieces on fixing the Republican Partys policy problem one by Ramesh Ponnuruin the pages of this newspaper, one by James Pethokoukis in National Review, a lengthy essay by Pete Wehner and Michael Gerson in Commentary, and a sketch of a right-of-center health care reform by Douglas Holtz-Eakin and Avik Roy for Reuters. The proposals vary a bit, but theres an essential unity to the ideas that they promote. To borrow Gerson and Wehners language, theyre all addressed to voters who now regard the Republican Party as wholly out of touch with ordinary Americans, and they all take the obligations of governing more seriously than a lot of recent right-wing rhetoric has done. This, from the Commentary essay, is a solid formulation of the pieces common theme:

title: Back in Her 'G.M.A.' Anchor Seat
description: After battling a life-threatening illness, Robin Roberts goes back to work. | Blogger Andrew Sullivan on The Dish. | Nickelodeon releases a new app. | David Pogue reviews the Sony Cyber-shot RX1.

title: Deal Between Office Depot and OfficeMax Not Quite Ready for Release
description: The just-announced merger of Office Max and Office Depot has some unfortunate signs that the deal was not ready for prime time.

title: Tibetan Teenagers Die in Double Self-Immolation
description: Two Tibetan teenagers killed themselves by self-immolation on Tuesday to protest Chinese rule in Tibet, according to reports on Wednesday by a Tibet advocacy group and Radio Free Asia. The two were among the youngest Tibetans to kill themselves in protest, and the act was a rare instance in which Tibetans committed self-immolation together.

title: Stage Scenes: Laura Osnes
description: A look at some of the actresss past stage performances.

title: A Small Camera, but Its Big Inside
description: The Sonys Cyber-Shot RX1 fits in a coat pocket, but it has a full-frame sensor that lets it take low-light pictures and blurry-background portraits perhaps better than any other pocketable camera. Its expensive ($2,800), but its also astonishing.

title: Google Will Offer Its Glasses to Select Few
description: Google is letting a larger segment of the public test its futuristic eyeglasses.

title: Even Clowns Can Have Aging Knees
description: Years ago, while he was performing on Broadway in Fool Moon, the rascally clown David Shiner dumped a bucket of popcorn on my head. Last month he tried to steal my wallet.

title: Alberta Ferretti: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Walters Art Museum Names New Director
description: Julia Marciari-Alexander, deputy director for curatorial affairs at the San Diego Museum of Art, has been appointed executive director of the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore. Ms. Marciari-Alexander is replacing Gary Vikan, who is stepping down after more than 27 years at the Walters, 18 of them as its director.

title: Can Republicans Win the Senate in 2014?
description: Democrats, faced with a daunting set of Senate races in 2012, not only survived but thrived, adding two seats to their majority.

title: Fed Meeting Shows Dissent on Measures to Lift Job Growth
description: WASHINGTON  There are widening divisions among officials of the Federal Reserve over the value of its efforts to reduce unemployment, but the authors of its bond-buying policy remain firmly in control, according to an official account of the January meeting of the Feds policy-making committee.

title: Conservative News Outlets Cite Fake Group in Opposition to Hagel
description: A couple of weeks ago, the conservative Web site Breitbart.com reported that former Senator Chuck Hagel had received financing from a group called Friends of Hamas.

title: Now Showing | Karl Lagerfeld for Fendi
description: Karl Lagerfelds new video for Fendi, which is called Peplum People and features the brands spring collection, stars models Kati Nescher, Saskia De Brauw, Joseph Dolce and Willy Cartier. Watch it exclusively here.

title: Karl Lagerfeld for Fendi
description: Karl Lagerfelds exclusive new video for Fendi, which features the brands spring collection, stars Kati Nescher, Saskia De Braw, Joseph Dolce and Willy Cartier.

title: Cat Trapped?  Call in the Spelunkers
description: For most New Yorkers, the Feb. 8 snowstorm was at worst a mild inconvenience. But one Brooklynite  a Norwegian forest cat named Venusaur  braved the snow while trapped in a deep crevice only two feet wide between two buildings.

title: Hobbit Makeup, Yak Hair and All
description: The dwarfs who accompany Bilbo Baggins in The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey may be small, but their hair and beards live large. Pounds of yak hair were used to create their elaborate wigs, and an intricate plan was followed to make sure every braid, and every bulbous prosthetic nose, was in place.

title: Homes for $700,000
description: Properties in New Orleans, New Mexico and Wisconsin.

title: Apologies All Around for Office Depot Announcement Mishap
description: When it comes to Office Depots inadvertent announcement of its $1.19 billion deal for OfficeMax, its all apologies.

title: Unexpected Detour Leads to a New Home: Israel
description: Growing up in Brooklyn dreaming of playing in the N.B.A., Ramel Bradley, now 28, never imagined he would one day have his name on the back of an Israeli league jersey.

title: What You Get for ... $700,000
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Getting Along Without God
description: The Stones weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

title: Datsyuk vs. Five Nashville Players; Datsyuk Wins
description: By the end of most seasons, Detroit forward Pavel Datsyuk has contributed several candidates for goal of the year. He registered a leading contender in Tuesday nights game against Nashville, which was mesmerizing even by Datsyuks high standards. He basically grabbed the puck in the Red Wings zone, stick-handled past every one of the five Predators on the ice and bounced a puck past goalie Pekka Rinne.

title: An Interview With Andrew Sullivan
description: The editor and founder of The Dish discusses how his readers, and not advertisers, are financing his newly independent blog.

title: Young Drivers Most Likely to Pay Insurance Penalty
description: Younger drivers are the most likely to get hit with higher insurance rates after getting a ticket, a new report finds.

title: TimesCast: An Interview with Andrew Sullivan
description: The editor and founder of The Dish discusses how his readers, and not advertisers, are financing his newly independent blog.

title: Sanfords South Carolina Campaign Begins With Appeal for Second Chance
description: In a Congressional race with 16 Republicans, high name recognition is key. Though in the case of Mark Sanford, South Carolinas former governor whose very public confession of marital infidelity seemed to end his national political aspirations less than four years ago, there can also be a downside.

title: WCBS-TV Anchor Resigns After Arrest
description: Rob Morrison, a news anchor for WCBS-TV in New York, said on Wednesday that he had resigned from his job after his weekend arrest on charges of choking his wife during a domestic dispute at their home in Darien, Conn.

title: Self-Discovery in a Silk Tracksuit
description: It is possible to like a look and not crave it, to appreciate it and yet know its for someone else. Clothes, like photographs and poems and reality TV shows, work on several levels. Sometimes its best to stand back, out of the blast radius.

title: Jane Lynch Will Be Miss Hannigan in Annie
description: Jane Lynch, who knows a thing or two about keeping young women in line as the fearsome cheerleading coach Sue Sylvester on Glee, will soon have a new brood to boss around: Beginning May 16, she will portray the blustery orphan-keeper Miss Hannigan in the Broadway revival of Annie.

title: Armstrong Refuses to Meet With U.S. Anti-Doping Agency
description: Lance Armstrong has refused, once again, to meet with the United States Anti-Doping Agency and give testimony under oath about the doping practices that fueled most of his career as a cyclist.

title: With Roberts Back, Good Morning America Looks to Widen Ratings Gap Over Today
description: Robin Roberts is back from a nearly six-month medical leave of absence, a fact that ABCs Good Morning America celebrated with a special broadcast on Wednesday.

title: Shia LaBeouf Withdraws From Broadways Orphans
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Designers of Aston-Martin Rapide S Embrace Golden Ratio
description: With the first Aston Martin Rapide, which went on sale in 2010, Marek Reichman, the Aston design chief, and his staff impressed their colleagues around the world. They figured out how to stretch a classic two-seater sports car, the DB-9, to accommodate four without making it look gawky or awkward.

title: Immigration Debate Hits Home
description: Ashley Parker reports on John McCains push for an immigration overhaul in Washington while facing strong resistance at home in Arizona.

title: Model Diary | Karmen Pedaru
description: Welcome to Milan Fashion Week! Karmen Pedaru is the green-eyed 22-year-old Estonian beauty who walked in todays Gucci showshes also the face of the current spring campaign. Before her career on the catwalk, she was a goalkeeper on her national soccer team. Shes had a busy few weeks so far, having clocked Michael Kors and Marc Jacobs in New York and Burberry and Tom Ford in London, so dont be surprised if you see her relaxing somewhere like the bar at Hotel Principe di Savoia, her favorite watering hole in Milan.

title: Taxing Carbon
description: Long considered the biggest holdout in climate change negotiations, China said this week that the country would implement new taxes designed to curb greenhouse gas emissions. Officials in Beijing provided few details, but a report by the state-owned Xinhua news service suggested that the government is working on a relatively modest plan.

title: Teachers Union Sues Over States Tax Cap
description: The New York State teachers union filed a lawsuit on Wednesday challenging the constitutionality of the states cap on annual increases in local property taxes, one of the signature measures of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos time in office.

title: Mother Asks Putin to Return 2nd Son After Death in Texas
description: MOSCOW  The Russian mother of two young boys who were adopted by a Texas couple requested on Wednesday that the younger child be returned to her, after his brother died under unclear circumstances in a case that has given new impetus to a long-running controversy over foreign adoptions.

title: Nurturing a Star of Operas Next Generation
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Lawyers Question New York Cardinal in Milwaukee Suits
description: A week before Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan is set to leave New York for Rome, where his name is being floated as a candidate for pope, he was questioned in Manhattan for three hours on Wednesday behind closed doors in a legal deposition concerning the sexual abuse of children by priests.

title: Moving Pictures, and the Empty Spaces Left Behind
description: Im an avid Instagram follower, and every day I look forward to posts by Pete James, curator of photographic collections at the Library of Birmingham in England, which for nearly 40 years has housed one of Britains most significant photography collections. The collection, which comprises approximately 3.5 million images spanning from 1841 to today, is currently closed to the public as the staff prepares for a move to a new building, which is still under construction but expected to open on Sept. 3.

title: After First Round, Mother Nature Is in the Lead
description: MARANA, Ariz.  Jason Day stood on the seventh hole at the Golf Club at Dove Mountain, staring at a sky that looked like a pewter carpet unfurling. Mother Nature was coming up quickly on Day and his first-round opponent, Zach Johnson. They clearly were going to have to let her play through at the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship.

title: Quel Brouhaha! A Diatribe on Unions Irks the French
description: PARIS  How stupid do you think we are?

title: Effects of Bullying Last Into Adulthood, Study Finds
description: Victims of bullying at school, and bullies themselves, are more likely to experience psychiatric problems in childhood, studies have shown. Now researchers have found that elevated risk of psychiatric trouble extends into adulthood, sometimes even a decade after the intimidation has ended.

title: Times Company to Sell New England Media Holdings
description: 9:22 p.m. | Updated

title: James Beard Awards: Geography vs. Quality
description: You dont have to live in New York to believe that the city has some of the best restaurants in the country. This is widely acknowledged by just about everybody who keeps up to date on food  everybody except, apparently, the men and women who oversee the restaurant and chef awards given by the James Beard Foundation.

title: A Farmers Market in Warmer Climes
description: We know youre tired of winter, that you want to toss off your coat and go out to the farmers market for the kind of fresh produce you can find around New York only in the summer. Maybe it will help to watch this video by Jacob Mann, of the SoCo Farmers Market in Costa Mesa, Calif., where the stalls are piled high with fresh strawberries, cucumbers and red and golden cherries, and a girl in a sleeveless dress waits her turn at a truck selling baked goods. The video comes via The Huffington Post.

title: Where the Nudity Is Just Skin Deep
description: The first sounds we hear in Juliana F. Mays Commentary = not thing are heavy footsteps. Three dancers take purposeful strides across the stage before breaking into skipping runs. Not long after that comes heavy breathing. Its the kind of dance in which effort is on defiant display, emotions run high, and bodies are heard as well as seen.

title: A Peek at Works in Progress
description: The theater composer Adam Guettel is so overwhelmingly gifted that any news of his activities stirs the kind of fervent expectations that surround Stephen Sondheim, and before that, Leonard Bernstein. On Tuesday evening at 54 Below this handsome, smiling grandson of Richard Rodgers opened an exceedingly rare New York engagement in which he previewed several new songs from two works in progress: a musical based on the Danny Boyle movie Millions, and an adaptation of Days of Wine and Roses.

title: Now Showing | Trevor Paglen
description: In his latest project, The Last Pictures, the photographer Trevor Paglen tackles some huge questions: What is an image? What happens to an image when you detach it from history? And what is the future? Parts of the project, which began five years ago, are on display at Metro Pictures gallery in Chelsea. The project culminated last fall when a Russian space shuttle launched from Kazakhstan carrying 100 images (chosen or shot by Paglen) encoded onto a silicone disc that is meant to remain in orbit long after the planet is gone. In other words, short of some art-world space race, Paglens work will ostensibly be the only surviving piece of art history in the universe in a few billion years.

title: Romney Will Address Conservative Conference
description: 3:59 p.m. | Updated  When Republican activists gather for the annual Conservative Political Action Conference in March, a long roster of the partys rising stars will be on hand.

title: Egyptians in Port City Reject Presidents Effort to Mollify Them
description: CAIRO  Thousands of demonstrators in the Egyptian city of Port Said temporarily shut down the road to a major port at the Mediterranean entrance to the Suez Canal on Wednesday, brushing off moves by President Mohamed Morsi to placate the city with promises of economic development.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: When the Guest Shows Up, but the Gift Doesnt

title: Boeing to Propose Redesign of 787 Battery to F.A.A.
description: Boeing has developed possible fixes for the battery problems in its grounded 787 jets and could have them back in the air within two months, industry and federal officials said Wednesday.

title: Another Prize for Robert Caro
description: Robert Caro will add yet another item to his groaning literary trophy cabinet in April when he collects the New-York Historical Societys American History Book Prize for Lyndon Johnson: The Passage of Power, the fourth volume in his continuing biography of the 36th president. The award, previously won by Doris Kearns Goodwin, Ron Chernow and Drew Gilpin Faust, among others, comes with a $50,000 prize, an engraved medal and the title American Historian Laureate.

title: Struggling Sabres Part Ways With Ruff
description: 6:32 p.m. | Updated The Sabres fired Coach Lindy Ruff, the longest-tenured N.H.L. coach, Wednesday afternoon in the middle of his 15th season behind the Buffalo bench.

title: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Sony RX1
description: David Pogue reviews Sonys Cyber-shot RX1.

title: New Era for Coach, Team and Region
description: TRUMBULL, Conn.  Over the last 50 years, Vito Montelli led the boys basketball team at St. Joseph High School to 878 victories, the most by a New England high school basketball coach. St. Joes, as its devoted alumni call it, also won 11 state titles. The Basketball Hall of Fame announced this month that Montelli would receive a Morgan Wootten Lifetime Achievement Award.

title: John McCain Faces Angry Town Hall
description: At a town hall in Tucson, Senator John McCain answered questions on immigration and border patrol from an angry crowd.

title: A Newspaperman Dies. His Son Chases the Story.
description: Michael Haineys mother taught him about Michael Corleone. She loved The Godfather, and her favorite scene was its last one. She explained how the movie transformed Michael into the ruthless tough guy he never intended to be, and how at the end Michael devastatingly shuts out his wife, Kay. She asks Michael if he ordered the murder of his sisters husband. Dont ask me about my business, Kay, Al Pacino menacingly replies.

title: A South Korean City Full of Food, History and Bargains
description: There are two phrases to learn if you visit Jeonju, a 650,000-person city  and a paradise for Korean food-lovers  three hours by bus south of Seoul.

title: Independent Booksellers Sue Amazon and Publishers Over E-Books
description: Three independent, brick-and-mortar bookstores have filed a lawsuit against Amazon and the big six publishers, claiming that they are violating antitrust laws by collaborating to keep small sellers out of the e-book market.

title: The Daily Do | Gucci
description: The modern, slippery-when-wet look of Guccis half-up is both sinuous and sophisticated.

title: MetroCards Become More Flexible
description: The bad news: subway and bus fares are still going up next month. The good news: paying them just got a little easier.

title: A Stephen Burrows Retrospective
description: The designer, known for his disco-era look of rainbow jersey dresses, is once again having a moment.

title: Dont Forget About Stephen
description: STEPHEN BURROWS IS NOT making another comeback. At least not right now, when he is once again having a moment.

title: Fashion News Were Reading Now
description: The French luxury conglomerate PPR  has acquired a majority stake in the label of the British fashion designer Christopher Kane.

title: Will You Pass On Your Junk Food Addictions?
description: Like so many of you, I clicked on the article in the middle of The New York Timess home page, The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food, and the image that greeted me  unmistakably that of a nacho cheese Doritos chip  presented a problem.

title: A Life in Basketball
description: Vito Montelli led the St. Joseph High School basketball team to 878 wins, the most by a New England high school basketball coach.

title: Staging Stories That Are Torn From the News
description: CHICAGO  Conflict, suffering, mans reliable inhumanity to man: the world will never be without the raw material for wrenching drama. A single issue of a daily newspaper could supply fodder for at least a dozen stage tragedies. But there are many ways of writing about the sorrows of human experience, even when playwrights are drawing on a specific real-world calamity. Different challenges too. Stick to the facts, and the story may fail to take dramatic shape. Stray too far into the imagination, and it may lose the power it derives from allegiance to actual events.

title: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 4
description: Matchday 4 in the Round of 16 in the UEFA Champions League. After a winter break, we continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

title: Playful Meets Artisanal in Paris
description: As exciting new takes on the bistro, including Le Chateaubriand and Septime, began to attract food-conscious locals to the once-grungy 11th Arrondissement in Paris, the district matured, paving the way for other ambitious young chefs.

title: On the Red Carpet, No Blemishes Allowed
description: With all the clamor about gowns and jewels, one element of Academy Awards preparation often goes unnoticed. In hotel suites, private houses and medical offices across Los Angeles, facialists and dermatologists are now wielding microcurrent wands, oxygen blasters and laser beams in a collective effort to deliver poreless, glowing complexions for the high-definition cameras on Sunday.

title: A Bronze Look for Oscar Night
description: Many actors and actresses appear to compete not only for the Oscar but also its golden glow, splurging on these tanning pros.

title: An Interview With Bashar al-Assad
description: Excerpts of an interview with the Syrian president featured in a new documentary on the conflict by the filmmaker Hubert Seipel.

title: Wipe Away the Tears, Pump Up the Beat
description: Few bands have given themselves a more extreme makeover between albums than Tegan and Sara, who started a two-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night. Tegan and Sara Quin, twin sisters from Canada who have been writing songs and recording together since the 1990s, had moved from folky guitar strumming to folky indie-rock over a decade. They write songs that console the vulnerable, singing about unstable relationships that are full of insecurities, apologies, pleas, tears and forlorn hope. And they have built the kind of devoted following that filled the Beacon with singalongs and squeals of recognition throughout Tuesdays set.

title: Scene City: Giants Among Social Animals
description: Explorer Club hosts a screening of Battle for the Elephants.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, Yemen and Greece.

title: Vienna Jewish Museum Chided Over Nazi Loot
description: When the Jewish Museum of Vienna was founded in 1988 it was entrusted with safeguarding the art, books and Judaica that survived the Nazis attempt to exterminate their owners.

title: Microchips and a Musician, Together in a Duet
description: So many wires and power cords were tangled on the stage at Roulette on Tuesday evening that the piano appeared to be nestled in a giant serpents nest. Forty loudspeakers, 20 on each side of the stage, and each wired to hand-built electronics, framed the instrument.

title: Rallying for the Elephants
description: When Kristin Davis, the actress, visited Africa for the first time several years ago, she had eyes for one animal above all others.

title: 30 Accessories from London Fashion Week
description: Highlights from the fall collections, from playful handbags to practical gloves.

title: Pentagon Warns of Widespread Civilian Furloughs
description: Most of the Pentagons civilian employees will face a furlough in the coming months if the planned across-the-board budget cuts come to pass on March 1, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned Congress on Wednesday.

title: The Daily Shoe | No. 21
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: A Digital Update to Those Old Family Photo Albums
description: The days of sticking photos into the plastic pockets of a family album are all but gone, thanks to the rise of digital photography.

title: Inside the Oscars Writers Room
description: Melena Ryzik speaks with the comedian Carol Leifer about writing jokes for the Academy Awards telecast.

title: Emeli Sand Wins Big at Brit Music Awards
description: Emeli Sand, a soulful Scottish-born newcomer on the British pop scene, emerged as the big winner at the 2013 Brit Awards in London on Wednesday, winning best British female artist and taking the album of the year prize for her debut Our Version of Events, according to wire reports.

title: Fox Broadcasting Partners With YouTube Channel
description: Big television networks are sometimes portrayed as being on one side of an invisible boundary, with Web video firmly on the other side. But thats becoming less and less accurate, as an announcement on Tuesday by Fox Broadcasting and a YouTube channel called WIGS demonstrates.

title: My Look, My Ego, My Brand
description: They perch along the runways like birds on a wire, each with vivid markings: the celebrity editors Carine Roitfeld, working her swag of dusky hair, kohled eyes and killer stilettos, and Grace Coddington, her flame-colored mane framing her face like a cloud; and the photographer Terry Richardson, his downward-drooping mustache lending him the look of a 70s porn king.

title: Some Headphones Amplify Celebrities Over Sound
description: If you are planning a $200 splurge on premium headphones  as millions of people are this year  who will give you the most for your money? Maybe a rapper like Dr. Dre, 50 Cent, Nick Cannon or Ludacris?

title: His and Hers
description: Two identical studio apartments on East 57th Street, from two points of view.

title: One Size (Small) Fits All
description: The so-called micro-pad is now a buzz phrase and a cultural touchstone, thanks to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. But when single-room living was being sketched out in the floor plans of Manhattans first apartment buildings, particularly during the boom years of the 1920s, it was called the studio apartment.

title: Among the Oscar Contenders, a Host of Connections
description: With few exceptions, this years nominated actors, directors and producers have long worked on films with Oscar histories.

title: Peggy Bayer Trophy in England
description: What is the highest winning victory-point percentage in a multiteam international event?

title: In Reversal, Florida to Take Health Laws Medicaid Expansion
description: MIAMI  Gov. Rick Scott of Florida reversed himself on Wednesday and announced that he would expand his states Medicaid program to cover the poor, becoming the latest  and, perhaps, most prominent  Republican critic of President Obamas health care law to decide to put it into effect.

title: Londons New Designers Unleash Their Creative Force
description: London produces some of the best naked thinkers, but too few achieve commercial success.

title: I.B.M. to Take Big Step Into Mobile
description: For I.B.M., mobile computing has come of age. At least, smartphones and tablets may be popular enough to make I.B.M. several billion dollars.

title: A Different Kind of Printer
description: It may be only a matter of time until a 3-D printer shares space with the laptop or the coffeemaker.

title: Commercially Creative
description: Between 9 p.m. Monday and 10 the next morning, a lot happened in London. Christopher Kane drank too much tequila. J. W. Anderson was kissed by Carine Roitfeld. Tom Ford boarded a plane for Los Angeles and the Oscars. Simone Rocha designed a dress for a girl waiting at a bus stop.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Feb. 21
description: Bombers and varsity jackets arrive for spring; VFiles, a social media site, showcases emerging designers; and Maryam Nassir Zadeh introduces a line of footwear.

title: Bold Tailoring and Patterns, and a Golden Girl
description: Londons role in the global luxury market was a topic of conversation during the shows, but Tom Ford and LWren Scott seemed miles ahead. And though Christopher Bailey of Burberry lightly evoked a British sex scandal of the early 60s, a leopard pencil skirt will probably fly anywhere.

title: A Factory on Your Kitchen Counter
description: In his State of the Union address last week, along with the standard calls for education reform and energy independence, President Obama gave a shout-out to a growing technology. In a lab in Youngstown, Ohio, the president said, Workers are mastering the 3-D printing that has the potential to revolutionize the way we make almost anything.

title: Scouting Report
description: Shop the Look

title: Market Ready
description: Q. My home has mismatched baseboards. Should I try to make them consistent throughout the house before putting it on the market?

title: Shopping for Soap Dispensers
description: Hlynur Atlason, an industrial designer from Iceland, says that dispensers should be easy to interact with and easy to clean and refill.

title: Soap Dispensers
description: A THREE-LETTER word has dominated conversations for months now: flu.

title: Palestinian Filmmaker Describes Detention at Los Angeles Airport
description: The Palestinian filmmaker Emad Burnat, who had a hard time convincing immigration officers at Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday that his invitation to this weekends Academy Awards was real, described his brief detention in a statement on Wednesday.

title: A Solid, Comforting Family Member
description: The last time I saw my familys Nakashima dining table, it was upended on a dusty Dodge Ram, a gray blanket wrapped around it. The ropes that tied the bundle to the vans roof didnt seem up to the task of keeping the precious cargo from slipping off and crashing on the road somewhere

title: A Devotion to Wooden Churches
description: While communism, collectivism, worms, dry rot and casual looting failed to destroy the majestic wooden churches of Russia, it may be ordinary neglect that finally does them in. Dwindled now to several hundred remaining examples, these glories of vernacular architecture lie scattered amid the vastness of the worlds largest country. Just over a decade ago, Richard Davies, a British architectural photographer, struck out on a mission to record the fragile and poetic structures. Austerely beautiful and haunting, Wooden Churches: Traveling in the Russian North (White Sea Publishing; $132) is the result. Covering thousands of miles, Mr. Davies described how he and the writer Matilda Moreton tracked down the survivors from among the thousands of onion-domed structures built after Prince Vladimir converted to Christianity in 988.

title: Anheuser-Busch and U.S. in Talks to Resolve Antitrust Concerns
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

title: A Juicer Worthy of a Crush
description: If you find it hard to live in this decade without embarking on a juice fast, you might want to upgrade your juice-extracting technology. Thats what drove this reporter to try the Premium Slow Juicer/Smoothie Maker from Hurom ($400). Like previous versions, the machine crushes rather than whirls its contents, which uses less energy, obtains more juice and preserves more nutrients, the company says. This model also has a lever to control pulp.

title: Japanese-Inspired Fabric for a Rhode Island Chair
description: Since Cade Tompkins opened her gallery space three years ago in her home in Providence, R.I., she has been using the mid-19th-century brick Italianate house, designed by Russell Warren, as more than just an installation site. It has become a collaborative device in her shows of contemporary artists like Beth Lipman, who covered Ms. Tompkinss dining room walls with 30,000 pieces of glass, in a shimmering illusion of wallpaper.

title: Op Art for Every Room
description: Ordinary wallpaper companies mass-produce their goods and sell them in rolls, but Wall & Dec creates murals that are custom printed to fit each site, resulting in room-size works of art.

title: A Broadway Revival, Starring Orchids
description: About a decade ago, Elle Ronis went to the Home Depot to buy caulk and came home with her first orchid. When you buy an orchid that has a bud on it and you nurture it and it opens, its, like, addictive, she said. Today she tends some 5,000 orchids in her basement in Connecticut and supports the habits of other gardeners with Blooms on Broadway, a botanical expo that opens Thursday and runs through Sunday.

title: Sales at Amy Helfand, the Golden Calf and Others
description: This weekend, Amy Helfand will discount some rug samples as much as 60 percent and all custom orders 20 percent (the 8-by-10-foot Prayer rug, regularly $12,800, will be $6,400); Kea Carpets and Kilims, 477 Atlantic Avenue (Third Avenue), Brooklyn, (718) 222-8087, amyhelfand.com.

title: Survival of the Fittest, or Just of Coping Skills
description: The latest production from the BBC Natural History Unit is a typically eye-catching, years-in-the-making chronicle of animal life that is tainted by the urge to anthropomorphize. Despite its vague title, One Life holds a clear focus across its transcontinental series of short, dramatic segments: the intricate survival behavior displayed by the planets cleverer beasts (and one plant).

title: Whats Billboards No. 1? Now YouTube Has a Say
description: What makes a song a hit? In the Gangnam Style age the answer often has as much to do with its popularity on YouTube as any other factor.

title: A Treasure on Every Table
description: TUCSON  The earth is made of them and space is littered with them and, for two weeks every February, this city of roughly a half-million swells by another 50,000 as mineral hunters from around the planet descend on southern Arizona in passionate pursuit of more rocks.

title: Teslas Earnings Indicate Some Customer Cancellations
description: 9:30 p.m. | Updated

title: With PlayStation 4, Sony Aims for Return to Glory
description: For the Sony Corporation, a tech industry also-ran, the moment of reckoning is here.

title: Deal Advances Development of a Smaller Nuclear Reactor
description: WASHINGTON  The Tennessee Valley Authority will pay Babcock & Wilcox, a nuclear equipment company, to complete extensive design work and apply for permission to build a new kind of nuclear plant, a small modular reactor, at a site in Oak Ridge, Tenn., the T.V.A. and the company announced on Wednesday.

title: Assad Denies Starting War in New Interview
description: Last Updated, Thursday, 3:48 p.m. The Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, denied in an interview broadcast last week on German television that he was responsible for starting the bloody conflict tearing his country apart.

title: Posada Is Set to Help, as Berra Helped Him
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: Human Rights Watch Faults Mexico Over Disappearances
description: MEXICO CITY  Nearly 150 people and possibly hundreds more have disappeared at the hands of Mexicos police and military during the drug war with little or no investigation of the cases, a human rights group said Wednesday, as it called on the new government to account for the countrys missing.

title: Justices Eye Limitations on Offering Information
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday about whether Virginia may permit only its own citizens to make requests under the states freedom of information act.

title: Cult Beer Alters Town, but Not the Monks Who Make It
description: VLETEREN, Belgium  On the face of it, this quaint Belgian town has few attractions  a charming brick parish church; a tall wooden windmill at the towns main intersection. But it has the worlds best beer.

title: Louisiana: Nagin Pleads Not Guilty
description: The former mayor of New Orleans, C. Ray Nagin, pleaded not guilty in federal court on Wednesday to 21 counts of bribery, corruption and money laundering. A federal grand jury last month charged Mr. Nagin with giving favorable treatment to city vendors and contractors in return for cash, trips and benefits for his familys granite installation company. At the arraignment on Wednesday, Magistrate Judge Sally Shushan said that Mr. Nagin was allowed to go free on a $100,000 bond, and that his travel would be restricted to Texas, where he now lives, and Louisiana.

title: 1 in 5 Passed Advanced Placement Tests
description: Nearly a third of the nations 2012 public high school graduates took at least one of the College Boards Advanced Placement tests, according to the programs annual report on Wednesday. Nearly one in five got a passing score  three or more, out of five  on one of the 34 subject exams. Last year was the first time in a decade that the average exam score increased from the previous year. The share of students earning at least a 3 also rose for the first time in that period, and the 14.2 percent earning a top score of five was also the highest in the decade.

title: Renewal of AIDS Program Backed
description: The 10-year-old program to fight global AIDS started by the Bush administration is doing a good job and should be funded again after it expires this year, a panel of medical experts recommended Wednesday. But countries getting aid should be pushed to manage more of their own programs and pay more of the costs, the panel said. The experts, from the Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academies of Science, were asked by Congress to evaluate the Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, which has spent about $38 billion. In 2007, the institute criticized Congressional restrictions, saying too much money went to abstinence education. The new report said the program had become increasingly flexible about preventing H.I.V. infections, but needs to do more about sexual transmission. It also needs to do better at getting patients into medical care and assuring that they take their antiretroviral drugs daily.

title: Amid Questions on Ethics, Battle-Tested Senator Digs In
description: He has taken to little-used routes in the nations Capitol to avoid attention. His allies have hinted at conspiracies hatched against him, perhaps by shadowy enemies in Cuba. And he has even hired a prominent lawyer well versed in Congressional investigations.

title: Missouri: Body Found in Rubble
description: A body was recovered in the bar area of the rubble of a popular Kansas City restaurant that exploded on Tuesday evening, officials said Wednesday. The identity had yet to be determined, the Kansas City fire chief, Paul Berardi, said during a news conference as he stood alongside Mayor Sly James. Obviously, it is sad news, Mr. James said. We also cant be sure, 100 percent, that we can account for every single person who may have been at JJs last night when the incident occurred. The explosion at the restaurant, JJs, was caused by a broken gas main and left 15 people injured, three of whom remained in critical condition on Wednesday and one of whom was in serious condition. Investigators and the Fire Department were still sifting through the layers of broken glass, bricks and other debris, hoping to get as much as possible completed before an expected winter storm.

title: Iceland Looks to Export Power Bubbling From Below
description: KRAFLA, Iceland  Soon after work began here on a power plant to harness some of the vast reserves of energy stored at the earths crust, the ground moved and, along a six-mile-long fissure, began belching red-hot lava. The eruptions continued for nine years, prompting the construction of a stone and soil barrier to make sure that molten rock did not incinerate Icelands first geothermal power station.

title: New Chatter Around First Ladys Portrait
description: Four years ago, the buzz was all about the arms when the White House unveiled the official photo portrait of first lady Michelle Obama. Now it is all about the bangs.

title: State Aims to Lift Curbs on a Lottery That Beguiles
description: Pronto Lotto does not look like much. It sits outside the entrance to a busy subway stop in Elmhurst, Queens, supplying passers-by with cereal, chips and milk like any other bodega.

title: Who Will Mind the Drones?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Cry, the Misogynistic Country
description: JOHANNESBURG

title: Plan Would Let State Take Control of Citys Teacher Evaluation System
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo proposed a measure on Wednesday that would establish a new teacher evaluation system for New York City if the Bloomberg administration and the teachers union remained at odds over adopting one.

title: The More Things Change
description: Despite spending a lot of time reading and thinking about the Voting Rights Act case the Supreme Court will hear next week, theres a puzzle Im still trying to crack:

title:
G.O.P. Is Resisting
Obama Pressure on
Tax Increase
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans, shrugging off rising pressure from President Obama, are resolutely opposing new tax increases to head off $85 billion in across-the-board spending reductions, all but ensuring the cuts will go into force March 1 and probably remain in place for months, if not longer.

title: WWS 594E, Economics of the Welfare State: Class 3
description: Retirement (pdf).

title: Debbie Ford, Author of Self-Help Books, Is Dead at 57
description: Debbie Ford, a former drug addict whose popular self-help books, including the best-selling Dark Side of the Light Chasers, encouraged people to acknowledge their faults rather than pursue perfection, died on Sunday at her home in San Diego. She was 57.

title: Budget Cuts Seen as Risk to Growth of U.S. Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The fresh round of federal spending cuts scheduled to begin next week would slow economic growth in the next year, though not nearly as much as going over the so-called fiscal cliff might have, economists said.

title: Tucson Takes on the Gun Lobby
description: As lawmakers in Congress bob and weave around the issue of assault weapons, officials in numerous statehouses and city halls are feeling pressure to act to protect their communities. Among the more encouraging steps was a unanimous decision this month by the Tucson City Council to move toward requiring background checks at gun shows at city-owned facilities.

title: Following the Compass Home
description: For centuries, humans have been studying the historic dispersal of our species across the planet. We can trace the movement of populations, now using genetic samples, with extraordinary detail.

title: A Trans-Atlantic Grand Bargain
description: President Obama and European Union leaders last week kick-started an ambitious effort to negotiate a free-trade agreement that would cover nearly half of the worlds economy. A balanced deal that reduces trade barriers and offers sensible regulatory standards could give a significant boost to the global economy and renew Americas most important alliance.

title: Our M.I.A. Surgeon General
description: When CBS airs its newly commissioned pilot The Surgeon General, Dr. John Sherman  the most powerful doctor in the nation  will become the best-known (albeit fictional) surgeon general since C. Everett Koop. No one I asked (including a member of Congress) could name the current one.

title: A Game of Chicken
description: Well, here we go again. Another season, another manufactured, self-inflicted, completely preventable crisis of government. This time its the sequester.

title: Supreme Court Limits Reach of 2010 Ruling on Deportation Warning
description: WASHINGTON  In 2010, the Supreme Court ruled that criminal defense lawyers must warn their clients if deportation could be a consequence of a guilty plea. On Wednesday, the court limited the reach of that ruling, saying it did not apply retroactively to people whose convictions had become final by the time the justices announced their 2010 decision, Padilla v. Kentucky.

title: Peculiar Naming Rites
description: The Postal Service is looking to launch a clothing line.

title: Google Searches for Style
description: People wearing Googles glasses are transported to a strange new world in which the Internet is always in their line of sight. But for people looking at the people wearing those glasses, the view is even stranger  someone wearing a computer processor, a battery and a tiny screen on her face.

title: Immigration Reform and Workers Rights
description: Members of Congress and President Obama have been working in earnest to deliver on their promise to overhaul immigration this year. Mr. Obama would clearly prefer a bipartisan bill, and last week the Senate Judiciary Committee held its first hearing on possible changes in immigration law. News reports last weekend suggested that the White House would fashion its own bill should negotiations between Republican and Democratic supporters of reform collapse.

title: Testing Cosmetics for Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns and Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Targeted Killings Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Online U.: A Look at the Rankings
description: To the Editor:

title: New Federal Rule Requires Insurers to Offer Mental Health Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration issued a final rule on Wednesday defining essential health benefits that must be offered by most health insurance plans next year, and it said that 32 million people would gain access to coverage of mental health care as a result.

title: Too Many Restrictions on Sex Offenders, or Too Few?
Reporters in Syria See No End in Sight
description: It has been nearly two years since Syrias president, Bashar al-Assad, deployed troops to clear the streets of first peaceful protesters and then armed rebels intent on overthrowing him.

title: To Block Gaza Tunnels, Egypt Lets Sewage Flow
description: GAZA The Egyptian military is resorting to a pungent new tactic to shut down the smuggling tunnels connecting Sinai and Gaza: flooding them with sewage. Along with the stink, the approach is raising new questions about relations between Egypts new Islamist leaders and their ideological allies in Hamas who control the Gaza Strip.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Feb. 21, 2013.
description: Do the right thing and fall further behind.

title: Oscar Broadcast Rivals Super Bowl as Showcase for Ads
description: THIS year, Madison Avenue seems to be anticipating the Oscars as much as Hollywood.

title: Steinems Support for Quinn as Mayor Depends on Sick-Leave Bill
description: Gloria Steinem, the feminist author and activist, said this week that she would withdraw her support for Christine C. Quinn in the New York City mayors race if Ms. Quinn, speaker of the City Council, did not allow a vote on sick-leave legislation that is a cherished cause of liberal groups.

title: $500 Million Chasm Opens in Proposed State Budget
description: A $500 million hole has opened in Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos proposed state budget because of changes in how Washington plans to reimburse the state for the care of people with developmental disabilities, the governor said on Wednesday.

title: From New York, Making Guns the Issue in a Chicago Race
description: STEGER, Ill.  On the second floor of a firehouse in this Chicago suburb, Debbie Halvorson, a candidate for Congress, let the news cameras zoom in as her fingerprints were taken  the final step in her application for a license to carry a concealed firearm in 31 states.

title: Betting on Trade, Center Claimed a New Role
description: TORONTO  Two years ago, after holding out and requesting a trade from the Phoenix Coyotes, center Kyle Turris was labeled as having an attitude problem. But 66 games into his tenure with the Ottawa Senators, Turriss gamble is paying off.

title: Workers Who Protested Sale of Carwash Will Get New Jobs
description: Less than two weeks ago, workers at the Sixth Avenue Car Wash in Greenwich Village dropped their sponges and walked out for several hours, protesting the owners decision to close the shop, a move they saw as retaliation for their recent decision to unionize.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Mets Latest Problem Comes From Off the Field
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets outfield headaches have not been confined to the field.

title: Happy With Tourist Influx, City Wants Still More Visitors
description: New York City residents who feel besieged by foreign tourists have Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to blame for the onslaught. Or, as he sees it, to thank.

title: Corrections: February 21, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Anatomy of a PAC Attack
description: This timeline shows how Independence USA, the super PAC created by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, has spent $2.1 million on the campaign to pick Jesse Jackson Jr.s successor in the House.

title: Verrry Interesting
description: Administrivial Liz Gorski Alert! A message about a special puzzle event at the U.S.S. Intrepid, from constructor Liz Gorski: Ahoy! When the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum asked me to create a crossword puzzle for Kids Week 2013, I jumped at the chance. Kids love the interactive fun: Virtual Flight Zones, Cockpit Simulators, sports, entertainment, games. The Intrepid is an Essex-class aircraft carrier located @ 12th Avenue at 46th St. (its floating in the Hudson). The puzzle will be available through Sunday, Feb. 24.

title: Irked British Judge Sets Retrial for Ex-Wife of Ex-Official
description: LONDON  After nearly 15 hours of jury deliberations over four days, a judge on Wednesday abruptly ordered a retrial for Vicky Pryce, the ex-wife of a former energy minister, who became entangled in a feud with her husband over a decision 10 years ago to accept responsibility for a speeding ticket he incurred on a highway outside London.

title: Some Victims of Online Hacking Edge Into the Light
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hackers have hit thousands of American corporations in the last few years, but few companies ever publicly admit it. Most treat online attacks as a dirty secret best kept from customers, shareholders and competitors, lest the disclosure sink their stock price and tarnish them as hapless.

title: Chvez Family Encouraged, Bolivia Leader Says at U.N.
description: President Evo Morales of Bolivia said Wednesday that Hugo Chvez, the cancer-stricken president of Venezuela and one of his closest friends, had endured most difficult moments and that Mr. Chvezs doctors and family were encouraged now that he had returned home, more than two months after surgery and convalescence in Cuba.

title: In Their First Game After the Break, the Knicks Fail at Everything
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Knicks said they would change their losing ways. They vowed to be the team they were in November, not the one that struggled into the All-Star break, losing four of their last five games. They would smartly pass the ball to one another, make intelligent decisions and play defense. But sometimes, talk can be just that  talk.

title: White House Tactic for C.I.A. Bid Holds Back Drone Memos
description: WASHINGTON  The White House is refusing to share fully with Congress the legal opinions that justify targeted killings, while maneuvering to make sure its stance does not do anything to endanger the confirmation of John O. Brennan as C.I.A. director.

title: Admitting to Security Breaches
description: Some of the major companies that have recently acknowledged being hacked seriously enough to compromise their computer networks.

title: Lawyers Seek Final Appeal for Man Due to Be Executed
description: MIAMI  Lawyers for a man scheduled to be executed in Florida on Feb. 26 for killing a state trooper filed a motion in federal court on Wednesday arguing that the prisoner had been wrongly denied his final appeal because of a missed filing deadline.

title: Virginia Lawmakers Pass Photo-ID Requirement for Voters
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Virginia lawmakers on Wednesday adopted a strict photo identification requirement for voters, a contentious issue nationally in last years presidential election.

title: After Super Bowl Success, a New Local Ad for Dunder Mifflin
description: A new technique for gaining attention during the busy Super Bowl advertising season is to do the opposite of spending many millions of dollars to run a commercial nationally during the game: Spend a small sum to run a spot in a handful of local markets, perhaps even in only one such market.

title: Routed by Katrina, Stuck in Quagmire of Rules
description: NEW ORLEANS  Errol Joseph has the doorknobs. He has the doors, too, as well as a bathtub and a couple of sinks, stacks of drywall, a hot water heater, pipes, an air-conditioner compressor, and big pink rolls of insulation. They are sitting in a shed.

title: Nets Rally Past Bucks and Close in on Division Lead
description: MILWAUKEE  For three quarters Wednesday night, the Nets looked overmatched by the Milwaukee Bucks and their electric point guard Brandon Jennings.

title: A Go Local Focus Is Used to Resolve Unpaid Wages
description: MIAMI  Compared with many other states, Florida has not been hospitable to the cause of worker rights.

title: Universities Abroad Join Partnerships on the Web
description: Over the last year, elite American universities have raced to stake out a place in the new world of free online courses  and now, universities around the globe are following suit.

title: The Benefits of Exercising Outdoors
description: While the allure of the gym  climate-controlled, convenient and predictable  is obvious, especially in winter, emerging science suggests there are benefits to exercising outdoors that cant be replicated on a treadmill, a recumbent bicycle or a track.

title: Word of the Day | acquittal
description: acquittal \-kwi-tl\ noun

title: Children in U.S. Are Eating Fewer Calories, Study Finds
description: American children consumed fewer calories in 2010 than they did a decade before, a new federal analysis shows. Health experts said the findings offered an encouraging sign that the epidemic of obesity might be easing, but cautioned that the magnitude of the decline was too small to move the needle much.

title: Chinese Ask About Cultural Revolution Case: What of the Ringleaders?
description: BEIJING  Its reminiscent, perhaps, of the trials of people accused of Nazi-era crimes, a John Demjanjuk, or a Samuel K.: in China this week, a man was tried for murdering a doctor during the Cultural Revolution, The China News Service reported.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 7 P.M. (HBO2) HANNA (2011) Saoirse Ronan, above, stars as a teenage assassin trying to elude a ruthless Central Intelligence Agency operative (Cate Blanchett) and her two huntsmen in this action movie from Joe Wright, who also directed Ms. Ronan in her Oscar-nominated role in Atonement. Eric Bana is the warrior father, wrapped in animal skins, who has trained Hanna from childhood in northern Finland to become a killing machine. In the end there might not be much to this tale other than titillation, but theres plenty to be said for Ms. Ronan, who was the best thing about Atonement and holds her ground against forceful screen presences like Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Bana, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. That Ms. Ronans translucent blue eyes, transformed here into opaque pools, dont reveal much is part of the big surprise, as well as a liability in a movie that is by turns startling and generic, subtle and blunt, and consistently keeps you in its grip if not its heart, Ms. Dargis added.

title: In Praise of Bangla, My Mother Tongue
description: I take pride in the fact that despite being born and raised in New York City, I speak Bangla fluently. I credit this mostly to my Bangladeshi parents for being brutal in their approach to teaching my younger sister and me a language that that was so violently fought for.

title: News Quiz | February 21, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Police Replace Pistorius Detective in Setback
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  In the latest in a series of abrupt twists in the Oscar Pistorius homicide case, the South African police replaced the lead investigator on Thursday after revelations that he was facing seven charges of attempted murder stemming from an episode in which police officers fired at a minivan.

title: Fish Are Commonly Mislabeled, Study Finds
description: A new nationwide study by Oceana, a nonprofit ocean conservation group, has found that the mislabeling of fish sold in U.S. retail outlets is common.

title: Survey Finds That Fish Are Often Not What Label Says
description: SEATTLE  Many Europeans are fretting these days over horse meat, and whether it might have adulterated their shepherds pie. Over here, its all about the red snapper.

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 21
description: NEWS In a little-noticed trial in a small courtroom in Cyprus, a 24-year-old man provided a rare look inside a covert global war between Israel and Iran, admitting that he is an operative of the militant group Hezbollah, for which he acted as a courier in Europe and staked out locations that Israelis were known to frequent. Nicholas Kulish reports from Limassol, Cyprus.

title: A Home for Fashion Nerds Gets a New Look
description: Imran Amed started his blog The Business of Fashion about five years ago on his sofa. I had no idea where it would lead, he said the other day in London. Mr. Amed, a Harvard Business School graduate and a former McKinsey consultant, had decided to turn his career in another direction, or rather, perhaps, expand it. He is one for taking on several hats, including writer and teacher, at Central Saint Martins.

title: One Last Pas de Deux for Stars of the Royal Ballet
description: LONDONOn Thursday night at Covent Garden, Sergei Polunin and Tamara Rojo will give their last performance, for the foreseeable future, with the Royal Ballet in Frederick Ashtons Marguerite and Armand, a condensed retelling of the Traviata story that was created in 1963 for Margot Fonteyn and her much younger new partner, Rudolf Nureyev.

title: VW Introducing a Hot Diesel Hatch for Europe
description: To Americans with lingering memories of General Motors diesel cars of the 1970s and underpowered import oil burners of yesteryear, diesel performance may be an oxymoron. In Europe, that is not the case, and Volkswagen will underscore the diesels old-world performance credentials next month at the Geneva auto show when it introduces a new and more potent version of its Golf GTD sports hatch for the European market.

title: As Indian Parliament Session Opens, Much Work to Be Done
description: Indias parliament starts a new session on Thursday with a massive agenda.

title: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 21, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article A Prodigy on the Way to Stardom.

title: More Companies Requiring College Degree for All Positions
description: In It Takes a B.A. to Find a Job as a File Clerk, Catherine Rampell writes about how an increasing number of companies are requiring a college degree for all positions.

title: Biswas Nath, the Cycle Shop Owner from Uttar Pradesh
description: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this years 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.

title: New Leader of China Plans a Visit to Moscow
description: BEIJING  The Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, has selected Moscow as his first foreign capital to visit as president, to be followed immediately by a trip to South Africa for a summit meeting of the group of leading emerging-market countries.

title: Looking Beyond the Literal
description: Armando L. Sanchez is a 25-year-old freelance photographer who was born and raised in Austin, Tex., and is now based in Chicago. He studied photography at Western Kentucky University and received a B.A in interdisciplinary studies last year. He has had four  yes, count them, four  newspaper internships: at The Tennessean in Nashville, The Saginaw News in Michigan, The State Journal-Register in Springfield, Ill., and most recently at The Chicago Tribune.

title: Where Should Colleges and Sports Teams Draw the Line in Selling Naming Rights?
description: Companies often pay big money for the right to attach their name to a sports stadium, college football bowl game or even athletic team (think New York Red Bulls). But does corporate naming ever cross the line? This week, Florida Atlantic University announced its plan to rename its football stadium after a multibillion-dollar private prison corporation. What do you think?

title: Twelve Angry Central Bankers
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Classes Warfare
description: NEW DELHI  It was a widely awaited verdict: Tens of thousands of parents seeking admission for their children to nursery schools in New Delhi were hoping for some remedy against a system that rewards inherited privilege and access to political power. But the High Court of Delhi upheld the status quo on Tuesday.

title: MaxMara: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Italian Police Arrest Man in Soccer Match-Fixing Inquiry
description: ROME  The police in Singapore said Thursday that the Asian man thought to be at the center of a global soccer match-fixing network was now cooperating with them, even as the Italian police said they had made an important breakthrough, detaining a key suspect.

title: One Phone Call From Disaster
description: One morning in May 2004, Steve Ciepiela, co-owner of a financial planning and wealth management firm, heard his phone ring while he was in his garage. It was the office manager. She told Mr. Ciepiela that his partner in the firm, Charles Stephens & Company, had just had a brain aneurysm and was in critical condition. Within 24 hours, he had died.

title: On the Enduring Appeal of Die Hard
description: With the release of A Good Day to Die Hard, the fifth film in the Die Hard series, the cinematic life span of John McClane has been elongated to a robust 10 hours  longer than sturdy pop icons like Ellen Ripley, Indiana Jones and John Rambo (four films each) and Michael Corleone (three films and nine hours). Once you add in the fact that McClane has appeared on-screen in four different decades, hes arguably the most durable contemporary American film character not named Batman or Rocky Balboa.

title: How Come Martin Brodeur Is Still So Good?
