title: 3 City Leaders Squabble Over Fines for Businesses
description: On the surface, it was a simple skirmish over New Yorks rising fines against small businesses, an everyday nuisance of municipal life.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Feb. 22, 2013
description: "There are three reasons for this war: tribe, land and politics.

title: Despite Aid, Borrowers Still Face Foreclosure
description: A year after five of the nations biggest banks reached a pact with state and federal officials over claims of vast foreclosure abuses, the banks are taking credit for giving more than half a million struggling homeowners roughly $45.8 billion in relief.

title: Deadbeat Father Pleads Guilty to Evading Child Support
description: A man who owed more than $1 million in child support and was labeled the nations most-wanted deadbeat parent by federal authorities pleaded guilty on Thursday to traveling across state lines and overseas to avoid making his child-support payments.

title: Judge Says State Cannot Withhold Aid to City Schools Over Teacher Evaluation Impasse
description: State officials, for now, cannot stop $260 million in aid from flowing into New York Citys schools as a penalty for the citys failure to iron out a plan for evaluating public school teachers, a state judge ruled this week.

title: Lottery Numbers
Patrick, Primed for a Sunday Drive, Takes No Chances
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The only way to mar the heavily promoted storybook start to the 2013 Sprint Cup season would have been for the Nascar darling Danica Patrick to crash in a qualifying race Thursday at Daytona International Speedway and lose her place on the pole for Sundays season-opening Daytona 500.

title: Corrections: February 22, 2013
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Lord of the Ring
description: Administrivial A.C.P.T. Alert! If you plan to be in the New York area March 8-10 for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, there is still time to sign up for the Friday night Cru Dinner, an unofficial regular part of the festivities. Hosted by puzzlers who hark back to the old crosswords forum  and thats a lot of harking, believe me  the Cru Dinner is a great way to meet your fellow puzzleheads if youre a first timer, and a wonderful way to catch up with old friends if youre a veteran. Click here for more information about how to register for the dinner.

title: A Titans How-To on Breaking the Glass Ceiling
description: Before Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, started to write Lean In, her book-slash-manifesto on women in the workplace, she rereadBetty Friedans The Feminine Mystique. Like the homemaker turned activist who helped start a revolution 50 years ago, Ms. Sandberg wanted to do far more than sell books.

title: Court Temporarily Halts Plan to Close a Brooklyn Hospital
description: A state judge has temporarily halted plans to close the financially ailing Long Island College Hospital, giving a victory to hospital workers who say that its closing would be devastating to community health care.

title: Sheryl Sandbergs Lean In Foundation and Movement
description: Documents circulated by Lean In to potential partners explain what Sheryl Sandberg is trying to do  and also suggest why she is already attracting criticism.

title: The Rise of a Protest Movement Shows the Depth of Italys Disillusionment
description: ROME  For months, he has been shouting his way from piazza to piazza, drawing tens of thousands as he rails against tax collectors, corrupt politicians and financial speculation. And when he arrives in Rome on Friday for the final campaign rally of his Tsunami tour, Beppe Grillo, the Internet-savvy comedian turned populist rabble-rouser, may lead Italys third-most popular party.

title: After Shipping Off Brewer, the Knicks Add Martin to an Already Volatile Mix
description: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson wanted a roster infused with experience and passion. Lately, the experience has looked more like old age, and the passion has turned to volatility.

title: A Retiring General Notes the Price We Have Paid
description: WASHINGTON  In a reflective farewell on Wednesday evening, Gen. John R. Allen recalled a recent trip to Section 60 of Arlington National Cemetery where, he said, you can see the entire swath of the American experience in Afghanistan.

title: Russia Backs Off Claim of Murder in Death of Adopted Boy in Texas
description: MOSCOW  Russian officials retreated from allegations of murder against a Texas woman whose 3-year-old son adopted from Russia died in late January, as investigators in the United States said the cause of the boys death remained unclear.

title: Space Holiday by Powerful Robot
description: Video game companies like Powerful Robot, which has developed for clients in the United States, are finding a base in Montevideo, Uruguay.

title: D.E.D. by Trojan Chicken
description: D.E.D., a detective game in which players solve thefts of national heritage, is designed to be played on inexpensive laptops distributed to schoolchildren across Uruguay.

title: Pastoral Uruguay Yields a Crop of Digital Yetis and Adventures
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay  For a start-up that has a hit video game for the iPhone, the new loft-style offices of Ironhide Game Studio are exactly what one would expect  a newly hired staff labors feverishly on software updates not far from a pinball machine and custom-built monster arcade cabinet intended for letting off steam.

title: Robert C. Richardson, Laureate in Physics, Dies at 75
description: Robert C. Richardson, who shared the 1996 Nobel Prize in Physics for coaxing a rare form of helium into a bizarre liquid state that had never been seen before, died on Tuesday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Man Acquitted in Officers Death Gets 2 Years for Probation Violation
description: A man who was acquitted of murder last week for his alleged role as the getaway driver in the fatal shooting of a New York police officer was sentenced on Thursday to two years in prison for violating his probation in an unrelated case.

title: Venezuela: Chvez Continues Treatment
description: President Hugo Chvez continues to be treated for breathing problems two months after having cancer surgery in Cuba, a government spokesman said Thursday. Mr. Chvez returned to Venezuela on Monday but has not been seen in public since before his Dec. 11 operation. The respiratory deficiency that arose in the course of the postoperative period persists, and its tendency has not been favorable, for which reason he continues to be treated, the information minister, Ernesto Villegas, said in the first official update on the presidents health since his return. He did not say what the treatment was, but last week he said the president had a tube inserted in his trachea to aid in breathing.

title: Germany: Morning-After Pill Allowed for the Victims of Rape, Bishops Say
description: In a softening of their hard-line stance toward the use of contraception, Germanys Roman Catholic bishops said Thursday that hospitals run by the church could provide women who had been raped with versions of the morning-after pill that prevent fertilization. The Catholic Church has faced strong criticism after a rape victim was recently turned away by two hospitals it runs in Cologne, because staff members were concerned about having to counsel the woman about emergency contraception. In a statement issued Thursday, the bishops said they had not been aware that various forms of emergency contraception were available, and after consulting with medical experts and with the Vatican, agreed that administering drugs that in no way aborted a fertilized egg was justified in cases of rape. The bishops said the new policy would be discussed with hospitals run by the church to ensure that women who have been the victims of rape are provided human, medical, psychological and pastoral support, which could include administration of the morning-after pill.

title: Somalia: U.S. Promises More Food Aid
description: An American delegation led by the administrator of the Agency for International Development, Rajiv Shah, met with Somali leaders in Mogadishu, the capital, on Thursday and announced $20 million in new American food aid for Somalia. Mr. Shah said that after two decades of conflict, famine and terrorism, it was necessary not only to address Somalias critical emergency needs but also to promote stability and recovery. It is important now to build a government and capacity for this country to become self-sufficient and to prosper economically so that children dont die because they dont have food to eat, Mr. Shah said. In January, Washington formally recognized Somalias government for the first time since 1991.

title: Cmon, Knicks: Go Bold. Go Old.
description: As the N.B.A. trading deadline approached Thursday afternoon, the Knicks sent 27-year-old guard Ronnie Brewer to the Thunder for a draft pick. That left the Knicks with a roster spot to fill, and a few hours later they said they were going to sign 35-year-old forward Kenyon Martin, who has yet to play an N.B.A. game this season. By replacing Brewer with Martin, the Knicks, who started the season as the oldest team in N.B.A. history, got even older. Surely a team that in the off-season signed Rasheed Wallace, a 38-year-old who had been out of the N.B.A. for two years, has more vision than that. Here are some suggestions.

title: Martin Zweig, Who Forecast 87 Market Crash, Dies at 70
description: Martin Zweig, an influential investor and television pundit who predicted the 1987 stock market crash, published a closely followed newsletter and in 1999 made what at the time was the most expensive residential purchase in New York history, died on Monday at his home in Fisher Island, Fla. He was 70.

title: Otto Beisheim, German Retailing Pioneer, Dies at 89
description: BERLIN  Otto Beisheim, who revolutionized retailing in postwar Germany by introducing the concept of selling wholesale goods directly to customers and the builder of the countrys largest retailer, Metro, was found dead on Monday at his home in Bavaria. He was 89.

title: Taking a Stand for 46 Hours
description: I was driving my daughter home from college last year when we stopped at Penn State to visit a couple of her friends. I treated them to breakfast when they urged me to do a story on Thon.

title: First Winners of Kennedy Playwriting Prize Announced
description: Two plays, Dan OBriens Body of an American and Robert Schenkkans All the Way, are the inaugural winners of the Edward M. Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History, Columbia University and one of the late senators sisters, Jean Kennedy Smith, will announce on Friday. The two writers will each receive $50,000 and collaborate with Columbia librarians to create Web sites featuring scholarly articles and discussion relating to the content of the plays.

title: Word of the Day | ethos
description: ethos \e-ths\ noun

title: Pat Derby, Champion of Animal Welfare, Dies at 69
description: Pat Derby, a former animal trainer for television shows like Lassie and Flipper who became a crusader against animal exploitation in entertainment and founded of one of the largest privately operated wildlife sanctuaries in the United States, died last Friday at her home in San Andreas, Calif. She was 69.

title: Kevin Ayers, a Psychedelic Rocker, Dies at 68
description: Kevin Ayers, a wayward, witty British rocker who helped shape early psychedelia and was admired throughout his hard-lived life as a musicians musician with little appetite for stardom, died on Monday at his home in the town of Montolieu, in the South of France. He was 68.

title: North Korea Widens Internet Access, but Just for Visitors
description: HONG KONG  North Korea will finally allow Internet searches on mobile devices and laptops. But if youre a North Korean, youre out of luck  only foreigners will get this privilege.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) SISTER ROSETTA THARPE: THE GODMOTHER OF ROCK & ROLL From the 1940s through the 60s, Ms. Tharpe (1915-73), above, accompanying herself on a newly electrified guitar, introduced spiritual passion into the secular world of rock n roll and inspired stars like Chuck Berry, Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis and Little Richard. American Masters begins its 27th season with this chronicle of Ms. Tharpes life, from her impoverished childhood as the daughter of cotton pickers in Arkansas and her adolescence in Chicago, where she developed her distinctive performing style in church, to her move to New York. There she caught the eye of Cab Calloway and Duke Ellington through songs laden with sexual innuendo at the Cotton Club and Caf Society. But soon she returned to her gospel roots and drew packed houses throughout the United States and Europe. Directed by Mick Csaky, this documentary merges archival performance footage with new interviews with Joe Boyd, the tour manager of the 1964 American Folk, Blues and Gospel Caravan; Howard Carroll of the Dixie Hummingbirds; Roxie Moore, a lifelong friend; and Gayle Wald, a Tharpe biographer.

title: As Deaths Rise in Hyderabad Blasts, Questions Emerge Over Ignored Warnings
description: Updated at 3:00 p.m. ISTThe death toll from Thursdays explosions in Hyderabad has risen to 16, officials said Friday, and the number of injured is more than 100.

title: News Quiz | February 22, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 22
description: NEWS In Spain, an intensifying investigation aimed at Iaki Urdangarin, the Duke of Palma and the kings son-in-law, has placed the palace under siege. Doreen Carvajal reports from Madrid.

title: Warning Signs Seen Ahead of India Bombings
description: NEW DELHI  The death toll from Thursdays explosions in Hyderabad, India, rose on Friday to 16 people, as new information about Indias deadliest bombing since 2011 suggested the attacks had been long planned, raising questions about whether they could have been prevented.

title: Pistorius Is Granted Bail in Killing of Girlfriend
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  After four days of combative hearings, a South African magistrate on Friday granted bail for Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, in a case that has horrified and fascinated the nation and much of the world.

title: Can Doordarshans New Look Attract Profits?
description: After it became the first TV channel in India in 1959, the public broadcaster Doordarshan enjoyed a monopoly on viewership for decades. Even after the government opened the airwaves to private players in 1992, Doordarshan enjoyed a 90 percent share of the audience in the 1990s and had no reason to take the threat of competition seriously.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Feb. 22, 2013
description: As of Feb. 15, were posting new questions each Friday that test your editing skills. To learn more about why we are substituting these for the critical thinking questions wed previously asked, see our note.

title: 3-D Printers Might Be the Must-Have Gadget of the Future
description: In A Factory on Your Kitchen Counter, Steven Kurutz writes about 3-D printers available for the consumer market.

title: Russia Sends Aid to Mali as Fighting Flares
description: MOSCOW  Russia sent a planeload of food, blankets and other aid to war-stricken Mali on Friday, a day after Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov warned about the spread of terrorism in North Africa, which the Russian government has linked to Western intervention in Libya.

title: Chinese Buoys Are Focus of Latest Dispute Over Contested Islands
description: TOKYO  Japan has asked the Chinese government to explain why Chinese ships have strategically placed several buoys in the East China Sea near a group of disputed islands, a Japanese government spokesman said on Friday.

title: Have You Ever Found Something Valuable?
description: Residents in some Siberian towns in Russia are searching for meteorite fragments buried in deep snow and lodged in roof tiles after last Fridays fiery explosion in the sky. Speculators are offering upward of a thousand dollars for pebbles, and Russians are pondering what to do with the treasure they find.

title: Renewed Signs of Europes Economic Weakness
description: BRUSSELS  Despite growing confidence that Europe is managing its debt crisis and is poised to embark on a recovery, fresh developments on Friday indicated that the region continues to struggle to stimulate growth while cutting spending to pare deficits.

title: Moschino: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

description: In Todays Times:

title: Daily Report: Digital Access to Runway Fashion
description: Fashion Week, which wrapped up last week in New York and moved on to London and to Milan this week, used to be an insular industry event. Buyers and editors attended and made calls as to what their customers would want months from now.

title: For Traumatized Caregivers, Therapy Helps
description: I recently wrote about caregivers who experienced symptoms of traumatic-like stress, and readers responded with heart-rending stories. Many described being haunted by distress long after a relative died.

title: Q&A: Moving the Macs Dock
description: Q.

title: Bala Panditji, a Priest from Delhi
description: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this years 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.

title: Learning Social Media Tricks From the Big Boys
description: If you still have doubts about whether social media marketing can be effective, heres a quote from a recent Bain & Company study that you might find interesting: Customers who engage with companies over social media spend 20 percent to 40 percent more money with those companies than other customers. They also demonstrate a deeper emotional commitment to the companies, granting them an average 33 points higher net promoter score, a common measure of customer loyalty.

title: General Electric Chief Remains Cautiously Optimistic About India
description: NEW DELHI  On a visit to India, the head of one of the worlds largest companies painted a fairly optimistic portrait of Indias growth prospects, although he hinted that Indian policy makers had reasons for concern.

title: The Meat of the Matter
description: LONDON  The sun was shining in North London on Wednesday, but the wind was cold and biting, so the vegetable packers were working indoors. Two of them  a young man in a hooded top and a woman with long blond hair  were weighing onions and sorting them into brown paper bags.

title: Would You Cut Down on Meat to Help the Environment?
description: The phrase I could eat a horse has acquired a new meaning in Europe, where horse DNA has been found in products labeled as beef on supermarket shelves.

title: For Kyrie Irving, a Milestone Week
description: For a 20-year-old manning the games toughest position, Kyrie Irving has second-year numbers that have been increasingly eye-popping: 23.5 points, 5.5 assists, 1.7 steals, a true shooting percentage of just under 57 percent (including 42.5 percent on 3-pointers), and a player efficiency rating of 22.3.

title: Critical Differences Belie Hopes for a Grand Bargain
description: WASHINGTON  Even as President Obama lashes out at Republicans over the automatic spending cuts that take effect next week, he is simultaneously sending them a strikingly different message: he is still interested in a big deficit-reduction deal and as evidence of his good faith has left on the table proposed Medicare and Social Security cuts that liberals hate.

title: Oscar Predictions, Election-Style
description: Twice before, in 2009 and 2011, I sought to predict the Academy Award winners in six major categories based on a mix of statistical factors. My track record? Nine correct picks in 12 tries, for a 75 percent success rate. Not bad, but also not good enough to suggest that there is any magic formula for this.

title: Opinion Report: Hydrocodone
description: From the editorial page

title: Etro: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: The Lichtenstein You Know, and the One You May Not
description: LONDON  At a preview of Lichtenstein: A Retrospective, at the Tate Modern earlier this week, a man pushed a toddler in a stroller as he considered the artwork. Both studied the paintings with apparently equal interest, which you could understand, since the bold patterns, the thick, graphic outlines and bright colors of Roy Lichtensteins work often resemble the simple, eye-catching illustrations of a childs book or comic.

title: Friday Reading: A List of Overused Medical Tests
Banning Corzine Proves Problematic
description: BANNING CORZINE PROVES PROBLEMATIC | The National Futures Association, the self-regulatory group for the futures industry, faced an obstacle in considering a lifetime ban for Jon S. Corzine, the former Democratic senator who ran the now-defunct MF Global: Mr. Corzine isnt a member, DealBooks Ben Protess writes.

title: In Dells Waning Cash Flows, Signs of Concern
description: The proposed Dell buyout may be motivated more by fear than greed.

title: Russian Nationalists Say Nyet to Foreign Words
description: LONDON  Nationalist Russian legislators have introduced a bill to hold back a tide of foreign words, specifically English ones, which they claim is swamping the Russian language.

title: Running on Amnesia
description: NAIROBI  I was negotiating one of Nairobis terrifying traffic circles  a maneuver that requires jumping over a lattice of open sewers while playing chicken with a line of trucks snorting their way toward Uganda and Congo  when I was confronted with a vision to chill the heart and drop the jaw.

title: Cheating On the Delivery Guy
description: Dear Diary:

title: What They Said: Could the Hyderabad Explosions Have Been Prevented?
description: As more information emerges about the most recent bombs in Hyderabad, many in India have begun to question the role of state and central government authorities, intelligence agencies and local police, asking whether they could have done more to prevent the attacks.

title: NATO in Talks on Scale of Afghan Role After 2014 Deadline
description: BRUSSELS  NATO defense ministers meeting here on Friday said they had made progress toward planning a military assistance mission in Afghanistan after the alliances combat role expires at the end of 2014, with some partner nations already offering to participate.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Nielsen Adds Web-Linked TVs to Ratings, and a Tight Oscar Races Final Recap
description: Nielsen announced that its TV ratings would begin including viewers who watch shows on Internet-connected TVs, and pledged to include those who use iPads or other mobile devices in the future, Brian Stelter writes. Although the percentage of TV viewers who rely on the Internet exclusively is negligible, television executives are concerned that many consumers are being missed regularly. Most Internet viewings of TV shows are not counted in Nielsens ratings because they are shown without commercials or with different commercials than when they aired on television  and new streaming services, like Aereo and one in the works from Intel, stream shows and ads without cable. The expanded ratings will allow executives to count customers that these types of services may steal away from cable.

title: The Gun Report: February 22, 2013
description: There are some days when it is more difficult to read about gun violence than others. Yesterday was awful, filled with senseless shooting and the deaths of children, some shot by accident, others on purpose. Here is our report.

title: What Should the Parent of a Bully Do Next?
description: This weeks quandary comes partly from my conversation with Emily Bazelon, author of Sticks and Stones: Defeating the Culture of Bullying and Rediscovering the Power of Character and Empathy, and partly from a conversation I had with another friend about the book.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Names Chief to Lead a Major Downsizing
description: BERLIN  Alcatel-Lucent, the struggling French telecommunications equipment maker, on Friday hired a former Vodafone and France Tlcom executive, Michel Combes, to lead the company through what might be a major downsizing.

title: More Swiss Myths
description: Oh, boy  it turns out that I, too, wasnt nearly hard enough on Holtz-Eakin and Roys health care op-ed. In praising the allegedly more free-market Swiss system, they declare:

title: Robert De Niros Tears and Other Campaign Moments
description: All the other best picture biggies went to Washington, so before the Oscar voting closed, the star and writer-director of Silver Linings Playbook, Bradley Cooper and David O. Russell, turned up inside the Beltway.

title: National Parks on a Precipice
description: Unless Congress can reach a budget agreement by March 1, the countrys national parks will be hit by a $110 million budget cut, resulting in shuttered campgrounds, shorter seasons, road closings and reduced emergency services, a parks advocacy group reports.

title: Paul De Grauwe and the Rehn of Terror
description: Nobody has taught me as much about the euro crisis as Paul De Grauwe, who brought to the fore a crucial point almost everyone was overlooking: the importance of self-fulfilling debt panics in countries that no longer have their own currencies. Now he has a new paper with Yuemei Ji  following up on that insight, and offering yet more evidence of the incredible unwisdom of European economic policy.

title: What Were Reading
description: Forktales: A melancholy post about searching for great food, and finding only great tango, in Buenos Aires.  Julia Moskin

title: As Good as It Gets
description: When I was 13 or so, I watched a movie in which a young writer (played by Frank Sinatra?) and his girlfriend go to an Italian restaurant to celebrate the acceptance of his first short story. The restaurants owner is celebrating too, as are all the people sitting at the other tables, which are covered with checkerboard tablecloths and lit by candles dripping wax. Everyone wishes the writer well, no one more so than I, who tried to foresee such a moment when I, too, would become a writer. The acceptance of the story. The cheers. The girl and the life of my dreams.

title: Kids Draw the News: Micro Apartments
description: Childrens submissions of their very own, very small apartment, from a shoebox and other art supplies.

title: Up Front
description: Jess Walter, who reviews Teddy Waynes novel The Love Song of Jonny Valentine this week, was born into a blue-collar cattle ranching family in Spokane, Wash., where he still lives with his wife and three kids. My dad worked his whole life at an aluminum plant, Walter said in a recent e-mail, but he managed to keep a piece of the old ranch. There are no cattle there now, but we go up to burn slash piles of fallen timber and pull old, rusted farm equipment out of creek beds. Were slowly cleaning the place, returning it to some sort of natural state. Also, we just really like to burn things.

title: Ask Well: The Nutrients in Fruits and Veggies
description: Question:

title: Eric Stoltz Is Still All Kinds of Wonderful
description: After I came back from spending time on the set of Nashville, I had to concede that yes, Connie Britton, the star of that show and subject of my recent profile, is cool, as nine million adoring blog posts, tweets and Tumblr accounts attest (many of those posts authors developed their admiration for her when she played Tami Taylor on Friday Night Lights).

title: A Stars Circle
description: I suspect Im not alone in feeling as if, at some point, I accidentally earned a Ph.D. in Brangelina. Its not just that I can tell you the names of Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolies six children; I also can tell you their birth order and country of origin. I could write a dissertation, or perhaps teach a graduate seminar, on Pitt and Jolies past relationships, political activism and respective tattoos.

title: The Scariest Thing I Did in India
description: An auto-rickshaw is basically a lawn-mower engine encased in a cut-rate gazebo. Its a three-wheeler intended for short journeys, which is why my three friends and I had some trouble driving one from the top to the bottom of India, a country famous for its road fatalities. With only a month to make the journey, we soon abandoned our scenic route (the burning ghats, the Taj Mahal) and instead pointed south.

title: Who Made That Pantone Chip?
description: In the early 1960s, as Lawrence Herbert drove to work in a blue Cadillac with cherry red seats, he mulled over a problem: How to create a universal language of color. Herbert, the owner of the Pantone printing company, had just produced a retail display card that helped shoppers choose pantyhose. He had to hand-mix the subtle beiges of each swatch, because it was so difficult to buy the exact shade he wanted from an ink manufacturer. Each company defined colors differently, and when you ordered wheat or taupe or cream, you couldnt predict what youd get.

title: The 2.10.13 Issue
description: FRANK OCEAN CAN FLY

title: Should My Therapist Stop Cross-Examining My Love Life?
description: Im a middle-aged, never-been-married woman. I rarely, if ever, bring up an interest in men during therapy sessions. Still, my therapist diverts the conversation to cross-examine my efforts to find a husband. I am unsure whether my therapists matchmaking focus is because she believes I would be more fulfilled with a partner or because  in her culture  women are less whole without one. Is it unethical for a therapist to project their cultural values onto her client? NAME WITHHELD, BROOKLYN

title: David Lynch Is Back  as a Guru of Transcendental Meditation
description: Inside David Lynchs bunker of a studio in Los Angeles, a small crowd of happy people gathered on a late summer morning to meditate and learn about the nature of consciousness. The dozen or so young actors and musicians and others were recent initiates of Transcendental Meditation, a trademarked form of relaxation that involves sitting quietly and saying a mantra to yourself for 20 minutes twice a day. T.M. initiation  a multiday instruction program that includes the bestowing of a secret personalized mantra  costs, on average, $1,000. But those gathered had been initiated as a gift of the David Lynch Foundation for Consciousness-Based Education and World Peace. Through its work, Lynch, who has been practicing T.M. for 40 years, hopes to teach meditation to the world and, as a result, create world peace.

title: Editors Choice
description: LINCOLNS TRAGIC PRAGMATISM: Lincoln, Douglas, and Moral Conflict,  by John Burt. (Belknap/Harvard University, $39.95.) A work of history presented as an argument on moral conflict, and a work of philosophy presented as rhetorical analysis.

title: Paperback Row
description: A LAND MORE KIND THAN HOME,  by Wiley Cash. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $14.99.) Cashs first novel, set in an insular Appalachian town, embeds a tender coming-of-age story within a chilling mystery. Its three narrators  an elderly midwife, a tormented sheriff and a precocious 9-year-old  are caught in a struggle against a local church and its pastor: a twisted, charismatic man whose frenzied religious services include snake-handling.

title: Home Truths
description: Writers make uncomfortable kin. Not only do they shut themselves off from family in what the novelist Jamaica Kincaid calls the infernal room from which their stories come, but, worse still, those stories are quite likely to deal one day with the dreams, terrors, tics and moral lapses of their loved ones. Theres a reflex in every writer that trumps even the maternal instinct, a part of her that, even while her newborn suckles at her breast, is cold-eyed, choosing words to describe the pit-bull clamp of its gums, the crusted globe of its skull, with the same dispassion with which she might describe fellow passengers on a bus.

title: Me and My Shadow
description: For creative writing teachers, stalkers are such a basic condition of employment that, in the interest of full disclosure, they should probably be included in the job ad: Poor pay; negligible benefits (if any); and yes, you will be stalked. As James Lasdun discovers in this smart, rigorous and beautifully written memoir about being on the unwelcome end of someone elses attention, its not always easy to determine that precise moment when the already peculiar relationship between a creative writing student and a teacher starts to go horribly wrong. Sometimes, the student might just be a bit too conscientious about doing the homework  and that homework turns out to be you.

title: The No-Trade Deadline
description: That whistling sound you heard Thursday afternoon was the air going out of all those N.B.A. thought bubbles. You know, the ones popping up like crazy with all the wild and wacky trades that were going to happen at the deadline. Atlanta was going at one point to trade Josh Smith to every one of the other 29 teams in the league. Utahs Al Jefferson was hopping all over the country and women and children everywhere were being warned that Kevin Garnetts legendary mouth might be taking up new residence away from Boston. Heck, maybe Dwight Howard could have been traded by the Lakers to two teams at once!

title: The Isles at the Center of the World
description: An overseas empire produces a vast sea of paper, John Darwin writes. That sea  wide, deep and often treacherous  is what remains of the British Empire for historians to trawl, though few attempt to chart the whole of it in one relatively compact volume. Darwin managed something similar with his previous books The Empire Project: The Rise and Fall of the British World-System, 1830-1970 and After Tamerlane: The Global History of Empire Since 1405  emerging from the imperial brine with poise and balance where lesser historians would have beached themselves like lost whales or glugged down to the depths, tangled in the tentacles of a giant squid. In Unfinished Empire, he turns his attention to the British Empires why, who and how: small words that signify very big questions.

title: The Awakening
description: Umbrella takes its title and epigraph from Joyces Ulysses: A brother is as easily forgotten as an umbrella. Umbrellas do play bit parts in Will Selfs ambitious new novel, but they also echo the fates of its characters, themselves bit players in the vast, indifferent dramas that dominate modern British life. Impersonal bureaucracies and brutal industrial processes serve less as backdrops than as the central obsessions of the book, which moves us through the munitions factories and killing fields of World War I, a psychiatric hospital and a creepily gentrified modern London where those who cant afford exorbitant rents are ruthlessly pushed out. In this world, people are as disposable as umbrellas, which are never contracted for, only mysteriously acquired, to be fleetingly useful, then annoying and cumbersome before eventually being lost.

title: Breakdown
description: Detroit is one of those taxing places that require you to have an opinion about them. This opinion expresses no mere preference. It amounts to a stance, from which may be inferred your electoral leanings, your racial politics, your union sympathies and the general sunniness of your disposition. The entire city signifies. It can get tiring.

title: The Lives of Others
description: The German novelist Christa Wolf was a close observer and a survivor of two ignominious regimes. She grew up in Nazi Germany, fled her home at the end of the war and was rescued from starvation by the Soviet Army. In Communist East Germany, she bravely chronicled life under a dictatorship in novels like Divided Heaven and The Quest for Christa T, acts of nuanced dissent that earned her surveillance by the secret police, the Stasi. When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, she welcomed the collapse of the Communist government. Four years later, however, Wolfs reputation was stained by a shocking revelation: she had collaborated with East German intelligence officers in the early 1960s. Wolf insisted, to widespread disbelief, that she had forgotten the episode.

title: Secret Passages
description: An enchanting, darkly mysterious ballerina. A dead rock star. An unsolved double homicide, decades old. A father felled by a shadowy past. An older sister as beautiful as she is mad. A gay vegetarian chef covered in tattoos. His transvestite lover. Secret passageways, nighttime trysts, affairs, embezzling, illicit recordings  all of it revolving around one 6-foot-8, humble, sincere, Ivy League-educated orphaned professional football player. Really, what more could you want?

title: Model Mothers
description: A portrait of the origins of beauty.

title: The Bank Job
description: When it comes to language, Irish poets place a distant second to the crooks in crime novels. Say youre planning a big bank heist. The crew you recruit for the job is likely to include a jugmarker, the tactical genius who designs these delicate operations; a lip man to deliver the bosss orders; a boxman to crack the safe; a bagman to handle the loot; a wheelman to drive the getaway car; and maybe a couple of buttonmen (they hurt people) to facilitate the whole enterprise.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THIS CAKE IS FOR THE PARTY  By Sarah Selecky.  Thomas Dunne/St. Martins Griffin, paper, $14.99.

title: American Obsession
description: There are a few Hollywood movies so thematically rich and so historically resonant they may be considered part of American literature. The Searchers is one.

title: Idol Gossip
description: Admit it. You idolize George Clooney and know hed be your close friend, or at least a good drinking buddy  if only youd ever met. And that mass schadenfreude the culture indulges in whenever Lindsay Lohan crashes another car  isnt that comforting? Stars may be rich or beautiful, but we get to feel sane in comparison.

title: Jay-Z and Justin Timberlake Announce 12-City Tour
description: The dapper duet that Jay-Z and Justin Timberlake performed in black tie at the Grammy Awards earlier this month turns out to be just a warm-up: the two stars said on Friday that they will do a 12-city North American stadium tour this summer, Live Nation announced. That tour, Legends of the Summer, will start at the Rogers Center in Toronto on July 17 and continue through August 16, when it wraps up in Miami at the Sun Life Stadium. The show will come to Yankee Stadium on July 19. After a few years focusing on acting and the movie business, Mr. Timberlake is returning to music with The 20/20 Experience, his first album since 2006, which is expected to be released on March 19. The albums first single, Suit & Tie, which features Jay-Z, has been a Top 10 hit on pop radio since its release six weeks ago. Tickets will go on sale to the general public for all shows but New York on Feb. 28, with some presale tickets available sooner.

title: Kids Draw the News: Tiny Apartments, in 3-D
description: The city of New York may have picked a winning design, but the submissions we received for this special 3-D assignment of Kids Draw the News would have given any of the architects a run for their money. Thanks to all who answered our call, and to those who were willing to have their masterpiece pictured at the Museum of the City of New York. Your pictures may be seen in the slide show that accompanies this post, and even more can be viewed here.

title: Notes From the Recipe Tester: Mallorcas
description: Mallorcas, the exquisitely delicate, lightly sweet buns described in Mireya Navarros article in this weeks Dining section, are easy enough for a novice baker, but impressive enough to serve at a festive brunch or office party. The trick to making beautiful buns is in the shaping and baking.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | DSquared2
description: Dean and Dan Caten, the designers behind fashion label DSquared2, wanted their models to shine all over at last nights show. They wanted the girls to look healthy, the makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury says. So she highlighted the top of the cheeks with gloss, creating a glimmering architecture, and used pink balm and lip conditioner to emphasize the natural rose color of the lips. Even the chocolate-brown-painted eyelids were topped with lots of gloss. For the nails, the expert Antonio Sacripante used a shimmery, dark red polish  enriched with precious metals  called From Paris With Love. This color will be one of the hottest hues next fall, he predicts.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in London, Virginia, San Francisco
description: Victoria & Albert Museum, London It goes without saying that David Bowie, a musician who has adopted personas from the glam alien Ziggy Stardust, above, to the suave Thin White Duke, has a theatrical sense of style. It will soon be the subject of a survey at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, which will display Mr. Bowies elaborate costumes, music videos, set designs and other ephemera in David Bowie Is from March 23 to July 28. Curators combed Mr. Bowies archives for the show, choosing 300 objects meant to offer a window onto the musicians creativity. Or meant as bait, to draw avid fans. (vam.ac.uk)

title: Pistorius Not a Flight Risk
description: The Timess Marcus Mabry and Lydia Polgreen in Pretoria, South Africa, report on developments in the Oscar Pistorius case.

title: F.D.A. Approves a New Drug for Advanced Breast Cancer
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a new type of drug that combines the widely used breast cancer medicine Herceptin with a powerful toxin to more effectively kill cancer cells while potentially reducing side effects.

title: A Deli King in Trouble
description: The Timess Marcus Mabry and Sam Dolnick report on a Staten Island businessman who, according to federal prosecutors, engaged in an $82 million check-fraud scheme.

title: Depression May Stifle Shingles Vaccine Response
description: Depression may lower the effectiveness of the shingles vaccine, a new study found.

title: In Tandem
description: Merger and acquisition activity tends to rise and fall with the stock market.

title: Found-Footage Nixon Documentary Will Conclude New Directors/New Films Series
description: Just in case Richard M. Nixon was not doing enough documenting of his own presidency (with the occasional gap in the archives), his confidants H. R. Haldeman, John Erlichman and Dwight Chapin were also filming him, his family and his White House using Super 8 cameras. Now this footage has been used to create a new documentary that will be shown as the closing night feature of New Directors/New Films, the annual series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, those organizations said on Friday.

title: Why Am I Still Getting Pimples?
description: You no longer have to gaze over a school lunchroom, hoping to find a seat at a socially acceptable table. You dont rush to get home at night before your junior license driving restrictions kick in. And you men no longer have to worry that your voice will skip an octave without warning.

title: Promotions at New York City Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet has reconfigured its roster with the promotion of 11 dancers, the company announced on Friday morning. Three of the dancers  Adrian Danchig-Waring, Chase Finlay and Ask la Cour  become principal dancers, and eight members of the corps de ballet are now soloists.

title: Student Crossword | World War II
description: Learn more about World War II by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Johnny Marr, Inveterate Sideman, Takes the Spotlight
description: Larry Rohter speaks with Ben Ratliff about Johnny Marr, the ex-Smiths guitarist and songwriter who has also performed with The The, Modest Mouse, Electronic and many others. He is releasing his first solo album on Tuesday.

title: Consumer Complaints May Offer Insight Into Pyramid Schemes
description: There is a big unknown at the heart of the debate over Herbalife: Regulators have given no indication of what they think about the diet supplement companys business practices.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Teddy Wayne talks about his novel The Love Song of Jonny Valentine; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Caryn James discusses Gods Like Us, Ty Burrs new book about movie stardom; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Postal Service Revs Up Another Automotive Stamp Issue
description: Though the leaky, sputtering Postal Service may seem as broken down as Detroits Big Three during the financial crisis, our post offices love affair with classic American automobiles keeps roaring along with a healthy enthusiasm.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 22
Join Us on Oscar Night
description: Join us on Sunday night for all things Oscar. Beginning at 7 p.m. Eastern time, check out the real-time red carpet photos, behind-the-scenes posts and commentary from Melena Ryzik (the Carpetbagger), Dave Itzkoff, Jon Caramanica, Eric Wilson, Simone S. Oliver, Brooks Barnes, Michael Cieply and other Times reporters and critics. Well also have winners, live video analysis throughout the show from David Carr and A. O. Scott, and other features.

title: In Alaska, Fun on the Snow and Ice
description: From ice climbing to skijoring, sports help enliven the Alaskan winter.

title: Inside the List
description: BARED TEETH: If you want to call your book Drinking and Tweeting  thats the title of a dishy new divorce memoir by Brandi Glanville of The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills, at No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list  then you should probably make sure your Twitter account contains more scintillating entries than Going back to sleep. But never mind. Glanvilles book, written with Leslie Bruce, reinforces her reputation as a brash gossip unafraid to mouth off about the husband who ditched her for the has-been country-music singer LeAnn Rimes. Apparently a husband isnt all the two women have shared, either. Two days after Rimes filed a malpractice suit against her former dentist, claiming his crown work had impeded her career, Glanville hit Twitter with a defense of the same practitioner: My dentist of 17 yrs, she wrote, whom I love is perfect.

title: Primed for a Dramatic Return
description: One of the most anticipated concerts of the spring is the Met Orchestras program at Carnegie Hall on May 19. James Levine is scheduled to conduct, two years after his last performance anywhere. But will he show up? Will he be the James Levine who led the Metropolitan Opera through 40 years of artistic growth and became the most important American conductor on the international scene since Leonard Bernstein?

title: Vikings Come Ashore in a New Light
description: They are akin to NASA astronauts or the pioneers of Silicon Valley  except they lived 1,300 years ago, and it was the high seas that demanded navigation, not outer space or the Internet.

title: Looks Familiar, but Somethings Funny
description: On the Internet found material is often recycled as comedy: a decade-old commercial, a foreign music video, an amateurs footage from the zoo. But for the Brooklyn comedy troupe Sunset Television the opposite is true. Its videos are meant to play like artifacts discovered in serpentine YouTube searches.

title: Repertory Selected for Maximum Impact
description: It should be chiseled above the doors of every symphony hall: What an orchestra plays matters as much as how it plays, if not more so.

title: Success, Interrupted
description: In only its third season Spring for Music has already reached its autumn.

title: Making Sounds That Bach Might Recognize
description: The New York Philharmonic is hoping to become a little more hip this spring with the help of an unlikely ally: Johann Sebastian Bach. Well, make that HIP, as in historically informed performance.

title: As Spring Approaches, the Core Is Hardening
description: I havent seen so much energy around the hardcore scene in New York in a long while. Just for starters youve got an array of young New York bands: Perdition (agitated, crusty, fast, noise-caked assaults), Hank Wood and the Hammerheads (garage-punk, with Farfisa organ), Dawn of Humans and Crazy Spirit (sort of Germs-like  feckless/gargling/angry-baby singing, with propulsive and articulated drumming).

title: The Season When the Sides Take Center Stage
description: In indie rock, it seems, everyone has a side project: a break from the other band members, a chance to toy with different genres and recording methods, a fling with no long-term commitment.

title: Bye, Its Over (Over and Over)
description: Its so hard to say goodbye to yesterday. No, honestly  its practically impossible, especially in an age of cyclical nostalgia and Internet-assisted memories. Old musical acts have always gone on comeback tours, but these days the disappearances are getting shorter and nostalgia is fully taking its place alongside discovery as a valid aesthetic-appreciation strategy. Why listen to the new bands that sound like the old bands when the old bands will be back before you know it?

title: R&B From Another Edge, Jazz When It Was Still Fusing
description: Bilal

title: Lost in Back-of-the-Seat Translation
description: In the world of opera, when directors update repertory works to contemporary settings, they almost always remain true to the original music and libretto. This is in effect the bargain that production teams strike with passionate opera buffs, especially the more tradition-bound members of the audience.

title: A Smith Asserts His Own Name
description: What took so long? Twenty-five years after he left the Smiths, perhaps the most influential British pop band of the 1980s, the guitarist Johnny Marr has finally made a solo album.

title: In a Warming World, Look to the Herbivores
description: In the unending quest for effective ways of adapting to climate change, it seems that musk ox and caribou may have some of the answers.

title: Sometimes Its Good Not to Forgive
description: IT seems, these days, that we can barely keep pace with the tales of the famous and near famous who climb to great heights, plummet to great depths and then try to work their way back into the publics affection.

title: Debating House of Cards': What the Show Gets Right and Wrong About Journalism
description: The Washington that majestically unfurls in the credits for House of Cards is recognizable to anybody who has spent time there. But even though it can be a monumental kingdom filled with portent, it can also be a fairly quotidian and sometimes ugly small town  but thats not the kind of place you make a huge, expensive television show about.

title: Mets Push Back Santanas First Appearance
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Around this time last year, the left-hander Johan Santana was the dominant talking point around the Mets spring training facility. He was rehabilitating his surgically repaired pitching shoulder, and it was unclear how much he might be able to contribute during the 2012 season or beyond. It was supposed to be different this time around. Santana was named the Opening Day starter when camp opened, and his spring training was going to unfold like those from more carefree times.

title: Furthur to Play Eight Shows at Capitol Theater
description: It is a sad fact that the Grateful Dead can never return to the Capitol Theater in Port Chester, N.Y., where they gave memorable concerts in the early 1970s, because the guitarist Jerry Garcia has joined the ranks of the actual dead.

title: Growth Vanishes in Developed Economies
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported this week that the combined economies of its member countries shrank in the fourth quarter of 2012, the first time that has happened since the credit crisis.

title: Trying to Block Negative Exposure of Spains Royal Family
description: In the post-modern world of the Spanish monarchy, a picture is worth a mighty kingdom.

title: In the Developed World, Growth Contracts
description: FOR the first time since 2009, the economies of major developed countries are shrinking.

title: Get Em While Theyre Young
description: For those who really like to discover young designers ahead of everyone else, even before theyve had a chance to be featured in Vogue or discussed on a blog, there is an annual talent-scouting event happening in Milan, Italy, this week that might be worth your attention.

title: The Sound of East Harlem, in a Hardware Store
description: With all the changes that have washed over East Harlem, it was only a matter of time before the cowbells, maracas and drumsticks that once made music echo through the fabled neighborhoods streets ended up under glass. Just steps off Lexington Avenue and 107th Street  inside a storefront still adorned by a sign declaring HARDWARE STORE  lies an array of instruments, pictures and other mementos from the golden age of Latin music.

title: Thin Snowpack in West Signals Summer of Drought
description: DENVER  After enduring last summers destructive drought, farmers, ranchers and officials across the parched Western states had hoped that plentiful winter snows would replenish the ground and refill their rivers, breaking the grip of one of the worst dry spells in American history. No such luck.

title: Mindful of Bubbles in a Boom for Deals
description: Warren E. Buffett has teamed up with 3G Capital to buy the venerable H. J. Heinz Company for $23 billion. But the famed value investor isnt exactly buying low: when the deal was announced on Valentines Day, Heinz shares were trading at a record high of nearly $61. Had Mr. Buffett and his partners bought a year ago, shares were selling for $53, a 13 percent discount.

title: Book Review Podcast: An 11-Year-Old Heartthrob
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Jess Walter reviews The Love Song of Jonny Valentine, Teddy Waynes new novel about an 11-year-old singing heartthrob. Mr. Walter writes:

title: Rolls-Royce Recalls Phantoms for Possible Fire Hazard
description: Rolls-Royce is recalling 27 of its 2013 Phantom models for a possible fire hazard, according to a report the automaker sent to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Thanking Harvey Weinstein and God, in That Order
description: 1:23 p.m. | Updated  Thanks to the Academy, you can read (and watch) most of the winners acceptance speeches, going back decades. But you dont have to, because a grad student at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta did it for you, all in the name of research.

title: Photos of The Moment | Prada
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Royal Remains Draw the Curious to Leicester
description: The man with the job of protecting the most famous parking lot in the world was having a busy day a couple of weeks ago. Sorry, guys, Jake Jones said as the latest in a steady stream of onlookers tried to walk through the gates. Youll have to wait for the guided tour.

title: Video Game Inspired by Clashes in Egypt and Italy Allows Gamers to Fight the Police
description: Accompanied by ominous music, shouts and sirens, the video shows a series of turbulent scenes: a man throwing an explosive into a police car, someone kicking a shop window and uniformed officers launching projectiles and marching with shields.

title: Extreme Alaska
description: The wind came from the northwest. It blew down from the glacier-studded peaks of the Alaska Range, through the icebergs of Turnagain Arm and across the frozen expanse of the Twenty Mile River. It was an unrelenting wind, the kind that fells trees, shapes mountains and drives people to their firesides. And there I was among the sculptured snow ridges and frozen grass on the banks of the Twenty Mile, attached to a giant kite, wearing a pair of skis.

title: This Is a Hostel?
description: Grupo Habita, the Mexico City-based team behind the upscale Htel Americano in New York, is known for taking an unconventional approach to hospitality. Still, its latest property  Downtown Mexico, a hotel within a 17th-century palace in the Centro Histrico district of Mexico City  houses a bit of a surprise: the companys first hostel, Downtown Beds.

title: Hiking, Biking and Bubbly in South Africa
description: Breakfast is better with bubblies.

title: Popcast: Johnny Marr, Inveterate Sideman, Takes the Spotlight
description: In this weeks popcast, Ben Ratliff talks to Larry Rohter about his recent encounter with Johnny Marr, the guitarist and songwriter for the Smiths during the first half of the 1980s, and finally  at age 49  in charge of a record under his own name, The Messenger. Mr. Rohter explains an unusual guitar hero, or Godlike Genius, as per the award just bestowed on him by Englands New Musical Express: one who has built his reputation around rhythm and texture rather than solos, around collaboration rather than leading, and around constant change rather than the creation of a static brand.

title: Zero Dark Thirty, Through a Theological Lens
description: Almost nine years ago, journalists on 60 Minutes II and at The New Yorker revealed a trove of photographs showing the abuse and humiliation of Iraqi detainees by American soldiers at Abu Ghraib prison. The images of inmates variously stripped, hooded, leashed like a dog, piled into naked heaps and forced to simulate oral sex then spread widely, causing international outcry.

title: Where the Water Is Soft and the Tea Is Bold
description: To truly taste the tea of East Frisia, Germany, you may just need to go there yourself.

title: In Northern Germany, a Robust Tea Culture
description: For years, I was a green-tea snob who would drink only the freshest Dragon Well or Azure Conch Spring. Even worse, as a longtime Sinophile living in Beijing I aped Asian cultural practices, and when it came to tea, that meant fanatically seeking out the tender shoots harvested right after the first flush, usually in early April. Everything else was taboo. Black teas, especially, never crossed my tongue.

title: Election Violence in Kenya
description: The Timess Marcus Mabry and Marc Lacey, a deputy foreign editor, discuss the ethnic clashes that erupt in Kenya during each election cycle.

title: Weekend Fare
description: A pasta-making class for families will include a recipe demo for parents to watch while children can roll and stretch dough to make various shaped pastas at Giovanni Rana Pastificio and Cucina, 75 Ninth Avenue, in Chelsea. The hands-on class is on Sunday at 9:30 a.m. and is $60 for a child and an accompanying adult, and includes beverages and pasta dish. Call (212) 370-0975 for reservations.

title: Government Joins Suit Against Armstrong
description: The Justice Department on Friday joined a federal whistle-blower lawsuit claiming that Lance Armstrong, his former team manager and the company that owned his cycling team defrauded the government because cyclists on the team, sponsored by the United States Postal Service, were engaged in a systematic, covert doping scheme.

title: In Battling Tax Dodgers, Britain Gives Shame a Try
description: LONDON  A hairdresser in Liverpool and a knitwear manufacturer in Nottingham were among the first nine people and companies publicly branded tax scofflaws by the British authorities as part of a government name and shame campaign.

title: Torture, Lies and Hollywood
description: I WATCHED Zero Dark Thirty not as a former F.B.I. special agent who spent a decade chasing, interrogating and prosecuting top members of Al Qaeda but as someone who enjoys Hollywood movies. As a movie, I enjoyed it. As history, its bunk.

title: Why Oscar Will Snub Zero Dark Thirty
description: Sunday night is Oscar night, the 85th Academy Awards, high holy day for Americas most influential cultural export. Zero Dark Thirty, once thought to be a favorite for best picture, has been pummeled on the way to the finish line. It increasingly looks like Argo, a tidy drama about an imaginative rescue mission in Ayatollah Khomeinis Iran, will win.

title: Intense Downpour Floods Athens and Strands Motorists
description: ATHENS  Torrential rain of an intensity not seen in decades flooded roads in Athens on Friday, overturning parked cars and stranding dozens of motorists, including a 28-year-old woman who died of what appeared to be a heart attack.

title: What to Eat With Montsant Wines
description: Some people keep a house wine on hand. Montsant? Maybe. I have a friend who has a house dish, which she always serves for dinner parties. Its the chicken Marbella with prunes and olives from The Silver Palate Cookbook. With this friend coming to dinner at my house, and Montsant to pour, I decided to do a riff on that decades-old recipe and made a chicken tagine with prunes and olives. I used only chicken thighs, which stayed moist. My dish had some of the Mediterranean spirit of the original and, not accidentally, of the wine.  FLORENCE FABRICANT

title: Predicting a Crisis, Repeatedly
description: Economists are not very good at predicting crises, but the problem is generally an absence of warnings. Its not easy to anticipate which low-probability catastrophe will end up happening.

title: Iglo and Birds Eye Pull Meals After Finding Horse Meat
description: LONDON  Another big food producer was ensnared in the scandal over horse meat in beef products Friday when the company that owns the Iglo and Birds Eye brands withdrew a dozen types of prepared meals from stores in four European countries.

title: Emerging From the Shadows
description: The wine universe has been expanding at an accelerated rate over the last decade or so, and no place illustrates it better than Spain. New appellations have joined historic names. Forgotten regions have reinvented themselves. And everywhere, despite the countrys poor economy, new producers have jumped into the global fray.

title: Roma Is Isolated in Transitional Uncertainty
description: MILAN, Italy  Several hundred protesting Roma supporters awaited the manager, Zdenek Zeman, and his players outside Stadio Olimpico in Rome. His time at the helm of the capital club was all but officially over after a devastating defeat against Cagliari.

title: Lynch by Lynch, the Film Director as Self-Portraitist
description: For this weeks article about David Lynchs efforts to promote Transcendental Meditation, a trademarked form of relaxation, we asked the film director to create a self-portrait. Our thinking was that while he is known mostly for his TV series Twin Peaks and films like Eraserhead, Blue Velvet and Mulholland Drive, Lynch is also a painter, printmaker, musician and photographer, so maybe hed like to make some art to go with his profile. The result was the photo seen above, taken while Lynch was at the Idem printing studios in Paris working on a new set of lithographs. Recently I put to him a few questions about self-portraiture:

title: Qualcomm Reveals Its Donations to Tax-Exempt Groups
description: Qualcomm, the countrys largest maker of computer chips for mobile devices, has voluntarily disclosed previously secret political contributions to tax-exempt groups under a settlement with the New York State comptroller that was announced on Friday.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A seven-bedroom Sea Cliff Victorian built in 1890, and a four-bedroom colonial in Old Greenwich.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Midwood, Brooklyn apartment on a tree-lined street, an Art-Deco one-bedroom on the Upper West Side and a Midtown South listing featuring a private elevator.

title: Engagement Party
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: In Push for Transparency, Law Firm Releases Financial Results
description: Call it the Dewey & LeBoeuf effect.

title: Watching the Oscars With ...
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about what theyll be doing on Sunday night for the Academy Awards. Care to join them for the glamour, the glitz and the upsets?

title: A Supporting Actress Upset and Other Surprising Predictions
description: LOS ANGELES  The awards machinery is in overdrive now, with nearly every possible angle explored, from the earliest moments of the nominees and their films to what productions would look like in pie-chart form. (What percent of Life of Pi is actually your stoned freshman-year roommate discussing his comparative religions class? Its sizable!)

title: White House Uses Air Delays as Budget Prod
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Friday warned of potentially severe disruptions in air travel if across-the-board spending cuts take effect in less than a week as President Obama intensified pressure on Congressional Republicans to entertain spending reductions and tax increases to avoid furloughing federal workers and limiting services.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 22
description: A view of the day in sports, including ski jumping in Italy and spring training baseball in Florida.

title: Q & A
description: Refinancing a Sponsor Unit

title: Gay Marriage: Style and Substance
description: The AP announced on Thursday that it would treat gay and straight couples the same, stylistically. Its new husband, wife Stylebook entry reads: Regardless of sexual orientation, husband or wife is acceptable in all references to individuals in any legally recognized marriage. Spouse or partner may be used if requested.

title: How A.O. Scott and David Carr Are Voting
description: The Times co-chief film critic A.O. Scott offered an early hint of Argos Oscar chances when he wrote about seeing it at the Telluride Film Festival last summer. The Media Equation columnist David Carr knows a thing or two about the Academy Awards from his former life as the Carpetbagger.

title: The Consensus Candidate
description: A composite portrait of the 116 men who will elect Pope Benedict XVIs successor.

title: Starter: Bringing Vietnamese Flavor to Carroll Gardens
description: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

title: Reasons to Avoid Buying Stocks, and Why You Should Ignore Them
description: THERE are always reasons not to buy stocks. Investors may think the Dow Jones industrial average is too high, as was the case in 1954 when the index topped 360. In 1941, there was Pearl Harbor. In 1962, the Cuban missile crisis. In 1997, the Asian financial crisis.

title: Messiah Without a Cause, but With a Guitar
description: So, like, Jesus is a total stoner and sometimes, you know, kind of a jerk. But hes totally cute, and totally good on guitar.

title: A Tale of Two Aston Martin DB5s
description: Lot No. 200 at the RM Auction in London in 2010 was a British racing green 1965 Aston Martin DB5, which sold for 224,000 (about $385,000 at the time). That seemed a fair, if unspectacular, amount for such a car; it was in near-showroom condition, with full factory documentation and complete prior ownership information.

title: A Life of Pie
description: Pie is an indulgence often saved for holiday time. But this week Martha Rose Shulman shows us how to bake a pie and eat it too, without the guilt. She offers savory vegetable pies, showcased in whole grain crusts. She writes:

title: Never Underestimate the Power of a Good Hug
description: When Robert Turetsky was growing up, there was always a degree of artistic ferment in his life: one of his grandmothers, Dora Wasserman, had founded a prominent Yiddish theater in Montreal, and Mr. Turetsky said he essentially grew up sleeping in the aisles.

title: A Bleak Winter for Hourlong Series
description: Its been a long, cold winter for the broadcast television networks, for which almost every new series has been met with an equally chilly reception in the ratings.

title: Photos of The Moment | DSquared2
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Sweet Spot: Watching the Oscars With
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about what theyll be doing on Sunday night for the Academy Awards. Care to join them for the glamour, the glitz and the upsets?

title: Patron of Siena Stumbles
description: SIENA, Italy  Cut into the stonework of the imposing Palazzo Salimbeni is a name that has been entwined with the fortunes of this Tuscan city for five centuries: Monte dei Paschi, or Mount of the Pastures.

title: Citigroup Pay Plan Raises the Bar Just a Bit
description: Citigroups new executive pay plan raises the bar, just not quite far enough. The banks board has put into effect a compensation scheme with more rigorous targets for the chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, and his lieutenants. One important performance metric, however, keeps expectations too low.

title: Are Standardized Tests Worth the Stress?
description: Po Bronson and Ashley Merrymans Feb. 10 article on why some students are worriers (those who fall apart when under pressure) while others are warriors (those who thrive on it) generated 404 online comments. Central to the debate was whether standardized testing is beneficial or not.

title: The Yankees One-Tool Player
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Travis Hafner, the Yankees new designated hitter, owns two baseball gloves. One is an outfielders glove, and the other is a first basemans mitt, which even has his nickname  Pronk  stamped on it in bright gold letters. The gloves collect dust in his locker.

title: Little Money, Little Time, Big Visions
description: No child in the history of mankind has ever said, I want to be a film distributor when I grow up, says Jeff Lipsky, and though he is a distributor, one with a compelling track record, he was no exception. I always wanted to be a filmmaker. I just didnt know it was going to take another 20 years.

title: Salley Offers a Healthy Assist
description: When Carmelo Anthony went on a vegetarian diet a few weeks ago and caused the biggest culinary conundrum in sports since fried chicken and beer had starring roles in the Red Sox clubhouse, John Salley could only shake his head.

title: Hailing a Passing Flying Carpet
description: The Thief of Bagdad

title: The Last Word on Granola
description: We loved hearing your secrets for making tasty granola after Jeff Gordiniers article this week on what chefs, artisans and entrepreneurs are doing with it. Your suggestions came through our blog, and on Twitter.

title: Scud Missile Attack Reported in Aleppo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Antigovernment activists in Syria said the military fired Scud missiles into at least three rebel-held districts of Aleppo on Friday, flattening dozens of houses, killing at least 12 civilians and burying perhaps dozens of others under piles of rubble.

title: The Great Air Race
description: Because a room with a view has always been preferable to one without, the price of air in New York City is becoming more expensive. Yes, the air is for sale, but not on sale.

title: South Korean Crossover in Hollywood
description: For nearly as long as there have been American movies there have been foreign directors making them, in a symbiotic arrangement that gives the visitors freedom, cash or exposure and the domestic film industry cachet and infusions of creativity. In Hollywoods early years Europeans classed up the joint, particularly those from the center of the continent: von Stroheim, Lubitsch, Lang, Zinnemann. More recent waves of talent have washed in from Australia, Hong Kong and Latin America.

title: Alive and Well at Merkin Concert Hall
description: The Wafels & Dinges truck was getting ready to close for business when I hurried out of the subway at Lincoln Center this week, and the heady smell of burned sugar followed me as I turned north in the direction of the Kaufman Center. I was going to a New York Festival of Song concert, the first half of which was dedicated to the music of Jacques Brel, Belgiums greatest gift  somewhat ahead of gaufres de Lige  to civilization. That prospect, in combination with the smell, turned knots in my stomach.

title: Wearable Looks Emerge from the Cocoon
description: A year ago, the fashion collections in New York and Europe seemed a coordinated effort to bury women in stuff. Remember Marc Jacobss oversize coats and head-gobbling Seuss hats? In Milan, Miuccia Prada layered up silk trousers and maxi-vests in diamond prints. Haider Ackermanns lavishly composed outfits had editors raving, but, like a lot of fashion in recent seasons, you wondered why it needed to be so complicated.

title: Deciding Whether to Dip a Toe in the Market
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about all the reasons  and there are always reasons  that investors decide not to invest in the stock market. He names a few in his column, among them the Cuban missile crisis in 1962 and the Asian financial crisis in 1997, from a list compiled by Bel Air Investment Advisors for every year from 1934 to 2012.

title: Islanders Reach Inevitable End with DiPietro and Waive Him
description: The Islanders waived goaltender Rick DiPietro on Friday, possibly ending one of the oddest and most expensive sagas in team history.

title: Seeing Citizenship Path Near, Activists Push Obama to Slow Deportations
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama intensifies his campaign for a broad overhaul of the nations immigration system, advocates for Americas 11 million illegal immigrants are stepping up demands that he stop what has become one of the most aggressive and efficient efforts in decades to round up and deport people who are in the United States unlawfully.

title: Permit Ready, Foundation Poured
description: At their sagging, graffiti-tagged worst, the blue plywood fences that surround construction sites can be symbols of everything that went wrong in the housing bust, as stalled projects languish behind them.

title: Taking Liberties With Cassoulet
description: You need cold weather for cassoulet, that rustic, earthy and not-exactly-light slow-cooked indulgence. I make it at least once every winter, usually in February, when spring is still weeks away.

title: Hossa Cleared to Play as Blackhawks Close In on Record
description: CHICAGO  The last time the Blackhawks Marian Hossa took a shot to the head, it was seven months before he was cleared to return. This time, it took just three days.

title: After Heinz Deal, Other Food Companies Could Be Takeover Targets
description: After the Warren E. Buffett-backed takeover of Heinz, Big Food merits a fresh look. Companies that are purveyors of meals, sauces and spreads may offer better value than is immediately obvious.

title: Aerosmith and Foreigner Songwriters to Join Hall of Fame
description: The Songwriters Hall of Fame will honor members of Foreigner and Aerosmith during the 2013 induction ceremony to be held in New York this summer.

title: Online Gambling Heats Up
description: The two big casino states, Nevada and New Jersey, are racing into online gambling as a way of protecting their turf. They will in essence become laboratories for what is and is not feasible in Internet wagering.

title: Dennis Hopper on One Kings Lane
description: The stylish home furnishings sale site One Kings Lane might seem an unlikely place to sell Dennis Hoppers possessions. But tomorrow, an estate sale featuring items from the personal collections of the actor, director and artist, who died in 2010, will go live. And collect he did. Hopper, known for his screen roles from Easy Rider to Blue Velvet, spent decades amassing art and objects that filled his homes in Venice, Calif., Taos, N.M. and Wilmington, N.C.

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 22
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a book signing, the end of a citywide bus strike and a conference on gun violence in Connecticut.

title: Week in Review: Sweeping Changes or a Symbolic Reprimand?
description: Prosecutors, shifting strategy, are building a new model for Wall Street cases. | Morgan Stanley is striving to coordinate two departments often at odds. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says Steven L. Rattners reputation, once sullied, has acquired a new shine.

title: Palestinians Protest Route of Marathon to Sponsors
description: JERUSALEM  A lawyer representing Palestinian government agencies sent letters this week to an American sneaker company and an international hotel chain threatening a boycott and legal action if they did not withdraw their sponsorship of the Jerusalem Marathon, which the Palestinians say violates international law.

title: Judge Sides With Einhorn and Halts an Apple Shareholder Vote
description: 9:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Here Comes Earnings Puffery. So Buy the Stock.
description: 5:36 p.m. | Updated with closing stock price.

title: Rivera Pitches and Posada Jokes
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Spring training had a nostalgic flair for the Yankees on Friday, as two familiar faces made returns of different types.

title: Robert. Dad. Stepdad. Whats in a Name?
description: I grew up in a bubble. A slightly dysfunctional bubble. The term broken home was something Id only heard of on TV. We had our share of problems, but they all stayed within the realm of the imaginable for me, and divorce was something I hadnt really imagined.

title: Ethnic War in Myanmar Has China on Edge
description: Chinese Army units have been undergoing intense training near the border with Myanmar in anticipation of an ethnic war there spilling into southwest China, according to official Chinese news media reports on Friday.

title: A Brand-New Tradition
description: It is hard enough for a young composer to invent sounds. But Tamzin Elliott invented an entire culture.

title: Major Overhaul for Nascars 2013 Models
description: When a Daytona Beach gas station owner by the name of Bill France founded the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing in 1948, his immediate objective was to establish one set of rules for entrants in the race he was promoting. That principle  uniform, stable regulations  has been maintained through decades of Nascars rise to dominance, with the so-called stock cars barely changing even as the production models they were based on evolved.

title: A New SS for Chevrolet and Nascar
description: Daytona Beach, Fla.  The 2014 Chevrolet SS performance sedan was introduced to the public and the press in the infield of Daytona International Speedway hours before its Nascar doppelgnger rolled onto track for the first race of the season, a preliminary to the Daytona 500. The car is the companys first rear-drive performance sedan since the 1996 departure of the Impala SS.

title: Tailoring a Look for Awards Season
