title: The Gun Report: February 23, 2013
description: Here is todays sampling of gun violence in America. We will return on Monday with the weekend report.

title: Sandberg, Feminism and the Politics of Class
description: Sheryl Sandberg, perhaps the countrys most prominent female tech executive, aspires to share her secrets through success via a new social movement.

title: Roberto Cavalli: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: You Asked. Carnival Answered. (Sort Of.)
description: 5:18 p.m. | Updated More than a week after I first asked about the capacity of the lifeboats on board the Triumph, Carnival told me that the ship had 24 lifeboats, 2 rescue boats, and 74 life rafts (primarily intended to accommodate crew) for a total lifesaving capacity of 6,670. Had the company decided to evacuate the ship, there would have been enough room for all the passengers.

title: Satellite Tracking of Middle East Aquifers Points to the End of Data Denial
description: Jay Famiglietti, one of the authors of an important new study on the rapid depletion of aquifers under the Tigris and Euphrates river basins, hasposted an excellent overview of the work and its context for policy, and noted that he and other authors are preparing for a two-week water diplomacy tour to discuss their findings in the affected region.

title: Skill on Saturday: Berbas Blast
description: He has often been called languid and uninterested, a man with a passing resemblance to Count Dracula.

title: Austerity Europe
description: Some readers have been asking me for the data source for Paul De Grauwes measure of austerity. Im working on it. Meanwhile, however  and partly for my own reference  I discovered that I can do a similar exercise over a somewhat longer time horizon, which Im posting in large part as a note to myself.

title: Photos of The Moment | Versace
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Lawsuit Against Lance Armstrong
description: The Justice Department on Friday joined a federal whistle-blower lawsuit claiming that Lance Armstrong, his former team manager and the company that owned his cycling team defrauded the government because cyclists on the team, sponsored by the United States Postal Service, were engaged in a systematic, covert doping scheme.

title: Photos of The Moment | Sportmax
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Little Statesmen and Philosophers
description: So, people want me to comment on the Moodys downgrade of Britain. No real news there. As a guide to the future, ratings agency judgments are literally worse than useless; remember, US bond yields actually fell after the 2011 S&P downgrade. Still, its kind of a poke in the eye for Cameron/Osborne, who are subjecting their country to pointless austerity because confidence!

title: Ice Fishermen Not Immune to Dopings Reach
description: With an eye on an Olympic berth, competitors at the World Ice Fishing Championship had to submit to the same examinations as world-class sprinters and weight lifters.

title: Dope Tests in Ice Fishing? No, Beer Doesnt Count
description: WAUSAU, Wis.  The ice fishermen spent a week on the frozen lake, and on the last day, after emptying perch and bluegill from their buckets and scrubbing bait from their hands, several winners of the World Ice Fishing Championship were ushered into their rooms in the Plaza Hotel.

title: Variety: An Explosive Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I got a BIG BANG out of todays acrostic, not only because it was an interesting way to learn how the phrase the Big Bang came into the lexicon, but because I can always be bought with food, and if no food is present, humor.

title: Ozzie Sweet, Who Helped Define New Era of Photography, Dies at 94
description: At the end of World War II, Ozzie Sweets picture of a friend posed as a German soldier surrendering appeared on the cover of Newsweek  the magazine of news significance, as it billed itself then. Not a stratagem that would pass muster in contemporary journalism, but Mr. Sweet, who had apprenticed to the Mount Rushmore sculptor Gutzon Borglum, appeared in a Cecil B. DeMille film and helped create promotional ads for the United States Army, found the art in photography to be in creating an image, not capturing one.

title: When Moms (and First Ladies) Dance
description: The first lady, Michelle Obama, won rave reviews on Saturday for her dancing.

title: French Intervention in Mali Raises Threat of Domestic Terrorism, Judge Says
description: PARIS  The French military intervention in Mali has increased the threat of domestic terrorism, with some French citizens of black African ancestry becoming more willing to fight under the banner of jihad, according to Frances most prominent investigative judge dealing with terrorism.

title: A Tent City for Fun and Profit
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Duke is an elite private university where the buildings are pretend Gothic, where tuition is $42,000 a year, and where hundreds of students eagerly and voluntarily spent five wintry weeks camping in the famed tent city known as Krzyzewskiville for one simple reason: to get a good seat for the basketball game against archrival North Carolina.

title: Ahead of Trial, Talk of a BP Settlement in 2010 Oil Spill
description: With a major civil trial scheduled to start Monday in New Orleans against BP over damages related to the explosion of an offshore drilling rig in 2010, federal officials and those from the five affected Gulf Coast states are trying to pull together to strike an 11th-hour settlement in the case.

title: Scandals and Intrigue Heat Up at Vatican Ahead of Papal Conclave
description: VATICAN CITY  As cardinals from around the world begin arriving in Rome for a conclave to elect a successor to Pope Benedict XVI, new shadows have fallen over the delicate transition, which the Vatican fears might influence the vote and with it the direction of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Pompom Girl for Feminism
description: WASHINGTON

title: Jil Sander: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Emory Universitys Leader Reopens Its Racial Wounds
description: ATLANTA  A reception on Friday at Emory University to celebrate the work of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in the years after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. could have been more poorly timed, but not by much.

title: In the Wake of Emancipation
description: For many enslaved people, 1863 began not with freedom but with profound uncertainty. The legal and practical effects of the Emancipation Proclamation were a matter of dispute among white critics and observers, as they have been among historians for 150 years. If the proclamation applied only to areas under Confederate control, did it really free anyone right away? What, if anything, did it mean for border states and Union-occupied territory? For slaves who got their news in rumors, the proclamations details could seem especially unclear. As late as the summer of 1864, an enslaved woman in Maryland, Annie Davis, wrote to Lincoln himself for clarification: Mr president, she asked, please let me know if we are free.

title: Model Diary | Liu Wen
description: Liu Wen feels like she lives from airplane to airplane, constantly traveling for work for the past five years. So this season, shes making sure to take it easy and enjoy herself a little in each city. Saturday, the 25-year-old jet-setting model is in Milan, where she walked in Roberto Cavallis show in the morning. Sunday, shell walk in Dolce & Gabbana.

title: In Italy, Illusion Is the Only Reality
description: IT takes a certain talent to live in happy denial, to slide toward the edge of a precipice and be perfectly relaxed about it. Of all the talents that Italians are renowned for, such nonchalance is perhaps their greatest. Their economy is in deep recession; more than one in three young adults are unemployed; they are unable to compete economically with their neighbors; yet they continue as if nothing were happening, or as if a small glitch in the dolce vita could be fixed with the wave of a wand.

title: The Snowman
description: Jeremy Jones made his name in snowboarding by riding steep lines from helicopters. Now hes reinvigorating the sport by climbing and riding mountains on his split-board.

title: A Soft-Spoken Snowboarder Blazes Icy Trails
description: TRUCKEE, Calif.  The snowboarder Jeremy Jones arrived at the Atomfjella Mountains on Svalbard, an island above the Arctic Circle, after 30 hours of tundra crossing on a rattling snowmobile convoy in April 2011. He had invited Terje Haakonsen, known in the snowboarding world for his ability to ride almost anything, any style, to attempt the summit and first descent of a set of precipitously icy couloirs.

title: Angry and Disillusioned, Italians Prepare to Vote
description: ROME  As Italian voters head to the polls on Sunday and Monday to elect a new Parliament and three regional governments, the prevailing mood is one of anger and disillusionment.

title: Chances Are Extra Work in Off-Season Involves Baseball, Not a Second Job
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Collin McHugh, a 25-year-old right-handed pitcher, achieved a lifelong goal last year when he was called up to the Mets.

title: Notable Names Drinking Whiskey and Eating Carbs
description: LOS ANGELES  The convergence of so many stars makes Oscar weekend a magnet for all kinds of charities and causes hoping to piggyback.

title: The Price of Public Violence
description: EVERY year, the Chicago Police Department issues a report with the macabre title Chicago Murder Analysis. Its a short but eye-opening document. Do the calculations and you realize that in the past 15 years, 8,083 people have been killed, most of them in a concentrated part of the city. Theres one particularly startling revelation that gets little notice: in 2011, more than four-fifths of all murders happened in a public place, a park, an alleyway, on the street, in a restaurant or at a gas station.

title: Yankees 1913 Season Was Sunk by a Rogue Captain
description: Setting sail a century ago from Pier 42 on the East River for spring training in Bermuda, the Yankees faced the 1913 season with considerable optimism.

title: New York Builds Momentum in Sports
description: New Yorkers like to think they live in the center of the universe, and when it comes to finance, theater, advertising and other areas, they may be right. But when it comes to sports, the argument is shakier. Sure, the Yankees are perennial contenders and the Giants, among others, have at times risen to the top. But for all the money in New York, many of its teams fail to grab the national stage.

title: Congress Set to Consider Tighter Rules on Firearms
description: WASHINGTON  After weeks of sometimes wrenching debate over gun safety, Congress will begin to consider legislation this week that is likely to include expanded background checks for gun buyers and increased penalties for those who purchase guns for criminals.

title: Rays Price Is Realistic About His Worth and His Future
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  David Price was shooting a commercial for a home-security company at his house in Tampa on Feb. 7 when his brother, Damon, called. Price ignored him once, then twice. With the third call, he finally picked up. He figured it must be important.

title: In Mens Basketball, Scoring Suffers in Physical Game
description: ATLANTA  The basketball was so agonizing to watch that one coach buried his head in his hands, another dropped his head in dismay and fans shook their heads in disgust. Clemson shooters sailed balls past the rim, and Georgia Tech fans ridiculed them with chants of air ball, air ball. When a Tech player missed everything, the handful of Clemson fans bounced the barb right back: air ball, air ball.

title: Coming to a Track (and Showroom) Near You
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Richard Petty competed in Nascar from 1958 to 1992, long enough to have won seven championships while driving dozens of racecar models. So he could not help chuckling when asked about the name of the racecar being introduced this season in the Sprint Cup series.

title: Drew LeBlancs Comeback Lifts St. Cloud State Hockey
description: ST. CLOUD, Minn.  The St. Cloud State hockey players and coaches who were there grimly recount the gruesome details of Nov. 5, 2011, the night when Drew LeBlanc, the team captain, broke his left leg.

title: Primed for Controversy
description: IN 2005, the writer Malcolm Gladwell introduced readers to the phenomenon of thinking without thinking  the mental work we all do automatically  in his blockbuster book Blink.

title: North Korea Threatens U.S. Over Joint Military Drill
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Saturday warned the top American military commander in South Korea that if the United States pressed ahead with joint military exercises with South Korea scheduled to begin next month, it could set off a war in which American forces would meet a miserable destruction.

title: Emory Universitys President Faces Criticism
description: Students at Emory University protested for the removal of the schools president, James W. Wagner, saying that a column he wrote  as well as recent sweeping budget cuts  both revealed Emorys bias against minority students.

title: Do Warriors Have a Secret Weapon Up Their Sleeves?
description: Having lost 16 consecutive games to the San Antonio Spurs entering Fridays contest, the Golden State Warriors would probably have tried anything to get a win. It turned out, all they needed were sleeves.

title: Who Has the Guts for Gluten?
description: WE know that the proteins called gluten, found in wheat and other grains, provoke celiac disease. And we know how to treat the illness: a gluten-free diet. But the rapidly increasing prevalence of celiac disease, which has quadrupled in the United States in just 50 years, is still mystifying.

title: Help for Veterans Twice Betrayed
description: This month, Representative Chellie Pingree, Democrat of Maine, and Senator Jon Tester, Democrat of Montana, introduced a bill that would make it easier for veterans to receive benefits for disabilities linked to sexual assault in the military. The bill is named for Ruth Moore, a Navy veteran who has been outspoken about what she calls her double betrayal.

title: The Nuclear Agenda
description: President Obama set an ambitious goal in his first term when he endorsed the vision of an eventual world without nuclear weapons. After some early achievements, namely the New Start treaty mandating cuts in deployed strategic weapons, the effort stalled for two years until he picked up the theme again in the State of the Union address this month. Now he needs to follow through with a more sustained commitment.

title: Canadiens Renaissance Keeps Its Edge
description: The morning after Tuesdays 3-1 victory against the Rangers vaulted the Canadiens into first place in the Eastern Conference, Montreal commuters waiting for the No. 107 bus were greeted by the words BRAVO Canadiens on the display where the route number usually appears.

title: The Next Frontier Is Inside Your Brain
description: The Obama administration is planning a multiyear research effort to produce an activity map that would show in unprecedented detail the workings of the human brain, the most complex organ in the body. It is a breathtaking goal at a time when Washington, hobbled by partisan gridlock and deficit worries, seems unable to launch any major new programs.

title: Refugee Influx Threatens Balance in Lebanon
description: Many in Lebanon worry that the influx of up to 400,000 Syrian refugees, who are mostly Sunni, may disrupt the delicate balance in the country. Lebanon fought its own sectarian civil war from 1975 to 1990.

title: A Mind of Their Own, and the Freedom to Speak It
description: SEVERAL years ago, the columnist Paul Krugman veered from his usual practice of writing about the economy and began writing columns about the war in Iraq.

title: How Mexico Got Back in the Game
description: MONTERREY, Mexico

title: Stranger Than Fiction on the Cop Beat
description: In the late 80s, I became the news clerk in The Miami Heralds Fort Lauderdale bureau. I answered the phones, composed obits and even reviewed a Barry Manilow concert  that is, after every other single reporter on the paper declined.

title: A World Without Work
description: IMAGINE, as 19th-century utopians often did, a society rich enough that fewer and fewer people need to work  a society where leisure becomes universally accessible, where part-time jobs replace the regimented workweek, and where living standards keep rising even though more people have left the work force altogether.

title: Claire Chiang
description: Claire Chiang is chairwoman of the Singapore Zoo, considered among the worlds best because of its vast natural habitat exhibits. The daughter of Chinese migrants, Ms. Chiang is also co-founder and senior vice president of Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts, which has 40 luxury properties on 5 continents. She previously served as a member of Singapores Parliament as well as on the board of the countrys male-dominated Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

title: Violent, Drunk and Holding a Gun
description: Multiple mass shootings by deranged young men have made keeping firearms out of the hands of mentally ill people a big part of the gun debate.

title: Sunday Dialogue: The Future of Medicare
description: Readers weigh in on problems with the health care program.

title: Tips for Public Speaking
description: Nearly everyone gets some anxiety about public speaking  even Oscar-winning actors. Here are some tips to help you through a big speech:

title: Tennis: Love-Love
description: Bounce, bounce, bounce. Its four-all, 40-30, and Im serving. I toss the ball high and in the act of reaching up I over-adjust my swing and hit it long. Fool. One more chance to redeem myself, to succeed, to set in motion, at the very least, an opportunity to win the point, the game, the set. Who knows what heights remain to be scaled, what triumphs lie in wait?

title: Ultimate Sport
description: Founded in the late 1960s, in the heyday of hippiedom, ultimate Frisbee is often associated with pot smoking and people who dont like rules. In college, ultimate is relegated to club status, the stepchild of athletic departments.

title: Solitaire: Me vs. Me
description: When friends tell me that they are trying to give up smoking, I suggest they take up solitaire. As a reward for having completed a task, as a mini-holiday from everyday stress, as a means of improving ones mood without a doctors prescription, the game offers many of the same benefits as cigarettes, only its cheaper and doesnt have the harmful effects of tar and nicotine. When I gave up smoking, it wasnt because Id replaced it with the pleasures with solitaire. Its more that the pleasures of solitaire remind me of what I used to like about smoking.

title: Poker Is America
description: Lets start by getting this straight: poker is about money. If you took the money out of it, I wouldnt play. But even when I lose, Ive had a good time. I love playing poker as an escape from the world I usually live in, and I especially love playing at Hollywood Casino in Charles Town, W.Va., where you can find me about two afternoons a week.

title: Weighing In on Sensor Size
description: Wow. My post on Thursday about the relationship between sensor size and soft-focus background certainly lived up to its opening premise: photographers online are a cantankerous lot. Photography, in the end, is something of a black art, and everybodys got an opinion.

title: Ping-Pong: Head Game
description: A gold-toothed man of 76 polishes his $300 paddle. The tall, elegant gentleman who is used to overseeing maquiladoras in Tijuana silently pulls three-star balls out of a box. Mrs. Fukuoka, 80 next month, flicks shots into the corner at such cunning angles that she wins every other point. Im never tired, she giggles, hiding her smile behind her bat, because I never move. At another of the eight championship tables, a bald guy and a grandmother exchange low forehand topspins with such relentless intensity they attain a rhythm thats almost sexual.

title: Ahead of Election in Cyprus, Gloom and Voter Apathy Tied to Financial Woes
description: LIMASSOL, Cyprus  Evagoras Georgiou will go to the polling station at the Tsireio middle school in the St. John neighborhood here for Sundays presidential election. But he will leave his ballot blank, voting for neither of the two candidates in the runoff for Cypruss most powerful political office.

title: The Invisible War: An Update
description: My column today, about rape in the military, centers on The invisible War, which features servicemen and women sharing brutal tales of sexual assault perpetrated by their colleagues and superiors. One of these victims, Kori Cioca, was a Coast Guard seaman when she was smacked across the face by her attacker with such force that it dislocated her jaw, relegating her to years of pain, unable to eat anything but soft foods like Jell-O and mashed potatoes. During the course of filming she tries to get the VA to pay for her treatment, but is ultimately denied.

title: Lin Does a Lot by Not Doing Too Much
description: When the Houston Rockets outbid the Knicks for Jeremy Lins services in the off-season, Carmelo Anthony called Houstons offer ridiculous. Lin had played well in his 25 starts, but the $25.1 million offer seemed outrageous to Anthony and many others.

title: Dont Call Him Mom, or an Imbecile
description: THE hapless, bumbling father is a stock character in product marketing. He makes breakfast for dinner and is incapable of handling, or sometimes even noticing, a soggy diaper. He tries desperately to hide the crumb-strewn, dirt-streaked evidence of his poor parenting before the mother gets home.

title: Patrick Drawing Crowds Before the Engines Start
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The window to the Nascar garage at Daytona International Speedway through which fans watch Danica Patricks crew work on her racecar is covered with marker messages.

title: Seen as Nature Lovers Paradise, Utah Struggles With Air Quality
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Utah has long been known as an outdoor lovers utopia. The skiing and mountain biking are among the best anywhere. And the snow-clotted mountains that tower around Salt Lake give this city a mythic quality during winter.

title: How the Bagger Is Voting (Down to the Animated Shorts)
description: LOS ANGELES  Can we begin with a caveat? This years ever-shifting race, with its wealth of good movies, has some really tight contests, like best original screenplay. Though Mark Boal (Zero Dark Thirty) won the Writers Guild Award in the same category, the consensus here seems to have shifted since we wrote about the race this week and now favors Quentin Tarantino, for Django Unchained, with a passionate faction going for Michael Haneke and Amour. So mark that one on your ballot at your own risk.

title: As Cuts Loom, Governors Seek More Control of Federal Funds to Lessen the Pain
description: WASHINGTON  Governors of both parties said on Saturday that they knew federal budget cuts were coming, and they pleaded with President Obama and Congress to give them more discretion over the use of federal money so they could minimize the pain for their citizens.

title: Reeva Steenkamp, Steve Biko and the Quest for Justice in South Africa
description: LONDON  The title of the presiding judge 35 years ago was the same, chief magistrate of Pretoria, and the venue for the hearing, a converted synagogue, was not far from the modern courthouse seen on television screens around the world in recent days as Oscar Pistorius, the gold medal-winning Paralympic athlete, fought for bail in the killing of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.

title: Hard Budget Realities as Agencies Prepare to Detail Reductions
description: WASHINGTON  In the first week of March, a laid-off person living on $300 a week in unemployment benefits is liable to find a surprise in the mailbox: notification from Uncle Sam that come April the check will be $33 lighter.

title: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Dells Intentions Get a Hard Look
description: IS Michael Dell trying to take over the computer company he founded on the cheap?

title: Shifting Hats and Working in Small Teams
description: This interview withLily Kanter,co-founder and chief executive of Serena & Lily, a home decor company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 24
description: With the federal government warning that the across-the-board budget cuts scheduled to take effect Friday could cause air travel delays and other problems, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood will join NBCs Meet the Press on Sunday.

title: Overcoming Obstacles to Better Health Care
description: AMERICANS spend far more on health care than people in other countries and we have little to show for it. And as we live longer after retirement, the share that will be paid by the government will rise.

title: An Average Traveler
description: I WAS born in Hollywood, Calif.  truly a shocking notion if you know how unstruck I am by stars.

title: Where the Cuts Will Fall
description: Beginning March 1, automatic spending cuts were set to hit, trimming $85 billion from the 2013 fiscal year budget and even more from each annual budget for the next decade. Some areas will be hit harder than others, as many programs are exempt from the cuts.

title: Ozzie Sweet, Photographer, 1918-2013
description: Mr. Sweet, whose work often appeared on the covers of Sport magazine, was less interested in capturing images than in creating them.

title: How Offices Become Complaint Departments
description: THERE is the ideal life, and then there is life as it really exists. We have various ways of expressing discontent over this inevitable gap, and one of the most common is complaining.

title: Buddhists, Reconstructing Sacred Tibetan Murals, Wield Their Brushes in Nepal
description: LO MANTHANG, Nepal  Dozens of painters sat atop scaffolding that soared toward the roof of an ancient monastery. With a swipe of their brushes, colors appeared that gave life to the Buddha. Gold for the skin. Black for the eyes. Orange for the robes.

title: Calling Out the Robocaller
description: LAST month, the Haggler was sitting at home when the phone rang.

title: Third Teenager Is Arrested Over Forced Fight Between 7-Year-Olds
description: The police have made a third arrest in a case involving a group of teenagers goading two 7-year-old girls to hit each other in a Bronx park. A video of the fight was widely viewed after being posted to YouTube and other Web sites.

title: Investors Rediscover Risk-Taking Abroad
description: RISK-TAKING may be staging a comeback overseas.

title: Last-Lap Crash in Nascar Race Injures Fans
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  At least 28 people were injured in a crash at the end of a Nascar race at Daytona International Speedway on Saturday afternoon, bringing the issue of safety at racetracks back to the forefront on the eve of Sundays season-opening showcase, the Daytona 500.

title: Photos of The Moment | Bottega Veneta
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: I Surrender!
There Is an Algorithm for Everything, Even Bras
description: THE two and a half miserable hours that Michelle Lam spent in a fitting room, trying on bras, one fine summer day in 2011 would turn out to be, in her words, a life-changing experience. After trying on 20 bras to find one that fit, and not particularly well at that, she left the store feeling naked and intruded upon.

title: SimCity, for Real: Measuring an Untidy Metropolis
description: THE notion of a science of cities seems contradictory. Science is a realm of grand theory and precise measurement, while cities are messy agglomerations of people and human foible. But science is precisely the ambition of New York Universitys Center for Urban Science and Progress. Founded last year, the center has been getting under way in recent weeks, moving into new office space and firing off its first project proposal to the National Science Foundation.

title: In-Law Says Spains Royal Family Had No Business Role
description: MADRID  A son-in-law of King Juan Carlos I denied Saturday that his wife and other members of the Spanish royal household had any direct involvement in his past business dealings, which have been at the heart of a fraud investigation that has embarrassed the monarchy.

title: Veterinarian Squeeze
description: In the wake of the economic downturn, pet ownership and visits to veterinarians in the United States have declined. Meanwhile, the number of vets entering the work force has been increasing while their average debt load has risen and their starting salaries have fallen.

title: High Debt and Falling Demand Trap New Vets
description: HAYLEY SCHAFER chose her dream job at the age of 5. Three years later, her grandmother told her that if she wrote it down, the dream would come true. So she found a piece of blue construction paper and scrawled on it with a pencil: Veterianian. No one told me how to spell it, she remembers. They just said, Sound it out.

title: A Flood of Vets From the Caribbean
description: The Ross University School of Veterinary Medicine, located on the Caribbean island of St. Kitts, graduated 287 students last year, triple the number of many American schools.

title: Circus Arts, for the Stage
description: For nearly 50 years, Hovey Burgess has been teaching circus techniques to acting students at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University.

title: Major Banks Aid in Payday Loans Banned by States
description: Major banks have quickly become behind-the-scenes allies of Internet-based payday lenders that offer short-term loans with interest rates sometimes exceeding 500 percent.

title: Photos of The Moment | Jil Sander
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Witness Accounts and Images of Crash at Daytona
description: As our colleague Viv Bernstein reports, the end of the Nationwide Series race at Daytona International Speedway in Daytona Beach, Fla., was marred by a wreck that injured dozens of spectators and sheared the front from one of the cars. The impact of the crash was strong, ripping the car driven by Kyle Larson nearly in half and sending debris high into the stands.

title: Languishing in Lebanon
description: Syrian refugees are making do in Lebanon with the help of aid organizations and some municipalities but little support from the Lebanese government.

title: Syrian Refugees
description: As a tide of Syrians flees civil war, their soaring numbers threaten neighboring Lebanons precarious balance. And the Lebanese governments anemic response leaves the refugees scattered and struggling to survive.

title: Swollen With Syrian Refugees, Lebanon Feels Its Stitching Fray
description: QAA, Lebanon  Quietly but inexorably, a human tide has crept into Lebanon, Syrias smallest and most vulnerable neighbor.

title: Aleksei German, Director of Anti-Soviet Movies, Dies at 74
description: Aleksei German, a Russian director known for grim, hypnotic films that captured the darkness of the Soviet era and especially Stalins rule, died on Thursday in St. Petersburg. He was 74.

title: Dolan Deflecting Talk of a Possible Promotion
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, wearing a black cassock and a large pectoral cross, stood at the center of an Upper West Side synagogue on Saturday, stretched his arms toward the heavens with his palms facing up, and joked to the standing-room-only congregation, Does this look papal enough?

title: Stringer Is Left With No Milestone, Again, and No Answers
description: With three minutes left, C. Vivian Stringer stood in front of her bench, arms folded, and slowly shook her head. After having so many answers during her 42-year, 899-victory coaching career, she seemed as baffled as her Rutgers team.

title: Princeton Team Wins Title at a Top Amateur Event
description: The biggest social events of the chess worlds year are the amateur team tournaments held in four American cities over Presidents Day weekend.

title: Big East Settles for Deal With ESPN
description: Two years ago, the Big East hoped for television riches. Now that dream is over.

title: Fault-Finding Grows Intense as Cuts Near
description: WASHINGTON  First the White House and Congress created a potential fiscal crisis, agreeing more than a year ago to once-unthinkable governmentwide spending cuts in 2013 unless the two parties agreed to alternative ways to reduce budget deficits.

title: Samsungs New 8-Inch Tablet Takes on the iPad Mini
description: Samsung Electronics is taking yet another swipe at its longtime partner, Apple. The South Korean manufacturer on Saturday introduced a new 8-inch tablet, intended to compete directly with Apples 7.9-inch iPad Mini.

title: Another Chapter in Rivalry Ends With Georgetown Win
description: SYRACUSE  There was history on the court, on the sidelines, even in the deepest reaches of the Carrier Dome, where fans stretched out farther to watch basketball than ever before.

title: Wheeler, Mets Top Prospect, Looks in Top Form in Spring Opener
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  As much as players and coaches and members of the news media like to play down its importance, the first game of spring training always brings a certain measure of excitement, if only as a sign that meaningful baseball rests on the horizon.

title: Some See a Move by Cornyn to the Right
description: After more than a decade representing blood-red Texas in the United States Senate, John Cornyn finds himself in an unusual spot: burnishing his conservative credentials.

title: Martin Set to Prove to Knicks He Belongs
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  About halfway through Kenyon Martins first interview session after he signed a 10-day contract with the Knicks, he was asked if he could once again embody the qualities of a warrior on the court.

title: Church Helps Fill a Void in Africa
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  The young woman slept soundly on the cool marble floor before the altar, a break from the chaos at home. In the courtyard, neighborhood teenagers filled giant jerrycans with purified water from a stone fountain. In an aisle, a rail-thin young woman from a nearby slum said she had not eaten since yesterday but was expecting sustenance here.

title: Dozens Hurt in Crash
description: As many as 28 people were injured in a crash at the end of a Nationwide Series race at Daytona International Speedway.

title: Advocates Seek Mental Health Changes, Including Power to Detain
description: SHERMAN  A worried call from his daughters boyfriend sent Paul Boren rushing to her apartment on the morning of March 27, 2004. He drove the eight blocks to her apartment, peering into his neighbors yards, searching for Andre Thomas, Laura Borens estranged husband.

title: At Scouting Combine, Teo Faces First Interview Test
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Manti Teo did double takes in the grocery store to see if people were staring at him, and it troubled him that his last name had been splashed everywhere. But by Saturday, Teo said he was no longer embarrassed, or he would not have been able to do what had been anticipated since the story of a bizarre hoax about a nonexistent girlfriend was first revealed more than a month ago.

title: Cervelli, Back Behind Plate for Yankees, Is Doing His Best to Stay There
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Francisco Cervelli was crushed last season when the Yankees sent him down to catch for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre. After spending most of the previous three seasons in the Bronx, he figured his roster spot was secure. He was wrong.

title: Sometimes the Things Are Not All Aubusson
description: I dont usually respond to e-mail invitations from people I dont know, but the one from Judy Robinson, who runs one of Houstons A-list estate sale companies, was hard to resist: Estate sale from the Houston residence of the late Mildred Yount Manion II, heiress from an important Texas oil family and Kentuckys famous Spindletop horse farm.

title: A Conservative Provocateur, Using a Blowtorch as His Pen
description: At 11:42 a.m. on Feb. 14, a conservative online magazine called The Washington Free Beacon posted a dispatch about a speech Chuck Hagel gave in 2007 in which it said he called the State Department an adjunct to the Israeli foreign ministers office.

title: Lottery Numbers
Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 24
description: Theres something to be said for stabbing people in the front in a town where everybody goes around all day stabbing each other in the back.

title: Mark Dold, Edgar McIntosh
description: Mark H. Dold, the son of Mary L. Dold and Dr. Henry J. Dold of Glenview, Ill., was married Saturday evening to Edgar Joseph McIntosh, a son of Anne M. McIntosh of Amherst, Mass., and the late Robert E. McIntosh. Dr. Dold, who received a one-day solemnization authorization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated at the Red Barn on the campus of Hampshire College in Amherst.

title: Danielle Rosenthal, Ashley Summer
description: Danielle Shira Rosenthal and Ashley Boland Summer were married Saturday evening at the Old Courthouse in Cleveland. The Rev. Bob Javorsky, a minister of the Unity Church, officiated with assistance from Cantor Elliot J. Portner.

title: Stephanie Miranda, James ODonnell
description: Stephanie Miranda and James Maitland ODonnell were married in New York on Saturday. The Rev. Damian OConnell performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral.

title: Paula Kweskin and Yoni Weiss
description: Persistence (and a bluff) pays off.

title: Priscilla Flores, Harry Dohnert Jr.
description: Priscilla Flores and Harry Joseph Dohnert Jr. were married Friday at St. Agnes Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. John M. Knapp, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Robert Wallace and Donald Witkowski
description: The attraction was immediate.

title: Brad Hoylman and David Sigal
description: Brad Madison Hoylman and David Ivan Sigal were married Friday afternoon at Congregation Beit Simchat Torah in Manhattan. Rabbi Rachel S. Weiss performed the ceremony.

title: Yoshino Woodard and Cameron White
description: Yoshino Nashira Woodard and Cameron Rashod White were married Saturday at Canaan Baptist Church in New Castle, Del. The Rev. Christopher Alan Bullock, a Baptist minister, officiated with the Rev. Rudolph Varica Oliver, also a Baptist minister, assisting.

title: Eliana Bavli and Samuel Tisch
description: Eliana Yael Bavli, the daughter of Madeline Bavli and Dr. Samuel Bavli of Cedarhurst, N.Y., is to be married Sunday evening to Samuel Aaron Tisch, a son of Merryl H. Tisch and James S. Tisch of Manhattan. Rabbi Philip Hiat, the grooms maternal grandfather, is to officiate at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan, with Rabbi Kenneth Hain taking part.

title: Azmina Jasani and Faheem Madhani
description: Azmina Noorallah Jasani and Faheem Karim Amin Madhani were married Friday at Hotel El Convento in San Juan, P.R. The Rev. Cory Casterton, a nondenominational minister who was ordained by the Elim Fellowship, officiated. On Monday, the couple is to have a religious ceremony at the Manhattan Ismaili Jamatkhana, a prayer center where they met in 2009. Mayur Lakhani, a friend of the couple who is affiliated with the center, is to lead it.

title: As Oscars Fever Builds, Some Chinese Ask: What About Our Films?
description: BEIJING  As Oscar fever grows around the world with the 85th Academy Awards set to begin in Los Angeles just hours from now, excitement is building in China, even though it has no films in competition. There is also a sense of frustration here about why Chinas movies arent nominated for the worlds biggest awards?

title: Corrections: February 24, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: For Cream of the Bundesliga, a Week to Savor
description: We didnt think it would be so easy, was the resonant battle cry that seemed to strike the tone of German soccer so perfectly last week after a resounding display from each of its three participants after the initial leg of the first knock-out round of this seasons UEFA Champions League.

title: Making a Statement With Wool
description: For his latest Bottega Veneta collection, the creative director Tomas Maier primarily used wool. He said he was interested in the attitude of wool and the various ways it can be considered. This meant various treatments like boiling and washing and, as if wool were not stiff enough, bonding it to another material. Some flannels were washed so many times that I thought an off-white dress smeared with a red collage of fabric bits might be muslin. But it wasnt.

title: In Last Sunday Address, Pope Says He Will Continue to Serve God
description: VATICAN CITY  In his last Sunday blessing before he retires, Pope Benedict XVI reassured Catholics that he was not abandoning them but would continue to serve the church even in his retirement.

title: Marni: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: French Tax Proposal Zeroes In on Web Giants Data Harvest
description: PARIS  Only a few weeks after the French Constitutional Council rejected one new tax idea  a 75 percent levy on annual incomes of more than 1 million euros ($1.3 million)  another began percolating through the halls of the finance ministry here: a proposal to tax the collection of personal data on the Internet.

title: Photos of The Moment | Emilio Pucci
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Opera for an Era When Money Is Tight
description: VIENNANot long ago it looked as if cuts in arts funding would sound the death knell of the Vienna Chamber Opera, known in German as the Kammeroper, an ensemble esteemed for its chamber-scale productions in an intimate, inviting setting. The Austrian federal governments decision to eliminate entirely its support, which constituted half of the companys governmental subsidies (the other half coming from the city) effectively put the Kammeroper out of business.

title: Debt, Spreads, and Mysterious Omissions
description: Binyamin Applebaum reports on a new paper by Greenlaw et al alleging that bad things will happen to America, because debt over 80 percent of GDP leads to high interest rates, and is skeptical  but not skeptical enough. I found the paper amazing, and not in a good way.

title: A Birth Mother With the Right Regrets
description: My mother looked shocked and said, I cant raise this baby for you, but I was ready with my reply.

title: Sasha Luss Transforms Backstage at Moschino
description: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper390 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

title: At the Spirit Awards, Love for Silver Linings and, Well, Spirits
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  A debut feature made by a neophyte director with a nonprofessional cast was overlooked in favor of a film with Hollywood names and a budget that was $20 million higher as Beasts of the Southern Wild lost several times over to Silver Linings Playbook at the Film Independent Spirit Awards here on Saturday.

title: Palestinians Dispute Israels Findings on a Prisoners Death
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Health Ministry said Sunday night that preliminary autopsy findings could not determine the cause of death of a 30-year-old Palestinian prisoner, which Israeli officials had at first attributed to a heart attack. But Palestinian officials said the lack of heart damage coupled with bruising on the mans chest, back and neck suggested that he was tortured during interrogation.

title: Euro Delusions
description: Ive been browsing through the collected speeches of Olli Rehn, the vice-president of the European Commission, who has emerged as the face of denialism when it comes to the effects of austerity. What I wanted to do is pinpoint what, exactly, he and those who share his position see as the evidence that their view is right. And I think its two things.

title: Disruptions: Data Without Context Tells a Misleading Story
description: Several years ago, Google, aware of how many of us were sneezing and coughing, created a fancy equation on its Web site to figure out just how many people had influenza. The math works like this: peoples location + flu-related search queries on Google + some really smart algorithms = the number of people with the flu in the United States.

title: In Artists Game Show, the Prize Is a Passport
description: In a quiet museum in a placid Connecticut community, Lee Walther, 72, is shrieking. She clasps her hands in an Oscar-winning pose, then throws them wildly toward the air. Shes just discovered that shes won a passport from the United States of North America, which will allow her to travel anywhere in the world.

title: Feliciano Sidelined While Doctors Determine Heart Issue
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Pedro Feliciano will be sidelined for two weeks while doctors determine the cause of some irregularity in his heart, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson said Sunday.

title: Framework Announced for Peace in Congo
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Leaders of several African countries and United Nations officials on Sunday announced a new framework to tackle instability in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a war-torn country that has become synonymous with suffering and has eluded countless attempts to build a lasting peace over the years.

title: Mozilla Builds an Operating System for a Firefox Smartphone
description: Apple and Google are getting a nonprofit competitor, which aims to swamp them by using Web-based technologies that act like smartphone apps.

title: A Quiet Oscar Weekend at the Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES The Academy Awards, or the Super Bowl for women, as the media industry often refers to it, typically makes for a quiet weekend at the multiplex. This year was no exception, even though both new wide-release films were aimed at men.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 85TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Seth MacFarlane makes his debut as host of this ceremony, broadcast live from the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are predicting that Daniel Day-Lewis will take home the Oscar for his portrayal of Abraham Lincoln in Steven Spielbergs Lincoln, which earned 12 nominations, including best direction, picture, screenplay (for Tony Kushner), supporting actor (Tommy Lee Jones) and supporting actress (Sally Field). The best actress category ranges from 9-year-old Quvenzhan Wallis (of Benh Zeitlins Beasts of the Southern Wild, a debut feature that earned four nominations, including best directing and best picture) to Emmanuelle Riva, (of Michael Hanekes Amour, which received five nods, including best direction, picture and foreign language film) who turns 86 on Sunday. The best picture category is filled out by Ben Afflecks Argo, Quentin Tarantinos Django Unchained, Tom Hoopers Les Misrables, Ang Lees Life of Pi, David O. Russells Silver Linings Playbook and Kathryn Bigelows Zero Dark Thirty. Mr. Lee and Mr. Russell are also nominated for best director. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 5 on the TV Guide Channel; and at 6 on Channel 11. Red-carpet coverage (above, the carpet being rolled out) begins at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E!

title: Governors Issue Warning on Impact of Cuts
description: Governors in both parties warned on Sunday of the potentially damaging consequences across the country if President Obama and Congress do not agree on a plan to avoid across-the-board spending cuts that are scheduled to take effect beginning on Friday.

title: The Daily Shoe | Bruno Magli
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Lawmakers Dismiss Chinas Denials Over Cyberattacks
description: In some of his strongest public remarks yet about the cyberattacks on American companies and government agencies that are believed to have been sponsored by China, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said Sunday that the situation was as bad as Ive ever seen it and exponentially getting worse.

title: A Complex Role for Medicare in the Standoff in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  In some ways, the partisan standoff over looming budget cuts resembles earlier links in the chain of fiscal battles that began two years ago.

title: Model Diary | Drake Burnette
description: Fashion week newcomer Drake Burnette is in her first season of shows and already making waves in the industry since opening for Christopher Kane days ago. T gets in on the conversation with the 27-year-old buzzworthy brunette, who was in her first movie just months ago (Larry Clarkes Marfa Girl) and has gigs morning, afternoon and night today in Milan (Fendi, Dolce & Gabbana, and Ferragamo).

title: Afghanistan Bars Elite U.S. Troops From a Key Province
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government barred elite American forces from operating in a strategic province adjoining Kabul on Sunday, citing complaints that Afghans working for American Special Operations forces had tortured and killed villagers in the area.

title: Missoni: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: The Daily Do | Pucci
description: Emilio Puccis free-flowing fringe combined the gypsy bohemian feel of Anita Pallenberg with the cool, sleek modernity of Lou Doillon.

title: After M.T.A. Setbacks, No-Swipe Fare Cards Are Still Stuck in the Future
description: For nearly 50 years, coins were the currency in New Yorks subway and bus system. Tokens carried the next 40 years, until the MetroCard first slid into riders wallets in 1993. The next big thing was to be a contactless fare card  no swipe required.

title: Conservative Is Elected President in Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  The conservative candidate in the Cyprus presidential election won a double-digit victory on Sunday, ahead of crucial negotiations between the financially ailing nation and international lenders over a bailout.

title: Britains Economic Malaise Brought Ratings Downgrade
description: LONDON  At the root of Moodys decision to downgrade Britains credit rating is a crucial economic reality: Britain has begun to trail its peers in Europe  even bailed-out euro zone economies  when it comes to bringing down its budget deficit and making it attractive for foreigners to buy its exports.

title: An Unforgettable Day for Two Clubs That Had Come So Far
description: LONDON

title: As Wary Fans Return After Crash, Nascar Plans Safety Review
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  It was Sunday morning and Fran McCabe of Ormond Beach, Fla., was back in her customary seat in Section H a few rows up from the catch-fence along the front stretch at Daytona International Speedway. That is where McCabe and her husband and son sit every year for the Daytona 500.

title: Chilling View of Authority
description: Anyone who doubts the old truism that power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely should get to the Metropolitan Opera before March 16.

title: The 100-Year Flood of Stravinskys Rite Rolls On
description: Conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra in Stravinskys Rite of Spring on Friday night at Carnegie Hall, Yannick Nzet-Sguin kept the mysterious Introduction restrained and elusive to eerie effect. The elegiac melodies played a game of tease with slinky inner voices in the reedy woodwinds. Mr. Nzet-Sguin, in his first season as the orchestras music director, strongly emphasized the musics primordial elements.

title: He May Have Nothing to Hide, but Hes Always Under Watch
description: The Chinese conceptual artist, sculptor, photographer and filmmaker Ai Weiwei has a company that bears the tongue-in-cheek name Fake Design, but the challenges he faces are all too real. As one of Chinas most outspoken political dissidents he has been detained, arrested, beaten and repeatedly harassed and censored while trying to exercise rights supposedly enshrined in Chinas constitution.

title: Broken Arm Sidetracks Granderson Move
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees were already trying to gird themselves for a season without a ton of power in their lineup, and then Curtis Granderson stepped into the batters box to face the Toronto Blue Jays J. A. Happ on Sunday.

title: Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: San Francisco Symphonys Oboist Collapses During Performance
description: The principal oboist of the San Francisco Symphony collapsed in mid-performance of Richard Strauss oboe concerto Saturday night and was taken by ambulance to the hospital. An orchestra spokesman, Oliver Theil, said the musician, William Bennett, was standing on stage before the orchestra and performing when he passed out. He said Mr. Bennett, 56, suffered a brain hemorrhage and was in the hospital in guarded condition on Sunday. The oboist joined the symphony in 1979 and has been principal since 1987.

title: Drug to Treat Asthma Could Relieve Hives Patients of a Chronic Itch, Study Says
description: An asthma drug has shown promise in relieving itchiness for patients with chronic hives who do not get relief from traditional antihistamine treatment.

title: Threes a Trend | Wet Hair
description: In Milan, models hair appeared more wet than set, adding an undone element to deceptively skillful looks.

title: Photos of The Moment | Roberto Cavalli
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: In Spring Game, a Glimpse of the Mets Future
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  For two innings Sunday at Osceola County Stadium, the Mets could see their future. Matt Harvey pitched to Travis dArnaud for the first time. The Mets hope it will be a productive battery for years to come.

title: One Summer and One Girl Will Define Him Throughout His Lifetime
description: The title, setting and central romance of Stuart Nadlers Wise Men are whoppingly bland. The novel is about two men, a father and son, whose surname is Wise. Its main setting is a pokey but fabulous seaside compound on Cape Cod. And at first it seems to be about That Summer, the time when a shy boy develops a hopeless crush on some unattainable woman and seems unlikely ever to get over her. Lots of gooey romances fit this description.

title: Riffing on Prokofiev and Downsizing Schumann
description: The Argento New Music Project took a circuitous route from the recent past to the near future at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music on Saturday evening, plunging deep into history along the way.

title: Is That All There Is? And How. But Thats Plenty.
description: Because a vocal signature is as distinct as a fingerprint, there is a crucial difference between shows that pay tribute to a singer and those that salute a songwriter. Unless the performer is a skilled impersonator, what you hear are distant echoes of a voice that only call attention to the absence of the musician being remembered. In the case of a songwriter the material speaks for itself.

title: Clearheaded Again, Oldest Oriole Is Back
description: SARASOTA, Fla.

title: Twirling and Leaping, Before and After
description: Do you like your dances down and dirty or cleaned up with lights and costumes? In Stripped/Dressed the choreographer Doug Varone has created a series in which audiences are shown two sides of a production: the first half reveals inspirations behind a dance, while the second half showcases the piece itself.

title: Dolan Offers Role Model for Choosing Next Pope
description: Some cardinals have a list of qualities they want in the next pope: an eager evangelist, master communicator, and deft administrator, with an ear for languages and a heart for the developing world.

title: A JPMorgan Deal Maker Is Returning to the Law
description: 8:32 a.m. | Updated with memoOne of JPMorgan Chases most senior deal makers is heading back to the practice of law.

title: Its Her Day, but His Victory
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A day after a horrific crash took the focus away from racing and threatened to turn Nascars season-opening showcase, the Daytona 500, into an afterthought, Danica Patrick did what she does best. She put the focus right back on her.

title: 11th Slava Memorial Cup in Moscow
description: The 11th Slava Memorial Cup concluded in Moscow on Sunday. The tournament is named in memory of Slava Grinuk, a promising Russian player who died of cancer at the age of 28 in 1999.

title: The Forgotten Emancipationists
description: On the 150th anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation, discussion over who freed the slaves, fueled by movies like Lincoln, have become commonplace. While historians have debated the relative roles of Abraham Lincoln and the slaves themselves in the coming of emancipation, few have paid attention to the abolitionists, the forgotten emancipationists in the story of black freedom.

title: Photos of The Moment | Marni
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: An Oratorio of History With History of Its Own
description: By the time of Wynton Marsaliss 1994 oratorio, Blood on the Fields, written for three singers and a 15-piece band, his scale for musical structure and organizational planning was big and getting bigger.

title: Songs of Childhood With an Undertow of Fear
description: On Saturday evening the mezzo-soprano Magdalena Kozena and the pianist Yefim Bronfman presented an elusive and poetic program of songs at Carnegie Hall. Their selections of works by Mussorgsky, Rachmaninoff, Ravel and Bartok brought to light absorbing facets of these composers and their relation to language. It was a sensitive and often unsettling performance that forced the audience to listen closely.

title: The Next Cinematic Annie Is Not an Unknown
description: Quvenzhan Wallis, the 9-year-old Oscar-nominated actress, has been cast in the title role of a new film adaptation of the musical Annie, Sony Pictures Entertainment announced on Sunday. Directed by Will Gluck (Easy A), the film is scheduled for release during the winter holiday season in 2014. In a statement Hannah Minghella, president of production for Columbia Pictures, said that Ms. Wallis, right, is, an extraordinary young talent with an amazing range, not only as an actress but as a singer and dancer, and we cant wait for audiences to further discover her. Ms. Wallis has earned numerous accolades for her portrayal of Hushpuppy in Beasts of the Southern Wild, and is the youngest person ever to be nominated for the best actress Academy Award.

title: Banksy Work Removed From Miami Auction
description: A stenciled work by the British graffiti artist Banksy was withdrawn from auction in Miami on Saturday after residents of a London community lobbied to reclaim it, The Associated Press reported. The mural, Slave Labor (Bunting Boy), above, features a young boy using an old-fashioned sewing machine to create Union Jack flags. It appeared last May on a wall outside a discount store in Haringey, a north London borough, but subsequently vanished this month, leaving only a patch of exposed brick. After learning that the work would be auctioned, members of the Haringey Council sent an open letter to Fine Art Auctions Miami requesting that the work be returned. The piece was expected to fetch $500,000 to $700,000, but the auction house removed it from the planned sale without explanation. Claire Kober, who leads the Haringey Council, said the council wants to bring the work back to London.

title: New Works and Repertory Play to Company Strengths
description: LONDON  Who can reconcile the contradictions of todays Royal Ballet? At the end of last week, in a bill of six ballets by the founding choreographer Frederick Ashton (1904-88), the most conservative of mid-20th century theater masters, the dancers looked unaffected, fulfilled and marvelously contemporary. Yet in a program of George Balanchines Apollo and world premieres by Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon, the two finest choreographers working internationally in ballet today, everybody applied lots of exaggerated facial expressions, as if nobody trusted the movement to speak for itself. I shall return to the Ashton program in a later review. Here I respond to the premieres and Apollo.

title: To Test Some Boundaries, First You Charge Forward, and Then You Back Off
description: A choreographer chatting about his work can make for a dull spot in a dance program. But at Florence Gould Hall on Friday, Richard Alston not only spoke illuminatingly about his own choreography, he also gave an accurate endorsement of the troupe performing it, New York Theater Ballet. I like the company I keep here, he said, meaning both the unpretentious dancers and the high-class repertory.

title: Like a He-Man
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Angela Olson Halsted made her 2011 New York Times debut on the puzzle page in a bummer of a collaboration with Doug Peterson (Across Lite, Solution, blog) and if you do the Los Angeles Times crossword, Ms. Halsted might also be familiar to you as PuzzleGirl, the former writer of the L.A. Times Crossword Confidential blog.

title: A Campaign to Underscore Risk of War Coverage
description: Friends of journalists who have died covering the violent Arab Spring uprisings are trying to put their grief to good use. They are putting together an online campaign called A Day Without News? to persuade the public to pay attention to the sacrifices journalists make.

title: Top British Cardinal Faces Accusations of Committing Inappropriate Acts
description: LONDON  Britains most senior Roman Catholic cleric, Cardinal Keith OBrien, has been accused of committing inappropriate acts in his relations with three priests and one former priest, the newspaper The Observer reported Sunday. The accusations, which date back to the 1980s, have been forwarded to the Vatican.

title: Barnes & Noble Weighs Its E-Reader Investment
description: Even for a company with a lot of bad news lately, the bulletin from Barnes & Noble this month had an ominous feel.

title: Morsi Moves Election Day in Egypt to Avoid Holiday Conflict
description: President Mohamed Morsi on Sunday changed the dates for the parliamentary elections to avoid conflict with the Coptic Christian celebrations of Palm Sunday and Easter on April 28 and May 5. The announcement last week that the elections would begin on April 27 and 28 and continue on May 4 and 5 set off an uproar among Coptic Christians because the overlap with their holidays would have put a special burden on Coptic voters. Mr. Morsi is a Muslim who led the Muslim Brotherhoods political arm, and the scheduling decision also raised questions about his awareness of the concerns of Coptic Christians, who make up about 10 percent of Egypts 85 million residents. Almost any Copt could have told the government that the initial voting plan called for balloting on both holidays. Citing unnamed sources in the presidents office, Egyptian state media said the initial scheduling was an unintentional error and quickly fixed. The elections will now begin on April 22.

title: Photos of The Moment | Emporio Armani
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: For Stocks, an Upturn Is Battered by Doubts
description: The investor euphoria that began the year is beginning to seem like a hazy dream.

title: A Mismatch Any Fan Could Love
description: Rob Hughes writes about Sundays League Cup final at Wembley in London, a 5-0 victory by Swansea against fourth-tier Bradford City that was forgettable by competitive standards but unforgettable for supporters of any stripe. Read his article on the final here, and come back to comment.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Merkel Raises Turks Hope Of European Union Entry
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany arrived in Turkey on Sunday for talks with Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, holding out hope for new impetus in the stalled negotiations for the country to join the European Union.

title: Italians Begin to Vote in Two-Day General Election
description: ROME  Italians began voting on Sunday in a two-day general election that is being closely watched by Italys European partners as well as investors, who share the concern that unless a clear winner emerges from the voting, a new period of political and market instability lies ahead.

title: Photos of The Moment | Salvatore Ferragamo
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Riddle of the Human Species
description: The task of understanding humanity is too important and too daunting to leave to the humanities. Their many branches, from philosophy to law to history and the creative arts, have described the particularities of human nature with genius and exquisite detail, back and forth in endless permutations. But they have not explained why we possess our special nature and not some other out of a vast number of conceivable possibilities. In that sense, the humanities have not accounted for a full understanding of our species existence.

title: Nigeria Abuzz Over Who Paid for Beyonc Concert
description: Did the Nigerian president, Goodluck Jonathan, divert $1 million from an anti-poverty program to finance a trip to Lagos by American pop stars Beyonc Knowles and her husband Jay-Z?

title: Two Precedents Republicans Can Look to
description: In my Letter From Washington this week, I discuss Karl Roves efforts to minimize the role of radical elements in the Republican Party. William F. Buckley and former President Bill Clinton did something similar, to very different groups, decades ago.

title: On Portugal Beach, Riding a Wave That Hits Like a Quake
description: NAZAR, Portugal  The big ones typically come only once a year, in the winter. Whipped up by powerful storms in the North Atlantic, they roll for days toward Europe, rising to seemingly impossible heights before crashing on the shores of Praia do Norte, a beach along the Portuguese coast just north of this picturesque fishing town.

title: Panel on Health Care Work Force, Lacking a Budget, Is Left Waiting
description: WASHINGTON  One of the biggest threats to the success of President Obamas health care law comes from shortages of doctors, nurses and other health care professionals. description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The pond sits hidden behind a barricade of greenery, and it is mostly quiet there, save for the crunch of yellow grass under sneakers and the rustling of reptiles and rodents through the shrubs.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead

title: Nearly 100 Rebels Are Reported Killed in Mali Battle

title: In Cyberspace, New Cold War

title: Giving Viewers What They Want
description: In the television business, there is no such thing as a sure thing. You can have a gold-plated director, a bankable star and a popular concept and still, its just a roll of the dice.

title: Turks Debate Modest Dress Set for Takeoff

In the 60s and 70s the trend continued with fashions straight off the Paris runway, designed to show Turkeys European flair on its flagship airline.

title: A Costly and Unjust Perk for Financiers
description: OF the many injustices that permeate Americas byzantine tax code, few are as outrageous as the tax rate on carried interest  the profits made by private equity and hedge fund managers, as well as venture capitalists and partners in real estate investment trusts. This huge tax benefit enriches an already privileged sliver of financiers and violates basic standards of fairness and common sense.

title: Shared Wounds in Korea

title: Common Sense in Connecticut
description: A little over two months after the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Gov. Dannel Malloy of Connecticut has asked Hartfords balky Legislature to join him in reforming the states outdated gun control laws. We have changed, the governor said last week, referring to Sandy Hooks impact on the nation and on his state in particular. And I believe it is now time for our laws to do the same.

title: What Mortgage Relief?
description: A year ago, when the nations biggest banks settled with state and federal officials over claims of foreclosure abuses, the public was led to believe that the deal would allow millions of hard-pressed borrowers to escape the threat of foreclosure. It still hasnt happened.

title: Hope for the Teamless in Seattle
description: SEATTLE  Back in the 1992 N.B.A. playoffs, poor Alton Lister stepped between Shawn Kemp and the basket, back when Kemp sprinted and jumped as if from another planet, back when he and the SuperSonics made the spectacular routine. Kemp approached, elevated and jammed home a signature dunk for Seattle sports.

title: Austerity, Italian Style
description: Two months ago, when Mario Monti stepped down as Italys prime minister, The Economist opined that The coming election campaign will be, above all, a test of the maturity and realism of Italian voters. The mature, realistic action, presumably, would have been to return Mr. Monti  who was essentially imposed on Italy by its creditors  to office, this time with an actual democratic mandate.

title: Chinese Moving to East Harlem in a Quiet Shift From Downtown
description: For 10 days last month, a robbery pattern in East Harlem drew the heightened attention of the Police Department, which flooded the area with patrol officers and papered storefronts with wanted posters.

title: Less Innovation, More Inequality
description: ONE source of the outsize inequalities in America is the dynamism that made economic activity so rewarding. An economy open to new concepts and novel ventures is bound to generate unequal gains. To tax all of those gains would close off the prospects for success that many entrepreneurs need if they are to undertake ambitious ventures  a big mistake. But it would also be a mistake to misunderstand the relation of inequality and innovation. It is less innovation  not more  that has widened inequality in the United States in recent decades.Americas peak years of indigenous innovation ran from the 1820s to the 1960s. There were a few financial panics and two depressions, to be sure. But in this period, a frenzy of creative activity, economic competition and rapid growth in national income provided widening economic inclusion, rising wages for all and engaging careers for most. Innovations gave workers better tools to work with and better products to make, thus lifting their wages. Then this innovation began to retreat, most of it to an area of land along the West Coast. In the early 1970s the rate of indigenous innovation (as measured by its estimated contribution to the rate of growth in labor productivity) dropped by about half  to around 1 percent since then, from about 2 percent before then.

title: Defense and the Sequester
description: The arbitrary budget cuts known as the sequester will exact a toll on not only domestic programs but military spending as well. Hence the howls in Washington from the Pentagon chieftains and their ardent Congressional supporters. But the truth is that the military budget not only can be cut, but should be cut, though not with this kind of political machete and not in the way the service chiefs say they plan to wield it.

title: DNA and the Constitution
description: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear argument about whether it is constitutional for a state to collect DNA from people charged with violent crimes but not yet convicted. Last April, the Maryland Court of Appeals ruled that a state law authorizing such collection violated the Fourth Amendments prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.

title: Whats on Monday

In The Way We Were (1973), at 3:30, Ms. Streisand, in another Oscar-nominated role, plays a fiery liberal fighting for the survival of her marriage to a preppy writer (Robert Redford) during the McCarthy era.
