title: Soft-Drink Giant Wants Consumers to Be Impressed
description: McKayla the not-impressed Olympian sounds as if it might be the title of a song or a book. But as most Americans with access to a TV set, computer, smartphone or mobile device know, it is a reference to McKayla Maroney, an American gymnast at the 2012 Summer Olympics in London.

title: Royalty Pharma Offers to Buy Elan for $6.6 Billion
description: 11:34 a.m. | Updated

title: Monday Reading: Why Junk Food Is So Addictive
Japan Plans to Sell $10 Billion Stake in Cigarette Firm
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government is set to loosen its grip on Japan Tobacco, one of the worlds largest tobacco companies, by selling a third of its stake in a sale that will net the country about $10 billion.

title: Glenn Beck Begins Campaign to Urge TV Systems to Add His Web Channel
description: 8:48 a.m. | Updated  Glenn Beck is beginning a campaign to get his Internet channel, TheBlaze, onto cable and satellite television systems across the country, and the one system that already carries the channel, Dish Network, is backing him up.

title: Ode to the Humble Slice of Pizza
description: Dear Diary:

title: Giorgio Armani: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Milan

title: Lumire | Dance Fever
description: The Paris Opera Ballet, the oldest national ballet company in the world, dating to the 17th-century court of Louis XIV, has dared to break with tradition: for the first time in its history it is asking ordinary citizens for money.

title: The Single Logic of Continuous Russian History
description: MOSCOW  I am living through one of the most enjoyable periods of parenthood: My middle child, who is 11, is discovering some of the books and stories that shaped me. She still wants tickets to Justin Biebers April concert in Moscow, but we are engaged in a daily conversation about the Soviet past, which means I am answering questions and explaining concepts that touch me deeply.

title: The Gun Report: February 25, 2013
description: Every day, when Jennifer Mascia and I compile this report, we are stunned at the number of children who are accidentally shot  and often killed  because a gun-owning adult in their household has put a loaded gun someplace where they can get their hands on it and shoot it. We have three such examples in todays report, one of which resulted in the death of a 4-year-old in Houston. Other nations mandate that gun owners keep their firearms in safes bolted to the floor. Why dont we?

title: How Syria Is Becoming Bosnia
description: Typhoid and hepatitis outbreaks are spreading. An estimated 70,000 people are dead, and another 850,000 are refugees. After covering the battle for Damascus for a month, photographer Goran Tomasevic of Reuters declared the situation a bloody stalemate.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: NBC Ratings Tumble and Twitter Hacking Can Undermine Brands
description: NBCs ratings have plummeted since a great prime-time run last autumn, Bill Carter reports. NBCs viewership has dissipated to numbers never before seen by any broadcast network  certainly not during sweeps month. In February NBC was not only well behind its competitors but also the Spanish-language channel Univision. The numbers are so bad that NBC may have to offer make-goods, or free advertising time, to cover shortfalls of ratings guarantees. Audiences for once-promising sitcoms like Go On have disappeared; new shows like 1600 Penn have drawn little notice; and Do No Harm became the lowest-rated network drama on record before being canceled after two episodes. Saturday Night Live, the networks highest-rated show even though it is 38 years old, was the only silver lining.

title: Dislocation, Dislocation, Dislocation
description: GANGCA, China  It is 1 p.m. in the small Tibetan restaurant. Four middle-aged men crowd around a low table strewn with bottles of beer. As the afternoon goes on, more men join them, sporting gold teeth and thick sheepskin robes slung over jeans. They are resettled nomads, and without their flocks, I am told, they dont have much else to do but drink.

title: Horsemeat Scandal Grows More Serious and More Bizarre
description: LONDON  As European governments struggle in vain to draw a line under the scandal over horsemeat being sold as beef, the affair seems only to be widening, in sometimes bizarre ways.

title: A Tale of Two Adjustments
description: A commenter on my last euro post asks a good question: didnt Germany once have a problem of excessive unit labor costs, which it cured with a protracted squeeze? And in that case, why is it so terrible if Spain is asked to do the same thing?

title: The Ant, the Grasshopper and Electricity Prices in New England
description: The electricity crunch in New England that I wrote about on Feb. 15 persists, and it is clearly related to a shortage of natural gas pipeline capacity relative to growing demand. But experts say the root cause is something more complicated: a structural flaw in the regional electric market.

title: What Were Reading
description: NPR: Despite the lingering drought, the U.S.D.A. is predicting a record corn harvest, up nearly 40 percent over last years yield. The only problem is that the agency made nearly the same prediction last year, but the weather failed to cooperate.  Glenn Collins

title: The Daily Shoe | Bally
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Zeleny to Move From Times to ABC News
description: Jeff Zeleny, a top political reporter for The New York Times, was hired on Monday by ABC News, which said he will become the networks senior Washington correspondent next month.

title: From a Well-Traveled Chef, Pearl and Ash
description: The chef Richard Kuo has had a world of influences. Born in Taiwan, he lived in Australia before landing in New York, where his first job was at the wildly pioneering WD-50. Most recently, he took on New Nordic cusine at the short-lived Brooklyn pop-up Frej, with Fredrik Berselius.

title: Iran Enters Nuclear Talks in a Freshly Defiant Mood
description: TEHRAN  When Irans nuclear negotiating team sits down with its Western counterparts in Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Tuesday, it will offer no new plans or suggestions, people familiar with the views of the Iranian leadership say. More likely, they say, the Iranian negotiators will sit with arms crossed, demanding a Western change of heart.

title: For Seth MacFarlane, Thumbs Up From Fellow Comedians
description: 1:02 p.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES  Was Seth MacFarlane a terrible Oscar host or just a mediocre one? (He said it himself, onstage.) Or was he good? Our colleague Alessandra Stanley noted that as an M.C. he brought together old and new Hollywood, vaudeville-style shtick and contemporary humiliation humor. Other assessments are still trickling in along with the ratings (which early on, at least, show a rise), but backstage after the show, Jennifer Lawrence was certain.

title: Marine Deleeuw Transforms Backstage at Marni

title: Reality Wins the Race
description: Daytona 500 week had been filled with so much hope for Nascar. Certainly this was the year, racings grand pooh-bahs had to be thinking, that we would not be talking about rain delays or potholes or jet dryers bursting into flames. No, this year the forecast was good. The starlet Danica Patrick had won the pole position. The other drivers seemed to be keeping their Danica fatigue under wraps. Combustible Twitter feuds seemed to quiet to a manageable simmer. The stars all seemed to align just so.

title: The Promise and Peril of the Data-Driven Society
description: A small group of academics, business executives and journalists gathered at the M.I.T. Media Lab last Thursday, and the purpose was to toss out ideas and discuss the concept of Data-Driven Societies. A daunting topic, ambitious and vague at once, it seems.

title: A Troubled Papacy
description: The Timess Laurie Goodstein discusses the resignation of Cardinal Keith OBrien, Britains most senior Roman Catholic cleric, following accusations of inappropriate acts.

title: Look of The Moment | Oscars Edition
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Pocket of Manhattan Where No One Stays for Long
description: It seems like a perfectly nice apartment.

title: Distance from Carnage Doesnt Prevent PTSD for Drone Pilots
description: As debate raged over whether drone operators deserve a new medal, researchers with the Defense Department have found that pilots of drone aircraft experience mental health problems like depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder at the same rate as pilots of manned aircraft.

title: H&Ms Oscar Moment
description: While the Oscars red carpet was generally a success on Sunday night, there was a notable and disappointing absence of younger and more independent designer labels, like Zac Posen, Proenza Schouler and Joseph Altuzarra (at least not until the after-parties, where Madonna wore a look from Mr. Altuzarras fall show). Its a challenge for smaller fish to compete in a pond that is dominated by big labels like Valentino, Dior and Armani.

title: Image of the Day: Feb. 25
Williamstown Festival Will Include Animal Crackers and Bridges of Madison County
description: Hey, you got Animal Crackers in my Bridges of Madison County! No, you got Bridges of Madison County in my Animal Crackers! There may be no resolving this debate, but whether youre a fan of madcap comedy or musicals adapted from best-selling romance novels, this summers Williamstown Theater Festival will have something to offer you, judging by Mondays announcement of its lineup.

title: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
description: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

title: The Onion Apologizes for Tweet About Quvenzhan Wallis
description: The satirical publication The Onion apologized on Monday for a post published Sunday night on its Twitter account that made an obscene reference to Quvenzhan Wallis, the 9-year-old actress nominated for an Academy Award for her performance in Beasts of the Southern Wild.

title: Bob Hope Estate in Palm Springs Is Up for Sale
description: The huge Palm Springs estate of Bob Hope, the comic icon of midcentury film and television, and his wife, Dolores, is being brought to market for the first time this month, at an asking price of $50 million.

title: The Oscars: A Morning-After Report
description: On Saturday, at a lunch at the Beverly Hills home of Diane von Furstenberg and Barry Diller, where the guests ranged from Eddie Redmayne to George Hamilton, someone was talking about what it was like to attend the Oscars in person.

title: Awaiting the Dimming of G.E. at 30 Rock
description: What do the Apollo Theater, Katzs Delicatessen, the Chelsea Hotel, Pepsi and 30 Rockefeller Plaza have in common?

title: As Oil Spill Trial Opens, Push for a Deal Continues
description: NEW ORLEANS  BP finally faced off in court Monday against an army of federal and state prosecutors, lawyers and even its contract partners over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill three years ago, contending that it alone should not shoulder blame for the rig explosion that killed 11 workers and soiled beaches and marshes from Louisiana to Florida.

title: What Barnes & Nobles Retail Arm Might Be Worth
description: Though Leonard S. Riggio has sought to push Barnes & Noble into the future by supporting its Nook e-reader business, the booksellers chairman has long held a soft spot for the retailers brick-and-mortar outlets.

title: The Mathematics of Climate Change
description: Climate change is arguably the most important issue humanity has ever faced. The Earths average surface temperature continues to climb and weather is increasingly volatile. Our current trajectory looks perilous.

title: On Our Radar: Prison Term for Biodiesel Fraud
description: A Maryland man is sentenced to 12 years in prison for selling $9 million worth of bogus renewable fuel credits. The fraud scheme undermined the reputation of a program intended to reduce the nations dependence on foreign oil. [Environmental Protection Agency]

title: Michelle Obama Makes a Star Turn at the Oscars (via Satellite)
description: 6:21 p.m. | Updated She may not have walked the red carpet, but Michelle Obama  all bangs and biceps and bling  had her own star turn during Sunday nights Academy Awards ceremony, when she announced the winner for best picture via satellite from the White House.

title: Too Many Pills in Pregnancy
description: The thalidomide disaster of the early 1960s left thousands of babies with deformed limbs because their mothers innocently took a sleeping pill thought to be safe during pregnancy,

title: At 125 Years, a Rechristening for The Herald Tribune
description: The New York Times Company said on Monday that it was planning to rename The International Herald Tribune, its 125-year-old newspaper based in Paris, and would also unveil a redesigned Web site for international audiences.

title: Pynchon Takes On Silicon Alley
description: New Yorks technology scene is getting the Thomas Pynchon treatment.

title: Kerry Vows Not to Leave Syria Rebels Dangling in the Wind
description: BERLIN  Secretary of State John Kerry said on Monday that the Obama administration has been considering new steps to increase support for the Syrian opposition and hasten the departure of President Bashar al-Assad and that some of them would be decided at an international conference in Rome this week.

title: Lindsay Lohan to Guest Star on Anger Management With Charlie Sheen
description: In the surest sign that peace, calm and normalcy had been restored to Hollywood after a raucous Academy Awards ceremony, it was announced on Monday morning that Lindsay Lohan would appear in a coming episode of Anger Management, the FX sitcom starring Charlie Sheen.

title: What if the Republicans Had Won the Senate?
description: Alternative history is a popular niche in fiction. What would the world look like if Pickett had carried the day at Gettysburg? What if the Japanese had prevailed at Midway? How different would current events be if President Kennedys assassination had been thwarted?

title: Stars Celebrate at the Governors Ball
description: Winners basked in the limelight after the Oscars.

title: WWS 543, International Trade Policy: Class 6
description: Import-substituting industrialization (pdf).

title: After the First 100 Days of Xi Jinping
description: Xi Jinping has been general secretary of the Communist Party of China for just over 100 days. Last week, official media praised Mr. Xis first 100 days in office and his focus on the Chinese Dream as well as peoples livelihood issues like health, education, property prices and corruption.

title: Not Exactly the Social-Media Oscars
description: Adele Performs  Skyfall  Oscars 2013 by IdolxMuzic

title: Safety Agency Investigating 725,000 Fords
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is opening or upgrading investigations into about 725,000 Ford cars and sport utility vehicles, almost 88,000 Honda Pilots and an undisclosed number of Graco child restraints, according to reports posted on the agency Web site over the weekend.

title: Clock Ticking Down on What is Time Contest
description: If you have or are pursuing a graduate degree in the sciences, you have until March 1 to help Alan Alda and the folks at Stony Brook Universitys Center for Communicating Science answer this simple, but complicated, question: What is time?

title: Photos of The Moment | Giorgio Armani
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Small Picture: Mercy, Were in Season!
description: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

title: Continuing the Conversation on Paid Parental Leave
description: Dozens of readers wrote to us with their companys parental leave polices after reading theYour Money column, which discussed how American public and private organizations offer the least generous paid leave policies in the world.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: And1, Aliso Viejo, Calif., the basketball footwear and apparel company, chose Catch New York as agency of record. Billings were not disclosed. The assignment had previously been handled by Frank Creative, Portland, Ore.

title: Dynamos Boniek Garcia Has the Name, and He Has the Game
description: Perhaps only in soccers globalized realm could a guy from Honduras be named after a famous attacking midfielder from Poland and play professionally for a club team in the United States.

title: G.O.P. Drafts Plan to Give Obama Discretion on Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans are preparing to counter increasingly dire warnings from President Obama about the impact of automatic budget cuts with a plan to give the administration more flexibility in instituting $85 billion in cuts, a proposal they say could protect the most vital programs while shifting more of the political fallout to the White House.

title: For Autodesk, a Step Into a Nanoscale World
description: Autodesk, a quirky software start-up in Marin County, north of San Francisco, rose to prominence in the early 1980s because of AutoCAD, its computer-aided design program that was intended for use on personal computers. Over the next decade, AutoCAD became the standard design tool for architects and engineers.

title: How Will Magazine Titans Merge? Carefully
description: When Jack Griffin, the former president of the magazine company Meredith, took the reins at Time Inc., he threw a holiday party for his staff on the 34th floor of the Time & Life Building. For many employees at the famously hierarchal company, their first visit to the rambling executive suites that inspired the sets of Mad Men became known as The Miracle on 34th.

title: In Performance: Ethan Hawke & Dana Lyn
description: Ethan Hawke and the violinist Dana Lyn perform the number Aura Lee from the New Groups production of Jonathan Marc Shermans play Clive.

title: Healthy Bacteria in Babies
description: Infants may fail to develop a healthy mixture of intestinal bacteria if they are delivered by Caesarean section or do not drink breast milk, researchers are reporting.

title: Are These Ads Worth the Paper Theyre Not Printed On?
description: A campaign to promote the value of using paper is turning to everyday situations to make its point after spending more than two years at the office.

title: The Daily Shoe | Alejandro Ingelmo
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: With Rent Ever Higher, Irish Pub Gives Up
description: In a neighborhood where shiny outposts of big-name retailers have displaced the little stores and restaurants where everybody seemed to know everybody else, a longtime holdout is finally planning a last last call.

title: Videos and Recipes for Your Mediterranean Diet
description: Good news for your heart, and taste buds: a rigorous study published Monday on The New England Journal of Medicines Web site shows that heart disease in high-risk patients can be prevented by following the Mediterranean diet, which is rich in nuts, beans, fish, fruits, vegetables and olive oil. Even a moderate quantity of wine is allowed. These cooking videos and recipes can help get you started.

title: Will Yahoo Increase Productivity by Banning People From Working at Home?
description: When Marissa Mayer swooped into Yahoo last year, she tried to make it a more desirable place to work, adding perks like free food and smartphones.

title: German Central Bank Leader Joins Critics In Lecturing France on Government Debt
description: FRANKFURT  The head of the German central bank said Monday that France should not give up trying to bring its government deficit below 3 percent of gross domestic product, adding to the criticism being heaped on President Franois Hollande of France from abroad.

title: Root Vegetable Sweetness
description: Last week I got a Facebook message from a Recipes for Health fan that said: Help! Drowning in pounds of root vegetables from CSAwould love recipes for sweet potatoes, yellow potatoes, and carrots Since root vegetables and tubers keep well and can be cooked up into something delicious even after they have begun to go limp in the refrigerator, this weeks Recipes for Health should be useful. Root vegetables, tubers (potatoes and sweet potatoes, which are called yams by most vendors  I mean the ones with dark orange flesh), winter squash and cabbages are the only local vegetables available during the winter months in colder regions, so these recipes will be timely for many readers.

title: Walkabout  2/25: Looming Budget Cuts Threaten National Parks and Airports
description: Americas Best Idea, Endangered Absent a Congressional compromise to avert budget cuts, the National Park Service will be significantly reduced starting March 1, park retirees warn. (The New York Times)

title: Notes on the Decline of Work
description: My Sunday column on Americas declining rates of workforce participation raised a provocative issue without addressing all the possible objections to my claim that this is something we should be concerned about. With that in mind, here are provisional responses to three questions that a careful reader might have about my argument.

title: Visa Teams Up With Samsung on Mobile Payments
description: The idea of paying for things with a phone is still foreign to most people, but now Visa and Samsung Electronics are working together to make mobile payments easier.

title: An Inside View of How We Recruit (Without Recruiters)
description: Last week my post, Why We Never Use Professional Recruiters, spawned a terrific discussion with many commenters taking the time to share their views on the best way to do recruiting. Im grateful for each of the comments. As I said in my very first post for this column, I am hopeful that together, we can discover how to build a great team.

title: Quiz: Do You Have a Mediterranean Diet?
description: Take this survey, as designed by the researchers from the University of Barcelona to determine if your current diet is heart healthy.

title: Italians Head to the Polls
description: Italians voted Sunday and Monday in a general election that is being closely watched to see whether a clear winner will emerge.

title: The Challenge of Sentencing White-Collar Defendants
description: Are white-collar defendants treated more favorably than other criminals when it comes to sentencing? A case involving the chief executive of a technology firm in Ohio that collapsed in 2003 after fraud allegations seems to indicate that perhaps there is such a thing as being too lenient, according to a Federal Appeals Court.

title: Ask Charles Isherwood About the New Theater Season
description: The spring theater season can be hard to pin down. Sure, Broadways got its share of celebrities, including Tom Hanks in Lucky Guy and Bette Midler in Ill Eat You Last: A Chat With Sue Mengers. But there are also new plays and musicals about complex and compelling women and the worries of the working-class. Making decisions about what to see  Cinderella or Matilda? Ann Richards or the Virgin Mary? Diana Ross or drag queens?  wont be easy.

title: Pelfreys Fast Recovery Excites Twins
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  The Mets drafted Mike Pelfrey with the ninth overall pick in the 2005 draft, and like all teams choosing that high, they hoped they were getting a star. In hindsight, a better choice would have been Andrew McCutchen, Matt Garza or Jay Bruce, who were all picked later in the first round, but Pelfrey had his moments. He won 50 games for the Mets.

title: Have an N.H.L. Question? Slap Shot Has Answers
description: 4:48 p.m. | Updated Are the Blackhawks really this good? Are the Canadiens for real? Whats behind the Devils enduring success? And will any of it matter during the playoffs of a lockout-shortened season? Jeff Z. Klein, the national hockey writer for The Times, and longtime Slap Shot contributor Stu Hackel will answer questions from readers this week. Write your questions in the comments field below and answers will appear later this week on Slap Shot.Comments for this feature are closed.

title: My Dear Michael, Weve Discovered DNA
description: Writing to his son, Michael, Francis Crick tells of a most important discovery. (Related Article.)

title: The Daily Do | Gianfranco Ferr
description: Gianfranco Ferrs double French twist felt sculptural yet undone, almost as if it had been caught in a wind tunnel.

title: A DNA Lesson, From the Experts Pen
description: Dear Michael, Jim Watson and I have probably made a most important discovery.

title: Minnesota Wins Duals Again
description: Minnesota wrestlers had their head coach back in their corner. And now theyll have the National Duals championship back in their trophy case.

title: Yahoos Blow to Work-Family Balance
description: Yahoos.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Cooking Classes and Kids

title: H.P. and LG Put WebOS on Television
description: Maybe the little operating system that couldnt will gain a new life inside televisions, cars and washing machines.

title: Preparing Lemon Grass
description: The next time you come across a recipe that calls for lemon grass, dont turn the page. Melissa Clark shows how to handle it.

title: The Owl Comes Into Its Own
description: WASHINGTON  The day after a frigid, star-salted night spent tromping through the Alexandria woods with David Johnson of the Global Owl Project, and listening to the stridently mournful cries of wild barred owls that remained hidden from view, I stopped by the National Zoo around sunset to take visual measure of the birds I had heard.

title: Hungry Photography
description: A food photographer, food bloggers and a chef offer suggestions on how to make mobile food photography more appetizing.

title: Assemblyman Defends Wearing Blackface to a Party
description: A prominent state assemblyman from Brooklyn defended himself on Monday after wearing blackface to a party he hosted to celebrate the Jewish holiday of Purim, saying he did not mean to offend anyone.

title: Vietnamese Shrimp, From Cane to Cake
description: The hardest part about making Vietnamese shrimp on sugar cane, called chao tom, is finding the sugar cane.

title: Making Money After the Oscars
description: Timescast Media+Tech: How studios and networks continue to profit after the Academy Awards. | Taking social media food photography to the next level. | NBC struggles after its ratings plunge.

title: Buyout Offer Will Likely Not End Elans Deal Ambitions
description: Royalty Pharmas $6.6 billion indicative offer for the Elan Corporation probably wont be enough to end the latters ambitious dreams. Elan has grand acquisition plans after selling most of the rights to its blockbuster drug, Tysabri, for $3.25 billion this month. Royalty Pharma may well use that cash more wisely than Elans management, but the 4 percent premium it offered wont seal the deal.

title: The Sequester, State by State
description: The hatchet job on the federal budget commonly known as the sequester will hurt all 50 states both directly and indirectly, but it wont hurt them equally.

title: Really? Annoying Songs Get Stuck in Our Heads
description: THE FACTS

title: Split Vote Sends One Clear Message in Italy: No to Austerity
description: ROME  Italian voters delivered a rousing anti-austerity message and a strong rebuke to the existing political order in national elections on Monday, plunging the country into political paralysis after results failed to produce a clear winner.

title: Trusts Offer a Legal Loophole for Buying Restricted Guns
description: A growing number of shooting enthusiasts are creating legal trusts to acquire machine guns, silencers or other items whose sale is restricted by federal law  a mechanism that bypasses the need to obtain law enforcement approval or even undergo criminal background checks.

title: Debating House of Cards 2: How to Reap the Cable Whirlwind
description: Welcome back to House of Cards, the Recap. Today, Ashley Parker and David Carr take on episode two and tease apart the collaborations between the various estates in Washington. Abundant spoilers so proceed at your own viewing peril. If you missed the first installment, you can read it here. More to come in the next few days and in the meantime, please consider weighing in with a comment below.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Making Money After the Oscars
description: How studios and networks continue to profit after the Academy Awards. Taking social media food photography to the next level. NBC struggles to recover from its ratings plunge.

title: Taking Sides
description: Q. Why are some of our internal organs on one side rather than the other? Does anyone ever get an organ on the wrong side?

title: Sigrid Agren Transforms Backstage at Jil Sander

title: Through Owl Eyes; Pushing to Map the Mind; DNA Discovery in Cricks Cursive
description: New science on a wise old bird, John Markoff on an effort to map the brain, and Nicholas Wade on Francis Cricks letter to his son.

title: An Out-of-Character Day-Lewis and a Characteristically Candid Lawrence
description: LOS ANGELES  The pile-up of biggie awards at the end of the Oscars telecast last night meant that the major winners did not come back to be quizzed in the press room until well after the show was over. But they still had some choice comments before heading out to the parties.

title: Connecting the Neural Dots
description: In setting the nation on a course to map the active human brain, President Obama may have picked a challenge even more daunting than ending the war in Afghanistan or finding common ground with his Republican opponents.

title: Whistles May Harm Hearing, Study Shows
description: As a basketball referee in his spare time, Nathan Williams thought the whistles were unnecessarily loud.

title: How to Prepare Lemon Grass for Cooking
description: In this weeks column, I write about how to make Vietnamese shrimp on sugar cane without the sugar cane. My answer is to fry up the shrimp paste into cakes and serve it over rice noodles.

title: A Healthy Diet That Includes, Yes, Chocolate
description: The Mediterranean diet that participants in the new study were told to follow differs in some respects from the advice people generally get about healthy eating. It allows people to eat as many nuts and eggs and even as much chocolate as they want, as long as it is chocolate with more than 50 percent cocoa. It permits unlimited consumption of fish, seafood, whole-grain cereals and low-fat cheese.

title: Monday Motorsports: Jimmie Johnson Basks in Second Daytona 500 Victory
description: Jimmie Johnsons win at Daytona 500 on Sunday was his second in Nascars premier race; his first victory came in 2006. Johnson led only 17 of the 200 laps around the Daytona International Speedway tri-oval, but he remained out front when it mattered most, over the final 10 laps.

title: With New Laws, a Focus on Nurturing the Citys Native Plants
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law on Monday three green bills, one intended to increase the citys native biodiversity.

title: One-Upping His Dad, Josh Pettitte Throws No-Hitter
description: He is only a senior at Deer Park (Texas) High School, but young Josh Pettitte has already earned one accomplishment in baseball his dad Andy, in 491 major league starts, has not. Last Friday, in a game against Boerne Champion High, Josh Pettitte struck out 10 batters and gave up no hits in a 9-0 victory.

title: An Avian Tribe Apart
description: Scientists and bird lovers delve into the subtle and surprising world of owls.

title: Giving Voice to a Tale of Pursuit and Desire
description: The remarkable resurgence of Handel operas in the last quarter-century owes at least as much to their abundant opportunities for vocal display as to their overall musical quality, which can be spotty, or their dramatic persuasiveness, which is often feeble. So Carnegie Hall was well filled with voice aficionados on Sunday afternoon for a concert performance of Handels Radamisto, with the fine period-instrument band English Concert deftly conducted from the harpsichord by Harry Bicket.

title: Online Piracy Alert System to Begin This Week
description: The Copyright Alert System, a program of escalating warnings and prods against people suspected of online copyright infringement, is finally going into effect this week, more than a year and a half after the plan was announced as part of an agreement between the entertainment industry and five major Internet service providers.

title: Elevating the Land of Nod
description: Those flat-bed seats for international business-class fliers? Now that most airlines offer them, they are not so special anymore.

title: Primitive Mythology
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Scene City: After the Oscars
description: Vanity Fairs must-stop party after the awards.

title: Family Spectacle
description: Garrett Leight, the son of the Oliver Peoples co-founder Larry Leight, dabbled as a journalist and D.J. before giving in to fate in 2010 and starting his own line of retro optics in Venice, Calif. My dad of course is my mentor from a design standpoint, Garrett, 28, says. But while the father takes his inspiration from glamorous 1930s film stars, the sons frames channel bespectacled rebels like Hunter S. Thompson and Charles Bukowski. In an industry where brand names seem to matter more than ever, Leights glasses  logo-less and hand-finished  embody understated cool.

title: War of the Ants Intensifies in U.S.
description: An aggressive species of ant may be losing ground in North America to a more aggressive  and potentially dangerous  species, according to a new study.

title: Growing Wings and Rising Oceans
description: BOOK

title: The Stars and Their Little Gold Men
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  It was around midnight when Ben Affleck found his little brother, Casey, near the bar. Oscar in hand, Ben, the director of the best picture winner, Argo, horsed around with his brother, while a jazz trio played. They posed for a few selfies as their wives, Jennifer Garner and Summer Phoenix, looked on.

title: Benefits of DNA Testing (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: American Catholicism: Decline But Not Exhaustion
description: Just to add some context to my exchange last week with Rod Dreher over the possibility of Catholicisms ever exerting real influence again in late-modern America (and do read his follow-up here), these findings from a new Pew survey of American Catholics seem worth highlighting:

title: Discord Over Scholars Tribal Research
description: The battle among scholars over an American anthropologists research on an Amazon tribe has spread to the National Academy of Sciences, the nations most prestigious scientific body.

title: After Measles Success, Rwanda to Get Rubella Vaccine
description: Rwanda has been so successful at fighting measles that next month it will be the first country to get donor support to move to the next stage  fighting rubella too.

title: Heady Times for Compost Pioneers
description: Is it possible to make a living by turning rotting food into usable compost while also helping to curb greenhouse gas emissions and reduce landfill disposal costs?

title: Sad Day for Gotham City: Robin Will Die
description: Maybe its time for Batman to consider going solo again. On Wednesday DC Comics will publish issue No. 8 of Batman Incorporated. The comic, written by Grant Morrison, will feature the death of Damian Wayne, the son of Bruce Wayne and the current Robin.

title: Redefining Womens Work
description: Gloria Steinem is the star. She always was.

title: A Costume Too Far
description: As Prince Harry learned a few years ago when he wore a Nazi armband to a friends Colonial and Native themed event, a costume party is no excuse for ignoring good taste and generally acting idiotic. The prince eventually apologized, but the lessons of his faux pas apparently never reached New York State Assemblyman Dov Hikind in Brooklyn.

title: House-Made With Niceties
description: It was the blueberry jam that prompted the hesitation. The other ingredients in the drink called the Halleys Comet seemed fine  Makers Mark, lemon, a sage leaf, nothing that a person would consider startling.

title: For Encores, an Artist Invites Social Media Onstage
description: NEWARK  An encore, of course, originally meant just that: again. It was the repetition of a piece that had garnered enough applause to be performed once more.

title: With Its Eye on Infotainment, General Motors Is Upgrading OnStar
description: General Motors said on Monday that it would provide 4G LTE mobile broadband connectivity in certain 2015 Chevrolet, Buick, GMC and Cadillac models. The broadband connection will be delivered through the AT&T system and will replace the 2G connection used by the automakers OnStar connectivity system.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the West Bank, Mali, Thailand and Kuwait.

title: No Vitamin D and Calcium for Older Bones
description: A government task force formally recommended on Monday that healthy postmenopausal women avoid taking low daily doses of vitamin D and calcium to ward off bone fractures.

title: Questions About Robotic Hysterectomy
description: Ever since it was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 2005, robotic surgery for hysterectomy has been heavily advertised. Surgeons promise that using the da Vinci robotic device will bring better results and an easier recovery, and many hospitals claim that patients will experience less pain and fewer complications, getting back on their feet faster.

title: The Benefits of Olive Oil
description: The Timess Gina Kolata on a study looking at a Mediterranean diet.

title: Mapping Out the Path to Viral Fame
description: How has the Korean pop star Psys wacky horse-dance video, Gangnam Style, managed to rack up more than 1.3 billion views on YouTube? Why did a 30-minute video by a small nonprofit group calling for the capture of the Ugandan warlord Joseph Kony become a media sensation, racing across Twitter and Facebook eventually to snag the top spot on Unruly Medias list of the 20 most shared ads on social media in 2012?

title: Children Toil in Indias Mines, Despite Legal Ban
description: KHLIEHRIAT, India  After descending 70 feet on a wobbly bamboo staircase into a dank pit, the teenage miners ducked into a black hole about two feet high and crawled 100 yards through mud before starting their day digging coal.

title: Liquidation Authority and the Bankruptcy Clause
description: The litigation against the Dodd-Frank Acts orderly liquidation authority continues, with an amended complaint filed last week, adding a few more states to the mix, and the deadlines with regard to the governments motion to dismiss reset accordingly.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: San Quentin Entrepreneurs and Cyborg Roaches
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: An Addendum on National Park Cuts
description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar offered more details on Monday about how the automatic federal spending cuts set to take effect on Friday would hit national parks. With a budget cut of 5 percent, or $112 million, thousands of National Park Service employees would be furloughed and thousands more seasonal workers would not be hired, he said. That would mean sharply reducing visitor services and access to interpretive centers, campgrounds and hiking trails, he suggested.

title: Bloodshed Before the Battle
description: Theres a lot going on in Edward Einhorns ambitious new adaptation of Iphigenia in Aulis  Puppetlike masks! Comic-book drawings! A rock band!  Euripides tragedy about the sacrifice of a young virgin required before the Greeks can set sail to Troy.

title: In the Future, Everybody Will Be Commissioner for 15 Minutes
description: What is it with CBS and New York City police commissioners? It already has one, played by the 68-year-old Tom Selleck on Blue Bloods. On Tuesday night it adds a second, played by a British actor named Theo James (whos 28), in the new series Golden Boy. Its as if they were collecting a full set  next a middle-aged black man, then an Asian woman ...

title: Link Eyed Between 1908 Siberian Fireball and Record Heat in New York
description: Speaking of meteors and their local impact, as we were on Friday, the Siberian fireball brought the mind of Stephen Fybish, City Rooms Omniscient Weather Nudge, back to the Tunguska Event, a cosmic burp inflicted on Siberia in 1908 when the airburst of a still-unidentified object believed to be a meteor or a comet fragment flattened tens of millions of trees across 800 square miles.

title: Skepticism Abounds as Six World Powers Resume Nuclear Talks With Iran
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Talks between Iran and six world powers over its nuclear program resume here on Tuesday after a break of eight months, but there is a general atmosphere of gloom about their prospects for success, even if narrowly defined.

title: Street Style: Military Inspired
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Feb. 18.

title: Simple Only on the Surface
description: You never know what a little vanity will do for a persons health. Some people bloom in their quest for physical improvement, others wither, and a few are completely destroyed. Despite centuries worth of efforts to penetrate the complicated thickets where health and beauty intertwine, there is always more to explore, as two new books make clear.

title: Oscar Telecast Attracts 40.3 Million Viewers
description: ABCs telecast of the Oscars Sunday night didnt get great reviews, but the ratings partly made up for it: the show attracted 40.3 million viewers, the most for any entertainment show on television in three years. Even more importantly for ABC, the audience surged among the viewers the network most wants to reach, viewers between the ages of 18 and 49.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 25
description: A view of the day in sports, including hair-raising drills at the N.F.L. combine.

title: The Turn of the Screw at BAM
description: New York City Operas updated version of Benjamin Brittens 1954 chamber opera opened on Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Vamped-Up Vans
description: Designers have remade the slip-on in leather, suede and mock croc, turning a skate-park staple into a lazy-man luxury.

title: Accounting for 2/26 in a 9/11 Exhibition
description: Twenty years ago Tuesday, a deadly calling card was left at the World Trade Center.

title: Sneaky Dogs, a Cool Conference and More
description: By age 14, Emily Dickinson had assembled a prodigious herbarium, a well-labeled collection of pressed flowers and plants. At the time, this was a voguish hobby. Most all the girls are making one, she wrote in a letter to a friend in 1845.

title: Accusations of Anti-Semitism and Other Hosts Whove Crossed Lines
description: LOS ANGELES  As he predicted, Seth MacFarlane angered some people with his Oscar patter. Among the long list of isms that Mr. MacFarlane engaged in, perhaps the most expected was anti-Semitism. This is, after all, the guy who made a Hitler joke when he was announcing the nominees.

title: Memo to Europe: What About T-Bills?
description: In my column on Friday, I looked at the proposed European transaction tax from a stock market perspective, and found it to be reasonable.

title: Excerpt: Golden Boy
description: Theo James is an upstart detective in this new CBS series.

title: Poltergeists Stalk a Murky Playroom
description: At the start of Brittens chamber opera The Turn of the Screw, adapted from the Henry James novella, a character called the Prologue is supposed to stand before a lowered curtain and explain the back story. The opera, which had its premiere in 1954, tells of a Governess who comes to a country house in mid-19th-century England to care for two orphaned children.

title: Albums From Atoms for Peace, Ana Moura and Antonio Sanchez
description: ATOMS FOR PEACE

title: A Fresh Five Push Michigan Into the Title Picture
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  The fun started last summer at the same moment Michigan basketball became cool again. It was the players first week together. They were spread across the gym, lounging after a scrimmage.

title: Indias Child Labor Problem
description: Though a new law will mandate that children from the ages of 6 to 14 be in school, some 28 million are working instead, Unicef says.

title: Academy Award Show Raises Ratings and Hackles
description: LOS ANGELES  Jewish, womens and family organizations on Monday publicly flung knives at Seth MacFarlanes off-color Oscar show. Hollywood for the most part stayed true to form and aimed its cutlery at his back.

title: Even a Rock Star Has to Be Careful
description: I HAVE flown so much that most of my trips are routine. Im either off to a concert or coming back from one. Im actually very Zen-like when I fly. I just accept the delays since theres nothing I can do about it. But all the travel is great because I love seeing new places and meeting new people. Or, sometimes, seeing people Ive known for a long time.

title: Not the Same Old Cup of British Tea
description: Saying that a television series depicts the English aristocracy on the brink of World War I and beyond is almost a disservice  the description sounds like yet another big Masterpiece Theater bore, or worse, an amusing one like Downton Abbey. Parades End, a co-production of the BBC and HBO that begins on Tuesday on HBO, looks like a lush elegy to the Edwardian age, but its not nearly as swoony and nostalgic as most others of the genre. Tom Stoppard adapted Ford Madox Fords tetralogy into a five-part series, streamlining and speeding up the story without dumbing it down.

title: Parental Leave Policies at Some Big Technology Firms
description: Last week, Facebooks chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, made waves with an interview about her new book, Lean In, which encourages women to take more responsibility for their own career advancement.

title: A British Mainstay Current Beyond His Years
description: LONDON  In his prime, the choreographer Frederick Ashton (1904-88) seemed a pillar of the British establishment. The founding choreographer of the Royal Ballet, he was honored by, and was a friend of, the royal family. Although he was certainly a master, some of his ballets appeared dated in his lifetime, and few appeared radical.

title: Threat of Cuts Intensifies the Air Travel Headache
description: IM not foolhardy enough to venture guesses about what, if anything, may happen in Congress this week as the deadline for deep spending cuts looms on Friday. But there is the prospect of significant effects on air travel.

title: Treasury Pick Tries to Cast His History as Right for the Job
description: As the Senate gears up to vote on the next Treasury secretary, President Obamas choice for the job, Jacob J. Lew, has been forced to navigate through something of a political minefield.

title: Senate Judiciary Committee Set to Consider Gun Legislation
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee will begin to consider four separate gun safety measures on Thursday, although the process of narrowing actual legislative language will most likely dribble into next week.

title: Senate Committee Said to End Zero Dark Thirty Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES  Citing an unnamed Congressional aide, the Reuters news service on Monday reported that the Senate Intelligence Committee had ended its inquiry into Central Intelligence Agency cooperation with makers of the film Zero Dark Thirty. The investigation began after three SenatorsDianne Feinstein, Carl Levin and John McCainpublicly objected to what they saw as the films incorrect portrayal of torture as having helped in the hunt for Osama Bin Laden. Those objections came at the height of an Oscar campaign that closed on Sunday with no major awards for Zero Dark Thirty, which was nominated for best picture and had once been seen as a strong contender. According to Reuters, the investigation was closed on Monday after it had gathered material indicating that C.I.A. officials did not actually tell the filmmakers that torture helped to find Bin Laden, though they helped in the development of the films characters.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,159 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: 2 Palestinian Teenagers Hurt Amid Israeli Gunfire at Protest
description: JERUSALEM  Two Palestinian teenagers were seriously injured Monday when Israeli soldiers used live ammunition to disperse a demonstration at a holy site outside Bethlehem, as clashes in the West Bank continued for a fifth day and thousands attended the burial of a 30-year-old Palestinian who died in an Israeli jail over the weekend.

title: Video Shows Group Holds Family Seized in Cameroon
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  A French family kidnapped last week on the Cameroon-Nigeria border appeared on a video posted Monday on YouTube, with one of the hostages and a gunman saying that the family is being held by the Nigerian Islamist extremist group Boko Haram.

title: A Liqueur Breaks a Barrier as Hollywood Toasts Itself
description: FOR viewers driven to drink by the Academy Awards on Sunday, Oscar had something different for them to consider imbibing.

title: Gupta Ordered to Reimburse Goldman Sachs $6.2 Million
description: A federal judge on Monday ordered Rajat K. Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director, to pay the bank more than $6.2 million to reimburse it for legal expenses connected to his insider trading case.

title: St. Joe Co. Investors Lose Appeal of a Fraud Lawsuit
description: In October 2010, the hedge fund manager David Einhorn took the stage at an investor conference and announced a large bet against the St. Joe Company, a large owner of Florida real estate. He walked through a presentation titled Field of Schemes: If You Build It, They Wont Come, laying out his case that St. Joe vastly overvalued its property holdings. The companys stock promptly plummeted 20 percent.

title: $40 Million in Air Rights Will Let East Side Tower Soar
description: The price of air in Manhattan apparently knows no bounds.

title: Justices Hear Arguments on Missed Deadline in Murder Case
description: WASHINGTON  Floyd Perkins, a Michigan man serving a life sentence for murder, says he has evidence proving his innocence and should be allowed to present it long after a one-year filing deadline has passed.

title: In the Tracking Wars, Its Browser Makers vs. Advertisers
description: Last fall, Microsoft announced that its newest Web browser would allow users to signal whether or not they would like to see targeted advertisements. That was seen in some circles as a clash of corporate titans: a salvo from Microsoft against Google, which is its main rival in the browser market and which has a thriving targeted advertising business.

title: Confirmation Hearing for S.E.C. Nominee Said to Be Set for March
description: Mary Jo White appears poised to face a Senate confirmation hearing next month, a crucial step for the former federal prosecutor on her path to becoming the top Wall Street regulator.

title: Patrick Hitting Milestones but Managing Expectations
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Danica Patrick is more than a Nascar novelty. She can be a contender on the track and a game-changer for the sport.

title: China: 2 Tibetan Monks Carry Out Fatal Protests
description: Two Tibetan monks have died in separate self-immolation protests in Tibetan regions of western China since Sunday, according to reports on Monday by two Tibet advocacy groups. Phagmo Dundrup, in his early 20s, set himself on fire at the Chachung Monastery in Qinghai Province on Sunday, according to a report by International Campaign for Tibet, a group based in Washington. On Monday, Tsesung Kyab, in his late 20s, set himself on fire outside the main temple of Shitsang Gonsar Monastery in Gansu Province. He was a relative of Pema Dorjee, 23, who carried out a similar protest at the same monastery last year. Since 2009, at least 106 Tibetans have set themselves on fire to protest Chinese rule in Tibet. Most have died.

title: Russia: Putin Signs Law to Ban Most Public Smoking
description: President Vladimir V. Putin has signed a law to ban smoking in most public places, the Kremlin announced Monday. The ban will be phased in starting June 1. Nearly 40 percent of Russian adults smoke, the World Health Organization says, and related health care costs are estimated to run nearly $50 billion a year. Cigarettes generally cost $1 to $2 a pack, and, by volume, Russia is the second-largest cigarette market in the world after China. The law, signed on Saturday, will ban smoking near the entrances of subway and railroad stations, and ultimately in restaurants, cafes, hotels, government buildings, universities and stadiums. It will also raise taxes on cigarettes and other forms of tobacco, restrict tobacco advertising and prohibit cigarette sales by street-side kiosks. Many kiosk owners say the law, coupled with a new ban on beer sales at kiosks, could put them out of business.

title: Italy: Prosecutors Request Indictments for Cruise Ship Captain
description: Italian prosecutors on Monday asked a judge to issue an indictment on manslaughter charges for the captain of the luxury liner Costa Concordia that ran aground in January 2012 off the Tuscan coast, an accident that claimed the lives of 32 people. The prosecutors also want to try the captain, Francesco Schettino, on charges of causing a shipwreck and abandoning the vessel before its 4,229 passengers and crew members were safe. In addition, the prosecutors requested that five crew members be tried on manslaughter charges. The judge will rule in the coming months on whether to accept the indictment requests. Costa Cruises, accused of administrative offenses related to the charges against its employees, is trying to reach a plea-bargain agreement with prosecutors. A settlement could cost the company more than $1 million.

title: U.S. Exposure to Horse Meat: Answers to Common Questions
description: The alarm in Europe over the discovery of horse meat in beef products escalated again Monday, when the Swedish furniture giant Ikea withdrew an estimated 1,670 pounds of meatballs from sale in 14 European countries.

title: Some Play to the Crowd and Some Are for Real
description: MILAN

title: Extension for Brady, With Cap a Factor
description: Tom Brady, the most successful quarterback of his generation, reached a three-year contract extension Monday that will probably keep him a New England Patriot for the rest of his career, a person familiar with the contract said on the condition of anonymity because the team had not announced it.

title: Talk of Inquiry, but Not Much Is Sure After Afghan Ban on U.S. Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A day after President Hamid Karzai ordered elite American forces out of a strategic province near the capital, very little was clear other than his increasing assertiveness in dictating the Western military role in Afghanistan.

title: Strong Storm in Plains Brings Added Hazards
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A treacherous winter storm stretching from Texas through a large part of the Great Plains brought blustery, blinding snow on Monday to many areas still shoveling out from a storm that dumped more than a foot of snow on them last week.

title: Low Pay at Weight Watchers Stirs Protest as Stars Rake It In
description: Tammy Williams became a Weight Watchers leader in Texas five years ago after losing 97 pounds in the program. The supplies that she handles fill a bedroom in her home, and she holds four meetings a week advising more than a hundred customers about the diet regimen.

title: Yankees Suddenly Seem Short of the Long Ball
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Symbols can be powerful in spring training. The games are exhibitions, the lineups filled with strange names. On Monday the Yankees faced a playoff opponent from last fall, the Baltimore Orioles, and brought just two players from the postseason roster: Brett Gardner and Jayson Nix. The starting first baseman wore No. 98.

title: Academic Freedom in Brooklyn: Part Two
description: The comments responding to my account of what happened when two supporters of an academic boycott against Israeli universities spoke at Brooklyn College on Feb. 7 displayed a set of related misunderstandings.

title: Weapons From the Former Yugoslavia Spread Through Syrias War
description: The use of social media by opposition groups and activists in Syria has allowed those of us who follow these sources carefully to pursue a different form of insight into conflict reporting than had been possible before the time when opposition fighters reflexively videotaped their operations and posted them online. With hundreds of videos showing the activities of fighting groups now posted on YouTube each day, external analysts have been allowed to build a picture of events in Syria that in past wars have gone unrecorded. These videos, often shared via Twitter and Facebook, allowed analysts and arms spotters in 2012 to track almost in real time the escalation in the conflict on both sides, including the use of cluster bombs and incendiary bombs, as well as potential war crimes committed by the government and the opposition alike.

title: Now the Desert Is Just a Desert
description: LOS ANGELES

title: In Putins Russia, Shooting the Messenger
description: DALLAS

title: Comedians Blog Morphs Into Major Political Force in Italy
description: Last Updated, Tuesday, 6:40 p.m. Although an aide to the former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi demanded a recount late Monday, after his center-right coalition appeared to lose the battle for the Italian Parliaments lower house to the main center-left coalition by less than 0.4 percent, a look at the raw vote totals reveals a sharp decline in support for him. According to the provisional count, Mr. Berlusconis party got about six million fewer votes than in 2008, slipping from first place all the way to third.

title: Citing Urgency, Georgia Governor Ousts 6 Members of DeKalb County School Board
description: ATLANTA  Gov. Nathan Deal removed six members of the DeKalb County School Board on Monday, trying to save the states third-largest school system by exercising a relatively new power in Georgia that allows him to supersede the choice of voters.

title: Banks Fear Court Ruling in Argentina Bond Debt
description: A fierce battle between the government of Argentina and investors led by a group of hedge funds has already led to the seizure of a naval ship and dragged in the United States Treasury. Now a federal appeals court is hearing the dispute, and how it rules could have a major impact on world debt markets.

title: We Paid for the Research, So Lets See It
description: The Obama administration is right to direct federal agencies to make public, without charge, all scientific papers reporting on research financed by the government. In a memorandum issued on Friday, John Holdren, the presidents science adviser, directed federal agencies with more than $100 million in annual research and development expenditures to develop plans for making the published results of almost all the research freely available to everyone within one year of publication.

title: A Vote on Sick Leave
description: For many months now, advocates of paid sick leave on the New York City Council have seen their efforts put on hold by Speaker Christine Quinn. Now, one of Ms. Quinns prominent supporters in the upcoming mayors race, Gloria Steinem, has said she would withdraw her backing if the speaker continues to block a vote on sick leave. Making life fairer for all women seems more important than breaking a barrier for one woman, Ms. Steinem said.

title: Recipe for a Perfect Photo: Clear Sky, Sunset and Water
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  The photographers were packed so tightly along the riverbank that they looked like paparazzi stalking a starlet. In this case the Lindsay Lohan in question was a wispy little ribbon of water falling thousands of feet down the face of El Capitan, the worlds largest single chunk of granite.

title: The States Get the Bad News
description: In Kentucky, home of the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell, residents woke up on Monday to news articles like these: Widespread government spending cuts that begin on Friday will cost 21,484 jobs in the state. A construction project at Fort Knox will come to a halt. Three airports may endure partial shutdowns. Nearly $12 million in grants to public schools would be cut, putting at risk the jobs of 160 teachers and aides. More than 1,000 children would lose access to Head Start.

title: The Wages of Celibacy
description: The resignation of Britains most senior Roman Catholic clergyman, accused of unwanted advances toward younger priests, will ratchet up the usual talk about lies, double lives and hypocrisy in the church, and rightly so. The churchs leaders preach a purity that its own clerics cant maintain. They cast stones, and are so very far from blameless.

title: Saudis Step Up Help for Rebels in Syria With Croatian Arms
description: Saudi Arabia has financed a large purchase of infantry weapons from Croatia and quietly funneled them to antigovernment fighters in Syria in a drive to break the bloody stalemate that has allowed President Bashar al-Assad to cling to power, according to American and Western officials familiar with the purchases.

title: After Bales Latest Strike, Only Praise Fills the Air
description: LONDON  This was not just another edgy contest between two long-established London rivals, Tottenham and West Ham. Instead, Monday nights encounter was preceded by a stern warning from West Hams owners that harsh sanctions would be imposed on any of the clubs supporters who resorted to the anti-Semitic behavior that a group of West Ham fans had apparently engaged in the last time the teams met, in November.

title: Shareholder Democracy Can Mask Abuses
description: Martin Lipton, one of the nations top corporate lawyers, was dismayed.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Feb. 26, 2013
description: How can we not work? We have to eat.

title: Secrets to Success in Online College Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vote for Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Public Preschool a Smart Investment?
A Proposal for New York: Instant Runoff Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Second Adolescence
description: In Fridays column, I wrote that the Obama administration has no plan to avoid the sequester save raising taxes on the rich. That was unfair. The White House approach is not what I would like, but it is more balanced than I described.

title: As Budget Cuts Loom on the Horizon
Sheryl Sandbergs Lead
description: To the Editor:

title: Confirm Chuck Hagel
description: Barring some last-minute snag, the Senate is expected to vote to end a Republican filibuster on Tuesday and then move on to confirm Chuck Hagel as defense secretary. The filibuster was pernicious from the start, and Mr. Hagel should be approved without further delay.

title: C. Everett Koop, Forceful U.S. Surgeon General, Dies at 96
description: Dr. C. Everett Koop, who was widely regarded as the most influential surgeon general in American history and played a crucial role in changing public attitudes about smoking, died on Monday at his home in Hanover, N.H. He was 96.

title: Rebuilding on Their Own
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Shipping U.S. Horses for Slaughter
description: Horses have not been slaughtered for human consumption in the United States since 2007.

title: Yahoo Orders Home Workers Back to the Office
description: Since Marissa Mayer became chief executive of Yahoo, she has been working hard to get the Internet pioneer off its deathbed and make it an innovator once again.

title: States Can Cut Back on Medicaid Payments, Administration Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Monday that states could cut Medicaid payments to many doctors and other health care providers to hold down costs in the program, which insures 60 million low-income people and will soon cover many more under the new health care law.

title: Ikea Recalls Meatballs After Detection of Horse Meat
description: LONDON  The furniture giant Ikea joined a growing list of brands that have been touched by Europes food scandal on Monday and withdrew its signature Swedish meatballs from its markets and cafeterias across most of Europe after one batch was found to contain traces of horse meat.

title: Duda Reports No Pain, but Will Sit Out Anyway
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The familiar spring training ritual of bumps and bruises, stops and starts, continued for the Mets on Monday.

title: Where Youll Drink the Night Away
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I had a strange feeling of deja vu doing this puzzle. It wouldnt surprise me to see that this theme had been done before and, in fact, it is similar to a puzzle constructed by Holden Baker back in 2002 (Across Lite, Solution.)

title: Corrections: February 26, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Striking a Pose on the Tracks
description: The jutting copper-colored platforms that form Mimi Liens set for the Signature Theater Company revival of David Henry Hwangs Dance and the Railroad provide a pleasingly serene vista for the eye. Cleverly echoing the Frank Gehry architecture of the Alice Griffin Theater, where the production opened on Monday night, the sets soothing beauty is further enhanced by the shifting, multicolored lighting of Jiyoun Chang.

title: Amway Moves In at Citi Field
description: The Mets have not acquired any high-priced free agents in the off-season, but they have a new tenant at Citi Field: Amway.

title: To Curb Suits, City Now Opts to Fight Them
description: The Bloomberg administration has embarked on an aggressive legal strategy intended to curtail the rising number of federal civil-rights lawsuits filed against New York. Instead of offering small settlements to avoid trial, the city started to identify weaker cases and has been contesting them in court, pushing many to trial.

title: Rangers Mum on Status of Nash and McDonagh
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers are riddled with injuries and are being extremely coy about them as they begin a four-game homestand Tuesday night against the Winnipeg Jets.

title: From the Schoolhouse to the Factory Floor, Girding for Cuts
description: As $85 billion in spending cuts loom, people across the country who rely on government services have been trying to fathom what it would mean for them.

title: Reduced Spending Would Limit Park Services and Revenue, Interior Secretary Says
description: WASHINGTON  Mandatory federal spending cuts scheduled to begin Friday are already affecting operations at many of the nations national parks and wildlife refuges, officials said Monday.

title: Obamas Treasury Nominee Got Unusual Exit Bonus on Leaving N.Y.U.
description: President Obamas nominee to lead the Treasury Department, Jacob J. Lew, got a $685,000 severance payment when he left a top post at New York University in 2006 to take a job at Citigroup.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Baffling Benching of Lopez
description: When the final minutes arrived Sunday night and the Nets offense went to pieces, it was easy to point to the absence of Joe Johnson, their dynamic, do-everything shooting guard. Johnson was resting a sore heel, robbing the Nets of their No. 2 scorer.

title: In Cannibal Case, Officers Wife Testifies About a Chilling Discovery
description: One day last September, the wife of a New York City police officer opened her laptop computer and discovered that her husband had used it to visit a fetish Web site on the Internet. She said she went to the site and saw a photograph of a dead girl.

title: Senate Set to Test Support for Vote on Defense Pick
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate was scheduled to vote Tuesday on whether to consider the embattled nomination of Chuck Hagel as defense secretary, in a move that seems likely to ensure his confirmation this week.

title: Reclaiming Storm-Torn Homes, Step by Uncertain Step
description: Stroll down Seabreeze Walk in Roxbury, Queens, and take a footpath down to the gray blue of Jamaica Bay. There you find a Caterpillar backhoe smashing at, gnawing at and pulling apart a string of once picturesque bungalows.

title: Knicks Collect Free Throws With Anthony Leading the Way
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Sometimes, Carmelo Anthony is so productive, it takes Coach Mike Woodson until the next day to figure out what was the best part of Anthonys performance.

title: Miami-Dade Sees Failure in Company It Favored
description: MIAMI  When Banah International Group, a sugar company, agreed to establish its headquarters in Miami-Dade County  lured by $430,000 in state and county tax breaks  the announcement was trumpeted from County Hall to Capitol Hill.

title: For Yankees, Power Doesnt Always Have to Be On
description: The Yankees have long been synonymous with home runs; in many of their 27 championship seasons, they finished at or near the top of the American League in that category.

title: Republicans Sign Brief in Support of Gay Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  Dozens of prominent Republicans  including top advisers to former President George W. Bush, four former governors and two members of Congress  have signed a legal brief arguing that gay people have a constitutional right to marry, a position that amounts to a direct challenge to Speaker John A. Boehner and reflects the civil war in the party since the November election.

title: Thank You, Xie Xie, Namaste: A Movie Undercuts Old Rivalries
description: BEIJING  After the Taiwan-born film director Ang Lee won big at the Oscars on Sunday evening in Los Angeles, including scooping Best Director for Life of Pi, he effusively thanked his place of birth. But his thanks didnt make it into China, at least not via the official media.

description: dynamic \di-na-mik\ adjective and noun

title: From Hyderabad, a Tale of Two Snack Bars
description: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh On Thursday, when Bakka Reddy, 23, was busy at work at Mirchi Point, a snack bar near Venkatadri Theater in Dilsukh Nagar, he heard an explosion.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) CELEBRITY WIFE SWAP Kate Gosselin (above, with suitcase), the mother of 8-year-old sextuplets and 12-year-old twins, formerly featured in Jon & Kate Plus 8, and Kendra Wilkinson, an ex-girlfriend of Hugh Hefners from The Girls Next Door, now the mother of a 3-year-old son, trade lives for a week  and introduce their own rules into each others households  in this Season 8 premiere.

title: News Quiz | February 26, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 26
description: NEWS Italian voters delivered a rousing anti-austerity message and a strong rebuke to the existing political order in national elections on Monday, plunging the country into political paralysis after results failed to produce a clear winner. Rachel Donadio reports from Rome.

title: U.S. Officials Propose Sharing Drone Surveillance Data With Algerians
description: WASHINGTON  The American ambassador to Algeria and senior counterterrorism officials have proposed sharing more information with Algerian security forces to help them kill or capture militants in their own country and in areas just across their borders.

title: Six Nations Await Irans Response to Overture in Nuclear Talks
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Talks between Iran and six world powers over its nuclear program will go into a second day here, with Western diplomats waiting to get a clear response from Tehran to an offer of step-by-step sanctions relief in return for confidence-building measures from Iran, Western diplomats said on Tuesday.

title: Britain Seeks to Restrict K.G.B. Inquest Disclosures
description: The British government sought on Tuesday to limit the information it would disclose at a planned inquest into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former officer in the K.G.B. who succumbed to radiation poisoning in London more than six years ago. The coroner hearing the case said that it may now be postponed.

description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Paintings by Masters Go Unloved Without a Good Name.

title: Automatic Budget Cuts Loom as President and Congress Dont Compromise

description: Indian Railways Minister Pawan Kumar Bansal presented the railways budget for the financial year 2013-14 in Parliament in New Delhi on Tuesday.

title: Narmada Devi, the Housewife from Uttar Pradesh
description: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this years 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.

title: Are We in Danger of a Beer Monopoly?
description: Every day, the Web site BeerPulse tries to list every single new beer available in the United States. And thats harder than you might imagine. Recently, the site posted Cigar Citys Jamonera Belgian-style Porter, Odell Tree Shaker Imperial Peach IPA, as well as a rye lager, a cherry blossom lager and a barley wine. And the list goes on, and on. In 1978, there were 89 breweries in the United States; at the beginning of this year, there were 2,336, with an average of one new brewery per day. Most of them are tiny, but a handful, like Sam Adams and Sierra Nevada, have become large national brands. At the same time, sales of Budweiser in the United States have dropped for 25 consecutive years.

title: When Violence Is Against Domestics
description: Photographing young Englishwomen training to be nannies, Gratiane de Moustier couldnt help laughing as she watched the students cradling and feeding dolls as if they were children with toys.

title: What Would You Wait in Line For?
description: Lines are an unavoidable part of life. We wait in lunch lines, lift lines, gas lines, bathroom lines and fan lines.

title: Israel Struck by Rocket From Gaza After a Death
description: JERUSALEM  A Grad rocket fired from the Gaza Strip struck in southern Israel early Tuesday, threatening to further escalate tensions that have been mounting since Saturday, when a 30-year-old Palestinian prisoner died in an Israeli jail.

title: Egyptian Balloon Explosion Kills at Least 19 Tourists at Luxor
description: CAIRO  The explosion of a hot-air balloon over the ancient temples at Luxor killed at least 19 sightseers Tuesday, delivering a grim blow to Egypts critical tourism business just as it had begun to show signs of recovery from the shock of the revolution two years ago.

title: Philippine Leader Urges Rebellious Group to Leave Borneo
description: MANILA  President Benigno S. Aquino III on Tuesday ordered a group of armed Filipinos holed up in Malaysian Borneo to return home and said their leader could be criminally charged for inciting war.

title: Critiquing a Web Site That Tries to Keep It Simple
description: It sounds easy. Sell your product online. Design it to tempt every visitor into becoming a buyer. Add an easy-to-use self-service interface that lets customers get answers without interacting with a salesclerk. Everything seems to happen magically, and everything goes smoothly, without any issues. There may be businesses that manage to accomplish this, but rarely without a few struggles. In this post, we look at one company, Recruiterbox, and its attempt to attract customers and interact with them seemlessly.

description: NAKURU, Kenya  If youre an outsider writing about Africa, the T-word  tribe  can get you into trouble. Ive received poison-pen letters from readers and been upbraided by academics for using it.

title: In Pursuit, on Wheels and on Foot
description: Most of us have no way of judging how realistically television shows portray the lives of police officers. If you scan Web sites where law enforcement professionals gather to chat, however, you can assemble a list of series that get some grudging praise for being slightly more authentic than the norm: Adam-12, High Incident, Hill Street Blues, Homicide, The Wire and  many a deskbound cops favorite  Barney Miller.

title: With Virginia Shipyard as Backdrop, Obama Warns Again on Cuts
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va.  President Obama flew on Tuesday to the vast shipyard where the nations nuclear-powered aircraft carriers are built to send a warning that automatic cuts in the Pentagon budget, only three days away, threatened the jobs of tens of thousands of workers and Americas fragile economic recovery.

title: Opinion Report: Paid Sick Leave
description: From the editorial page

title: Music Industry Sales Rise, and Digital Revenue Gets the Credit
description: The music industry, the first media business to be consumed by the digital revolution, said on Tuesday that its global sales rose last year for the first time since 1999, raising hopes that a long-sought recovery might have begun.

title: Inconclusive Vote in Italy Points to Fragmenting of Political System
description: ROME  In recent years, recession and financial turmoil have felled governments throughout Europe as voters looked for change in an era of economic distress. Now, experts are asking whether politicians are capable of promoting plans that offer a way out of the malaise  or whether they could be elected if they did.
