title: Gates, Zuckerberg, Other Tech Icons Promote Youth Coding in New Film
description: A new nonprofit seeking to rally interest among children, parents and schools in computer programming is getting help from some big guns in the tech industry, including the founders of Microsoft, Facebook and Twitter.

title: Table Talk | Le 6 Paul Bert
description: If you think French food has lost its laurels, next trip to Paris, head for the rue Paul Bert. Thanks to the shrewd and very amiable restaurateur Bertrand Auboyneau, this short, quiet street in the 11th Arrondissement offers a full house of addresses that will prove you wrong. The mother ship is Le Bistrot Paul Bert (No. 18), which has become an internationally renowned cult favorite for being the bistro thats been ticking all the boxes on what the whole world thinks a Paris bistro should be ever since it opened some 10 years ago  were talking a gorgeous flea-market interior, great traditional French grub, a terrific wine list and service with just enough pouty posing attitude to let you know youre in Paris. Then theres the superb Ecailler du Bistrot (No. 22), which tips its hand to show why Paris is the best city in Europe for seafood lovers  it pulls in the best of Frances small boat catch daily, and the oysters come directly from the bivalve park of Auboyneaus wifes family in Brittany.

title: The Gun Report: February 26, 2013
description: We continue to get complaints that our anecdotal approach overstates gun violence in comparison to other forms of death and injury, such as, you know, slipping in the bathtub. But yesterday, ProPublica published an interview with Dr. Mark Rosenberg, who led the Centers for Disease Controls gun violence research until 1996, when Congress cut its funding after intense NRA lobbying. Before the funding was cut, Dr. Rosenberg said, the CDCs research showed that not only did having a firearm in your home not protect you, but it hugely increased the risk that someone in your family would die from a firearm homicide by almost 300 percent. Having a gun in the home also raised the risk five-fold that someone in your household would commit suicide.

title: A Musical Pitch to Albany to Raise Minimum Wage
description: As the battle over whether to raise the minimum wage heats up in Albany, some laborers are pressing their case in a musical fashion.

title: Did Democrats Get Lucky in the Electoral College?
description: President Obama won the Electoral College fairly decisively last year despite a margin of just 3.8 percentage points in the national popular vote. In fact, Mr. Obama would probably have won the Electoral College even if the popular vote had slightly favored Mitt Romney. The tipping-point state in the election  the one that provided Mr. Obama with his decisive 270th electoral vote  was Colorado, which Mr. Obama won by 5.4 percentage points. If all states had shifted toward Mr. Romney by 5.3 percentage points, Mr. Obama would still have won Colorado and therefore the Electoral College  despite losing the national popular vote by 1.5 points.

title: Comparing Asias Giants, China and India, on Rape
description: BEIJING  Women in China experience less sexual harassment in public places than women in India, two Asian nations with similar sized populations and fast economic growth which I compare, in terms of rape, in todays Female Factor Letter.

title: A Warning on Abuses of Shareholder Power
description: The effort by the hedge fund manager David Einhorn to press Apple to return some of its huge cash hoard to shareholders did not sit well with Martin Lipton, one of the nations top corporate lawyers. In a scathing memorandum to clients, Mr. Lipton wrote: The activist-hedge-fund attack on Apple  in which one of the most successful, long-term-visionary companies of all time is being told by a money manager that Apple is doing things all wrong and should focus on short-term return of cash  is a clarion call for effective action to deal with the misuse of shareholder power.

title: Tuesday Reading: Mediterranean Diet Lowers Health Risks
Nature, Re-engineered to Meet Energy Needs
description: Thousands of inventors, engineers and entrepreneurs gathered in a suburban Washington convention center on Monday for the annual three-day meeting of Arpa-E, the Advanced Research Projects Agency  Energy. It wasnt quite the Oscars. At the registration desk, attendees received a goody bag that included a report on clean energy from the Pew Charitable Trusts and a refrigerator magnet that showed the periodic table of the elements.

title: Slow Time Could Be a Real Problem
description: Every year, the N.F.L. scouting combine is filled with coaches and personnel gurus who gather with their stopwatches and amateur psychology degrees and nod while the medical folks send every suspicious pinkie toe to the magnetic resonance imaging test machine for a look-see. Normally, this all only borders on the absurd. This year, thanks to Manti Teo and his iffy grasp on reality, it took the express train to the heart of Absurdistan.

title: What Were Reading
description: Cocktail Buzz: With spring just weeks away, is it time to start sipping lavender?  Jeff Gordinier

title: The Breakfast Meeting: A Bid to Privatize Barnes & Noble Stores, and a Magazine Mergers Culture Clash
description: Leonard S. Riggio, Barnes & Nobles 71-year-old chairman, is preparing a bid to buy the companys 689 stores that would save them from a risky future in public markets, Michael J. de la Merced writes. The move would effectively separate the retail arm from Nook Media, the companys struggling e-book division, although it seems probable that Nook devices would still be featured in the stores. Analysts thought the deal made sense only if Mr. Riggio paid a low price for the legacy stores, which analysts valued between $484.5 million to more than $1 billion. Investors appeared sanguine Monday, as Barnes & Noble shares jumped 11.5 percent, to $15.06.

title: How the Baggers Predictions Worked Out
description: The Bagger has trouble with self-promotion (and also with referring to herself in the third person). So we will leave it to the blog Pundittracker.com to note that of 22 prognosticators who made predictions in all 24 Oscar categories, we came in tied for second this year, along with our pal Anne Thompson of Indiewire, with 20 correct picks. Entertainment Weekly and The Hollywood Reporter tied for first. (See our ballot here. If only wed gone with our gut on the short documentary category, wed be No. 1!)

title: Fed Defends Stimulus in Testimony to Senate
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, played down concerns about the Feds economic stimulus campaign on Tuesday, describing it as necessary and effective and making clear it was likely to continue for some time.

title: Why Einhorns Win May Be Apples Gain
description: Greenlight Capital and David Einhorns victory against Apple in Federal District Court in Manhattan is a small one, serving only to highlight the bizarreness of the entire fight. The odd thing is that the result is actually more of a win for Apple than Mr. Einhorn, and the outcome will probably have a bigger effect on other companies.

title: Parking Spot Causes Fight (No Drivers Are Involved)
description: Kate Blumm moved to Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in June 2011, seven weeks before her daughter, Zelda, was born. After falling in love with the merchant community, Ms. Blumm, and her husband, Michael De Zayas, opened a cafe last March on Franklin Avenue called Little Zelda.

description: Fatalities among teenage drivers rose sharply for the first six months of 2012, according to a new report.

title: Beware of Investments Promoted as Just Like a C.D.
description: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: A Trimmer Trunk
description: Between loud surf Jams and ill-fitting board shorts, American guys too often err when it comes to beachside style. Adam Brown, the British designer behind the culty swimwear brand Orlebar Brown, offers a corrective. His classic trunks  trimly tailored with a fixed waist and adjustable side tabs  come in three decreasingly daring lengths: the thigh-exposing Setter, as modeled by Daniel Craig in the most recent Bond flick (here in the new-for-spring Fiorentina print by the late designer David Hicks); the midlength Bulldog, for shyer sorts; and the Dane, a slimmed-down board short that marries Old World prudery with a New World fit.

title: Benedict XVI to Be Known as Emeritus in Retirement
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Benedict XVI will keep the name Benedict XVI and become the Roman pontiff emeritus or pope emeritus, the Vatican announced on Tuesday, putting an end to days of speculation on how the pope will be addressed once he ceases to be the leader of the worlds 1.1 billion Roman Catholics on Thursday.

title: Fantasies of Presidential Will
description: Greg Sargent is rightly disturbed by the latest meme in the effort to make the sequester a bipartisan failure. Pundits acknowledge that Republicans are being intransigent, while Obama has been willing to make concessions  but its nonetheless Obamas fault, because he should be exercising leadership, whatever that means.

title: Right to Marry
description: Margaret Hoover, a Republican strategist, speaks about why she wants her party to support gay marriage.

title: Morrissey Cancels TV Performance, Citing Animal Serial Killers
description: Morrissey has canceled an appearance on Jimmy Kimmel Live on Tuesday because he considers the other guests, stars of the reality series Duck Dynasty, to be animal serial killers. Morrissey, the singer and former leader of the Smiths, is a well-known animal-rights activist and vegetarian. His views on killing ducks for sport are pretty far from the bushy-bearded duck-hunting gang on Duck Dynasty, who manufacture calls and other gear for hunters.

title: Roasted Carrots and Scallions With Thyme and Hazelnuts
description: I bought incredibly sweet, thick red scallions and multicolored bunches of carrots from a farmer at my market and roasted them with fresh thyme. Then I sprinkled on some crushed toasted hazelnuts, which contributed a nice crunchy texture and nutty finish to the dish. If you have a bottle of hazelnut oil or walnut oil on hand, a small drizzle just before serving is a welcome touch.

And once on their iPads, people buy items at rates higher than they do on smartphones.

title: Guest Post | Five Key Elements for a New Model of Apprenticeship
description: We invited Robert Greene, author of Mastery, to be a guest writer on the blog for us. His specialty, in this book and in previous ones like The 48 Laws of Power and The 33 Strategies of War, is to analyze the lives and philosophies of historical figures from Darwin to Michelangelo to Henry Ford to determine what causes certain people to excel, or become masters in their chosen field.

title: At Trial, Officers Friend Recalls Abduction Threat
description: She had been friends with the New York police officer since their college days in Maryland, and they kept in touch mostly through text messages over the years. So when she was warned of his bizarre threat against her, she said, she immediately dismissed it.

title: Candidate Who Backs Gun Control Wins Race

Jackson Jr.

title: Are Body and Sex Education Books for Parents, or Kids?
description: The Care and Keeping of You: The Body Book for Girls has just been updated and reissued, along with a companion book, The Care and Keeping of You 2: The Body Book for Older Girls.

title: Memories of Floating Over Luxor, Now Tinged With the Macabre
description: My 5-year-old son spent the entire hot-air balloon ride over Luxor, Egypt, crouched in the bottom of the basket, terrified of the flames that kept shooting into the balloon  the flames that produced the hot air that kept us afloat. He missed the glorious views: of the ancient ruins and the quilts of green grass, of the magnificent sunrise and the dancing shadows it created out of the dozens of other hot-air balloons with which we shared the early-morning sky.

title: Schwab Promotes Lower Cost of Its Index-Only 401(k)
description: Last year, Charles Schwab began offering an index-fund-only 401(k) option for companies seeking a lower-cost retirement savings option for employees. Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, has written about the benefits of retirement plans that offer more index fund choices because the funds have lower investment management costs than actively managed funds. That generally means the employee keeps more retirement savings.

title: Youve Got African-Americans, Youve Got Hispanics
description: The Supreme Court almost never says why it refuses to take a case. On Monday, however, when the court denied a petition from the man convicted in Calhoun v. United States, Justice Sonia Sotomayor, joined by Justice Stephen Breyer, issued a rare explanatory statement.

title: Apple Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Over App Purchases by Children
description: Apple has agreed to reimburse parents whose children purchased virtual goods in mobile apps without the parents knowledge.

title: Excerpt: 'The Madrid'
description: Edie Falco, left, and Phoebe Strole in a scene from the Manhattan Theater Clubs production of Liz Flahives new play at City Center.

title: Tribune Hires Investment Banks to Weigh a Sale of Its Top Newspapers
description: 8:18 p.m. | Updated

title: Business Owners Confront the Budget Impasse
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the conversation focused on the end of the payroll tax holiday, the impact of the federal budget impasse, and the challenges of implementing new technology.

title: Prince of Perfume
description: How a former professional basketball player from Stockholm has turned an amateur interest in fragrance into the cult brand of the fashion world. Go to interactive slide show ->

title: Intels Big Data Push
description: As its mainstay business of equipping personal computers slows down, the Intel Corporation is scrambling for new ways to kick-start semiconductor sales. The company has financed development of new kinds of laptops, an effort that has been unsuccessful so far, and invested in Internet-based television. Now the chip maker is eyeing the boom in Big Data.

title: M.L.S. Commissioner: The Digital Don
description: Don Garber, the commissioner of Major League Soccer who stalks Twitter as thesoccerdon, will make his preseason address Wednesday in electronic form in an online forum.

title: Video of Fatal Balloon Crash in Egypt Captured by Witness
description: Last Updated, 6:26 p.m. As our colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, at least 18 people were killed and three were injured when a high-altitude balloon carrying tourists burst into flames near the Egyptian monuments at Luxor on Tuesday.

title: Cdric Charlier: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: Foils for the Heat
description: I love the vibrant freshness and balance of Vietnamese food. The characteristic herbal flavors and mild chile heat place it among the easier Asian cuisines to enjoy with wine.

title: Cheap Bus Fare Lures Riders Despite Companys Troubles
description: For the dozens of people milling about on a sidewalk of Canal Street in Manhattan on Tuesday afternoon, reports that a popular Chinatown bus line was being shut down were drowned out by the siren song of a $15 fare to Boston.

title: Macys Dresses Up Herald Square Dining
description: Second floor: womens shoes. Third floor: mens suits. Sixth floor: prosecco, wood-oven pizzas, beef short ribs with polenta and Florentine gelato.

title: In America, You Have a Right to Be Stupid, Kerry Says in Defense of Free Speech
description: In a robust defense of free speech during a meeting with young Germans in Berlin on Tuesday, Secretary of State John Kerry explained just how far the limits of tolerance extend in blunt terms. In America, the countrys top diplomat explained, you have a right to be stupid.

title: Hat Tricks
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Family Meal, With Your Peers
description: Saying a little prayer to the gods of thermodynamics, I peered over my enormous vat of water, potatoes floating inside, and willed it to boil. Calm as a frozen lake.

title: From Boehner, a Salty Demand That the Senate Act on Spending Cuts
description: Speaker John A. Boehner said in no uncertain terms Tuesday morning that he expected the Senate to pass some sort of alternative to the $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts set to go into effect on Friday before the House would take any more action.

title: Chinese Intellectuals Urge Ratifying Rights Treaty
description: HONG KONG  More than 100 Chinese scholars, journalists, lawyers and writers urged their national legislature on Tuesday to ratify a major human rights treaty, in the latest challenge from intellectuals seeking to curtail arbitrary Communist Party power.

title: Measuring Your Health With Jawbones Up
description: The Up band, made by Jawbone, is an electronic bracelet that helps you log your activities, eating and rest, and it can record an awful lot of data. But the more detailed the data you want, the more work youll have to do to get it.

title: Hidden After Offending, Mural at a State Office Is Back, for Peeks Only
description: ALBANY  For the last decade or so, one of New Yorks most curious and controversial pieces of public art has been hiding, Oz-like, behind a big green curtain.

title: Next, 4-D Printers?
description: Now that the promise of 3-D printing has landed on the national agenda, researchers want to increase the stakes  with so-called 4-D printing.

title: Can You Say Hamantaschen?
description: Purim may be over, but its never a bad time to make hamantaschen, the triangular pastries that are traditionally eaten during the Jewish holiday. The Jewish cooking expert Joan Nathan demonstrates how to make them from scratch, filling and all, for Tablet Magazine. As she bakes, she dispenses her wry cooking commentary: Its mostly butter. How can that be bad? says Ms. Nathan, who has also written about her cooking for The New York Times, as you can see here and here.

title: Back to the Office for Yahoo Workers
description: As Marissa Mayer ends a work-at-home policy at Yahoo, what the data show about working from home.

title: The Velocity of Autumn Set for Arena Stage
description: Eric Cobles play The Velocity of Autumn, which had been announced for a spring opening on Broadway only to be postponed last week, will be part of the 2013-14 season at Arena Stage in Washington, the theater announced on Tuesday. Set to run Sept. 6 to Oct. 20, the production will star the Oscar winner Estelle Parsons and the Tony winner Stephen Spinella, and will be directed by Molly Smith, the Arenas artistic director. All three had been announced for the shows Broadway production.

title: Off the Menu
description: Headliner

title: Post-Fukushima, Arguments for Nuclear Safety Bog Down
description: Alarms sounded and lights flashed as control panel dials at a nuclear power plant in upstate New York warned that the power for safety equipment was failing. The room went dark until the emergency lights kicked in. But there was no reason to worry on this frozen winter morning.

title: Italian Deadlock Rekindles Anxiety About Euro Zone
description: ROME  The political gridlock in Italy revives a question that hasnt been heard lately: Is the euro zone crisis really over?

title: App Smart Extra: More Slide Show Apps
description: Last week in App Smart I talked about the many apps that promise to turn photos from your smartphone or tablets digital photo album into an attractive photo slide show. These apps make looking at digital photos of a vacation, or perhaps an event like a wedding, into the modern equivalent of flipping through a photo album.

title: Musical Time Machine
description: These rare recordings from late 19th century Russia are believed to be the oldest of classical music ever discovered. They are being released in November by the Marston record label.

title: Music in a Divided Land
description: Dalia Moukarker is one of a new generation of Palestinians who have been swept up in a rising tide of interest in Western classical music.

title: Anthony Vaccarello: Fall 2013 RTW
description: Paris

title: When Parents Kill Parents in the Name of Literature
description: We werent very far into Little House on the Prairie when it hit me: Ma was kind of a bummer.

title: Tough Truths from China on CO2 and Climate
description: Im way overdue to post excerpts here from an extraordinary recent China Dialogue with Zou Ji, the deputy director of Chinas National Center for Climate Change Strategy. (China Dialogue is a fascinating independent dual-language blog with offices in London, Beijing and San Francisco that is supported by several foundations and other institutions.)

title: A Really Horrible Boss Gets His Just Deserts
description: Sometimes, when the boss starts raping and pillaging in the office, the grunts just have to beat him to death with a calculator.

title: Study Sees More Breast Cancer at Young Age
description: The incidence of advanced breast cancer among younger women, ages 25 to 39, may have increased slightly over the last three decades, according to a study released Tuesday.

title: Hilltop Town, a Host to Popes for Centuries, Prepares for an Eminent Retiree
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy  This cramped hilltop town outside Rome is in its final preparations for the arrival on Thursday afternoon of an honored guest: Pope Benedict XVI, who will commence his new life as pope emeritus, one of the titles by which he will be known.

title: The Pacers Pick It Up
description: Heading into this N.B.A. season, much of the Eastern Conference discussion revolved around one question: Which team, if any, could challenge the Miami Heats supremacy?

title: A Report Card for Global Food Giants
description: The antipoverty group Oxfam has come up with a scorecard that evaluates the impact that the supply chains of behemoth food companies have on water consumption, labor and wages, greenhouse gas emissions and nutrition.

title: After the Flood, Drying Off the Classics and Letting Them Fly
description: Hurricane Sandy was hard on the Martha Graham Dance Company. In the West Village basement where most of its sets and costumes were stored, floodwaters nearly reached the ceiling. But this is a troupe driven by its mission to preserve masterpieces, and so sets were refurbished and costumes remade, and in the companys current season at the Joyce Theater most of the important things look as good as they did before the deluge.

title: Dolan Says Papal Conclave Should Be Occasion of Repentance
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan spent the final morning before his departure to Rome to help select the next pope presiding over an intimate service with his clergy and staff in Manhattan on Tuesday, asking them for their prayers and telling them that he hoped the papal conclave would be an occasion of repentance for the church, its cardinals and its faithful.

title: Heading to Portugal for the Algarve Cup
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  My first article for the Goal blog was posted on Feb. 9, 2010 and titled, Im Going to Portugal With the U.S. Womens National Team. As I read over my thoughts before heading to the Algarve Cup (the same tournament for which I am about to depart) not so long ago, I was taken aback by how these past three years have shaped me as a professional soccer player and changed my perspective about what I do every day.

title: Revisiting The Group by Mary McCarthy
description: 9:30 p.m. | Updated  Our live discusion about The Group has concluded. You can find the conversation here.

title: Instagram Your Local Escapes
description: This Sunday we will publish our Voyages Issue, which includes photographs and articles from around the world. But we are also interested in travels closer to home  the nearby treasures that you can find over, say, a long lunch break. On Thursday, we will feature a gallery of Instagrams submitted both by readers and the photographers we assigned; we will continue adding new photos until Monday, March 4. Share your photos with us starting now by tagging them on Instagram with #NYTvoyage, and include in the caption a description of where the picture was taken and how far it is from your home. It neednt be the biggest waterfall or the tallest mountain, or even an outdoor spot. We simply want to see your midday getaway, wherever it is in the world.

title: The Wrong Way to Attack Mitch McConnell
description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader who pioneered the no strategy when President Obama was elected in 2008, and who encourages the worst instincts of the right wingers in his party, deserves plenty of criticism  but not the kind of criticism he received recently, which focused on his wife.

title: McIlroy and Woods Play Their Own Match-Play Final
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  As the Accenture Match Play Championship wound down Sunday outside Tucson, Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods contested their own match-play final at Medalist Golf Club in Hobe Sound, Fla., a short drive from PGA National, site of this weeks Honda Classic.

title: Christie Says Hell Take U.S. Money to Expand Medicaid
description: TRENTON  Gov. Chris Christie, one of the most strident Republican critics of President Obamas health care overhaul, announced on Tuesday that he would accept federal money to expand the Medicaid program in New Jersey.

title: Gay Couples Face a Mixed Geography of Marriage
description: MOSCOW, Idaho  The border with Washington State is just two miles from the home that Henry D. Johnston and his partner, Alex Irwin, own here in western Idaho, but for a gay couple it might as well be a thousand. Over there, just a brisk mornings walk away, same-sex marriage was approved by a majority of statewide voters last fall; over here, the Idaho Constitution, through an amendment passed by voters in 2006, says that even a civil union granted elsewhere has no validity.

title: A New Whiskey, Intensely Flavored
description: With Russells Reserve Single Barrel bourbon, the renowned whiskey distiller Jimmy Russell and his son Eddie introduce Wild Turkeys first bourbon to eschew chill filtering, the process by which whiskeys are rid of fatty acids (and, say detractors, some of their character). A high bottling proof of 110 further intensifies the rich flavor profile of vanilla, toffee and licorice. The whiskey, a permanent addition to the Russells Reserve line, has no age statement, but it is roughly eight to nine years old: Available in early March, $50 for a 750-milliliter bottle, wildturkeybourbon.com.

title: On the Job, and Reading Between the Gritty Lines
description: Mathew Henderson is a young Canadian poet who has spent time working in his countrys oil fields, and hes emerged with a spare and eloquent first book of poems, The Lease, that cuts into its primary subjects  grease, technology, physical labor, alienated sex, mud, fear, profound loneliness  like a welders oxyacetylene flame.

title: Misogynistic or Retrogade? Discuss.
description: LOS ANGELES  Whats a little boob humor before an audience of millions? The debate raging loudest over Seth MacFarlanes Oscar performance is whether it was unabashedly misogynistic or just pleasingly retrograde, like an old Playboy cartoon come to life.

title: Toward a Republican Synthesis
description: Ive been reading with interest the discussion the Claremont Review of Books is hosting on moderation, conservatism, and the Republican Party, which opens outward from William Voegelis review of Geoffrey Kabaservices recent history of moderate Republicanism, Rule and Ruin, and then loops in Steven Hayward and David Frum as well as Voegeli and Kabaservice for a wide-ranging conversation. This discussion is brought to a point in Voegelis concluding back-and-forth with Frum, which provides a neat capsule summary of two very different ways of thinking about the Tea Party/Ryan budget era in Republican politics, and how the G.O.P. candidates of 2014 and 2016 should approach their task. First, Voegeli:

title: Feeling For | Reed Krakoff Stilleto
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Met Will Lower Ticket Prices
description: Attendance is down this season at the Metropolitan Opera, and officials there acknowledge that the fault is their own. They made going to the opera too expensive.

title: A Look at the Hagel Confirmation Saga
description: The Timess Jeremy W. Peters examines Chuck Hagels nomination for defense secretary.

title: Front Burner
description: To Shop: A Butcher Shop Expands With Sausages and Game

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 26
description: A view of the day in sports, including skiing in Italy, the N.F.L. combine in Indianapolis and baseball spring training in Florida.

title: Barbara Walters to Return to The View
description: After more than a month sidelined with chicken pox, Barbara Walters will return to her hit ABC daytime show, The View, starting next week.

title: Pictures of the Day: Vatican City and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Vatican, Scotland, Egypt and Syria.

title: Home, Where the Fizz Is
description: It can take just 90 seconds and a rubber band.

title: In Wall St. Tax, a Simple Idea but Unintended Consequences
description: Some say that a financial transaction tax is a cost-free way to kill many a bird with one stone  raising revenue, preventing financial crashes and making markets safer. But advocates of this neat idea conveniently ignore the century of less-than-successful experience with this tax, including New York States own failed attempt.

title: Hacking Your Soda-Making Machine
description: As SodaStreams and other home carbonators become more ubiquitous in American kitchens, so too have the hacks anything that goes beyond using the machine for its intended purpose of turning tap water into sparkling water. Curious cooks have used their carbonators to make everything from herb-infused sparkling wine to fizzy cocktails to sodas with all-natural syrups. (It should be mentioned here that many home carbonators manufacturers warn against using anything but water; the warranty may be immediately voided if other liquids are used.)

title: In Seoul, Gangnam Frugal Style
description: Last summer, Korea started singing along to Gangnam Style, by the K-pop star Psy. By October, my nephews in Maryland had joined the chorus. A couple of months ago in Chongqing, China, I saw women exercising by doing its signature horse-riding dance in a public square. In February, Psy performed before thousands at Brazilian Carnival.

title: Yellow Cab Industry Joins City Against For-Hire Vehicle Operators Suit
description: A powerful group of yellow taxi fleet owners has moved to join the citys defense against a lawsuit seeking to bar so-called e-hailing smartphone apps from yellow cabs.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: A Tough iWatch and Pynchons Alley
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: House Republican Expresses Support for Guest-Worker Program
description: Representative Robert Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia, appeared willing to carve out a sliver of middle ground on Tuesday in the debate over the future of the nations immigration system, offering up the possibility of a guest worker program as a trial case for how the country handles both legal and illegal immigration.

title: World Trade Center Site, 12:19 P.M.
Seared by a Flop, DreamWorks Animation Reports $82.7 Million Loss
description: 9:59 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES  Charges totaling $165 million, including a hefty write-down related to the underperforming movie Rise of the Guardians, prompted DreamWorks Animation to report an $82.7 million loss in the fourth quarter.

title: The Fever Swamp of the Center, Continued
description: I love Jonathan Chaits phrase the fever swamp of the center; it really is true that self-identified centrists are sounding crazier and crazier, as they try to reconcile their fanatical devotion to the proposition that both parties are equally at fault with the distressing reality that Obama actually advocates the policies they claim to want. And todays WaPo editorial on the sequester takes the fever to a new pitch. The editorial admits that Obama is calling for exactly the polices the WaPo wants, while Republicans are off the deep end in refusing to consider any revenue; but the piece is nonetheless written as a criticism of Obama, because

title: Now on Idol, Viewers Can Tweet While Contestants Sing
description: These days, as more people watch television with a phone in hand or a computer in lap, its de rigueur for a network to have a Twitter hashtag on the screen. Television producers and stars  at least the ones with thick skins  appreciate the instant feedback, and now theyre figuring out ways to incorporate it into their shows, thereby completing the feedback loop.

title: Wine Is a Joy, Not This Years Oat Bran
description: As a wine lover, Im reassured to hear that moderate wine consumption can be part of a healthful diet, if only because the opposite would be so much worse. But honestly, whether science demonstrates the benefits of wine is largely irrelevant to me.

title: When Diet Meets Delicious
description: The How do I eat? thing has become increasingly combative and confusing. Do you give up carbs, or fat, or both? Do you go vegan or paleo?

title: Senate Republicans Fail to Reach Consensus on Alternative to Cuts
description: Senate Republicans emerged from a policy meeting Tuesday deeply divided over what they should offer to replace or mitigate across-the-board spending cuts scheduled to hit Friday, probably postponing a showdown in the Senate on the parties two approaches.

title: Women and Sex in The Group
description: 9:30 p.m. | Updated Our live discusion about The Group has concluded. You can find the conversation here. Read Ginia Bellafantes first post on the book here. A response from James Collins, author of the novel Beginners Greek, is below.

title: An Unusually Partisan Confirmation Vote
description: Former Nebraska Senator Chuck Hagel was confirmed Tuesday as President Obamas new secretary of defense. Mr. Hagel  after failing to clear a Republican filibuster 12 days ago  cleared a cloture vote easily early Tuesday before being confirmed by the Senate by a vote of 58 to 41.

title: Celebrity Collisions and a Possible Pinch
description: LOS ANGELES  From media titans (Rupert Murdoch) to reality competition mainstays (Tom Colicchio), the Vanity Fair Oscar afterparty contained more celebrity collisions than can be contained in a mere single post.

title: Medicare Needs Fixing, but Not Right Now
description: Whats the rush? For all the white-knuckled wrangling over spending cuts set to start on Friday, the fundamental partisan argument over how to fix the governments finances is not about the immediate future. It is about the much longer term: how will the nation pay for the care of older Americans as the vast baby boom generation retires? Will the government keep Medicare spending in check by asking older Americans to shoulder more costs? Should we raise taxes instead?

title: Ashleigh Good Transforms Backstage at Cedric Charlier
description: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper883 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

title: CBS Finishes February Sweep Month on Top
description: With the Super Bowl, the Grammy Awards and the strongest regular lineup in television all on its schedule this month, it should be no surprise that CBS will be the big winner when the official February sweep rating period closes Wednesday night.

title: A Live Conversation About The Group by Mary McCarthy
description: 9:30 p.m. | Updated  Were calling it a night. The live portion of our discussion has concluded. But you can still share your thoughts on the book in the comments section of this post. Thanks to James Collins and all our readers!  Ginia Bellafante

title: Health Spending Slows
description: Medicare spending growth slowed sharply in the last few years, in line with the slowdown in health care costs. But the government expects it to rebound as economic growth recovers.

title: Only Half of First-Time College Students Graduate in 6 Years
description: As weve covered here many times before, there is an abundance of evidence showing that going to college is worth it. But thats really only true if you go to college and then graduate, and the United States is doing a terrible job of helping enrolled college students complete their educations.

title: Excerpt: 'Jackie'
description: Tina Benko in a scene from Elfriede Jelineks play Jackie, about Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

title: Bags, Baubles and Bibs From the Milan Fashion Week
description: A selection of accessories from the Milanese runways.

title: This Awards Season, the Politics Didnt End With the Oscars
description: In a stroke of timing that is either meaningless, fortuitous or suspicious, the Senate Intelligence Committee decided to end its investigation into Zero Dark Thirty on Monday, the day after the film took home only one statue at the Oscars.

title: Desperate Hunt for Day Care in Japan
description: TOKYO  Ayaka Okumura was barely pregnant when she began fretting over how she would hold on to the management job that would have been out of reach just a generation ago, when Japanese women were often relegated to dead-end office lady jobs pouring tea and greeting guests.

title: Wave of Concussions Hits the N.H.L.
description: For the last two seasons, concussions and hits to the head were frequent talking points in the N.H.L., with the Pittsburgh Penguins star Sidney Crosby serving as the catalyst.

title: N.F.L. Will Expand Concussion Efforts During Games
description: Where are we? Who did we play in the last game? What is the date today?

title: Dimon Pledges to Change JPMorgans Practices on Payday Loans
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, vowed on Tuesday to change how the bank deals with Internet-based payday lenders that automatically withdraw payments from borrowers checking accounts.

title: N.F.L. Concussion Test
description: The N.F.L.s sideline concussion assessment tool will now be used in app form on an iPad by all 32 teams.

title: Does Bernanke Have the Best Inflation Record?
description: In his testimony before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, boldly declared: You called me a dove. Well, maybe in some respects I am, but on the other hand, my inflation record is the best of any Federal Reserve chairman in the postwar period, or at least one of the best, about 2 percent average inflation. (To which the Twitterverse responded, #ohsnap.)

title: Afghan Sign of Progress Turns Out to Be Error
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American officials, when looking to quickly illustrate progress in Afghanistan, have in the past few months highlighted a 7 percent drop last year in what they call enemy-initiated attacks. Fewer attacks, the reasoning went, meant Afghans were safer and the Taliban were weaker.

title: BP Executive Testifies That a Rig Explosion in the Gulf Was a Known Risk
description: NEW ORLEANS  On the first day of testimony in the BP Gulf of Mexico oil spill trial, BPs top executive for North American operations at the time of the disaster acknowledged on Tuesday that a well explosion had been identified as a risk before it happened.

title: Bernanke: By Unemployment, Not So Good
description: As Catherine Rampell notes, Ben S. Bernanke pointed to the low inflation in his tenure in Senate testimony on Friday. Inflation has been lower during his tenure than during that of any postwar Fed chairman. But the Fed has a dual mandate:

title: John Merwin, Angler With Story Angles, Dies at 66
description: John Merwin, who learned to fish, then learned to write, then learned to write about fishing and spent the rest of his life doing so with distinction in magazines and books, died on Feb. 20 in Lebanon, N.H. He was 66 and lived most of his life in Dorset, Vt., not far from the Battenkill River.

title: Oyster Farm in California Gets a Reprieve
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An oyster farm can continue operating at Point Reyes National Seashore in Northern California for at least a few more months after a federal appeals court decision on Monday.

title: Judge Cant Play TV Bigot, New Jersey Argues
description: A man told his wife, who was at the beach and wearing a bikini: Youre fat. You look pathetic. You look stupid. He added, in case his point had not been made clear, You look like Shamu.

title: Tunisia: Killer of Opposition Leader Remains at Large, Authorities Say
description: The police have arrested four ultraconservative Islamists who are suspected of being accomplices to the assassination of the leftist leader Chokri Belaid this month, but they have not arrested the killer himself, Interior Minister Ali Laarayedh said Tuesday. Earlier reports citing unnamed sources had said the assassin was under arrest. Mr. Laarayedh said the police believed they had identified the killer as a hard-line Islamist who is still on the run.

title: Florida: Court Blocks Drug Testing for Aid Seekers
description: A federal appeals court on Tuesday blocked a 2011 state law requiring applicants to undergo a drug test in order to receive public assistance. Gov. Rick Scott called the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit disturbing and said he would appeal. Drug use by anyone with children looking for a job is totally destructive, said Mr. Scott, a Republican. The ruling upheld a lower courts decision in 2011 to temporarily block drug testing because it most likely violated the Fourth Amendments prohibition of unreasonable searches. The appeals court concluded that the state did not show a substantial special need in requiring that applicants be tested when no suspicion of drug use was evident. The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida sued the state over the policy on behalf of a Navy veteran, Luis Lebron. The state cant do what it wanted to do to me and my family without reason or suspicion, Mr. Lebron said. Im glad that the court agreed.

title: Maryland: Judge Wont Drop Charges in Leak Case
description: A military judge at Fort Meade on Tuesday rejected a bid by lawyers for Pfc. Bradley Manning to have leak charges against him dismissed on the grounds that he had been denied a speedy trial. The military judge, Col. Denise R. Lind, noted that Private Manning had spent more than three years in jail awaiting trial on charges of providing some 700,000 confidential government documents to WikiLeaks. But she ruled that given the almost unfathomable complexity of the case and the governments reasonable diligence in pursuing it, the delay had not violated Private Mannings rights under the Constitution and law. His trial is currently scheduled for June 3.

title: F.A.A. Is Not Ready to Approve 787 Test Flights
description: Boeing is conducting laboratory tests on its proposed fixes for the lithium-ion batteries on its new 787 jets, and federal regulators said Tuesday that they would need to see the results before deciding whether to allow flight tests.

title: After Report of a Mugging, a Very Different Account
description: Like a visual exhibit to go with James Fordyces account of being mugged outside a subway station last week, a map of violent injury was drawn across his face. Purple bruises circled his eyes and streaked along his cheekbones. Down the length of his swollen, broken nose was a line of scabs.

title: Bradford Perkins
description: Mr. Perkins, 70, is a founder and chairman and chief executive of Perkins Eastman, a planning, design and project management firm. The company is working on the Willets Point redevelopment project in Queens and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering/Hunter College campus; several years ago the company designed the TKTS booth in Times Square.

title: In Stamford, Gambling on an Office Complex Makeover
description: The New York-based firm George Comfort & Sons, perhaps best known as the landlord of the Worldwide Plaza complex in Midtown, is making a big bet on Stamford, Conn.

title: After Years of Delay, a Lower East Side Gap Is Ready to Be Filled
description: Nearly half a century after a neighborhood of tenements on the Lower East Side was razed in the name of urban renewal, the area  which happens to be the largest undeveloped swath of city-owned land in Manhattan south of 96th Street  is finally poised for redevelopment. Last month, the city released a request for proposals from developers, ending a bitter chapter in New York Citys development history.

title: Bradley Struggles and Says the Uproar Over His Putting Stroke Is to Blame
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Few golfers were happier to leave the West Coast behind than Keegan Bradley, and not just because this weeks Honda Classic, the first of four consecutive PGA Tour stops in Florida, is a short drive from his home in Jupiter.

title: Rivalries Begin to Emerge in a New Seat of Power
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Home to Apple, Google and other high-tech pioneers, the 17th Congressional District here recorded a political first in last falls elections, becoming the first majority Asian-American district in the mainland United States.

title: The Mets Like Flores in the Infield, Not in Left Field
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Wilmer Flores has continued to distinguish himself as one of the more promising hitters in the Mets organization. But he is a player who, at the moment, seems to lack an obvious position.

title: Denis Forman, British TV Innovator, Is Dead at 95
description: Denis Forman, a television executive who served as steward to some of the most ambitious and popular British programs ever made, including The Jewel in the Crown, Brideshead Revisited and the celebrated 7 Up documentary series, which has revisited the lives of a group of Britons at seven-year intervals, died on Sunday in London. He was 95.

title: Voting Act Challenge Hinges on a Formula
description: The Supreme Court is hearing arguments on Wednesday in a major voting rights case. Here is some of the history of the law and the issues that are likely to be raised before the court.

title: S.E.C. Nominee Tries to Allay Skepticism
description: Mary Jo Whites path to the Securities and Exchange Commission has reached a crucial juncture: the Congressional charm campaign.

title: SFX Entertainment Buys  Electronic Dance Music Site
description: SFX Entertainment, the company led by the media executive Robert F. X. Sillerman, has agreed to buy the music download site Beatport, part of the companys plan to build a $1 billion empire centered on the electronic dance music craze.

title: Opposition Will Boycott Egypts Vote for Assembly
description: CAIRO  Egypts main opposition coalition declared Tuesday that it would boycott the coming parliamentary elections, all but ensuring that Islamists will continue to dominate the legislature and that their rivals will continue to question their legitimacy.

title: Miamis Surprise Season, Meticulously Planned
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  Jim Larranaga always has a plan. He plans by the day, week, month and year. If anyone wonders how he stays so organized, Larranaga walks behind his desk here at BankUnited Center and opens two large cabinets, which house more than two decades worth of Franklin Covey daily planners: thick, three-ring monstrosities the size of dictionaries.

title: Dependents of the State
description: Of all the sins to which an American can succumb, the worst may be dependence on the state.

title: Justices Wrestle Over Allowing DNA Sampling at Time of Arrest
description: WASHINGTON  About halfway through a Supreme Court argument on Tuesday over whether the police may take DNA samples from people they arrest, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. reflected on just how momentous the issue was.

title: Revamped Warriors Use Small Fixes for Big Gains
description: Last season, the Golden State Warriors won 23 games in a lockout-shortened season, an equivalent to about 29 wins in a regular season, or four fewer than the Warriors (33-23) have already won this season.

title: No Move Yet by U.N. Body After Test by Koreans
description: The international expressions of anger and dismay that followed North Koreas announcement of a nuclear test a few weeks ago, punctuated by a United Nations Security Council pledge to immediately work on appropriate measures in a new resolution, appear to have given way to slow-motion diplomacy and some frustration that not even a draft has been circulated among the Councils 15 members.

title: Plan to Pave Bronx Trail Has Some Standing in Way
description: In a city awash in asphalt and concrete, perhaps it is no surprise that such furor could erupt over a one-and-a-half-mile dirt trail that runs quietly through the northwest corner of the Bronx, along a brook, past a golf course and into the woods.

title: U.N. Official Sees Desperation, Hunger and Fear on Visit to Mali
description: A top United Nations relief official who just returned from a trip to northern Mali said Tuesday that desperation, hunger and fear had pervaded the region in the year since Islamist militant extremists seized control, and that only $17 million of the organizations appeal for $373 million in emergency aid had been donated so far.

title: Tensions Rising With North Korea, but Dennis Rodman Is There
description: Dennis Rodman may not come across as the most natural choice for a sports star turned American diplomat, but North Korea apparently begs to differ. Rodman has traveled to Pyongyang along with three Harlem Globetrotters and a documentary film crew for some basketball exhibitions and, the film company hopes, an audience with the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, who is said to be a devoted basketball fan.

title: G.O.P.s Ideological Split Appears in Virginia Governors Race
description: RICHMOND, Va.  As Republicans debate ways to appeal to voters whom their positions have pushed away, some Republican leaders in Virginia are warning that the party is poised to repeat the mistakes of last November, choosing a nominee for governor who turns off younger, female and nonwhite voters.

title: New Report on Syrian Missiles Shows Extent of Death and Damage
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government fired at least four ballistic missiles last week that hit civilian neighborhoods in Aleppo, Syrias largest city, killing more than 141 people, including 71 children, according to a Human Rights Watch report released on Tuesday.

title: Recalling Killing That Led Officers to Reclaim the City
description: The old police cruiser sat at the corner of 107th Avenue and Inwood Street in Queens, just as it did 25 years ago. On Tuesday afternoon, this throwback  a refurbished Caprice Classic  served not only as a powerful reminder of Edward Byrne, the 22-year-old rookie officer who was shot and killed inside it while on patrol one morning in 1988, but of the pervasive violence that defined the era.

title: Out West, Reaching the Summit
description: HIGHLAND, Utah  Here, among a string of quiet Mormon towns, where the spires of Latter-day Saints churches glint against the Wasatch Mountains, is the home of what many consider the nations best high school boys basketball team.

title: After Fukushima, Tasks Remain for the American Nuclear Industry
description: Among safety proposals being discussed are hardened vents in older reactors and filters to trap radioactive particles.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Feb. 27, 2013
description: How am I supposed to go about reporting something when the person Im supposed to report to is the person who raped me?

title: Theft of Dal Drawing Brings Guilty Plea
description: A fashion industry publicist avoided a jail sentence by pleading guilty on Tuesday to stealing a drawing by the Surrealist artist Salvador Dal from the wall of a newly opened Manhattan art gallery last year.

title: An Eerie Silence on Cybersecurity
description: Apart from a few companies like Google, which revealed that Chinese hackers had tried to read its users e-mail messages, American companies have been disturbingly silent about cyberattacks on their computer systems  apparently in fear that this disclosure will unnerve customers and shareholders and invite lawsuits and unwanted scrutiny from the government.

title: Austerity Is Already Here
description: Federal government spending often falls after recessions and wars, but the current round of cuts in investment and spending on goods and services is unusually deep.

title: The Latest Hurdle to Gun-Law Reform
description: Of all the proposals to reduce gun violence now pending in Congress, there was one that seemed most likely to bring the two parties together: requiring background checks for buyers in private gun sales. Republicans and Democrats said this measure would help keep guns out of the wrong hands, especially the proliferating handguns that now account for nearly three-quarters of gun deaths.

title: Rape on the Reservation
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: Grand Old Parity
description: WASHINGTON

title: Limiting Carbon Dioxide Pollution by Power Plants
description: WASHINGTON

title: Unbridled Secrecy
description: The Supreme Court severely damaged the rule of law in its decision on Tuesday to disallow a lawsuit challenging the federal law that permits broad, secret surveillance and interception of international communications involving Americans. The suit, brought by lawyers, journalists and human rights activists, charged that the 2008 amendments to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act violate their rights to privacy and free speech.

title: Ethics Panel Report in Lopezs Harassment Case Is Withheld
description: A special prosecutor conducting a criminal investigation of a sexual harassment scandal involving Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez has asked the New York State Legislature not to release a report drafted by the state ethics commission.

title: Austerity Kills Government Jobs as Cuts to Budgets Loom
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government, the nations largest consumer and investor, is cutting back at a pace exceeded in the last half-century only by the military demobilizations after the Vietnam War and the cold war.

title: Corrections: February 27, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Yankees Dont Plan on Moving Nunez or Re-Signing Damon
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  When word began to filter through the Yankees spring training complex Sunday that Curtis Granderson would be out 10 weeks with a broken arm, Eduardo Nunez wondered for a moment if Joe Girardi would ask him to play left field again.

title: How Children Should Be
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  And now, a Tale from the Curmudgeon Files: When I was in high school, I was a member of the speech and debate team. One of the most valuable things our coach did for us  even though I resented it at the time  was to break us of the like, yknow habit when speaking.

title: Mom Bolts, and No One Knows Why
description: Edie Falco, whose face usually seems like an open window, has pulled down the blinds in The Madrid, Liz Flahives muted, murky new play at City Center Stage I.

title: Get Off of Your Cloud
description: WASHINGTON

Lone Star Shift? A Daughter of Texas Speaks Out

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Carrin, Sole Latino Candidate, Announces Third-Party Bid for Mayor
description: Declaring that he was hungry for common-sense solutions to escape the tired ways of doing business, Adolfo Carrin Jr., once a rising Democratic star, officially began his third-party bid for mayor on Tuesday night before a raucous crowd in the Bronx.

title: Body Parts of Bronx Woman Are Found in Bags on Street
description: It was the sort of macabre discovery usually reserved for police dramas set in New York: Out for an early morning walk with the dog on Tuesday, a man and his son found severed body parts packed into bags and dumped curbside on a Bronx street.

title: Father Held in Visa Plot Stretching to Pakistan
description: A Brooklyn woman said she was held captive for three years in Pakistan by relatives who threatened to kill her if she did not marry a Pakistani man. After the marriage, she escaped with the help of the American Embassy last month and came to a secret location in the United States, away from her father, who had ordered the union, she said.

title: Attacked at 19 by an Air Force Trainer, and Speaking Out
description: SAN ANTONIO  After her Air Force training instructor raped Virginia Messick, a young recruit, he told her it was fun and they should do it again, she remembers. Then he threw her clothes at her and ordered her to take a shower.

title: Owning the Past
description: Women who have just completed an intensive therapy program for veterans in Long Beach, Calif., shared their experiences of sexual trauma in the military, which led to homelessness for some.

title: A Channel Reflects the Reshaping of TV Demographics
description: A TELEVISION network that offers programming aimed at African-Americans is stepping up advertising sales operations as it attracts a growing roster of blue-chip marketers.

title: Depleted Rangers End Up Defeated by Miscues and Jets
description: Even a wild third-period rally could not save the injury-ravaged Rangers from losing their fourth straight game Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Lottery Numbers
Now Gathering in Rome, a Conclave of Fallible Cardinals
description: The sudden resignation of the most senior Roman Catholic cardinal in Britain, who stepped aside on Monday in the face of accusations that he made unwanted sexual advances toward priests years ago, showed that the taint of scandal could force a cardinal from participating in the selection of a new pope.

title: Yahoo Issues a Statement on Work-at-Home Ban
description: In a front-page article in The New York Times on Tuesday morning, Catherine Rampell and I wrote about Yahoos new policy banning employees from working remotely. The company declined to comment for that article, but on Tuesday afternoon, it issued a statement about the ban against work-at-home arrangements.

title: Is Mexico the Comeback Kid?
description: MONTERREY, Mexico

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Amid a Family Reunion, Lopez Finds a Spark
description: NEW ORLEANS  The Nets have been trying to rekindle some of the fire in Brook Lopez, their All-Star center, for two weeks now, as his production and dependability have inexplicably slumped.

title: Lackland Rape Victim Talks of Ordeal
description: Virginia Messick was raped by her training instructor at Lackland Air Force Base in 2011. She is the first Lackland victim to speak publicly, in this exclusive interview with the reporter James Risen.

title: Gagne Returns to the Flyers
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have reacquired forward Simon Gagne from the Los Angeles Kings in exchange for a conditional 2013 draft pick.

title: Powerful Leader of Mexican Teachers Union Is Arrested
description: The leader of Mexicos powerful teachers union, the largest labor syndicate in Latin America, has been arrested on accusations that she embezzled millions of dollars in union funds for personal expenses, including California residences, cosmetic surgery and artwork, the countrys attorney general announced Tuesday night.

title: A Place at the Table: Pro-Hunger
description: Part 13: The cast and crew of the film explore the strategies they think can succeed in effecting political change on the hunger issue.

title: A Place at the Table: A P.R. Problem
description: Part 6: The cast and crew of the film argue whos ultimately responsible for the political inaction on hunger in the United States.

title: A Place at the Table: Trim Tabs
description: Part 11: The cast and crew of the film discuss the challenges of getting people interested in a tough subject.

title: A Place at the Table: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the cast and crew of the documentary film A Place at the Table.

title: TimesTalks | Table: Preview
description: The cast and crew of the documentary film A Place at the Table explore the issue of hunger in the United States.

title: A Place at the Table: Tank Drives
description: Part 10: The cast and crew of the film explain why churches and charitable organizations arent actually in a position to fix the problem of hunger.

title: A Place at the Table: Stigma and Shame
description: Part 9: The cast and crew of the film talk about how the role of food banks, along with who they serve, has dramatically changed.

title: A Place at the Table: Culture of Blame
description: Part 2: The cast and crew of the film reflect on why hunger is an invisible issue in the United States.

description: Part 15: The cast and crew of the film talk about why the tactic of calling Obama the food stamp president in the 2012 election backfired for Republicans.

description: Part 12: The cast and crew of the film recall the origin of the term food insecurity and why its an apt description of what 50 million Americans experience.

title: A Place at the Table: The Late 70s
description: Part 7: The cast and crew of the film explain why theres a clear historical precedent for effective government action on the hunger issue.

title: A Place at the Table: Empty Seats
description: Part 8: The cast and crew of the film speak about what they tried to accomplish in making a film about the hunger issue.

description: Part 3: The cast and crew of the film recall how they got involved with the film and with the issue of hunger.

description: Part 14: The cast and crew of the film reflect on the challenge of doing effective activism work that depends in part on funding from industry.

title: What Housework Has to Do With Waistlines
description: One reason so many American women are overweight may be that we are vacuuming and doing laundry less often, according to a new study that, while scrupulously even-handed, is likely to stir controversy and emotions.

title: Word of the Day | caste
description: caste \kast also kst\ noun

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 6 P.M. (Oxygen) WALK THE LINE (2005) Joaquin Phoenix, above, in his second Oscar-nominated performance, channels Johnny Cash, and Reese Witherspoon, who won for best actress, is Cashs wife, June Carter Cash, in this biopic from James Mangold. Well cast, competently written (by Mr. Mangold and Gill Dennis) and carefully costumed, it adheres to a familiar Behind the Music formula, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, following its subject through childhood trauma, marriage and divorce, alternating offstage melodrama with recreated performances that remind us why we should care about this guy in the first place. And while Mr. Phoenix and Ms. Witherspoon give respectable if rarely transporting renditions of famous songs, you have to wait until the final credits to be reminded of what Johnny Cash and June Carter really sounded like, Mr. Scott added.

title: Hong Kong Grapples With Aftermath of Deadly Balloon Accident
description: HONG KONG  Relatives of nine Hong Kong residents who were killed in a fatal balloon accident in Egypt were headed to Cairo on Wednesday to claim the bodies, a day after the balloon exploded into a fireball while preparing to land.

title: A Difficult Budget Balancing Act for India
description: Indias fiscal budget will be announced on Thursday amid slowing economic growth, soaring inflation, a growing fiscal deficit and flagging investor confidence. But with national elections only a year away, analysts fear that instead of cutting the deficit,the government will buckle under political pressure and increase spending on social programs.

title: News Quiz | February 27, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: As Negotiators Ease Demands on Iran, More Nuclear Talks Are Set
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Two days of talks between six world powers and Iran over its nuclear program ended on Wednesday with specific agreement for further meetings in March and April over a proposal that would sharply constrain Irans stockpile of the most dangerous enriched uranium, in return for a modest lifting of some sanctions.

title: Kai Po Che and the Strange Case of the Vanishing Villain
description: Kai Po Che, or Brothers for Life, which opened in Indian theaters on Friday, isnt a film about the Gujarati entrepreneurial spirit, or friendship, or cricket, or any ofthevarious themes that the popular author Chetan Bhagat has suggestedin press interviews over the past two weeks.

title: Time for an Asian Pope?
description: BEIJING  As details emerge about what Pope Benedict XVI plans for his imminent retirement   hell be called pope emeritus, live in the Vatican next door to the radio station, keep his white papal cassock but swap his signature red shoes for brown loafers, according to the Vatican spokesman, the Rev. Federico Lombardi  a bigger issue is swirling: who will be his successor?

title: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 27
description: NEWS The political gridlock in Italy revives a question that hasnt been heard lately: Is the euro zone crisis really over? Judging by the panic that seized financial markets on Monday and carried over into European stock and bond trading on Tuesday, the answer seems to be no. Liz Alderman reports from Rome, and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt.

title: Thousands Gather for Popes Final Public Address
description: VATICAN CITY  He circumnavigated St. Peters Square in the popemobile for the last time. He gave his final waves to cheering masses. And most profoundly, Pope Benedict XVI bestowed his valedictory words to the world on Wednesday in a heartfelt, sometimes wistful address that highlighted the price of being a pope  and its rays of happiness.

title: India Posts Optimistic Economic Projections Despite Slowdown
description: Indias economy severely underperformed expectations over the past year, and has slowed considerably since 2008, but the government projected strong growth in the coming fiscal year.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 27, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article San Diego Ex-Mayor Confronts $1 Billion Gambling Problem.

title: Researchers Are Taking a Closer Look at the Mysterious Owl
description: In The Owl Comes Into Its Own, Natalie Angier writes about owls, and the latest research into their behavior, biology and sensory prowess.

title: Land and Loss in Colombia
description: Land is no small thing in Latin America. Dynasties flush with wealth and power have arisen from plantations and cattle ranches owned by a select few families. For those left on the margins, taking over a tiny, fallow plot long forgotten by its owners may be the only thing keeping their family alive.

title: How Should Children Be Taught About Puberty and Sex?
description: Puberty and sex are tricky subjects that often no one really wants to teach soon-to-be teenagers. But how should children learn about these very important topics? From parents? Teachers? Books or Web sites?

title: What They Said: Are Indias Economic Predictions Realistic?
description: The Economic Survey for the fiscal year 2012-2013, released on Wednesday, said that theIndian economy is likely to grow between 6.1 percent and 6.7 percent in the fiscal year that begins April 1, up from 5 percent in 2012-2013.

title: Arab Spring Blues?
description: TUNIS  The Arab revolutions are going through a rough patch, from political uncertainty in North Africa to daily massacres in Syria. Egypt appears, at times, on the brink of either economic collapse or a military coup. Tunisia is still reeling from a political assassination and may face prolonged instability, as negotiations for the formation of a new government unfold with little chance of a consensus emerging. Many ordinary citizens in both countries are depressed and disoriented.

title: 20 Afghan Police Officers Killed in 2 Attacks, Including a Mass Poisoning
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Twenty Afghan policemen were killed in two attacks on Wednesday, including a mass poisoning, in southeastern Afghanistan, officials said.

title: Is the Pope Frail?
description: White-haired at 85, Pope Benedict XVI looks a bit hunched in photos. He has had a pacemaker for years, the Vatican recently confirmed for the first time  an indicator of long-standing heart problems. His older brother has said that age is taking its toll.

title: Im Admitted. Now What?
description: As the excitement of the college admissions season starts to wear down, and the realities of the second semester of my senior year start setting in, I cant help but feel a little lost.

title: The Early Word: Losses
description: In Todays Times

title: In Massachusetts We Trust
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Benedict XVI Holds Final Papal Audience
description: Pope Benedict XVI delivered his weekly audience on Wednesday to a large crowd at the Vatican, the last before his retirement.

title: In Hong Kong, a Budget With a Surfeit of Surpluses
description: HONG KONG  As the United States prepares for mandatory budget cuts on Friday, Hong Kong is grappling with a very different problem: spending money as fast as it sluices into government coffers.

title: Rethinking Mill and Paternalism
description: The Stones weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

title: Balance? Dont Believe the Hype
description: How can fast-growth entrepreneurs lead a more balanced life? is one of those agonizing questions that I am often asked. The good news is that there is a rather simple answer: You cant. Save your money, and dont waste your time on the books and coaches who want to sell you advice. Here is why.

title: Q&A: Moving iTunes Libraries
description: Q.

title: Daily Report: Music Industry Sales Rise, and Digital Revenue Gets the Credit
description: In Wednesdays New York Times, Eric Pfanner reports on a possible sign of revival in the music industry.

title: After Fukushima, Friction
description: A dispute is developing between the nuclear industry and regulators, and among the regulators themselves, about the necessity of more safeguards at power plants, Eric Lipton and Matthew L. Wald write. Read more

title: European Regulators Block Ryanair Bid to Buy Aer Lingus
description: 3:04 p.m. | Updated

title: Shakti, the Religious Student From California
description: Why do millions of people, from entire Indian villages to urbane middle managers to foreign tourists, brave the crowds at the Kumbh Mela? During this years 55-day pilgrimage, to Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 100 million Hindus and others are expected to take a holy dip in the Ganges River to wash away their sins. India Ink interviewed some of them.Shakti, 22, who described himself as a student of religion, was one among them. This is what he had to say.

title: Union Leaders Call on Obama to Fill Labor Board
description: ORLANDO  The nations union leaders are voicing alarm that the National Labor Relations Board might remain paralyzed for a year or more as a result of a federal appeals court ruling that found President Obamas recess appointments to the board to be unconstitutional.

title: Another Attack of the 90 Percent Zombie
description: Mark Thoma points me to a post by Miles Kimball titled What Paul Krugman Got Wrong About Italys Economy. So I wondered what important features I got wrong  but to my great disappointment all I found was yet another invocation of the Reinhart-Rogoff claim that bad things happen when debt goes about 90 percent of GDP.

title: The S.E.C. Nominees Charm Campaign
description: Mary Jo White, President Obamas nominee to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, is trying to quell concerns about potential conflicts of interest as she approaches her Senate confirmation hearing. Facing questions about her lack of regulatory experience and her work defending Wall Street clients, Ms. White recently scheduled meetings with members of the Senate Banking Committee and answered a 20-page boilerplate questionnaire, DealBooks Ben Protess reports.

title: Despite Uncertainty, Private Equity Remains Bullish on Europe
description: BERLIN  David M. Rubenstein remains bullish on Europe.

title: Ghostlike and Vulnerable, the Manta Ray Finds a Friend
description: On Sunday, 177 member nations will gather in Bangkok at the 16th Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species to decide whether to accord international protection to a growing roster of plants and animals.

title: Opinion Report: Background Checks
description: From the editorial page

title: Add a Song, Make a Movie
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  The Guild of Music Supervisors gathered here a few weeks ago for its third annual awards. And judging by the turnout, it will need a much bigger venue for next years event.

title: Benjamin Moser to Write Sontag Biography
description: The writer Benjamin Moser signed an agreement this week to write the authorized biography of Susan Sontag, the prolific novelist, essayist and critic who died in 2004 at 71.

title: Still Reeling From the Death of Chris Kyle, a SEAL Brother
description: Its a strange place I find myself these days, in my late 30s, and faced with the reality of friends, SEAL brothers, lost and gone from my life. The most recent include my friend Chris Kyle, who was killed last month, and Glen Doherty, who died six months earlier. I find myself often rereading saved e-mails from the guys because they give me comfort and an occasion for a much-needed laugh or cry, and Im not afraid to admit the latter.

title: Fight Over Spending Cuts a Prelude to Budget Battles Ahead
description: It may be hard to believe, given the intense partisan strafing already ignited by the automatic government spending cuts that begin on Friday, but this years budget wars have yet to get fully under way.

title: Hole in the Wall Wins Indian Educator $1 Million TED Prize
description: Sugata Mitra, an Indian education innovator, was awarded the first $1 million TED Prize for what the global organization called his innovative and bold efforts towards advancing learning for children.

title: A Fresh Look at Chinas Long March on Energy and Emissions
description: March 5, 6:41 p.m. | The second target below has been updated. See addendum for original language. |The Rhodium Group consulting firm has released a report card on Chinas energy trends and policies that describes the countrys intensifying efforts to increase the proportion of renewable sources like wind and hydroelectric dams and boost the efficiency of coal use (essentially the metric called greenhouse gas intensity by President George W. Bush). The blunting upward trajectory in the graph above reflects progress, but a long path ahead.

title: Wednesday Reading: Frugal Gangnam Style in Seoul
Fortress Profit Doubles on Rising Investment Values
description: Add the Fortress Investment Group to the list of alternative investment firms who ended 2012 with strong earnings.

title: Conservatives Love Affair With Christie Is Over
description: In September 2011, when Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was considering making a last-minute entry into the presidential race, I pointed out an incongruity in Republican attitudes toward him. Many Republican organizations and activists, including some very conservative ones, were enthusiastic about the possibility that Mr. Christie might enter the presidential race. But Mr. Christies history of actions and issue statements was fairly moderate.

title: Sweeping Before the Storm
description: Dear Diary:

title: Three Dead in Shooting at Swiss Factory
description: GENEVA  At least three people were killed in a shooting at a Swiss factory on Wednesday, the police said, adding that the gunman was among the dead. The episode was the second mass shooting in Switzerland this year.

title: Eve Best Returns to the Globe, This Time as a Director
description: LONDON  The recent press conference announcing the 2013 season at Shakespeares Globe on one level seemed like variations on an ongoing theme.

title: Activist Investors Ratchet Up Pressure on a Big REIT
description: A pair of activist investors ratcheted up the pressure on CommonWealth REIT on Wednesday, filing a lawsuit to block a proposed stock offering and reiterating a proposal to acquire the real estate company outright.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: A Loss at DreamWorks Animation, and a Cute Interspecies Rescue Was Fake
description: DreamWorks Animation reported an $82.7 million loss in the fourth quarter after taking an $87 million write-down related to the flop Rise of the Guardians, Brooks Barnes reports. DreamWorks shares dropped 1.3 percent in regular trading and less than 1 percent in after-hours trading. Jeffrey Katzenberg, the companys chief executive, said there would be layoffs of around 350 of the companys 2,000 employees.

title: The Gun Report: February 27, 2013
description: Two police officers were shot and killed as they followed up on a sexual assault investigation in Santa Cruz, Calif., Tuesday. Sgt. Loren Butch Baker was a 28-year veteran of the department and Detective ElizabethButler was a 10-year veteran of the department. The suspect, who was also killed in the shooting, was identified as 35-year-old Jeremy Goulet.

title: Wazes Maps Now Change as Roads Close
description: Even the best map is out of date the minute it is printed. But a new feature from Waze, a mobile app built on information gathered from its users phones, will be able to change the apps maps in real time, reflecting temporary road closings as they happen.

title: Kiss and Yell
description: If you prefer your jeans black and your hair messy, Richard Hell may be the most important musician youve never heard of. A founding father of the New York punk scene, Hell is often credited with establishing, along with the sound, the style of the movement.
